Maybe I'd come back for lunch but for dinner its just ridiculous. I also made reservations for my boss here once before I ever came here and he said he got the worst service of his life although both times I have been here service has been okay.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
A bit overpriced and gimmicky. 

The baked oysters are like loaded mash potatoes in an oyster shell. I could barely taste the oyster! 

My favorite appetizer was actually the tomato crustini. It had a really nice grilled flavor to it. I had the fish entree and it was just OK.
author: Heather H.

description: Stumbled upon this restaurant, roaming the neighborhood. I was intrigued by the decor, looked like a parlor and had a long wait - must have been good. I order the Lambrusco to start. I then have the crispy brussel sprouts chips and the bone marrow dish that comes with salsa verde and ate over a bread chip as my meal, which are two appetizers. They were delicious. Actually paired together quite nicely and then ordered the Cab with my meal. I finished with a sherry for dessert. All in all, excellent meal and attentive staff. I'd recommend a reservation before you go because it's even reserved seating at the bar.
author: Alexandra C.

description: Great food, great service. Love the marlowe burger and their fries. You can also have the option of combining fries and salad with your burger with no extra charge. Coming back for sure.
author: Mario H.

description:
Actually, I've always wanted to give this restaurant a 5 star, because every time I would fly up to Bay area this place would be to go for brunch or drinks and I would drive from San Jose after flight from San Diego just for their Pimm's Cup cocktail and some nibble...  Unfortunately, after 4 times dinning here this last Saturday 1/27/18 I lost my appetite for Marlowe because of how unwelcome we felt, we made very late 10:30 PM Saturday reservation, we flew in to SF very late so there was not a lot of options to dine so late and when I saw Marlowe on Open Table for 10:30 PM I was exited to try their dinner service, since we loved it previous times.. so we show up on time we have our dinner and of course my fave Pimm's cup and food was decent I mean the kitchen folks were rushing meal, I asked my rib eye medium rare and it came out rare ... 

However, since we came so late we could tell everything was rushed and the worst part the staff turned on the lights bright right after we said we don't want any desert... Like really Marlowe? If we are not paying more you low key want us out ?  I understand its 11 PM and people want to go home and we are the last table at the restaurant, but its lack of professionalism to turn on the lights bright when you seated us and we are paying for the experience...
It's pity, for great restaurant that it is. Not coming here again, there's other good places in San Francisco with great food, drinks and service that you don't need to feel rushed...
author: Simba M.

description:
I came here for lunch and I think I just didn't order the right stuff. Or at least what they're known for. 

I split the shrimp roll with fries and split it with a co-worker. I was thinking it was on the pricier side at $18 but they had decent portions, and the kitchen staff split our meal for us which was very thoughtful!

As for the shrimp roll it wasn't bad but it wasn't what we were expecting either. It had pickled cabbage on it giving it a kimchi flavor to it- don't get me wrong I'm Korean and love me good kimchi - but it wasn't what I wanted on a shrimp roll. I was looking for a creamy based shrimp roll so we were both slightly disappointed. 

On a positive note, fries were great! They had good seasoning and a nice crunch and shoe string fries are my fave. 

Staff were also very nice and always filling our waters so I think next time I'll just have to return for dinner sometime and get something else.
author: Mandi W.

description: I went here with family and came in between lunch and dinner service. I understand shift changes however the original server that took our order was nowhere to be found after it was placed. No waiter was introduced to take care of us during the change. For bar food only not full menu our food food took FOREVER! I'm not one to complain and typically don't express extreme displeasure in service but they completely forgot about our table. Groups seated 20 plus minutes after us were served. Despite having a good cocktail I would not come here.
author: Brandon L.

description: I don't think the food was worth the price. The setting is nice and staff is good. Not a big selection of items either.
author: Arjan N.

description: Great Brunch spot with a variety of options on their menu. I got the Open Faced Reuben dish with corn beef hash in it. Great appetizers and desserts. The donuts are amazing!! Service was perfect and the ambiance of the place is beautiful with lots of outdoor lighting coming in. This is not super casual or super fancy and falls in the in between category. A little pricey but worth it! Definitely will be coming back here again!
author: Sophia K.

description:
My coworker and I made reservations for a weekday lunch here. We were glad we did because the restaurant was pretty packed at 12:30pm on a Monday.

SERVICE: Our waitress was super friendly. She was quick to take our order and to bring out the food. Top-notch service!

FOOD:
*Brussel sprout chips: These were crispy and flavorful - the perfect starter to get our taste buds going! The chips maintained their crispiness without tasting like they were soaking in oil (soggy Brussel sprouts are no bueno).
*Di Stefano burrata: The burrata was served with grilled radicchio on top of sliced country bread, and drizzled with aged balsamic vinegar. The balsamic vinegar was SO good. I'd totally purchase this on its own if they sold it by the bottle!
*Marlowe burger and fries: We ordered the burger medium rare, and it came out perfect and juicy. The caramelized onions and horseradish aioli both complemented the burger very well.

Overall, I'm giving this restaurant 3.5 stars (minus half a star for the relatively pricey menu). It's not a restaurant I'd consistently go back to, given the plethora of food choices popping up in the city. But I'll be back to try the bone marrow and the deviled eggs!
author: Diana Y.

description:
TLDR - Trendy spot, great service, food is good. Marlowe won't disappoint but won't wow you either.

Very busy for a Sunday night - would definitely recommend making a reservation in advance. It's a lively, trendy spot. A little crowded and loud, but service is friendly and attentive.

Food overall was good but I wasn't necessarily impressed. Nothing really stood out as must-haves or something I'd want to come back for, but Marlowe is a good spot if you want that lively SF ambiance for dinner. It's rather expensive here though - dinner for 2 cost about $60/person after tax/tip.

* STEAK TARTARE ($16) - 4/5
[poached quail egg & crostini]
Good but pretty standard steak tartare.

* PAN ROASTED COD ($29) - 4/5
[pork belly, littleneck clams, salsify, fennel & tarragon beurre meuniere]
Really nice moist, flaky texture and delicious flavor.

* PORK CHOP ($28) - 4/5
[jalapeno sweet potato puree, blistered grapes, persimmon & smoked ham hock jus]
I'm usually not really into pork but theirs really impressed me. The portion size was a lot bigger than I expected (2 pork chops) so it's pretty filling. The sweet potato puree, jus and grapes added a lot of flavor to the pork and really pulled the dish together.

* LORETTA'S VACHERIN ($10) - 4/5
[coffee ice cream, meringue, toasted almond, chocolate sauce]
Simple coffee ice cream with some texture from the meringue.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Went in solo for a quick bite. Delicious drinks and burgers. Doughnuts were a hit, and burger were perfectly cooked. 
Service was pleasant but a little noisy at night. Overall a great spot for a slightly more special than usual brunch.
author: Ellie S.

description:
Went to Marlowe with a friend on a Sunday around 5 o'clock so we got to order from their Bar Menu. Not too many options, but for our purpose it was okay!

The staff was very friendly and helpful when explaining the food and helping us make some decisions!

Here is what we ordered:
1. Crispy Brussels SPROUT chips ($9.5)
    Unfortunately this was not a favorite. They were very very oily and when you got the the bottom of the plate it became overwhelming. We ended up leaving behind almost half the serving.
2. Half Dozen Oysters (MP)
    They were very yummy, but if you were to put these six tiny oysters together, you'd get two normal ones... so that was unfortunate
3. Marlowe Burger ($17)
    This was very yummy and cooked perfectly fine. They even cut it in half and gave us both our own separate plates with a  generous amount of fries. The fries were also very good!
4. Pink Pearl APPLE Crisp ($10)
5. Loretta's VACHERIN
    Both of these desserts were AMAZING! No, seriously amazing! I will have no problem coming back for their dessert and cocktails!

The location is beautiful and the service was great, unfortunately I felt as if the place was a bit overpriced for their potions and the food was more on the oily side!
author: Kassie E.

description: If you're looking for a delicious brunch spot in SOMA, try Marlowe! My friend and I arrived before 11am on a Sunday and were able to get good seats at a communal table. I started with an Americano, and she had a fancy peppermint tea. She ordered the crispy fried chicken sandwich, and we both agreed that the chicken was fried to perfection! I ordered the buttermilk pancakes with pieces of smoked bacon because I was craving pancakes that day, and I have to say, it was absolutely divine! I was too full to try the candied bacon, but my friend definitely enjoyed it. We look forward to coming back next time!
author: Joanne K.

description:
Not a large menu and a rather limited entree selection, so our group decided to grab appetizers (they sounded tastier anyway). Got the baked oyster, grilled asparagus, shrimp, bone marrow, cauliflower mac and cheese, grilled octopus salad, beef tartare, and Brussels sprout chips. 

We all enjoyed the shrimp, which tasted fresh and looked huge. It wasn't very marinated, but the freshness of the shrimp didn't need many spices. The cauliflower Mac and cheese and the bone marrow also deserved special mention. The Mac and cheese tasted literally as it sounds. It wasn't too cheesy and the sauce was runny (in a good way). The bone marrow was cooked well, with marrow dripping off the spoon. The other appetizers did not deserve any special mention. 

Drinks were good but overpriced. It's worth a visit if you can swing the cost.
author: Jeffrey Y.

description: After our civil ceremony, we rented out the back patio at Marlowe.  It's so beautiful back there.  The staff there is just as amazing as the food.  My guests loved the location, the food and kept raving about the service  (nga you're amazing!).
author: Sharlene T.

description:
Marlowe is great! Food is delicious, nice atmosphere, consistent good service. The Marlowe Burger is probably my favorite burger in the city - you definitely have to like horseradish, though. They have lots of other great options on their menu, too. There is bone marrow for dinner, which is very, very good. Good drinks, too!

My only complaint is it can be incredibly noisy when busy (which is most of the time). I think it's just the size and acoustics, but hard to hear people you're eating with. Nice tip, though, we discovered on our last visit. They have a patio on the other side of the kitchen/bathrooms (they literally walk you through the kitchen to get to it) and it's much quieter. It's outside, but doesn't really feel like it - they have heaters, it's covered, and closed off on all 4 sides.
author: Derrick S.

description:
Came here for a belated Valentine's Day my bf n myself sharrd one deviled egg, baked oyster, bone marrow, and burger!!  All super good!  
The deviled eggs was about bite size, it had a jalapeno spread which had a bit of spice that you kinda notice it and you can enjoy the flavors. 
The baked oyster I was surprised (in a good way). The description was like, "clam crowder in a shell".  And I wish I had ordered one of my own, instead of sharing it!  
As for the bone marrow, so good!  They had some parsley that added some level freshness, and a sauce that had cappers which wasn't overpowering from its usually saltyness.
Then the burger!  The bun was on point, soft with a hint of toasted-ness, the meat was moist and had a bit of salt from the bites of bacon (but then again everything with bacon is good!)
author: Tiffany H.

description: Delicious cocktails and entrees. The outside patio has a wonderful ambiance. Recommend the scallops!
author: Westy L.

description:
Went here on a weekend for brunch to catch up with a friend. Made a reservation beforehand, but the place wasn't too crowded either for 11:30am on a Saturday. The restaurant decor had a combination of a rustic and modern aesthetic. It's a bit out of the way of where I usually go for brunch (near AT&T park), but it was a nice place to discover. The table we were seated at was in the corner. It was bit of a snug fit, but not too bad. 

The waitress came by to take our order for drinks. I was feeling a bit adventurous, asked what she recommended for people who love fruity drinks. She recommended The Baker's Wife, so that's what I got. It was delicious. I could barely taste the alcohol. I'm also a huge sucker for grapefruit, so that definitely played a part. 

I ended up ordering the cast iron frittata. The frittata had your average ingredients: potato, egg, spinach. It was a good, but I've made my fair share of frittatas. It seemed more like a scramble than a frittata. I typically prefer it if the potatoes were sliced, since they'll cook faster that way and soak up more of whatever seasoning you use. Couldn't really taste the cheese throughout the frittata; it was mostly concentrated at the top of the dish rather than incorporated throughout. I also typically like more of a sear on my frittata to add another texture to the dish. 

My friend ordered the Dungeness crab Benedict. They had run our of their ham for the benedict that day, so they replaced it prosciutto. I really liked the creativity and execution of my friend's benedict. Instead of an English muffin, the prosciutto and the poached egg sat on a savory fried potato cake, like a latka. I hadn't seen anything like before eating at Marlowe. Definitely a good brunch pick for anyone who loves eggs benedicts in general. 

Overall, I liked the ambience and service was good. It's definitely a place I would go back to, to try some of their other food!
author: Christine L.

description: I have been wanting to come to Marlowe for the better half of a year. Since I had seen so many rave reviews about the bone marrow and the burger, I knew I had to try both. I have never had bone marrow before so I was quite startled to see just a thin layer atop a hefty hunk of bone, but it seems like this is just a natural limitation of how much bone marrow is in a bone. What the bone marrow lacked in portion size, it more than made up in flavor. The salsa verde and herbs really kick the flavor up a notch, and the result is just exquisite. Definitely a must order at least once. For the burger, a lot of hamburgers can be rather unwieldy to eat, but this wasn't the case at all. The soft patty and bun make it super easy to scarf down! I found the flavor to be a bit bland, until I hit the slightly spicy horseradish aioli which was a game-changer, and the fries are generous and crispy. The service was also really great, even though the restaurant was busy.
author: Naomi J.

description: Underwhelming Marlowe Burger compared to the hype. Squash Blossoms salad was SO delicious and fresh! Next time I'll try the Octopus and Squid Salad. Overall, I'll come back, but I'll skip the burger.
author: Margana S.

description: Drinks are great and the food is awesome! I love the retro kitchen ambiance and how bright and open the space is.
author: Ryan C.

description:
We were mistakenly charged $139 at brunch when we only ordered an $11 housemade donuts.

Needless to say had we not looked at our bill we could've easily been overcharged by $128. With service this careless, inattentive after being provided with a brunch before being told later that brunch will no longer be served and that only bar food is available, it's no surprise this happened. 2 Stars only because the donuts were decently tasty.
author: Barry A.

description:
Stopped by to get food before a Giants game. Had to wait in line for 20 min and still got very uncomfortable seats next to the window. We were all facing the window so it was difficult to talk to each other as well T_T
But the food was pretty good! I would like to try again when it is less crowded haha
Servers are really nice and the place is very clean. 
Just like any other SF restaurant, i would not recommend driving there. It's close by muni!
author: Yeonhwa S.

description: We went here hearing great reviews from our friends and family but were very dissapointed with the service. We clearly told the host that we wanted the tables outside but after waiting for nearly an hour and a half the host took us to this very tiny patio like area near their kitchen. It was very uncomfortable even to talk let alone eat. I wouldnot mind this at all considering space is very limited in sf but after waiting for almost an hour and a half  and spending 120 dollars for brunch, I think we deserved much more.
author: Manjil S.

description:
The good: 
Jenny, the General Manager.
The bone marrow, which is what brought us here.
And... that's about it.

The bad:
The clearly made up "30 minute wait", while half the restaurant is empty, to make the place seem more desirable. 
The waitress, whose shirt-sleeve pally attitude is bordering rudeness.
The salad which listed avocado as the first ingredient, had ZERO avocado in it. 
The rest of the food, which was completely over-salted.
And (are you ready?) the unannounced $5 coke refills. No heads up from our "pally" waitress whatsoever. 1 coke with 2 refills = $15
Who are these people?
This place is way overrated.
author: Ron P.

description:
EVENT: It's date time! Ya'll know... it's been a long, long week... needed some drinks and some delish food. Haven't been back to this place since 2012! WOW! Where did time goooo??? Now, that I live close by... I can walk here now... yes! No ubering needed. WOOTS

SERVICE: very friendly people, sat us down right away. Oh, we had reservations! Yes, Friday night... a reservation is needed and recommended!

FOOD:
(1) Grilled Pork Chop, $28 -very flavorful kale, mash potato is to die for, and pork... is like nom noms! 4 stars! Huge portion! I had to get a box.
(2) Petrale Sole, $29:  OMG love the sauce! Sole in the middle and calms spread throughout the dish. Limey and sweet! MMmm!

DRINKS: ... wine with dinner is a must

**MUST GET: Sole... mmm! Sauce is deeeelllisshhhh!!
author: Mindy Y.

description: Good spot for lunch definitely come early if you can...I've been wanting to try the burger out for awhile and finally made it in...juicy and cooked to perfection...the pink apple crisp was a bonus, I like there non-alcoholic drinks for lunch...I had the west bay sparrow which is a bend of pineapple juice, lemonade and a dash of hibiscus
author: jonathan h.

description:
After being on my "To try" list for the longest time, I finally came here for Saturday brunch with my friends. Upon walking in, I immediately loved the aesthetics of the restaurant. Marlowe had a very clean and homey feel. Luckily we made reservations for brunch & we didn't have to wait for a table. My friends and I looked over the menu & opted to eat brunch family style (my personal favorite way to eat!). 

House-made Ricotta Toast- (5/5) light & fresh with just a hint of sweetness from the honey

Smoked Dungeness Crab & Rock Shrimp Benedict- (4/5) only 1 crab/shrimp cake with 1 poached egg. tasty but unexpectedly smaller portion

Marlowe Burger- (4/5) perfectly cooked medium rare, but slightly overpriced 

Pork Shank & Potato Hash- (3/5) the pork was on the drier side & the dish didn't have enough flavor for me

House-made Doughnuts- (5/5) so light & fluffy. There was a light lemon and ricotta flavor and the blueberry jam accompanied it perfectly. 

The service was excellent & the food was marvelous. I loved my meal here & I would definitely recommend Marlowe for a tasty brunch in SF.
author: Melanie H.

description:
After everyone else's glowing reviews of this upscale bistro, I wanted to see if it was all true. (Plus I haven't had good bistro-style food in a while.) While I truly wanted to like their food, it seems I just wasn't served the same good quality food as other Yelpers. 

Marlowe is located on Brannan Street in the SOMA area of San Francisco. There was a lot of construction going around the restaurant so it wasn't as easy driving around the area, but we managed to find a metered parking space across the street. It's situated on the corner and right across from a Wells Fargo and Starbucks.

This review is purely for their dinner service. I haven't been there for their lunch/brunch yet so I can't comment on that. 

I did really like the overall look of the restaurant. The upscale bistro feel was there. The interior isn't that big (maximum capacity at 88.) but you can tell they tried to fit in as much tables as they could. For that reason privacy is nonexistent, but if you like listening on to other people's conversations, you're golden! There's a smallish 6 seater bar area, a large communal table, and a couple of small individual tables. 

This place gets very noisy during peak times and we felt like we couldn't even hold a decent conversation after a while. Our server was really nice and came by to check on us twice. I will have to agree with Vincent L with the saltiness of our food. With each bite, they got even saltier. I expected better quality from a restaurant with 4 stars and over 2000 reviews, but sometimes there are exceptions. I would go again to try their brunch fares, but probably not order their popular Burger or Brussels Sprouts again. 

Brown Butter Brussels Sprouts : Very salty. Wasn't the kind with a crispy exterior. They were boiled and just over-salted. 

Roasted Bone Marrow : The only dish I would order again. There was a good amount of marrow inside the two sides. They had really good flavors too. 

Spiced Jumbo Gulf Shrimp : The shrimps were pretty big. Some areas weren't completed cooked and still of transparent color. 

Marlowe Burger : Very salty. The fries were good tho.
author: Julie W.

description:
I gave Marlowe another chance recently, and it completely blew my mind. 

Don't bother ordering anything else rather than burger and beef tartare, and remember to get their French fries! Do not repeat my mistake the first I was here! 

Seriously, I think this is my favorite burger spot now lol
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
Well this was very disappointing. Came for what was supposed to be the best burger in town. Spending $18 on something that I can get much better at other places for less, ain't do that again. 
Lastly the waitress was extremely bad. She made you feel that you were there for her, rather than she was there for you. No smile, didn't ask if everything was ok, didn't want to know if there was anything else she could get you, she just didn't care. Waste of time and money.
author: The A.

description:
Good. SO good! The staff, the food, the ambiance. We loved it all! Made reservations and fortunately, my date and I were seated in the patio. Much more intimate, it was lovely. There was a short wait but one of the servers took our drink order before we were seated - my bf says they make a great old fashioned! 

Started with the oysters followed by the steak tartare and the bone marrow that you MUST try! My mouth is watering again - oh my! 

My bf had the burger that he saw most people in the main room eating, so he had to try and loved it. I had the poulet. Incredibly yum! Lastly, we had the coffee ice cream over the meringue with chocolate sauce and sliced almonds. It was perfect. 

Overall, great first experience! We will definitely be back.
author: Julie Ann M.

description:
We Love Marlowe.

From the Big Night Group, it all started with Marlowe, with their perfect sense of hospitality and outstanding food. Deviled eggs, (or deviled egg sandwich at lunch), Brussels sprout chips, chicken fried okra, oysters, crispy fried chicken sandwich and the Marlowe burger are some of our favorites.
author: John C.

description:
This is one of my favorite, go-to spots in SOMA. Great ambiance for date night or drinks/food with friends. Resos generally get booked up, but if you're in a pair, you can typically walk in for a seat at the bar or at the window sill. 

Fantastic cocktails (my drink of choice is the spicy jalapeno gin drink) and solid wine. What to get: brussel sprout chips (I could eat these all day, every), little gem salad (super fresh and lots of avocado), deviled eggs, burger, bone marrow. More brussel sprout chips.
author: Sally C.

description:
I hate to round down what's otherwise a 3.5ish rating, but I just can't go all the way up to a 4.

Yes, everything I tried, whether a deviled egg, baked oysters, or their famed Marlowe burger was tasty enough, but for me it was all somehow tasty in a cloying - or just plain salty - way. Service was OK enough. 

What Marlowe has going for it is that it's a modestly upscale brasserie / bistro in a suddenly overly moneyed neighborhood where the number and quality of its competitors haven't caught up to Mission or Financial District levels of saturation. Indeed, while I was here, the crowd screamed "business dinner." There are many other good choices out there in SF - just perhaps not in Marlowe's immediate vicinity.
author: Vincent L.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVED IT!  
Everything start to finish was incredible.  We got the squid/octopus salad and bone marrow to start.  I dont care for eating straight fat but the marrow and the relish they served it with were delicious.  The scallop dish was unbelieveable as was my husbands pork chop.  Both cooked to perfection.  The rhubarb and an expresso were the perfect finish.  O yea, and our server was great -- we could totally tell he loved working there!
author: Debbie R.

description:
Cute little restaurant! I came here on a Wednesday night and it was packed. Had to wait 30 min just for a bar seat. 

As a whole, the food was good. The Brussels sprout chips for an appetizer was definitely a highlight. Perfectly crispy and well seasoned. I also got the burger which was pretty too notch. Medium rare was cooked how it's supposed to be cooked. 

Only complaint was it was really overpriced (shocker I know it's SF). But even the wine by the glass menu was kinda ridiculous, with lowest option of red at $15. Not entirely sure I'd come back but did enjoy this meal here.
author: Grace A.

description: I visited 4:30 at Friday. No booking, just walked in for a couple of drinks. We sat in the bar and order a couple of happy hour menu. I would say everything is ok in best. Oyster had some funky smell so I didn't really enjoy them. I spend over $100 with a couple of drinks, a few bad oysters, cheap fries. Not worth it IMO.
author: Sarah K.

description:
So I was at brunch at Marlowe, eating my fried chicken sandwich, when there was a strange taste in my mouth. *lips smacking* Is that.... no.... it can't be... fish? Yep, there was Caesar dressing on my sandwich, and guess what's in that. Anchovies! Such a strange flavor combo. If it weren't for that, my sandwich would have been fine. The fries that come with it are thin and well fried.

The French toast was served like Lincoln logs but unfortunately were soggy. The two sauces they came with were a hit at my table, though I thought both of them were overly sweet.

The donuts were the best part of the meal - fluffy and moist.

The shrimp and crab benedict was mislabeled on the menu and was more like a crabcake in its presentation and taste. Apart from being disappointed in not getting a fluffy English muffin benedict, the shrimp/crabcake as it were, was not very good.

On the upside, they take brunch reservations, which is always a plus in SF.
author: Christina G.

description:
My girlfriend and I were looking to get brunch the day after Christmas before heading back to SoCal. After calling a bunch of places, Marlowe was the only one that was still serving brunch so we decided to stop by. Upon arrival, we were seated immediately, lucky for us, there was a table available. 

We started off with some drinks, I got The Donkey and my girlfriend went with the Pimms Cup. Both great drinks to start, the Pimms Cup was light and refreshing. For food, we got the Steak Tartare to share, I got the Marlowe Burger and she got the Lunch "Poulet Vert". The food took a bit to get to us, since there was a large party ahead of us that got their order in before, but it was well worth the wait. The steak tartare was really flavorful, would recommend getting it. The burger was delicious, meat was juicy and tender. The chicken was also really well made.

Service was great our entire visit. very helpful and attentive. My only complaint is that the tables were a bit close to each other, but after reading some of the reviews, I guess it's a common thing in SF. Overall, great brunch spot, I would definitely come by again if I'm back in the area!
author: Nick C.

description:
I love the environment here. Crisp, bold, classy, but not pretentious. The tables are close together (standard SF), but not INCHES close together. Perfect place for a date night or dinner for a group. Reservations can be made 1 month in advance, which I would highly recommend. It's SOMA, so lots of metered parking (which is a plus). 

Given my love of brussel sprouts, we tried both the chips and the brown butter ones. Both were lovely but I would definitely suggest the chips. I LOVED the devilled egg (jalapeno, bacon, omg), and wish I had ordered more than just 1 for myself.

Supposedly one of the best burgers in SF... but honestly I don't think it didn't live up to the hype. By no means was it bad, but I've definitely had better. I would still absolutely come back here, as I hear their brunch game is pretty strong.

We were celebrating a birthday (which I added in the reservation notes), and they brought out cookies and a little candle to celebrate. Very low-key and really perfect, honestly. 

Highly recommended. Totally a SF staple restaurant.
author: Steph D.

description:
Giving Marlowe one star is tough, but after last night, it is well deserved. 
I've come here many times, and might even come here again, but the service my mother, girlfriend and I received last night was so terrible that I had to write a review to make you, and Marlowe, aware.
Our server had an extremely poor attitude with us throughout the night, sighing loudly when we were looking over the menu, and giving us looks of disgust while passing us by. My mother has a thick German accent, so maybe he does not like Germans, but I can't say for sure.
Lastly, when our plates were being removed, we asked if the leftovers could be boxed, which was roughly half of our food as the portions were quite large. Instead, the boxed food never came, and our waiter was nowhere to be seen. 
For $150, you would expect better service. I am sorely disappointed.
author: Jason C.

description:
Stopped in on a whim to kill time before heading back to North Bay (avoiding traffic). Had two glasses of wine and a tasty cup of Brussels sprout chips. They were absolutely delicious. 

Fun, smart, sarcastic bartender team were a delight. Nice wine list, great cocktails I'd like to try next time. Really charming vibe and while the seats make your bum go numb after a while, it's worth it to have a place like this in the neighborhood. 

I look forward to going back for a proper meal sometime!
author: Sarah S.

description:
Marlowe is really really good and deserves its reputation as one of the most classic establishments in the city. The vibe is really nice - dimly lit, spacious, and enough background chatter without being too loud. 

The food is also just incredible. The brussel sprout chips are SO good, the corn soup is really flavorful/creamy, and all the entrees we got were great as well. Highly recommend for a nice night out
author: Kimberly T.

description:
Had dinner here twice now when in town and it's a great spot. Nice setting and reasonable prices for SF. 

Their burger and fries are great, as are the salads. A friend had the pork chop and loved it.
author: Meredith V.

description:
I like to read the SF Chronicle Top 100 Restaurants book. Comes out once a year and is full of great restaurants. Marlowe is in the book. 

Well, my anniversary was coming up, so I went to the book and tried to find one with reservations available. It's tough to find one that has openings in the same month, most are fully booked. Anyhow, after looking through I found Marlowe. I noted it is well thought of for the most. I made a reservation for a Monday night at 630. 

We arrived early, and found seats at the bar. We were barely seated and the hostess had found us a table. There were a few empty tables. In spite of that, the place was hopping and after 15 mins there was quite a few people waiting. 

The tables here are very close together. Inches. I sat across from my wife but was actually closer to the people at the tables next to us. That can be nice, when the person next to you is chatty and friendly. And not so good if not. At least the positive is it's easier to hear your conversation in here. And it's a loud place, not ear splitting but loud. 

We were greeted by the water boy promptly. Our waiter showed up quick, but was really unpleasant. And, once he said hello, I did not see him again for 15 minutes. The table next to us had a like response. They were friendly. And they eat here often. 

So we had plenty of time to review the menu. We decided on cocktails, appetizers and entrees before the waiter returned. The waiter returned, mood the same, and helped us in his way to place our orders.  The waiter did his job but I have a much better time when the waiter is engaged in his job. 

We placed our orders. I got a cocktail off their signature menu called the Baker wife ordered an old fashioned. The apps, deviled eggs (a specialty, and some sautéed pistachios. Emily ordered the burger and fries (said to be best in SF) and I got the polenta. 

Drinks and appetizers arrived quickly. I have to say, my cocktail, The Baker, was absolutely superb. Fantastic.  Flavorful. I was only able to have one, I'm driving, but I wanted another at double volume. Yummy. Wife's cocktail was no better than average and probably a little worse. She ordered what I had ordered the first time. Like I said, yummy. 

Our appetizers were much the same. The deviled eggs were good, but not great, and I expect a lot out of top 100 status. Btw, I love deviled eggs and had read quite a bit about these ones. I can only assume those who bragged about them online are people who don't make them. Or eat them very often.  The pistachios were excellent. Better even than the ones my wife makes. Sweet, savory and crunchy and a very good pair with cocktails or beer. 

Entrees next. Burger and fries? I'm coming back and ordering my own. (With the great cocktail).  Starting with the fries, se bed with ketchup and awesome horseradish aioli. They are absolutely to die for. And, I hate fries. They are worth a trip. The burger was fabulous, and could be the best in SF. It is that good. I know, I did not order the burger, I just helped Emily eat hers and he fries too. I did order the polenta. Saying that is not enough. The polenta is mixed with mushrooms, covered with greens and shaved Parmesan, and has a poached egg in the middle. The dish may not have been best in city but I loved it. Crunchy, creamy, savory, just beautiful. Loved this part of the meal. 

With all this food we had to have dessert too. My stomach had not exploded yet. I ordered the apple crisp with ice cream and Emily ordered the Vacherin which is coffee ice cream cover with chocolate and a meringue with shaved almonds. Again, my wife ordered well. The coffee ice cram dish was excellent for texture and flavor and satisfaction. Sorry I did not order it. The apple crisp was just not good enough. And there was no crisp. I think it was cobbler. It was ok but really had nothing to recommend it. And, again, not top 100. Sorry. I make apple crisp and it's far better than theirs. I expect better.   We also had coffee which was very good.

I will mention, service was very good, except for surly waiter, the ambiance was active and friendly and I loved that. The interior seems cozy, I like the noise and activity. 

I can recommend this place and I want to return. I will certainly get more familiar with the menu and that can only help.
author: Bill V.

description: Marlowe is amazing! We ended up at Marlowe after having a really bad experience at a nearby restaurant. The service was terrible and we ended up walking out after being lead to, and left alone at, our table for 15 minutes. We decided we'd see if Marlowe could seat us and, in spite of being completely booked, they found us a table. My husband and I were celebrating our 4 year anniversary and Marlowe went out of their way to accommodate us and make our night special. They immediately decanted our wine and brought us complimentary champagne. We had a great dinner followed by complimentary dessert. The staff at Marlowe was so kind to us, I'm almost tearing up as I write this. The food was solid and we enjoyed everything we ordered, especially the rib eye, which was cooked to perfection. 5 stars for both the food and the service. Thanks so much for saving our special night, Marlowe staff!
author: Jen S.

description: I believe it was date night for the hubs and I and I usually get a say in where we go :) The place is pretty tight when it comes to space. You're literally a foot away from the party next to you. Then again, that's the city for you! Besides that, the food was great and tasty mixed drinks.
author: Lai S.

description:
Small unfussy restaurant serving up very delicious food.

I made reservations a week in advance, and there were plenty of open time slots. We ordered the polenta and the pork chops, to share. 

The pork chops were a huge serving, very juicy, with an even pink all the way through. Loved the collard greens and beans that came with it. 

The polenta was a perfect complementary item as it's not as heavy. The polenta was extremely creamy and rich with the truffle oil and the Parmesan cheese. The arugula is a genius addition as it cuts through the richness to keep the dish from being too cloying and flat. I don't really know if the egg really adds anything to the dish, but I love a poached egg on anything so I'm all for it.

We came during the heat wave in SF. Remember those two days when it was over 100? We were recommended to sit in the patio because it was much cooler than the inside, which is true. However, me and the couple at the table next to us were eaten alive by mosquitoes? I came home with 4 bites on my arm and another 4 on my foot. Somehow my boyfriend left unscathed.

Would def come back for the food but would sit inside.
author: Jacqueline V.

description:
The infamous Marlowe burger. My friend and I went to Marlowe on a Saturday night to try this place out. We've been hearing about this burger for ages and needed to go for ourselves. We walk in and was greeted by the hostess and seated immediately (make sure you make reservations). We looked through the menu and decided to get 3 things to share. The baked oysters, bone marrow, and the burger. 
The baked oysters were good. It tastes like a baked potato but in oyster form. 
The bone marrow was probably the highlight of the meal for me. It was so rich and delicious. I could not get enough of it. And the salsa that comes with it is the perfect compliment. 
Lastly, the burger. They kindly cut it in half for us and put it on two plates. My friend and I both agreed that we enjoyed the fries more than the burger. The burger itself seemed very salty and then the horseradish aioli seems to just overpower the taste of the whole burger. 
I was pretty excited about this restaurant but left a bit disappointed. Nothing is really luring me back through the door any time soon.
author: Celia Z.

description:
I came here for lunch with a group of 6 (we had a reservation). 

Food wise: 
- Brussels sprouts chips to share: 3/5 they are good but weren't my favorite, probably because I don't like chips but they are nice to wait for the meal and they are good
- Poulet vert: 4.5/5 great dish! Chicken was tender and tasty, Brussels sprouts were crunchy. My only critique is that the dish was too salty. The bacon and date bits were amazing, I wish there were more.

My friends got the steak salad or burger and everyone seemed really pleased with their choice.

For me, the highlight of the meal was desserts. They have few options that all sound and are actually delicious. 
- Cookies: 4/5 gooey, warm, chocolate cookies.
- Chocolate pudding: 3.5/5 I loved the pudding and mascarpone cream but wasn't a big fan of the coconut (and there is a lot of it). 
- Vacherin: 3/5 again this was good but not my favorite. It's mostly ice cream but meringue was crunchy and tasty.
We also got the chocolate and peanut butter bites but I didn't try them.

Overall great experience! I will definitely come back!
author: Coralie S.

description: My faves are open faced deviled egg and burata, my sister's smoked cod and shrimp Benedict was not so good. Portions are tiny, so if you are hungry you need to either spend a lot of money here or eat somewhere else.
author: Mel C.

description: Had an awesome waitress on a super hot Wed evening dinn experience, celebrating an anniversary. We ordered baked oysters, bone marrow(everyone there ordered this), pate, crudo over round watermelon slices(very pretty presentation), steak(enough for two people) and grilled char. We had the rose ice cream dessert to finish off the night. Place was packed, tables really closed to other guests but did not feel rushed at all. She was a very friendly a d attentive server...made such a difference! Thanku...
author: Vee V.

description:
Dinner was amazing! We dined in the back patio which was perfect! I was having a catch up dinner with a friend and loved that we were able to have a conversation away from the noise. The ambiance was very romantic and cute. Dim candle light setting. Service was phenomenal. Very friendly staff as well. We had a great dinner overall!

Beverage choice: the glitter bomb. Tasted like a lemonade. It was refreshing. 

Starters: We had the deviled eggs and bone marrow. The deviled eggs had s kick to it. I like spicy foods, but my friend said it was a bit too spicy for her. We both enjoyed the bone marrow. 

Entree: I ordered the Marlowe burger as my entree. It was good, but I would love to try something else next time. The fries were made perfectly! 

Dessert: We shared the Pink Pearl Apple Crisp. Its topped with vanilla bean ice cream. It was delicious! Perfect ending for the dinner. 

Parking: We got lucky and found street parking upon arrival. We parked about a block or two away.
author: Lucy L.

description: Made a reservation at 8 am for 10:15 am the Saturday morning of Labor Day weekend. Plenty of metered parking on the street.  The space is small, but it was pretty empty when we got there. Definitely did not need a reservation this weekend but not sure how much busier it would be normally. I ordered a gin cocktail, The Juicer, and the husband ordered The Butcher, their version of a Bloody Mary. That gin cocktail is spot on! The spice is fantastic ... perfect way to start a long day of drinking.  The Butcher is a bit smoky for my taste (almost a hint of bbq sauce flavor) but right up the husband's alley. The husband was waffling between the Ruben and the burger, and the waiter said he absolutely had to get the burger, which he claimed they are famous for. I ordered the Anson Mills polenta with mushrooms. As soon as the food came to the table I could smell the truffle in my polenta dish ... so luxurious. The fries came out smoking hot and ultra crispy ... perfect fries. He asked for the burger medium rare, and it came out on the verge of extremely rare but was crazy delicious. The polenta was reminiscent of a few polenta dishes I had in the Italian alps ... very solid dish. I think if the mushrooms were braised a bit longer, their flavor could be richer. The polenta could have been a tiiiiiny but looser, but the dish was still excellent. The parmesan added the perfect salty note. After we finished eating, we ordered one more round of drinks to get our Saturday off to a good start. Would definitely go back and try the Ruben and the thick bacon. $117 out the door for a nice tipsy breakfast for 2.
author: Kristen B.

description:
Had Sunday brunch here and made reservations ahead of time which I would recommend. 

I dined with two other friends and we did some Yelp research which ended with us ordering the following:

1) House Made Doughnuts (to share): it was so delicious!  Lemon, ricotta & house made jam.  I think this ended up being one of my favorite dishes.  That jam!

2) Di Stefano Burrata (to share): one of my friends didn't like it, but she wasn't expecting the fig preserve (bad taste on her).  I thought it was very tasty.  They don't skimp on the burrata.

3) Smoked Dungeness Crab and Rock Shrimp Benedict: was very fresh.  Probably the best of the main courses ordered.  However, there was only ONE benedict.  So little.  What a shame.  Especially at $18.

4) Pork Shank & Potato Hash: This was my dish and I felt it was unmemorable.  I always get so let down by pork hashes I guess. Looked better than it tasted.  Which was a bit heavy.

5) Marlowe Burger: fries were very good and that horseradish aioli was on point.  But the burger itself was whatever.  Truly not the best burger around.

I had their coffee which was not burnt. 

Service was good.  Vibe was nice for brunch.  It was more a 3.5 feel for food, but I'll bump it to a 4 because those doughnuts were a treat.
author: Kim D.

description:
Super solid place for brunch. We came after a morning of hiking up in Marin County, and we were almost deliriously hungry. Thankfully, I had the foresight to make a reservation, and we were seated promptly. The OJ they had was freshly squeezed, so we all went for some, and didn't look back. I appreciated the bistro-like vibe, and it was very easy to relax after a very active morning.

Our favorites:
- Burrata on grilled levain with prosciutto, fig preserves: Probably my favorite dish, the bread was grilled perfectly, and each bit had a little bit of sweetness from the honey
- Pork shank and potato hash: Collard greens were perfectly cooked, and the pork was super tender
- Marlowe Burger: Solid burger, but not sure why people would call it the best ever. Horseradish aioli was decent
- Candied bacon: Kinda like what you get at a steakhouse, the bacon was very thick-cut, and perfectly cooked
- Crab & Rock shrimp benedict: It comes with a lot of greens to make it look like a lot of food. Regardless, it was very filling, and the crab/shrimp both had really great flavors.

Service was pretty attentive throughout the meal, except at the very end when it took us about 15 minutes to get our check after asking for it a couple times. Prices are very reasonable for brunch, with the main dishes ranging from $14-18. 

Easily one of my new go-tos for brunch in SF. Most everything we had was excellent, and despite the burger not being the world-beater that people said it was, there are plenty of dishes worth coming back for again and again. Plus, you gotta get an extra side of that candied bacon, because it's totally worth it.
author: Eric J.

description:
OK - so Marlowe is normally good. I live 2 blocks away and work on the same block, so I'm always there for business lunches, dates, and drinks etc. I'm actually writing this to petition the chef to change the brussels sprouts recipe back to whatever it has been until last week.

Every time I sit down for dinner, I get a starter with a side of brussels sprouts and that's my whole meal. No, not the brussels sprout chips - but the actual side that comes in a rectangular cast iron pot. I dream about those brussels sprouts. They rock. 

BUT I came last Thursday and they were almost.. raw? Super green and mushy, where I'm used to them being blackened. They sucked. I was mortified at how much I'd raved about them to the people I was with for dinner. I didn't eat them and it was a weird vibe the whole evening and I 100% blame the sprouts scandal. 

I asked the waitress about it who said that this was normal and she didn't know what I was talking about when I asked when they changed the recipe. 

Pic attached, die hard Marlowe brussels sprouts fans will see the pic and know what's wrong immediately - you're welcome to join my support group, DM me.

Change back the recipe or else me and my other, less outraged colleague will ONLY come for cocktails. Maybe we'll split the burger. The steak tartare is GREAT so might do that. But really guys. Not cool about the sprouts.
author: Julia O.

description: I just moved to the San Francisco area and this is one of the first places I tried. Delicious small bites and superb cocktails. Service was a bit slow but it was extremely busy so I don't fault them. I will definitely be back!
author: Jerry M.

description:
Class act! I must congratulate you on impeccable service! Ordered the pork chop and it was severely overcooked not only did you make us a new one you also comped it! We were asked what we thought we mentioned it's overcooked and weren't looking for anything as we were filling up and then you went out of your way to ensure a perfect dining experience! That was more than necessary. Service as a whole is less than optimal in sf and our waitress was wonderful the whole meal! 

Pims cup: it was large, it was gingery and it was beyond refreshing! One of the better ones in the city the flavors melded so well. 10/10

Other cocktail was on special the butchers mistress was more like a mimosa though was  described like a sangria 5/10. Description didn't match taste and it was warm had to add ice to it.


The real star of the food was the scallops get these! Scallops with clams 10/10 

Baked oyster 8/10

Warm deviled eggs, never had them warmed but wowza 11/10: seems everyone is doing deviled eggs now and the subtle differences in your really makes them stand out 

Pork chop second one was cooked perfectly the grits were quite crunchy and chewy while the flavors were subtle 6/10 I just prefer a bit more flavor, was a little flat to me. Personally get a little porkchopped out here in SF. 

The crab and lobster poppers 6/10 the sauce is impeccably creamy and rich however for a salt fiend like my self I shuttered at how salty the greens served with this dish are, eek

German chocolate pudding 10/10 who even serves German chocolate anymore other than my mom, thank you for this is was perfect and just enough of the classic to keep me elated! 

The meal itself was overall very rich and salty but I am a favor of those flavors. I walked out of there with a real full belly!

The 5 star is truly for the manager or proprietor she elevated our experience from something that could have left a sour spot about this place. We will come back likely so for the apps and to try out their brunch menu!
author: Morgan S.

description:
Tip: Unless you have reservation or you want to eat around 9:00pm, don't even both trying your luck to get a seat here.  It's extremely small, quant and pack all the time. 

Fried Okra: OMG, the seasoning was perfect on the breading for the fried okra.  However, I wish the breading did not be falling out of the okra when you pick it up.  The flavor of the fried okra tasted a little like fried chicken, but when you bite into it, it's a soft and tender okra.  If you love okra, this is the dish you must order.

Smoke Salmon and English Cucumber: Nice refreshing dish that can accompany other heavier appetizers.  The smoke salmon was so fresh that it has no fishy taste at all.  The creme fresh was light and lemony, which went well as a second appetizer to our fried okra.  Unless you're a super fan of smoke salmon, you can skip this dish.

Angus Ribeye: The best ribeye I've ever had!  The aged ribeye was so tender, so well good, so well seasoned!  I got the meat medium and it just melts in my mouth.  The scallop potato on the side was creamy, soft, tender and the best scallop potato ever.  The salad has a lemony dressing that cuts the fattiness of the meat and potato.  If you're up for someone else besides the burger, this is your dish!

Dessert: Loretta's Vacherin.  Not a bad dessert, but not a great dessert.  The nutellaish ice creme pairs really well with the crunchy meringue on the bottom, but if there are other dish you're eyeing on, I would go for that over the desert.
author: Rosemary T.

description:
Nice dinner tonight with our buds who live in SF. Former site of Coco500. Think American bistro. Just the right amount of ambiance. Somewhat tight space, holds about 85. Everything thing hard surface, floors, ceiling walls all hard surfaces so it's a but loud4/5 scale, plus they play music is the background not bad but hard fir conversation.

Our server was Nah ( phonetic) and she was very good. We all started with cocktails that were made perfectly. Great way to start. We also did the Brussels sprouts chip, deviled eggs ( I could have had 4-5 myself they were that good), baked oysters (3). Great table starters. 

Next we ordered our dinners. Chicken, the Poulet, mine done excellently. The burger and the Crudo were also ordered as was the Tartar. All excellent and the correct portion size.

I brought a special bottle of wine, corkage $25, reasonable and nice, correct size wine glasses served.

No dessert but there were several tempting things listed. Next time. We'll be back for sure. A fun, lively spot.
author: Greg C.

description:
Came here for brunch with two girlfriends on a Saturday and was very pleased. Luckily we had reservations otherwise the wait would have been fair, but nothing too hefty. 

The inside reminds me of spots I used to frequent in Boston, a bright open bar, lots of hard wood, a little back garden area with fresh plants and heaters. The tables are an elegant solid wood, there's kitchen accouterments hanging from an elegant pot chandelier close to the entryway. 

We started our meal with a delicious sparkling rose and enjoyed the kind patience of our waiter while we debated foods. I was very impressed by the flavor packed selections, though a bit remised that nothing was very veggie heavy. I selected the dungeness crab and rock shrimp benedict, intrigued by how the combination would be presented. I was pleasantly surprised with a seafood filled patty, crusted with cornmeal and lightly pan fried. I was looking for something that wasn't heavily breaded and I think this was a gem- I could distinguish between the rockfish and crab, the textures played very well together and the light dish was overall a total delight. I would definitely try this again. 

My girlfriends tried the truffle polenta which was completely divine and a repeat dish for her. I stole a bite and can vouch that the flavor is elegant, full, and smooth. The mushrooms are perfect, the polenta is moist and rich, and it comes served atop with a delightful soft egg. 

Our other friend enjoyed the buttermilk pancakes which she reported hit the spot and came in generous enough portions that she didn't even finish. 

I look forward to a chance to visit again and explore the menu more- especially during other meals.
author: Angela D.

description: Such a cute spot! A friend and I came today for Sunday brunch. Making reservations was easily done online via opentable and as soon as we arrived, we were seated right away in a little corner booth. Not only was their food delicious, but the ambiance was perfect for a beautiful Sunday morning in San Francisco. Nice and lively but not overly noisy or busy.  They have a wide array of food choices, even for those who are vegetarian, which my friend is. And their mocktails are amazing! I'm definitely coming back to try more of their dishes!
author: Imogene T.

description: I had a good time and didn't notice anything to complain about. The food was great and everyone at our table enjoyed what they ordered. That was the best salmon bagel I've had yet!
author: Ben H.

description: Great atmosphere, friendly service. Only a couple of mains to choose from (which increases your chances to get something freshly made). Loved the chicken. Will try desserts next time. Don't forget to book your table if you don't want to wait!
author: Clémentine C.

description: Loved the drinks here. Nice ambience. Got free appetizer since there was some confusion in seating us. But not many options for food.
author: Prerna M.

description:
A perfect place for a dinner date at the bar! We loved the decor and warm lighting. 
The service was topnotch. Our bartender, Tou, could not have been more attentive! The oysters are a must, but I also enjoyed the cauliflower with cheddar and smoked gouda. Lovely wine list too!
author: Anne S.

description:
Well made reservations for a Saturday night got there and table wasn't ready as "our table" still had people there. They couldn't provide an eta of how long we would have to wait was about 35 mins at bar. Then hostess was very unprofessional she was rude when we asked her go long we would have to wait etc. 
luckily the manager made up for our night by sending us a complimentary starter and bubbles. The food was all very tasty but waiting for a table when reservations are made is just crazy .
author: Stori M.

description: Overpriced place with unfriendly host and just ok food. The host set a walk-in instead of us and just deleted us from waitlist( they said 15 min wait). I really don't mind it as everybody can make a mistake. But she was unfriendly and with attitude. She told us to go to the bar, I had to tell her that there were available tables and we had already waited for 15 min outside. The server was nice but never checked on us while he gave so much attention to the table next to us. Food was ok, but not worth the price. Scallops and steak tartrate were very good. Baked oysters nothing special. The olive oil cake was something like a grocery store muffin. I don't understand the hype around this place.
author: Kate E.

description: Cool location. Food was very delicious and well balanced. Drinks very fresh. Waiter was very knowledgeable and easily gave suggestions.
author: J H.

description:
Awesome place to have your brunch  - great cocktails, awesome-looking food, and very delish! Would definitely be back for brunch/dinner.
Nice to have this place in our neighborhood.
author: Vadim K.

description: Great place that is close to the cal train station. We came here to meet some friends that were visiting from out of state. We came here 30 minutes before our reservation time and we were happy that they were able to seat us early. Our group ordered the baked oyster and burrata for appetizers. I ordered the ribeye for dinner and thought the flavoring/seasoning of the ribeye was great. The meat came out medium rare as I requested. Overall our friends and I thought the food tasted pretty good. For dessert I ordered the strawberry shortcake which was pretty bomb. We don't get to eat out in SF often but I'm glad we got to try this place out.
author: Aaron L.

description:
This place is a gem. I live in FiDi and have been hearing about the Marlowe burger and brussel sprouts for about a year. I finally had a chance to go for lunch this week with a co-worker. The food lived up to the expectation, and the ambience was the cherry on top. If you come here for lunch, I recommend the burger (with garlic aioli - yum!), brussel sprouts (chip style!), and definitely the Di Stefano burrata.

One thing to note: I only recommend going here over lunch if you have a little extra time. We came at noon and luckily had a reservation. If we hadn't, it looked like there would have been a bit of a wait. The service was great but Marlowe seemed to be a bit slower than an in-and-out workday lunch spot. 

I'll definitely be back for dinner!
author: Katie R.

description: I like the food here but they mostly have the same menu for brunch and dinner, so it can get pretty repetitive. Service is good, and I can almost always get a reservation via Yelp. You can walk in but this place fills up pretty fast so I recommend making a reservation if you can. My only thing is that it's pretty pricey for the quality of food that they serve. It's still pretty good, but not the best thing in the entire world. They have a really good drinks menu, and have delicious mocktails if you want something non-alcoholic.
author: Mara Y.

description:
I like this place, cute nice ambience and we didn't have a reservation but got seated almost immediately on a Sunday evening! Got great seats too.

We ordered the half order of the oysters, it was the small ones but very tasty and we enjoyed it thoroughly. For drinks we ordered the Paso Robles 2014, always a safe bet I know but still delightful. We ordered couple more dishes all very tasty and we had a great time.

The only thing was towards the end the waitress made a really snarky comment, which personally I didn't appreciate. Hope they can guide their staff to draw the line between being funny and insulting.
author: Darshana S.

description:
The fish was really good, probably one of the best I've had in a long time. 

The steak was flavorless and of diner quality. Half of the brussel sprout chips were overdone.
author: Eve M.

description: Honestly, I was really really hoping to give this place 4 or 5 stars. I went in ready. What we got was lackluster. Nothing really stood out about it and I'm confused how it got 4 stars and so many reviews. We had the avocado salad, brussel chips and the warm deviled egg... while snacking we decided to make reservations somewhere else. Because it was like we didn't even eat anything... Disappointing.. :(
author: Stephanie R.

description:
A friend who works up the street took me here for lunch.  A 3rd friend suggested getting the burger.  These guys were good friends, they did me right.  The burger was solid, very tasty all the way around.  The fries on the side were crisp and salty, almost too salty.  My friend got the fried chicken sandwich and that looked pretty good too.

It was a sunny late-summer day, and the room was lit up beautifully.  It was buzzing, and maybe on the edge of too noisy, but for a lunch catch-up, very pleasantly convivial.  I'd definitely enjoy coming back when I'm in the area.
author: Larry C.

description:
So AMAZING! 

Ambiance:  perfectly decorated, clean lines, lots of white and grey finishes.  Seriously in love.  It's a bit loud,  but nothing you cannot handle.  The tables are pretty close together but what restaurant in SF isn't like that?!? 

Food:  My friend and I split the burger and the fried chicken sandwich both were phenomenal.  The French fries were perfectly seasoned and went great with both.  The waitress was so sweet she cut the orders in half so we could each have two plates.  It made sharing so much easier.

Waitstaff:  super friendly and lovely.  It took us about 2 minutes to get sat.  We had rezzies.  Our waitress was super attentive and made sure everything was to our liking.  I would absolutely recommend this place to everyone.
author: Kristin R.

description: This was a delightful restaurant! Although we didn't have any reservation we were provided a common table. The cocktails were great. We had the specials of the day! The scrambled eggs were savory. I would definitely recommend it.
author: John H.

description:
Four of us ate here last night, the food was quite good, met expectations for a higher end brasserie. 4 stars.

Where Marlowe REALLY shined was the outstanding service from the wait and bus staff. They were personable, fixed the one problem we had immediately, and the reason you're getting this review:

Thank you for watching and waiting to make sure all parties had finished each course before clearing, as opposed to barging in and whisking away plates.

It's so rare to get that level of thoughtfulness, even in "higher end" restaurants. Thank you.

This means we can bring our Francophile parents here and not listen to them complain that the staff is trained wrong. We're definitely bringing them and, no doubt they'll read this review.
author: Paul T.

description:
MY FAVORITE WAS THE CORN CREAMY SOUP.
BEST 
CORN 
SOUP 
EVER. 
But disappointed because I was celebrating my hunny pot birthday and we had to wait for awhile because our food came out really late. 
Generous of them for giving us 3 desserts. Burger was really good. They are really known for their burgers. 
At the end I give it a 8/10.
author: Julia D.

description:
When I want a nice, hearty brunch, this place hits the spot!

Came here on a date for Saturday brunch (12:45pm reservation) so it was pretty packed.  

Venue / service: love the white interior with black accents, which make the room bright.  It can get a bit cramped since tables are placed near each other.  As expected with a brunch spot, it. 
 Service was friendly and not too slow, given how busy it got during brunchtime.  

Food: great American comfort food!  The dishes we got were very rich, and portions tended to be on the bigger side.
-- Half Dozen Oysters (smoked mignonette and scallion)(MP) - the oysters were a bit small (but maybe because I'm used to large ones on the east coast) but tasty, especially with the mignonette.  The ones we had were a little on the sweeter side and not too briny.  Don't remember the price for these guys, but was probably around $20?
-- Anson Mills Polenta (wild mushrooms, parmesan, truffle salsa verde & poached farm egg)($16) - super tasty!  I liked how the polenta wasn't super creamy (being lactose intolerant) but still had enough cheese to give it a mild parmesan flavor.  The poached egg worked well in adding more richness to the dish and the mushrooms a great unami/ earthy tone.  This dish was also piled high with arugula to refreshingly contrast with the otherwise heavy meal (and to make me feel less guilty since I'm technically still eating veggies).  Out of necessity to carb load for a half marathon, I managed to finished 3/4th of the plate.  
-- Marlowe Burger (caramelized onion, cheddar, bacon & horseradish aioli with fries)($17) - my date ordered this one and was nice enough to give me a taste.  Now I understand why this burger is highly recommended by peers!  Super juicy without being too oily and just enough freshness from the horseradish aioli and lettuce to make you temporarily forget how rich this dish is.  Personally not sure if I would have been able to eat one whole burger on my own, but if I did, I'd be one very happy camper.  Fries were nice and crispy on the outside, soft on the inside.  

Everything came out to around $25-30 per person at most (depends on price for oyster and whether or not you order a drink).  

Overall, very happy with the dishes we ordered and service so that I didn't mind the tight space.  I probably wouldn't come here every single weekend, but when I was a super satisfying brunch, yeah I'd come back and perhaps next time order my own burger.
author: Audrey H.

description: What a great dinner we had tonight. Wonderful tempura squash blossoms with a very light salad. Excellent burratta with pea salsa. Very very tasty harissa on a crispy chicken. Really good cocktails and good service. Overall a lovely evening. Ambiance is loud and from drinks to coffee not cheap. $150 for 2. But very satisfying.
author: Rebekah F.

description:
I definitely don't mind paying good money for good food and drink, but this place was incredibly expensive for small servings and mediocre food. The staff and decor were nice enough, and the cocktails were very good (though a bit expensive for even how good they were). The Juicer was spicy, flavorful, and refreshing, but cost quite a bit.

I had the oysters of the day plate which was a plate of 6 incredibly tiny oysters with a single shaved leek and some vinegar and garlic. No other accoutrements and just some super tiny oysters. They were tasty, I admit, but for how much I paid, they shoulda been twice as big (or there should have been twice as many on the plate).

I also ordered the steak tartare which was also fairly pricey for a tiny blob of tartare that was a bit salty, a bit slimey, and without any other flavor or character.

Definitely not worth going unless you just want a nice cocktail and the Marlowe Burger (which is great and can also be had at their sister restaurant: The Cavalier -- see my review of that place...much better!).
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
If I knew what a "hipster" restaurant looked like, I would pin Marlowe as fitting the bill. This restaurant is beautiful, lots of unique decor and small details that make the ambiance seem super upscale and hip. For example, there's a roll on paper on the wall, pots hanging from the ceiling, you get my vibe? 

The food - meh. Came with a group of friends and we all got different dishes, pretty much everything on their lunch/brunch menu. Personally, I tried the burger and the chicken sandwich. The burger was OK, I thought the meat was well cooked and it was average overall. The chicken sandwich was a huge disappointment - the meat was COLD and stale. When I have fried chicken in a sandwich I expect it to be hot and crispy, there was also no flavor whatsover to the dish - it was bread and stale chicken pretty much. Fries were delicious, I believe they use kennebec potatoes - only thing that was redeeming, which is really sad. 

Service was pretty spotty, the servers were very pushy to get us to order when we got to the table and after taking our orders was never to be seen again. We didn't get our waters filled for a long time and not until we asked. Not a great experience at Marlowe, would not recommend if you are looking for good food, maybe if you were looking for a hopping spot that looks good for your Instagram feed.
author: Kimberlie L.

description: I've been to Marlowe for both brunch and dinner. At night it can be a cool spot for date night. The ambiance is dim and sexy. It's also great for brunching with friends. It's nice and airy during the day. The menu also has great options.
author: Ali R.

description:
Came in late on a Saturday night to cheerful smiles. Christopher was our waiter and he had the warmest smile and demeanor. He definitely made our dining experience that much better. 

Yummy: Leo oysters, candied pistachios, squid/octopus frisée salad, wild mushroom soup, nicely cooked thick pork chop 

So-so: burgers (beef patty was too mushy)

Highly recommend this business to anyone looking for non pretentious food in an inviting atmosphere.
author: Star K.

description:
Marlowe is always the best Wine and food in Soma! We love sitting at the bar and staff and Management are the best at getting you seated, courteous and helpful! This place rocks and can get crowded on a Friday night!!! The drink pours are generous with great service, people and value
For the money!!! Love this place!!
author: Johnny D.

description:
Love, love, love this place. Super trendy little bistro-feeling spot right on the corner down the street from AT&T Park. We felt lucky to get a table and had a great meal with an old friend from out of town.

Tried a bunch of stuff including the oysters - perfection - as well as the lovely deviled eggs and a pretty amazing duck liver mousse.

Also had the amberjack crudo which had this interesting yellow watermelon on it. At first read it seemed like maybe incongruous, but it worked perfectly and what a delicious dish.

Ultimately had the arctic char and a pretty amazing cauliflower side dish.

All in all, really wonderful meal and thanks Marlowe.
author: Bob K.

description: If you just want a simple, clean, wholesome breakfast brunch meal this is the place. Never too long of a wait and their service is awesome. Buttermilk pancake was very fluffy and filled w wholesome goodness. Sprinkled with bacon bits but who doesn't love bacon. Will go back and explore the menu for sure.
author: Joe M.

description: Terrible service. We needed salt, more syrup, more hot water...but server was no where to be found, so we didn't get any of it. She didn't check on us once during the entire meal and was rude when taking our order and giving us the check.  Disappointed.
author: Susannah F.

description: A walking distance from the train station, it's a great place to have brunch with friends. Super cute and minimal place. Their food selection is a bit pricey for a small portion of food but they come out as good quality. It's definitely a great place to go for a lunch date or with a friend.
author: Pailin E.

description: I can only speak of the burger here as we dropped in for a quick snack in between dinner.  Their Marlowe burger is a tasty burger as are the fries with horseradish aioli.  We split the burger and they gave us each a generous serving of fries as you can see in the picture. The service was attentive and professional.  I'd like to stop by for dinner sometime to check out the real menu.  They have a limited menu in between their lunch and dinner service just FYI.
author: Spencer W.

description:
Hip bistros are nothing new in San Francisco, but great service (thanks Alissa) paired with wonderful drink concoctions deserve a review. We had stumbled upon this restaurant while walking on Brennan and decided to go in for a drink and some starters. The Bone Marrow, Duck Liver Mousse, and Brussels Sprouts Chips caught our eye - they were standard and were enough for us to consider staying for the rest of the meal. The fare wasn't incredible, but it was enjoyable, and that's something people don't talk about enough, the area between meh-food and great food, enjoyable food.

And besides, their Bone Marrow is prepared Henderson-style. You can't go wrong with Henderson.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Went for dinner. 
The steak & burger were amazing. 
Cauliflower very tasty. 
The place itself was very crowded but the waitresses and waiter were friendly and fast. 
Wish the place was a little bigger and had more stuff from the lunch menu for dinner.
author: Laila M.

description: The food and drinks are DELICIOUS Our server was the sweetest.! Wasn't too sure what to get and she led me in the right direction.. definitely will be going back for more and hopefully she's there too.
author: Silvia R.

description: Had a friend's birthday dinner here with four ladies. It's very nice on the inside with bright white tiling and good service. The drinks can get expensive (but probably not if you drink within reason, which me and my friends aren't really known for doing), but the food is great. They tend to err on the "Californian/American" style side, with some smaller dishes so it's like American tapas? Highly recommend their Brussel sprouts and their liver spread- really really good. I had the burger last time I went and was so so happy!
author: Lai-Nin W.

description:
3.5/5

Love the cocktails, aesthetics, service and the apps but the entrees leave something to be desired. I highly recommend reservations however for as popular as this restaurant is, open table usually has something available a week in advance. 

I've been to Marlowe a few times now and after experiencing brunch, HH and dinner here are my hits, okays, and misses.

+ bone marrow (Creamy and delicious. Enough for 5 little toasts)
+ the baker's wife (A yummy elderflower vodka cocktail... The selection here is on trend.) 

~ brûléed citrus (a refreshing side but really not worth $10)
~ burger (good but not the best)
~ pork chop (bang for your buck because it is huge and juicy but lacked flavor)

- poulet vert (decently cooked bird but all my table mates and I were expecting softer dumplings--not ones that resembled taters along with a more vibrant sauce)
- smokey baked cauliflower (it's like gluten free Mac and cheese but I found the cauliflower chunks too large and mushy)
author: Tammy T.

description:
Marlowe's lunch is nothing to write home about. The atmosphere is welcoming and trendy, very east-coast eatery. I loved the cow decor, but my coworker claimed the burger to not be up to snuff for repping their cow love so much.

The wait staff during our particular lunch was awkward, yet friendly. It felt like they haven't practiced the menu enough as they couldn't answer our questions on the spot and often had to return with an answer from management.

Food-wise, the lobster roll was a 2/5. The bread roll was delicious, but that's not the only reason I ordered the dish! The lobster was mediocre, not buttery, and covered in kimchi. This preparation was barely advertised on the menu, so I was disappointed when I couldn't avoid the kimchi and strong flavor. I had been seeking a buttery, satisfying, New England-style lobster roll.

Redeeming for Marlowe are their cocktails. Yes, lunchtime cocktails! Don't leave without tasting the lavender gimlet which might be worth getting even just for the photo :)
author: Kerry G.

description:
I was slightly disappointed when I went to Marlowe. Our group of four arrived a little past the lunch rush when most of the tables were finishing up. There were a couple of tables available on the floor but the hostess told us there was no space but we could sit at the bar if we wanted. Okay fair enough. 

Our bartender was really nice except he didn't seem to have enough knowledge of the wines on the wine list. We asked for something full bodied and jammy but ended up getting something that was quite light and wasn't a great match with our meal. 

My friends and I all ordered the steak salad, medium rare. First thing I noticed was that the sizes of the steaks were pretty inconsistent, some pieces fattier than the others. Portion sizes were pretty big and the flavours were good but overall things just fell kind of flat.

It's a shame as I had high expectations for this place and had it bookmarked for awhile. Better luck next time.
author: Eunah T.

description:
Marlowe is an upscale, French-inspired restaurant in the South Beach area of SF that offers up some really delicious food! I came here with a group of four on Sunday evening after watching a show at AT&T park, and we were seated right away with our reservation. The menu is relatively small, but there were so many enticing food and drink options! The décor is pretty as well, though the restaurant is relatively small and can get crowded.

We started off our meal by sharing a few appetizers. First, we had the burrata, which came on toast with prosciutto and greens. The toast was perfectly warm, crispy, yet thick, and provided the perfect contrast to the cool, soft cheese. Delicious! We also had the steak tartare with a poached quail egg--this dish had a very strong flavor of Worcestershire sauce and had just the right amount of spice/kick!
