author: Tanay J.

description:
Marlow is known for their burger, and everyone raves about the bone marrow, but...holy, beautiful garlicky mushroom polenta.  The polenta is phenomenal.  I don't care if you're a carnivore, you *owe* it to yourself to try it.

We started with the roasted brussel sprout chips, and some great whisky cocktails. Everyone enjoyed their meals - pork chops, burger and fish.  And you know my feelings on the polenta!

I would recommend reservations, especially on the weekends.
author: Kelly E.

description:
Absolutely loved this place! As soon as we walked in, it felt like we were transported back to NYC.

We were able to grab a walk in table at 930pm and were seated fairly quickly. Our waitress was super nice and accommodating and when our main meal took a while to come out, the manager came by and gave us a roasted pistachios which were uber delicious!

Our dishes:
- Brussels sprouts chips: a bit on the saltier side but still really good 
- Chicken fried okra: imagine fried okra with fried batter, like fried chicken but without actual meat. Good but could pass.
- Deviled eggs: actually so delicious! Must get. Only $2.5 per half egg.
- Anson Mills Polenta: a delicious mix of arugula, mushrooms and Polenta 
- Roasted cauliflower: completely unexpected but tasted like a delicious mac and cheese 

Also due to a mixup in the kitchen, they gave us a free dessert which was ice cream over a light cookie base. The service was incredibly top notch and would definitely recommend!
author: Christine L.

description: OMG who thinks of putting clam chowder in their baked mussels, and then sprinkles some chives on them? Marlowe, that's who. And fried brussels sprout chips! Not overly salted, a little bit of lemon, so crisp and delicious. And a great burger and open faced deviled egg sandwich. So delicious. Cannot wait to come back!!
author: Jaching H.

description: Love this place - definitely one of those places you "crave"! Sunday nights have a "Sunday burger" and wine pairing! Great atmosphere.
author: Nicole C.

description: Wasn't really impressed to be honest. Had the burger, burrata app, and brussel sprout chips. All were OK, but not very memorable
author: Laura D.

description: We were an hr early for our reservation, but the host was helpful and sat us in 15 min. Very appreciative. We both enjoyed our cocktails. We both had the Black Cod and it was perfectly delicious. We had the nectarine berry crisp for dessert, nice end to our dinner. Props to the chef. Our server was attentive and friendly.
author: Laura D.

description: Absolutely amazing! Great cocktails and great service. And the food is to die for. We started with raw oysters from Washington- yum. Then we had beef tartar- seasoned perfectly. We shared a main of pork chops, which I'm not a big fan of usually but the waiter recommended it, and fell in love. All in all- great date night and shares.
author: Leslie S.

description:
I've been wanting to come here for the longest time.  With stellar reviews, great location in SOMA, always busy and never any available reservations unless it's way pass normal dinner hours, this place has all of the signs of a poppin' restaurant.  So after months and a chance of a life time, we were able to score a reservation for a double date with friends on a Friday night at 8pm!  We were situated in the back room where it's much quieter and intimate rather than the main floor where you wouldn't be able to hear your date.

Since it was an 8pm dinner and we all saved our stomachs for this, we definitely didn't hold back.  Below is a list of items we shared family style:
* Crispy Brussels Chips
* Crab Crepes
* Steak Tartare
* Tomato Soup
* Little Gem Salad
* Steak
* Grilled Niman Pork Chop
* Loretta's Vacherin

Of the ones listed above, I felt the appetizer items were the best.  The crispy brussel chips and the steak tartare were great starters to complement our wines.  I usually fancy a nice European red wine so the steak tartare definitely hyped me up for more.  The brussel chips were just awesome.  We could have easily ordered more but decided not to since we had entrees to try.

For entrees, either we were overhyped for months or we enjoyed the appetizers and wine so much the entrees just didn't live up to the hype.  The pork chop was cooked well and was tender but we all felt there wasn't any taste or spunk to make it memorable.  The steak was filling with the potatoes and even though it was cooked medium rare (the way I prefer), again it didn't have the flavor or spark that makes me want to come back for more.

Overall, a decent place to try out.  I'll need to go back since there's a few entrees that other reviewers mentioned and posted photos that makes me salivate.  Until then...
author: Ronald L.

description:
TL;DR - Nothing to complain about, but nothing special.

Ok. So.... I've been to Marlowe at least once for every meal now... so I feel like I can properly review this place now.

The vibes are cool here. A little rustic, a little minimalist, clean, white, homey interior. The service is pretty meh too. If you are a smaller party, they tend to kind of ignore you.

Food:
Seriously... just ok. From brunch, to raw bar to lunch to dinner, everything was good, but not memorable. You can't really go wrong ordering anything... just don't expect to be blown away.

Actually no, scratch that, pass on those gross little donut balls at brunch. Ick. 

If you are to get anything, get a burger or the smoked salmon plate.

But honestly, for the price, there are better options.
author: Crystal Z.

description: Solid brunch. Bright space.  Excellent service and great wine. Would like  to have seen a salad or two on the brunch/lunch menu.
author: Joe C.

description:
First visit after the relocation to the old Coco500 space and had a few munchies at the bar. With the larger location, they now have a full bar with cocktails. Not sure I like all of the white tile.

I'm in the minority, but the Warm Deviled Egg (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=EwKn3TfLpGpm97sSAiTQsw#x6e10CnPnPtSQy7Bif9gWg) here is not a favorite. Something with the texture w/ the bacon & melted cheese on top (It's not you, it's me). Good, but not craveable.

Baked Oyster was a similar story. The "New England clam chowder in a shell" is served on a bed of rock salt (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=EwKn3TfLpGpm97sSAiTQsw#06-s5iNy9uLDXVxjY-D4rA). I liked the crispy bread-crumbs on top and it was creamy / cheesy, but didn't find it very clam chowder-y (or oyster-y even). Also a little salty (and I like salt). Would have prefered raw oyster.

Steak Tartare with poached quail egg & crostini (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=EwKn3TfLpGpm97sSAiTQsw#ImGjqwSWzRW8juAng_jgzA). Meal redemption! This was excellent. Just enough mustardy flavor, the poached quail egg had an oozing yolk that added some nice richness (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=EwKn3TfLpGpm97sSAiTQsw#bnmPqvmdECqxOnJbe-vN1g). Good balance of flavors.

Cocktails were tasty, but kind of weak pours, imo . . .
author: Andrew C.

description: Marlowe is our go to brunch place! We love it! I always always always get the deviled eggs! I often just want them to bring me out a platter of them for my meal. They're so good! We recently tried the hash brown Benedict that was unreal!! So amazing! I like the French roast soldiers, but I think they need to get better chocolate sauce (the maple syrup is good!). The crispy fried chicken sandwich is another of my favorites! I always get a Pimms cup when I'm there. So refreshing and delicious! I love it!
author: Samantha M.

description: Met a good friend who lives in San Fran for dinner. The meal was excellent from the drinks to the appetizer and our main course. My daughter's steak was huge and delicious. Seating was a bit tight but the free cocktail made up for it.
author: Tracey L.

description: Such an amazing brunch! It's a little pricey, but so is all of San Fran. Everyone at my table got something different and raved about their food. Dessert is a must. I went here for brunch, but now I desperately want to try their dinner. Go here!!
author: Allison F.

description:
Wow!! Simply impressed. If you haven't been to Marlowe, book a table now. Superb service and the most delicious food.

The service: 5 stars! We arrived with no reservations on a crowed Friday. The wonderful hostess informed us that they were booked for the night, but they might have room at the bar. As soon as we left the hostess to wait for the bar space, a waitress immediately asked if we had been help, if we had could she start us with drinks. Wow! That was fast. She was super friendly and had wonderful drink suggestions such as the summertime old fashion & the sipping Lou seal. Both refreshing and amazing. 

Food: 5 stars! This is the kind of food that makes you wonder, "if this is the way food is supposed to taste, then what have I been eating all these years?" We had the Niman Pork Chop & Petrale Sole. Omg!! I'm still dreaming about the delicious, creamy cauliflower risotto that came with the Sole. So delicious, I could have a bowl of that risotto by itself.  The Niman Pork Chop was seasoned perfectly and it was huge!! A little under for my preference, but still delicious. We were both stuffed by the end of the meal. Only item to get a 3-4 stars was the Brussel sprouts. Had high hopes for these, but the were just fine/normal. When everything was so AMAZING, we weren't ready to go back to "normal" quite yet. 

Overall impressions: simply amazed with this small quaint restaurant. As one who used to work in the Biz, I can honestly say these guys are on point when it comes to service & their attention to detail with each plate. Well done, Marlowe. Well done!
author: Monika Y.

description:
Went for lunch spontaneously without making a reservation and had to wait for a while, but it was well worth it. 

For starters, we were recommended the brussels sprout chips. GET THEM. THEY ARE AMAZING. I would suggest getting them to share because they can be a little salty, but they are full of flavor, perfectly crispy, and fun to eat. However, the standout dish was of course the famous Marlowe burger -- by far one of the best gourmet burgers I've ever tasted. The meat was perfectly cooked and absolutely out of this world and it was so decadent that I had trouble finishing it, and the sharpness of the horseradish aioli with the fries was a genius combination. Save some room for dessert, though -- the pudding with the cocoa nibs is not to be missed.
author: Em S.

description:
What is it with restaurants now serving shrimp with all the shell on? Is it to prove it's really a shrimp? I don't go out to eat so I can eat with my hands -- especially on a first date! The place was packed so we sat at the bar and ordered craft cocktails. I enjoyed mine quite a bit. Then we ordered a couple of bites to share. Surprisingly, there wasn't much that looked appealing to share as snack food. 

We got the Jumbo Gulf Shrimp and Little Gem Salad. The salad was kind of fantastic with thin shavings of fennel and a delicious dressing. But the shrimp -- and there weren't very many -- came in a sauce with the whole shell on. They tasted more like crawdads than shrimp and the whole peeling experience kind of grossed me out. Eh, I love the way Marlowe looks on the outside but I don't recommend it for a drink and bar bites.
author: Angelique L.

description:
Now this is supposed to be one of the best burgers in SF? I've had Marlowe bookmarked for so long and was extremely disappointed when I came here the other night. The perfect burger is all about balance which Marlowe's lacked. The meat patty was too thin compared to the thick bun it came with. I actually ate the burger without the top bun. Just way too much bread. 

On the other hand I really liked the smokey baked cauliflower. It's oozing with baked cheese and taste similar to a mac and cheese without the pasta.
author: Cindy A.

description:
Sat at the bar, we shared dishes including the cauliflower, brussel sprouts, polenta and tartar. Cauliflower was great - but anything covered in cheese is generally fabulous in my book, polenta was delish (super filling) and tartar is also recommended.  Personally I am not sure what the obsession with brussel sprouts (and deviled eggs too) is but I've seen these dishes on many a menu since moving here. I would bypass the next time. 
Ambience was great - good light, buzz and conversation level.  Bar men were engaging and were on point when it came to refills.  
Overall - good experience. Thumbs up from me.
author: Fiona G.

description:
My boyfriend made a reservation here around 2 weeks in advanced for our anniversary dinner. I've passed by this restaurant several times but never knew that it was Marlowe (but then again they just recently moved to this location and idk what it was before) 

We came here on Saturday evening, and found parking very easily (street/metered parking). The restaurant is small and has an intimate setting (dimly lit), but a very nice vibe. Our table was ready when we walked in. Once we sat down and took a look at the menu I saw that there were so many delicious looking items to choose from! Boyfriend and I decided to just order a whole bunch of items to share (very smart choice).

We ordered:
BITES - 
Crispy Brussels SPROUT Chips ($9): I'm not a HUGE fan of brussel sprouts but these were seasoned deliciously! They also were broken down so I wasn't eating an entire brussel sprout, but picking from the crisps that were made. We ate them all, down to the very last bite!
Baked Oyster ($3/1) : These looked so good when they came out! On the menu it says that it is baked with new england clam chowder. I am always immediately drawn to anything with clam chowder in it. It was nice and warm and the oyster was a good size. 
Warm Devlied Egg ($2.5/1): These deviled eggs were really good. Definitely leaves you wanting more

STARTERS - 
Little Gem Salad ($12): Out of everything we ordered, this would have to be the least favorite. It wasn't bad, but compared to our other options, we could do without.
Roasted Bone Marrow ($14): LOVED it! This is only the second time I've had bone marrow, but i'm a big fan now. It came out with four little pieces of bread, which we used to spread the bone marrow on. My only complaint is that 4 pieces of bread is not enough! So we asked for more and got more :).

MAINS - 
Marlowe Burger ($16): The Marlowe Burger comes with fries and horseradish sauce (on the side - not a fan). Boyfriend and I shared half a burger each. With the amount of food we ordered this was a good choice on our part. Boyfriend likes it medium rare, but I'm always scared to eat my meat pink so when it came out and I saw it I was worried. However - it was cooked very nicely and just the right amount for each of us.

Overall, awesome dining experience and I will definitely be back!
author: Michelle C.

description: Dined here for Brunch before a Giants game. They were obviously very busy, but you could tell our server was doing her best along with the manager to get everyone in and out so they could get to the game. That being said, our food came out waaaaayy late and sadly we had to scarf it down because we had to leave for the game. What we did have was great! Open faced Ruben was delicious, the bread was a little hard, but everything else about it was so good! Had the French toast soldiers, I preferred them with the syrup, I tried them with the Mexican chocolate too but it was a bit too sweet for my liking. Burger that I heard so much about was good, not great, in my opinion. Oh, drinks on point. After the game we went back and I had the game day special with tequila and tried a friend's The Baker....sooo good!
author: Jennifer C.

description: First time customer. The food and service was very good!! The noise level is too loud. It was difficult to hear what my friend was saying sitting next to me. I would suggest they turn the volume down on the music.
author: mary f.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by Marlowe. With a week heavy in finer dining restaurants, Marlowe was one that came through with quality, cost, and atmosphere. 

Prices are reasonable and I especially enjoyed the bone marrow and deviled eggs appetizer. I hear there's a deviled egg sandwich for lunch, and that just sounds flat out amazing. 

The pork chop is immense and savory/sweet, and again seems to be a dish SF does well in general. The burger is also hefty but is on the simpler side with that horseradish dipping sauce. If you like a sharp kick in the nose with your beef then this is your burger. And luckily enough I like the pain. Sticks and stones and chains and whips. Jk.
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
We had an awesome dinner here a few weeks ago. Our server, whose name I think was Sam?, was awesome, super friendly and knowledgeable about the tastes and drinks we were having and mixing. I liked the space of the restaurant, it reminded me of a tightly squeezed French bistro, with tables real close and the heat emitting from the kitchen, I liked it. 

I love chalkboard menu specials so we tried the vegetable dish of the evening that was soo good with some kinda pork in it I think, and then bone marrow, a burger and cod, all worth trying and eating. Prices are a little higher than would be somewhere else but the quality and vibe match the price and the city so it's well worth it in my opinion. Anyone who can cook bone marrow gets an A in my book and they did not disappoint. Our drinks were also perfecly made and well poured, I will definitely return one day!
author: Crystal B.

description:
Pros:
-The food. Loved the bone marrow, burgers & fries, pork chop, and the gingerbread cake with vanilla ice cream. The bone marrow was very seasoned and flavorful, but the portions were tiny and watery (I've had more substantial bone marrow at Chapeau!). The gingerbread cake and ice cream was very delicious and rich. The meat of the burger, in medium rare, was pretty amazing and the pork chop wasn't as dry as other places.
-The atmosphere. Dark setting. Real lighted candles in the middle of the table. Servers wore unique blue aprons.
-Great for birthdays. Let them know, and they'll bring out a birthday candle with your desert.

Cons:
-Not the best selection for people who don't eat meat. There were only 5 main courses to pick from and 3 of them were meat-based (burger, steak, pork chop). They do have a lot of non-meat sides/starters/appetizers though. 
-Apparently from the other reviews, the service has been decreasing. I didn't see any problems with the service, but I have had more upbeat servers at the Olive Garden.
-Tables are very close to each other and it is very loud inside.
-Hard to get a good time for a reservation, so make sure to call early!
author: Vicki L.

description: Next to no wait on a Sunday night, one of the few spots open until 10pm for a bite. The burger was the standout, with a daily special available. The ambiance was cute, intimate and datey. Would recommend!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
4 of us dined in a Thursday late evening. It had been raining an hour or so before. 2 of the party checked in, they wouldn't seat them until the other 2 showed up. Normally, I wouldn't question, however part of the first was a lady on crutches that just had ankle surgery 5 days before. They explained the story that the other 2 were just parking and that the surgery had happened. They asked if they could be seated. 

Hostess was not moved and said no. 

5 minutes later,  entire party was present. It took another 10 minutes to be seated with a reservation.  

The bill was just shy of $300, 3 cocktails included in total. 

Food was very ok, but not worth $270. 

Pork chops, burger and pasta .. just not a $300 meal.
author: Tammy P.

description: Great for a date night. My Ribeye was amazing, a perfect medium rare. Everything was well seasoned. The service was was very professional.
author: Zach D.

description:
Come hither friends, this is the same Marlowe with the same delicious menu, just a block away from it's old location!

I've only had lunch here and it was amazing each time. I luckily work only a few blocks away so I decided to take my co-workers for one of their birthday lunches...best decision ever! We made resis through open table because when I've gone to the old location before they'd always be packed around lunch hours to the point we had to order for takeout. The new location now is a bit more spacious but still the same modern/rustic décor and surprisingly there was no wait with multiple tables vacant.

We started off with the crispy brussel sprout chips, which all of us loved. The serving size is kinda small for $9 and the recipe isn't all that complicated either, but for whatever reason the few times I've attempted baking brussel sprout chips in the oven, they've never turned out as tasty as these! I literally could've had a serving to myself.

One of my co-workers went with the Marlowe burger cooked medium rare while the other got the open faced devil egg sandwich. I got the crispy fried chicken sandwich with Caesar aioli and bacon , which is the only thing I've had off the lunch menu cuz it's too good not to get! All these meals came with a side of fries. It has a nice crispy crunch on the outside, but the meat is so juicy and flavorful and the bacon adds that extra flavor. The serving size doesn't look like too much, but it is super filling. My co-workers loved their orders as well, we damn near cleared our plates completely.

We didn't have room or time for dessert, but everything on their menu sounds so yummy! The service was so-so, our waiter was friendly but it was a tad slow considering the place was close to empty. It's on the pricier side but it's nice to come once in awhile to treat ourselves to a quality and tasty lunch. Will definitely be back and hopefully come by for dinner sometime.
author: Georgina G.

description: The food is really good. I like the place as it's convenient. The service was satisfactory as well.
author: Babak G.

description: One of the best restaurants in SF. Great causal yet classy vibe, very comfy. The drinks are highly recommended along with the bone marrow, a must have.
author: Dave M.

description:
As an old customer of Marlowe I was super excited to have a new year dinner at their new location. Service was excellent. Food was a huge disappointment though. The menu was prepared with simple nice food which sounded delicious. But when arrived at table, it looked and tasted like something I would order at a next door diner. No balance in taste and too much of everything at the same time. Definitely not worth the money. 

Keep it simple, especially with classic dishes as duck and petit filet. Desert made it all good tho...
author: Kamila r.

description:
Great food at a great price. 

Some of the highlight dishes:
Brussel Sprout chips were addicting and perfect with your alcoholic drink. 
Duck liver mousse was super creamy and delicious.
Beef tartare with egg on top was also very good.
Burrata Toast was great as well. 
Fanny Bay Oysters were on point. 

The appetizers and starters are absolutely amazing and you can just order bunch of these as your meal. 
For entree we tried the NY steak, Poulet Vert, Pork chop, and Marlowe Burger.

Poulet Vert was very good. 
Pork Chop was juicy and smoky. 
The burger here is probably one of the best in the bay area. 

The desserts were nothing really special. Warm cookies were not warm or soft. 

Prices are not bad for the quality of food. Will return again.
author: tsubasa m.

description: Little fancy shmancy but down to Earth. I'm liking the food (try the burger!) and vibes. Solid lunch spot or dinner date before heading over to coinop.
author: Howe L.

description:
Fancy date night with the hubs! I really wanted to like this place. We had reservations before 6pm and only a few people were there but the hostess sat us at the worst seat of the house! We were placed next to the kitchen where the door kept on opening and closing, noises and light kept shining disturbing our very rare date night.  I could not concentrate to the hubs because I was so bothered. They should put a curtain there or never sit anyone there unless it is packed! 

I ordered the bone marrow and the toasts were burnt. My hubs ordered the pork chop and it was pink! Arrrrrggggg. 

Ambiance was ok. Service was ok. I just would not go back to spend another $150. Only good thing was the company that I was with. 

Very disappointed.
author: Stacey C.

description:
Visited SF with my girls one weekend and I was super excited to try this place out. I love their weird and random pictures located near the bathroom. It gave me something to do while waiting in line for the bathroom. Came here on a Saturday night with a reservation so we didn't have to wait. It slowly started to get packed so I recommend getting a reservation if you're impatient like me. 

The best thing on their menu is definitely their Brussel sprouts chips!!!! They're extremely addicting, crunchy and delicious. They are a bit oily and greasy, but what chips arent? Seriously tho, get these if you're here, you won't regret it. 

I got the Anson Mills Polenta which was AMAZING! I never tried polenta until this moment and I surprisingly liked it. It reminded me of this yellow Chinese porridge that I've had before. The best part about the dish was literally everything! This dish was so perfect for me because it had all of my favorite ingredients in it. It comes with mushrooms, arugula, Parmesan, truffle salsa verde and a poached egg. This is like a vegetarians dream dish, at least it was mine. I forsure recommend this dish, and I can't wait to come back to get this again. 

My other friends didn't really enjoy their dishes as much as I did. They thought it was mediocre and nothing special. I would give this place 4 stars since my friends thought this place was whatever's, but I really enjoined my dishes so I just gotta give it 5 stars.
author: Christina G.

description:
Overall, I'm giving Marlowe 4 stars as the synergy of the food, service and the ambiance lifted this place above most other places for brunch.  Yes, we had reservations so we were promptly seated.  Most of our party had a spicy-hot Bloody Mary while I had an au lait, generously served in a large mug.  
The wait staff was friendly, helpful and gave us time to caucus over the menu as we wanted to be able to share some items. 
 
On the 'gotta have more' list are: 
  Deviled eggs (we ordered 1/2 doz; 3 with bacon on top, 3 w/o bacon.  All w/jalapeno)
  Housemade doughnuts

On the 'pretty darn good' list are: 
   Spring scramble (plentiful and filling)
   Marlowe burger
   Crispy fried chicken sandwich (extra star for putting non-lettuce greens on the bun)

 On the 'do over' list is: 
  Overly-salted salad  (too bad as the greens were varied and looked fresh but there was so much salt it was rendered inedible)  

On the 'complete Nirvana'' list is:
  Vacherin

The service was so good, particularly two aspects:  1) When our order was ready, several wait staff brought it out so that we were all served together  (A+ for that aspect)  2) Spilled jam and crumbs were unobtrusively cleaned up between  and I guess there is a third aspect 3) Since a birthday was being celebrated, the Vacherin was delivered to our table with a lit candle.

We'll be coming back - great food, great vibe.  Thanks to the folks at Marlowe!
author: Judey M.

description:
This is my favorite SF restaurant. Been here 5 times now and will be back about 1/month. Drinks are great. They even share the recipes! So now I don't have to go there for a Solstice Manhattan (my liver just kicked me). Food is awesome. Super creative comfort food that's delicious and different. It's got a great atmosphere to boot and the German chocolate pudding is to die for. Fantastic service as well. You can't beat Marlowe!

The location kinda sucks right now since it's right next to the 4th Street construction, so give yourself a little extra time to get there if you're driving.
author: Steve T.

description:
Marlowe is the type of place I would go to if I wanted a nice meal yet don't want to break the bank for it. It's also conveniently located near the Caltrain station (ever since I started taking public transportation everywhere, this factor has become a huge deal for me!), so that's a plus for people who may not live in SF and don't want to deal with SF traffic.

Now there were some good items and bad items... I think what's interesting is how much on the opposite ends of the scale they were. For example, the good items included the brussels sprouts, the steak tartare, and the polenta. The bad items included the okra (did not seem to be fried properly), the bread pudding (I've seen MUCH better), and even the burger was a little overrated and I have heard a lot of good things about it.

The same could be said about the drinks as well. I thought the cocktails were great, but given that I heard some good things, I expected the wine list to be equally as good, if not better. I am picky about my wine but even that being said, I was very unimpressed.

Overall, like I said, a nice place to stop by if you don't want to break the bank, but just be mindful of what you order.
author: Kunal N.

description: This was just delicious! Grabbed lunch here on a recent trip, and loved every bite. Had the Brussels sprouts chips, and enjoyed the first half of them very much. The second half, on the bottom of the serving cup, was a soggy grease-soaked mess. This dish would benefit from a re-think on the plating. Also split a burger and fries, and both were terrific. Really liked the clean, cozy interior and we had great service. Highly recommend!
author: Lisa B.

description:
Being on the Whole30 plan this month (no dairy, no grains, etc.) made my trip to Marlowe a little bit more bare-bones than I would have wanted. However, a burger is a burger, and I don't need a bun (or cheese) to tell me if a burger is amazing. Do they make burgers better? In some cases. But if the beef used is high-quality and properly seasoned, an unadorned burger should be able to stand on its own.

And this one did. While it was topped a few nights later by a newcomer on the burger scene up in the Marina, it was definitely one of the top 3 burgers I've had in my 11 months in SF. The flavor was great, the temperature was right and everything worked. I thought they might be able to accommodate my request for no bun with a lettuce wrap, but it seems the burger lettuce is pre-shredded, so it wasn't something I could pick up with my hands. Still yummy.

The brussels sprout chips were a yummy starter that vanished quickly, and the side salad that I had with my burger was very nice too. My major issue with this burger is probably the price point. Even for such high quality, I think $19 is steep.
author: David B.

description:
After an afternoon show of Cirque du Soleil at AT&T Park Marlowe was the perfect place to refuel with both food and drinks. Show let out mid afternoon and at that time there is not a lot of sit down places serving food, especially on Sunday in that part of town.

Marlowe was serving their limited "Bar" menu but for us that was not a problem. Started with some crispy Brussel sprout chips, warm deviled eggs and fries with horseradish aioli.  Loved them all, especially the deviled eggs which came with aged provolone, pickled jalapeno and bacon. They were exceptional.  We all followed with the Marlowe burger and you can believe the hype. Came out a perfect medium rare as suggested by our server and was delicious. Came with carmelized onions, cheddar, bacon horseradish aoili and fries. Very tasty and a good size burger.
I had a craft beer which hit the spot (long drive ahead) and others had the cocktails which were excellent. Had a taste of the Juicer and it was creative with a spicy kick. Shared one dessert, the German Chocolate Cream Pudding and it was spot on with coconut, walnuts, marcapone cream and cocoa nibs. Yum!. Service was friendly and helpful throughout the meal.
Based on our visit I would definitely go back for dinner and sample more of the complete menu.
author: Tom D.

description: Very friendly and knowledgeable waitstaff.  The food is delicious.  We tried the cast iron skillet fritatta, the  marlowe burger, the hash brown benedict, the smoked salmon bagel and the doughnuts for brunch.  All were fantastic!  The restaurant has a really nice vibe, almost European like a french bistro.  Most excellent coffee.  I was really impressed and I recomment highly.  One of the best in San Francisco.  Next time we go I want to try the interesting cocktails - the menu is really well done.
author: Katrina S.

description: My favorites were the oh so lemony, buttery-tasting brussel sprout chips. I think they were flash-fried but when I bit into these crispy, salty morsels, there was the perfect ooze of oily goodness that was akin to good 'ol butta. The Marlowe burger, which I requested to be made medium rare, was truly elevated by the well-seasoned shoestring fries and horseradish aioli. The decadence described here was not excessive. I was incredibly satisfied and would highly recommend to everyone.
author: P C.

description:
It's all the rage right now and literally next door so I had to try it right? Not really.

Upon walking in the hostess was on the phone and super friendly and apologetic that we had to wait. No problem there and I was actually upset for her as the restaurant was so loud I could barely hear myself think, let alone imagine talking on the phone. She deserves a star to herself.

As for the food- it was ok. We ordered the Brussels sprouts that everyone is in love with and they were good, but worth $9 or whatever it was? No. We also ordered the burger and that was okay as well. I'd say it was also not worth $16. For $16 I want to be wowed. Or it better have something crazy rare or truffles or something happening in there that makes it amazing. Nada. 

We also ordered cokes. And I know you're thinking okay how can a soda go wrong? Well. It was $4, which is gladly pay in an upscale bar or in a fancy hotel- somewhere where I know I am paying extra for the ambiance. The waitress also asked if we would like refills which we said sure to only to be charged an additional $4 on our bill.

In all, $8 each for 2 glasses of flat coke, $9 for some sprout flakes that probably cost $1 to make and $16 for an okay burger. I probably should've just gone to umami down the street.
author: Leina K.

description:
We had a reservation so the wait was not an issue. The restaurant is small so reservations are recommended. Service was very friendly and efficient, although once the food was dropped off at our table our waiter was MIA for a bit.

The menu is pretty short. We ordered the deviled eggs and a couple of beers to start. The deviled eggs were good, if not so different from other versions I've had before. My wife ordered some oysters as well and she was very happy with them (I can't eat them). 

For our entrees, I got the pork chop and she got the steak. Our two entrees were done well, but again, it just tasted like things we've had before. I think in retrospect we should have ordered the burger just to see what all the fuss is about. 

We went with the waiter's recommendation for the dessert which was the vacherin (a meringue dessert) with coffee ice cream. This was actually something that was unique and interesting, and we enjoyed it a lot.


To be honest I had a hard time with the rating...I was struggling between a 3 and a 4. The food was good but not outstanding (maybe it was our fault for ordering steak and pork chop?). However, we experienced very good service and I found the ambiance to be the right amount of loud / happening while still retaining an intimate feeling. Consider this more of a 3.5 star rating
author: Alvin J.

description:
My boyfriend took me here for my birthday dinner and every dish we had was a 9/10 out of ten. They do not have a big menu, but the dishes they offer are fantastic! He ordered pork chops, that could almost melt in your mouth, which was paired with grits and collards greens. He's southern, so he was in heaven. I had the cod, which tasted more similar to sea bass than I remember. It had a thai influence with a veggie coconut broth. It was incredible. I ordered champagne and the manager topped me off complimentary, which made us feel special. Oh yea, we came for the bone marrow and it did not disappoint. Tip, you have to eat the bone marrow with the caper/olive sauce and herbs to really appreciate the flavor. 

My only compliant are the tables are very close to one another and folks talk really loud, but the food and service was so good, I had to give them 5 stars!
author: Tabitha S.

description: The ambiance is great and the service is excellent. Parking is not that easy (parked on the street at a meter) and the outside is a bit sketchy. The food itself was average. I was told by the waiter that most people come for the Marlowe burger so my expectation of it was rather high. It was good but not great. They recommended getting it done medium-rare which was a good decision however I wasn't to fond of the bread that it came on and the burger was rather small for the price that you pay ($17 for burger and fries).
author: David E.

description: The polenta brunch dish with truffle oil on top is out of this world! Great service and atmosphere!
author: Ashley G.

description: Marlowe was impeccable, from the drinks to the food, although it was very crowded on a Thurs night and the tight seating felt like we were packed like sardines. The beer battered asparagus was unique and delicious, the little gem salad an absolute beauty, the polenta was fine and the poulet vert was well-done as well. They made the glitterbomb drink alcoholic for my friend and it was so fun with all the muddled raspberries. So amazing, would love to come back when there's more room to breathe.
author: C C.

description:
Checked out the new location for brunch and was overall impressed. Service is solid and decor lightened up yet feels very upscale but casual.

Food:
Dungeness Crab Toast (5/5) - not heavy and very focused on getting that delicate crab taste to come through
Coffee (4/5) - not your average restaurant coffee. Definitely higher quality.
Tomato Baked Eggs (3/5) - not bad, not great but not very flavorful. It was healthier for you and the veggies seemed fresh but it just didn't come together with the harissa as much as I thought it would.

Good spot for a classier take on brunch!
author: Victor W.

description:
I have always wanted to try Marlowe, as i was a big fan of their popup Marlowe Burger. Its a place you go with a bunch of friends and hangout have good food and forget what time it is. We had a group of six, we had no trouble with our reserved table, the food was really good, was bummed they didn't have lamb although the chicken and the pork chops were delectable. The service was absolutely top notch. i have been to many fine dining places and the service here was better than some of those. 

If you are thinking of this place as a date night, well might have to be like a 5th date, as the place is incredibly loud, so i would suggest it more for groups. 

It was a great experience and i would recommend it to anyone.
author: Anuj C.

description: Food is amazing and service is equal! Shannon even went above and beyond and printed out show tickets because I thought I could just have them scan my ticket in my phone! WHAT A LIFE SAVOR!
author: Natalie M.

description:
Marlowe is one of those SF restaurants that has earned such a good reputation over the last few years that I had high expectations when our group dined here on a late Friday evening.

The layout is cozy and pretty dark, which makes it a relatively cool spot to catch up with friends or maybe a casual date. I would not want to be taken here for a romantic date because the noise levels are high and all of the tables are spaced tightly together.

Upon ordering, our waitress reminded us the kitchen was closing in 10 minutes and looked very nervous like she wanted to end her shift and start her Friday evening asap. 
All of the dishes we had ordered and shared were three stars. They were too bland for my taste. Although I don't crave desserts, I did find the two we ordered interesting and above average.

All in all, there is nothing about Marlowe that makes me want to come back. On to the next cool spot in SF.
author: Angela L.

description: We get there and the waiter did not even introduce himself. It kind of seemed like they were rushing us to order, but anyways, we ordered quickly because we didn't want to hold up the table for future dinner guests. We ended up waiting a little over an hour for our dinner to get to the table. It doesn't make sense that a small restaurant would not be able to bring out the food quickly. If there was some sort of issue going on in the kitchen I think they should let customers know that there's a delay; personally I prefer I'm told what's going on rather than being left in the dark. Anyways, drinks were good, food was food, but service was underwhelming.
author: Cristal F.

description:
I wish Marlowe had more selection of beer... That is my ONLY constructive criticism. 

Service, ambience and food were completely impeccable. Every dish was amazing. Our plates were perfectly timed. I even fell in love with the staff's stylish aprons. The small back patio is adorable and quiet, perfect for a date. 

I would list stand outs, but literally everything was good. Just go.
author: Catie F.

description:
Was here for dinner tonight and had a mixed experience. Walked in relatively early when it was fairly empty and was digging the ambience. As the night progressed, it got increasingly busy and loud and I ended up with a hoarse voice from all the yelling trying to have a conversation. Not a big deal but just an observation.

The food and service was the part that was mixed. Our waitress was very pushy and kept checking on us every 5 mts and asked the same thing over and over. "Another drink?"... "ready for appetizers"..."ready for entree". We ended up ordering way more than we needed...yes, I am weak.

The Pimm's cup was refreshing. The brussel sprout chips, the deviled eggs and the bone marrow were good. I don't think you can go wrong with a burrata toast and they did not either. The polenta was very salty and disappointing. Ideally I would have had dessert but we ordered way too much food and ended up getting stuffed.

Decent place but there are too many options here, I don't think I will be back.
author: Sunil R.

description: Let's be honest: get the burger. It's part beef and lamb, and it's topped with the most delicious horseradish aioli! We had a few appetizers, but nothing spectacular. Unfortunately, our brussells chip were burnt. The burger, which is probably top 3 in SF, is worth the trip though.
author: Benjamin A.

description: Just came home from dinner and still feeling the salt in my mouth. We tried baked oysters, Brussels sprouts crips and Marlowe burger. Everything was over salty. Burger was under cooked from what i'd like. Waiter was rude. The place is overrated. Bread of the burger was not good. Not recommended at all!
author: Gzde C.

description:
This place has earned a place on my list of go-to places in SF! 

I'll keep this review short and simple:

Order the bone marrow and brussels sprouts.

You're welcome.
author: Vicky P.

description:
This place is a ten minute walk from my apartment, and I absolutely love it! I've been wanting to go for months and finally had the chance. The decor is adorable and makes for a perfect date spot. The servers are incredibly friendly. 

As for the food, it was very good! The duck liver is fantastic. The bone marrow wasn't really what I expected, but I think that's because I don't like bone marrow in general. If I did like it, I would say it was prepared very nicely though (if that makes sense).  The burger was nice, but I didn't think it was as amazing as everyone makes it sound.

The desserts delicious, and you need to order it! I recommend the Loretta's Vacherin and chocolate creme pie! The Loretta's Vacherin is meringue with coffee ice cream. This may not sound yummy, but it totally is! The chocolate creme pie is heaven, with dirt like chocolate on the bottom. Get it!

I would recommend making a reservation. They are always packed, especially evenings, and they don't really have any good area to sit or stand while waiting for a table!
author: Nadia H.

description:
I'd like to give this place 3 stars baed on the service. My husband and I went here for dinner. We made reservations through open table. I started w the bakers wife cocktail, it was decent if you like vodka. The deviled eggs were amazing. I got the New York steak medium rare as an entree. It was cooked medium instead. I don't like sending food back especially meat because it's a waste but I did tell our server just so she was aware. She made things awkard. My husband got the duck special, very good. LOL  Our server was also constantly asking if I wanted drink or if we were okay, it was pretty annoying. There's a difference between being attentive and overbearing. She also took our check before we left which was poor etiquette. I remember my first day on the job LOL

Service was a 3
Food was a 4 - wish they would've cooked it med rare, would've been a 5!
author: Mal L.

description: My husband and I shared the ribeye, polenta, and a little gem salad. Afterwards both of us had food poisoning. I used to really love Marlowe, but not so sure anymore. Maybe if I come back I'll just get cocktails and fries. :(
author: Marina K.

description: This is EXCELLENT food and service. Seriously the best crudo and burrara I've ever had. We also brought in a baby which can be annoying to servers typically but they all smiled at him and were so kind. This is a phenomenal spot!
author: Sarah D.

description:
Marlowe must be the name of a deity because the food was simply divine. That sounds silly but for me the food was almost a religious experience. The menu is succinct, the decor dark and a little rustic, but it all comes together creating a church or temple of nose to tail tastiness! 

We were a big group so we ordered a serious selection of appetizers to start. I fell head over heels for the big bad ass BBQ shrimp. Head on grilled gulf prawns, charred to perfection and infused with a light smoke, served with a craveable cocktail sauce. These are definitely the kind of skrimps you wanna peel the tail and suck the head! I could eat a mountain of these and never get tired of the taste. My second love had to be the duck liver toast that night. Crispy grilled bread with a delicate duck liver pate, set off by a tiny bit of whole grain mustard. My mouth is watering as I type this! 

Just as I thought it couldn't get any better, the main course arrived, and that was my moment of religious epiphany. A large plate landed in front of, at the center of which rested a perfectly cooked Niman Ranch pork chop. The chop sat on top of some braised greens, and scattered around the plate were chunks of deep fried morcilla (Spanish Blood Sausage). This combination was a beautiful masterpiece that left me craving bite after bite. 

Just recapping this visit has me wanting to return for a do-over. Not that I'd change anything about the evening, just wanting to do it again and bring more people to try it with me!
author: Michael T.

description: 4.5 stars rounded down. Marlowe is one of those rare restaurants that we keep coming back to over and over again. I've been here both for brunch and dinner and the experience is always a great one. They're always busy and we never manage to make a reservation on OpenTable, but calling the restaurant usually yields a table the night of, albeit usually not at an ideal time (9pm or later). Service is always great, food is always fantastic, cocktails are always delicious as well. We've tried almost everything on the menu throughout our various visits and we always get the brussels sprout chips, the bone marrow, and the Marlowe burger. Have also had the oysters, polenta, cod... really can't go wrong with anything on their menu. As for dessert, as everyone have already said, the vacherin is the perfect way to end a meal here. Thanks Marlowe for many wonderful meals and we will keep coming back!
author: Wendan L.

description:
Cocktail hour review!

Old Fashioned was the best my boyfriend, in his words, has been served in the city! Stunning creation, if you are an Old Fashioned aficionado, be sure to stop in Marlowe for a taste!!!


Dinner review!

Marlowe Burger: 10/10
Medium-rare cooked to perfection. Excellent consistency. And the AIOLI! The horseradish Aioli Sauce is fantastical, no better way of describing. It is perfectly balanced with the cheese, onion and meat. Incredible. 
The Jumbo Shrimp. It's like taking a bite out of the ocean. Even without the sauce, the shrimp is delightfully sprinkled with a tasty sea salt. 

Super awesome dinner and drinking spot. We showed up at 5pm on the dot, on a Saturday. No wait. Half hour later BOOM, packed!  Extremely courteous service, impeccable food and cocktails, chill atmosphere. This a true SF gem.
author: Ihsuan Y.

description:
It's a shame that I only recently discovered Marlowe's brunch. My big sis took me here for a birthday treat and we both thoroughly enjoyed everything. 

We started with the dungeness crab and poached egg appetizer. It's SO good. The egg is poached perfectly and the crab tasted buttery yet light. My only wish is that there was more texture to the crab... and had more crab chunks. 

For our entrees, I had the chicken sandwich while big had the smoked salmon with bagel. Initially, she requested toast instead of bagel because "bagels are too thick" (ugh, we are the freaking worst). The waitress humored us and even though it was impossible due to the integration of the dish, it was nice of her to try. 

While the chicken sandwich was delicious, the smoked salmon stole the show. The acidity of the citrus went perfectly with creaminess of the salmon and avocado. It was refreshing and vibrant and I can't wait to come back just for this!
author: Xinxin W.

description:
I try to avoid Sunday brunch whenever possible. The lines are insane and you can never make a reservation ahead of time. Marlowe, though, allowed us to make a reservation, even for such a busy brunch time. 

We tried the Deviled Eggs, the Marlowe burger, the Crab & Rock Shrimp Crepe and the French Toast Soldiers. 

The French Toast Soldiers were amazing. By frying them in strips, there was a crunchiness to every bite and it almost resembled steak fries.

The deviled eggs, were interesting, with jalapeño and bacon on the eggs, but it was a dish that I would try once, but maybe not twice. I'm not sure if jalapeño, bacon and provolone cheese are necessarily the best combo with an egg....maybe not all at once? Such contrasting textures, so much flavour, my tastebuds were a bit overwhelmed. 

The crab and rock shrimp crepe was a bit disappointing. There was not a lot of seafood but too much crepe and the taste of the crab and shrimp were overpowered by the crepe skin. Although the waiters suggest this as a dish to try, it is not a dish I would personally recommend.

The Marlowe burger, on the other hand, is worth the hype. It was tender, flavourful, and everything you ever wanted in a burger. This was easily my favourite dish in the restaurant. 

I've also tried Marlowe for dinner. I found their dinner dishes to be good, but disappointing compared to their brunch dishes. Nothing particularly stood out, with the exception of the burger. I had the pork chop, and it was nice and tender but there was nothing special that differentiated it from other restaurants that served pork chop. It was...nice, but not a stand out. The bone marrow was also quite lovely, but again, it encountered the problem in which it tasted quite similar to those of other establishments. 

Overall, a restaurant I highly recommend for brunch (but do your research on what's good to order as not all food is made the same, although the fried chicken sandwich is supposed to be amazing), but skip the dinner, unless you're just looking for a dinner restaurant with a nice ambiance.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Marlowe took me by surprise. I expected it to be another SOMA restaurant, pompous and overhyped. But it was a great dining experience, accompanied by great service.

Crispy Brussels Sprout Chips. Love brussels sprouts, but never tried them as chips. I liked them, although it was a tad oily. Also the leaves were tiny, which made it difficult to eat. Ended up using fork and knife and scooping them into large bites. Despite that, tasty and addictive.

Marlowe Burger. Lived up to its reputation. The meat was delicious. My friend and I ordered medium rare, and so I was able to taste the freshness and quality of the beef. Along with the bacon and horseradish, it was a nicely done burger!

Grilled Niman Pork Chop. Hands down, this was the star. I'm still salivating thinking about it. The cut, the seasoning, the grilling, it was the most flavorful and tender pork chop I've ever had in my life. The restaurant was dark. My friends repeatedly shined a light at the dish so I can time and again confirm that I wasn't eating steak. Wow, I never knew. Thank you Marlowe for changing my view on pork!

The service was excellent as well. Our water was constantly filled. Napkins were fold when we were up and about. Plates were promptly cleared and replaced. And the staff was so friendly and courteous. Great time at Marlowe! =)
author: Marti L.

description: This place is my favorite in the mission Bay area. Really great ambiance. Think farmhouse w chic.  Best bloody I've had in the city.  Burgers are out of this world. Service is great too.
author: Shelly H.

description: Very nice upscale resturant. The shrimps for appetizers and the pork chops for the main dish were amazing. The wine selection was incredible and the staff was great.
author: Jolie M.

description: Good food in a rustic ambiance.  Limited menu but items are well done.  Had the Rock shrimp sandwich for lunch and it was spiced just right.  Service was good as well.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Marlowe Burger, their signature claim to fame, is clearly still a huge draw for people. I showed up on a Wednesday at 12pm for lunch and found myself welcomed by a packed house! I looked around at what people were ordering and can safely say half the patrons there were having the burger. Luckily, the host was kind enough to slide me in a the community table so I didn't have to wait forever. 

I've had the Marlowe Burger once before at Bartlett Hall (current chef used to be the former chef at Marlowe) but left feeling disappointed. However, I didn't give up hope for I knew the birth place would redeem itself.

Suffice to say, the burger was quite good. The meat was well seasoned, had a great meaty texture and still juicy. If i had one call out it would be the horseradish could at times overpower the dish. 
 
To accompany my meal I ordered the More Cowbell-such a delightfully refreshing drink. The sharpness of the gin cuts through but balanced well with the citrus sweet notes. 

For the burger ($16) + Drink $10 + tip/tax I walked out spending $36 on lunch so keep that in mind. Marlowe is definitely not a budget friendly lunch spot but well worth the trip.

Side note, can't wait for the burger window to be open! Yes you heard correctly, there will be a window take out dedicated to their burger! 

Overall Thoughts

An amazing burger but IMO best burger in SF still goes to Nopa
author: Eddie W.

description:
I pass Marlowe all the time walking home and finally decided to stop in for the Marlowe Burger on a Wednesday night around 8:30 or 9pm. I was very surprised at how busy this place was at this time. Such a cool spot though, I really liked it.

MARLOWE BURGER ($16) - really good burger but I wasn't a huge fan of the bun. It tasted like a cheap bun they bought from a grocery store. Other than that I really enjoyed it. 
BRUSSELS SPROUTS ($9) - drenched in something (butter and lemon?). A little too soggy for me and not well done enough

DRINKS:
Sculpin IPA - awesome IPA - would definitely get this again

The service here was good and it's a great spot but a little too expensive.
author: Ilana B.

description: The shrimps for appetizers and the pork chops for the main dish were amazing.  Doughnuts were a hit, and the burger was perfectly cooked.
author: Adeline P.

description:
I felt like I had been to Marlowe before but then I realized that it reminded me of the countless restaurants I've been to just like it: mediocre food, nice presentation, hipster decor, overpriced menu. Yup, that about sums it up.

We walked in for brunch on a Sunday and arrived early enough to grab seats at the counter. The bartender/waitress looked very overwhelmed and it took her a while to get to us. We ordered 1) Dungeness Crab Toast, 2) Crispy Fried Chicken Sandwich, and 3) Burrata Tartine.

The crab toast was underwhelming; the crab was not the star of the dish and it could have passed for canned tuna. The crispy fried chicken was the best item we tried but it didn't blow me away either. The burrata tartine was a form of open-faced sandwich with greens flying all over and it was hard to eat. The takeaway from my Marlowe experience is thank goodness I didn't have to pay.
author: Yi Z.

description: Ok, I used to have this spot at 5 stars but my last visit with my partner was less than expected. I was so disappointed because we came for my birthday and I had raved about the pork and he was excited to try their burger. Nothing special about the burger at all. It was quite salty and my pork was nearly flavorless. Maybe an off-night? We may come back to try again.
author: Melissa D.

description:
My experience was similar to Kristen C.'s

Not having your table available at the reserved time apparently has its advantages at Marlowe.

Our table was close to 45 minutes late which is completely unacceptable. But, what made up for it was the comp'ed bar tab and great food for our party of three. We sat at the bar as we waited to be seated and had the bone marrow, brussel sprout chips, and the little gem salad which were delicious all the while guzzling what felt like barrels of wine and champagne.
author: Edward Y.

description:
A lovely and energetic yuppie ambiance!!

The food, a great touch of innovation on many american or french dishes: really tasty!

Great service and very friendly and helpful personnel!

The restaurant is usually very crowded (popular): make sure to make your reservations well in advance.

The area where the restaurant is very much under construction: not the best though safe.
author: Gilbert B.

description:
Go, don't look at the menu and just order the Marlow burger and the RyePA, this is the can't miss formula.  The burger is to die for, the fries come out hot and crisp and stay crisp (which is hard to do), and the beer is a perfect match. 

Burger heaven!
author: Heather D.

description: I don't ever give out 5 stars. Ever. Especially when it comes to food as I consider myself a foodie. Today's brunch is the best meal I've had in years. Shrimp. Gem salad. Burger. Don't walk, run here. It's THAT amazing!!
author: Inna L.

description:
Went to Marlowe for dinner recently after a friend recommended the restaurant. We made a reservation for Friday evening, and it was pretty packed. 

I am not a frequent red meat eater, but after reading a number of great reviews on the Marlowe Burger, I knew I had to try it out! I ordered my burger medium rare, and when it came out, it was cooked perfectly, so juicy and flavorful. Definitely a great choice--it really hit the spot! My friend ordered the risotto, which she said was delicious. 

Overall, great food, ambiance, and service. I know I'll be back.
author: Christine T.

description: One star, for bob the server only... Visiting San Francisco on business... came for lunch.. blonde hostess/manager was extremely rude...  didn't greet us or look us in the face at all ... she only gave two out of three of us menus.. bob, our server was very kind and welcoming but the initial impression was offputting. Steer clear if you're black.
author: Mikaela B.

description: I had brunch today at Marlowe. The staff is nice and friendly. The coffee was great. The warm deviled egg was awesome. The lemon donuts and the French toast shoulders were great. I had the Marlowe burger and its was excellent. Great experience, hope to return soon.
author: Sophoria W.

description:
I think you have higher expectations when Michael Bauer keeps listing Marlowe as a perennial go-to spot especially for the burger but I left feeling that was the most underwhelming part of the meal. 

It's decent burger with classic toppings that work together like the horseradish, caramelized onions, and cheddar cheese but I felt the patty tasted a little anemic which was surprising considering that there's a little bit of lamb in it too. Also had the fried chicken sandwich and appreciated the combination of flavor but the fried chicken was a little dry. The bright spot food-wise was the brown butter Brussels sprouts that were crispy, flavorful, and so addictive. 

Service at Marlowe strikes a contemporary balance of laid back professionalism and I thought that was the highlight of the meal. Our server was absolutely lovely and attentive. Probably will return for work lunches but not making a deliberate effort just for the burger.
author: Jon L.

description: I think brunch ended at 2 and we arrived at 1:50. The host was super friendly and found a spot for us even though it was super busy. He even offered to help us move to another table that would better fit the size of our party but we were okay with squishing a little. The restaurant was pretty cute but a little cramp. Prices for brunch ranged from $16-23, which is a little pricey for what it was but pretty typical for SF. I got the Polenta, which was good for a couple bites in, but the cheese got tiring. Probably won't be back just because I'm not much of a brunch person, but not too bad
author: Gina L.

description:
Good meal overall. Burger was amazing, shrimp and crab poppers were good. Salad a little too much dressing and rest of menu was good but not overwhelming.
Could be a little more innovative
author: sanjay P.

description: I love Marlowe. The casual ambience of this small restaurant is great. It is a great location for a first date or a meal with friends. Our server was very attentive, the good was great. I had the burger. It was perfectly cooked and seasoned to perfection. Additionally, we ordered the duck liver pate which was very flavorful and possibly the highlight of the meal. The drinks were strong. I have added Marlowe to my list of go-to restaurants because it was such a pleasant experience.
author: Justin H.

description: I like it!  Can't give 5 because I didn't actually 'eat' here but from the crowd at lunch I'd say it's hot. I'm at the bar while the husband is in surgery down the road at UCSF Mission Bay. So I needed a bloody and they delivered. It's packed but there's room at the bar for one. Friendly bartenders. Good drink. Clean. Light. Good vibe. I'll be back!
author: Katherine E.

description:
***************************** 1371 ***************************

   Top 100 Bay Area Restaurants (2012, 2013, 2014) Michael Bauer, SF Chronicle, that tells you something about this well establishment, same management for The cavalier, and Park Tavern, and Marlowe Burger in San Francisco. 

   Took over Coco500 spot on Brannan in SoMa. A cool spot, bright light, and a busy bar that you can rarely get a spot open. Quite nice barman and a good list by the glass, if you nice, he even let you tries it first. 

   They have 1 of the best Roasted Chicken in town, and if you get lucky, you might get the Secret Fried Chicken on your plate. Their burger is also well-loved by fans. 

   Crispy Brussel Sprout is always 1 of my favorites. Baked Oyster, New England Clam Chowder is a must try. And the Grilled Pork Chop was always a hit for me. 

   Service was always good for me when I visit. Sitting at the bar is my favorite table!
author: Manda Bear B.

description: In town on business and walked to Marlowe due to the Yelp reviews. I wasn't disappointed. I ate at the bar, had the bone marrow and French fries. I almost wish I'd ordered more bone marrow. It was outstanding, a perfect light dinner. Highly recommended.
author: J W.

description:
Love the ambiance but the menu was very limited and nothing special. Out of the duck lover mousse, Brussels sprout chips, burrata and the burger, the burrata was by far the best! Cocktails seemed pre-made in batch and, again, nothing special and not worth the hype or money. 

If you decide to go, bring your hopes down and get the burrata.
author: Moriah M.

description:
I did lunch/dinner (linner?) here with my girls. The setup inside was so cute. Loved it. The drinks here are amazing too but a bit pricey. I had the Baker and two of my friends had the Baker's Wife. The Baker's Wife was a bit sweeter but they both tasted amazing and were quite strong. 

They only had a bar menu at the time we went (4pm). The only real 'meal' they had on the bar menu was the Burger + Fries for $16. So we had four cheeseburgers and we also tried the Brussel Sprouts. Everything was tasty and our tummies were satisfied in the end.
author: Andrea V.

description:
EATING GOOD ON A BUDGET

This is a French inspired American Bistro with modern butcher shop decor, which I might add is slightly confusing as Marlowe is not a steakhouse.

Apparently Marlowe is known to have the best burgers in SF and you have to try the signature baked oysters, both of which I did not try.   I was still impressed with my meal.   I had the seared scallops, my friend ordered a steak, and we shared bone marrow.  I think their menu changes from time to time because this is a late review and the scallops are no longer on the menu.

I want to highlight how amazing the service is here.  Top notch.  Five stars.  Two thumbs and two toes UP!

Imagine talking to a really incompetent person.  "Huh?"  "What?"  "Uhhhhh?"  I was the incompetent person.  It was 5 pm, I hadn't eaten much all day, partied all night, drank too much, and just finished a 12 mile hike.  How could this guy on the phone stay so patient with me?  He even told me that if I got to the restaurant in 45 minutes, there would be a table ready for me (he observed a couple receiving their main entree).

Reservations are required because this place is teeny tiny, accommodating maybe 40 people max (this is just a guestimate).
author: Jannis W.

description: Was visit SF and it was the delicious meal I was searching for my whole stay. Everything was fresh, interesting, a little salty but soooo good. Good service too :)
author: Che F.

description: Service is so underrated. The evening started off somewhat disastrously but the team at Marlowe went above and beyond to revert a snafu that we'd encountered earlier. It's evident that the team here really cares about the quality of service. It helped that the burger was absolutely delicious. We'll be back soon.
author: Anand I.

description:
Meh! Slow service. Mediocre food that wasn't really special. I'm sad that this place is over hyped for what it is. Maybe if I didn't have such a high expectation walking in it would've been better. 

Overpriced, over dressed bar food is what it really is. I'm not sure what everyone likes about this when there are so many great places to dine at in the area.
author: Mike N.

description:
We went for dinner, and the food was wonderful. However, above all, the service was absolutely amazing. All of the staff were extremely attentive and handled everything in a very timely fashion. Regarding the atmosphere: it was very chic and "SF hipster". Would be a great place to host a private event as the space is small enough to feel intimate, but isn't so small that there isn't any space to move.

Regarding the food, the Smoked Crab and Rock Shrimp Poppers are delicious.

Overall, would recommend!
author: Emily X.

description:
Marlowe is AMAZING!! From amazing food, great service, and good atmosphere, it's definitely 5 star worthy and a must visit in SF. And it's affordable! I'm so glad my friend Priscilla W. took me here. 

1) DEVILED EGG - 5 stars - $2.50 for half an egg, but trust me, it is WORTH IT! Burst of extreme goodness in one bite

2) BAKED OYSTER - 5 stars - creamy, rich, crunch, topped with bacon, amazing

3) STEAK TARTARE - 4.5 stars - ahh, this dish with crostini was made to perfection as well. 

4) BONE MARROW - 4 stars - this was my first time having bone marrow so I can't compare anywhere else, but these were delicious and my friends believed it to be better than most places. I thought the crostini in this dish was a little burnt that overpowered the bone marrow though, but it was still good

5) BRUSSEL SPROUT CHIPS - 4 stars - interesting! if you are a brussel sprout lover, you will love this.  I will say this is probably the best tasting brussel sprouts I've ever had. 

6) MARLOWE BURGER - 3.5 stars - they say burger is what people think of when they hear "Marlowe."  The burger was good, but definitely not the best dish we had this night.  Meat was tender.  

OVERALL: We were very happy with every dish.  With 3 girls sharing 6 plates, it only came to $29 a person!! Wow, for the quality of food, this was a steal.  I'm so happy and impressed.  Marlowe it won't be the last time I'll be seeing you!
author: Raquel Y.

description:
Service was great. But not the host. 
Not enough space to move around the table.
Food wasn't great. This is the second time I visited. Burrata was hard to eat. Pork chops were good. But it was just too much meet and the veggies were very bitter. Brussels chips were good but the amount was a joke for a group of three. That should tell us to order more. 

And not food related. 

The neighborhood is shady. Stay safe. 
Someone broke into my car just few steps away from the front door of Marlow.   

I'm not going back.
author: Jo G.

description:
We came in for Saturday lunch! We weren't very hungry so we ordered a light lunch. We had the brussel sprout chips, deviled eggs, and shared a marlow burger and fries! Everything was really good. The brussel sprout chips and the deviled eggs were especially flavorful! I would order those again. The marlow burger was good but nothing special. 

The restaurant is pretty small. It has a nice bar and interior. The service was good but the food took some time.
author: Eunice L.

description:
Marlowe had been on my list of restaurants to try but never planned ahead enough to get a reservation here on the wkends. Passed by it today and decided to get lunch here. Wait was very reasonable and short - about 20 min. We had requested 1st available. When the text arrived that our table was ready. we were shown to 2 seats at the bar. This was fine but as there were several other tables available, I asked if we could take one of those instead and she stated that they were already reserved for other people (although she had earlier stated that the tables by the bar were first come first serve). Not a great 1st impression but the bar was also a nice environment. The wines are priced a bit on the high end for their quality but we settled on a sauv blanc and pinor noir rose. 

I have had the pleasure of enjoying a burger at Park Tavern (their sister restaurant in north beach?) and it was so amazing that I could have licked the plate! So of course, I decided to order the Marlowe burger here as well. Unfortunately, this was a big disappointment. The bread was hard-ish, greasy and not fresh. I asked for dressing on the side but my entire side salad was drenched in it. The burger at Marlowe was unrecognizable compared to the Park Tavern counterpart :( 

~$70 lunch for 2 without tip (2 glasses of wine, 2 sandwiches, 1 side). I expected better for this price point. Not convinced that I'll be back despite its good reputation.
author: Yin H.

description: LOVE this place! A little pricy but the food, atmosphere  and cocktails were amazing. Upscale/casual for any occasion. Great special on Sunday night for burgers and a glass Boudreaux  wine!
author: Tatiana M.

description:
I didn't notice anything special that would bring me back.  I went here on a Saturday night and it wasn't too busy.  The food was OK.

My boyfriend took me here for my birthday and we were planning to have a fun night, but our server seemed like she didn't like her job or anything else and it kind of ruined the tone of our dinner.
author: Sarah S.

description: We went here for a quick dinner and had a great time. They forgot our appetizer, but made up for it by bringing out a free dessert for us. The pork chop and brown buttered brussel sprouts. The brussel sprout were incredible.
author: Lyndy W.

description:
We had an open table reservation, but they couldn't find it, and we had to wait. Even though we had it on our phone which clearly stated we had a reservation.
Then we placed our order the waitress didn't write anything down, since she was trying to memorize everything. Which would have been great if she actually remembered. 

We had to repeat our order twice.

Then she forgot the brussel sprouts, and asked me what was missing? Third time repeating our order.

The oyster was very salty due to the bread thing on it, and the duck liver toast was very bland. It tasted like pate out of a can (the one with the Devil one it). When I asked my friend about her burger, she said the bun tasted "stale." Then she just ate the meat. I felt really bad because we were debating between Marlowe and La Fusion, and I told her that this had great ratings. Now, I looked like a fool because the service and the food were a major disappointment.

The brussel sprouts arrived way after dinner was over, and we ordered desserts, mine for here, her's to-go.

The waitress, again did not writing anything down, but this time it should be easy right? She forgets once again!

She comes back and asks if we're having all our desserts here. Ugh....so sad.

And the worse part is every time we had a meal change and they took away our silverware, they never replaced it, so we had to ask and wait. Same with the water which took forever to flag someone down.

And when I asked the waitress for water, she gave me a little attitude, then waited for the busboy to get the water.

Even the bone marrow that I was looking forward to was a let down. Small, overly salted, and just not really flavorful.

Just a note to Marlowe: If you're going to remember orders (I was a waiter in college so I should know), it's best to remember it off the bat and not ask customers to repeat their order. Glasses should always be refilled without having to ask, same with replacing the silverware.

The worse part was that OpenTable then sent us an e-mail saying we were no shows, and we had to contest it. Wow Marlowe, really? You lose our reservation. Make us wait for a table. Give us poor service, and mediocre food. Then we have to dispute our visit with Open Table too? 

Wow, how crazy is that?
author: Jack R.

description:
Not sure what I can say that hasn't already been said. However, what I appreciate about restaurant reviews on yelp is when people tell me what to order...so here goes...

Must get: brussel sprout chips + egg salad sandwich.

The service was good, not super duper. The location sometimes difficult for parking if you come in your car. 

Get a reservation!
author: Amy O.

description:
Solid 3 stars. Here's why...
1. Service-attentive but not overbearing 
2. Grilled shrimp. I felt this was the best thing we had. Good flavor but a few of the shrimps were over cooked.
3. Bone marrow-good flavor but the pairing with the capers did mask the delicate flavor of the marrow. Capers should be excluded.
4. Steak-well cooked but the charring was a bit bitter. 
5. Scallops-well cooked but overloaded with beans. It made the dish too starchy. 
6. Strawberry shortcake. Very disappointing. The biscuit was really dry and underdressed with very few strawberries but overloaded with whipped cream. Could have used more strawberry sauce and some garnish of fresh strawberries.
author: Mai C.

description: My guy bestie and I came by Marlowe last weekend for brunch and anytime you can make rezzies for lunch is an A++ for me! I don't wait in lines, I'm not about that foodie life. So here I stroll right on in with our table ready for us! Another plus, you don't have to wait until your whole party is here to be seated which is always great. There were a bunch of people seated and waiting for their friends to arrive. I had the doughnuts and the bacon and 1 deviled eggs and my friend ordered the eggs Benedict over a crab cake I believe and two deviled eggs. Deviled eggs came at $3 a pop which is pricey and it's good but I can't justify spending another $3 on just good. The bacon was a thick cut of meat! Oh man, it was juicy with all the fats seeping from it, yum yum yum! The doughnuts didn't have filling which I thought it did but it was still delicious with the jam they provided! My friend thoroughly enjoyed the benedict. I then ordered another benedict to go for my bf that was home sleeping and for the check as well. We get the check with a paper bag with 1 deviled egg inside and I thought oh man that's so nice of them to give us a free deviled egg! We sit and wait for the check and my benedict to go and when we get the check my friend said, hey they didn't charge your benedict to go on this receipt. I take a look and realized they charged us for the deviled egg and then I realized that the waitress must of heard deviled egg instead of eggs benedict lol I waved down another waitress (I love that this establishment lets all waitresses serve each other's tables, makes things so easy). She apologized and said we can keep the deviled egg and she will remove it from the bill and bring us one with eggs benedict. When she came back with the benedict she also included a little box of the peanut butter chocolate crunchies or whatever which was awesome because I wanted to try them anyways! Such great service and the staff we all very friendly and ON TOP OF IT! Will definitely be back as it was such a great experience and delicious bites!
author: Yvonne L.

description:
Marlowe offers up amazing food, with a side of amazing service.

Did I mention? The food was AMAZING. We ordered a bunch of appetizers to share and a Marlowe Burger. Our server (also the bartender) told us what order our stuff would come out in; turns out everything we ordered roughly equated to a three-course meal. He even split up items like the soup so we could both gluttonously dive in without worrying about our dining partner's share.

We thoroughly enjoyed everything we ordered: Warm Deviled Eggs, Baked Oysters, Roasted Bone Marrow, and the Marlowe Burger. The Marlowe Burger deserves a special shout-out for being one of the most amazing burgers I've ever had. And it was also cooked exactly as I requested. It's really amazing biting into a burger cooked rare! So, so, so juicy!
