Dessert impressed as well. The Upside Down Strawberry Crisp and the TCHO Chocolate Cream Pie closed out a wonderful meal. 

My dining partner and I were sitting at the end of the bar. A friend joined us halfway through our meal. I was worried we were going to get hassled for blocking the passage between the dining hall and the kitchen. Instead, we found the staff offering us another stool for the friend to sit next to us.
author: Mark C.

description: Ended up here with the husband for a date night. The ambiance is fantastic- perfect mix of rustic and French and romantic! Food was pretty good but a few points of critique - ordered the burrata and figs appetizer which was even better than I thought! Then had the poulet for my main course which was cooked well but definitely too salty. Decided to splurge for dessert and ordered the chocolate cream pie which was quite good but definitely not pie - just a cup of mousse! Overall pleased with the romantic date night vibe and fairly good good -- just a bit of room for improvement!
author: Martha E.

description:
It was a very busy and crowded Tuesday night, but that just creates more energy. The hostesses handled the situation with friendliness and efficiency. (I was a bit worried about being able to get out of my seat and then past the seats at the bar, because it was so tight and I ate so, so much.)

The brussel sprout chips, little gem salad, ribeye, burger,  and baked cauliflower were too much for the two of us to share (no surprise there....a ton of food), so we didn't really end up eating the cauliflower, which was more of an au gratin. We loved all but the little gem salad, which was one of the prettiest salads I have ever seen...but the dressing had a flavor neither of us enjoyed...less citrus and more of a non-specific seafood taste. Not sure what that was about. I finished mine. My dining companion passed on hers after a few bites.

The issue the evening we were there: our server. He finally approached our table after at least a ten minute wait to be even acknowledged --as he dealt with tables within 18 inches of us on the right and left. And when he finally decided he would come to serve us, he approached the table and said, "Are you ready?" without a smile,questioning whether we'd like a cocktail, etc. I just stared at him, I was so taken aback. I let him know we'd like to order drinks, he took our orders and left. 10-15 minutes went by and we finally got them. He then took our dinner order. And we waited. And waited. And waited....while the couple who came in 20 minutes after we did were served all of their courses. He nonchalantly came over and we had to ask about our dishes. He was unapologetic, never smiled...just unbelievable. Said he'd check on them and seemed perturbed with us. It has been a very long time since I had such lackluster attention or such a bad attitude. I said to my guest that maybe he was just having a bad day, and gave him 20% anyway, but I definitely got the feeling that Ernesto had sized us up and thought two women were not going to order much....or tip much. This is a feeling I have not had in years, dining all over the world. It's the only way I can sum up how we were treated. 
I know Marlowe is not suffering from a lack of business, but I also know you don't want customers leaving with the feeling that they are a bother, rather than appreciated diners who order cocktails, 5 dishes and tip 20%. We are friendly people. It was not a pleasant experience. And I am hoping it was just a bad day. We all have them. I'll leave it at that.
author: Maribeth S.

description:
Absolutely incredible service! Came for evening meal with a party of six.
We had requested the outdoor area but unfortunately our reservations had a mix up and they could only cater us inside on a shared table with another party, we didn't mind too much. 
The food was delicious! 
I just had a devilled egg as a appetiser and the steak for main. The steak is totally worth the $39! Perfectly cooked and delicious sides! 
This is a great place for either groups or a romantic night out. 
Will be back to try the brunch menu!
author: Christine S.

description:
There's a stacked bar at the back of the place which has almost all the spirits you can ask for.  It's got a minimalist layout that's very open.

Got lunch here.  Recommend the fried chicken sandwich with fries on the side.

The ginger beer is great on a hot day , really refreshing but maybe get it without ice.

The Marlowe burger is also pretty good but more subtle flavor.

Also, I'm a fan of small/limited lunch menus.
author: Rajat S.

description:
Marlowe is on the corner of 4th and Brannan (the center of construction hell and traffic). However, I was able to find parking at a lot a couple blocks down and walked in without a reservation to a 30 minute wait around 7-8pm. You're also welcome to grab a drink at the bar while you wait. If you're not looking for the noise and cramped spaces, opt to sit in the back room/patio. They have a little garden in the back and it's much quieter. 

For food, I had the baked oyster from the "Bites" section, and Roasted Bone Marrow from the "Starters" section. I really enjoyed the baked oyster. It was hot and fresh off the grill. The bone marrow was good too, but especially with the sauce and little toasted bread that came with it. I also shared the Marlowe burger (they're willing to cut in half for you) and it was well-seasoned and exactly how I imagined it to taste. Overall, everything wasn't amazing, but it was still pretty good.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Talk about long overdue.  

The months it took me to finally finish/post this review was bad enough, but they pale in comparison to the number of years it took me to finally experience the awesomeness that is Marlowe.  What's even worse is that I have no one else to blame but me!  Man, I'm such a jerk to myself sometimes.  Especially considering how Marlowe is now one of my favorite restaurants in SF!

Between the friendly workers and fantastic vibe (love the look/décor), there was plenty to like even before our meal started.  Going through the menu though, there was even more.  Everything sounded fantastic!  And as what usually happens when Jenny K. and I have our reunion dinners, we (happily) ordered a ton.

-- WARM DEVILED EGG with Aged Provolone, Pickled Jalapeno, and Bacon...$2 each
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=RW0Vyzd4hcwgBYuNrgbEMA#CRd9s-LD9bOvKeWRDdVSLg)
I've had some great Deviled Eggs, but Marlowe's is the best thus far.  The cheese, the jalapeno, the bacon...it was so delicious, we got a second order as soon as we finished our first.  That should be reason enough for you to try.

-- CRISPY BRUSSELS SPROUT CHIPS with Lemon and Sea Salt...$8
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=RW0Vyzd4hcwgBYuNrgbEMA#owr-IPwg81PzOVuWs8BiKw)
This wasn't one of my must tries, but I'm glad Jenny got it.  Each leaf was perfectly crisped and tasted amazing!  A close second for "favorite of the night" and a must get!

-- STEAK TARTARE with Poached Egg, Arugula, and Crostini...$14
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=RW0Vyzd4hcwgBYuNrgbEMA#ftHd39p3fR6OpPPxedkE_g)
Steak tartare has never appealed to me (it's raw beef and I worry about food safety) and I'm not sure if I'll ever be a fan, but this one wasn't bad.  Especially with the arugula.  I let Jenny have most of it, but I would trust getting Marlowe's again.

-- DI STEFANO BURRATA with Spicy Broccoli Rabe Pesto, Marinated Artichoke Puree, Wild Arugula, and Grilled Levain...$14
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=RW0Vyzd4hcwgBYuNrgbEMA#tfMNo_wnyApuAD4BVnwq6Q)
I worried the burrata was over seasoned, but it was terrific!  Then again, how could it not be?  The burrata alone made the dish a success, so the broccoli rabe and artichoke puree were like a bonus.

-- ROASTED BONE MARROW with Salsa Verde and Fine Herbs...$12
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=RW0Vyzd4hcwgBYuNrgbEMA#0rp4kmUa0BAP8kI83vWSug)
So, so good!  The serving size was pretty solid, with both bones had plenty of yield.  Even though it was a little heavy on herbs, the marrow's luscious, buttery flavor still shined through.

-- MARLOWE BURGER with Caramelized Onions, Cheddar, Bacon, Horseradish Aioli, and Fries...$14
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=RW0Vyzd4hcwgBYuNrgbEMA#XLnQsvgQjigk6c6vSO632g)
Ironically, the dish I was most excited for was also the least impressive (though still pretty decent).  The biggest culprit for me was how thick and bready the bun was, but the fact the patty was a little overcooked didn't help.  However, the taste still wasn't bad (the condiments meshed really well) and the fries were great.

-- VANILLA BEAN PANNA COTTA AFFOGATO with Amaretto and Lemon Biscotti...$8
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=RW0Vyzd4hcwgBYuNrgbEMA#JTN4LwVMMPydomCpFj5wCw)
I really liked how balanced it was.  Each bite starts a little bitter and finishes a little sweet without going too far in either direction.  The biscotti cookies were a great complement as well, though they took it away before I could finish mine.

With a location right across from the CalTrain station (and mere blocks from AT&T), Marlowe is super convenient to get to.  Parking is pretty ample as well, but make sure to check the parking signs.  Parking limitations/hours run longer in the area and meter rates are more expensive on game days.

Also, since it's somewhat small, reservations are recommended.  However, unlike State Bird (my other favorite SF restaurant), you won't have to plot out months in advance on when to come.  Though it still might be worth it even if you did.
author: Mike L.

description:
3.5

Cute, workman chic ambiance and exceptionally peppy waitstaff. Their lunch men consists of several soups, salads and sandwiches so it is a great place to go with a group.

The brussel sprout chips were a table crowd pleaser and I highly recommend that you order one for your table. Crispy, salty, flaky goodness awaits your palette. Don't miss out!

I had the Little Gem Salad and a baked oyster for my entree and was not as impressed. The salad dressing was very acidic tasting (and I'm a girl who loves her citrus) and there was almost zero avocado in my veggie mix. I was seriously looking to my daily dose of fats and oils so this salad definitely left me wanting more.

The baked oyster's presentation was phenomenal but at the end of the day it was just too salty for my taste. 

Next time, I'm getting a sandwich!
author: Kimberly S.

description: The ambiance, the fried chicken sandwich, the innovative drinks. I love everything about Marlowe besides how hard it is to get a reservation for more than two people. Also - avoid the oysters, they're so pricey and will add onto your bill fast. Plus, there's better oysters in the city.
author: Ellie J.

description: The servers were extremely nice!! We came here on New Years Day and though it was busy, we still got excellent service. Prices are pretty high but understandable because of the overhead for businesses in SF. I had the polenta. It was very good! However I felt that there was more greens than anything. Not exactly a bad thing, but I like a hearty meal on weekend mornings. That being said, it was delicious! Also a great selection of drinks!
author: Christina B.

description:
Came here to try the bone marrow and Brussel sprout chips for a date night with the BF. 
The decorations were cute with strung up lights outside and it was semi lit making it pretty. We got reservations quite easily two days in advance and was quite packed when we got there around 7. Tables are packed right next to each other so it could be a little awkward when trying to get up. Service was outstanding for us. 

My favorite thing on the menu was the Brussel sprouts chips and the coffee ice cream. The chips is definitely something you can make with a baking pan, salt+pepper & lemon twists but it wasn't outrageously priced. They were crispy but not burnt. The coffee ice cream was just Amazing with a marzipan(??) cookie at the bottom. Portion was perfect for two. 

The waited bone marrow was interesting, but mostly just fatty tasting. They had tiny crackers and a interesting tangy sauce. It was novel, but I suppose it wasn't something my taste buds loved. 

The entrees on the other hand were a little disappointing. The steak was in soy sauce and the steak wasn't dry and cooked just right but didn't have any flavor. The green beans were drenched in the soy sauce making it on the salty side. The burger was a normal and uninteresting burger that in my opinion needed some sauce cause it seemed dry. 

End note: go for the snacks and appetizers! I didn't order any drinks but I was watching the bartender and the drinks looked yummy.
author: Maybo H.

description: Great food, great drinks (even non-alcoholic!), and a cool environment. Been here a few times now, and always have a good experience. Waiters are very professional and give good recommendations. They always have a vegetarian entree that is good, too. My husband loves the burger.
author: Helen W.

description: Ordered the burger which had been recommended; when it arrived it had lettuce, cheese, bacon, none of which I can eat.  I shared these with my husband, who was happy to have these extras on his burger.  Since this left me with meat and bun, I requested tomato and onion from the server.  He said, "We aren't allowed to do that.  The Chef feels that the burger is her INTELLECTUAL property, and doesn't allow any changes to her creation."!!!  I've never heard anything so pretentious.  We spoke with the manager who gave us a longer version of the intellectual property BS.  Her tone was condescending; as if we didn't understand how precious their burgers were.  She later comped the burgers.  The only saving grace for the evening was the server.  He came back and invited us to join them for brunch where he said the burgers included tomato!
author: Tamra-Shae O.

description: Good environment, fresh and stylish food! The only thing I might say is that the portion is not that big for a brunch.
author: Allison C.

description: Good food, but very expensive. The service was good, portions were small. The Crab was excellent.
author: Ali A.

description: What a lucky day! We started out late, everything had a 2 hr wait, but marlowe host was willing to squeeze us at the bar or communal table, when we spoke to him on the phone. Got there, he got us a real table, our hostess was really sweet - brussel sprout chips weren't on the menu, but she said she'd have them make'em anyhow. SCORE! E got the butcher drink, their twist on a bloody mary; we got the chips and a deviled egg each; then split the burger and crispy chicken sandwich. EVERYTHING WAS OUTSTANDING!!! we were left so impressed. Never ran out of water, either! Great attention, amazing flavor explosions and very cute spot! Oh! Even got lucky with parking on the first try! Double score!
author: Tatiana P.

description: I stayed up until midnight to make reservations on-line for Valentines Day. I was excited to secure a table, only to have them call back and tell me that it was going to be a pre-fixed menu for $85 per person. So, that's $170 plus tip ($34) for a total of $204 to not have the ability to chose your own food. It really is shame that places do this. I'm sure Marlowe makes gobs and gobs of money, catering to the 1%ers, so it won't matter to them. Just another example of how San Francisco is doing wonders to push-out the middle class.
author: Mark N.

description: This place was packed on a Thursday night! We worried that the crowd would mean slow service but were pleasantly surprised by the responsiveness of all the staff. Drinks were uniquely crafted and quite delicious. The beer-battered beans were good but I would probably opt for a different starter next time. The entrees--ribeye and fish--were full of flavor. The timing of food and drinks was superb. We were very impressed with our first visit and will definitely be back!
author: R P.

description: As bougie as South Beach feels, it suffers a dearth of dinning establishments outside of the Michelin 3* tier. Marlowe fills this gap, and serves as my neighborhood favorite. Whether I grab a burger for a simple lunch or the chicken for an elevated dinner, Marlowe is always a great time. The polenta and the Brussels sprouts are the other dishes not to miss.
author: Geoffrey Y.

description: Interesting atmosphere.  Good for less intimate dinners. Fairly noisy. Wait staff is welcoming and attentive. The menu is creative - but nothing was noteworthy. Everything was average or below. I had the burger - it was tasteless and dry. Some others had the pork. It looked really good - but ultimately tasteless.  Same for starters. Great expectations - but disappointing.
author: Patrick A.

description:
Came here on a whim with my mom
We came with no reseys but we were sat pretty quickly
The service, food, and ambiance was great!
The only negative i have is the fact that the tables are extremely close together! There really is no room to move freely and your neighbor is within a foot of your table. 
Other than that I would love to come back for the bone marrow! lol
author: Natasha I.

description:
I never, ever leave poor ratings, but I love good food and was sooo not impressed with this place. The decor and service is great, as well as the tartar, but you're not going to convince me this is the "greatest burger in the bay" when  serviced a cold bun with my burger. Just threw off the entire thing. 

I was recommended the pork chop, which was pretty good, but nothing I'd brag about. The dish had 20+ plus whole tiny peppers on it (not exaggerating) which caused my S.O. to immediately come home and yak is brains out. He shouldn't have eaten 10 of them, but I didn't eat a single one, and I'm sitting here pretty uncomfortable. Not worth it.
author: Nicole M.

description:
Cute little bistro. I'm not necessarily a bench seating/picnic table kinda gal, but that's because I wear mostly dresses and I'm definitely going to end up flashing someone trying to sit down! Plus, in the middle of the table was a huge beam that made it difficult to talk to the person across from you. Just weird design. But seating aside, it was an enjoyable experience. 

The first thing that spoke to me was the BBQ lamb sandwich and it did NOT disappoint. It was delicious and the BBQ sauce was tangy and plentiful. To the point were it definitely dripped out the bottom and just narrowly missed my lap!

I was also excited about the crispy Brussels sprouts and they were incredible! I don't even want to think about how much olive oil was on it, but who cares, it was delish!

The fries were just okay, bordering on mediocre. The waitress really talked them up, so I was expecting greatness. But they weren't as crispy as I like and were kind bland. But the horseradish aioli was amazing, as expected! Just could have used more! Came in a small dish... I enjoy gallons of sauce!

So moral of the story is, get the side salad like you'd planned, those lost calories on the fries weren't worth it! And make sure you double up on napkins for the sammich!
author: Rachel C.

description:
If I looked up the definition of New American or Brasseries, Marlowe's photo would fittingly sit next to the dictionary definition. Marlowe is the epitome of a New American, Brasseries restaurant. Trend-ayyyye. 

Menu: You got your fancy schmancy brussel sprouts (can't be New American without those), your petite salads, and some sammies (yeah, don't that colloquial terminology or you will probably get an eye roll) with deliciously seasoned thinnish cut fries. The typical selection of wines and alcohol of course far outnumber actual menu items. The only awkward food that doesn't seem to fit is the shrimp LOL. But, don't worry, even that fits because your shrimp will be in a crepe or sandwich. 

Food: Well, like these types of restaurants typically - very fresh food, flavorful, fancy (the three f's), but not too much of it. I ordered the Little Gem Salad (because I am such a little gem). 

Atmosphere/Service: Trendy. I actually passed this place a hundred times over several years and finally just got here. I definitely remembered it because it certainly has that attitude of a place you go for a work lunch (yes, I went here for a work lunch...surprise!). The place isn't too large, and reservations are recommended as it seems to be constantly busy. As with the usual American (New), the service was extremely polite and there was frequent refilling of water glasses.

Basically, the above is the definition of American (New) and Brasseries. Trendy, attentive service,  and the three f's of food (fresh, flavorful, fancy). Can someone transfer this review to the dictionary for those unfamiliar with American (New).
author: Libby J.

description:
Service: Friendly, but seemed a little overwhelmed at times due to the place filling up quickly. 
Atmosphere: It got crowded quickly around midday for people coming in for lunches or late breakfasts. The restaurant was full, but it was roomie, there was plenty of booth space and it never got too loud.
Drink: I had water... Though they had a full bar and specialty cocktails for the day or night.
Food: The eggs were done perfectly and to my asking and I shared the Toy Soldier French Toast. You must get the French toast and even have it for yourself as a main dish if you wish. I would recommend sharing it with the table so you could all enjoy a piece. Most things brought out of the kitchen looked good and were eaten quickly across all of the tables. 
Overall: For brunch/lunch this is a great spot and a pretty good value. It can accommodate groups and it offers various types of food for all sorts of palates. All were happy after a visit here.
author: George S.

description:
One of my new favorite restaurants. I wanted to try this place on NYE, but they only had a prixe fix menu that night and they were out of reservations anyway. My boyfriend made reservations for Valentines Day weekend about a month in advance (although I'm sure you don't need to make them THAT early! We made sure not to book it on V-day so we didn't have to do a prixe fix. But I see why you need reservations...the restaurant is TINY! It gets kind of packed, but the dim-lit ambiance is pretty nice. I didn't actually see a restaurant sign outside but it's right across the Caltrain station and you can see all the quotes decorating the window panes outside.

APPETIZERS:
Warm Deviled Eggs (with aged provolone, jalapeno, bacon) --these were quite delicious, but at $2.50 for a small half of an egg, I may not order too much of these.

Crispy Brussel Sprout Chips( ($9)--so. bomb. I need to make these somehow. Seasoned with lemon, olive oil, and sea salt. WANT. MORE.

ENTREES:
Grilled Niman Pork Chops ($27) --wow, I never knew pork chops could be so succulent and juicy and savory. Loved the grilled taste and sauces coating the pork chops, and the portion of this was actually HUGE. Over a bed of sauteed spinach and several pieces of maple roasted apples on the side, along with Morcilla sausage (spanish blood sausage). The sausage was interesting...I didnt know what it was when I first saw it but you could def taste the fatty savory meat flavors and it just crumbled in your mouth. There was also a square slice of "pumpkin pudding"...more like an eggy pumpkin bread. The whole dish was great...good pairing of flavors, nicely done and so worth it.

Seared Cod ($26)--cod was cooked nicely with crisp top but soft inside in a lentil/white wine sauce with grilled leeks and calamari on the side. This dish was a lot smaller than the pork chops though and I would definitely order the pork chops over this again. My bf quickly realized I wasn't going to finish my pork chop dish and was relieved because the cod dish was so much smaller in portion size for him...haha =P

DESSERT
Upside Down Strawberry Crisp ($8) --what a simple yet heavenly combination of crumbly brown sugar/oatmeal/graham cracker cookie over bourbon ice cream drizzled with brown butter caramel sauce and topped with fresh diced strawberries. SO. GOOD. Perfect way to end the meal!

Not a huge menu but the food is all cooked wonderfully and I would come back even to eat the same stuff all over again! Maybe try some specials... =) Thanks for a great Valentines weekend meal, Marlowe! 

P.S. Parking is validated at Safeway for 90 min if you buy something. There's metered street parking more so in the streets behind Townsend. I think we found one just behind the building in front of some apartments for 25 cents an hour.
author: Jasmine C.

description:
First of all.... Service is on point. Our server (sorry I forgot her name), was super friendly, made us feel right at home, and she made an awesome recommendation with the pear cider. It was fruity, bubbly and you could barely taste the alcohol in it until your face starts to feel warm.... Oopsie!!

On a side note, she very quickly noticed that I was looking at Yelp for pictures to help me visualize their menu, and I definitely appreciated her offering to answer my questions and her recommendations in lieu of me staring too hard at my phone. Lol! I felt like I could depend on her for menu making decisions as she explained in detail what and how everything was prepared. I didn't mean to be a royal pain in the you-know-what... But I was so excited to finally try Marlowe!!

Second of all, every dish served was excellent. It's rare I think for anyone to have an excellent dish from start to finish and  Marlowe nailed it for me.
We ordered:
Crispy Brussel Sprout Chips: Highly addictive! Perfect with the recommendation of the light pear ale. Yummy!)
Di Stefano Burrata with Vinegared Strawberries: genius combination
Open-faced deviled egg sandwich: Delicious. Totally satisfied my brunch-like craving at the time
Vacherin: it was like a deconstructed sundae on a perfect meringue cookie.

I know, it's already got stellar reviews, but I wanted to add my schpeal on it. I'm definitely looking forward to my next meal there. It will be dinner this time, because they only serve their popular bone marrow at dinner time. I can't wait!!
author: Natalie W.

description: Fabulous!!  We stopped by without a reservation at 9pm on a Saturday, and got lucky to have 2 seats open up at the bar (otherwise would consider a reservation). The staff was super friendly. I had the polenta dish, which was unbelievably good: polenta with mushrooms, arugula, parmesan, a pesto sauce?, poached egg and truffle oil, and it was absolutely fantastic. My husband had the "Marlowe burger" and was raving about it as well. So happy with this cute place!
author: Anne M.

description:
Wanted to try this place since awhile ago but honestly was a bit underwhelmed for the price paid and all the hype. Probably closer to a 3.5 but should seriously be $$$ rather than $$.

-----

English Pea Pancakes ($12): One of my favorite dishes from tonight. The pea flavor was a bit drowned out amongst the other flavors going on, but the spices and smoked salmon worked well together. Overall very tasty. 

Brussel Sprout Chips ($9): Definitely lived up to expectations. Light, crispy, and just right amount of salt and lemon. 

Steak Tartare ($16): Not bad but the seasoning was definitely on the heavy side. It tasted a bit vinegar-y and spicy like Tabasco sauce mixed with mustard, which should be delicious, but not when the food is completely doused with it. Also the poached quail egg on the top is too tiny to taste among the flavors. 

Marlowe Burger ($16): It was good but really, just good. Like the meal, it left me underwhelmed. A bit on the greasy side with the bacon and none of the flavors particularly stood out. 

Rum Soaked Nectarine Split ($10): I honestly could not believe that this is the most expensive dessert. It was literally one modest-sized scoop of vanilla ice cream covered in caramel sauce, a handful of blueberries, and three slices of nectarines. The nectarines weren't even ripe and were instead hard and tasted very sour compared to the sweet ice cream and caramel.

------

The service was very good. Polite, friendly, but not overly intrusive or constantly checking up on you to the point that you can't enjoy the meal. 

Would definitely recommend reservations as the place quickly filled up by 6pm.
author: Megan L.

description: I have been looking forward to visiting Marlowe for a long time, given the glowing reviews and the constant line of eaters waiting to get in. Perhaps this is a case of heightened expectations, but my visit left me befuddled. The burger was cooked to order, but underwhelming in taste. I didn't find the drinks particularly balanced, and the sides of Brussel sprouts and cauliflower "gratin", were acceptable. Just acceptable. The cauliflower was overwhelmed by the cheese, and the Brussels were swimming in a brothy/oily soup mixture. The service level and ambiance were fine, it was the food that left me wanting... less.
author: Mike S.

description: Great experience! The brussel sprout chips and charred octopus salad are must-haves for apps/small plates! I had to order the burger for my entree and it was cooked to perfection, definitely one of the best burgers I have ever had. The service was good, but we came with a large party and were sat in the corner at a communal table and would have preferred to have sat elsewhere, especially since we had made a reservation far in advance. Overall it was a good experience and the food was amazing!
author: Caroline C.

description: I had fried chicken sandwich and this was way too salty. My hubby had pancakes and they were good.
author: EunJoo C.

description:
This restaurant has been bookmarked for a long time for me! Worth the wait!

Must haves: Brussels sprouts and deviled eggs. They just do it much better here than other places.

Entrees:
My husband and I shared the pork chop - they were so nice to split up the meal for us! Good flavor, but not the best pork chop I had. 

The other couple shared the Marlowe burger, they said it was good.

May not get the next time: bone marrow. I think we had a small bone, so not worth it. 

Dessert:
We had the seasonal stone fruit and ice cream - one of the best desserts I've had! 

Service:
Excellent!

Willing to go back again? YES!
author: Mary H.

description: Everything was awesome! Ordered oysters, steak tar tar, Angus beef, borrata, octopus salad and it was all top notch. Wish we tried the polenta too
author: Carole Y.

description:
I had an amazing dinner tonight. It was a short walk from home so it was convenient for a early dinner. There was no wait because we arrived around 5:30 on a Wednesday. 

We began the night with some delicious cocktails! Get the one with Pimms Gin in it and ginger beer, it was delicious. My friend and I weren't super hungry so we decided to share two appetizers. We got the pea pancake with salmon and caviar as well as the burrata and tomato starter. Both were perfect and I am excited to come back and try the bone marrow and famous burger!
author: Vivien H.

description: This chic, slightly out of the way bar and restaurant has a fabulous menu full of surprises, good quality ingredients, and delicious combinations. Great cocktails, nice wine selection, and absolutely professional service in all respects. I loved my pan seared scallops, served with cranberry beans - I asked for bread on the side and they offered me a lovely plate of artisanal toast - special, and the crunch was a welcome addition to the plate. Others raved about the pork chop, Poulet "vert", and the Marlowe burger. The smokey baked cauliflower side was decadent and promptly devoured.  Try their peanut butter pretzel nougats (with a dose of dark chocolate) - nice little poppers to round out your meal.  Marlowe was absolutely the BEST meal I had during my four days in San Fran - highly recommended!
author: Karen K.

description:
Just had brunch and it was really good! 

Came in around 1:30 for a party of 2 with no reservation, and were seated within 2 minutes. 

Ordered the Crab and Shrimp Crepe, their pancakes, and a side of two eggs, with a coffee.


Food was delicious!!!! Will be back.
author: Tootsie R.

description:
I had a Christmas Eve brunch here and had very high expectations after great experiences at sister restaurants Park Tavern and Cavalier.  This was the single worst service experience I have ever had at any restaurant in my entire life.  First, and certainly most forgivable, the metered parking out front had so many warnings and times you could and could not park there I couldn't figure out for the life of me if I could park there on a Sunday morning or not.  I ask the hostess as we walked in if I was good where I parked and she had no idea.  A little odd not to know if your customers can park in the spots right in front of your restaurant, but okay, I moved my car to be safe.  With all the construction around there it took me 10 minutes to get around the block, almost got dropped on the Bay Bridge, it was great.  

When the hostess goes to seat us there's about 3 groups of people for 25 tables and she plops us right next to this couple in a weird corner table where my wife and I literally could not fit both of our legs without resting them against eachother and my wife is 5"1.  And the couple next to us was totally oblivious and the woman had her huge purse right where my wife was supposed to sit and didn't do anything to move it.  Hostess really should have noticed that, but didn't catch it at all.  I stood up and was just like, we need a new spot, that's not working for us.  She moved us to a much better location, great.

Then we get the waitress helping us out who I would best describe as completely hostile.  At one point my wife turned to me and said, I think she wants to tackle me and I have no idea why!  She came up to me about 15 seconds after I sat down from moving my car and asked if I was ready to order my meal, and I said I needed a few more minutes and she was NOT pleased with that response clearly.  So that was also lovely.  

Then we order our food, and in spite of the fact she was clearly taking her life into her own hands by doing so with the aforementioned waitress, my wife asks if she can (gasp!) get no truffled salsa verde on the polenta.  Because honestly why any decent restaurant would taint their food in 2017 with truffle oil, I can't imagine, but okay.  The waitress surprisingly says that will be fine, great!

Food comes out and it just reeks of truffle oil and you can literally see it dripping off the polenta (which by the way was about 3/4 greens which wasn't even in the description, so I would not recommend that dish, egg was cooked perfectly however).  My wife says, ummm, I ordered no truffle oil.  The server, different guy from our beloved waitress, says yeah, there's not truffle oil on there.  My wife points to a dripping piece of spinach and says, I can see it right there dude!  He says, oh, I'll take care of that.  Takes it back, and brings the plate back 3 minutes later like he just completed the Sistine Chapel with his correction to this dish, and it literally still reeks of truffle oil, though to his credit it is no longer dripping off the spinach.  My wife sucks it up and just eats it, fine.  Only later am I haunted by the vision of Horatio Sanz in the 90's comedy Road Trip licking off the unwanted condiments (among other things) and just sending it back out.

Again this is a 16 dollar breakfast dish, they should have re-fired it for sure considering they clearly messed up the order or if you can't do substitutions just say it.  

All is not lost however, the huevos rancheros that I had were incredibly creative and delicious and whoever was cooking the eggs that day was on fire because they were perfectly runny without appearing undercooked.  The bloody mary (they call it something else) was also fantastic, nice and spicy.  And again, this may have been a Christmas Eve debacle on their part, but it was a debacle of epic proportions i must say.  I have not left a really crappy tip in at least 10 years out of spite, but I recalled tipping the cleaning ladies in the hotel $5 and I was like there's no way i'm going higher than that for this level of service.

I will certainly return to the sister restaurants in the near future (I would tolerate just about any form of treatment for a Marlowe Burger), but it just won't ever be at this location again that's for sure.
author: Joshua D.

description:
Dine About Town 2014 review!

I had bookmarked Marlowe back in 2012, so when I saw it listed for DAT, I knew I had to go.

Originally, when I looked at their menu, I didn't think their DAT offerings were that good of a deal. The maximum value of the items was $11 (soup) + $14 (burger or sandwich) = $25, which is pretty darn close to the $19 DAT price. I considered just ordering their famous Marlowe burger on its own because I rarely order soups (can't justify the price for something that I normally consume from a can...). But, I was dining with a friend and didn't want our food to be out of synchronization, so I took a leap of faith that the soup could possibly justify $5.

Cleared the jump, phew!

The DAT 2014 appetizer we opted for was their $11 CAULIFLOWER SOUP with pork lardons, raw oysters, and chives (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=_Q3wfnELKrxcwEifOJc5GA#_Q3wfnELKrxcwEifOJc5GA). According to Wiki, a lardon is a small strip or cube of pork fat used in a wide variety of cuisines to flavor savory foods and salads. AKA cured ham AKA bacon lol. The raw oysters were majorly fresh and tasted very strongly of the sea (The Little Mermaid, anyone?). The soup itself was smooth, creamy, and rich like a chowder. And the dash of paprika was a nice touch.

We both chose the same entree: the famous MARLOWE BURGER with caramelized onions, cheddar, bacon, and horseradish aioli. Normally $14, the burger comes with a side of salad (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=_Q3wfnELKrxcwEifOJc5GA#zpro8C2zB50VIlBEnVXYtA) or a side of Marlowe fries (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=_Q3wfnELKrxcwEifOJc5GA#HTIzNI2Uvk6yiFrxlEUGgg). The Marlowe fries are delightfully crispy but were way too salty. The side salad was very arugula-y, meaning I basically had to force myself to finish it (I have this thing with leafy greens...don't ask about it). At least the bitter salad made the burger that much more delicious.

And delicious the burger was. At first, the bitterness from the horseradish aioli caught me off-guard because I ABHOR horseradish--it's so bitter and overpowering. Fortunately, a good amount of the aioli got squeezed out with my burger drippings, so it wasn't too detrimental to my burger experience.

The ciabatta bun they use is wonderful. It's lightly toasted to a nice crunch, and it's dense enough that it manages to hold the insides together without getting too soggy. Another subtle highlight was the caramelized onions that lent a slightly sweet undertone. I initially didn't even taste the onions until my friend pointed it out to me, probably because my tastebuds were way too fixated on the danged horseradish. The bacon, with its salty crispiness, was awesome as always, and the melted cheddar cheese was so perfect that I can't even put into words how perfectly they melted that cheese onto the patty. And they attempted to squeeze in some veggies by adding a few shreds of lettuce.

However, amidst all these glowing pluses, the rarity of the meat could use some work. As usual, we requested medium-rare, and we just got...medium (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=_Q3wfnELKrxcwEifOJc5GA#VFd79UVW93Kn9Rf1nVqCuA). Hrrrrnnnhhh okay fine. At least it was juicy. So, creds there. Even then, there were 2 charcoal-burnt patty pieces that stood out to me... :(

Since Marlowe is located in east SF, there's some legitly good sunlight pouring through the windows. It has a mix of small tables and communal benches. Service isn't the warmest (though the actual restaurant is warm, temperature-wise; you'll be taking off some layers), but their water refills are prompt. Really prompt.

The portions looked small, but both of us were full and satiated after the meal. We ended up paying $24 each after tax and tip. In my mind, that means that the value of the DAT menu is not having to pay tax and tip. Not bad, but I wouldn't come here exclusively for the DAT offering. The burger itself is worth the visit.

Gawd but srsly, I hate horseradish. Next time I eat here, I'm ordering the burger sans the aioli. Gawd.
author: Adele F.

description:
I made a reservation at Marlowe for a group of 4. The restaurant has a nice date vibe and was packed, even at 10 pm. Break down of our food:

French Fries w/ Aoli: Please please please do not get this. Wow, I was SO disappointed. It tasted like stale McDonalds fries with flavoring. The portion was tiny AND it was $7. 

Deviled Eggs: Due to all the raving reviews, I wanted to try this. Albeit pricey, we figured it was worth it and ordered 2 to split 4 ways. Basically it was a bite each and I expected my bite to be heavenly. Unfortunately it fell totally flat. Basically it's a normal boiled egg with cheese and bacon on top. If the cheese was still hot and melted, it might have tasted better....but by the time it got to the table it was kind of hardened and easily fell off the egg. I was disappointed.

Scallops: My sister and I shared this for our main entree. This is where the redemption started.  The scallops were cooked perfectly and flavors were good. There were only 5 pieces though, so it's not a ton...but then again seafood is just expensive in general. 

Pork Chop: My sister's bf ordered this and he really liked it. I had a piece and the meat was tender and juicy. It was also cooked very well.

New York Strip Steak: My bf ordered this and he really liked. The sauce was good and it came with some delicious green beans and snow peas.

Strawberry Shortcake: Basically a scone with whipped cream and strawberry sauce. Just ok. I don't think I'd order it again.

Overall the main entrees redeemed this place for me, but I would never order the appetizers again. With so much good food in SF, I don't think I'd voluntarily come back unless someone else wanted to eat here.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Some of the BEST deviled eggs I've ever eaten!

The starters are portioned for little fairy princesses...I ordered the pea pancakes thinking it would be enough for a meal but instead got three tiny disks the size of poker chips. 

My friend got the burger and the most remarkable part of it was the sauce for dipping the fries, kind of had some wasabi/horseradish snuck in there.

Maybe we just failed at picking the right dishes?
author: Susan L.

description:
My cousins & I decided to come here to celebrate my bday dinner & we surely were not dissapointed. They were known for their bone marrow, Brussel sprouts & the burger so that's exactly what we ordered plus a salad, champagne, & dessert. Not to mention our service was great even by checking in 20 mins early for our rsvp they immediately sat is down to our table. But be cautious it is very tight & small here.
So for starters we ordered a salad which was okay. From the looks of it, it was a radish peels with some lettuce and an interesting dressing. We also orderee the fried Brussel sprouts which were amazing & tasty! We then ordered the bone marrow which came with slices of bread & a very intriguing spicy sauce. This was my first encounter trying the bone marrow & words cannot explain the taste of all 3 of the combo together! Greatness in one bite! Last but not least we had our entree which was the sensational burger that all my fellow yelpers have been talking about. Cooked to perfection & not to mention the aeoil fries!! 4 happy women with full tummies! Just to add a bonus our great waiter gave us free chocolate covered peanut butter pretzels. One happy customer & belly! I am a fan & will come back!
author: Lisa S.

description:
After reading up on the phenomenal Marlowe burger and fantasizing about how delicious it would taste after my morning workout, I decided to take the plunge this Sunday morning.

Called in my burger to go and decided to be a good girl and get the salad on the side. Summer sacrifices, you know? 

All in all, a pleasant experience, until...

I got there, got the bill, handed over my $20, and the hostess disappeared with my $20 to escort a group to their table. Granted, the burger was $18, and I was planning on leaving the change. But given the type of establishment Marlowe is, I would have expected that the hostess would have acknowledged that she was gonna give me some change since it was a to go order and let me make the decision on whether to tip or not. 

Further, if someone orders a salad with their burger, what are they gonna do, eat the salad with their hands? That's right, folks, there was absolutely no fork, no napkins, nothing but the burger and side salad provided. 

All in all, given that I'm forking over $18 for a burger from a classy joint, I would've expected better quality service.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Marlowe is a great meeting point- it's right across the Caltrain station on Townsend and 4th. The restaurant is a bit small so make sure to make reservations. 
One thing I appreciated about this place is that they were really good about refilling your cup and making sure you had something to drink- whether it was from their wine or beer selection or just water. 
Other than that, I think their food was a bit overpriced for the portion size and quality. I had the Marlowe Burger and it was OK. I feel like I could have eaten two of them- not because it was particularly delicious but because I was still hungry after my meal.
author: Grace L.

description:
We came here at 5pm on a Sunday and they were serving a limited menu.  The full dinner menu starts at 5:30pm.  We ordered:

- Baked Oyster: Oyster baked with cheese and bacon bits. It was good but very small, basically just one bite.
- Little Gem salad: I liked the vinegrette, but the vegetables were a little bitter.  The avocado was very salty.
- Brussel sprout chips: Good, but a bit too salty for my tastes.
- Marlowe burger: Very good burger. Patty was cooked to perfection, and overall tasted good.  The fries were also pretty good.

Overall, I thought the burger was great, but the rest of the dishes were just ok.  Everything is also a bit on the pricey side.
author: Michelle A.

description: The place is gorgeous. Id love to spend time in here taking a ton of snaps :)  Im sad though, that the service makes me uncomfortable. Every time Ive come in, they act like, "what are you doing here?" Strange. 4 staff asked if we'd been helped, yet no one got to the bottom of getting us a seat. ???  (4 customers in the entire place). We got there at 5:15 pm, and they dont start serving dinner until 5:30.....however we were approached every 30 seconds to see if we'd decided on something.  We felt a hard sell. Food was meh, totally. Ambiance is lovely, but not worth returning. So much potential, yet service pretty much kills it.
author: Alisa F.

description:
Marlowe is by far one of the best spots in Soma. It's often crowded for dinner, so I would recommend a reservation if you can get one! For two people its generally not too bad to wait and get a drink at the bar. I also was a huge fan of the pop up Marlowe burger so am sad to see that go, but glad I can still order the delicious burger at Marlowe.

On my last visit I went for brunch. We had a reservation and arrived on time. It took them about 15 minutes to realize we were there which was a little annoying. However, once we got our waitress they quickly made up for it. Started with the bloody mary's and coffee. The bloody mary is on the spicy side! Next shared the deviled eggs which are a must. My friend and I then shared the kale caesar and the smoked salmon. The kale caesar was really great. I enjoyed the smoked salmon and its not something I would usually order but I might try something else next time. Another guest in my party ordered the burger, which he claimed is one of the best burgers he ever had!
author: Tracy S.

description:
Together with my wife and friends we like to check out a new place once a month. "Marlowe" was this months choice. I'll start with how friendly our waiter was....that is to say not at all, he could have been part of the guard at the royal palace, with a never changing, displeased look on his face. He kept coming over to see if my wife was done with her plate of appetizers and when he would find that she was not - he would walk away dissatisfied. We ordered the bone marrow, burgers, salmon with cucumber, roasted cauliflower and a couple more appetizers. Let me start with the bone marrow - it was not cooked through and was just roasted on top, so the texture was completely off. On top of that it was extremely salty  and served with a salty souse and salted greens. Actually that was the theme of the evening - everything was extremely salty. My buddy ordered a well done burger, which was extremely salty by the way, and when he bit in to it he realized the meat was rare. The burger was served with fries and salty horseradish.
I could not stop drinking water for hours after the meal. I have to add that i usually love salty food and add more salt to all of my dishes, but this was just extreme - like they let a child play with the salt shaker.
Oh - and lastly - the prices. Three burgers, five appetizers and three drinks - $200 before tax and tip. Should have went to "In and Out" instead.
Never again!!
author: Clovis L.

description:
I discovered Marlowe on my walk down Brannan between office buildings. I was in need of a late lunch before my evening yoga class.

I love the ambiance here. Lots of white, tile floors, nice bar and beautiful marble countertop. They had a stuffed cow's head on the wall to emphasize their specialty on burgers. They had a great looking cocktail menu as well.

I sat at the bar and ordered right away. I was in the mood for something light but filling. I opted for the gem lettuce salad ($14). PRETTY damn expensive for a salad if you ask me. I asked if I could get meat added.. like shrimp since that was offered on another dish. The bartender turns to the manager and asks if he can add meat to my salad, and she says no... I'm sorry, what? You can't add meat to a salad? I've never heard of that before... She said I could order the shrimp as a side but they couldn't put the shrimp on the salad... That sealed the whole experience for me.

I was pretty disappointed and wasn't impressed by the portion or the quality of the salad. Maybe next time I'll opt for a burger.
author: Norah C.

description:
Finally got around to checking out Marlowe. I called in on a Saturday and they were able to put our names on a list, headed there and our table was ready, I was very pleased!

It's a cute place, lovely for a small group of friends or a date night. The cocktail list was great and The Bull and Country Lawyer were ours favs! 

We decided to get small dishes and glad we made that decision bc they were all delicious! We tried the Brussels sprouts, cheesy cauliflower, and a tapas plate which was a special of the day.

I know they change their menu often so I look forward to going back!
author: Hetal P.

description:
Great ambiance at this place. Went here the last day before they are moving to their new location. The food was great. Started with the Brussels sprouts chips which were excellent! I definitely recommend getting this, because they are addicting and make you wanting more! Ordered the bone marrow too, really good as well! It definitely makes you want to order more! It was cooked to perfection. Also got the steak tartare, good too! All the appetizers were good and would definitely recommend them all! For entree got the burger and pork chop! I thought the pork chop was amazing and it seems people don't order it much here and doesn't get recognized! It's amazing and people should order it! Has such great taste and nice and juicy! As for the burger it was ok but I don't think it's the best burger but it was still good!! 
Overall good food!
author: Shauna f.

description:
Marlowe is my kind of place.  It's intimate, beautifully designed and most importantly, the food is killer.  I like that they offer a bunch of small plates, that range from veggie-centric to seafood-heavy, in addition to the bigger entrée portions.  And because first impressions are important, I was impressed right off the bat when they gave us complimentary champagne for our anniversary.  That's too cute.

We started with the fried okra and warm deviled egg and whoa, both were so good!  I'm a sucker for anything involving okra and these managed to be breaded and fried without losing any of that good okra slime that I love.  We were hesitant about the egg but it ended up being the best we'd ever tasted.

For dinner, we split the pork chop.  I'm usually opposed to splitting meals, but the table next to us had already gotten their entrées and they looked HUGE.  The split portion ended up being the perfect size for both of us.  My only criticism was all the smoky flavors.  My drink was so smoky and something on the pork chop plate was as well.  Maybe I'm just not a fan, but that was not pleasant.
author: Lauren D.

description: Was craving an apple crisp and stumbled upon this place while looking up dessert places. As it turns out, Marlowe is absolutely perfect for happy hour, dinner, or an evening drink (wine or coffee). The atmosphere is wonderful - very cozy but cool at the same time, the service was quick, and the food delicious. Definitely coming back here again with friends and fam!!
author: Kyra S.

description: This place definitely lives up to the hype. It's definitely packed but a great atmosphere for a date. Our waitress Aisha (sorry if that's incorrect- it's super loud in the restaurant) was super duper awesome and Sam is an awesome waitress as well!! Very friendly. Definitely get the Brussels sprout chips . Best thing on the menu. The bone marrow is good and rich, burrata was good and the burger is flavorful. Not a fan of the porkchop. I would highly recommend making reservations before you come here.
author: Heather S.

description: What a cute ambiance!! My girlfriend and I got to sit in their outdoor area, which hardly qualifies as 'outdoors' - it's closed off with an actual wall and is covered, so you can't get in any way but through the actual restaurant. There were adorable succulents and lights everywhere, and the service was great! The waitress even asked me if I liked my drink to see if she could replace it for me when she saw I was sipping slowly. We came for brunch, and we shared donuts and each had fried chicken sandwiches. The donuts were good, and the sandwiches had great flavor even if they were a little too salty. I would definitely come back for the look/feel of the place and the service, because there were a few things on the lunch menu that got my attention!
author: Nina M.

description:
I'd give it 2.5 stars but maybe this, if nothing else, will draw Marlowe's management's attention.

My boyfriend and I went out of our way to find a day to visit Marlowe. We got an early reservation, were among the first five customers for dinner service, and sat and ordered before a group of four, who ordered a few minutes after us.

We ordered the Brussels sprouts and little gem salad and the burger. The first two arrived promptly and were delicious. 

We then waited 35 minutes for our burger. Around us, the party of four each received a burger. the restaurant filled up, at least 15 tables were seated and received food. When, at around 20 minutes, we mentioned it to our server, he said it would be out "soon," and brought out our ketchup. We waited another 15 minutes before it arrived. Not only that, but our server felt the need to say that our burger was "medium," when in fact it was so clearly medium rare that it was pink and bleeding.

It was still delicious, so we ate, and figured we'd speak to the manager about it after the meal. After we paid, my boyfriend approached the host and told him we had a weird experience and waited 35 minutes for our burger. The host apologized, but did not offer to grab the manager. We left.

We wanted to like Marlowe, we really did. The rest of the menu looked good and we were looking forward to returning to try more. But considering our experience and service's apathy about addressing it, we won't be back any time soon.
author: Veronica R.

description:
Came by for a quick bite before the Giants game. The food is good here but I have had the same experience as other diners - for some reason some of the food takes forever. 

I came here a couple of months ago and didn't write a review. I stopped in the bar and ordered a couple of things including some sauteed shrimp. I had 45 minutes to eat then I had to walk to Caltrain to meet my wife. I kept asking the waiter when my shrimp was coming and eventually I paid the full bill and had to leave before the shrimp came out. It wasn't crowded and shrimp only take a minute to cook. 

This time I ordered grilled shrimp. They came (and they were delicious) but they came 20 minutes after the rest of my food.
author: Scott H.

description:
Marlowe is a solid restaurant. It's trendy (think ironic taxidermy on the wall, hipsters under-dressed in shorts, and tourists in wind-breakers) and they obviously think highly of themselves there - it just didn't totally 'do it' for me. My husband and I tried it for a Friday night dinner while passing through San Francisco. 

I started with the Warm Deviled Egg, which was delicious. FYI, the 'bites' section of the menu should be called 'bite', because they are literally one bite. I would have thought a deviled egg would include both halves, but no, it's a deviled half-egg. Next I had the Pan Roasted Sea Bass. It was fine, but not very flavorful. 

My husband had the Roasted Bone Marrow to start. He seemed pleased with the flavor, but, again, a small portion compared to other restaurants where he's ordered bone marrow. He had the grilled pork chop as a main dish. It was good (not great).

For foodies, I would recommend ordering a few appetizers in lieu of an appetizer and entree. The appetizers showed some imagination, while the main course options were obviously 'safe'. 

We were pleased to find a Muga rosé on the menu. We visited the Muga winery in Spain last summer, so that was a nice, nostalgic treat.

The staff was very competent and the food was fine, but I frankly would have expected a little more oomph for the price. We had a nice time, but it's not a place I would seek out again if/when I revisit San Francisco.
author: Rae S.

description:
FOOD:
I went to Marlowe with a group of 8 people and we went late at night on a Saturday so we did not have to wait for a table. Everyone ordered different dishes and all I can remember is the brussel sprouts and the burger. The brussel sprout chips are really crispy and salty and the burger was good. Everything else wasn't that great especially since I don't remember. 

SERVICE:
Staff is awful. We had to flag them down several times to get their attention. You would think that they are more attentive to such a large group-but no. There were several times where we saw our waitress flirting with a customer or spending a lot of time at a different table rather than helping us. We wanted to order more dishes and more drinks but no one helped us.

WOULD I RECOMMEND IT? No.
author: Kelley Y.

description:
It was good but not OHH IT IS THE BEST THING EVER. It was nice to eat near North Beach again and heard this place was good.

Unfortunately, it was after lunch and they only had bar menus available. But we got their burgers and salad, and our server was kind enough to make us custom cherry cokes.

The salads were delicious, light lemony and creamy from the avocado. 

The burgers were the right size and were cooked appropriately. I don't usually eat horseradish but theirs was light. I liked the fries too.

The ambiance was pleasant too, minus the flies buzzing around. 

For the price, it's definitely a once in a while thing, but it did entice me enough to maybe consider it if I'm nearby.
author: Bahar A.

description:
I love the interior of the new location. It's bright and airy! Hex tile floors, Subway tile walls, marble and wood tables, and lots of brushed metal.  Great service and wait staff.

The burger has gotten smaller from the last time I was here, what a shame. The tables are so close to each other, you're practically dining with the table to your left and right. Every time I had to get up, we had to move the table over.  

We were seated promptly for our noon reservation.  This place gets surprisingly crowded on a weekday for lunch, so it's not just dinner that's  impossible.  It started to fill up around 12:15, people were even waiting outside. 

Loud. Very loud. You hear all conversations around you. 

$37 for two burgers and no alcohol. Not including tip.
author: Angelica C.

description:
3.5 stars for lunch.

My intention was to go here for dinner but the Giants game was at 1:05pm so we decided to do lunch instead. The place was somewhat small therefore having a reservation would be ideal. On the other hand, parking was sucky sucky sucky as we all know when coming to SF.

Anyway, we ordered:

- Cauliflower soup = creamy, buttery and full of goodness. Working my belly for some real appetite. 

- Crispy brussels sprout chips = with lemon and sea salt. Absolutely ADDICTING like crack! I even tried to replicate it at home (good, but can't beat Marlowe's way). 

- Warm open faced devil egg sandwich = the sandwich was the size of my fist. It was nothing spectacular. Barely there bacon and the devil egg need some flavoring.

- Duo of Ahi Tuna = this was more like an appetizer than main entree. The ahi tuna was good despite all the junk they put on top of it. Very salty entree I must say. 

I enjoyed their appetizer way better than their main entree, but not impressed with their lunch menu overall.  Maybe I should have waited to try their dinner instead.
author: Owie N.

description:
Review #500 goes out to Marlowe! 

I actually celebrate my birthday with several dinners throughout my birthday month. Marlowe was one of my last bday dinners in Sept. I am sooo glad I picked this place! They seriously do have one of the best burgers I have ever had! More than half the people at our table ordered the burger and everyone raved about it! Sooo juicy and full of beefy goodness! My mouth is watering just thinking about it! And the fries! Crispy but still soft inside. It was the perfect fry!!!

Another must order are the brussel sprouts. Nice and salty and crispy. I couldn't stop eating them!

The bone marrow, baked oysters, deviled eggs, mussels, beef tartare, chicken, etc. All were raved about while we were having dinner. I didn't get to taste everything, but the bone marrow was nice and buttery. The mussels were plump and juicy. And the baked oysters were creamy and delicious!

I came with a group of 8 people. Sometimes it can be hard to please everyone in a group of that size. But everyone was so happy and full after our dinner. And isn't that what you want from a dinner? For everyone to walk away completely satisfied?! Awesome bday dinner!!!
author: Elena N.

description: Everything is delicious. Service is great. Drinks are pricey but worth it. We walk in without reservations half the time and they always find us something at the bar or in a corner. Burger is great, polenta is amazing. I'm always happy to be there and completely satisfied when we leave.
author: Ray K.

description:
Wow.  

Deviled. Eggs.  

I would like to say that their deviled eggs is one of the best I've ever had.  It's warm, it's complex -- the pickled jalapeno and bacon offers a nice wholesome balance of crunch to this otherwise soft, delicate appetizer.  I order a few of these because this goes down so easily, one can binge in such delectableness in seconds.

Aside from the deviled eggs, the the bone marrow and brussel sprout chips are all very tasty.  Their appetizers are some of the best I've come across.  Their burgers, on the other hand, are just mediocre...but then again, you don't come to a place like this for just burgers.  It's their entire collection of appetizers, drinks, mains as a whole that makes this place wonderful.  And it's all a different variety.  If I were to go for a main, I whole-heartedly enjoy their petrale sole because it balances very nicely after some brussel sprouts and deviled eggs.  

Marlowe's variety of simple, balanced dishes in a small, sweet restaurant is truly captivating and delicious for what a small restaurant space can offer.  Oh, and their bar menu options is also quite diverse and extensive.  Try it out!
author: Dararith L.

description:
I loved Marlowe the first time I dined here, but my birthday dinner here was a little disappointing. Last time, I only got appetizers and desserts so I was prepared for the small portions. However, I didn't realize that the main courses were pretty small as well!

Dungeness Crab and Rock Shrimp Crepes ($14): Delicious, but definitely not worth $14 for crepes the size of my finger.

Crispy Brussel Sprout Chips ($9): The chips came in a very small cup. Most of the chips were wilted and soggy.

Warm Ceaser Toast ($8): The ceaser salad was very salty. My stepmom and I couldn't finish eating ours. 

Marlowe Burger ($16): Only thing we ate that felt like we got our money's worth. Everything from the meat to the bun was prepared perfectly. But even then, $16 for a burger so small leaves me wondering...

Chocolate Cream Pie ($9): Smooth, creamy, rich, chocolatey, and salty all in one jar. What's not to love? 

Banana Coconut Walnut Cake ($9): Delicious! And the only thing that was actually big in size! Definitely something to share with one other person.

Overall, the food is good. However, the portion to the price point doesn't add up. Be prepared to leave here hungry.
author: Hana K.

description:
Super nice, hip, and friendly.  We were very late for our reservation, and they were super nice and accommodating.  Granted, it was early, 6pm.  Still, the place was hopping when we arrived and they had saved our table.

Our server was great - professional and friendly.

The drinks were tasty and the food yummo-licious!  Two of had the fish in coconut milk with summer vegetables  The flavors were delicious, but it was the textures of of creamy coconut milk, punctuated by the fave beans, potato and corn that really made the dish special for me.  In retrospect, I wish I had asked for some kind of heat as that would have made the dish even better!  The other two people in our group ordered the pork chop (Marin Sun Farm) which was enormous!  They were quite happy with their dish, as they cleaned their plates - despite joking, initially, that they should have split the order.

Because we were going to a concert, we only ordered those dishes.  However, I will definitely return to Marlowe in the future!
author: Carly B.

description:
Delicious food even though we were 15-mins late ordering from the regular lunch menu on a Saturday afternoon.  A warning would have been appreciated while we navigated our way around the crazy one-way/construction blocks in the area.  We were presented with a limited snack menu and ordered:

Corn soup - smooth, silky, creamy, and slightly sweet.  A perfectly beautiful yellow-hued concoction.  Great balance with a touch of chili oil on top.  Could eat this for days!

Marlowe Burger - wonderfully juicy but 4/5, as have had better burgers.

Deviled eggs - WOW.  Just incredible.  Again wonderful balance with fat (bacon/yolk) and something pickled between the layers of lusciousness.

Brussel chips - not a fan of Brussel sprouts but these actually tasted like potato chips.  Greasy and salty goodness!

Shrimp cocktail - skip this one.  Nothing great about this and the cocktail sauce was spicy as hell (and I love a great spicy sauce but this one just wasn't good)

** TIP: they do NOT offer soy milk. What kind of SF hipster joint doesn't have soy milk??  My friend was lactose intolerant and didn't have a choice but to take their regular milk in her latte.  When I go to a hipster establishment I expect hipster options like gluten-free soy milk!
author: Cin P.

description:
I had the Marlowe Burger and a few appetizers including the okra and baked nuts.

The apps were delicious but the burger was over salted. It is interesting as I really like a well seasoned and salty burger but this one was just too much. 

I will go back again at some point and try the burger again but for now a bit underwhelmed.

cheers
Steve
author: Steven W.

description:
I had this place on my list of restaurants to try for a long time. I came here with a coworker for lunch today and we shared the steak tartar, the chicken and shrimp sandwiches.

The steak tartar was just OK. The meat had good texture, but it was too salty and there wasn't enough acid to balance out the salt. The wild arugula added a nice bitter and textural contrast, but it wasn't enough to save the dish.

The chicken and shrimp sandwiches were also just mediocre. There wasn't anything glaringly wrong with them, but there was no wow factor. The shrimp sandwich was pretty strong, with a lot of hot sauce in the slaw, so much so that I could barely taste the fish. They probably could have used something fancier than a standard hotdog bug, although they did toast it. The chicken in the sandwich was crispy, but it wasn't juicy. Just typical white meat fried, not dry but not moist. The greens was one note and didn't have enough to contrast with the bland-ish chicken.
author: Alice W.

description: Wow, my friend and I had oysters and their steak salad for lunch.  Both were very good.  The salad was a good portion and a great mix of flavors, with some grilled vegetables and an excellently prepared steak.  Might actually come back to try their bone marrow later tonight.
author: J L.

description:
The good:
- Bone marrow appetizer was delicious and came out pretty quick.
- Burgers were cooked well.
- Good service.
- Sole entree was delicious.
- Deserts were yummy.

The bad:
- 4 entrees took a really long time to come out. (Around an hour? Most of the reason I'm giving the place a 3.)
- Horseradish on the burgers was overpowering.
author: Michail Y.

description:
Just fine food ! 
Enjoyed a lot with my friends.
author: Jaein C.

description:
I've heard many good things about the Marlowe burger so I was in area and decided to have lunch and see what the hype was about. Seemed like at least one person at each table was devouring a burger so I was pretty excited to finally try it.

Ehhh for $16, before tip and tax, I was expecting something much more but I wasn't very impressed. Mind you, it was good but that's it. Nothing really special. I think the fries with the horseradish aioli was better than the burger itself. I might be back if I'm in the area and craving a burger but I wouldn't go out of my way to come here. 

3 stars for the food but 1 star for the bartender who was serving us. He was friendly and was helpful when we couldn't choose what drink to get. I forgot the name of the drink he recommended but it was refreshing and yummy.
author: Joanne L.

description: I LOVE Marlowe - whether it's dinner, drinks, or brunch this is a spot to check out. I would try and make a reservation if possible, it's very popular. They have great decor and a fun communal table to sit at. Their burger is my favorite thing to get at dinner. I also like to get a side of Brussels sprouts.
author: Makenzi B.

description: A co-worker encouraged me to visit Marlowe for one of the best burgers in town. She wasn't wrong! Upon arrival, there was over an hour wait but the hostess checked the bar and said seating would shortly be available. Waiting at the side of the restaurant, four different servers asked me if I wanted anything to drink. The bar area was nice and it wasn't cluttered like most. Overall, the food is great but the service is better.
author: E C.

description:
3.5 stars, review of burger only.  It's good, but not worth the $16 price tag in my opinion.

I actually had the Marlowe Burger burger before I had the one from the original Marlowe.  I thought the Marlowe Burger one was decent but not amazing, and thought that perhaps they had tweaked the recipe a little for the casual joint.  But nope, it's the exact same burger, except for a couple bucks more, my patty at Marlowe was actually smaller than the one I received at Marlowe Burger!  I mean, it still tasted good - juicy medium rare, the excellent horseradish aioli, a small portion of iceberg and tomato.  I just don't understand how this burger got such a good reputation.  But the fries... now that's something to rave about!  Just like at Marlowe Burger, the Marlowe fries are perfection. Especially with the horseradish aioli.  

Given what I know now, I really wouldn't bother going to Marlowe for their burger+fries when I can get the exact same thing a block away for $2 less without the crowds.  Unless I want better alcohol options.  Since it was Negroni week, I ordered a Negroni, and while it was very well balanced and not too heavy handed on the Campari, I don't think it justified the $14 price tag.  My friend was in the mood for something refreshing and ordered The Bull (lemongrass-infused gin, blanco vermouth, and tonic) and I couldn't discern any lemongrass and found it pretty underwhelming.  

Obviously I only sampled a fraction of their menu and the other food looked and smelled good... I just don't think the burger lived up to the hype.
author: Beatrice W.

description:
1. The food is delicious, if a little pricey. But the taste value benefit is good. 
2. I've been here at least, if not more than, ten times in the last 2 months. I live a half block away. Mostly for brunch. Not a GLIMMER of recognition by a single employee. 
3. Breakfast egg items come with mostly one egg. Seriously? Two egg minimum. 
4. I have yet to be here where they haven't messed my order somehow. Time to ratchet up the service. 

Better service will easily propel this place to a consistent 5 stars. Please do so. There are so many great places to eat in SF, you can't be caught with your pants down like this. And the two egg minimum thing!
author: Gregory Z.

description:
Marlowe is a gastropub -- limited seating, marble decor, some nifty cocktails and a limited menu. Everything is nice but feels... formulaic without a real spark of authenticity. That would be fine, except that at these prices, you would hope for a little more novelty.

The brussel sprout ceasar salad was interesting: slightly wilted brussel sprouts tossed in ceasar dressing and cheese. The burger was a standard burger with seasoned fries. 

Overall, no complaints, just not excited either!
author: James W.

description:
While I am not an expert food critic or even have a lot of experience in fine dinning, I have to say that this place is overall, a good place to eat.

I understand that SF typically has a mark-up on everything because it is SF and so I will overlook the prices here for that reason and say that the ambiance is typical and nothing special, just clean and practical.
The food however, well the food is delicious. Well seasoned dishes with adequate portions. I had the Pork Chop and I must say that is was the best pork chop I have ever had anywhere. The outside was crispy and the inside was tender and juicy. Not undercooked and not overcooked at all. It had the flavor of light and tender bacon with the texture of a fillet mignon. I recommend!!!!

The only issue I have with this place is the bathroom situation. I just wanted to wash my hands and it took me 20 minutes in line. Either way, good food, average ambiance, SF prices.
author: Benny T.

description: Came here during a vacation with my wife. The service was good, but the food was just ok. I was excited about the Brussels sprout chips, but thought they were greasy. Also started with a deviled egg which was the highlight of the meal by far. My wife and I both order burgers - one was the traditional Marlowe burger and the other was the Sunday night special. Both were decent, but definitely not epic. The fries were good, but nothing out of the ordinary. The cauliflower side dish was way over salted and almost inedible. Then we ended with chocolate chip cookies for desert which were terrible. I've honestly had better at a gas station. Overall a disappointing choice in a city filled with great restaurants.
author: David T.

description:
Yuummm!!! Was just there for a birthday dinner last night and want to go back already. Incredibly cosy little place (reminded us a lot of the crowded NYC cafes we used to haunt back in our younger years...) with delicious food and really attentive (but not annoying) service. We started with cocktails and beer - the Blow Torch was kind of a play on a pomegranate mojito; not quite what I expected but still good. The little gem salad was wonderfully colorful and tossed in a bright citrusy vinaigrette, and the bone marrow was rich and decadent as bone marrow should be (would have liked more crostini to grab up the leftover "sauce").

In a vegetable mood, I took the polenta as main - so good and a massive (but beautifully plated) portion of polento topped with a poached egg, arugula, parmesan, and truffly wild mushrooms (tons of them!). He got the Sunday burger, which was cooked to a perfect medium and topped with more truffly mushrooms and ramps.

We skipped dessert, but were given a couple of chocolate chip cookies on the house.

Love this place and will return without a doubt.
author: MichLee A.

description:
Our server was really nice. The service was fast. The food was.... 

We had a fried chicken sandwich and burger. The fried chicken sandwich was not hot and fries are too salty. I honestly think Chick-fill-A does much better job. At least they are hot and tasty. Given its price, I had to give 1 star even though the server was nice.

This is my first 1 star review.
author: Ryosuke K.

description: This used to be my favorite place. Birthdays, anniversaries, "out of town family" go to spot, or just cause I'm hungry for good food. Not sure if they changed chefs but it's definitely not as good as it used to be. They used to have an awesome kale Cesar salad on baguette but took it off the menu. The gulf shrimp used to have more flavor, but this time around they were unflavorful and yet Spicey. Brussels sprouts chips were left in the deep fryer a little too long. Bone marrow is my favorite.That was still delicious but then again you can't mess that up. The chicken was smothered in gravy and again unflavorful and unappealing.  My all time favorite spot was a huge disappointment.
author: Shana W.

description:
The food was EXCELLENT.  I had the Brussel Sprout Chips, Smoked Salmon, and the Burger.

The space is tight and slightly cramped which is my only knock on the place.

Highly recommended if you can make a reservation in advance.
author: Tiger S.

description: I like this place a lot. Came here at least 3 or 4 times. Very good food, good drinks, nice atmosphere. The only thing is, the place is small so it is loud.
author: Alisa G.

description:
