We came to Marlowe on a busy Saturday night for a special occasion, and the place was packed since the Giants game just finished and I was very happy that I made a reservation for our large group. 

We were offered the option of switching from the communal table (where they typically seat parties larger than 4) to a more private table if we waited about 15 minutes. We quickly grabbed drinks at the bar while we waited, and our group was impressed by the bartenders and cocktails. This initial feeling soon wore off as we ended up waiting 45+ minutes to be seated after our reservation time and that part of our group placed the same drink order 3 times to the same server and not once was brought their drinks. 
 
Once seated, our server made a point to apologize in the form of a round of appetizers and comped the drink orders that were never brought to our friends. While we were still a little annoyed and frustrated with the service from the host staff team, I appreciated that time was taken to address the issue immediately and was happy by the offering.

We ordered our own round of appetizers, more cocktails, and shared some plates for dinner, and some of the highlights were The Baker cocktail, the bone marrow appetizer, and the cod. 

All in all, very happy from a food/drink perspective but service left a lot to be desired. In the future I would probably just come for drinks at the bar.
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Went here for brunch before the Giants game on May 28. The food, service and ambiance was a very nice. The staff here does a good job. Keep up the good work!!
author: Butch L.

description: This was OUTSTANDING!!! The bakers wife cocktail was phenomenal -- so light and refreshing! The fried chicken sandwich was soooo good with the horseradish aioli and the burger was a home run! We also started with the burrata appetizer and we were all speechless. If we lived here, we would go weekly! Service was super and the dress is dressy even during the day.
author: Victoria M.

description:
I come here pretty much anytime there is an open reservation. It's actually one of the first restaurants I search for. The food is outstanding. The Brussels sprout chips are to die for. They probably have the best steak tartare I've ever had outside of France. The poulet vert might be the single tastiest chicken dish I've ever had. Even their salads are outstanding. 

The restaurant can get a bit noisy at times but otherwise no complaints at all. The food, wine, cocktails are all worth a visit.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
***Marlowe is a popular restaurant and it is easy to see why with their delicious, nicely prepared food at reasonable prices***

Marlowe is located in a slightly industrial part of SoMa near AT&T Park that is very crowded.  This area does not necessarily seem like a touristy part of the city, but the streets are busy and it is hard to find parking.

Marlowe serves casual food, but everything here is well prepared and well presented.  The kitchen utilizes high quality ingredients and there seems to be a lot of care that goes into each plate of food.  For lunch, Marlowe features a few small upscale snack-like bites (sweet and savory pistachios and baked oysters), some starters (from light salads to richer items like steak tartare), several upscale but hearty and approachable sandwiches, and a few entrees.

I started with one of their bites.  I had their baked oyster selection, which was described as New England chowder in a shell.  It sounded very inviting.  Unfortunately, I think it was really hard to experience how great this baked oyster could be.  It was supposed to be eaten in one bite, but the oyster was so hot (I did not want to risk burning my lips).

The oyster was good and maintained its plumpness and juiciness despite being cooked.  The oyster had a good crunchy top and you get a creamy chowder part, but there was just not enough of it.  You do not really get that chowder in a bite experience.  Instead, it ends up being a hot oyster with a slight flavoring of cream and chowder.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=bOx79queF48DDtN_RlE4dg#pLilrzM3i-VmeR--SCKoJw

For my entree, I had their Poulet Vert and it was exceptional.  It was a very hearty lunch entree that utilized a simple protein (chicken breast), but there were enough nice touches to really elevate this entree above most chicken courses.  The chicken breast sat on creamy mashed potatoes.  Circling the mashed potatoes were several pieces of chicken fried okra.  The chicken fried okra delivered the crispiness, crunchiness and saltiness of fried chicken, which was nice to have given that the chicken breast was roasted and not fried.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=bOx79queF48DDtN_RlE4dg#EJ9eFf2AAR-R2bkCtdZW6g

The chicken was tender and featured moist meat.  I also enjoyed the herb paste that they used between the meat and the skin.  It created a fragrance that really added needed flavor to a typically bland protein.  The chicken was topped with fresh and leafy arugula.

Dessert was a slight letdown.  It was a banana coconut walnut cake.  While all the flavors came across well, the cake was too dense.  The cake was topped with good vanilla ice cream and a sticky and sweet but not too sweet caramel.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marlowe-san-francisco-2?select=bOx79queF48DDtN_RlE4dg#FqJmdB3QoThoMHUjgfGKDw

Service was very good--quick and personable.

Prices were reasonable.  Most of the sandwiches were $15 and below.

Marlowe has a nice look.  With the white tile and small, packed dining room, it has the feel of a downtown hot spot or breakfast spot.  With the tables and dark brown bar, you get an upscale and contemporary but also still very classic bar feel.  With the animal drawings to the chalkboard specials on the wall, Marlowe also reflects a gastropub feel.

While I did not love all of the food I had at Marlowe (the chicken was excellent while the rest of the food was slightly disappointing), almost all of the food served here looked very appetizing (the appearance of the prawn cocktail really stood out).  The menu sounded very good and I think there are probably several great dishes here.  The dinner menu is more ambitious and features more exciting proteins.  If you can only make it to Marlowe for a weekday lunch though, I think you are likely to leave very satisfied.

Street parking is very hard to find.  There is a nearby pay parking lot, but it is expensive at $15-$20 per vehicle.
author: Anthony N.

description: Marlowe totally earned its reputation for great brunches this morning. The menu had so many enticing offerings that it was hard to choose, but my husband and I feasted on a shared starter of French soldiers (basically French toast fingers) served with maple syrup and chocolate dipping sauces; the Hashbrown Benedict (poached egg on a bed of potatoes, bacon and frisée salad with the traditional bearnaise); and a delicious toasted bagel with smoked salmon, melon, and some sort of citrus dressing. We also enjoyed cocktails (a Bloody Mary variant for me and a mimosa for him) and coffee. Everything was delicious, and we left feeling sated and satisfied. Service was friendly and professional. All this goodness didn't come cheap (this is San Francisco after all) but I didn't mind paying the premium for such great food and service. I look forward to trying out some of the dishes I didn't get to this time.
author: Denny A.

description:
I was curious about Marlowe bc it has been on Michael Bauer's Top 100 list for a few years. I like it! I was able to make a reservation for brunch, which is fab (no waiting starving for an hour on the sidewalk), they had mimosas, gluten free friendly, allergy friendly, great service, and home made doughnuts. 
The staff greeting you at the door are super friendly. The wait staff are attentive to any special food requests. Also, they had a nice brunch menu and a full bar! I didn't try the famous burger but I did have the tomatoe baked eggs, which were yummy. French toast soliders, Loretta's Vacherin (meringue w/ coffee ice cream), and peanut butter pretzel nuggets were super. 
Also, if people are driving, much easier parking in this part of SOMA than other SF neighborhoods.
author: Laura F.

description:
Akeisha the server is awesome - 5 stars for her.

The ambiance was nice.

The drinks were good.

All in a solid spot.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Probably one of my favorite places to dine in SF. Also doesn't hurt that this is where my bf and I had our first date. 

We originally went to their first location on Townsend and loved the ambiance, food, and service. We recently returned to Marlowe at their current location on Brannan and I was quite impressed. The exterior is definitely an upgrade and the interior is just beautiful. It's warm and inviting inside and although it is still quite a tiny restaurant, it can fit quite a few people!

Here are some things we have had:

- Little Gem Salad: really good. Can't go wrong if you're looking for a veggie app
- Roasted Bone Marrow - my first time having bone marrow and it just melts in your mouth like butter.
- Marlowe burger - probably my favorite burger in the city (and I'm a girl determined to find the best burger in the city). Fresh ingredients, cooked to perfection, and complemented by a bun that's soft, yet sturdy. 
- Smoked black cod - solid fish dish. Tasty and surprisingly filling.

On our first date night, we had some dishes that are no longer on their menu, but were delicious from what I can remember... The service is great and the food is incredible. Also, I believe the chef is up for a James Beard award this year (2015).
author: Leana L.

description:
I started off with the Brussels sprout chips and let me tell you... it was perfect. Crispy with a wonderful sauce on top. Then I moved on to the baked oysters. Be careful... I was so excited that I threw one in my mouth as soon as it came out and burnt the crap out of my mouth... But it sure was worth it! They were heaven. I finished off my meal with the steak frites. Cooked to perfection and had a perfect amount of sodium for my liking. Fries were nice, salty, and crispy too.

They have a unique selection of beers here. I tried the oregon lager and ... something else I can't remember at this point in time. They were both great beers.

I came here during lunch time only to find out that some of the dishes I saw on yelp were not offered until dinner! How upsetting... I guess I'll just have to revisit this restaurant next time I'm back in town! 

The bartender was cool and his service was on point.
author: Phi N.

description: The burger is great, serve Icelandic beer, overall nice place, what more can you ask for?
author: G I.

description: Just finished a lovely brunch. Good cocktail list and menu. The service was also very attentive. We had some good starters, including the candied bacon, which tasted more like a pork belly and was very good. The burrata was delicious, as was the kale and Brussels sprout salad. Only 2 blocks from Caltrain, which was a plus for heading back to San Jose afterwards.
author: Margo M.

description: I seriously can say that the customer service is good and the meals are great. I honestly think brussels sprout chips was delicious but Shrimp roll was typical. My visit here was pleasant. I will return.
author: Natasha R.

description:
Even before the doors opened, there was a line filling the foyer, and within 15 minutes of seating people, the place was full - most definitely a good sign.

Marlowe has another one of those gorgeous menus where everything looks absolutely delicious, and your eyes will tend to be bigger than your stomach (not sure if this is a bad thing for this restaurant).

The crispy brussels sprout chips were quite good, although the smaller leaves were difficult to eat by hand, and it became more of a fork-stabbing event to devour these sea-salt covered beauties.

The baked oysters were quite good - I've only eaten them raw, and this was a delicious take - it's described as New England clam chowder in a shell, but more solidified, and a creamy delight to spoon out of the shell.

We ordered burrata (aka the cheese love of my life), which came with a spicy pesto, artichoke purée, arugula, and grilled bread - it was delicious, beautifully presented, and a joy to devour at the table.

Finally, we went with the steak tartare, topped with a poached quail egg and accompanied by crostini. It was delicious - fresh, perfectly seasoned, and I was mildly disappointed there wasn't more once we had finished it.

Love the interior of the restaurant, good service, delicious food, highly recommend!
author: Claire S.

description:
Giving it a five star because they made my best friend's birthday amazing! The host is so accommodating even though I changed the reservation last minute. We got seated in the outdoor heated patio area and it's seriously the PERFECT spot for a birthday party!!! 

When we first entered the restaurant we were slightly confused on where we were going because you have to go through the kitchen area to get to the patio. It had such a cozy & cute atmosphere with lots of plants and beautiful lighting around. Made us feel exclusive haha because we were tucked away from the kind of noisy bar area. 

My favorite dish of the night was definitely the pork chop. I'm still dreaming about it... The pork was just so tender & juicy with a nice flavorful crust on the outside. The farro that came with it was cooked to the right amount too! I love how it soaks up a little of the meat sauce yet it's still chewy.

If I were to come back again I'd probably order the bone marrow instead of the steak tartare and I'd also skip the scallops too. The scallops were good but I've definitely had better.
author: Crystal W.

description:
Wow. Got the brunch on Sunday. Deviled Egg was fantastic. The had the scramble which was amazing. OJ good too.

A must visit.
author: Chandler H.

description:
Five of us for lunch on a Friday at their new location. 

We were seated in the corner.  I think it was the best table in the house.  Tables are so close together you'd easily carry a conversation with other diners.  

Pros:
We got the bites - 
*brussel sprouts chips.  Excellent. 
*french fries.  Hot and crunchy.
*fried corneal coated okra.  Great.

Four of us decided we'd split the Marlowe cheeseburger and the fried chicken sandwich with a green salad on the side. We got two orders each.  The fifth person went with the calamari entree.

I bit into my fried chicken sandwich.  Soggy coating.  And pieces of fried chicken.  More bacon strips than chicken.  Felt like nuggets instead of an entire chicken breast. Disappointing.

Took a bite of my burger.  Wasn't as memorable as before.  

Is this what happens when you expand?

We concluded with coffee and two desserts - the two house made cookies and the chocolate pudding.  That was yummy.

Overall 3.5 stars.

$40 p/p inc tax & tip.
author: Shirley N.

description: Love this place - great fresh food, relaxed staff, super fun!  San Francisco local at its best.
author: Lauren H.

description:
The dinner experience at Marlowe was amazing- both filling and delicious. 

My friend and I each ordered the Marlowe burger and shared the bone marrow. The Marlowe burger portion was larger than expected and the side of fries salted just the right amount. The garlic aioli added wonderful flavor to the heavy meat patty.

The bone marrow was mouth watering. I never had a side of finely chopped capers to top off the bread and bone marrow before so it was a first time culinary experience--definitely my new favorite appetizer. 

Overall, I will be back! Great service, excellent food, what more can you ask for?
author: Kristi L.

description:
Have you ever had a restaurant manager invite you to criticize their food and service while you are dining? Me either. Does it inspire confidence? "You betcha!" As Marge in Fargo would say. So we did.

The food and service were both inspired at their soft brunch opening. We began with Marlowe's version of a blood mary, harmonious tang and spicy accented with a green olive, pickled onion and lemon wedge on a spike for $11. Next up the seasonal eclairs, 3 mini versions piped with lemon curd and coconut shavings napped in white chocolate. Alongside were 3 chocolate chip minis with chocolate icing. The choux pastry was light and fluffy, the fillings divine but served a bit too chilled. That was our first criticism.

Round 2 featured two warm deviled eggs hinting of pickled jalapeno nd topped with crisp bacon and melted provolone. I could have eaten a plate of these beauties.

Three buttery crepes enfolded fresh dungeness crab and plump rock shrimp, a teriffic brunch entree enlivened by a light and lemony hollandaise. Really scrumptious, rich and satisfying without being gloppy or pasty as some brunch hollandaise treatments are. A salad served alongside was clearly just picked out of the garden and punctuated with herbs.

Hubby had the famous fried chicken sandwich and french fries. No doubt the fries served with a horseradish aioli were the best i have ever eaten.

At this point a waiter other than our own noticed my empty drink glass and asked "If I wanted another of whatever it was I was drinking?" Nice intention but a bit clodly, criticism 2.

Our waitress was finesse itself, even shadowed as she was by a trainee. Plates were removed and the table wiped between courses. Very refined!

I enjoyed the fort bragg coffee and the cream served in tiny milk bottles. The interior had sound baffling so conversation was easy, thank goodness! I would gladly return to any restaurant that allowed for conversation without strain. 

The brunch with tip was over $100 for 2, a real splurge but well justified by the food, service and ambiance. I felt spoiled yet comfortable, you will too!
author: Kelly K.

description: I wanted to like this place more. I went on a random Tuesday night and it was packed but I got a seat at the bar. I'm not sure if the surly bartender was a bit, or if he was just having a bad day. "Hungry? Wutchawant?"  Noise level on here says average, but it's loud. "Glad to be outside again," loud. Ordered a very well balanced Old Fashioned (true marachinos!), but when he asked again whether I ordered bourbon or eye, he screamed bourbon at me when he couldn't hear my reply. Ordered the ribeye midrare, and it was very good, but given the lessened cook time, the edge fat desperately needed some trimming. Cutlery wasn't up to the task without some real sawing. Price was on par with trendy SF places.  Lastly bar seating was a problem. Several walk-ins sat at the bar, only to be booted by the bartender or a hostess that wasn't at the front to police it.
author: Jason N.

description: We had burgers, fries and rings.  The food was okay.  I've had better burgers for five dollars less than Marlowe.
author: Al G.

description: We really had an excellent meal here- creative but not weird. There are several variations of Brussels sprouts, which I love. I had the Poulet Vert, which was perfectly prepared. A bit noisy, but not my strongest memory. Can get pricey.
author: Marie D.

description: This place is amazing. The bone marrow appetizer I could eat all day , everyday. Porkchop was slamming as well. Perfectly cooked. Nice cocktail concoctions as well!
author: Angel R.

description: Easily one of my favorite places in SF. Nothing but quality. The burger is consistently one of the best around. This time I also got to try the heirloom bruschetta. Well worth it. The service was outstanding and the bill is reasonable. Go here for a great experience.
author: BRADY K.

description:
absolute delightful experience.

they sent us in the little back Garden room they had, which I love it very much. Very nice place to sit down and it will be quite if not many ppl is around.

the food is excellent, and I am very satisfied with everything we ordered.

the service is also excellent, nice looking gal and guy, very experienced.

over all excellent!
author: Zack Y.

description: Burgers were small and not that appealing. It is a popular restaurant in the area and I can see why people go there but nothing stood out and I don't think i would go there again. I had the brussel spouts and those were good, but not on par with zero zero or etc. The fried chicken sandwich was okay...not amazing. Bone marrow was standard and so were the deviled eggs.
author: Lily P.

description:
Like everyone says, the brussel sprout chips are really quite something. They're crunchy and lemon-y, and they come out at the perfect temperature to whet your appetite. My girlfriend and I came here for lunch on a Friday at 2:00pm, and it wasn't difficult to get a seat at all. We split a few appetizers and a dessert, but the wait staff was pretty awesome. When we ordered and said we were going to split the items, they did it for us by giving us two separate plates for each course, and they parceled out the plates by asking us if we were done.

Loved the mushroom soup as it was super creamy, and I have to say that the creme brulee was a little pricey, but it was pretty freaking good too. Super creamy, and you could taste the egg custard. Their cornmeal shortbread was a great way to accompany that last dish too. Didn't get their famous Marlowe burger, so can't comment on that one!
author: Danny C.

description:
Totally scrumptious  burger and fries. Sat at the bar and got excellent service. Solid rose (if a bit overpriced, but what isn't these days?).

Chocolate cream pie was tasty with a slightly salty hint. 

Space was well lit and airy. Despite atrocious construction outside, it was a lovely vibe. Highly recommend.
author: Ginny S.

description: It was good but over hyped. There are so many great places in SF. Marlowe doesn't stand out for me.
author: Ann L.

description: 2,000th review! Great meal. Always appreciate the boulevardier on the cocktail menu. Little gem salad was amazingly fresh and diverse. Burger was great and well balanced in flavor.
author: Ryan S.

description: I love this spot! Based on the quality of the food and service, this restaurant deserves a Michelin star. The Marlowe burger is exquisite, the Little Gem Salad is impeccable. The service was top notch!
author: Zack H.

description:
I used to be a huge fan of Marlowe. 

We had reservations for 8:30pm, but the place was so packed full of diners, so we ended up waiting for about 8-10 minutes. Fine, that's not so bad. 

I T  W A S N ' T  T H E  S A M E
I had visited Marlowe when they were at their old location, about 3+ times in the past two years and it was one of my top restaurants in SF! The food was good, and the service was solid. But, this time I was in for a much different experience. 

S T A R T E R S
Brussel Sprout Chips- Yes, these were just as good as I remembered them to be. The only difference is that it is now served in a much smaller bowl.

Bone Marrow- My favorite appetizer. Still the best bone marrow I've had at any restaurant. 

Deviled Eggs- They were okay. Nothing to write home about. 

T H E  F A M O U S
Of course I ordered the burger that everyone raves so much about, the Marlowe Burger. I've had this burger twice before, but this time I noticed a difference in taste. I couldn't quite put my finger on the reason why, but maybe what I have to say next will shed some light.

W H A T  S E R V I C E ? ? ?
Ah yes, service. One of the important keys to running a successful business! Well luckily for my friends and I, we got stuck with the "ghost waiter." He makes an appearance when he pleases, or when he gets "caught." Okay, so he took our order, brought us dessert menus, brought our bill, and took our money. Do you notice anything missing here?

He did not once come to our table to simply ask us, "How's everything?" Normally at restaurants, the waiter or waitress comes out after you've gotten your food, to check on you. RIGHT, or am I just crazy? Well, we did not get that here. I also noticed he was paying more attention to a table full of older people. He even thanked that same table for dining at Marlowe, as he dropped off the bill. Well, when he dropped our bill off to us- he didn't say one word. Not even a thank you. Then as we left in front of him, he still didn't say anything!! No, "Have a good night." or a "Thank you." He had that DISGUSTING attitude of someone who doesn't give an f, extremely cocky and very UNPLEASANT. 

WHAT A HORRIBLE EXPERIENCE!!! Needless to say, I left the restaurant extremely upset, and told myself that I will NEVER set foot in their establishment ever again.

C O N C L U S I O N
The interior was unappealing to me; it felt as if I was eating in someone's old kitchen. I much rather prefer the darker interior, and ambiance at the old location. Also, the tables at their new location are fairly tightly packed. So be prepared to slide your bottom across your neighbor's table. 

Marlowe used to be one of my top recommendations, well not anymore! Treating your customers poorly will result in poor reviews. Why would anyone in their right mind's recommend an eating establishment where they were poorly treated. 

2 stars because they still have the best bone marrow in town.
author: Heather C.

description: I have been to Marlowe for lunch in the past and was truly a fan. It did not fare well for dinner. The food was good but not great. The ambience was good and cozy. Great date spot. The Brussels sprout chips and the burrata were definite highlights. I think their chicken sandwich served during lunch is the winner overall.
author: Joel V.

description: Great fantastic super burger. Service was a bit wishy washy. Slow. No drink top-ups. Unexpectedly poor service.
author: Cameron O.

description:
Everything I had read about Marlowe was true. The food was delicious. The drinks converted a non whiskey drinker to a whiskey drinker. The services was friendly. The place was packed until 11 on a Thursday. 

Ordered:
Mushroom soup  - hands down the best thing I had
Burger - also as good as the hype 
Buratta - the pear pairing was wonderful
Brussels sprout chips - addicting
author: Shalizeh D.

description: So sooo delicious!!  I've only eaten in the dining room and at the bar so far. Looking forward to trying out the patio. The inside of this restaurant is a beautiful space while not being stuffy. The staff is really attentive and friendly. I've tried the chicken sandwich and the open faced deviled egg sandwich with mixed greens. Both are very good!
author: Christy H.

description: Delicious dinner with a few standouts: deviled eggs, incredibly light yet crunchy Brussel sprouts, huge shrimp cocktail, and yummy cocktails. Cozy, friendly, classy ambience. All around lovely dinner experience.
author: Jannine V.

description: Came here for brunch and loved it. Atmosphere is nice and the food was good. We had the donuts, omelette and crab Benedict. Will def be back to try dinner.
author: Sandra S.

description:
Ate here during an awkward time (around 4:30) so we had to eat off the bar menu. There wasn't much selection but everything we had was great and really tasty!

Definitely recommend:

Brussel sprouts chips
Marlowe burger
Little gems salad
author: Sanaz O.

description:
we gathered here on a monday night as a reunion of sorts between 4 friends who rarely get to see each other even though we all live in the same city. and i couldn't have asked for a better venue.

pros:
+ excellent service! our waters were constantly refilled before they ever neared empty
+ good ambiance and chatter buzz, without it being difficult to hear conversation at the table
+ great menu for sharing bites/appetizers (the bone marrow!!!)
+ terrific selection of drinks (beer, wine, cocktails) but not too long of a list for those who are indecisive
+ food is generally good if not excellent (the bone marrow!!!)

cons (hardly):
- space is a tad small but tables are not right on top of each other, so that's nice i guess
- people rave about the marlowe burger, but i thought it was just average for a "gourmet burger"
- polenta was delish for the first half, but ultimately became too rich to finish
- we did order 2 side dishes that never came.. i think the waitress forgot because it wasn't even charged on our bill and we were too full to follow-up anyways.. so we just let it go

price not bad at all. roughly $60pp including 2 drinks each, an entree, and 2 shared appetizers between 4 people. will definitely be back to try the rest of the menu.
author: Yiwen S.

description: Impeccable food and service. Sara was literally trained to be a top notch server. The food was nothing short of foodgasmic. Whoever owns this place needs a 2 thumbs up for the concept and the ambiance and the food. Good job from a very picky selective foodie. Best place in SF ! Don't doubt this place. Just come and have a food orgasm.
author: Mariya B.

description: Marlowe is always a good meal.  The food is well-made classic American food, they environment is always nice, and it is always busy.  Definitely a great local spot for us SoMa residents!  I would recommend getting reservations since it's a smaller place.  If you want to have a big group there, they have a great long table for it, but again you would want to get a reservation well ahead of time.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Marlowe has always been a solid, go-to. The only reason I've docked 1 point is because sometimes (rarely), their front of the restaurant staff can be a little stuck up (but having worked that position, I know how much it sucks at times).
Marlowe has always had one of the best fried chicken burgers in the city (which is really saying something considering its a block away from the Little Skillet), and those brussel sprouts are to die for.
The drinks at Marlowe are also always on point, and the ambience at night time makes it a great date spot! 
I used to work on top of Marlowe (the old location), and we even used to have our investor lunch meetings there (everyone loves the food and the ambience)!
author: Aabhas S.

description: We were craving burgers on a Friday afternoon and decided to go for Marlowe's. Weren't disappointed at all, in fact, were surprised to find it so crowded. Got the bar seats and straight away ordered the delicious oysters, and Marlowe's burger and the crispy chicken sandwich with caramelized onions. They accommodated he request graciously and we were delighted by the quality, taste and service. Had a couple beers to go with it and Marlowe's fries. Kept it simple, lived the food and experience, will definitely visit again.
author: Rohit K.

description:
Too rushed. Our server tried to take our drink orders as soon as the menus were handed to us. She had seen that we hadn't even flipped the menu around towards the drinks and she's hovering around asking what we want. Yes, I had to ask her to return. 

We started off with the deviled eggs which was fantastic with perfectly salty crispy bacon. It's half an egg per order. My husband had been a fan of their burgers and ordered it frequently for lunch when we lived steps away from their Townsend location. I'd noticed he'd left a portion of it untouched and it was apparent he wasn't intending to finish it. He mentioned he was underwhelmed and it was not the same burger he used to love. 

I had the burrata toast with the honey glazed bacon. The bacon was extremely fatty and too sweet and did not go very well with the burrata, I thought. Salty bacon, yes but not the sweet bacon, no. 

I liked the new space. It was bright with subway tiled walls throughout in a nice corner location. Parking seemed easy enough for us that Saturday at noon.
author: Esther A.

description:
Not too sure why Marlowe is known for their burgers since it was pretty underwhelming. Buffalo Burgers on Castro St. in DT Mountain View has better items.  I felt all the dishes we orders in our party of 5 were overly salted. Pretty bad to actually be thinking "wow, this is so salty" when eating the brussels sprouts or polenta. I was afraid to feed too much of the dishes to my 18 month old baby!  

The service was great though - our server was the best. When we asked if they had a baby changing station, the server actually offered my husband a place next to the kitchen but another server came to lectured my husband about it, and when my husband told him that our server had offered the space to us, the other server went to lecture our server. This place is definitely not baby friendly =(.
author: Jackie L.

description:
I am over paying OUTRAGEOUS prices in SF for food that is soso and still leaving the table hungry since the portions are soooo small (compared to the price).

Came for the bone marrow, but the portion was soooo small for $17! The bone was small with barely enough marrow for one person to enjoy. I can get a serving with twice as much marrow and half the price at MUA in Oakland or Make Westing. - Fries were $9 and small portion also. It is just French fries for $9, really?

If you want to walk out with a $200 bill for two people due to small portions and overpriced appetizers, this place will be ok for you.


The pros- the bone marrow was well seasoned. Fries were crispy. Drinks were decent priced $11 and up. Servers were polite and attentive. Cozy restaurant.
author: Ivory M.

description:
Atmosphere: The setting was lovely. It had a nice bar in the back, behind regular tables. It was just the right amount of noisiness for chatting with a few friends or going on a date.

Drinks: I got the Pimm's Cup which was pretty delicious. It came to me kind of sticky though because some spilled on its way to me outside the restaurant.

Wait: When I got there at 6 without a reservation, it was a 20min wait for a spot at the bar and an hour wait for a sit down table. I opted for the 20min wait since it was a casual catch up with a friend. While you wait, you're able to sit outside by the trees and get your drinks brought to you, which was nice!

Food: Expensive (like $13 an appetizer and $30 for an entree) but delicious! My friend and I got 4 appetizers and a dessert to share. My favorite was easily the shrimp crepe. The sauce was so on point! We also got an asparagus dish ($13 ish for 5 asparagus and some pancetta lol), jumbo shrimp cocktail (great spice on the shrimp), and brussel sprout chips (crispy yumminess). To finish off, we had the strawberry shortcake which had a wonderful biscuit to pair with cream and strawberries. 

The only reason why I deducted 1 star was because of the price and wait. Otherwise, definitely loved this place!
author: Vio C.

description: Delicious arctic char! Sat on the outside patio and the ambiance was perfect for a dinner with coworkers. Definitely recommend!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
It's good food.  Simple.  Nothing that makes you want to come back and spend money like you just sold your kidneys.

The decor is outstanding, also the patio is beautiful.  Maybe I was expecting too much,  but it wasn't bad nor good.  Kinda of like watching a Superhero movie.
author: Sammy S.

description:
Great location. 
Busy AF even on a Tuesday at 5:30pm. 
It's a loud places so keep that in mind. 
Small menu but what they gave us well thought out and prepared 
My hubby had a burger and I had the seabass. Both were excellent with great flavor profiles. 
I have celiac disease and they had no trouble accommodating. 
The desert was great. It was a egg based cookie with coffee ice cream, chocolate sauce and toasted pecans!!! 
We will be back.
author: Nataliya C.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday at 1 PM and I was quite surprised how full it was for a weekday and it was already after regular lunch hour of 12 noon for those 8-5ers. Seems like it's everyone's favorite lunch spot! Luckily there was a table open for us and we got seated right away.

I ordered the chicken sandwich and the boyfriend ordered the shrimp roll. The fried chicken sandwich didn't look as big but once I was halfway, I knew I couldn't finish the second half but forced myself too because I was starving and because it was good. The shrimp roll was also really delicious. And it wasn't small so it's well worth the money. 

Both our orders came with fries and a horesradish aioli. The aioli was really good. It wasn't too strong in flavor but good enough to spread in my fried chicken sandwich without overbearing the already tasteful sandwich.

It's kind of loud so it's hard to have an intimate conversation here, but not loud where you have to yell at each other just to be heard. I, however, had a hard time hearing my server but that's also because he was pretty tall and didn't have much space to lean in towards us. He also probably had a hard time hearing us because he didn't put in our order of brussel sprout chips, so I guess I have to come back just to try it.

Also, the food takes awhile to come out. I'm not sure it's always like that or maybe it felt like it was taking forever because I was starving.
author: Liezel D.

description:
Typical San Francisco restaurant that has that SF hipster vibe with tiled floors and marble tables. 

My friend and I were here over the weekend for brunch. We were bummed because everything we wanted to order (Greek yogurt panna cotta & house made ricotta toast) happened to be "out." We ended up ordering brûléed winter citrus and buttermilk pancakes. 

Brûléed Winter Citrus:
- Perfect balance of sweetness, acidity, & nuttiness
- Definitely meant to be an appetizer or a side dish; portion is not large enough for someone who wants a full meal

Buttermilk Pancakes:
- Typical pancakes, nothing too special

The overall experience wasn't too bad. We just wish we were able to eat what we wanted to order, and not just something that was left in the kitchen because nobody else ordered it.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: Service is great! It was a busy Friday night but nonetheless the service from the host to the bartenders and our server were courteous and accommodating. I came here with a friend for drinks and a few small plates. He frequents this place for the the bone marrow but assured me there would be plenty of pesca/vegetarian options. We had the brussel sprout chips, burrata, Caesar toast, deviled eggs (*it has bacon) and his roasted bone marrow. The ambiance cute, cozy and dim..a bit noisy but not overbearing. Overall the appz were interesting, drinks nicely made and awesome service.
author: Chanel H.

description:
Little gems salad, 

You're all I need in this world.

I dream about you, I fantasize about you, I often find myself zoning out at work just thinking about you.

Please don't ever leave me.

Love,
Jen
author: Jen K.

description: Went here for brunch with a group of friends on a Sunday. We sat at the community table so we didn't have to wait too long. I recommend making a reservation. The food was delish! Coffee was ok. Service was great. We shared the deviled eggs and French toast soldiers. Both were really good. I had the Anson Mills Polenta...highly recommend it. The rest of the table got fried chicken sandwiches and the burger (which is apparently what they're known for).
author: Nina T.

description:
I'll probably not come back here again because...despite all the hype, the food was just...OK. And it was expensive. And I had to ask the waitress to cut out the salt in the rest of my food before my tongue could feel flavor again.

We came here for lunch. It was very busy at noon, pretty much fully seated, but I had a reservation. We ordered and received in order:


--- baked oyster: good
--- gem salad: TOO SALTY
--- steak tartare: TOO SALTY
--- burrata: good (becuz I told them to take the salt off)
--- fries: good (becuz I told them to take the salt off)

The gem salad is just a plain salad. A few crispy leaves of lettuce sprinkled with so much salt and dressing that I couldn't taste anything but the salt. I was very looking forward to the steak tartare (being an omnivore), but it was again, so salty that I almost cried. After these two dishes, I intercepted the waitress to ask her to cut the salt out of the remaining two dishes. The burrata and fries were, now with the salt taken off, tasting like actual food. But were they really good? I mean, how do you screw up burrata and fries? You can't, unless you had salted them, but I prevented them from doing that, so it was edible, and that's about as much as I can say about their food: it's edible.

There's some similarity in their dishes to say, what Beretta in the Mission provides. But Beretta is 100 times better. Their menu is more interesting, their drinks more fancy, their decor just as hip, and I never had to ask them to cut the salt.

So there, sorry, Marlowe. Not coming back.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Wow. My friends and I had just finished doing the Bay To Breakers and were looking for a good brunch/lunch spot. One of our friends recommended this place, so we head over and it was absolutely worth it. We had to wait outside for a bit, but when it was finally our turn, the girl at the front desk (British accent) walked us down the street rather than inside, and then pulled open what look like two big barn doors and led us in to this tiny little side room. 

We all ordered something different, but the winner for the day was the deviled eggs... Holy crap... They only come in servings of one egg, so keep that in mind (we ended up ordering like 12 of them they were so good). I also had a smoked salmon dish which was a spin off of a lox and bagels type dish, it was good as well. 

The service was fantastic, the waitresses were all very lively and helpful. 

100% recommend this place if you have the chance. It'll likely be busy, and you'll likely have to wait a bit, but its worth every bit of time.
author: Ryan S.

description: First vist was recently on  Easter Sunday and after planning to try this location for years, it was in fact very disappointing.  I know it was Easter, but we felt rushed to order and eat and then be on our way so not happy about that.  It was busy and that's okay ,but seemed a bit too cramped up ,so felt totally messy and made it uncomfortable at times .  I ordered the crispy chicken sandwich and  it sounded so good on menu ,but upon eating the sandwich , it lacked taste and flavor so this was a massive let down for me. The only good thing about my dish was the fries so thats all i have to say.  Based on my first experience, i would guess that this will be our only visit and cannot recommend this place to anyone in future I feel sorry to say.
author: Alan H.

description:
I was very excited to try Marlowe's since it is so close to my work and I always see a line out the door. However, I was very disappointed with my service. It took over an hour and a half for us to receive our food. I think something must have happened in the kitchen because the waiter started to avoid us after we had waited over an hour since we had ordered. We were starving and it wasn't even very crowded so I am unsure still what exactly the issue was. 

When we did eventually receive our food the burger was overcooked, skimpy portions for the fries, and an overall lackluster experience for such an exceptionally long wait.

The fried chicken sandwich was very tasty but the overcooked burger and the long wait ruined the experience for me. I hope to try it again someday and have a better experience because it seems to have great potential, but I hesitate to spend the money again with the possibility of a similar experience.
author: Monica M.

description: Yum! Food and service were great. Checked in but had a little wait so went to Bar Basic next door. Got a great seat and ordered the deviled eggs and warm cesear salad to start. Delicious! Had the burger and black cod for our main course. Burger had great horseradish aioli but the cod was so bland the staff was helpful and quick to change it out. We got the roasted bone marrow and roasted brussel sprouts instead. Amazing!!! Highly recommend this place for both the food and service.
author: Jen C.

description:
Marlowe is in a new location! The restaurant is on the small side so maybe not the best place for large parties. 

Pros:
- Cute bustling restaurant with a good vibe and a lot of activity. It has a "modern cafe" feel with bright white tile floors and booths. 
- Boozy shrimp was great. Six big, head-on shrimp made for a solid appetizer for sharing (though I was stingy!)
- Attentive service

Cons:
- Pea pancakes didn't have a ton of flavor and I could have been eating the smoked salmon off of just about anything
author: Wendy L.

description: The food gets 4 stars and the service gets 5! We've always gotten excellent service here whether we sit at the bar, table or patio. Our host made room for us even without a reservation. Our server remembered what drinks we ordered from the last time we were here. And the restaurant manager on duty brought me all the off the menu condiments. This really speaks to a staff who cared about providing excellent service. To top it all off, the cocktails are always interesting - the butcher's mistress- and excellent.
author: Chi C.

description:
It was really Meh ..
It was super cold that day, and they had no consideration in trying to keep the door closed.. Even one of their workers decided it was a good idea to stand in the doorway ..
The waitress was nice, but gave super long explanations of the food .. 
And the food was super salty ...
author: Zara R.

description:
Great space - loved the airiness and vibe,  Clean white with a little vintage feel.  Stopped by on a trip to SF - would definitely recommend. 

On to the food, in order of yumminess:

Bone marrow - Don't you hate it when you order bone marrow, and it's teeny tiny with nothing on it?  This is NOT that - 2 huge bones with plentiful marrow.  Awesome sauce.
Brussel Sprout Chips - THIS is how brussel sprouts should be done!  Perfectly crispy!  Why can't all placed do it like this?!
Cauliflower - cheesy, can't go wrong with cauliflower and cheese.
Black cod - black rice, artichoke, leeks - really can't go wrong with cod. 

Vacherin dessert - coffee ice cream, creme, meringue, chocolate sauce, almond - I honestly don't remember this dish, but I'm sure it was great!
author: Vicki C.

description:
I am really surprised at all of the 4 star and up reviews for Marlowe, I was incredibly unimpressed. The atmosphere and service are good, but I believe, to be expected. Marlowe is a small place, tight seating, but cozy...

We ordered the oysters, and they were OK, but nothing to write home about. The bone marrow was presented nicely, but I've had some amazing bone marrow and the dish at Marlowe did not even compare. We ordered the Burger, the bread was stale and cold. The fries were all cold as well - not at all enjoyable. The cauliflower side may have been the best tasting thing we ordered, it was covered and cooked in 8lbs of cheese, so I'd be surprised if it didn't taste good (and clog an artery). The steak was so-so, we were told it was nicely marbled but it was really just surrounded by fat around the edges, ALL the edges.

I wouldn't go back to Marlowe. There are so many amazing restaurants in SF and I don't get the hype about this place at all. At the very least, you should be able to serve up a decent burger...
author: Nikki R.

description: So far so good! Great service and the place has a very nice vibe. Staring with the baked oysters which were highly recommend. The burgers are well known so I might do that as my entree.
author: Naveed A.

description:
We went to Marlowe's for dinner. The whole place is very inviting. The waitress was super friendly and meticulous. She told us about the special drinks of the night which sounded amazing and hence I ordered that. This restaurant has a section of 'bites' before the starters which I felt was great. The portions of these bites is supposedly like a tasting menu for 3 people. We tried 5-6 items from this bites section and all of them were amazing. 

The chef adds eggs to almost all the dishes and you can infer she is a big fan of eggs. 

I am deducting 1 star because they have 2 restrooms which are both unisex. I used the restroom twice and both the times the restroom was dirty understandably because it was unisex. For such an upscale place their restroom really becomes a big disappointment.
author: Neha G.

description:
Went here to celebrate a good friends new job as an RN.  When we arrived, the hosts were fairly welcoming. Our waiter was nice. What impressed us was, management. They started us with a complimentary celebratory wine and congratulated my friend on her new job when we sat down.

At the end of the meal, I was clumsy and a few drops of chocolate drizzled on my white blouse. Management quickly popped up next to me (frightening my friend and I) and asked if I wanted some club soda to get the stain out. Thanks Marlowe!  

To review the food in a nutshell: bone marrow EXCELLENT! Deviled egg, YUM! We shared a pork chop, cooked well meaning it was chewy tough and it had good flavor and char. Brussels sprout chips are always a hit here. Okra- I'm not a fan of but tried it, I still am not a fan of it, but my friend said it was ok. Dessert: Loretta's Vacherin is what we got and were very pleased with the meringue, coffee ice cream, toasted almonds, & chocolate sauce. Delish! Do ppl still use that term?! Well, I'll start the word trend up again! Delish! :D
author: Jacqueline C.

description: Nice little restaurant.  We had a good meal here.  The Brussels sprout chips are tasty,  the burrata starter was very yummy and roasted tomato soup was good too.  The burger was quite tasty,  but it is just a burger so I wouldn't get overly excited about that. . So good food, not unreal but good.
author: Peter T.

description:
This is my first time back since they moved to their new space. 

As always, I got the burger and brussels sprout chips, which were awesome, but I also tried some other new things: 
- Polenta with mushrooms: a good vegetarian option
- Cauliflower gratin: cheesy, warm, served in a cast iron skillet 

Bonuses: 
- They have a full bar, so I tried the Grindr (rye based, a bit too sweet for me) and the Cuchilla (mezcal based, well balanced - loved this)
- Since it's not Giants season, parking was pretty easy out front, still 25 cents an hour until 10pm

I made a reservation online about 4 weeks ahead for a Tuesday dinner for 5 people, and it wasn't too hard to get.
author: Marilyn T.

description: LOVED this place!! Every single person was super welcoming and helpful, even when they were trying to close up. We went there for our anniversary and the waitress was so sweet, she put a candle on our desert. Seriously everybody was awesome and definitely made me want to go back. The only tiny complaint I had was that the food was a little over salty for me but otherwise the ribeye was the best ribeye I've ever had!! It's a must to go here for good priced awesome good and environment!
author: Morgan B.

description:
Warm Open faced deviled egg sandwich for lunch - off the charts great!
Started with a dozen oysters & the Buratta/ pea tendrils/ sugar snap peas -  terrific. 
Warm rock shrimp sandwich - also great.

Tables are close together; service is a tad slow - but, super pleasant and well worth it! (it ain't cheap) .. 
Lunch for 2 - w/ a glass of wine & 1 drink - $104 plus tip.
author: A H.

description:
It's really not bad. But it's really not great, either. For every hit, there was a miss. 

Hit: calamari and chorizo tartine. Spicy, flavor, greens. Excellent. 
Miss: bone marrow. Almost no marrow in two bones. 
Hit: liver mousse, mainly for the lovely marmalade accompanying it. 
Miss: pretzel nuggets. Basically the ones from Trader Joe's. 

There wasn't anything terrible or inedible. And yes, I know, SFO prices are higher. I'm just profoundly underwhelmed. Not a good value, and serves basically the universal hipster menu.
author: Alik W.

description: this place is overrated. I booked a table for business lunch but this place is way too crowded and noisy. ordered oysters but they were too 'malnourished'...fried brussels were pretty much all burnt and too greasy. I gave 2 stars only because their staff are truly good servers and very attentive to our needs.
author: Skylar G.

description:
Marlin crushed it tonight. Service, check! Food, freaking CHECK! And the attention to detail was amazing. It was my mom's birthday and they really made it feel special. Everyone -- not just our server -- was on point and made our experience a 10/10. Thank you Marlowe!

PS GREAT dry vodka martinis
author: Andrea S.

description:
The menu has something for all and for every meal. Many know that this is my favorite restaurant and I've been here countless times. That is only once in the new large and bright location with new menu that makes the experience even better!

I could go on and on about how the brussel sprout chips are amazing and they serve the best pork chop in the city ... but let the others do the talking as well. Make a reservation. Go here. It won't get any better without costing you an arm and a leg. 

Lunch - amazing burger. Best in town. New pop out window is happening.

Dinner - anything. From fish to pork chop to brussel sprout chips paired with whatever.
author: Joseph L.

description:
This place has great atmosphere and a modern but industrial feel to it. 

We all had the burger which was pretty good but not great.

Duck liver was good and rich and tasty. The bread was crispy on outside soft on the inside. I'd highly recommend it though duck liver isn't for everyone.

Ordered the corpse reviver 2, drink was strong but the strength of it overpowered the drink so it didn't taste particularly refreshing.
author: Derrick C.

description:
The food was ok. We came in a party of two. We ordered a diet coke, bloody mary, 1/2 a dozen oysters on the half shell, brussel sprout chips, broccolini, and a marlowe burger (medium rare). It took about 15 minutes for a bloody mary and diet coke to come out. When the food came out, the marlowe burger was well done. We would have told someone had someone came to check on us, but nope. One thing that can be said is the brussel sprout chips were delicious. So was the broccolini. This is probably the saving grace, and the only reasons I gave 2 stars. 

The service, terrible. We noticed they put us in this nook/cranny area in the front where the big bay windows were. No biggie. The issue began to arise when it took forever to get our initial order in. As I mentioned earlier, it took about 15 minutes to get our drink order. Mind you, it was a diet coke and bloody mary. How long does a diet coke take to pour? 15 minutes apparently. I noticed the food took a little longer. Especially because a table of 4 who sat down approximately 20 minutes after us received their food before we did. (Yaaayyyyyy... -_-) 

Let's proceed to the check. Remember how we were sitting near the bay window? Yes... We watched our server walk out the door. Yep. Right out the door. Didn't even bother to tell us she was leaving. No check. Maybe someone else was taking over? After waiting for 15 minutes, we finally asked the hostess what was going on. She then proceeded to tell us that we had no specific waiter, and it was pooled. I don't really care. Just give me my tab and let me get out of this place.

Tipped the bare minimum since I used to work in the service industry. Maybe that's why I was so aware of how ridiculous the service was. It wasn't even busy, which makes it even more ridiculous. I've never left less than 15%. Today was the day. Food was lacking. I spent over $80 total, just to get annoyed. I won't be coming back.
author: Stina H.

description: We went to this place last night and it was just incredible! We had bone marrow which was smokey and perfectly cooked. Next we had steak tartare which melted in your mouth with a little placed quail egg. We then ordered the burrata which was on a piece of toast with prosciutto, jam and figs plus arugula. Everything was just amazing. We had the duck mouse but honestly it was just too rich for us. It is now on my list of best cocktails. I got the juicer and it was absolutely insanely delicious. Will absolutely be coming back.
author: Savannah O.

description:
Marlowe is delicious and I am obsessed with the decor. It is so cute. I've had both brunch and dinner. I would say I enjoyed dinner more. 

brussel sprout chips- 5/5 these are great and I love the sauce, but they're salty little guys. 
half dozen oysters- 5/5 very fresh
smoked salmon & english cucumber- 5/5 this is my favorite dish. I absolutely loved this. The salmon was so good and I love the creme fraiche
spiced jumbo gulf shrimp- 2/5 these did not do it for me. They were very fishy tasty. 
steak tartare- 3/5 good, but I don't think I'm a hug steak tartare person in general. 
burger- 5/5 this burger is the bomb. And the fries ermagawd. I love the horseradish aioli they come with and I am not even a big horesradish person.

brunch 
I ordered the smoked salmon bagel in hopes that it would be as good as dinners smoke salmon, but it was mediocre. 3/5
buttermilk pancakes - 5/5 those are very very good.

I will say that brunch to me was a bit over priced. 

Overall I really like Marlowe and would highly recommend dinner.
author: Gabrielle C.

description: Came for a work lunch & had a wonderful experience -- didn't feel rushed at all, the restaurant is SO CUTE, the food is amazing (ORDER THE BURGER OR CHICKEN SANDY!) - can't complain :)
author: Riley M.

description: Connor made us the best shot, he called it the pizza party. Haha actually I've come back two weekends in a row with some friends from out of town. This place is amazing. I love the drinks, and the asparagus appetizer.
author: Chelsea S.

description: Great Place to eat and have a few drinks! Loves the boon marrow :)
author: Clifford H.

description:
Excellent Mushroom soup and good fries with horseradish sauce. 

There's not much space to sit, especially at the bar. The seats are squeezed very close together, and it can get loud to the point of not being able to listen someone sitting right next to you, but it's a popular restaurant in SF so not that surprising.

The server is friendly and jolly, wish I could catch his name but couldn't coz it is so damn LOUD.
author: Siddhartha G.

description:
Delicious burger, but that's about all I enjoyed.

$13 little gem salad was overpowered by raw onion slices. Boring dressing. Avocado in the salad was just some sad looking guacamole slabbed on a couple of gem lettuce leaves. Booooring. 

Grilled asparagus appetizer was way too oily, under seasoned. Fried egg was cooked perfectly, but the star vegetables definitely didn't shine.

For the price point, I wouldn't come back.
author: Michelle K.

description: Food is good and good portions; however, the service time can be long and our waiter took a while before letting us know our main food orders were backed up.
author: John I.

description:
3.5 stars. I came here recently on a Thursday night with a group of 4. I mostly wanted to try this place because it's on the Eater 38 list. We ordered a half dozen oysters, crispy brussels sprout chips, and burrata toast as appetizers. The appetizers were probably the highlight of the meal -- the oysters were very fresh and the brussels sprouts were crispy with just the right amount of salt. For my entree, I ordered the stuffed sole. While the fish was cooked perfectly, the flavors of this dish weren't spectacular. We also ordered the smokey baked cauliflower as a side to share, which was really like mac 'n cheese in texture and flavor. Overall, I wasn't blown away by this place, but there were some highlights.

-L.
author: Leeann C.

description:
I did some Googling on my drive into San Francisco and it seemed clear to me that my first meal should be Marlowe. I like burgers, I like horseradish. What else could be done?

I hadn't eaten anything substantial for about 8 hours by the time I got to Marlowe, so I went all out: I ordered myself the roasted bone marrow, and the Marlowe burger.

Having never had bone marrow before, I can compare it to anything. But it was so delicious. I'm not sure if it was because of how ravenously hungry I was, but that bone marrow tasted much like what I would imagine God's semen would taste like. Salty, but so deeply umami. I wanted to bathe myself in it, just so that I could lick my arms throughout the remaining day and still taste it.

I ordered the Marlowe burger cooked medium, and what I got was decidedly rare, but it, too, was absolutely delicious. There was not a bad thing about it, really. The fries were perfectly seasoned, the horseradish aioli was perfection. It didn't seem like the horseradish aioli was on the burger, just some mayo I think, as I didn't taste any horseradish on the burger itself.

I ate every single bite of everything. They delivered a free ("a gift for you!") deviled egg before my meal, even. My first deviled egg ever. It was, you know, an egg...

The place itself, the waitresses and all, is very typical "nice-ish bar/restaurant". Nothing interesting or unique about it. This was the first restaurant I've been to (disclaimer: I am low class) where after you move your silverware and napkin yourself, the waitresses move them back into position before serving your food. Both me and the other solo guy sitting across from me got complimentary silverware re-placements twice I think. So fancy!...? 

After my meal I walked the 30 minutes to Union Square, saw a play (surprisingly about digital pedophiles?!) and went back to my hotel room to go to sleep. Right as I was trying to fall asleep, maybe 4 hours after eating at Marlowe, I started to feel extremely nauseated and couldn't sleep. Short story even shorter, I had to run to the bathroom where I emptied my stomach into the toilet. Probably the most uncomfortable instance of throwing up I've ever suffered through. But after I felt just fine, fell asleep with no problem (aside from that I felt like I had chunks of puke in my throat that no amount of water would wash away), and the next day I felt 100% all better.

My suspicion is that my "not medium" burger was just a little too rare. I really don't know. It's been a long time since any kind of food made me do that. The main thing is that the food was totally delicious and I am willing to accept the fact that I puked my guts out as a outlier that isn't at all representative of the place. That said... probably won't be eating there again when I visit SF. Too many other choices!
author: Brad R.

description:
Food tasted good, but wasn't impressed with the presentation. 

I went back recently and had a couple Manhattans which are my favorite cocktail. Spot -On!
author: Andrew L.

description:
Stopped in here at an odd time (between 2:30 and 5 pm) so it was bit slow and they were only serving the between lunch and dinner menu. But I decided to give it a shot since dinner can get busy and waits get long.

I ordered the baked oyster, which was prepared in the most interesting and surprising way. A deep shelled oyster cup held a barely roasted oyster as well as a spoonful of a flavorful chowder. They were served on a bed of rock salt, a beautiful presentation. The chowder underscored the freshness of the oyster and provided some substantiality to the appetizer bite.

I also ordered the shrimp cocktail. Five prawns, delicately peeled but with the heads still attached for sucking, came accompanied with a spicy cocktail sauce that the waitress recommended squeezing lemon into. They were luscious, barely cooked, flavorful, and the roe from the head heightened the luxury of the bites.

Cocktails were perfectly executed, and the wine selection isn't bad either. Overall, highly recommended.
author: Lawrence H.

description:
I love the aesthetic of this place. The service is great and everyone who works here is very friendly. 

I had the fried chicken sandwich and was impressed. I'm from Kentucky. I know my fried chicken. I will come back here again for sure!
author: Claire W.

description:
The new space is lovely, the lighting is and seating is nice, but the place is  LOUD. 

Years ago when we went to Marlowe I wasn't eating meat, and missed out on the much raved about burger.

My husband and I  had a deviled egg, which were perfection. The perfect amount of creamy, spicy and salty with a great crunch, all in a few bites.

We also  split the burger and fries, and the NY steak.

Our burger was overcooked, and we sent it back and got a replacement FAST. I'm 
 guessing they grabbed someone else's.

The burger and fries were delicious, and the steak was fantastic.
 This is actually the first time I've eaten steak in a restaurant in forever.
It was seasoned and cooked nicely, I enjoyed much more than I was expecting. It was a smallish portion, considering no starch comes with it.
This seems to be the current trend, but c'mon, throw a couple roasted potatoes on or something :)

 We remembered liking dessert here, so we decided to split the their "chocolate cream pie." . It's actually more like  pudding in a jar with a layer of cookie crumbs. It was delicious , but it's not a pie.

We had a few cocktails too, they were good, but nothing memorable.

Service was pleasant, but SLOW. It took a VERY long time to get food, and to pay our bill.
Since the space is new for them, maybe they're still working out some kinks and training new staff.

There's a place much closer to me where I can get similar menu items of the same quality ,so I probably won't be back, unless someone else really want to go.
author: Amanda G.

description: Great food. My favorite dish is CORN SOUP. It's something you need to taste if you're in SF.
author: Andrew T.

description:
A new favorite restaurant. Chic decor with adequate sound absorption thanks to discreet tiles that blend with the ceiling. I hate it when you go to a great restaurant but it's too loud to have a conversation. Not only could we talk comfortably, but got in some fun people-watching. And we ate so well! Much of it is comfort food elevated to an art form, but still retaining that comforting aspect without getting heavy. The hubs & I shared: 

- the best tomato soup we ever had.
- char/roasted broccolini: smoky, cheesy, tangy, a very pleasant surprise.
- crab & shrimp crepes: scrumptious; make sure you get a little of everything in each bite.
- pea pancakes: the only dish that wasn't a "wow" but definitely tasty & I'd order again.
- bone marrow: perfectly cooked & seasoned, served w/a caper-filled salsa verde that nicely balanced the richness of the marrow.
- burger: get it with everything, especially the horseradish aioli. omg. excellent.
- meyer lemon buttermilk pannacotta: YUM. rich & creamy, cut with an intense strawberry sorbet.

Also the cocktails were well-made and I was able to taste a couple different wines to ensure I got a glass I liked (I recommend the Crozes Hermitage Syrah with the burger). Friendly and attentive service. I can't wait to come back and order the items we didn't try this first time! N.B. We had a reservation so there was zero wait to get in.
author: Sian K.

description: Visited this place twice and am looking forward to go again. Their deviled eggs was one of the best and although I've heard more good things about the burger I enjoyed the chicken sandwich much more. Probably would have loved it even more if the batter weren't so salty otherwise it was all great! Oh and the kale salad was also refreshing and good.
author: Sujin W.

description:
I really liked Coco 500, but I like Marlowe better. 

Outstanding, friendly, fast service. Tasty roasted Brussels sprouts and fries with horseradish aioli hit the spot. The excellent and well-priced Croatian white wine was a terrific accompaniment.
author: Kim C.

description:
I don't think it necessarily lives up to all the hype of having 2000 reviews and 4 stars, but it's still a great fine dining experience - especially considering the reasonable pricing. 

We ordered the half dozen oysters and the bone marrow to start. Oysters were good - pretty standard oysters for fine dining. Bone marrow had really nice flavor, especially with all the stuff it comes with: toasted bread, sauce, cilantro, etc. 

For the main dishes, the waiter recommended the marlowe burger, the pork chop, and cauliflower for the side. The burger was fairly good. It has a bit of a horseradish flavor to it though, so I can see that some people wouldn't love it. The pork chop was really good - one of the better pork chops I've had, and I'm really not a fan of pork. Very tender and great flavoring. 

The cauliflower was really good, too! It's more like a mac&cheese dish but with cauliflower instead of macaroni. So don't expect roasted cauliflower or anything. 

Overall, nice ambiance, pretty good food for a reasonable price. Very good but won't blow you away.
author: Andy H.

description:
Had the deviled egg, polenta, and grilled asparagus. All I have to say is YUM. My hubby and I loved every bite! The deviled egg is really interesting and definitely not like any other deviled egg I have ever had. I could probably eat those all day long. My husband had the polenta although I grabbed a bite. I thought it was yummy and he loved it but he did say it was a heavier brunch item than what he was expecting, probably because of the polenta and mushrooms. The grilled asparagus was awesome but spicy. I liked that they added greens to offset the spiciness so it had a lot of balance. 

Overall really great. One thing to note is that we did make reservations because of the holiday weekend. Not sure if it's a norm but it was definitely necessary in our case. Staff was great and we truly loved the place!
author: Marzena P.

description:
There's always a little bit of a wait here but nothing too crazy or over 45 minutes for two people. We usually put our names down and then go around the corner for drinks. 

This place is 5-star worthy for the bone marrow appetizer alone. I don't know who their butcher is, but it's just the most generous cut of fatty richness you can find.  I have dreams about it. Other restaurants, even top rated ones, don't come close.

The service is also good here (usually, I sit at the bar) and bartenders know their stuff.
author: Var N.

description: Rustic new American restaurants are so in right now! Marlowe was great and definitely fits in that category. I went there for a late dinner, and only had to wait 10 minutes for a table. Because I wasn't extremely hungry, I ordered a side of brown butter brussels sprouts and the bone marrow. While I thought the dressing/sauce on the sprouts was just a tad strong (though that's very subjective), the bone marrow was delicious. For someone who was at a 4/10 on the hunger scale, the food was just the right amount. In addition, the service was really great. Our waitress was very attentive and we never had to wait long if we needed something.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Marlowe is a gem in the rough. 

A cute, intimate little spot tucked away in SF. Marlowe screams date night like no other place I've been to. Dim lit, small tables, close.

Roasted Bone Marrow and the Marlowe Burger. The bone marrow was really good. My second outing with it and like it better this time. The salsa was a little much but still worked in very small amounts. The burger was decent, not as amazing as everyone said, but decent.

The food, in my opinion, isn't the draw here, it's the ambiance. Nevertheless, you should make a stop here.
author: David T.

description:
Expectations when it comes to dining establishments are a mixed blessing.
Our group had decided to come here for an impromptu late evening birthday dinner after a Giants game, as many of us have heard flattering comments about Marlowe. 

Our experience started off on the wrong foot when our waitress stoutly refused to add mushrooms to my buddy's burger. She explained the chef on a daily basis rations their mushrooms for their polenta. I understand and respect policy, however it was 10 minutes before the kitchen was closing and more importantly, it was just poor customer service to at least not talk to the kitchen staff(even it was just for show). Further, the hostess came over to explain the same policy with even more of a staunch attitude. Our waitress had to repeat our order several times, was a bit too eager to repeatedly remind us that the kitchen was closing soon, and in general was twitchy with a subtle "let me out of here" attitude. As my buddy was openly trying to rationalize to our table their #MushroomPolicy we caught her rolling her eyes as she was walking by. In her defense, she did keep checking in on us and refilled our water glasses several times.

The Steamed Clams were decent(if not a bit bland), the Brussels Sprouts side was pedestrian, the Steak Tartare was again bland. In general, none of the dishes we shared were spectacular. I will say, the Chocolate Cream Pie and the Strawberry and Rhubarb Crisp desserts were solid. 

The space is quaint, small, intimate, and there were several long communal tables. I imagine this would be an above average happy hour spot. As a bonus, they're located directly across the Caltrain station. Unfortunately, there are just too many dinner and drink spots in the great city that is San Francisco for me to choose to return to Marlowe any time soon.
author: Dennis W.

description:
I honestly really wanted to like this place. The food is good and so many of my friends love it, but seriously the service i've experienced has been horrendous. My first time there I arrived for my reservation on time, however, apparently our table wasn't ready yet and the host said you can try and find some room at the bar otherwise you can wait outside. luckily it was summer and not cold out, but I was immediately turned off by his attitude. I thought, ok it was just a host and gave this place a second chance a few weeks ago with some girlfriends.

Again, we arrived for our reservation and was seated right away. However, we sat for almost 20 minutes with NOT ONE server coming to greet us. The only interactive we had was a busser giving us water. FINALLY, after 15 minutes I had to ask the busser to go get a server. After waiting an additional 5 minutes, she apologized that we had been waiting long, but that was it. Definitely left a bad taste in my mouth for the rest of the evening. 

Honestly, there is ZERO excuse for being ignored especially when you have at least 3 servers walking by our table and one of them had gone by the table next to us TWICE without a single glance in our direction.

I really wanted to like this place because I think the food is great, but my second time going I remembered why I didn't like it. From my experience this place is overly-pretentious and disgustingly snobby. If you come here for the burger, go spend your $20 dollars elsewhere, like at Chez Maman or Monk's Kettle.
author: Micki C.

description:
I rarely feel the need to ever write reviews, but I had to rave about the service at Marlowe. We came in with a group of 10 (originally 13) for my best friend's going away party. Our waters were constantly filled and as soon as our cocktails were finished, we were immediately asked if we wanted another round. City dwellers know how long it can take to get a drink in SF.

Our server, the sweetest server I have ever had was very attentive and patient with our big group. A friend of mine ordered without realizing there was prosciutto with the burrata (she doesn't eat pork). Our server overheard and immediately apologized and took care of it, even if it was totally on us. 

She even made great recommendations, the "BAKER" cocktail is a MUST. Refreshing, smells wonderful, and somewhat sneaks up on you. Brussel sprout chips are nice and salty (in the best way) and the burger was super juicy and flavorful. I was so full but finished everything. We all left full and completely astounded by how wonderful the service was with only one server and our big group.
author: Veronica s.

description:
Marlowe is one of those restaurants I've very much anticipated going to especially since it's gotten a lot of good buzz. With all that anticipation came with just the same amount of disappointment.

The food was mediocre, is it bad to say the only thing I enjoyed was the baked oyster? Perfectly seasoned and fresh and hot when served, highly recommend as an appetizer if you come by here. Also I had the baked cauliflower which was something I would have probably enjoyed if I was 10. Imagine mac and cheese with cauliflower bits instead of macaroni. I was hoping for more of the cauliflower but the bits were just swimming in cheese.
The raved about Marlowe burger was faaaar from what I thought. A lackluster burger with a dry bun and overcooked patty. Nothing special here. Im quite upset that it turned out so bland because I was really anticipating this the most.

Decor and ambience is friendly, casual and comfortable. Service is decent and there isn't too long of a wait for walk-ins.
author: Veronica L.

description: 6 of us went to brunch at Marlowe. Very tasty food and friendly service - a bit pricey for brunch ($2.5 for half of a deviled egg) but overall we liked the food enough to try many things. We all agreed that the restaurant was chilly and drafty so it would have been nice to be seated away from the door. Would return to try more of the menu and the cocktails.
author: Caroline K.

description: What a horrible lousy lazy host. She's a brunette works on Sunday afternoon. No greeting nothing, she saw us and used hand gestures TWO with her fingers. Is she deaf? Or too bad mood after a long night of partying. And she has her stares on me. So weird and strange. We left right away!
author: Clemencia S.

description:
Been dying to try this place for ages. The verdict? Contrary to public belief, the burger isn't the best in SF (it's solid but not my favorite), but the rest of the food is incredible.

I had the best polenta of my life here -- order this dish for sure, especially if you like mushrooms.

The brussel sprout chips with bacon is an increasingly common dish at restaurants but they do a great rendition here.

The steak tartare (accompanied by a poached egg, arugula and crostini) is some of the best in the city.

The french fries are skinny (but not too skinny) and crisped to perfection.

I usually don't order dessert but my dining companion insisted. My advice is to skip the peanut butter pretzel nuggets -- I know they sound amazing but they're definitely NOT worth it. They tasted like frozen pieces of candy that had been sitting in the fridge for far too long.

I must come back next time to try their cocktails (I was driving so had to pass this time around) and their bone marrow.

Even though the burger was overrated, I still give Marlowe 5 stars because the rest of their dishes was so sound and their rustic decor is so on point.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Great ambiance and staff but I was totally disappointed with the burger.  $17 and the flavor just didn't do it for me and it definitely wasn't worth the money. It was far too rich and the bun was not fresh.  The fries were fine but not world-class as they claimed. That said my friend got the polenta and really loved it so I guess I just ordered wrong.
author: Jordan M.

description:
This place .... gee what can I say.... experience was nice and ok until the waiter became rude and unprofessional at the end of our meal

Came here for a birthday dinner for my cousin 
There were 4 of us ladies
Had dinner reservations so we were seated right away
