We started with the Burrata toast, (Burrata is an Italian soft cheese) it had a great pistachio crumble. The portion size was large enough that it could have been shared by a foursome. I had the polenta which was rich and creamy and friend had the chicken, it was amazingly moist. Our server suggested the chocolate cream pie. It was not your traditional pie, served in a short mason jar it was layered salty, chocolaty, cookie crumble, chocolate pudding, and a dollop of wimp cream.

The decor is simple with white walls, banquet seating and cow accents. The services was great attentive but not intrusive. I will definitely be back as more on the menu intrigued me.
author: Rachel G.

description:
First of all. The building structure is extremely awkward. I could not believe that there was a pole that literally went diagonally through the table. As I was talking to my friend, we were literally ducking below the pole or poking out heads above it to speak. I mean, we lucked out with spots, but it was just frustrating overall.

I tried the burger, and honestly my favorite part was the horse radish aioli. It was different and refreshing. The meat was a tad overcooked for everyone based on our requests, but the overall burger was not bad. I also ordered a lager to go with my steak, and was disappointed that they only offered bottled beer and none on tap.

The atmosphere of the location was decent (besides the pole..) and the burger was not bad. When I get the chance, I do want to return and try the pork chop or steak however, as well as the brussel sprout chips. I wish they would offer some beer on tap though!
author: Michael L.

description:
food 3.5/5
service 3/5

-brussel sprout chips were yummy.  super crisp and thin.  also super tiny.  
-deviled eggs were also yummy but it was also nothing special.  at 2.50 a pop you kind of expect a bit more, but again, not bad.
-baked oysters was probably my fave out of the bite menu.  if it didn't come out looking like an oyster i may have eaten it without even knowing it was an oyster.  it's super rich and creamy.  3.50 per oyster i believe.

boyfriend and i shared the pork chop entree.  i think the playground has messed up all future pork chops to be eaten.  i always expect something as delicious as that and am disappointed when it doesn't even come close.  they split up the entree without us even asking so that was nice, but it also left us confused when he served us two plates with no explanation.  this is where my service rating comes in.  our server was very short with us.  no explanations, no questions, no nothing.  he almost looked annoyed to have to serve us, but we did come near closing time, so i'm going to assume that was it.  the pork chop, although a bit on the fatty side, was actually pretty good, and i finished my plate.  

boyfriends friend ordered the steak, and it didn't quite come out cooked the way he asked, but he seemed to enjoy it.

would drop in again if we were in the area, but probably wouldn't go out of my way to go.
author: Jin L.

description:
Everything was perfect. The burger was cooked just enough but not too much. The complementary ingredients on the burger were fresh and flavorful. The salad had this nice salty edge to it. For dessert, we had a chocolate pudding with a graham and Oreo crumb foundation. It was incredible. We also had tasty and unique deviled eggs to start. Oh and great drinks (mixed drinks for him, wine for me). 

It was one of those meals that I want to repeat each time I return. But, dammit, I'm going to have to try the rest of their menu. My guess is that everything is just as good. Can't wait.
author: Melissa R.

description: The devil egg was really good. It almost makes me want to pop a couple down. Not too hot but has a little nice kick to it. It would make for an amazing canapé. The whiff of truffle oil made me just want to devour the polenta immediately. The mushrooms were decadent. The polenta itself was nice could could be a little more seasoned. The French toast soldiers came with such a delightful coffee creme that I almost wanted to drink it down. It felt like eating churros. Probably one of the best brunch places I've had in the city. The table was a bit wonky which caused my friend's coffee to spill. Not too acceptable for an establishment like Marlowe to have such tables. The food was good and was probably definitely worth the money we spent on it.
author: Han Teng W.

description:
The overall atmosphere of this place is great. It's filled with so many people to make it lively, yet you can still hear your friends when speaking to each other across the table! Their drink menu isn't very comprehensive IMO, and they aren't stocked up with various types of liquor to make you others. I think the waitresses are amazing! Ours checked up on us multiple times, and always made sure we were well taken care of.

The food is somewhere in between "Ehh I can get this elsewhere.." and "OMG I NEED MORE OF YOU IN MY BELLY!" depending on what you get. My favorite thing from the entire night was the bone marrow. Not many places serve this, because it's a little hard to come by, and not all the places that do serve it do it right. I'm glad to say that Marlowe does Bone Marrow perfectly, and I'd happily come back for more. That being said, their burger was okay; it wasn't amazing and i definitely felt like I could buy it anywhere. 

The main thing that makes this a 3-star experience was the wait for our table. We came 15 minutes early for our reservation at 9:30. We were told that we should be seated early. Our table was ready to go at about 9:25 or so, but when it came time to seat us, our hostess was busy chatting it up with co workers...and the table was literally right in front of her. We weren't seated for 15 minutes, and we were ravenous. 

I'd still come back though (hopefully I'll be seated at the right time) and get my fill of bone marrow :D
author: Thuy T.

description: I thought I'd *love* everything, but some items were disappointing (my expectations weren't well-managed based on Yelp pictures). I particularly liked the bone marrow and brussel sprout chips. Other items I tried were the baked oysters, burger and fries, duck liver toast, NY steak strip.
author: Kimmy P.

description: my husband and I came here before seeing the awesome Hamilton!  Marlowe's made for a great start to our evening.  The wine list and cocktails are delicious and the food was divine.  Service was really good, they were packed, but we didn't feel left waiting.
author: Lisa C.

description:
3/5 stars
Finally tried this place out.

Meh, it was okay, but not great.

Three awesome things that night were:
1) Good company
2) Brussel sprout chips
3) Anson Mills Polenta
author: Jen H.

description:
An amazing little place in SoMa. Items on the menu aren't necessarily unique, but everything is well cooked. Be sure to go with a group so that you can try a little bit of everything!

Brussel Sprout Chips: Great dish to pick at and share. I love the crunch and the sea salt, but it was just a bit oily for me. Definitely worth trying.

Duck Liver Toast: Duck liver--so buttery and rich. Enjoyed this dish.

Roasted Bone Marrow: flavorful, rich, maybe a little too much to go with the duck. I would get one or the other.

Marlowe Burger: Definitely a fan of this one. The meat is super juicy and flavorful. The cheddar went perfectly with the caramelized onions. Wished the fries were a little more crispy than soft.

Pork Chop: this one was definitely my favorite. The pork was so soft and tender and practically melted in your mouth. I was impressed by the side veggies as well. The flavors of the pork were definitely infused into the veggies. I also really loved the pumpkin pudding that was just slightly sweet and had the consistency of mashed potatoes.

The food, combined with the environment and awesome service, made this five stars for me.
author: Jade L.

description: My friends and I went here for dinner the other night before a show.  Outstanding!  FANTASTIC food and great energetic ambiance! Our service was excellent, despite the packed restaurant. We started with the crispy Brussels Sprouts Chips, which I could not stop eating (kinda like potato chips, once my hand is in the bag, it's a forgone conclusion that I will empty the bag!)  For dinner, I ordered the Poulet Vert with pancetta, Brussels sprouts hash and sweet potato puree. Absolutely delicious.  We also ordered a side of the Smokey Baked Cauliflower with provolone and smokey cheddar. So smooth and silky! Yummm! I am still thinking about this meal several days later.  That's when I know this is a "winner" in my book and that I will be back soon!  To note: Recommend taking Uber or a taxi, as this location is a challenge to drive to during rush hour on a weeknight as well as to find parking.
author: Ellen F.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend for brunch on a Sunday. Note that it seems like for weekend brunch you pretty much have to have a reservation or they won't be able to seat you. They said their tables were booked all day and we were only seated as walk ins because we had two and there happened to be open spots at their small side window bar. We saw them then away other parties afterwards with no reservations, so we just got lucky!

We started with the deviled eggs. These were super cute and delicious! The jalapeño gave them a nice kick and made these a little more unique than more ordinary deviled eggs.

I had the dungeness crab and shrimp crepe. This was alright to me; I wouldn't order it again. The whole dish overall was bland and lacked in any flavor other than the salt from the crab and shrimp.

My boyfriend liked his Marlowe burger a lot, and I LOVED the fries. The aioli sauce was delicious and the fries were perfectly cooked and seasoned. Could not stop eating them.

Service was slow but they were very busy.
author: Connie H.

description:
I'm a big fan of this restaurant and this was my third time there. My friend and I were running late and originally planned to be at the restaurant around 6 pm.  figured it wouldn't be that crowded on a Wednesday night. We got there around 6:15 and there was a 30 minute wait. Prior to this visit the restaurant opened at 6 pm, so I was usually guaranteed a seat if I got there early however they are now open all day. 

The hostess told my friend she'd call her once the seats were available. We waited in the area that was standing only. lol only in SF...she pointed to the area with a small shelf thats thin enough to hold a menu and we stood in the middle of the restaurant until our table was available. 

I love the restaurants brussel sprouts which is one of the appetizers, but opted for the burger as this is one of their best dishes and it comes with fries. I would not be able to finish my entree if I'd also had the brussel spouts. The burger was really good and my friend agreed that it was good. She also ordered deviled eggs, but I didn't want to eat them as there were only 2. 

All in all I give this place a solid 4.
author: Ebonie M.

description:
Heard so much about Marlowe and finally got a reservation on a rainy night. The service was great, but the food was way too salty for my taste. Interesting ideas though!

- Brussel sprout chips: really good, but too salty to eat many bites. Also, kinda greasy and portion is too big for 2 people =\
- Crab souffle: this was probably the best dish of the evening! But again, salty.
- Burger: it was pretty good, but too much mayo/mustard.
- Poulet vert: chicken was cooked very tender... but too salty!!
- Panna cotta: spot on.
author: Sherry L.

description: Marlowe is currently my favorite place to dine in San Francisco and lucky for me, it's just a few blocks away from my apartment. Every time I've been to Marlowe, the service has been exceptional, the food is always delicious, and I always leave totally satisfied. I've tried just about everything on their menu, but here are a few faves: the Marlowe burger (comes with yummy horseradish aoli), scallops with cranberry beans, fried okra, you HAVE to get the brussels sprout chips - they're a Marlowe staple. You really can't go wrong with their menu! I suggest getting a reservation and you'll need to do that at least a few days in advance if you're planning to eat during prime dinner hours. But, if you walk in, they are super accommodating and are great at squeezing people in.
author: Hannah C. R.

description: Marlowe.. the trendy hipster restaurant delivers on multiple levels. The service is impeccable and the food doesn't disappoint. Get the bone marrow, Brussels sprout chips and the Marlowe burger. The deviled eggs are a nice starter. For my veg friends, the Polenta is delicious! Even if you're not vegetarian, you have to try it!!
author: Lyndsi L.

description:
I've been to Marlowe twice and ordered/shared the deviled egg, sprout chips, beets, polenta, burger, and steak frites.  Everything was good though not great, and consistently too salty.  The sprout chips, polenta, and steak were especially salty, so if you want any of these then it's advisable to tell them you have hypertension and have them put half the normal amount of salt.

I found the service here just ok.  They're not especially friendly or descriptive, but it's not terrible either.

I felt the prices here were on the high side for what you get.  The beets especially were kind of ridiculous at $12 for the small amount you get.  Last time there I shared the beets, had two glasses of wine, the steak and a dessert and it came to $90 after tax and tip -- too pricey and not a good value.  SF has many other options at that price point that would be preferable.

Overall I wouldn't avoid Marlowe, but I wouldn't seek it out either.
author: Jeff D.

description: Fantastic brunch spot. Made a reservation ahead of time so beat the wait. Food was delicious and coffee was delightful. The staff was also very nice. Atmosphere and decor were very good. Overall a pleasant experience.
author: Yessenia M.

description:
Made last minute late reservations. Easily found street parking close by (the surrounding area is well lit) and were greeted by 2 courteous hostesses. Because we were really early for our time slot, we waited in this little standing area and an upbeat server took our drink orders and within minutes we had the drinks in our hands.

We were seated 15 minutes before our reservation in a little corner by their kitchen. The smells, draft, and harsh white lighting from the kitchen took away from the cozy ambience that the rest of the restaurant was experiencing. It was a full house and a late reservation, so by the kitchen is where we stayed. 

We had two solid servers but both seemed very tired and looked a bit disheveled. Because this was a late reservation I don't expect my servers to maintain high levels of energy this late into the evening, but the exhausted feels they were giving out took away from my experience here. 

Now the food: first we had the deviled eggs and bone marrow.  I'm actually mad at myself for paying $5 for 1 whole egg. It was good but I wouldn't tell my family and friends to order it. I spread the bone marrow on the toast it came with and could only taste the toast. I couldn't get any flavors from the marrow. (But this is my first time eating bone marrow this way so maybe I don't know what I'm talking about, but I just don't see the hype that surrounds this dish.)

But our main dishes?!?! I was literally clapping my hands in enjoyment. He ordered the steak and I ordered the polenta. The steak was cooked perfectly, had salty and sweet flavors throughout the dish and was very filling. The polenta had everything I loved in 1 bowl: arugula, tons of mushroom, Parmesan cheese and egg. Don't let this dish fool you into thinking it's a lighter main course option...oh no. This dish is hearty. 

The tawny port and Loretta's Vacherin (pronounced vash/ra) ended the meal nicely. 

Overall, this place is ok depending on where you sit-don't sit by the kitchen (also not a big fan of the communal tables there) and stick to their main courses and make sure to get the Loretta's Vacherin.
author: Mae D.

description: This may be the best restaurant in Soma. I've eaten here more times than I can even count and it has become an after work celebration for all of us. Wondering what to order? First, order deviled eggs. The mix of egg, jalapeño, bacon + cheese will have your taste buds doing flips. Then try the Burger and do yourself the ultimate favor by getting the fries on the side!
author: Natalie H.

description:
Maybe my expectations were too high but I wasn't super pumped on this place. I came here for dinner with my family and had heard GREAT things. Nothing we had was all that amazing, the burger was good but not amazing. We got a bunch of appetizers to share, the crispy brussel spouts and burratta salad were my favorite of those. 

The restaurant itself is pretty tiny and has a cramped feel. I was sitting kind of by the bathroom and kept feeling like I was in everyone's ways. The wine list is good, also pretty standard. I probably won't be back, I personally think Park Tavern has much better food and is more reasonably priced.
author: Lizzy U.

description: Super tasty burger, intimate but loud setting, really nice service,
author: Lori S.

description:
After picking an out-of-town friend up from the airport, we were on the hunt for something fabulous to eat in the city via Yelp. I'd narrowed our options down to three, and she made the final choice: Marlowe. I am beyond thrilled we stumbled upon this place! Very hole-in-the-wall, but will exceed your expectations once inside. Definitely get a reservation, as we ended up waiting for about 45 minutes to be seated without one.

You MUST have the deviled eggs, burrata, and Brussels sprouts. Just trust me. I've had the burger and scallops on each of my trips here. Both will be spectacular. I can't wait to go back and try the other menu items!
author: Natalie G.

description:
Revival.

Five star dinner in the original location followed by a three star lunch in the new location. Marlowe was no longer the slam dunk recommend it once was.

Then came brunch: 

- Superb and sublime deviled egg topped provolone, jalapeño and bacon
- Brilliant and beautiful baked eggs with chickpeas, artichokes and harissa
- Divine and delicious strawberry shortcake and coconut lemon filled mini eclairs
- Fresh and fantastic toast topped with smoked fish, poached egg and lemon

Only thing rivaling the food was our server. So friendly and engaging. Plus she gave me a sample of the excellent homemade seeded granola. 

Revival was complete after a Reviver cocktail featuring sparkling wine, Fernet and lemon. Like the food and service it left me satisfied and smiling.

Just about $40/person will let you try all the above. Absolutely worth it.

Marlowe is indeed alive and well.
author: Jason B.

description: always a pleasant experience. food is great. kudos to the staff for the happy & extremely helpful attitude.
author: Tina B.

description:
-----------BRUNCH ONLY-----------
This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city and whenever friends visit from out of town, this is my go-to. They moved and recently opened for brunch and MAN it's spectacular. Seriously. Every single dish was amazing. This has officially become my favorite brunch place in SF.

-Deviled eggs--worth the order. Just get it.
-Kale & Brussels Caesar salad - It's not healthy by any means but it's a warm salad that is way better than I expected it to be. Full of flavor and even my salad-hating friends loved it
-Dungeness crab & shrimp crepe - Oh my GAH this crepe was SO solid. Looks like normal, tastes like heaven. 

Unfortunately they don't do their famous brussel sprout chips for brunch so you'll have to go for dinner too. 

Also, super easy to make a reservation online so no wait!!
author: Diana Y.

description:
Overall solid food.  Chill ambience and great service.     

The brussel sprout chips were my favorite (5/5)
The burrata was also good.  (5/5)
The burger wasn't quite as good as some people make it out to be.  (3/5)

Overall I would go back if in the area.
author: Paul W.

description: Just enjoyed a fantastic dining experience here last night with some forever friends.  First of all...the welcoming staff and atmosphere lent its way into one tasty and flavor filled night.  The atmosphere, decor and charm of this SOMA establishment grabs you upon entering.  Love the flare and style of this place.  We started with Oysters, which were from WA....delish!  The cocktails we tried were so goooood!  My favorite....The Baker!  My husband had the masterful Manhattan which was smooth as silk going down.  We munched on the Brussel Sprout Chips, the Gem salad which was artful, light and just the perfect starter.  I enjoyed the Poulit, friends munched on the signature burger (which one friend claimed was the best burger he has ever eaten), the cod was poached just perfectly...flakey and seasoned nicely.  We all shared three of the desserts....the chocolate cream pie, the chocolate peanut butter bites and the warm cookies.....everything was more than a great treat.  We all had such a grand night that we all will be back again.
author: Nancy M.

description: The Prawns are the business!! Get em, trust me. Also the music always seems to be on point. I'll be back again.
author: Candace G.

description:
I went to eat at Marlowe on a Wednesday night with my boyfriend. We had reservations for 8:30 and got there a little early to get a drink at the bar. 

As you may know, Marlowe is not cheap, but you won't regret what you pay for! The cocktails are incredible. We got 4 drinks throughout the night total: Pimm's Cup, The Baker, Country Lawyer, and The Sow. All were delicious! I would say Pimm's Cup and The Baker were my favorites. 

We started with a Baked Oyster, Deviled Egg, and Bone Marrow. The Bone Marrow was DELICIOUS!!! Worth every penny. You can't get something like this at many restaurants so I highly recommend it! 

For the main entree I got the Poulet Vert (Chicken) with mashed potatoes and veggies. Again, SO DELICIOUS!!!! The chicken was cooked to perfection and very juicy. The veggies complimented the chicken very well. My boyfriend got the New York Steak which was also very tasty. The steak itself needed a bit of salt, but paired with the jus it tasted magnificent. All the food came out at a very nice temperature and made to order. 

For dessert we got the chocolate cream pie which was served in a little round bowl with the crust at the bottom. The chocolate had a very delicious rich taste. My boyfriend loved it!

I didn't take any pictures because it was too dark and I didn't want my flash to go off in such a nice restaurant.

I think my only complaint would be the small space for seating. I like to have my space in between tables and it felt a little crammed. Besides that, the servers were super sweet and attentive. I think this is a great place to take a date ;) 

I would definitely come back here again!
author: Vanessa P.

description: Went to brunch on Father's Day and was very disappointed.  The Chilaquiles Verde needs some serious help.  I almost thought the server brought my plate to me unfinished.  It was tasteless, unfinished looking and boring.  I just had the same dish two weeks ago at The Table in Willow Glen and it was amazing!  I think the chef should visit that restaurant and get some fresh ideas.  As far as my waitress and bartender they were lovely.
author: deborah g.

description:
After a long flight, nothing like a proper meal with some great company.

Reservations were made and we were easily seated with minimal wait.  Always good to see a restaurant accommodate their reservations.  Even at a restaurant as busy as Marlowe.  The location is convenient to the BART terminal station.  And parking wasn't a problem at ~8 on a non-gameday Thursday.  I am lucky with parking...

Brussels Sprout chips, tasted properly seasoned, light and fried.  Not quite healthy, but you knew that already.
The pan seared Arctic char was nicely prepared with the right amount of "char" both literally and figuratively.  I was also extremely pleased with the recommended Grilled Niman pork chop.  The chop was served in two sizable pieces with rich flavor from the fig sauce, along with sausage "coins" and risotto.
I'd recommend all three of the dishes mentioned.

The upside down Strawberry crisp, with bourbon ice cream was delicious to finish off the meal with something sweet.  But I think a proper or classic fruit crisp with a scoop (or two) of bourbon ice cream on top would have been better.   

Overall a great meal.
author: Oliver C.

description:
We had a great time celebrating a birthday at Marlowe. Our server was fantastic, attentive and well-versed. 

The food was delicious. I had the New York Steak and thoroughly enjoyed it!
author: Luke H.

description:
Great brunch on a Saturday, Aug 1, 2015.  
Food overall was 4-5 stars across the board:
- polenta
- deviled eggs
- kale Caesar 
- burger - good but not great. Too much bread for the patty size and meat was not seasoned enough. Still very good.

Drinks were also high performers:
- Butcher and Butcher's Wife. I'm not a big fan of grapefruit in my cocktails, but the Butcher was an exception. 

Service was 5 stars, including bartenders, our waitress, and the hostess. I'm not a fan of the hostess position for many restaurants bc in large part it's either poorly executed, over staffed, or unnecessary (e.g. Most small/med restaurants benefit more from an on-the-ball, roll-up-your-sleeves manager to greet and seat guests in my opinion). Regardless of where you stand on the hostess role, Marlowe's has one who really does a great job - greeting with a smile, welcoming demeanor, fast and efficient processing, personally showed us to the bar while we wait for table, when told bathroom needed attention she instantly had it addressed, and thanked every person who left. 

We'll be back.
author: B A.

description:
Yay for birthday dinners!

I picked Marlowe to be my first of my birthday dinners.  After my friend told me to pick out a place, I looked through my bookmark list and picked out a couple restaurants. Marlowe was ultimately chosen because it was open until 11pm on a Thursday.  

RESERVATION:
We did a walk in, but definitely make reservations!  We walked in close to 9:30pm and the place was still crowded.  Although we only waited about 10 minutes, there were parties still walking in after us.

APPETIZERS:
*Crispy Brussels Sprout Chips - Delicious!  I'm not a Brussels sprouts type of person, I actually despise them, however the chips were crispy and lightly coated with salt.  Simply delicious!
 *Roasted Bone Marrow - GOOOOD!!  The bone marrow was extremely tasty and was served with a salsa verde sauce which had a tiny kick to it.
*Steak Tartare - The tartare was good and tender.  It was served with an egg on top, just the way I like it.

MAIN:
*Marlowe Burger - YUM!!  I knew Marlowe was known for their burger, so that was a must order for me.  In fact, all five in our party ordered the burger.  My burger was cooked to a perfect medium rare and contained caramelized onions, cheddar, and bacon.  Also spread on the bun was a yummy horseradish aioli sauce (an additional dish is served on the side so you could dip your fries).  But note, don't think you can add additional things in the burger, the waitress told us the chef doesn't like people altering her burger.

SERVICE:
Great.  We were immediately greeted by the hostess upon walking in.  She mentioned there would be a 10 minute wait but we were welcome to grab a drink and wait at the bar.  Our waitress was friendly.  She was on top of her game and came over immediately when we had an additional friend come by for dinner.

AMBIANCE:
Marlowe is dimly lit and definitely had a romantic vibe to it.  The noise level was decent in the way where you could hear other parties talking, but it wasn't hard to hear the person you're having a conversation with.

PARKING:
Street metered parking, free after 6pm.  We were able to find parking easily, but it may be difficult on Giants game days since Marlowe is located only a couple of blocks from the park.

Thanks to my friends for a great birthday dinner!
author: Nicole S.

description:
Bone marrow was delish! Came out sizzling on a skillet with a little side of capers.

The Marlowe burger was also good, but not as mind-blowing. You can't really go wrong with bacon, but it made some bits a bit hard/tough and jarring. As I ate it some more, I realized it was a bit too salty. The fries that came with the burger were amazing! Crispy outside and soft inside. Greasy, of course.

Seating is mostly at the common table, which is a really long picnic table with cushioned seats. Obviously a private table is better, but I assume you need to be lucky or have a reservation to get those.

The service was good, though a bit scattered at the beginning of the meal, as they were dealing with a dinner rush. But as the night went on, the service got wayyy better--lots of checking up and water refills. The whole time our server was very friendly and chipper.
author: Chia-Fen Y.

description:
Hands down one of the best meals we had in SF! The service, ambience, the food, even the sayings on the wall: all amazing. 

Had the Vert, marrow, asparagus, and my friend had the scallops. All amazing. 

Can't rave enough. Definitely worth coming back to again when we're in the city!
author: Allie Y.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by this restaurant that tends to cater to the upper middle class ballpark crowd.

I think Marlowe has some good attributes of successful restaurant:

1. Keep the menu small and quality high (Burger, Mushroom polenta)
2. Have some killer desserts (TCHO chocolate pie)
3. Have a signature dish people have to try -- I thought Brussels sprouts are done to death but their Brussels sprout chips were refreshing -- for some reason, the meyer lemon note triggered my memory of Fruity Pebbles cereal. Didn't try the bone marrow, but it piqued my friends' interests.

Service was not too obtrusive and water was filled consistently.
author: William H.

description:
4.5 Stars

A restaurant that plays jams like Monica's "The First Night", Mary J Blige's "Be Without You' and Aaliyah's "Are You That Somebody" can easily get me hooked.  And to boot, Marlowe's food was pretty gosh darn delicious.

-Loved the lemon & salt on the Crispy Brussels Sprout Chips.
-The Louisiana Crawfish Bisque is unique; very tasty.
-The Marlowe Burger is one of the, if not the best, burgers I've ever had.
-The Caesar aioli added great flavor to the Crispy Fried Chicken Sandwich.

Please be mindful of your bench-mate when sitting at a communal table.  Excessive leg-shaking can be extremely annoying.  Thank you.
author: Rose A.

description: Fabulous place. Delicious food. Service is great, helpful, quick and smiley. Great find on the other side of the tracks. Get there!
author: Arek N.

description: Saw an amazing pic of the burger in San Francisco magazine and had to give it a try. Unfortunately I should have just eaten the page from the magazine and might enjoyed the experience about as well. Ingrediens weren't fresh and globes together. Maybe they ran out of ingredients?? They pushed the deep fried Brussel chips which were greasy and salty. The beer was cold and good which is why they were able to salvage a star! I will post a pic of the burger.
author: Pete R.

description:
Marlowe is an interesting combination of trendy and comfort. The interior is small and cozy---just one giant square of a room---but decorated with a lot of class. That's also how I would describe Marlowe's menu.

My friend and I decided to go family style and ordered:
(1) Dark Lager Steamed P.E.I. Mussels;
(2) Anson Mills Polenta; and
(3) Brown Butter Brussels Sprouts.

My friend had been raving about the brussels sprouts for weeks. Maybe that's why the initial bite was a letdown: my expectations had been built up too high. The first sprout was too salty, though it had a nice char to it. But maybe you shouldn't judge a dish by the first bite because the sprouts really grew on me. Maybe that first sprout was just over salted; maybe I just got used to the salt. Who knows?

The mussels were flavorful. Correction: the mussels DISH was flavorful, and that was all thanks to the chorizo. I have never seen this combination before. I like the idea in theory, but the chorizo overpowers the mussels. You don't even realize you're eating seafood. You just think you're eating a lot of spicy sausage. Don't get me wrong: the dish is tasty, but if you're expecting to taste mussels, this isn't the dish to order.

The polenta was nice and creamy with wonderfully sauteed mushrooms and a poached egg (again, I love eggs with most dishes). The arugula was a nice addition because it prevented the polenta from being too monotonous in its texture and buttery taste.

My problem with the mussels and the polenta, however, was that they were cold when we got it, and I really hate cold food. So while everything was good, they didn't blow me out of the water.

But then!!! my friend's fiance showed up and ordered the Grilled Niman Pork Chop. It was my favorite dish of the night. Wonderfully seared, juicy, and the apples/spinach/pudding/sausage added great textures and sweetness to the pork chop without masking its flavors. It's hearty and a big portion.

For dessert (we really indulged tonight), we had the Vanilla Bean Panna Cotta Affogato. It was a high note to end on. 

For the pork chop and panna cotta, I give it 4 stars; but if it were just the first 3 dishes we ordered, it would be closer to 3-3.5.
author: J J.

description:
I tried their burger here and it wasn't my favorite. I asked them to hold the horseradish dressing to the side (so that I could try it myself first) but of course it came in my burger. I didn't find the flavors interesting, although others did, so I think it's one of those places you have to go try for yourself. To me, the food was ordinary but not outstanding. 

Brussels sprout chips were good, although those are hard to go wrong. The place is tiny so make reservations.
author: Allison S.

description:
Two Absolutely fantastic experiences were had at Marlowe in recent weeks.  

At the Bar:  

The first expeirence was snacks and small plates at the bar amongst three of us.  We fell in love with the seasonal toast that did magic with tamarind and cheese and is a triumph.  All of us were blown away by this dish. We started and ended the meal with an order.   

Book-shelved between the toast were Chicken Fried Okra, Oysters, and Deviled Eggs were all fantastic.  Simple concepts that were executed incredibly well and enjoyed with good suggestions from the 

At the Patio:

The second experience was a lovely, romantic dinner on the patio.  We enjoyed the Chicken Fried Okra, English Pea Pancakes (Smoked salmon, caviar & everything spiced creme fraiche), and the Angus NY Steak. We ended the night on with their pretzel bites and coffee.  


The win here is simply dining excellence. Service, setting, and food made for two very different, but very excellent dinners.
author: Anand A.

description: Very nice dinner here with coworkers. Highlights were deviled eggs app and the side of brown butter Brussels sprouts. I had the Sole main dish which was good but a little to oily. The kale on the side was amazing though. Desserts were also great- my favorite was the chocolate mousse pie with marscapone whipped cream. Friendly staff and very nice atmosphere as well. Would definitely try another one of this group of restaurants!
author: Nora C. E.

description: The food was great with reasonable prices but honestly this 5 star is for our server Brandon. My man made sure we were covered for everything and took care of me and my girlfriend so well. If he was off shift I definitely would've bought him some drinks at the bar. Cheers Brandon.
author: Ray S.

description:
Was pretty amped about this place for the burger, since it was on multiple top lists for burgers in SF. I was disappointed. The burger was well-executed, but not sure if we had a bad batch, but both mine and my friend's burger tasted burnt? We looked at the various components of our burger but nothing was charred, so maybe it was just us. Can someone let me know? It could also have been that we were a bit full from the bone marrow & brussel chips that I didn't quite enjoy the burger as much as I could have. (Fries were awethum by the way)

Otherwise, I love the place, and the service is on point. The brussel sprout chips ARE TO DIE FOR. I would like to try to come again (maybe for lunch) and retry the burger (maybe spit it next time). Their other items looked really good too. Saw alotta peeps getting the mussels.
author: Emily C.

description:
Dropped in to this spot for lunch after searching a little of the beaten path- attracted by the space, decor and menus of fresh items. 

As a southerner- always suspicious when fried Okra is listed as appetizer- often send more back than finish...but this one was as good as family receipt in LA (lower Alabama) . 

Food was fresh- items which don't require any condiments proves that the chefs choice of the complementing flavors is perfectly balanced.  Really appreciate the diversity of crowd as the AT&T area has hit defcom 5 of hipster hangouts. It's comfortable and the food was worth the trip-
author: Deeg S.

description:
It's true, I ate here because my daughter's name is Marlowe.  The ratings weren't too shabby either.  My husband and I were on vacation (we go to SF often) and we always pick out where we want to eat in advance.  He wasn't on board with this choice and thought I was pretty lame for having to eat at a restaurant with our daughter's name.  I tried to convince him it would be awesome but I kinda failed.  

We both ordered the "Marlowe" burger (ok, guess he is lame now too since he ordered a burger named after his daughter, right?) and it was just OK.  I did happen to be very sick and nothing was very appetizing but I am a burger fan and this didn't hit the spot whatsoever.  I think my biggest issue was the cheddar cheese on it.  I hate cheddar on my burgers and I shouldn't have ordered it bc of that.   It wasn't awful, just not as awesome as I expected after reading all the other reviews.  We also had the warm deviled eggs, which I felt were really over priced for the size of them.  I swear they seemed like mini eggs, lol.  They were tasty though.  

The place is also very tiny and we were in a corner seat.  In order for the table of 2 next to us to leave their table after eating, we had to get up and move our table into the corner completely and then put it back after they left.  Not a huge deal but thought I'd mention it in case you don't enjoy being that close to people at dinner.  

Ultimately, the place was good but nothing I feel compelled to return to when we visit SF again.
author: Brianne H.

description:
Very San Francisco/hipster restaurant.  Noisy/and happening on a Friday night.

My husband and I wanted a sweet ending to our evening, so we went in for a dessert and sat at the bar.  We ordered this nectarine rum soaked ice cream and berries dessert.  IT WAS DELICIOUS!!!!!!!!!!!!  And if our Lentil could take some more alcohol, the cocktails that were being made at the bar there also looked really great.  

I definitely want to go back and try their regular dinner menu.  Looked very meat heavy (lots of bone marrows being delivered to tables left and right).
author: Arry Y.

description:
American styled small bar restaurant.
Burger and fries are surprisingly good, double fried French fries are very crispy and oysters doesn't have the fish smell as well.
author: Sunny J.

description: The food is delicious: burrata is an amazing mix of surprising ingredients. A bit noisy inside and you can hear a conversation at the table next to yours :-)  But the food is totally worth it. Don't forget a dessert: chocolate mousse is to die for
author: Margo O.

description: Just had a great afternoon happy hour! We are a burger and it was amazing. The side salad was also worthy of praise. We ordered the tomato soup and it tasted like a vodka sauce  so good!! The service was incredible and we had a fun bartender who treated us like gods  she made us special drinks and had us laughing up a storm. We walked over from the train station and then ubered to our hotel. The atmosphere is very modern and well designed.
author: Gregory S.

description: I think the ratings are fair for this place.  I had a good meal (chicken with farro and vegetables) but my husband did not really like his meal and 2 out of 3 appetizers were not good.   I would not come back.
author: Kelly M.

description: Love this spot! One of my favorite places to eat in San Francisco--the bone marrow is delicious.
author: Eva N.

description: Never disappoints. Delicious! Haven't had anything I didn't love. The burger is the best one I've ever had.
author: Laura P.

description: Stopped in to check this place out on my lunch break. I'm so happy they weren't busy, and we're very quick with no loss of food quality. I ordered the burger, and was bummed I didn't know about the deviled eggs which they seem to be known for. Something for which I will be returning to try. The Burger was cooked exactly how I ordered it, and the fries a crispy shell with a warm soft inside, with a parsley garnish. Little pricey, but worth a try once. Very cool inner decor, clean, tidy, and they have maximized the space they use.
author: Ari T.

description: Excellent dinner and wine tasting. I had a tartare which is probably the best ever tasted in my life. I ate so fast I did't have the chance to take a picture. My bf had a good hamburger and I had Brussels sprouts (fresh and tasty) and jumbo shrimps. If I were a citizen of San Francisco I'd visit this venue weekly. The place is nice, employees kind and friendly
author: Valentina C.

description: The burger was good but I didn't think much of it. It wasn't incredible but it wasn't bad. I'd say it was A-OK. Actually the brussel sprouts were more memorable. Can't speak about their other dishes since ive only had the burger and the sprouts. Great looking place though.
author: Thielson D.

description:
Was so excited to try this place out because of all the reviews but customer service was horrible. My friends and I came during a busy time and encountered some very unprofessional workers. We left before being seated and I didn't mind because all the seats/tables were crammed and it wouldn't have been comfortable anyways.

Update: I should have paid more attention to what other reviews said about the business. Most say the food was good but service was bad. I agree with another yelper on the "cocky arrogant workers." It's enough to make you bitter and ruin your dinner experience.
author: Kimmy L.

description: FOUND A PUBIC HAIR IN MY FOOD!  This has never happened in my entire life.  I was stunned and totally put off when I cut into my food and my knife drew out a dark black short public hair!  I sent the plate back and all Marlowe did was take that one item off our bill.  We can NEVER GO BACK THERE.  We were so kind and nice about it, maybe too kind.  I felt like screaming, but I didn't.  I guess this was no big deal for them....
author: Amy C.

description:
I am writing this review solely toward the Polenta at Marlowe. I literally dream about this Polenta. I wish I was kidding, but alas, I am not.

My dreams about this polenta have been as follows:

1. Ryan Gosling feeding me this polenta, while Bradley Cooper watches jealously.

2. That I actually cooked and learned how to replicate this dish in the comfort of my own kitchen. 

3. Me going to Marlowe and them not having this polenta (nightmare)

4. Me going to Marlowe and choking up and ordering something instead of the polenta (nightmare).

5. I have not had five isolated dreams about Polenta. Only four. Do you think I am crazy or something?

I think you should go here, order the dreamy polenta, and thank me for this advice after. 

That is all. 

xoxo
Lonely girl
author: Valerie H.

description:
Love the long community dining table setup. And IMO, this place looks even cuter at nighttime, especially because I always prefer a cozier environment for the evening (aka I'd probably feel claustrophobic here for brunch).

Standout items:
- Pimm's cup (haven't had one that tasted like theirs before, totally refreshing and still got lightly buzzed)
- Deviled eggs (w/ bacon and jalapeno? NOMS!)
- Poulet vert

Good, but not out of this world:
- Brussels sprouts
- Marlowe Burger
- Baked oysters
- Roasted bone marrow

I would definitely come back here for dinner again, and reorder the standout items + some other items I haven't tried. Also, excellent service to boot.
author: Diana K.

description:
After careful consideration and yelping, we decided to go to Marlowe to celebrate my 21st birthday. Admittedly, I don't have that much experience with cocktails or alcohol in general, but I ordered the Sow and it was delicious. We also ordered a side of fries and the baked oysters, which were deliciously seasoned. Albeit a bit expensive, this is definitely a nice place to eat and drink at the end of a long week. 

The ambience was a dream - I really liked the decor (I was especially obsessed with the bathroom wallpaper featuring outlines of cows!) and the dull roar in the bar was welcoming without being too overwhelming. 

The service was very attentive - staff was always stopping by the table to check on us and refill water. There seemed to be a bit of confusion among the wait staff though. Food that we didn't order was presented to us several times, and we had to awkwardly turn it away (even though the food looked delicious itself!)

Overall, the welcoming ambience and delicious food was definitely enough to warrant another visit!
author: Olivia T.

description:
Love Marlowe! Fun, energetic ambiance.  Food was excellent, I'd recommend making reservations as it seems to get pretty busy especially weekends.  

We went on a Sunday afternoon and started with a Blood Mary and Irish Coffee.  Although there is nothing like a Buena Vista Irish Coffee this one wasn't too bad.  We moved on to the Di Stefano Burrata toast and for entrees ordered the salmon sandwich and the grilled asparagus.  Everything was excellent, service was great as well. Location is perfect for those coming from the peninsula, it's right off King St.  

Will be going back again soon!
author: Vanessa R.

description: I had made reservations before our flight out of SF - we were seated immediately. Our waitress was good, and she was aware of our time crunch but she disappeared at the end leaving us no time for dessert and hanging for the check, which I guess is ok. Now, the food. The brussel sprout chips are indeed yummy - I'm gonna have to try to make these at home. The bone marrow was good but not enough to make me want to come here for it. The burger was also good. I had the poulet vert which was nice and moist (sorry I don't like using the word juicy) - meaty, lean and flavorful. The downside was the halibut - super salty and fishy, my friend couldn't even finish it and I can't believe she had to pay that much money for it. Food in SF is pricier than NYC but you hope it tastes as good or better than what I can get back home.
author: Fiona C.

description:
I was treated to a belated birthday brunch Saturday and was looking forward to trying the burger noted in top brunch spots on SF Eater. We sat at the bar and had excellent service throughout; everything we ordered was delicious from the warm deviled egg to the brussels sprouts chips, the burger, and the doughnuts.

When our waiter asked how everything was, I said the meal was great except the burger and fries and the chips were too salty. Apparently, we weren't the only customers to report over-salted dishes, but the chef continues to prepare them her way. Fortunately for me, I don't have hypertension but I do not plan on returning if the chef is too arrogant to take feedback seriously.
author: L. H.

description:
Easily one of the best options in this part of SF. Great atmosphere and solid grub. Here's the rundown based on a few visits over the years:
 - Warm Deviled Egg - I don't like Deviled Eggs, but I get these every time
 - Solid burger
 - Spiced Jumbo Shrimp were great
 - Burrata "wraps" they created were excellent. Original execution
 - Burrata + Proscuitto - do it
 - Perfect Brussels Sprouts
 - Exceptional Steak Tartare
 - Rib Eye - I don't like rib eye and enjoyed this w/ the fries and Brussels Sprouts
 - Black Cod - Solid
 - Average desserts - Pass

The only miss was the wine. We had a couple different bottles and both were a bit odd (arguably had a funk).
author: Jeff F.

description: Absolutely amazing! Everything was delicious. Fried chicken sandwich was perfect. We also tried the Burrata appetizer and it was divine. The Baker's wife was the perfect, refreshing cocktail. We highly recommend this place and would come back weekly if we lived here.
author: Val M.

description:
I love the ambiance and exceptional food. 

We tried the Brussel Sprout Chips, Bone Marrow, Oysters, and the famous Marlowe Burger. My taste buds were extremely happy!

The service we received was amazing, our waitress was attentive, knowledgable of the menu, and personable. Parking is a pain, though there are a alleyways where you might be able to luck out at. 

This is a perfect spot for a date night, birthday dinner, or any special occasion!
author: Juliette R.

description:
We came right before noon in the middle of the week. I recommend making a reservation any time of day you come, because we were lucky enough to grab the last table for two before there was wait. 

Our waitress was really nice and funny. I asked her what she recommended between the chicken or BBQ lamb sandwiches, but she described them both so well that she commented that she wasn't helpful at all! I ended up ordering the BBQ lamb sandwich and my boyfriend ordered the steak frites. My sandwich was really juicy and tender, but I could not tell it was lamb. The steak frites was cooked perfectly and the sauce was amazing. 

There are a lot of small, great touches here. I love that they put their specials hand written on butcher paper and put their steak knives on one of those magnetic strips. I just thought it was a little insane that sparkling water was $8 and iced tea was $6, even for SF prices. I would come back though! It is a great vibe and the food was delicious.
author: Alisha K.

description: Recently took my parents there for dinner... The food was delicious and the service was great the two most important things at any restaurant we will be back again.
author: Angy G.

description:
Hostess with short hair had bad customer service with our reservation this morning. I had a reservation for 1:30p. We arrived at 1:27p and was told we couldn't be seated because the table "scheduled" for us was still dining and closing up and was advised to wait at the bar. While next to the door there was an empty table for our party of 2, I inquired and was told "No" we could not sit there because it was for another party with a 1:15p reservation that was late. 

Why penalize us for being early? 

While we were seated at 1:44pm there was no waitress that came to the table until I complained to the second hostess at 1:53pm who became more accommodating to us. 

A friend in the hotel business recommended this restaurant to us but I'll be sure to let her know that may no longer be a good idea.
author: j j.

description:
Before running some errands in the City, my family decided to stop by a lunch spot. We stumbled upon this corner restaurant and was thoroughly impressed. 

The service was really attentive and polite; they were always making sure our time there was the best it could be. My family then proceeded to order the chicken OKRA and Little Gem salad, both of which were spectacular. The chicken came with a lovely side of lemon aïoli and the salad was like eating a fragrant garden. For the main course, my family ordered the four sandwiches on the menu. I ate the Marlowe burger with a side of fries and a bite of the Chicken/bacon sandwich( I forgot the name). Both of these exceeded my expectations. I expect to come back here in the near future as this restaurant was the needle in the haystack.
author: Yoshihiro K.

description:
Marlowe is obviously very popular among yelpers: I checked in on yelp on a random weekday evening and discovered after I got home that four people had liked my check-in!

I think it's a winner too.  I loved the ambiance and really appreciated the way that we were received by the personnel.  The host-person Melanie was totally gracious and professional when our group of six walked in.  She kept us in mind as our long table was vacated, cleared and then set up for our group.  In particular, she dealt firmly with some diners from a neighboring table who attempted to acquire more real estate for themselves while our table was being prepared.  Our server, a woman from New Zealand, was helpful and efficient as well.  Oh, I should add that I had a very informative conversation about parking with a staff member from the office who phoned the day before to confirm our reservation.  (As long as there's no game at AT&T Park, street parking is plentiful and perfectly cheap.  I paid $0.75 to park while we were at dinner.)

I'm a big fan of trains, by the way, even Caltrain.  What's not to like when you're seated across from a station and can trainspot while you're having dinner!

I tried several wines while I was at Marlowe and will confess that I didn't fall in love with any of them.  At the bar, we tried the New Zealand sauvignon blanc and liked it well enough.  We also tasted a South African chenin blanc that didn't appeal to anyone in our group who interacted with it.  I ordered a glass of Grüner Veltliner after rejecting the chenin blanc.  That wine was OK, but it didn't excite me.  The best wine that I had during our visit was the Bonny Doon Clos de Gilroy -- we got a carafe of it.  That wine is really pretty good; I'd forgotten how much I like Randall Grahm.  But there was no "This is wonderful, thanks for introducing me to this" moment while we were having dinner.

As for the food -- YUM!!  I decided before arriving that I'd get a hamburger, and I agree with Michael Bauer and just about everyone else in San Francisco that it's a standout.  I suspect that the only better burger I've had in the City is the one that I ordered at Zuni about twenty years ago late into the night.  But memories can be tricky and there's every rational reason to believe that the Zuni version would go down to defeat in a head-to-head competition.

What else did I eat?  I had plenty of the chip-ified Brussels sprouts and tasted the little gem salad, the polenta and the Tcho chocolate cream pie.  They were all plenty good.  I normally don't even like dessert, but I could have had an entire chocolate cream pie on my own.  (We got one to share.)

I except to return and even have fantasies of becoming a regular.  I'll just have to check the baseball schedule to make sure that parking won't be an issue.  In fact, you might enjoy this tidbit: I've been checking the SF Giants schedule off and on just to make sure that I don't get stuck in game traffic when I drive near the City.  Google's response is to flood my phone with game scores!!  Sorry, Giants and sorry, google, I'm not much interested in the team.  I just want to park near Marlowe.
author: Kenneth R.

description:
This is my 3rd time being here and for the first 2 experiences I would give Marlowe 5/5 stars.  

Today we came for brunch with reservations. When we arrived, the hostess was going to seat us right by the door.  Granted the restaurant was empty upon arrival, we requested for another seat that was away from the door which we thought was no problem.  The hostess gave us attitude and you can tell that she was not pleased, but she grudgingly changed our seat.  This started off our meal on a sour note, but I must give 5/5 to the rest of the staff.  They were super friendly and awesome as usual.  Too bad for the hostess.
author: Kristin C.

description:
Great food. I had the poulet vert (herb roasted chicken) and it was amazing. It was a bit on the pricey side relative to the quality and portions of food, which was why this isn't a five star review.

Be sure to make a reservation.
author: Brian C.

description:
Delicious! I went here last night with a friend for dinner for the first time and was impressed by the food, ambiance, and overall experience. I had the deviled egg as a starter. Only thing I have a real issue with here is the fact they only give you a half an egg for $2.50. It was really good, but come on, at least serve a whole egg for that price. My friend and I split the brussels sprout chips and they were very tasty, a bit on the salty side, but definitely had a great taste and were a good starter. I then had the Little gem salad and the polenta as a main course. The Little gem salad was alright, nothing to write home about, but the polenta was delicious (in fact, there was so much, I'm eating it for lunch today). The wild mushrooms and poached egg were a very nice touch to add to the already delicious flavors of the polenta. I'm a fan!

Next time I'm going to try to Marlowe burger since that's what they're well known for. Definitely coming back to this place!
author: Rachel P.

description:
If you're coming on a weekend, best to make a reservation or you can forget about eating here.  I've eaten at Park Tavern before and I loved it so I figured I would love this place too and I sure did!

Casual dining with a rustic feel.  Small place, but has bar seating.  Some tables have bench seatings for a nice family style meal.

For starters, we had their famous Deviled Eggs, Crispy Brussel Sprout Chips, and Di Stefano Burrata.  The deviled eggs are delicious, but they need to bring the price down as $2.50 for half of an egg is just ridiculous.  I can buy a dozen egg for that!  The brussel sprout chips were addicting.  I got a taste of my friend's mushroom soup and that was lovely.  Thick rich soup with a hint of truffle oil.

Our dinner took really long to come out; about 30 minutes after we finished our appetizers.  Turned out the kitchen overcooked one of the dishes so they had to redo all 4 of our dishes.  I ordered their famous Marlowe burger which came with caramelized onions, cheddar cheese, bacon and fries.  I couldn't resist after other tables around me were eating it.  For $14, it was a damn good burger!  The portion was just right that I ate it all by myself.  

I had a taste of the Pan Seared Scallops, "Poulet Vert," and the Grilled Niman Pork Chop dishes and all were delicious.  Comforting flavors.  In the end, they brought out all 3 of their desserts as complimentary due to the long dinner wait we had.  We had the TCHO Chocolate Cream Pie which tasted like cheesecake, Upside Down Strawberry Crisp with Bourbon ice cream and Vanilla Bean Panna Cotta Affogato.  All were really good.  Glad to have tried various menu items including dessert.  Although there was a long wait for dinner, the fact that they brought out 3 complimentary desserts was a nice offering.  Have to say that all the food was executed very well that I highly recommend this place.
author: Erica S.

description: We had brunch before the Giants game on 4.10. First: great service. Matthew was spectacular (he even helped us take well-posed pictures!). There were three of us "ladies who brunch" and each had a deviled egg...yum yum yummy. A must. Two had the kale/Brussels sprout 'starter' salad and thought it was off the hook. We thought it was more entree-sized. The other had the "starter" crab toast and loved it but also thought it was more than starter size. Add in cappuccino and iced teas and it was $25 each for great quality food, memorable good service and we didn't leave hungry. Bravo Marlowe!!! We'll be back!!!!!
author: Ottis M.

description:
As I wait in the hellish, earthly purgatory that is the pharmacy line at Kaiser, I figure it's probably time I wrote this review. So I've been to the old Marlowe once and then the newer one 3 times now, and it's always super solid. 

Steak tartare: I think it's pretty good, my boyfriend had never had it before and couldn't get past the whole "this is raw meat" thing, so it was a solid no for him. 

Bone marrow: Do I even need to say anything here? It's fucked up good. 

Burger: Welcome to Danktown, USA. Get it with fries, not a side salad. Commit. 

Polenta: Jesus H Christ on a cracker, the polenta is a must. Bury me in a vat of it. The mushrooms are amazing and I'm not even crazy about shrooms.

Poulet vert: My boyfriend got this but I tried it naturally - a little on the salty side but still pretty damn tasty. 

Brussels sprout chips: Good, but honestly I'm over this Brussels sprout trend.

Banana walnut cake: More of a bread than a cake, but it had a good little burnt caramel sauce and ice cream going on. 

All the cocktails are good, so just follow your little heart. That being said, the La Cuchilla was awesome.
 
I'll be back!
author: Jenna H.

description:
Lives up to the hype! 

The Marlowe burger certainly did not disappoint and quenches a carnivores thirst with it's Niman Ranch beef.  Perfectly balanced is how I'd describe the burger. Sweetness from the caramelized onions, brightness from the horseradish aoli, the smoky, sweet, and slightly salty bacon, great meat to acme roll ratio. Order it medium rare and the  red meat juice just runs down your hands. Vegetarians just don't understand! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c0WpyZFR3EoEBKcoY2LZ3Q?select=wG3Cm7SDH9WWrvBIYCzEOw)

Their seasonal green salad was saltier than salt so definitely opt for their fries. Crispy, airy. and light. The center was like a potato pillow! My vote for best fries in the city. 

I like the mish moshness of the SOMA lunch crowd. My group of 5 came  around 1pm and it was about 15 min for a table. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c0WpyZFR3EoEBKcoY2LZ3Q?select=WqO3UV2KaBJ4Vrw4mEOGVw)  and (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c0WpyZFR3EoEBKcoY2LZ3Q?select=Bwl_RopcARpK5bzOqi7TIw)

Their crispy fried chicken gives Bakesale Betty a run for her cookies. Twang from the Caesar aoli, bacon, and I don't need to wait in that insane line. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c0WpyZFR3EoEBKcoY2LZ3Q?select=EwKn3TfLpGpm97sSAiTQsw)

I'm not to big on Michael Bauer but he's on to something with this burger and Marlowe being on the top 100 new restaurants. I wouldn't say it's the best I've had but I'm definitely more than a fan.
author: Earl G.

description:
Only glowing reviews about this place, the service was excellent, food came out promptly, but oh my the food! From the menu:
Corn chowder- to die for lusciously sascreamy, fresh, velvety goodness
English PEA pancakes- 3 small bites of smoked salmon, crispy garlic flakes fried in chili oil, creme fraiche on a pea pancake delicious
Brussel Chips- crunchy light a bit salty for my taste
Marlowe Burger with fries- cooked to order, perfect medium as requested. If its a burger and fries you are craving this is it but elevated. 

Overall excellent experience and a must try if you are in SF. Only comment would be that alot of the items were a bit salty if you dont normally cook with alot of salt but I wouldnt knock stars
author: Eileen M.

description:
My husband and I went on a Friday night, we had to wait quite a bit to get a table because we didn't make reservations but it was so worth it! 
Food and drinks are excellent, the staff is friendly and the ambience is cool. Great spot!!
author: Valentina B.

description:
I had heard a lot about Marlowe before coming here on a packed Thursday night before the long weekend. 
We had reservations but it took us 20 minutes to get a table. 
The drinks we started with were pretty good. I had a "country lawyer" which is Marlowe's take on an old fashioned (I mentioned I was looking for something classic and strong with a base of bourbon )The food menu itself doesn't offer much for choice but you can't really go wrong with the poulet vert or the Marlowe burger (which was about standard as a burger can get, my medium rare was more of a full rare and it was also quite greasy in a good way). 
The appetizers are pretty scrumptious - half a dozen oysters is certainly the way to go !
The only problem I had was the wait time which was really unreasonable. Close to an hour and a half on a Thursday night for our food despite the fact that we had reservations, what really put me off was that other groups that came after us and ordered the same dishes were served in a third of the time. 
I hope to come here again and have a more favorable experience !
author: Manish R.

description:
Places like this make me miss the Bay Area more and more each day - as is evident by the fact that I'm sitting in my apt in Boston, a full year after moving here, still dreaming abt it whilst I should be writing a case review for a health law class. Hmmmm.

Obviously I can't add anything new insight to a place w/ almost 900 reviews, but what I will say is to a) book a table well in advance; b) order at least 3 orders of the lemon brussel sprout chips small bite (worth every bit of the slightly overpriced $8 they charge); and c) the menu is small (5-6 starters, 5-6 mains), but it covers most basic food needs, though vegans will struggle here - there is kind of a lot of bacon present. 

Ambiance is rustic industrial - swoon. Quiet, but not in an old, stodgy way. Approved for both parental and romantic dates. 

Wine list is small but reasonable - service is quite friendly w/o being pretentious or overbearing - din will run abt $40-50/pp, depending on if you get starters, etc - I think most mains are around $24 and starters are abt $10-14.
author: Rachel N.

description: I love popping in here for lunch. There is some prime people watching to be had along with really good food.List to techies broker million dollar deals while you chow down on a really terrific sandwich. I am partial to the burger, but on my last visit I enjoyed a bahn mi style rock shrimp sandwich. The slaw was delicious and I really enjoyed the fries on the side. they are super crispy and served with a side of horseradish sauce. Yum!
author: Nicole M.

description: Dined here with my husband while in San Francisco for the weekend. It was a romantic and cute/trendy little place. We ordered the salmon appetizer, crab and shrimp poppers and bone marrow. My fav was the poppers but I did love the salmon with cucumbers. The bone marrow was OK. We had a bottle of wine that was yummy. Also had the chocolate mouse for dessert (YUMMY). The service was great and I loved the music they played. Very cute date night spot.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Came here for a burger but was amazed by the other dishes. 
Our group had the bone marrow, corn soup, devils egg, baked oyster, burger. The corn soup was sooo Freaking Good! Some of my friends commented and said 'I can have a gallon of this'. So true! Everything was delicious 

Service was good. They explained some of the dishes and how it was prepared. I'm sure i will be back.
author: Thomas C.

description:
The little private patio here is an absolute dream.  If I couldn't have a real yard, I could happily make do with a space like this.  Hell, if I didn't have a dining room I could be happy with that patio, and might prefer it to be honest.
I sat at the bar this visit, keeping an eye on a group here for a work dinner in my coveted patio.
I sat at the bar for a LONG TIME. 
The staff remained kind, friendly, and responsive throughout - rather than being annoyed at having a water drinker taking up prime bar real estate during peak hours.
My food was great, and the cocktails sounded, looked, and smelled amazing, but the atmosphere and service are what will set this place apart for me.  Well done Marlowe.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I've been to Park Tavern and thought Marlowe would be similar. The food was good, but not extraordinary. Highlights were the Dungeness crab and rock shrimp crepe (I couldn't get enough!) and my entree (creamed polenta with wild hen mushrooms and a poached egg and arugula). Oh and the lemon creme brûlée . Just enough Meyer sweetness and tart lemon with creamy custard.

Not so great were the Brussels sprouts (park tavern's was so much better!) and the cod was a bit salty. Decent, but not my favorite.
author: Christina C.

description: Love the new space!  It's bright and airy.  On to the food.  We started with the spiced pistachios and Pimms in honor of the warm summer evening. Best decision.  Burger was amazing as were the scallops.  A solid SF staple!
author: Kamael S.

description: Holy Moley, what a place! Delicious from the first bite. I'd recommend the deviled eggs, prawns, and the burger. It's definitely a pricey joint, but it's also San Francisco. Kind of in a weird neighborhood, though. I'm not from the area but I wouldn't recommend walking here in the dark.
author: Bree H.

description:
This review is for my dining experience on March 8 from 9pm to 11 pm.

Food was amazing, but service was horrible. I normally don't write bad reviews, but after last night...I don't see myself going back to Marlowe even if the food was good.

Now this review is not directly to the hostess and the bartender because they were absolutely great with us (we were a party of 5). But it was our server and the manager who made the entire experience at Marlowe terrible. 

Not only did we have to wait over an hour to get our entrees, but both server and manager were defensive and were very unapologetic about the situation. Working in the restaurant industry in the past, I totally understand that mistakes happen or the kitchen is backed up. But the problem is that our server did not even follow up on our order until we had to flag a different server. The party of 5 that sat next to us that we're seated 15 minutes after us received and finished their entrees before we even received our entrees. We brought the attention to the manager and he was being very defensive and did not apologize. Our server apologized but it was a half ass apology. "I'm sorry that you feel that way" is NOT the correct way to apologize. After we received our entrees, our server pretty much avoided us all night. 

Halfway into our meal, the manager comes to us again and finally apologizes and decides to give us dessert on the house. And I only think he came to apologize after I mentioned to the server that the manager did not apologize. To be honest, all we really wanted was a genuine apology.
author: P. L.

description: Really nice brunch place! Oysters were super fresh, and I am in love with their burratas. Haven't tried out the burgers yet, but is definitely worth another visit
author: Carol Y.

description:
Came here based on my boyfriend's recommendation. He has been here a couple times and have had great food. However, I must have caught them on an off night. 

Here is what we ordered: 

Baked Oyster $3
Cod $26
Poulet Vert $28
Burger & Fries $14

First off, my $26 cod was the size of a half deck of cards. The cod was dry and the special "squid ink vinaigrette" didn't do much for the dish. The cod was served with a side of lentils, grilled leeks, and squid. The best thing out of the dish was probably the baby squid, but all in all, pretty underwhelming and forgettable. Not worth the $26. 

Baked oyster? It nearly took until my last two bites to find the actual oyster. 

Poulet Vert was ordered by the bf and both him and I agreed that the sauce was too salty. The chicken though, was cooked to perfection and was portioned well. The dish included half a chicken and vegetables. 

The burger I did not personally taste, but my friends seemed to have liked it. The fries were topped with parsley and served with a side of their horseradish aioli. The fries were delicious and the aioli tasted like the horseradish sauce from Buckhorn Grill.
author: Michelle C.

description:
As others have mentioned, Marlowe is a small place, so definitely make a reservation. I arrived a few minutes early for my reservation and was seated promptly, even before my friend arrived. I'm glad they didn't keep me lurking in the doorway. 

My friend and I ordered:

1) BRUSSELS SPROUT CHIPS: Delicious and so simple. Must have been sprinkled with lemon zest and a bit of salt. A bit oily, but a perfect compliment to any beer. I was so excited to dig in that I forgot to take a photo at first, then I couldn't stop eating them.

2) POLENTA: What a decadent dish - smooth, creamy polenta, thinly sliced mushrooms, a perfectly poached egg, truffle oil, and a pleasant bite from the arugula. The first few bites were to die for. However, the dish got heavy pretty quickly. I would have preferred this dish as an appetizer, or with something to break up the richness. More arugula? Pickled veggies? Fresh fruit?   

3) BURGER: My friend swears by the burger and devoured it before I had even fully stirred in the poached egg for my polenta. Enough said. 

4) BAKED CAULIFLOWER: I liked this as an alternate to the potatoes gratin that restaurants often offer as a side. However, it was rather rich, being coated with melted cheese. If I had ordered any entree other than the polenta, I would have appreciated the cauliflower more.

All in all, the service was excellent and I loved the vibe of the restaurant. The woodsy décor and cozy space makes it a perfect date spot (I'd recommend coming early, as the noise level definitely increased as it got later). I didn't fall in love with my polenta, but the other dishes were fantastic. I will definitely come back for more Brussels sprouts, as chips or as a side, and to try the bone marrow and other entrees.
author: Cindy T.

description:
Sooooo good. The second I saw the industrial beams coming down and the little glass lights hanging over the bar, my first thought was "hipsters". We started off lunch with a bowl of brussel sprout chips because everyone on Yelp has raved about them. They were just as good as everyone says they are.

I ordered the warm rock shrimp roll with a side of fries for lunch and was pleasantly surprised by the chili sauce. It wasn't very spicy but it provided a nice kick on top of the slaw. The highlight, though, was the dessert. I shared an upside down strawberry crisp with my friend. It was basically a bit of strawberry, brown butter caramel, and some walnuts/crispy stuff on top of a jar filled with bourbon ice cream. Amazing! Also, it was the perfect end to a meal during an unusually warm San Francisco day. 

I will definitely be back to Marlowe in the future.
author: Anna N.

description:
Maybe it's been hyped up so much, or maybe I always see a line out the door, or maybe I've just been eating A LOT of good food lately, but although Marlowe was good, I wasn't blown away.

It's a very tastefully decorated, and the waiter made excellent recommendations, but the food and drink came a bit slow.  Also, there was definitely a point in the meal where my date and I were straight up yelling at each other a la Chinese dim sum restaurant.  That being said, I love how a few of our dishes were split (without a silly split fee.. it made drinking the corn soup that much easier).  Said soup was a highlight, if a bit steeply priced at $11.  My favorite was definitely the poulet vert - chicken cooked well and the flavors were just amazing.  I would pass on the gem salad and the asparagus (which were the size of fingers!), not that they weren't good, they just weren't mind-blowing.

Despite Marlowe not quite meeting expectations, I know I'll definitely come back to try a few other things on the menu.  The fact that they take reservations is a huge plus if you can remember to book in advance!
author: Lil L.

description:
Went in for lunch today- has to have been a few years since I last had lunch here.  Big change;  the menus is very small now, and no deviled eggs. You can get a deviled egg sandwich, but that isn't really gonna do it for me.  Kind of sad about that, but I'll get over it...
Oh yeah, and the hostess asked me if I wanted the crummy table with the beam. She did not look surprised when I said no thanks. 
Lunch was still delicious.

Previous Review:
Ive eaten here 4 or 5 times now.  It's over all pretty good, and I like to support woman owned/run restaurants.

The great:
-deviled eggs (which often kind of scare me, but not here.  I keep trying to knock these off, but have not been successful)
-brussel sprout chips
-pate (duck liver crostini)
-oysters
-all their fish entrees
-little gem salad
-hostess really super last time I was there

The ok:
-burger and fries ( you know, its a burger and fries.  whatever)
-cauliflower gratin (not bad, not stellar... kind of sick of it halfway through)
-crab louie  (eh)
-waitstaff (I suggest you check your bill and the  waitresses are nicer than the waiters...Just saying)
-desserts ( im a huge dessert snob tho, so maybe it's just me...)

The bad:
-one table has a giant beam positioned for diners to bash their heads in. 
Marlowe should really get rid of that table because 1)  someone's gonna bash their head and sue, and 2)  cmon, paying good money here so dont give me that freaking crappy table. 
Saw some tall guy sit there once  who clearly didnt want to make a scene  (on a date or something?) by demanding a better table....he looked so freaking miserable that it kind of ruined MY meal watching him squirm. So, I'm gonna knock off a star in memory of tall guy....

Summary:
Oh yeah, I'll be back again.  I will ask for a good table (and leave if they try to give me the head basher table...really) order deviled eggs, a salad, and try one of the incredible looking caveman meat dishes which I haven't tried yet.  Portions look huge, and people look blissed out eating them.....
author: El B.

description:
This restaurant is pretty small but fits a lot of people. They have a small bar area and that's where we sat. They have a good selection on their drinks and best of all, they carry some pretty good Japanese whiskeys. I had the Pimm's cup which was really refreshing and also a glass of Hibiki 17yr (Japanese whiskey) to sip on. The bartender, also our server, was friendly. 

We ordered a few small plates to try so we can taste most items on their menu. First, we started off with the warm deviled eggs. It was good, but it doesn't hold still. When I picked it up with the fork, it was falling apart. Then of course the baked oysters on national oyster day. They were perfectly done and wish we had more. We also had the duck liver mousse. It's really smooth and flavorful and has this sweetness to it; maybe because they added cherries. Then we had was the pan seared scallops. It's really tasty with the sauce and at the same time, it still has its seafood taste (nicely cooked). Last but not least, we had the NY steak on top of long peas and spinach with house made fries on the side. We asked for medium rear but it turned out to be medium so it's slightly on the dry side. The vegetables that came with the steak were good and saucy. The fries were really crispy and not too salty. 

I would love to come back and try other items on their menu and I would also check out their sister restaurants.
author: Cindy W.
