I'm on the border or 3 and 4 stars ... The food is tastey, don't get me wrong. The problem is that, for the price, I can get a much better meal else where. I had the burger, which, according to those I know, is one of, if not the best in the city. Eh, I can name 3 burgers that are better (so you know my biases: Umami, Prospect, Roam).

I also tasted the pork chop, which looked superb! The chard (or a cousin) accompaniment was bitter, but, you know, it kind of worked given the starchey, BBQ glaze on the meat.

To start, the marrow was excellent. Then again, it was my first experience.

To help with digestion, the wine was quite good for (a mere) $45 a bottle.
author: Justin P.

description:
3.5 stars but rounding down since the service was uneven on this visit. This was my first lunch at Marlowe, and the first time I've been back since my initial dinner there two years ago. I made reservations a couple weeks out for a Monday, and thank goodness I did because the restaurant was packed at noon, and there would've been a long wait. We ordered:

-Crispy Brussels Sprout Chips (Lemon & Sea Salt, $7, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c0WpyZFR3EoEBKcoY2LZ3Q?select=afE-TQOh-LCH1rXK7oboQQ#afE-TQOh-LCH1rXK7oboQQ): Most inventive and delicious dish in a long time! I remember the first time I had these at Marlowe, and was blown away by how crispy and crunchy each brussel sprout leaf was, and how they added the perfect amount of salt and lemon. A must order!
-Crispy Fried Chicken Sandwich (Caesar Aioli, Bacon, Field Greens, $13, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c0WpyZFR3EoEBKcoY2LZ3Q?select=afE-TQOh-LCH1rXK7oboQQ#8rPGdkGThFcjjNFnCrdrZA): Although this is on the 2012 7x7 Big Eat list, the sandwich was really disappointing! The chicken piece was moist, but the dish overall was very dry. They needed more aioli, or a slaw for the sandwich. I wouldn't order this dish again.
-Marlowe Burger (Caramelized Onions, Cheddar, Bacon, Horseradish Aioli, $13, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c0WpyZFR3EoEBKcoY2LZ3Q?select=afE-TQOh-LCH1rXK7oboQQ#wyO-MFmJZbHzcx-jAX1Ksg): I've had this burger before, and didn't remember it, so I decided to re-order since this is one of the dishes they're known for. It was a solid burger, but I wasn't amazed.  It was on the small side, and although the beef flavor was good, it again wasn't memorable.
-Sauteed Blue Sole Po' Boy (Spicy Remoulade, Shredded Lettuce, Heirloom Tomato, $14, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c0WpyZFR3EoEBKcoY2LZ3Q?select=afE-TQOh-LCH1rXK7oboQQ#ZWkWu4k9icoE5m1xyQVK8Q): Skip! I didn't like this sandwich at all. It also needed more remoulade since it was dry, and the overall flavors were boring. 
-Upside Down Strawberry Crisp (Bourbon Ice Cream, Brown Butter Caramel Sauce, $7, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c0WpyZFR3EoEBKcoY2LZ3Q?select=afE-TQOh-LCH1rXK7oboQQ#jgIcBV_49Q8SEPByU7T6HA): Pretty good! The bourbon ice cream was really good, and I liked the strawberry crisp. However, I wasn't a fan of the glass they serve it in- although it looks cute, it gets hard to eat, especially when you're sharing and get towards the bottom.

Overall, there were some successful and not so successful dishes at Marlowe. Our server was attentive at first, but got busy later on and didn't check back at our table much. We had to flag her down to order dessert and grab the check. Also, since there was a large party that day, the kitchen was slow to come out with our dishes and it took an hour and a half to finish lunch. Although I still love the brussel sprout chips, I wouldn't make a special trip to come here again for lunch (only open M-F), but will probably give dinner another try. Parking can be really tough around this area, and the meters are expensive.
author: Amy D.

description:
Great ambiance, a little too packed for my taste (could hear conversation at both tables next to us). Great wine selection and definitely niches itself into a carnivore's paradise with all of its meat dishes and decor. 

We ordered the bone marrow (horrible both in its bland taste and gross texture), deviled eggs (really good - one of the best we've ever had).  We had salad and lamb for our dinner courses, both of which were decent but not memorable. 

Not likely to return but do not regret trying it.
author: Alice Z.

description:
I thought this place was wonderful. The space is a tiny bit cramped though. 

I went here while visiting SF with a friend and her family, and we were not disappointed. The marlowe burger, the mushroom polenta, and the bone marrow are all delicious. 

Service is great! Our waiter was very friendly and brought out a complimentary dessert after we finished our meals. 

I will definitely come back next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Sienna S.

description:
I've been going to Marlowe ever since they were at the 4th and Townsend and I love their burgers. Through time they have reduced the amount of stuff that comes in/with the burger as they've become more main stream. For example I'm getting less and less fries every time I come or there is less caramelized onion in the burgers. 

Now they serve you what I call the "Sad Burger" which is very plain and the chef doesn't allow you to add anything to it such as tomatoes, no pickles, and no avocados. I used to be able to add those extras before and now I can't. 

My one star review is for the waitress's behavior because as I was saying this to one of the other customers, she goes quietly to them and tells them that I'm lying! lol Why would I make such a thing up. Instead of making more money and losing your old customers, I recommend being more open to criticism specially coming from someone who's always dined there.
author: City T.

description:
I went into Marlowe last weekend and had the best deviled eggs of my life. I kid you not, order two of these (even though they come two per order) because sharing is inexcusable. 

Another great thing happened. The General Manager came up to me to ask about my Yelp review. She wanted to know how I felt about Marlowe, how they could be doing better (IMO shades of grey, they're already pretty kick ass), and shared with me what they aspire to be as a restaurant--the neighborhood bistro you can go to any time, for anything, and always feel welcomed. I can 100% dig that, and I love that she shared Marlowe's hopes and ambitions with me.
author: Arthur N.

description: First time visit - well, second visit but first lunch experience. We work nearby so stopped by about 12:30 yesterday but wait was a while so we made reservation for today - recommended for lunch visits from opening until about 1:30 when some tables were open. Otherwise seems quite busy with the suit crowd - or what passes for a suit nowadays !  We started with Brussel sprout chips with lemon and sea salt. They were light and airy despite leaving oil on our fingers, but not really something to fill you up. At just under $10 a nice try, but would skip them next time. Entrees were a cheeseburger and the open faced egg salad sandwich with pickled jalapeño and provolone cheese (also comes with two strips of bacon but I went vegetarian ...). Side of fries with garlic aioli dip rather than salad (salads I saw coming in were just green piles of - well, salad!)  was perfect! Shared (but could've eaten all by myself!) a cauliflower and cheese casserole. The sandwich was very good, on a light bread with mildly warm jalapeños - not too hot. The deviled egg was deliciously seasoned. The provolone was also a good pairing. The cheeseburger was on a nice bun (looked like an egg glaze?) with lots of condiments and was cooked perfectly to medium rare. Cauliflower is not a favorite of mine, but I'll eat this dish anytime. Well seasoned cauliflower with cheeses melted on top - the cheese was darkened (not my style) but didn't detract from overall taste in this dish. Both white and orange cauliflower was used for a nice visual variety. The drinks (water and iced tea) were kept filled by attentive staff, dishes cleared promptly. Noise level was very loud - not sure why, but it is a smaller dining area with tables close to each other (and some searing at the counter as well). Overall a great meal and nice experience. Would bring someone here as a guest to make a nice impression if business related - I think that's what many were there for judging by the conversations I heard around me, but a family with very young children (8 and under) also sat next to us at one point and the kids enjoyed their meals as well, so it seems a nice family option, too.
author: Mark K.

description: Ignore any bad review from Marlowe.  This place is amazing!!!  Very fresh, wonderful flavors, inviting atmosphere.  A+.
author: Scott S.

description:
So yummy!  Great place for brunch.  First of all the environment is comfortable, airy and a decent noise level.  Although the tables are a bit close, so no private conversations will be happening!  Food is really good.  Started with the french toast fingers that came with two sauces, chocolate and a vanilla pot-de-creme concoction.  Really yummy.  Bread is not too eggy.  Would go back for this.
Husband had the poached eggs with grilled asparagus.  Both are hard to get right.  They were perfect, runny yolk but cooked egg and asparagus was al dente. Ingredients were super fresh.
I had the warm kale and brussel sprout caesar.  So fresh and perfectly dressed. Nice level of garlic.  Again perfect poached egg.
Child had the Crispy Fried chicken Sandwich.  So yummy!  Chicken was juicy on the inside, crispy (as promised!) on the outside.  Nice spice. Bun was soft and had a nice chew.  Fries are perfect! Some of the best I've had.  
Lastly, prices are good... for San Francisco :)
author: Pikachu P.

description: Nice trendy place. Stopped by for a late happy hour on the way to a company holiday party. Super long wait, even at the bar. Drinks and the couple small bites we had were really good though.. Service was very friendly. Will stop by again at some point for dinner and drinks..
author: James S.

description: One of the best restaurants in SF! Definitely get the Brussel sprout chips... The polenta and the burger are excellent, and the banana walnut cake is to die for
author: C E.

description:
I've been here twice and enjoyed myself equally. 

Each visit, started the same.  Glass of water and the brussell sprout chips.

FOOD: 
I devoured the burger with its sexy caramilized onions, cheddar cheese, and bacon.  I mildly enjoyed the crispy fried chicken sandwhich and poulet vert.  Why mildy? The chicken was crispy, but something was off on the flavor. The Poulet was better, but fattier.  Keep in mind the poulet takes 20 minutes from oven to table-not listed on the menu. 

The beauty of the small menu is having the option to try everything once.  I read the descriptions and want this, that, and the other...

On my most recent visist, I ordered the TCHO chocolate cream pie. 
My goodness was that delicious.  So delicious, I kept licking my fingers to reach the left over graham cracker crust.

If you are on a diet, you may want to search for alternates. The food doesn't skimp on the richness or the taste. I suggest you share dishes and pair them with glasses of wine.

Props for being close to the ballpark, but that means parking can get tricky on day games. Reservations are a must, even for lunch. If you are loading coins in to the parking meter, expect a 2 hour visit at this establishment. Good food is slow food when the living's easy....
author: Flor D.

description:
The old Marlowe was such a cozy place for a great meal and catch up with a friend.  It's now moved to the old Coco 500 space which is much larger and open feeling so when you walk in the impression is great.  However, it was so loud and I literally had to yell the whole lunch to my friend just opposite to be heard that it diminished the overall enjoyment greatly.  

The food is still reliably good, but the memory of my hoarse voice afterwards makes me doubt I'd go back.  It was that bad. Coco didn't have that problem so it's definitely something to do with the remodel....sound proofing desperately needed!  Food quality is a big part of dining out, but so is the overall ambiance/service/experience.  Food/service 4 stars, everything else 2 stars.
author: Raj-Ann R.

description:
Marlow was great, not my first time here.  But this is the 1st time I have taken the time to write a review.

Met an old friend I was looking to catch up with.  We both had the burger and the brussel sprout chips.  The burger was very tasty and I have always been a huge fan of the brussel sprout chips.
author: Jeffery S.

description: Amazingggg meal! From the service to the cocktails to the food..! Have been wanting to try this place and boyyyy am I glad I finally went!! Will defiantly be back there very soon :)
author: Meagan M.

description:
I went to Marlowe before it relocated to it's current spot. I had just moved to SF and a few of my neighbors raved about this being their favorite spot in all of SF.

I should note that I moved here from South Carolina. We do happen to have FANTASTIC food but I was expecting Marlowe to wow my taste buds with the way everyone was bragging on it. 

Thankfully I didn't get the hamburger because I probably would have given it 1 Star knowing how amazing my hamburger eating life has been.

I got the Poulet Vert which was pretty good. The chicken was seasoned and cooked perfectly and matched nicely with the veggies included. I felt like even though I'm not a master chef, that I could make something just as good at home. I'm a pretty good cook but I go out to eat in hopes of having BETTER than what I can do on my own. I'd say it's a safe choice if some of the other options on the menu are a little out of your comfort zone. It's pretty much like getting a Rotisserie Chicken at Whole Foods- it's just harder to cut and doesn't fall off the bone as easily. 

All of the desserts the table got were terrible. I don't even remember what exactly they were intended to be. They ranged from cobblers, to pies, to mini cake like things all in short mason jars. It was basically like eating ice cream with crumbles and fruit topping. Go to Humphrey Slocombe if you want something that looks "meh" but tastes out of this world. These desserts just looked "meh" and tasted like super sweet ice cream with random crunchy textures. 

Whenever my boyfriend and I leave a restaurant we say: would we go there again? This was a unanimous vote in that we wouldn't. It wasn't a gross or bad meal. It just not worth the time to make another reservation when we've had better.
author: Karen A.

description:
Marlowe offers really well made food with humble portions.

I highly recommend the pork chop, it's so large that you can even split the dish with another person, it has a beautiful char on the outside, and is so tender and juicy on the inside.

The polenta is a nice, comforting dish with a ton of flavor, it's really the perfect dish for the weather we've been having.

I also recommend the mushroom soup and burrata if they're still on the menu if you go =).

Staff is always friendly, service is totally awesome, and there's a bar next door that you can go to while you wait for a seat. 

I would probably say this is a nice intimate location for a date or close friends.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Super cute brunch / dinner joint. We went for a late brunch - coffee was solid, donuts were surprisingly delicious (I am very skeptical of $10 brunch donut order but when you get 5 donut balls with an amazing chewy exterior and soft interior and jam to top them its worth it), the eggs & tomato dish went from brunch typical to memorable with the addition of leeks and chickpeas. 

On the service side, everyone is super friendly, they forgot our main order which slowed our meal down by an hour and were nice enough to comp the meal...which was probably a good investment, as we will be coming back. Excited to try the cocktails which looked great from afar.
author: Tim A.

description:
Wow!  Just Wow!  Great food, friendly service, comfortable atmosphere...did I mention great food?  We stopped in for some small plates to share and were told about the famous burger.  They weren't kidding.  That burger was amazing!  We also tried the jumbo shrimp (never seen shrimp this large), the brussel sprout chips and the devil eggs.  Everything was cooked perfectly with the perfect amount of seasoning.  We actually made it to dessert.  I tried the chocolate covered peanut butter pretzel nuggets of deliciousness and my hubby ordered the chocolate cream pie, a recommendation from the bartender.  Both were unbelievable!  

They do fill up fast though so make a reservation.  Can't wait to go back and try pretty much anything and everything on the menu.
author: Jen H.

description:
Overpriced salty shrimp sandwich with stingy portions.

the salad dressing was basically salt, grease, and lemon.

got to-go with the bartender who was nice and served me water, 3 stars for that

i'll have to come back and try the oysters or the wonderful smelling truffle oil on the mushrooms, but for now 3 stars
author: Tina A.

description:
What can I say about Marlowe but damn delicious! I went on Saturday night with a couple friends and had the best foodie experience. Everything we ordered was delicious!
- brussel sprout chips (yum!)
- deviled eggs (WELL WORTH the $2.50 you spend on each of them)
- Marlowe burger (the main event and has my vote for best burger in SF)

We ate here after a long day in Sonoma so didn't try any of the cocktails. I'm sure they wouldn't disappoint. 

No wonder Eater SF has rated this restaurant as one of the Essential places to try in SF. I will be coming back again and again.
author: Bukky E.

description: My wife I had dinner at Marlowe last night and had a really wonderful experience. They were able to get us in 6:30 pm even though we made the reservation last minute. Starting with the gals at the hostess stand through to the folks busing the service is super friendly. Our server was very welcoming and we made a great dinner of apps and starters. The Gruner Veltliner served by the glass was super delicious with the food. My favorite dish by far was the steak tartare with poached quail egg, crostini, and arugula. Good spot!
author: Jeff Wampler W.

description: Loved it! Fantastic cocktails and a good wine selection. The Brussel Sprout chips are so good we had to order another round. I had their famous hamburger and it was delicious. Lots of flavor, what are they putting in the meat? I can't wait to eat here again :)
author: Ginger L.

description:
The food was spot on. The brussels sprouts were so good and so was the pork.

Good wine selection. It wasn't too loud and the servers were very attentive. The place is small-ish and it felt a little cramped but after my second glass of wine, I got over myself.
author: Carlo I.

description: Came here for a biz lunch and had the burger. They were fast efficient and found the perfect moments to interrupt. The burger was good. I felt like it would have been nice to have more options to entree sized salads. We got there at 12:10 and left by 12:45. I'd love to try them out for dinner.
author: Wanster L.

description:
Mar-lowe?  Should be Mar-high!  The quality of food served here is really up there.

Brussel sprout chips, Marlowe burger, fried chicken sandwich -- they are all phenomenal!  The brussel sprout chips are seriously addicting (if you normally don't like brussel sprouts you'll enjoy them here...guaranteed), the burger is juicy, perfectly cooked and has a nice smokey flavor to it, and the fried chicken sandwich is excellent all around.  

I wish I worked and/or lived next door.  4.5 stars.
author: Erich D.

description:
If you're staying near the Moscone for a conference or something, this is the spot you'll want to grab dinner at one night (at least). Everything we had was amazing, so I'll just list it for you, starting with food:
Brussels chips 
Deviled eggs
Bone Marrow
Cauliflower baked w/ cheese (particularly amazing)
Marlowe Burger
Loretta's Vacherin

Drinks:
Pimm's Cup
The Baker
The Candlestick Maker
The Calf

The service was outstanding and the atmosphere is really fun. Make sure you've got reservations on the weekends, or you'll be waiting for a bar seat to open up and getting hangry seeing all the great food coming out.
author: Joe A.

description:
I initially liked this place, but after a while I did not like it so much anymore. We came on a week day, and it was pretty packed, but we still got a seat right away. There were 3 of us, and we had to share a table with another party of 3, which was a little awkward because we could hear their entire conversation.

I felt like the atmosphere was a little too fancy for me. It's the kind of place where hip professionals or hipster artists would come to be fancy. Our server looked like hipster barrister. The prices were also pretty fancy, averaging $18 per plate, I'd say.

We shared everything we ordered. We got the brussel sprout chips, which were really yummy initially, but felt too salty and oily after a while. We then shared the Tuna Conserva & Prosciutto di Parma, Anson Mills Polenta, and Marlowe Burger. It all filled us up quite well, but I think some of dishes were more filling than others. The polenta was very tasty initially, but then started to feel really heavy. I really enjoyed the tuna salad, but it was kind of tough to eat all together. I felt like I had to eat each piece of the salad one at a time. Also, they sprinkled red pepper flakes over it, so I got one bite that was extremely spicy, but the dish overall was not spicy at all. The burger was yummy, but also pretty standard. 

Overall, I don't think I'd come back again.
author: Jamie C.

description: Brussel sprout chips are rad, polenta is awesome, chicken sandwich is great. Nothing on the menu has ever disappointed. I keep coming back! Excellent cocktails as well. Be sure to make a reservation!
author: Nick C.

description:
Food was good. The chicken was unreal, great taste and large portion.  The burger was a little sloppy and basic in flavor. If I'm paying over $14 for a burger it should be a lot better then what I got . The service was probably the worst thing.  It took awhile to get water and situated with our waiter.

Also the bar forgot our drink and later replaced it with a free glass of champagne. 

Overall a good experience and I would eat here again.
author: michael s.

description:
Came here with a colleague for lunch - based on the high reputation they have for their burgers.  It's certainly popular.  Place was crowded and we had to wait for a table.  But service was good.  I really wanted to love the burger.  I did.  But it didn't happen.  It was maybe "above average", but not by much.  Had a nice charbroiled flavor.  But was on the dry side and the size of the burger was not inspiring, especially considering the price.  Maybe I just caught the kitchen on an off day.  But then again - a burger joint like this should not have trouble serving a great burger ... every time.

I'll have to try it again to see if they redeem themselves.
author: Lewis C.

description:
It has been a while since I dined at Marlowe. In fact, we ended up going to the old location before realizing that they moved.

We ordered our usual brussels sprout chips and bone marrow for starters, then the pork chops and polenta for entrees. I remember being blown away every time I had the pork chops here, but this time it wasn't so. The flavor was different, I enjoyed the pork chops at the old location more. I'm not sure what changed.

The brussels sprout chips was also not as crispy as before and the polenta was unexciting. We did like the bone marrow though.
author: Colin Z.

description:
Went there for the first time today. My friend got the fried chicken sandwich with fries, I got the calamari, chorizo tartine with an avocado base and topped off with microgreens and roe. In addition, we got the brussel sprouts chips as an apetizer. Awesome and unexpected combo. 

Overall the food was good, but a bit salty. It definitely left my friend and I dehydrated in the end. Other than that, the food was fresh. Will come back again, but will order something lighter. Definitely a better place to grab a drink and a snack versus eating a full meal in my opinion.
author: M L.

description: This is my go-to neighborhood lunch spot. Hamburger, Fries, Brussel Sprout Chips and Deviled Eggs are absolute must haves! The reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 though is because the rest of the menu in lacking. All the times I've ventured beyond those 4 items, I've been disappointed. But I would definitely still recommend it!
author: Zippy L.

description:
Damn. That POLENTA.

There's days and nights where I still dream about the moment i died and went to heaven. But then when i have those dreams I start to drool over that beautifully crafted dish. Polenta w/ mushrooms, parm, arugula & poached egg.

What more can you ask for? Oh we had amazing bone marrow. Maybe the bone marrow in canada was a little better but how do you top this meal? 

I also had their darkest beer. And it all mixed very well. I was surprised that the dark mixed well with the airy-ness of the polenta. But if i could get my hands on that everyday i would be a happy happy man.

Ambience - Basic Brasserie; candle light and dim lighting
Single Occupancy Bathroom
View of Soma
author: Tien L.

description: This place is small, but great food and ambiance. I only tried it once but can't wait to go again. We tried the fish, burger and bunch of appetizers. Loved it!
author: Sahar B.

description:
This was our first stop after landing at SF International. We hit the end of the lunch rush and sat at the bar as all the family style seating was taken. This ended up being a fortuitous event as the bar tender's service/customer repoir was outstanding. Shauntee was incredibly friendly and helpful... not to mention he put with all our tourist-y questions with warmth and friendliness.  

Aside from the great customer service, the food was amazing as well. We got the brussel sprouts, marlowe burger, and deviled egg sandwich. All well made and delicious. The horseradish aioli was a particularly tasty treat.
author: Daniel S.

description: Must try the Irish Coffee!!! It's not on their menu but it was the highlight of our dinner and it come a with marshmallow whip cream on top which I could and would eat off a spoon. In terms of food, we had the pork chops, butter brussels sprouts, polenta, fries, duck liver, chicken fried okra, and the cauliflower. All were good but the polenta was what stood out as the best dish for our group. Our server was also great and gave us extra bread for our duck liver and marshmallow whip cream.
author: Helen L.

description: My new favorite dinner place in SOMA. Bone marrow, steak tartare, pork chops... perfection.
author: Abi G.

description:
The place was crowded - it was Friday night. We had reservations but arrived early. Host offered us a cocktail and we waited for our table. Everyone was nice and accommodating. 

Ordered food to share - deviled egg, Brussel sprout chips and then split a burger - medium rare.

It all came out fine - waited a little long for the burger after apps, but it was ok. Burger was cooked exactly medium rare!

Rare -
author: Carol T.

description:
Have been coming to Marlowe quite a bit, hoping beyond hope they'd work on the seating situation. The seating is so cramped you are almost on top of your fellow diner's laps. We waited for a table and ordered drinks from the bar which was packed. Then got told we could not stand there. Told to go stand over by the other end, but we got bumped and jostled by all the wait staff, who I'm sure don't enjoy it any more than a customer but really you don't have to be so aggressively pushy. We're going to be paying to sit and eat. Please Marlowe! Rework the seating and waiting areas. 

The food is good - though the menu is small you won't go wrong on the Marlowe burger or the Okra. I will keep coming back, the bar staff are awesome and if you get there early enough and get a seat at the bar, you'll be happier. That being said you have to get there as soon as they open. The place fills up. Waiting spot, secondary bar seating or more room to eat. We'll all wait. Promise.
author: Elizabeth A.

description:
Came here last Saturday and made a last minute reservation. They get pretty packed, so if you can get a reservation in.. highly suggested. 

The staff are all friendly. We were seated immediately and our server as well as everyone else was super attentive to our needs and made sure our glasses were filled whenever needed.

I ordered the grilled calamari on chorizo flat bread with a poached egg. OMG. It was amazing. I'm usually not a calamari person, but this was exquisite! Grilled to perfection and not overly fishy. The chorizo added a nice saltiness to the palette and the egg of course neutralizing the flavor. The bread and sprouts were a nice addition to the plate.

I wish I could've eaten more... but my appetite wasn't there. I'll be back though because everything on the menu looks amazing!

And I love the decor. So cute.
author: Nathalie N.

description:
I tried visiting Marlowe a few times, but it is always crowded and there is always a wait. Made reservation a day before and finally got the chance to try this place out.

I'm generally impressed, I wish I had more people with me to try out more appetizers, they all looked really good. We had the brussel sprout chips and the bone marrow, and they are both highly recommended. For the main course, the Poulet Vert(chicken) and the Polenta are both really really good. My experience was not entirely perfect because of my dad's cod fish. It wasn't bad, it just wasn't really fresh, was expecting better. For dessert, we had the Strawberry and Rhubarb Crisp. Bourbon ice cream, strawberry and caramel? Heavenly! 

I'll expect around $40 per person. All in all, a very satisfying meal and will definitely come back again!
author: Jon C.

description: For the price and menu limitation, this place is just okay! But if you like over priced food that's just so so eat here! I get better food for free at work!
author: Michael B.

description:
I had the Steak Tartare, 1/2 dozen raw Oysters , and Bone Marrow.  All were fabulous, especially with a nice glass of white wine, which I had but thought was WAY overpriced. 

Place is a bit loud - small and intimate - but the service was good and I thought the bartender nice and attentive (I sat at the bar).  The big thing for me was the price and the wine selection - definitely not $$.  I will go back if I'm in that area again, but I hope to feel more full for $100 (solo at that).
author: Lauren G.

description:
Burgers are the new filet mignon it seems.

The progenitor for foodie best of lists, SF burgers are a 'have your cake and eat it too' philosophy.  Gourmet, topped with all kinds of indulgences (truffles, pecorino, etc) but no less artery clogging and sinful than the more blue collar burger.

Marlowe makes a cute little burger that is a happy medium.  Carmelized onions, aioli, cheddar, and bacon top the burger, which is delicious on the rare side.  The fries are yummy, and together made a nice lunch.  The brussels sprout chips are bathed in a perfect mix of olive oil, lemon, and salt.  The apple crisp with Bourbon ice cream in a mason jar is my choice for dessert, not that I needed it after such a filling lunch, but I was there for a celebratory occasion with co-workers, so it goes.

The space is small, so praise the lord for OpenTable! My party of six walked in at the exact moment of our reservation, and the hostess knew my name and the table was all ready.  Wait staff was gracious, and the espresso was perfectly pulled!

Yes, Mr. Bauer loved the burger, but so did almost 100 fine yelpers.  If that is not rave enough, I implore you to go try it yourself!
author: Joanna M.

description:
Came here after making a reservation a month prior with a group of four. The staff and service were very good. The atmosphere is casual with the service of a fine dining establishment - the waitress took the orders but all food and drink was delivered by a variety of bussers/wait staff.

Delicious cocktails - order The Baker. The food was very rich and savory. Our party shared appetizers and entrees. Of course we had to order the Brussel chips and the bone marrow. Perhaps we got a bad piece of marrow but ours was overcooked resulting in not enough meat for the small offering of crostinis that came with it. The pretzel nugget serving for dessert was a bit meager but the chocolate cream pie made up for it.

Make a reservation and try it out! Like all things in life high expectations lead to disappointment so go in a with an open mind and big appetite.
author: Allison I.

description:
Simply delicious - all around! Definitely worth trying amidst the myriad of restaurant choices that San Francisco has to offer. My foodie husband and I always find ourselves remembering the great dinners we had at Marlowe's and continue to place them in our top five restaurants to visit whenever we get the chance to visit this city. 
The go to for us are the burgers and fries ofcourse! As well as the brussel sprouts. 
Very cool laid back atmosphere and even cooler wait staff - very easy going and polite.  
A must try if you haven't.
author: Nadia G.

description:
Let's be honest, the food isn't worth the price.  

$9 brussel sprout chips that are dry.
$14 crab and shrimp cakes that were the best part of the meal, although the portion is tiny.
$16 burger that's far too small.  Ordered two as I was dining with a friend.
$9 desert that did its thing.  Nothing sang.
$15 glass of red wine.  $14 glass of rose.

Walked out paying $93 before tax and tip for a meal that didn't satisfy.  I left hungry.

As for the decor, hanging Edison lamps in what looks like a Noah's bagel shop just doesn't do it for me.  Even if you have a stuffed animal head over the bar.

All the tile makes this place extremely loud as well.
author: Bryan R.

description:
Delicious burgers? Absolutely. Had a business lunch here with a colleague and it's delicious. Because of how packed it is (go EARLY if you're trying to get a table, or make reservations early). 

We opted in for the brussel sprouts (pretty good) and the burger (delish). One of the better burgers I've had in SF (maybe top 3). It's really small inside, so if you expect a spot, think ahead.

Ambiance is casual. Chill spot to kick back, eat, and have a beer.
author: Albert K.

description:
Our new find in the city - simply outstanding!! Starting with our server, Craig, everything was impeccable. Wine list very reasonable: Laurent Perrier Champagne at $77!  

Starters were bone marrow (yummy) and steak tartare (seasoned perfectly), and pork chop for entree was the best I've ever had. Yep, ever!!  Terrific experience and can't wait to go back.
author: David S.

description:
Had heard a lot about this place. A lot of good things. The good things weren't lies. 

Had the deviled egg, which was absolutely, baconly amazing. Followed by the calamari appetizer, which was slightly citrusy and perfect follow-up to the heavier deviled egg. 

Ordered brussels sprouts chips to share, and they were amazingly crispy, citrusy and perfectly salty. Entree was pork chop, and that was the best pork chop I've ever had in my life. It didn't even taste like pork. 

To top everything off, service was great. So...yep, I highly recommend this place and am looking forward to coming back again soon.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
Incredible. All around beautiful atmosphere and great food. Service was perfect, super kind and on top of things but not annoying or excessive! Great job!

Went for my birthday dinner- 
DO make reservations! Make your life easier.
We started w cocktails at the bar. They were awesome! Lots of effort and love go into them.

We ordered: pistachios, corn soup, new york strip steaks, fries, and dessert. 

Everything was delicious. Perfect sided portions not too small and not overwhelming.

I know you will enjoy it!
author: Bea A.

description:
Right next to 4th & King Caltrain. Can be busy during dinner, but the fries and horseradish aioli alone make it arguably worth it. 

Came here Saturday night during the dinner rush. The host told us it would be about a 25 minute wait and that he would send us a text when the table was ready. We went for a quick 15 minute walk before heading back to make sure we would not be late. To our surprise, the party of the same size originally behind us in line had already been seated while we were told our table was still not ready. After waiting another 20 minutes (35 in total), we were finally seated and given the Deviled Egg appetizer as a thank you/apology for waiting. 

The eggs were definitely savory and filling, but a bit too small to command their price if I were to order them again next time. The Marlowe burger dripped with juice and comes out cooked exactly to your liking, but it's pretty standard for what you would expect from any premium burger joint. The fries and horseradish aioli -- these alone made our party forget about the wait. Fries were fried to the perfect amount of crispy, aioli had just enough horseradish to get the taste without the sting. Definitely worth ordering again.

Service: 3.5/5
Food: 4.5/5
author: Cliff H.

description: Good service, good food, small menu. the food was very tasty and service was very good. Menu was small and while the polenta was outstanding the small number of choices makes it difficult to give them 5 stars
author: Steve M.

description:
My go-to indulge treat for lunch. 

The brussel sprout chips are fantastic. The Marlowe burger is perfection. The drinks are yummy but a tad on the pricey side at $12 or so. 

I always come in and sit at the bar. Never sat at a table before but I will come in for dinner and reserve a spot. 

Very lucky to have a solid restaurant within steps of my office!
author: Lily M.

description:
This was easily one of the best restaurant experiences I've ever had. 

My boyfriend took me here for my birthday so we went all out on the menu. 

Wines: because they were moving locations, they didn't have all of their wines in stock but the staff was very knowledgeable and helpful in picking out replacements for the wine I asked for. 

Deviled eggs: these were the first things we got and they set the tone for the rest of the meal. The flavor combination of the pickled jalapeños, bacon, and egg is just the right amount of spicy and salty. 

Bone marrow: I think this might have been my favorite part of the meal. It had the best flavor of any marrow I've ever had.

Poulet vert: I got the chicken and it was a fantastic decision. The flavor went all the way through the meat and the outside edges were crisp. The parsnips served with it were almost glazed on the outside and complimented the taste of the chicken wonderfully 

Pork chop: my boyfriend got this and I was amazed not only by the taste but by the size of the meal itself. It was huge! Very tasty from the couple of bites I tried. 

We both had dessert and coffee/tea with it. 

I will gladly go back to Marlowe but be aware that even if the prices are manageable, they pile up quickly. My boyfriend and I spent close to $140 for two people. But it was money well spent in my opinion.
author: McLaren C.

description: Crafty cocktails are sometimes weird but generally very good. Food was excellent, tasty and artsy as well.
author: Renats S.

description:
We came here last night before going to Cirque du Soleil.  Though we could not get a reservation, I stopped by at 5:30 to put our name in, and they had a table for us at 6:30, so we went nearby for a drink.  When we returned our table was ready within about 10 minutes.  The hostess was very sweet!

We sat at the communal table, which wasn't bad since they put a seat between us and each party on either side, so we had our own space!

We had heard raves about the burger, so we both ordered the burger, and switched out one of the fries for brussel sprouts.  (We ended up being served the brussel sprout chips instead of the brussel sprouts, which were still good, though lacked any of the nutrition of brussel sprouts...hehe). 

Burger was tasty, juicy, well cooked and good flavor.  Not sure it meets the raves, but it was good!  The fries and brussel sprout chips were also tasty, I quite enjoyed the horseradish aioli!

Waitress was attentive though not the friendliest.  Our waters were continuously full, which I love.  

I will be back if we are in the area, but I won't make a special trip.  All the hype over the burger, it was good, but you can get the same thing with more variety and less money at Unami Burger.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Brussels sprouts chips...

If I don't have your attention, your taste buds must be on death row. 

When the deep bowl of light, crispy, salty goodness arrived to the table I almost grabbed it and hovered over it, like a dog, refusing to share with my 8 friends. But no, that wouldn't be right... right? I took a spoonful onto my plate and passed it on. Good thing I didn't taste it before passing it on because I would have stabbed someone in the neck if they had tried to take it away from me after that first blessed taste. 

No worries, there were more Brussels sprouts to come, this version had them sliced in half and sauteed in brown butter. I normally don't like veggies made in butter because believe it or not, it gives me a stomach ache, but these were tasty. That could be because I only ate a couple. They are good, but I'd order doubles of the chips. Trust me on that one as regular sauteed Brussels sprouts are not that hard to make (not dissing Marlowe's, because I sure as hell could *not* approximate anything the geniuses in the kitchen make here). Any restaurant that has not one but two dishes featuring these little spheres of delight is AOK in my book.

More on the preamble front: 
-the Burrata is bliss on the lips
-fries with aioli -- when can you ever go wrong with fries? Still, if you're deciding on just a couple apps, go for the rock stars on the menu as mentioned above, instead. 

And then the main course: polenta. See, I've been a grits addict since I was a child. Grits, polenta, however it's called. While my boyfriend makes the best grits/polenta on the planet, Marlowe's is a *very* close second. It's the only straight up vegetarian entree on the menu (you can get it made vegan. I, for one, left the egg off). Do not skip this dish, even if the meaty stuff is catching your eye, trust me. I say this because the meat eaters at the table were all over it when sampled. Creamy polenta, greens, mushrooms, shaved parm... seriously, I die just thinking about it. I'm about to whip up a bowl of grits and then cry into them because they will never be as good as Marlowe's. 

So, Chef Jennifer Puccio, I *kiss your grits*! (those born after 1983 will probably not get this reference). 

If this review were just about the food, it would be 5 stars without hesitation. My "issue" if there is one, is with the atmosphere. I don't mean aesthetically, as it gives off a dark and inviting kind of vibe... if it were empty. Despite the fact that it's a small room, it's not an intimate space. It's incredibly loud, and you will shout at the person sitting next to you. Add to that occasional beams that may crisscross part of the longer tables, blocking off all communication with the person across from you. 

And ladies, don't wear skirts here unless you wish to give your dining companions a crotch shot (curses to that picnic bench seating).

However, that food... it's just that incredible. Marlowe is now on my "must list" on my next trip to San Francisco.
author: Joi B.

description: Such a big fan of Marlowe! We had our first meal as an engaged couple here and since have been taken care of like family. Most recently we dined out for a casual Sunday night meal and they thoughtfully surprised us with two glasses of champagne to celebrate our four months of engagement. Five stars to Marlowe; it's beautiful decor, delicious food and amazingly attentive staff!
author: Raissa H.

description:
Went there with my Boss and a co worker.  We had a very nice lunch. It was a warmer than usual day in SF but thank goodness the inside of the restaurant cooled me down a bit. The ambiance was friendly and warm. I liked the decor. Very Metro chic. The hostess and the servers were attentative.  

The Brussels Sprout Chips were lovely with a hint of lemon. They were just a tad bit salty.    I ordered the Marlowe Burger.  It was good, nothing to write home about.  The salad that came with the burger was quite tangy.  I couldn't finish it all.   The side of fried were good. Overall, a decent meal.  Just didn't wow me. 

Would I go back?  Sure, because Service was topnotch and even tho the dishes may be off.. Could it be that it was busy?  Plus I have to try the shrimp roll.
author: Tiffany R.

description:
I like Marlowe's. One of the better quality restaurants in southern SOMA. Brussel sprout chips are awesome. I also like the small dessert offerings they have. In general all of the fish dishes are cooked just the way I like it (not overdone) with a variety of interesting sauces. Well worth a stop, but it's best to come early or late to lunch as it tends to get busy and a little loud. 

Overall one of my go-to lunch places.
author: Curt B.

description:
We went on a Sunday evening as a be-lated Anniversary celebration. Although I had expected Sunday to be on the slow side, the restaurant was brimming with people and vibrant with conversation.

Delicious is the easiest way to describe each and every element of our dinner experience from the first sip of my "Baker" cocktail to the last decadent bite of our Gingerbread Cake dessert.  In between, our meal consisted of...

- Brussels sprouts chips: wonderful flavor, but a little clunky to eat, 
- Warm deviled eggs: a near perfect bite!,
- Di Stefano burata: more salad and less cheese than expected, but it all worked together amazingly well,
- Grilled calamari and chorizo tartine: also unexpected as it was a bit like an open-faced sandwich.  Not much to look at, but again all came together harmouiously,
- Marlowe burger: burger itself was quite good, not anything that blew me away, but good. The fries and horseradish aolii are a match made in heaven

I would add that the Baker cocktail ( I had 2!) was easily one of the best drinks I have had in a while - smooth and just the right level of sweetness. I will be trying to replicate this one for a while!

The only drawback, which others have mentioned is how close the tables are together. I got to know my neighbors a little more than I had hoped during the course of the evening.  Would be lovely to have even a few more inches separating the tables. But, the food makes up for it and I will definitely go back!
author: Jessica B.

description:
Oh how I wanted to love Marlowe.  After all the great yelp reviews, expectations were high.  Came here after a Giants game, a playoff loss by the way, at about 9:30.  Cold night, so we in the mood for some good grub to warm us up.

Nice place across from the train station.  Friendly wait staff, attentive as well.

Five of us altogether, all 5 ordered the Marlowe burger.  From the reviews I expected the burger of my life.  Not quite.  First of all, too salty.  Taste was good.  Moist, not juicy.  Fries too salty too.  Maybe tonight's chef was salt freak.  Flavor was good, not mind blowing.

For the price, many better burger options out there.  Actually I was pretty disappointed.  I would rank it in the bottom third of burgers I've ever eaten.  If we go again, would probably try some of the other dishes yelpers have raved about.  Strike out on the burger.
author: Steve G.

description: When arriving to San Francisco, I came here  with my girlfriend for the Marlowe burger after reading so many positive reviews. There was nothing special about this burger, I would prefer a burger from one of the popular chains like In-N-Out or The Habit. My girlfriend ordered the fried chicken sandwich and she was also disappointed. Sadly food was nothing special. Having to wait over 40 minutes for my order didn't help the experience. I'm not sure what happened to our order but the server was very apologetic for the long wait time. We were given caramelized pistachios by the manager. All in all, friendly service and average food. It seems like a good place to have a drink and not much more.
author: Albert G.

description: I was back in town a few months ago, and saw they'd moved locations. A friend and I caught up for dinner and cocktails. It was as good as I remembered, and the new outdoor seating area was excellent. If I was local, this would be a go-to date spot.
author: Jehan A.

description:
Met a friend here, on the recommendation of someone with obviously great tastes in restaurants.

Small, convivial, wonderful spot. As Zak R wrote -- it's definitely cozy. Rustic feeling. Comfortable, not snobby.

Intriguing wine list, with several available by the glass... I love to try out new things, and Marlowe's list does not disappoint. I enjoyed a glass of a Cab Sauv blend from Bonny Doon (one of my favorite wineries!) as well as a new-to-me grape... or so I thought! Wait, it's a Mourvèdre in Spanish guise! In any event, it was tasty.

Started with the brussels sprouts chips, which were -- as basically everyone else has said -- excellent, as in "waitress-please-don't-take-that-bowl-until-we-are-DONE-WITH-EVERY-CRUMB" excellent.  

Also had the deviled egg, which was super good too. A nice little kick to it. I could've eaten several more... 

But then, I wouldn't have had dinner! I had the polenta, which I thoroughly enjoyed. I was sated, not stuffed. My friend enjoyed her meal as well. 

DO NOT MISS DESSERT. I had the TCHO chocolate "pie," which actually comes in a little Mason jar. It's not terribly huge, but it's a decent portion, enough to leave you wanting more. My friend had the crisp, and she thought it was awesome.

The one thing I found odd? In this city -- nay, this region -- of awesome coffee purveyors, they serve Stumptown, from Oregon. Don't get me wrong; I LOVE Stumptown (the Hair Blender blend is awesome), and Marlowe made me a really nice macchiato. But when you have so many roasters to choose from in the surrounding area... why go with Stumptown? A fairly minor quibble in an overall fantastic experience. 

The tea comes from local favorites, Republic of Tea.

Another great thing about Marlowe: It is very close to Caltrain, which is awesome if you're commuting, but not-so-awesome on Giants game days, because it's super busy. 

Make reservations.
author: Tami S.

description: I had the burger which was a bit underwhelming. The cauliflower starter however, was delicious - cauliflower has never tasted so good! The atmosphere was nice and it was an all round nice restaurant, which I was glad about considering the area it was in seemed a bit seedy but maybe I don't know better because I'm from out of town.
author: Maddison N.

description: I can't even begin to express my disappointment in their infamous burger.  It may very well be because we were there near closing time, but still, that's no excuse for such atrocity.  First off, the buns were hard and stale.  No joke.  Is this really how they're supposed to be? Lastly, we requested our patties to be cooked medium and we received overcooked patties.  Honestly, I don't understand how such a renowned restaurant can mess up a burger this badly.
author: Michele L.

description: Brunch here is wonderful! I had their deviled eggs, crab and shrimp crepe, fried chicken sandwich and smoked salmon bagel plate all to share. Fruit juices are nice too. I would love to come back for dinner soon.
author: Lily P.

description: Holy smokes, service gets a 5 but the pork chop brings it down. i actually had to get a second knife, because my first knife was a little dull, but it wasnt just the knife on the chop with the bone. it was kinda tough but the boneless part was actually juicy and flavorful. it made up for it. you want a place that not to fancy but a very chill place with the best attentive service. this is the place
author: Roy K.

description:
Marlowe. Burger. That's all you need to know. The patty had a slight smokey flavor to it, which really complimented the rest of the fresh ingredients. There's a reason why this place is often referred to as having the best burger in town.

All the other appetizers such as the bone marrow, the duck live crostini, and baked oysters are solid, as well.

I don't think you can go wrong ordering anything at this place. I haven't had a single bad dish!
author: Kazu O.

description: Their location in the old Coco 500 space suits them well!  Dinner at the bar was delicious (as expected) and social with the others sitting nearby.  Brunch with my mom was also a hit.  Thank you Marlowe for delivering when it counts.  ;)
author: Melanie C.

description:
Date & Time:  Wednesday February 17, 2010 @ 6pm
Dining Companion:  The Husband
Scene:  Attractive After-Work Singles in Pairs & Couples.  Guys w/ Messenger Bags in Business Casual & Girls in SpringTime Sleeveless Chiffon Tops & Little Milly Dresses
Vibe:  Chill
Music:  Eclectic Mix of Soundtrack from Shaft, Alicia Keys & Billy Joel
Decor:  Urban Rustic.  Edison Light-Bulbs & Candle-Lit.  White-Washed Exposed Brick Walls.  Menu Written on Chalkboards & Butcher Paper.  Communal Table & Wooden Tables w/ Leather Benches & Banquettes
Service:  Professional & A Tad Snooty(Not the Host/ Hostess & Our Server)
Imbibe:  Sauvignon Blanc & Imported Sessions Beer  
Devour:  Baked Oysters in New England Chowder, Parsnip Soup w/ Creme Fraiche, Bone Marrow w/ Salsa Verde, Steak Frites & Upside Down Apple Crisp w/ Bourbon Ice Cream & Butter Cream Caramel.  All Desserts Served in Rustic Glass Jars
Total:  $91.10
author: Genevieve Y.

description: Came for lunch on a weekday. No bone marrow on the lunch menu :(. Guess I'll be coming back for dinner another time. Refreshing black and white motif sets the ambiance. Service was on point and food to come back for. I had the burger with salad - although they brought me fries by mistake. They fixed that in a jiffy and told me to enjoy the fries too. Loved them, perfectly crispy. The burger hit the spot too. I really don't need to get into the brussel sprout chips...just order'em!
author: Leland H.

description:
Come for the burger, stay for the appetizers and sides!

Last time I came here was when it was only a few months old. Had lunch here with a coworker, and we each enjoyed their burger before they became known for it. This time, I came here with another couple on a Saturday evening, two ordered the burger, one ordered the polenta, and I ordered the roasted bone marrow and sweet corn soup. We shared the brussel sprout chips (which I guess isn't for everyone - more for me!). Loved, loved, loved the corn soup. I wanted to lick my bowl clean - though that would have been very rude and inappropriate.

The other half shared his burger with me and yes, it was good but not as amazing as what I ordered. The fries were a bit salty, but dipping it in the aioli fixed that. I had the cocktail special of the night and it tasted like sparkling pomegranate juice. It was sweet but pretty strong for a dainty drink.

Service was attentive. No attitude but not overly friendly either. Glasses of water were always filled. Nice date spot, but can get a bit loud, especially when they turn on the music later in the evening. Make reservations, it gets packed. Parties of more than four sit at the communal table.

I would come back and order two of the bone marrow and corn soup, just for myself.
author: Zell C.

description:
The post  South Food+Wine Bar  crew already have a hit on their hands. After only a week of re-opening that place was packed to the hilt. Even with reservations it was a 10-15min wait. We agreed to take the high table in the back and the staff were nice enough to buy us a round of drinks. A small but very interesting wine list fills the beverage category while a wonderful array of bistro entrees fill the food bill. Things tried:

-Crispy brussels sprout chips Meyer lemon, sea salt
-Roasted bone marrow, salsa verde, fine herbs
-"Poulet vert" herb roasted half chicken, warm chicory, olive & potato salad
-Steak Frites, 12oz Creekstone New York Steak
-Brown butter brussels sprouts
-Meyer lemon curd cake, Whipped cream, lemon zest
-Upside down apple crisp, Bourbon ice cream & brown butter caramel sauce
-Tcho chocolate pot de creme
-Monbazilliac, Chateau de Thibault, France, 03
-Garganega Soave, Inama, Veneto, Italy 08
-Malbec Bodega Atamisque, Catalpa, Mendoza, Argentina 08

Everything was super delicious and I have to say Chef Puccio can grill a killer steak. One of the best NY's I have had in a while, perfectly medium rare, with killer frites to boot. Friend said the same thing about his roast chicken and we all savored the brussel sprout dishes. Don't forget to read the various quotes in the windows outside. Go Team Marlowe! 4.5 stars.
author: Kim N.

description:
I'm struggling with how to rank Marlowe. My fiance originally booked a large party of 8 for a Saturday night for my bachelorette. Unfortunately, one of my friends was unable to drive up from the peninsula because she was ill. Due to this, the 4 girls she was car pooling with lost their ride when she wasn't able to make it. Thus, our party dwindled from 8 people to 3 people. We felt really bad about this, and called Marlowe as soon as we found out. They informed us that if we were to cancel, we would be charged 20$ a person, leaving me to need to pay $160 because we couldn't all make it. They were nice and said if we 3 came, they would wave the charge. Reluctantly, after already eating dinner, we went to Marlowe to avoid the $150 charge.

We got there and were sat within a few minutes. Again,we apologized for the change of plans. One of my friends is a waitress, and understood that they probably were frustrated. Anyway, we order our food, and because we are already full from dinner #1, we ordered an appetizer, and 2 entrees to split between 3 girls. The waitress was noticeably irritated when one of my friends passed on ordering an entree. I understand her frustration, but as any good customer service job, you need to learn to hide it. My friend really awkward after this interaction, but she just couldn't eat anymore.

20 minutes pass....30 minutes.....40 minutes....no one has come to our table at all, or apologize for the wait....50 minutes, and we count 15 other people who sat after us were all served......55 minutes later and finally, after flagging down the waiter our food arrives! Really?? 55 minutes to cook 3 scallops and a medium rare steak. Those in fact should take minutes to cook.

The two stars is for the food, which was quite good. Even after eating dinner #1 and being stuffed, we managed to eat all of our entrees. However, the frustration of the events had put a bad taste in our mouth.

My waitress friend was pretty pissed at this point, because she knows that 55 minutes is pretty unacceptable (especially without a single update). She also saw the waiter talking to one of the managers and pointing at us. She was thinking that as a courtesy, something would be taken care of, or offered to us....but no such thing. Not even an apology. I get it--we were a party of 8 that went to 3, its pretty crappy for them to lose (sort of) that business. This was unforeseeable and not any ones fault, but it was hard for us not to feel that the 55 minute wait was done to punish us. 

We missed our train, thus our plans had to change. My lovely bachelorette party unfortunately ended with a sour at Marlowe.
author: Yanna L.

description: Great food.  I had the scallops - they were both healthy (on top of delicious beans) and tasty. Great decor and atmosphere, highly recommended!
author: Eric B.

description: Whoa. Delicious food, plenty of it, and a delightful evening atmosphere for a nice night out. Take a date and share a sampling.
author: Paula R.

description:
What a great evening! My family brought me to Marlowe for Mother's Day and we had a great time. The waiter was quite informed and spot on about the various creative cocktails and the fare. The bartender made a fine Pimm's Cup and Manhattan. We started with Oysters on the Half Shell; fresh and delicious, Pea Cakes with salmon and caviar, delightful bites and the Bone Marrow, which was good. 
We then tried the pork chops, done to perfection with just the right amount of sides and the hamburger which was quite tasty, as others have written. The dessert which was coffee ice cream on meringue drizzled with chocolate sauce was very good. 
The atmosphere is upbeat and has a really good feel. A delicious place to dine, we will return!
author: Karla B.

description: As a First timer this is actually a good place to eat. Burgers are bomb! Waitress has good service super nice and polite. No rush.
author: Jae R.

description: Good solid food before going to a show at AT&T park recently!  I went by the advice of my fellow Yelpers and got the brussel sprout chips (yes, get it, it's so good!), bone marrow (so tasty good, I wanted more!!) and the burger (has bacon, loved the horse radish sauce, good with the fries too, what more do you need!!).  I had to try the 3 Bs the first time here of course, but the rest of the menu looked equally yummy - can't wait to come back and try other menu items!  But I might need to order at least the bone marrow again - yes, I liked it that much!
author: Maile N.

description:
Have been here so many times, finally decided to write them a fair review. There are already so many good comments about them, I will save everybody's time and not to duplicate. However, I do need to say, that Marlowe burger is one of the best I town. The crispy bacon, juicy grass fed beef, and fresh lettuce are just perfect combination. The smoky flavor is absolutely unforgettable. 
I tried chicken burger, too. It's good if you are craving fried chicken. But it's not nearly as impressive as Marlowe burger. Burgers come with fries and mustard mayo sauce. If you have been in Europe and miss fries with mayo instead of catchup, this is the place to go. 

Well, I have mixed feeling about crispy Brussels sprout chips. It could be very very salty sometimes.

As for service, um.... Did I mention there is an unfriendly waitress? If you open your mouth too many times for chatting with your friends instead of eating your lunch, she would be very unhappy...
author: Wen S.

description:
This small restaurant has a small menu, but it is filled with well prepared dinner options. 

My girlfriend and I started with the brussel sprout chips which were pretty good. For entrees, we had the risotto and pork chop. I am usually not a huge pork chop fan, but the giant grilled pork chop at Marlowe was crispy, juicy and hit the spot. 

The staff was friendly and attentive. 

Other things to know:
The restaurant is a quick walk from all the hotels on 3rd St. if you are in town on vacation.
It is also across the street from the train station so there are plenty of cabs there all night if you do not feel like walking.
author: Tony D.

description:
I would have loved to rate this 4+ stars, but the host and servers were just too subpar. Perhaps they can hire more staff and more pleasant ones.

The decor and atmosphere are great. Very casual and comfy. 

The food was average. We had the burger, crispy chicken sandwich, bacon pancakes, oysters and deviled eggs. All were decent but nothing to rave about. There was way too much aioli on the chicken sandwich. The best item were the pancakes.
author: Sharon L.

description: I've been a customer for years. I hesitate to write such a review, however we need to be able to count on placing a to go order especially after the closing of Marlowe burger. Tonight we couldn't place an order, and last time we ordered to go, we were shorted a dish which we got charged for. Anna and Jennifer...we love your restaurants, but please fix how you engage with your neighbors who regularly count on your restaurant.
author: Jaime F.

description: Amazing food, wonderful ambience and very knowledgable and helpful waitstaff made this an amazing experience.
author: Beth C.

description:
I would have given 4 stars for the old location. It's my 2nd time at Marlowe and heard they relocated so I wanted to check it out. I definitely miss the smaller intimate feel of the prior location. They also took off clams from the menu :(.
We ordered the Brussel sprout chips, chicken fried okra, Marlowe burger, and smoked black cod. The appetizers are great but the portions are tiny. I think the chips came in an even smaller bowl than my 1st visit. The okra was battered and fried...you can't go wrong there but it was a little on the heavy side. The burger was mehhh...but fries were yummy! It came with a lemon aioli which gave it a little twist. Black cod was pretty good. All the fixings that it came with just married together. 
It's a nice date night spot. Made for parties of 2-4. Food is decent. Overall 3.5 stars.
author: Linda P.

description: Really cute location and restaurant. Food is thoughtful and nice flavor. The poulet vert was the surprising the best dish, as I almost never order chicken in a restaurant. The polenta with mushrooms, cheese and egg was also a great lighter dish.
author: David L.

description: Delicious food. Brussels sprouts chips and the calamari were great starters. Deviled eggs were also delicious. We had also ordered the pork chops, chicken and polenta. The dishes that really stood out were the calamari and polenta. Burger was good but they undercooked it a bit and was chewy. The drinks were pretty good too. I loved the baker and the butchers mistress. It's a great place to eat.
author: Lisa M.

description:
Came to Marlowe for dinner after a Giants game. (Giants won 5-3)

Started with the brussels sprout chips and bone marrow. Loved the bone marrow, but the brussels sprout chips had a little too much lemon zest IMO. The first few chips were good, but the flavors got too strong after that.  Would definitely order the bone marrow again. 

I ordered the Marlowe burger, thinking that my 2 year old daughter would have some, but who am I kidding. She's a rice bucket. She loves carbs. And she has never asked for a burger. Plus, as soon as my plate comes, she's going for the fries...forget about feeding her a nutritious meal. 

5 minutes before my burger comes out, the waiter brings me ketchup. 

My daughter: What's dat!? Dat ketchup!? Dat for me!? 

Yup, she had fries for dinner that night.  While she enjoyed my fries, I enjoyed my burger - flavorful and juicy. 

My husband ordered the pork chop. It's actually a pretty big portion and can get heavy, especially with the risotto. He enjoyed it. 

Overall a good meal. Nice way to end a awesome day out on the other side of town. Btw, I ended up feeding my daughter chicken and rice when we got home. 

Note to self: Never let the waiter take the ketchup away when the kid still has fries in her hands.
author: Elaine C.

description:
This is a small upscale/hipster joint that doesn't quite deliver on value. Came here for lunch on a weekday:

-Brussel sprout chips were overly salted, and overly greasy. For 7 bucks, there was probably a total for 4 brussel sprouts in there
-Steak frites was okay but did not knock my socks off--cooked slightly over the requested medium
-Tuna duo was interesting and flavorful, this was something I would eat again but portion was relatively small
-Lamb bbq was very underwhelming. Feels like they through lamb into a slow cooker with some store bought bbq sauce and served it on grocery store bread.
author: Michael L.

description:
Thoughtful in every way. It was a Friday night, we had reservations at 6pm but could not make it. I checked Opentable and nothing else was available that night so I called and they were super accommodating. Long story short, they got us a table at an impossible time later that evening. When we got there, they already had the table ready for us, we didn't have to wait at all.

Our server, Jooley was so nice and again thoughtful. We ordered the burger and pork chop with intentions of sharing. We never told her that we were going to share but some how she knew and when the plates came, everything was cut in half and on separate plates. It was really nice.

The thoughtfulness even comes thru in the burger. The bacon was cut into pieces so it's easier to eat. The burger was the highlight of the evening. Sorry Nopa, I think Marlowe's burger is better. Pork chop, baked oysters and calamari toast were all good (not great).

No annoying Healthy SF charge. Again, thoughtful. It's the details that matter. 5 stars.
author: Andy W.

description:
Most stuck up restaurant I've ever been to. Server was alright, hostess was the worst, food was mediocre. Pretty pricy as well. 
Come here as a last resort only
author: Alex L.

description:
Since The Reviews Are So Great, It Must Be Me, But I Know It Is Not.

To set the record straight, at the outset let me say that I did not have a bad experience at Marlowe. No one "pissed me off," my reservation was not screwed up, I did not have to wait and my waiter was not unfriendly. Now that this is out of the way, either I do not know good food or a lot of reviewers of this restaurant are delusional.

I had the Marlowe burger, fried okra and Brussels sprout chips. Let us take them in order: (1) Folks, you can get better superior hamburger at In-N-Out Burger or Shake Shack for one-third the price; (2) the fried okra was good but not spectacular and lacked seasoning; and (3) the crispy Brussels sprout chips were like separating a Brussels sprout, dipping each portion in olive oil and seasoning and then placing it on a George Foreman Grill for about three minutes.  

This is a nice bright restaurant with friendly service and slightly above average food. I am sorry but there is simply nothing spectacular about the hamburger and the idea that this place is being compared to Four-star restaurants in San Francisco is just plain silly.
author: Chocoolate I.

description:
Came here on Friday to celebrate my birthday. 
My boyfriend made a reservation a few days beforehand (highly recommended considering their place is REALLY small!)

I really want to give this place 5 stars, because I loved their service & ambiance, but the food, although really good, just wasnt up to 5-star par. 

Appetizers

- Warm deviled egg w/ jalapeno & prosciutto: nothing special. 

- Chowder baked half shell oysters: very unique, really good (actually tasted like chowder in there) 

- Brussel sprout chips: really good & great idea, but just WAY TOO SALTY. I drank so much water just eating it & eventually just had to call it quits. 

- Roasted bone marrow: DELICIOUS. 

Main entrees

- Marlowe burger: JUICY & be aware that they put horseradish in there (not too big of a fan of horseradish but the burger was good). I was a tiny bit disappointed with the burger because I was expecting the best burger in SF, but nonetheless I was satisfied. The fries that came with the burger were also VERY salty. 

- Pork chops: probably the BEST pork chops I've ever had. The server pretty much swore by it so we thought we'd give it a try & we were definitely happy. The pork was tender & juicy, not dry at all. The only bad thing was that it was ALSO kinda salty. I love salt & sometimes probably over salt the food I cook, but Marlowe just seems to go on a salt overload! 

Dessert 

- Panna cotta: nothing special, a little bit too tarty. 

Overall, had a great experience. 
Hopefully, they'll ease up on that salt shaker next time I come.
author: Sylvia N.

description:
I went here twice now with my girlfriend and both time I was very impressed. They are really focused on service as much as they are focused on the quality of their food. We ordered several different items from the appetizer and main menu, very impressed with every single item. 

We would go back there for date night or even for happy hour drinks. Please make sure to make a reservation in advance.
author: Waseem A.

description: Good food. Very lengthy service. Main dish took them 30min to make. This waiting time is RIDICULOUS.
author: Sam N.

description:
San Francisco newbie here so where do we go to eat "San Francisco" food?  Well our friend's friend's friend took us here.  My first impression of the place was...

Whoah this is pretty fancy and I'm wearing my Nike Women's marathon hoodie, leggings, and rainbow slippers...oh boy!  

Our party of 6 waited a few minutes for our table to open up and by the looks of this place you could tell that good food awaited our tummies.  It's was almost as though this is where the cool kids go for lunch!   The menu was small but to the point, from my experience working in the restaurant industry that either means the chef puts well thought out food on a plate where presentation AND taste are one in the same.  OR they just want to make it easier on you to decide what you want.  To me, this place is definitely the first one. Just by reading the descriptions of the dishes I could tell we were in store for something good, no matter what we ordered.  I wanted to be modest and taste their less expensive dishes....to see if they put just as much care in them as they do in their $26 meals.

I ordered the citrus gem salad (i think that's what it's called) to get my daily dose of veggie on and paired it with french fries.  Oxymoran?  of course, but it was a french fry day too.  Our dishes took awhile to come out, but our attentive waitress filled our waters promptly any time they needed it.  

When my salad and fries came out I was eager to eat.  The salad looked small and if I wasn't in a nice restaurant I'd probably chow it down fast, but I'm glad i didn't.  There were so many flavors and textures going on it was a piece of ART! Just how I like my food :)  The freshness was undeniable, the presentation was a beauty, and the taste was citrus-ey but not tart.  LOVE!  The fries were memorable but the pork that our friend had was so moist and delicious I highly recommend it!  I know next time I'm in San Francisco I'm coming here and ordering the citrus gem salad and the pork.  You should too!
author: Ka'ili H.

description:
It's not big, but the burger rocks. 5 stars. The horse radish aioli is perfect to cut all that fat.

Brussels sprout chips are good if a little too much grease for one person. Good to share.

The chocolate dessert is 5 stars also.
author: John H.

description: This is a great place with great cuisine. You will not be jilted out of a great meal and a great ambiance if you have purchased a groupon. I never get Groupons but it's how I found this place so maybe I will.
author: Stacy B.

description: (4.5) Come here come here come here. If you're a lover of bone marrow, this place was the restaurant which introduced me to it.  Their steak tartar is massive (egg yolk and all) and their burgers are one of the more affordable, tasty things on the menu. I'm not a fan of their communal seating (seems to outnumber the standalone tables), but the food is exception and the ambiance is very Soma. I typically opt for wine here and don't have strong opinions one way or the other on it.
author: Irina P.

description:
First, they get 5+ stars for excellent service.  Our waiter was nothing but short of excellence.  He was friendly, made recommendations, and we never had to wait for them to refill our water glasses and they were never overbearing or pretentious.

Food...

We thought their appetizers, classics & sides on the menu looked much better than their mains.  There was so much stuff on the menu that we wanted to try. We wanted to try Honey Glazed Pork belly from the appetizer section but then the only main that really grabbed us was Grilled Niman Pork chop and while we love pork, we thought, even for us pork lovers, it was a bit much.

So we settled with our other alternative - twice baked dungeness crab souffle (every single word here was perfectly chosen to get your taste buds up.  twice. baked. dungeness. crab. souffle.)

Waiter recommended that we try their "must try" deviled eggs so we got those too.

I love brussels sprouts and they had two options to choose from - TWO brussels sprout dishes!!!  Crispy brussels sprout chips and brown butter brussels sprouts.  We thought the former (crispy version) maybe less healthy (?) for us so chose brown butter brussels sprouts (because brown butter is healthy...not...)

Oh and how can we skip steak tartare.  

So after ordering 5 dishes (crab souffle, brussels sprouts, deviled eggs, steak tartare & niman pork chops) we continued to chit chat away.  

Food came surprisingly quickly.  Restaurant was pretty empty when we arrived at 6:00 (a whole hour earlier than our original reservation) but before you know it the whole place was packed!  I would never come here without a reservation as they are usually fully booked.  

By the time our main pork dish came we were pretty much stuffed.  That may have also been the reason why we thought the pork dish was not as good as the other dishes we had.  

Although full their dessert menu was too good to pass up. We decided to try 
Strawberry & Rhubarb Crisp.  It was served interestingly in a jar.  It wasn't overly sweet and was a nice finish to our meal.

Would I come back? Certainly.

I thoroughly enjoyed my dining experience (food / vibe / service etc) at Marlowe!
author: Sujan H.

description:
Met a friend here for drinks and apps.  I was there early on a very warm day in SF so I started with a glass of nice Rose ($10).  My friend tried and liked so we ended up with another glass each, followed by a carafe ($20) of the same.

The deviled egg ($1.50 each) is a must have.  It is served warm so we started with one each and had another one later.  

We also had:
duck liver crostini - $11 - roasted Medjool dates, Paige mandarins & pickled mustard seeds.  This was delicious, the liver was very flavorful and velvety...

Baked Oysters - $3 each - New England chowder in a shell.  YUM!

Steak Tartare - $13 - with poached quail egg, crostini.  Very good.

Hostess and waitress were very friendly.
author: Gloria H.

description: It's a small elegant yet casual restaurant. It's got a cute little farm like style. The food though, it's probably the best I've had from all the times I've been in San Francisco. I had their special which was the smoked black cod conserra classic romaine mixed greens and saltine crackers.
author: Gwen C.

description: Delicious. Delicious. Delicious. Everything is amazing here... Deviled eggs, house made flatbread with multiple dipping sauces, Brussel chips, truffle mushroom soup... Strawberry shortcake and chocolate cream pie.. Yes, we did order everything on the menu!!
author: Tiffanie C.

description:
Do you remember the one gf/bf that had so many things wrong with them but was great in bed? You know the one with bad credit, no job, overly jealous, controlling but knew all the right buttons to make scream.

Marlowe for some odd reason reminded me of that one. Let me explain. The appetizers.  Baked oysters, salty but great contrast of texture with the crunch and cheese. Tartare, blah blah blah. Pate on bread, ummm no where's the flavor? Main dish (burger) overrated IMO, the bread was off, but the bacon was crispy as heck. So wait mr kwangto, why 4 stars? I save the best for last.
