Great ambiance - it feels intimate, casual and quality at the same time. The shrimp are amazing, but as a warning the cocktail sauce they come with is spicy! Also get the polenta dish, one of the best veggie dishes I have ever had. The flavors in there are a wonderful mystery.

The service was very attentive and i have to point out how polite the host staff was and how helpful the server was.
author: Ariadne R.

description: They added the Chocolate Cream dessert back to the menu. Thank you for giving me my lunch O-FACE back.
author: Terry C.

description: Meh.  Unenthusiastic service. 1 deviled egg is really half of 1, and had no flavor outside of small piece of bacon top. Gem salad had maybe 4 lettuce leaves, too much parsley and old smushed avocado. Burnt toast beneath decent calamari. Mediocre cocktail. More bun than flavorful enough burger.  Black cod was decent if slightly bland.  What a disappointment.  We had such high hopes for the reopening.  Hostess was reluctant to seat us at communal table vs. short seats at bar even though communal table remained mostly empty during our meal?  Server was completely uninspired in describing menu items. Busboys were great. Maybe they should run the show.
author: m h.

description:
Come here for the burgers, spiced prawns, and crispy fried chicken sandwiches. I have not yet tried the crispy fried chicken sandwich, but will next time I go. My co-worker says it's the only thing he orders at Marlowe.

The burger was just the right size (some may say too small) and was tastefully juicy. Will have to do two zumba workouts after this!

Service could use some improvement. 

The venue is set up as community style dining and tables. So be open to sitting next to a stranger on a bench if all other seats are taken.
author: Erin C.

description: Since the move to the new location, this place has been on my must-eat lists. We ventured there on a Wednesday at 5:30pm, and waited about 30 minutes until we could get seats at the bar (i guess the only place you can sit if you didn't snag reservations). Super friendly irish bartender. Brussel sprout chips are a must have, and have a really great light lemony taste. Had the deviled egg (or HALF an egg) and was not impressed. The bacon on top was a bit salty, and i can probably make better ones at home. Ordered the burger without the bun, along with the fries and the horseradish aioli. The aioli was on point, and it was a solid burger, cooked perfectly. Next time i will have to try the pork chop and a few of their cocktails.
author: Anita H.

description:
This place is really delish. The do a great job on all their small plates. The ambiance is pretty good, despite being across the street from the train.

You definitely get a lot of the commuter crowd, but if you go later in the evening that thins out to more of the "local" SoMa neighborhoodies (Yes we do exist).

Their fried brussel sprouts are delectable. I likes the fried.

The steak tartare was really surprisingly delicious! I usually love tartar at Chez Maman, but I almost liked this better. It had a little spicy kick at the end that was delectable. Mmm, I'm salivating just thinking about this. Yes, it definitely takes top spot of the evening.

The burger is delicious. But you already knew that because of all the other reviews.

The scallops were great too. Smallish but perfectly cooked with a super rich sauce. I may or may not have cleaned the entire plate. LAY OFF ME I WAS STARVING ;)

Paired it was a caraffe of the rose of pinot noir and I was happy as a clam. 

If you're looking for a sweet, romantic, dark, fun spot near the train station, make a reservation here (it fills up fast), and enjoy your tartare.
author: Shanee B.

description: Went for brunch, loud, cramped and mediocre. Burger left a puddle on my plate, had way too much bread (vs other ingredients) and was super salty. Over all it was just very underwhelming and the oppressive noise just made me want to leave.
author: Gabe S.

description:
If it was just based on the Dungeness Crab and Shrimp Crepe that I had for lunch, I would have given them 5 stars because it was scrumptious!  It was light and fluffy with the right amount of seasoning that brought out the delicious flavor of the seafood.  It was complemented with an arugula salad made with the freshest ingredients.  It was a perfect introduction to savory crepes!  However, with that said, I would have to knock down a star for finding hair on my food and another for service.  Restaurants are usually good at prioritizing the correction of sanitation faults but it took so long to get the replacement of my entre that by the time it came, my husband already finished his burger and fries.  I also ordered the Meyer Lemon Crème Brulee for dessert which I regretted, having to wait awhile for something mediocre.  If you have to finally ask your server when you think your food is coming, twice - you've waited for a long time.
Something also didn't add up when we first walked up and gave the hostess our reservation time.  First, she couldn't find our name and flat out said that we didn't have a reservation until my husband pointed the name out from her list.  Next, she indicated that the we made the reservation for the wrong time (3:15pm instead of 2pm).  Absolutely untrue as the reservation was made on Open Table and didn't have that 15minute option.  Luckily, they did have tables available and was able to sit us down right away.  So we definitely, got off on the wrong foot.  The crepe was their redeeming quality along with the place possessing a modern charm.  In any case, if my husband were to write the review, he would have given 2stars for the Marlowe Burger (excessive horseradish aoli) and unexceptional service.
author: Lys L.

description: Enjoyed the steak and frites (order rare) and burrata appetizer. The special cocktail (prosecco with elderflower, grapejuice, etc) is excellent. The noise level is a bit too loud for my taste.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Oh my- this place was good.  It is right across from cal train so I took the train here and met some girlfriends.  We shared the tartare, marrow, (yum) and the salad and the brussel sprout chips.  Brussel sprout chips were heavenly. Three of us got the burger, since there was this delicious horseradish aioli.  We loved our burgers.  My other friend got the stuffed fish with crab, and liked it a lot.  We split the chocolate pie, which we loved.  I remember reading reviews to NOT get the pie, but I am not understanding why.  It was great,  Sea salt, chocolate, crumbly crust in a glass....Also the lemon cake, (also in a glass) was super great.  The cake was light, and there was surprise fruit at the bottom of the glass.

The service was great, the place is small, dimly lit and there are tables and shared communal tables.  We sat at the communal, but in the corner, so it was almost as if we had our own table.  The food was fabulous, and I had a nice time.
author: Lisa M.

description:
This is a review for the rude welcoming that we had, we left before trying the food or any drink. 

It was saturday april 4th 2015, we wanted to go there to have a drink. The hostess before even saying hi, she asked "what can I do for you?" Never had that question entering a restaurant. Of course we want a table for a drink or to eat, what question is that? So we told her, we would like to have a drink. So she said " you can go to the bar". So we walk close to the bar and saw a small table that we try to sit on but she arrives and said "I meant THE BAR" Wwooo. Don't be so rude to us because we are french, we understood what you said, we just saw a table there and would prefer that. So we just looked at each other and you know, let's go somewhere else. We didnt feel welcome at all, we were not dressed like fancy but more like tourists so maybe that's why she acted like that with us. So that was our experience. We live in Sunnyvale and have visitors from Canada all the time but we will never bring anybody there again just because of a bad welcoming hostess at the entrance.
author: Émilie J.

description: Came here with a large group after a ballgame.  I was only in a snacking mood, so I just had beers and some apps.  None of the apps I had were particularly amazing.  I expected to be more wowed after reading of the reviews.  Tried the clams, flavorless.  The Brussels were were more interesting... but they weren't cook all that well.  The tartare was  okay... but again.. .could have used a little more seasoning.
author: Sam C.

description:
Marlowe is my new favorite name. A small place to be sure with only one bathroom but the food makes up for the lack of elbow room. Make sure you make reservations, especially if you've got a large party. 

Red wine was expertly poured as we perused the menu. Too many good choices! So we just ordered everything that looked good. Burrata, Warm Deviled eggs, brussels sprouts chips, steak tartar and marlowe fries. This was before dinner. 

Then we had polenta and burgers and steak frites. Or at least, that's what I tried. I couldn't fit one more thing in but literally everything we ordered was perfection. Marlowe's one of my favorite new stops in SF!
author: Kelly S.

description:
It was around 7pm on a weeknight and the place was packed. I sat at the bar with a friend, and talked business over dinner.

I ordered:

* Toasted Pistachios - excellent. If you're a lover of nicely toasted nuts, order this. I fought my friend for last bites on this one.

* Roasted bone marrow - excellent. They cross cut the bone vertically and serve it in two halves. Very small portion, but evert little bite was an explosion of flavor.

* Marlowe burger - I came here because of the reviews of this burger. I have to say it lived up to its reputation. I would definitely order this again, but next time I think I'll ask for a little less horseradish - I think it overwhelmed some of the other flavored. Minor complaint though.

* the wheat beer - I forget what it was called, but it was as excellent a Hefeweizen as I've had.

I started the review wanting to give four stars, but after typing up my review I decided it really is a five. =)
author: Anthony W.

description: I loved the sprouts and I had the fish. My meal was excellent and so was my cocktail. The only complaint I would have is how cramped the seating is. I was practically touching shoulders with the people on either side of me. When I got up to go to the restroom I almost knocked over the table next to me!
author: Savvy P.

description:
I'm going to try to keep this short. My husband and I went there for our 3 year wedding anniversary. We wanted just a cool place with good eats, and not too pretentious or fancy. Marlowe was on our "must eat while we're still here" list, so we figured why not.

Here's a breakdown of my star rating: 

ONE STAR: We arrive for our reservation time, and are greeted and sat immediately by a lovely host (or floor manager?) and provided menus that they had pre-printed "HAPPY 3rd ANNIVERSARY" on them special for our night. 

ONE STAR: Then, two free glasses of their signature champagne cocktail to celebrate our evening. 

ONE STAR: Our waiter, Mikey, who helped us select things to eat and didn't steer us wrong. Attentive, but not overwhelming. Courteous, funny and welcoming. 

ONE STAR: The freebies kept coming! We kept being given free appetizers and sides, our waiter specificially brought us each their super awesome deviled egg appetizer, to which he said, 'you cannot come here and not eat this. on the house." MORE PLEASE!

ONE STAR: The food. Of course. Holy shit, the food. I got the salmon, my husband the steak. Both were incredible. The appetizers of the brussels sprouts chips and the shrimp in the spicy drunk cocktail sauce were both great (the shrimp were grilled to perfection). But it was the deviled egg and the cheesy cauliflower that I'm still tasting in my mouth, three weeks after we went.

Marlowe, you had me at hello.
author: Brenda C.

description:
I would compare this joint to my favorite bar/burger in LA: Father's Office Burger.

Brussel Sprout Chips are pretty amazing, the first time I had them was better than the second because the first time we went earlier, there was less people so there was more time to prepare the chips.  They were hot and crispy.  Second time, the chips were a little cold so I blame it on it being busy.

Baked Oysters - new england clam chowder in a shell.  Definitely doesn't taste like New England Clam Chowder but still pretty darn tasty, not sure if it's worth $3 dollars though...you should try it and see for yourself.

The steak tartar was served with a quail egg and a crostini, pretty good in my book but again $12 is a little pricey.  It's almost the same price as the burger...

Marlowe burger is a lamb and beef burger topped with caramelized onions, cheddar, bacon, horseradish aioli & fries.  The first time I had the burger, it was quite juicy and the bread was nice and soft.  The second time I had the burger, it was less juicy and it was more charred so that charred taste over powered all the other flavors going on in the burger - again I blame the consistency on it being more crowded.  The fries however were definitely on target, nice and crisp on the outside and soft on the inside.  

The office burger down in LA wins my vote.  The onions are carmelized with a balsamic vinaigrette and adds a nice sweetness to the burger.  The burger is topped with blue cheese and arugula which adds a nice bite...and the Patty, the patty is always medium rare and super super juicy.  Marlowe's burger was juicy the first time but not the second time.  This restaurant would get a 5 in my book if it could keep up with their consistency even when they're busy.

I like the decor of this place; there is a slanted beam in the middle of the restaurant that runs through the table and I also like the service here.  The staff is really friendly and they do take reservations unlike Father's office where you have to hoover over people while they eat and chat and jump on their table once they leave.  

Parking may be a little tough, although the parking lot at Bank of America has opened up at night for $5 a spot.  My BF lives on Bryant so it's just a short walk for us which is a plus.


All in all, I'd recommend people to go to this place early for a good burger.  If you go at about 8:30 or 9:00pm, the consistency of the food may fall a notch.
author: Elaine C.

description: The food is good but it is impossible to get in if you do not make a reservation a day or two in advance. Since it is in my neighborhood I'd really like to be able to go there on more of a spur of the moment thing.  However, I love the feel of the new location so It's worth the crowds.
author: laura f.

description:
This quaint brasserie offers speedy and friendly service in an ambient setting. It often gets packed so if you can make a reservation, that's probably a good idea. Even if you make a reservation and it's busy, it'll still be packed in a sense that you're elbow-to-elbow with other patrons. This kind of stuff doesn't bother me.

Conveniently located, Marlowe is a hop and a skip away from Caltrain. I did not make a reservation, but remembered walking by this cozy-looking joint before and decided I would finally succumb to its dimly lit interior. 

It was another crowded evening filled with chatter. My walk-in status earned me a seat at the bar, or I could've opted for a table and test my hunger's patience. I chose the former, which ended up working out. My champagne glass was refilled quickly, which I'm sure would've taken more time had I been at a table. And I was able to enjoy some friendly conversation with the guy working the bar. The burger and fries I indulged in were worthy of savoring every bite, down to the last crumb. I look forward to returning to try some of the other tasty items I saw on the menu. Although it may be a challenge since I've kind of been on a burger binge lately. Guilty!
author: Jaime L.

description: Ok will start off by addressing the service issues brought up in previous posts. The first 15 or so minutes we were there it looked like we were in for a bad experience. Nothing could have been further from the truth. Service was great, and the food was amazing! One of the best meals I've had in a very long while. The marrow and duck pate are spectacular. Perfectly executed! I highly recommend this book place. I'm not a small person and the seating posed no issues as others have indicated. Do yourself a favor and eat at Marlowes.
author: Omar R.

description:
This place was not a let down, researched a good place to eat and looked forward to it and got what was expected. Yes its a bit on the higher end, but for the food and delicacies they serve its really not that pricey at all.

lol, at some of the reviewers, salty? yes this place is flavorful, i mean obviously do you not get the notion from the pictures and theme? but to say its overly salty or the dish is plain salt is straight disrespectful and untrue.

why dont you take your money to somewhere bland like olive garden or some other place that serves tasteless, cheap food. and some one said not enough beer food? guy, you insults this place and any other gourmet restaurant, some people, man some people.


The first thing we got was the Steak Tartare, it was amazing, this is the first time i tried an "American/French" type of tartare, i've tried korean and italian steak tartare and it was very flavor ful and i was itching for more. 

The baked oysters were more than delicious, with bread crumbs and baconbits wow it was just amazing.

the bone marrow was also delicious it came with some sort of chimichurri/caper sauce, and it did have a decent amount of marrow in there

the deviled eggs where amazing as well, probably one of the best appetizers next to the steak tartare



for the entrees i got a steak which i traded half of it for half of the porkchop. the steak was delicious, not  the best but it was good enough for the price and again this isnt a 60 dollar steak so i wasnt expecting the much, the reduction sauce was good as well.

but what was the best was the pork chop i dont know if they seasoned it with a little truffle, but it was amazing and the burnt flavor of the outside of the porkchop and the steak was memorizing


the service was great, although they accidentally gave me my friends steak (medium) and gave mine to him (medium rare), it wasnt a big deal nor did i make a fuss about it, because the service was great and friendly. not to mention i got a table for 4 without any reservations.


great place to eat,  but if you coming here look to spend atleast 50 dollars per person.
author: Timothy C.

description: Was excited to visit Marlowe's new location. The space is definitely bigger, so it will  be easier to get a reservation. The downside of this space is the noise level.It was painfully loud. Combined with the longer time it took for our order to come out of the kitchen and the experience was not great. The food quality is the same, thank god.
author: Barry G.

description:
Came with some foodie friends....... so we tried a bunch of different dishes. 

Honey glazed pork belly.  - omg so good. 

Smoky cauliflower gratin - non carb mashed potatoes? pretty good! 

Distefano burrata - think really soft mozzarella cheese! Yum. 

Twice baked crab souffle - YUM! 

Crispy Brussels sprout chips. - i didn't think i'd like this but it was super good! We were tempted to order a 2nd helping! 

Anson mills polenta - i'm normally not a polenta girl, but thsi polenta was creamy, flavorful and just plain good. i'm not a hater as long as they make it like this! 

Poulet vert. Green chicken. this was amazing!
author: Judy N.

description:
Amazing food and service! 

The boyfriend and I came here for dinner on a Saturday night and were treated to a fantastic dining experience. We scoped out the yelp reviews before ordering (as usual) and decided on the following:

- Kale chips: amazing crispy take on Kale. a great appetizer
- Deviled eggs: I think that deviled eggs are always such a treat, because I'm too lazy to make these myself. Lovely texture and so much flavor in two bites!
- Bone marrow: SO GOOD. Will definitely be ordering this every time I come. So savory and fatty and delicious. A must!
- Pork chop: Amazing! We only ordered one order but were pleasently surprised when our server brought us 2 plates. We were lucky enough to have a large pork chop which they split in half for us. 

Will definitely be coming again and again. 

NOTE: also brought a bottle of wine. they have a corkage fee.
author: Jessica D.

description: My boyfriend and I decided to go here for his 20th birthday because of their great reviews on their burgers and steaks. We had a reservation at 12:45, and it was really packed! Really small restaurant, yet a nice atmosphere. My boyfriend ordered the burger, and I ordered the crispy chicken sandwich; turns out this was both our favorite! They serve your entree with either fries or a salad, and we decided to both go with the fries, which were nicely salted and had horseradish aioli, which complimented the saltiness of the fries. Overall, our meal was very satisfying and filled us up pretty good!
author: Nicole S.

description:
Atmosphere reminded me of french bistro meets New York City diner. Cool spot. Food was good, but not great. Worth a visit for cocktails later in the evening.

Got the Brussels sprout chips (excellent), burrata salad (good), burger (ok), and pretzel dessert (good).
author: Anne K.

description:
It's ironic that Michael Bauer wrote up the burger at Marlowe today... 
I was there for dinner last night..and normally I wouldn't pass up the chance at trying a big, juicy burger. However..not last night.. 

As we sat down to enjoy our pre dinner wine..I couldn't help but notice (stare) at the chicken dish on the table next us...It was a half chicken plated in three pieces..and it looked deliciously seasoned and the meat looked tender and juicy. I was sold. 
No regrets on the chicken..it was as good as it looked..plated on a generous portion of greens and fingerling potatos.
My dining mate had the fish..which he quite enjoyed..we also split the brussel sprout chips..and the cauliflower au gratin..
Everything was rich and tastey..
Service is excellent here...I am so glad to have Marlowe in the neighborhood!
author: Mimi T.

description: Great food. Love the brussel sprout chips, baked cauliflower and cheese. The burger was perfection. Baked oysters and deviled eggs were outstanding. Very nice bar and cocktail list as well.
author: Brea S.

description:
Some girl friends and I dined at Marlowe recently. After hearing great things about this place, we had high expectations.. and I think my dining experience at Marlowe definitely met my expectations. 

We ordered and shared crispy brussel sprout chips, which was lightly seasoned with sea salt and lemon. Who knew that Marlowe could make me eat brussel sprouts? (well, the only other way to eat brussel sprouts is if it's cooked with bacon, in my opinion) And who knew you could turn a somewhat bitter vegetable into chips? What a brilliant idea! So, I highly recommend this app. We liked it so much that we ordered another one after finishing the first one within like 10 minutes max. 

For my entree, I ordered the grilled niman pork chop, which was cooked perfectly.. juicy, not dry! It came with a side of garlic-creamed spinach and beans. The portion was huge and more than enough for me, but as a dedicated foodie, I ate it all. 

For dessert, my friends and I shared the vanilla bean panna cotta affogato. I have to say this was probably the highlight of the meal and a great way to end it. The combination of vanilla, strong coffee syrup, and lemon biscotti was foodgasmic. I loved it and wanted to have more even though I was stuffed. It's a must-try for dessert. 

Overall, I'd recommend this place for a "I want to impress the girl- first date" location or a girl's night out with the besties.
author: Cassy H.

description: Lovely ambiance; excellent and attentive service--the standouts are the spicy jumbo shrimp and smoky kale and Brussels sprouts salad
author: Mopis T.

description:
Decent. But nothing special.
The burger was really good, but I'm avoiding beef and carbs so not something I would go here for.
Thought the scallops would be low carb, but they are drowning in a thick sauce that appears starchy.
The brussel sprout chips were good. Stir-fried, not deep fried.
Ambience is dark, cozy. Industrial feel as opposed to sterile refinement. 
Parking was easy even on a game day.
author: David C.

description:
I went here on a Friday and came back the following week. I thought it was that good.  It turns out the second time wasn't as good as the first (Hendrick's martini did the trick).

Both times I had the shrimp and beef tartare.  The shrimp was pretty good both times.  They seemed liked they were bbq'd on a grill.  Shrimp on the barbie anyone?  The beef tartare was ok.  Great the first time, but again it might have been the Hendrick's talking.  My husband had the pork chop, which he thought was too salty and the burger the second time.  Both dishes he thought were ok.

What I really enjoyed here was the service.  Really nice people and fun to talk to.  They even remembered us the following week when we returned.

Overall I recommend checking this place out.  Parking wasn't an issue for us since we had late reservations.
author: Mrs. N.

description:
SOMA isn't a place where I'd expect to see a great restaurant like Marlowe, but I stand corrected. Marlowe is a great restaurant, and it's in SOMA, conveniently located by the Caltrain Station on King Street.

And all of the popular dishes do indeed live up to the hype. The best deviled eggs I've ever had. The brussel sprout chips are salty and addictive and wonderful. The burger is fantastic.

But also try the:
Bone marrow -- ZOMFG. So rich and savory and yummy. We felt guilty eating it.
Anson mills polenta -- The most perfect runny poached egg sits on top of this creamy, delicious polenta.
Grilled Niman pork chop -- Gives the NOPA pork chop a run for its money.

And by the way, the service is always, always great.
author: Connie W.

description: Went here for my birthday and really enjoyed the atmosphere. It was lit very low, but I am into that. The burger was delicious.
author: Logan T.

description: While I've been to Marlowe a handful of times & loved it every time, this review is for their brunch. Service was great but their food & cocktails were very just so so and underwhelming. Going to stick to their dinner rather than going back for their brunch.
author: Kalani K.

description:
The place is pretty small so make sure you make a reservation. The hamburger was yummy so as the chicken sandwhich. I also love their fried brussel sprouts and the french fries are just delicious.

I love this place  for both lunch and dinner again make sure you make a reservations, very casual and hip. A great place for small group of 4 or 6 the most.
author: Joiera C.

description:
Good place to socialize after work or to go on a date with as long as you don't sit at the communal table with loud Brits hitting on the waitress. 
The customer service was good, not great. I was bummed when I didn't get the bread that I made a point to ask for. ::shrug::

Foodwise:
Jumbo prawns - underdone and soggy. Good spice with the cocktail sauce at first, but then the flavor downgraded to a cheap bloody mary, the bottomless kind you regrettably get at a Sunday brunch. 
Burger - good not great. Meat tasted unseasoned. Got the aoli on the side, but it's something that the burger needed to give it at least some flavor. Fries were good.
Brussel Sprout Chips - as good as everyone said it would be, for the first 1/4 of the bowl. If you don't eat it fast enough, the leaves wilt and absorb all that butter they sit in. If you don't have a carbonated beverage to offset all those fat molecules you're consuming, it could get nauseating.
The wine list was fairly diverse, but I ended up with a Porter. 
The ginger beer from Australia was delicious. 

Dark, intimate, but loud ambiance. Interesting place, but I am not likely to return unless I've got an out of towner to impress... or ignore.
author: Rosavida C.

description:
I notice myself returning not as frequently as Christine C, but enough to notice what an amazing menu Marlowe has to offer!

This time we got the artichoke soup which was mediocre
But the polenta was fantastic! The poached egg was an ingenious idea, it made the polenta a lot fluffier and less heavy! It was a savory yet heavenly dish :) 

Love this place
author: linda L.

description:
Took my best friend here to celebrate her "Best Decision Ever" anniversary and boy were we impressed! The restaurant itself is a little small and stuffy, but the staff is very friendly and the food is amazing. We ordered the Brussels sprouts chips as an appetizer which were very well seasoned and addicting. Next up was the Warm Deviled Egg which was to die for! I could eat 10 of these. And the Baked Oyster which was also delish. Our main course was split between a Marlowe Burger (caramelized onions, cheddar, bacon, horseradish aioli & fries) and Anson Mills Polenta. I'm serious when I say that this is the best meal I've ever had in SF. Everything was cooked to perfection and the flavors were amazing. One of those experiences where you don't want it to stop.

The beer is good, the atmosphere is casual, and the food is amazing. I definitely need to come back here as often as possible.

Highly recommended for a casual dinner or celebrating an occasion.
author: Jorge H.

description:
Arrived at Marlowe with no reservation, while it was crowded the staff was able to snag my boyfriend and myself two seats at the bar within 30 minutes. 

Ordered way too much and sadly didn't finish the tasty Cauliflower Au Gratin. Ordered the Steak and Frites for an entree and while this dish was good and the meat was tender and the fries very satisfactory, the overall taste left in my mouth was just salt. No explosion of flavor.. just salt. 
Desert was some sort of crumble in a mason jar. Very cute, pretty good. :)
author: Brie S.

description: Come for brunch! I get so bored with brunch in the city. When I want to go out on the weekend I want something stunning and delicious and Marlowe is just that. The wait staff is amazing, the menu is interesting and simple, and the food is exciting. Going again tomorrow with a group of friends. Seriously, if you cannot appreciate all the work and love and craftsmanship that goes into a place like this, then you really don't belong in SF. Oh, and try the mini eclairs!
author: Shana A.

description:
I was all queued up to love Marlowe but unfortunately, the food fell a bit short for me. Service was pleasant, the Aussie hostess is a darling. The bar area is a bit crowded, they could stand to lose a couple of barstools, but the dining room is quite posh.

The brussel sprout chips were fine, I still hold all fried brussel dishes up to Le Colonial's gold standard and these didn't quite get there. They had a lemony tang which was a nice surprise. Unfortunately we had to send back a tuna appetizer because it smelled exceedingly fishy... we conferred about it for a few minutes because really, I hate sending anything back and rarely ever do. The mains were lackluster as well - the chicken dish was super salty and my companion's polenta was "gooey."

Marlowe certainly isn't dead to me by any means and I'm more than happy to give it another shot, but this first impression was a bit rough.
author: Lisa P.

description:
I'm just gonna say it right off the bat. I am a total sucker for comp'ed stuff. Comp me a few appetizers and treat me with respect and a smile? Yeah, you got a repeat customer in me, baby.

I came here as a last minute decision with Matthew D. and another buddy because we wanted to go drinking in the city but wanted something tasty to soak up the alcohol too. This is where my fellow Yelpers did not let me down. I love you guys!

We had to wait about 15 minutes but the hostess took our drinks orders so we could at least have a beer while waiting. Got seated at the bar even though there were plenty of other tables open, but it should be known that bar seating is THE BEST. You have more interaction with the bartender and servers and if you're not looking for a romantic candle-lit dinner, makes for some great ambiance.

All in all, the food was great. Bone marrow was a half order because they ran out - we came at 9:30PM on a Saturday - and was given to us for free. Deviled eggs were out of this freaking world. I think it was half an egg for a buck? Yeah, normally that's expensive but these eggs were so delicious that we ordered another round. The hostess even told us that they have a regular that shows up and ONLY orders a half dozen deviled eggs.

For an entree I had the Pork Chop. Now, most people are scared, and rightfully so, of eating medium rare pork. But when you have a chop from a good quality pig, you have to have it just a tad pink. So good. Flavorful and tender over a bed of sweet potato mash and greens.

Yeah, it's not cheap or anything, but it's a hell of a dining choice in the SOMA area with all the other not-so-cheap places around. Highly recommended.
author: Aaron C.

description:
2nd visit
Good neighborhood restaurant
Vibrant bar scene
Cocktails = nothing special
Food = average +
 - brussell sprouts; tasty but greasy (deep fried not roasted)
- pear burrata; wilted and bland
- burger; really tasty, perfectly cooked
- polenta; best plate of the evening
- black cod - cooked perfectly but nothing memorable
- chocolate coconut cake; dry cake, super sugary frosting

Service was very good on both visits.

Price = ++ for quality
author: Amy B.

description:
Came here for my birthday lunch last week and loved it! Will definitely be coming back here as my office is right around the corner.

The place is teenie and seats approximately 20 people more or less I would say. Luckily, we came before the rush and waited less than 10 minutes for a table. Some of the tables are actually community bench types...so be prepared to be having lunch with strangers. (which nothing can be absurd here in the city)

For starters we had the steak tartare and baked oysters. Both were great. The tartare had a poached quail egg and came with crostinis. The baked oysters were cheesy goodness with bacon bits! Yum. The apricot iced tea was also nice and refreshing.

I had the marlowe burger with fries which came out and seemed a bit small in portion, but halfway through I was glad to find that I was actually pretty full. Although I asked for my burger well- done, the patty was still very juicy and flavorful. The fries were crispy and salted perfectly!

Service here is also pretty good. The waiters/waitresses are especially good with refilling waters.
author: Stine H.

description:
there is a lot of hype about the hamburger and the egg salad sandwich. HOWEVER, the cauliflower gratin was A-M-A-Z-I-N-G.  Really if it weren't so politically incorrect (or epi-error), I would order it times two and call it lunch. cheesy, creamy goodness that is far better than most mac & cheeses I've had.  I read that Bauer says this is the best burger in the city, well I still think that Lark Creek Steak's cowboy burger is far and away the best burger in SF.  For me the Fries were the star, the burger was fine, good really, but the fries that looked under-cooked were really the star of the plate.  

Our server was great (Jesse), BUT the place was hellish-ly hot inside at 2pm, on a fine sf day. Jesse said there is talk of getting windows that open, but if you are going on a day when the sun is shining, wear the least amount of clothing you can get away with.
author: Amy W.

description:
Must try's (in my order of preference):
Baked oysters
Crispy Brussels Sprout chips
Baked Bone Marrow
Steak Frite
Jumbo Prawns
Malbec red 
Upside down strawberry bourbon crisp ice cream

...below this is every other place nearby! Great atmosphere, excellent friendly and attentive service!
author: Mark C.

description:
I really want to love Marlowe. It's in the same building I work in, the staff are friendly and very nice and it just seems like a cool little place. But, I'm not quite loving it all that much. Here's why:

1) very pricey - seems a bit too high priced for location, though food quality is very good. There are no views.

2) very loud - too many hard surfaces makes this small space so loud that you will need to shout to be heard. I have to cup my ears to hear - not good for work lunches.

3) No beers on tap.

Here's what I like:

Marlowe Burger $14 - very tasty. Horse radish aioli really sets it off.

Crispy Brussels SPROUT Chips $7 - crispy, but melt in your mouth. Sometimes a bit salty, but very good - eat em up - YUM!

So I like Marlowe. I'll be back. Need to try the bone marrow app next...
author: Sean H.

description:
Marlowe is definitely one of my neighborhood favorites.  It's kind of hidden and unassuming; a total gem in the area!  They change their menu slightly every so often.

A few of my favorite dishes include:

- brussels sprouts chips - easily one of the best versions of this dish in the city.  I'm so glad to see this item on 7x7's 2014 list
- mussels - really flavorful broth
- roasted bone marrow - delicious, rich, and flavorful
- spiced jumbo gulf shrimp - this dish is amazing.  The shrimp are juicy and the "hot & boozy cocktail sauce" has a great kick
- smokey baked cauliflower - this is pretty rich and creamy side as it has aged provolone and smoked cheddar; it's amazing

It's pretty hard to get a table without a reservation, but you might get lucky with a seat at the bar area.
author: Nadia S.

description:
I came here for a birthday dinner with a group of 10. The place is pretty small so I suggest making reservations ahead of time. Everyone in our group ordered the burger and it was good. The meat was juicy and flavored well. The only flaw from my meal was that the inside of my bun was burnt so I it felt like I was licking a BBQ grill. At that point I was super hungry and just kept eating. They also add shredded lettuce rather than the usual peel from the lettuce bunch which I felt made it less messy and easier to consume. The fries were also good and crispy. Prior to our meal we ordered the crispy Brussels chips as appetizers. They're good IF you already like brussel sprouts. For dessert I had the chocolate cookie pie. It was a cute little dessert inside of a jar with crumbles on the bottom and chocolate mousses top. It's super sweet tho but I liked it. The strawberry crisp dessert wasn't available unfortunately which was kind of a bummer since I was looking forward to having it. Don't know how that happened since we arrived an hour after opening on a Sunday. Also, bone marrow isn't available to large groups. Our server was nice and checked up on us frequently however, they forgot to put a candle on the dessert for my cousins birthday and we really wanted him to be surprised so it was kinda lame having to send the dessert back and get it back with the candle. It wasn't our servers fault tho, it was someone in the back.  I would definitely come back for that strawberry crisp dessert! 


Parkin meters end at 6.
author: Brigitte M.

description:
This place is great for a nice, casual dinner. I loved the decor, although the place is a bit small. It's hard to tell there is a restaurant inside given the street it's on, but it's a pretty popular place among yelpers!

I got the baked oysters and burger - which were both fantastic! Everything looked good on the menu and the oysters were so delicious with creamy, baked goodness on top. The burger was also delicious with the fries and horseradish aoli :3 As I looked around, everyone was ordering the burger - but I wouldn't be afraid to order something else off the menu if I could eat more. 

I would definitely recommend coming here!
author: Samantha O.

description:
Marlowe is a good place to meet up with friends and/or family for comfort food, refreshing cocktails and warm service from friendly staff.

We had a 7:30 pm reservation on a Saturday night.  The place was packed from when we arrived to when we left at 10 pm.  Most of the parties there seemed to be celebrating something, including my party.  

We started with the brussel sprout chips and deviled ham w/ baguette slices and cornichons, a special that night.  The brussel sprout chips were crispy and well seasoned, but a bit on the oily side.  Definitely something where a person cannot just eat one.  The deviled ham was tasty and fresh and did not in any way resemble the stuff from a can!  

I ordered the burger with cheddar, bacon and onions.  It came with a side of french fries and horseradish aioli.  The burger was good, quite good.  Juicy and flavorful without a hint of greasiness or heaviness.  The fries were amazing.  They were really, really good - crisp, well seasoned, airy on the inside.  The aioli was a nice condiment, but for my taste I wished it had more horseradish in it as I found it rather bland and did not do much to complement the burger or fries.

I had noticed that a lot of people were ordering the poulet vert, which was my second choice for an entree.  One friend seemed to really enjoy his stuffed blue sole dish.  Entree portions are generous, but not ginormous.  Cocktails certainly play a role in the dining experience.  I had ordered a prosecco with raspberry and lemon juices, a drink special that night.

For dessert we split the chocolate cream pie and updside down pear crisp.  Both came in a jar (they really like their jars here!)  Both were okay, but neither were outstanding or memorable.

The staff, while friendly, seemed a bit short staffed.  While she was at our table our waitress was informed, helpful and attentive.  However, there were long lulls from when we were seated to when our food arrived where I could see that the waitstaff was really busy.

Would I recommend this place?  I already have.
author: Melissa L.

description: Sacre Bleu! it was amazinglyfabuloushously delicious. Lunch.Burger. Cooked to perfection! Chocolate posted creme, they call it differently, it made your palate scream for more! I WILL comeback. Even if I a driving from Petaluma!
author: Valerie F.

description: This was my first visit to Marlow. Very casual setting, almost a diner feel. The shared appetizers were tasty - from the deviled eggs (with jalapeño) to the bone marrow, it was vey delicious.  We all had the much talked about Marlow Burger and it didn't disappoint! My biggest gripe was the bill! $248 for 4 burgers, tapas sized appetizers, 1 beer, and 1 cocktail is way too high a price to pay for the experience. In. Nutshell: quality and service excellent! Quantity and ambiance for the money below average.
author: Matthew K.

description:
Meat warehouse. That was my original thought upon pulling up to this somewhat dubious looking exterior, but that is just the way of the world now - it's cool to be under the radar and somewhat 'edgy' Especially in one of the coolest cities of the world where you really have to up your 'cool game.' Another misconception that the exterior can provide is size. The dining area is surprisingly smaller than what it would seem. It's in a huge, industrial structure for darn sake. However, the size definitely doesn't discourage one from noticing the somewhat sever, yet elegant design of the restaurant. Large steel beams are serving as actual support, but provide an interesting aesthetic appeal while also dividing the open room. 

After all 9 of squeezed into the end of a long, family style table - we couldn't help but notice just how close we were to our stranger neighbors. Not a bother to me, but I can see how the close proximity while your eating could be a buzz kill. Nevertheless, we were instantly greeted and offered wine, to which we all happily obliged. We sipped on some delicious vino while we complimented the clever idea to showcase the specials on a large piece of butcher paper nailed to the wall and took in the delicately constructed entrees consisting of strong and poignant ingredients: mushroom soup with truffle oil, seared ahi tuna over a bed of Israli Cous Cous, haricot vert (whatever that is), and candied olives. From the fun chatter at the table, the burger seemed to be hit. As well as the brussels sprout chips. I, of course, went straight for the tuna and couldn't be more happy with my choice. Unlike other ahi tuna plates, this had an shockingly wonderful spice to it. The flavors were distinct and the tuna was perfectly prepared.
author: Frances H.

description:
Went here for a Thursday night dinner with 2 friends. We made reservations on OpenTable and were seating immediately.

The ambience is nice, kind of rustic, Western, American. It's a big open room yet the tables are proportioned properly so conversation was intimate.

We were craving brussel sprouts so we started with the bussel sprout crisps (appetizer) and whole bussel sprouts (side dish). The crisps were better. Sweet Meyer Lemon coupled with delicious savory, salty, oily goodness. Like potatoes, brussel sprouts are perfect vessels for oily goodness. 

For my main I got the burger medium. It was tasty, but by the end it was a little overwhelming with so much flavor -- bacon, white sauce, and grilled onions. It would have benefited from more lettuce/tomato/avocado to balance out the heaviness.

My friend ordered the pork chops. We agreed the pork was good but a bit too fatty for our taste.

The best main was probably the poulet vert, which my other friend ordered. Crispy-on-the-outside-tender-on-the-inside roasted chicken. Mmm.

I would go back.
author: Max H.

description: Best drinks but unfriendly bartender. I came to sf for my birthday and I found the best drink I ever had but the bartender was really rude and not friendly. I was really disappointed.
author: Tammy V.

description:
We had a great meal.  The pork chop was really tasty and the burger was great.  The cocktails were also awesome.  

We sat at the bar, and our bartender (the young lady) was really knowledgable about all the menu item details and made some great recommendations.  

Later some friends joined us and the restaurant was very accommodating.  Would highly recommend and visit when we're up I this area again.
author: Ege Y.

description: The poached eggs are perfect. Served in Kale Caesar salad and with polenta (which is outstanding). Good service. For people who don't want meat, they can make anything on the menu without meat (except the hamburger!). Dessert yum! I would come again
author: Phyllis K.

description: My favorite restaurant in the neighorhood, and it's not even close.  The food is consistently excellent, as is the service.  This place never gets old, and the new location is a significant upgrade.  The burger is especially fantastic.
author: Bret L.

description: Pretty good food.  Expensive, can of beer was $6, cheapest option. I would go back and try other dishes but the chicken sandwich was just ok.  Nothing to rave about.  With so many other options in SoMa, this place wouldn't be in my top 10.
author: Mike M.

description:
We came here for a casual biz lunch. 
The Brussel sprout chips were good, bourbon almonds were addictive, but my fried chicken sandwich was just ok. 
The desserts were strange. All our desserts were pretty much just cream/ pudding-like. 
Also, the food overall was quite salty. I found myself guzzling water all afternoon
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
We came here for lunch the other day (party of 4).
We made reservations in advance, so we were a little surprised when we were led to the communal table, when there were plenty of empty tables.  After we made that request, they moved us to a quad table.

Service was polite and fairly prompt.
We all ordered burgers, two medium, two well done.
After about 15 mins or so, our burgers arrived.  The medium people were happy, but the well done were not (pink is not well done) so we sent them back.  While we were waiting, they comped us some brussel sprout chips (tasty, but nothing I would have ordered).
Burgers returned, well done, and before we left, we discussed our opinions of the burgers.
Quality?  Yes.  Worth $12?  No.  Anything I couldn't have made at home?  Not really.

Perhaps we hit it on an off day, but I don't plan on returning.
author: dan s.

description:
Marlowe exceeds every joy you've ever experienced, whilst reducing you to tears, blowing your mind, making your heart swell in sheer rapture, and inspiring you to bow down at the feet of the staff and cow of your burger.

The food is difficult to review since it defies the boundaries of human perception. 

It's rumored the Mastodon burger human incarnate would be Alexander Skarsgard with the mind of Stephen Hawking.

However, studies have shown those who attempted to comprehend the awesome have: disappeared, spontaneously combusted, and/or driven themselves into a state of insanity.

Burger sex.
author: Jeri T.

description: Amazing Bone Marrow appetizer. Definitely make a reservation.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Airlifted in here with a number of colleagues recently, and pleased with the result: Marlowe is, like so many other restaurants of repute in the Bay Area, a cozy space meant to be shared with groups, which means that benches line up to encourage snug gatherings and spirited chatter. At least, such was the case on our recent drop-in, where the wine was flowing (and a bit of the brew too), and appetizers making rounds (the kale and the brussels sprouts were outstanding), and entrees meant rich explorations of the palate. 

I ultimately decided on the steak frites. The steak, served medium rare, arrived as a hearty cut and by the time we left I'd had plenty to balance out the duration of my evening. Our server was upbeat and at the ready (though never hovering) and genuinely helpful. My one concern was that with the density of the crowd there, the noise was enough that we occasionally had a bit of a hard time hearing her, but in the end, that's really a minor beef. And as long as we're talking beef, mine plate-full was a highlight.
author: Kevin N.

description: This is the new place to go in SF. Up and coming area. The the food and decor are what you would expect when looking for a cool new high end dining experience in SF. We walked in with no reservation and they accommodated us.
author: Labella G.

description:
This is just my initial thoughts on this place, I need to go back to give a full report. 

For the new kid in town, I think the small space works, the large communal table between the bar and the main dinning area helps make the place feel larger than it is. 

The wine list can use some sprucing up, the beer list id decent. 

As for the food, we tasted around: 

1. the baked oysters (best item on the menu), 
2. radishes and the soft cheese (ok), 
3. spicy shrimp (the shrimp were over cooked and the cocktail sauce not very impressive), 
4. chicken (very salty) 
5. Black cod (generally well prepared) 

The service was great. I'll be back a few more times before I cement my opinion, but I think they have what it takes to be good, its all about bringing it together.
author: G R.

description: Shrimp role is absolutely AMAZING! Super unique flavor. Had one today and can't wait until I'm back in the area and can have another! The quality of the food is wonderful and everything, even the salad dressing,  is unique in some way.
author: Gina A.

description:
We were looking for another restaurant when we ran into this one. Booked out for this day, the owner was able to squeeze us in their communal tables.
Place was packed and after tasting my first dish I understood why: food is divine. Desert is a must natural follow up
Highly recommend
author: Luis C.

description:
Came here a couple weeks back with my friend, Tiff. We both def enjoyed our meal!

Our rsvp was at 6 and I got there by 550 and the place was already pretty filled up, and it was on a Monday! Good sign that the food is good! The restaurant itself was super small. The tables were way too closely put together. I couldn't even get up without my behind feeling like it's pushing other patrons wine glasses over. 

Ordered a glass of Pinot Gris while I looked over their menu and waited for my friend to arrive. The menu wasn't too big but I knew what I wanted to order before I even sat down, thanks Yelpers!

Appetizer
Baked Oysters ($3each) : What is not to like? Perfectly cooked oysters with bacon! Like other Yelpers have mentioned, do not just order one, order at least two! You'll thank us later.
Roasted Bone Marrow ($11) : First time trying it and I thought it was just so-so. It was a bit salty for our taste. Also felt like I was eating a piece of fat cuz it's way too buttery for my taste.

Entree
Stuffed Sole ($23): AMAZING! Must try this. Sole was stuffed with crab, baby turnips, radish, lemon cucumber, pea tendrils and lemon verbena. It was a very light and refreshing dish. The fish was fresh and the ingredients stuffed in the sole was so good and went very well all together! I would def recommend this dish to anyone.

Service was friendly and attentive. Parking was super easy and plenty of them when I arrived. I would definitely come back and try out other menu items!
author: Juliane N.

description:
I am in love with this place! This used to be South, sad that it left, but happy Marlowe stepped in. 

Menu: 
Crispy Brussel Sprout chips
Baked Fanny May oysters
Prawns with spicy sauce

The MARLOWE burger

Chocolate ganache pudding 

Ask for bread if you are hungry, the two of us came right after the Sataurday game, so it was great, make reservations if you can, it's better than not having one. 

It does get a little busy and crowded, but that's the fun of dinning! We had a great time chatting with all the other dinners around us and sharing the laughs and even food with the table.
author: Judi K.

description: Creative, dark and cozy! The burgers are lovely and for the right price. This place knows how to make burgers and put's discipline in it. Sides are really good and complement the experience of eating in Marlowe. At night the place is a little dark which makes is commonly cozy. If you order a coke you get the Cane Cola. The stuff goes reel good with the burger.
author: Tyas L.

description:
- We ordered New York Steak and Black Cod for main, crab/shrimp crepe for starters.
- Good things first: waitresses are very nice and accommodating. The restaurant has the right vibe and decoration. The waitress offered peanuts to us since we waited a long time after starters.
- Food: over priced but tastes mediocre; we had to wait a long time (45min I think) after starters. It costs a total of $100, but we left underwhelmed. 
- The steak, ordered medium rare, but came out very rare (I didn't complain because I just wanted to finish and get out); the quality of the steak itself is blah. I had better steak at Outback Steakhouse. To be fair, the veggie and grilled garlic coming with the steak were great. 
- The cod was blah. My date said it was plain. The fish still tastes a bit funky to me (the normal fishy taste). In other words, the cook did a decent job of get rid off 80% of the funky taste, but I expect more than that. I love fish and might have high expectation for fish; I thought I could do better myself. On the bright side, I thought the grilled veggie was creative (I forgot the name of the veggie).

The next night my date and I had 2 Vietnamese sandwiches ($4/each) with grilled banana for dessert ($3), and we both a agreed that they beat Marlowe $100-plus-1hr-waiting meals hands down. We both agreed that would be the 1st and last time at Marlowe. Sorry.
author: K T.

description:
Started with the Tuna app with was terrific and the Crispy Brussels Sprout Chips that were indifferent. I wonder if you had the chips later in a meal if people would like them as much. Sure there good when you just walk into the place and are hungry, but after you've eaten a little and come back to the chips they're kinda blah. 

The little lady got the scallops with a side of the cauliflower which she enjoyed and I got the burger which was really salty for some reason. I'm not sure if it was the bacon or something else. I cut the burger in half and took the bacon off the second half and it was still salty. 

We shared the Strawberry Crisp with the bourbon ice cream. The ice cream was good enough to be served by itself.

The service was great and we enjoyed ourselves. Since the little lady is a pescetarian, her options are limited so I'm not sure we'd return.
author: Neil C.

description:
A girlfriend and I had dinner here one night while our men were over at AT&T park (just a short walk away).  Space is super cozy, there's a communal table in the middle but we got a nice solo table on the edge of the restaurant.  

Right off, started with a glass of wine (pretty good list,  nice mix of domestics and international wines), and we shared a ton of food.  They were out of eggs (we were there for a late dinner) so we didn't get to try them.  But we did have the crispy brussel sprouts, the pork belly and mushroom soup.  Everything was really good.  Crispy brussel sprouts were more like flaked chips (not whole or halves) - but lemon zesty with a perfect amount of salt and savory - an indulgence but worth it.  Pork belly was good (I've had better, but at the same time, I would order this again) and mushroom soup was warm, hearty and creamy.  

For dinner, I got the polenta - has a lot of truffle flavor (even though not described as such on the menu).  It was creamy and rich, but mine had a few smallish lumps in there (not a huge deal to me), mushrooms were a nice change of texture from the polenta itself.  Ad there was also some arugula served with this - nice spicy change of flavor and texture.  For me, having this dish once will be enough - it was satisfying and good, but super filling - I'm usually a really big eater but couldn't finish my plate.  And I always feel like certain dishes (risotto, polenta) tend to have the same flavor through the whole plate so I get tired of eating it eventually. 

But of course, even though I was stuffed, we needed to order dessert!  We ordered the chocolate cream pie - served in a cute little mason jar, it was a nice spin on real chocolate creme pie - topped with cocoa nibs which added a nice bitterness and crunch, and sea salt!  Wow!  That absolutely made it for me - just the right amount of salt where the dessert wasn't overkill on the sweet factor.  A perfect ending to the meal.  

Marlowe is a little out of the way, and an itty bitty space.  If i was in the mood for a nice splurge, I would return here.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
The food was 5 stars.  Great meal.  The stuffed sole, the fries and the cauliflower gratin were great.  This was one of the best meals I've had in SF since I moved here about 7 months ago.

If I'm raving about the food, why only 2 stars you ask?  The service.  Plain and simple.

So I had a 7:30 reservation on a Tuesday night.  I got there a bit early and wanted to see if I could move up the reservation.  The hostess explained to me that they were quite busy and probably wouldn't be able to seat me any earlier than the reservation time.  She invited me to wait at the bar and have a drink while I waited.  I understood that I was early and had no problem sitting at the bar.

Half way though my beer, I see one of the staff members walk over, look at me and then walk away.  Not sure what that was about, I went along with my business and sipped my beer.  A few minutes later, the hostess came back and asked me if I wouldn't mind giving up my seat at the bar and waiting "over there."  I thought this was a bit weird, since I was invited to sit at the bar and I had a drink, but whatever.  I'll go with the flow.  

"Over there" turned out to be the small area around the hostess stand where there were already 2 women standing.  I asked the hostess, "did you mean here?"  She said "There's a bench outside..."  and out I went.  Now, I've spent my entire life on the east coast and in the midwest and know what cold is, and SF in December is not what I call cold.  But it's not what I call warm or inviting, either.  My choices were either stand there in the way or sit out in the "cold."  

As I sat outside, I started to think about the events.  I understand that they were busy and probably overbooked.  I also understand that they were doing their best to accommodate their guests.  But, how do you invite someone to sit at the bar, which as far as I could tell was a first come first serve bar, and then ask them to sit outside so you can seat other guests.  

The same hostess also asked a party of four to leave the bar area and join me in the evening air so she could seat other guests for dinner.

I eventually go back in around the time of my reservation.  And wait.  And wait.  The hostess was apologetic and explained that people were lingering.  We waited for about 30 minutes past our reservation time.  

During this time, the hostess received a phone call and booked a reservation for 8:45.  The hostess seemed like a nice woman and she seemed to be aware of her surroundings, so I'm not sure what possessed her to book the 8:45 reservations.  When you have a few people with 7:30 reservations who have been waiting for more than 20 minutes and haven't been seated yet and more reservations walking in the door with no one leaving, does it make sense to make a reservation at 8:45?  

Maybe the computer told her there was a reservation available at this time, but her eyes, ears and common sense probably should have said otherwise.  To be fair, I've never worked as a hostess and I imagine there is some skill or sense that comes with it after awhile, so maybe she had some special knowledge that I did not have, but it didn't seem like a reasonable thing to do.  This is supported by the fact another hostess came over to the couple seated next to me around 9 or 9:10 and asked them to take their conversation to the bar so they could seat another couple.  

To the hostess's credit, she seemed sincerely apologetic about my wait and brought us a complimentary order of the brussel sprout chips after our reservation came and went.  However, inviting your guests to wait at the bar and then inviting them to wait outside so you can seat other guests really is the opposite of hospitality.  It's a shame, because the food was great
author: Larry L.

description:
i went to their sister restaurant, park tavern, first and loved it so i was slightly disappointed here

ordered:
-crispy brussel sprout chips: w lemon and sea salt.. although good i stopped eating it halfway through bc the salt was getting to me

-marlowe burger: w carmelized onions, cheddar, bacon.. perfectly cooked medium-rare and crispy bacon, the burger was probably the best i've had in a while.. i liked that it made a sound when i tapped my knife on the bun before i sliced it in half.. 

-marlowe fries: served with the burger and horseradish aioli.. not a fan of horseradish so i barely used the aioli and i was only able to eat half of the fries bc it got too salty for me
author: Raquel T.

description: A bit crowded (I'm not so fan of community tables, especially not at Marlowe, where the space seems even smaller than elsewhere. And you can barely hear what your dinner companion says across the table) BUT hands down one the best dishes I ate in my entire life is their Wild Mushroom, Truffle, Poached eggs, Polenta dish! Will go back for this many times, for sure.
author: M.S.E V.

description: First time eating at Marlowe!  We had a 10:00 reservation, we were seated promptly and we (party of two) ordered burgers.  Unfortunately, we waited more than thirty minutes for our food.  When the burgers were finally served we noticed the buns were cold, dry and really too big for the meat.  I think the meat used for the burgers was good quality and the toppings (bacon, cheese and grilled onions) were delicious and the fries were good but waiting 30 minutes for them was too long.
author: John V.

description: Looooved this place. I just wish it was easier to get a reservation! The deviled eggs are so so so good. Also really enjoyed the cocktails and service.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Wow... oh WOW.   I will come here again and again.  Wonderful meal and the service was on point!  Marlowe really know their flavor and service.

BRUSSEL SPROUT CHIPS: 
First thing that came out and I knew from these chips that i'll have a wonderful time here at Marlowe.  You'll love these chips even if you don't like brussel sprouts.  So crispy!

WARM DEVILED EGGS
I don't know what to say, they know how to make deviled eggs without being uber fancy.  Good starter

BAKED OYSTERS
I love baked oysters and it's always a winner for me, but Marlowe serves the best baked oysters yet

BONEMARROW
I don't care what you get here, you MUST MUST MUST MUST get the bone marrow.  MUST.  I'm telling you Marlowe know their flavors.  I'm not a fan of Bone Marrow.  i don't dislike it nor do I crave for it in general, but Marlowe made it just perfect.  I'll come back solely for this Bone Marrow dish.  DIsh includes a big bone marrow in half (my boyfriend says it's normally smaller than what I had), you put them on crostini and top them with tapenade.  The flavors together go so well.  Just thinking of it right now makes me want to go back this minute.

FRENCH FRIES W/ HORSERADISH AIOLI
This one gets addicting.  If you're trying to watch your carbs intake, don't dare to take one bite because you won't be able to stop.  The fries are done extremely well, it's so crispy and the horseradish sauce gives it the right kick that you can't help grabbing another one.  

MUSSEL, SQUIDS
I don't remember what this dish was called but it was a tonight's special menu. Another hit at the table.  Served with crostini, aioli sauce, but the mussels and squids and sprinkle with salt and viola!!!  

CAULIFLOWER GRATIN
If you like something rich and heavy, this one is great.  It's too rich for me, but my pops who ate my leftovers loved it.

BURGER
It's good.  But I can pass this one and order only small plates.

DESSERTS: 
PEACH CRISP
divine!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  Not a apple, peach or any crisp fan but I absolutely love this one!!

So I wrote this draft few months ago and never submitted it.  Came back since and it was still good.  Had a few other dishes, but can't remember what they were.  I do know I ordered small plates I havent tried and they were all yummmmmmmmmm.

My new favorite restaurant.
author: Joanne H.

description:
I wrote a review last night and used the words "vagina" and "g-spot" to reference one of my favorite cities in the world and my favorite hot chocolate in the universe. 

A couple of hours later I removed it said review as it just was not written to perfection.

Add a little lamb to ground beef is the path to burger Nirvana.
author: V B.

description:
This is a gem by the Cal train station.  Love the casual but well designed atmosphere.  Festive vibe.  The space is small, so it's a bit of a squeeze, like many SF places.  

Roast chicken with warm heirloom tomatoes is a must.  The chicken is tender and flavorful and over thin crisp onion rings.  The lambrusco (sparkling rose) is delicious.
author: Patricia L.

description: This is currently my favorite restaurant in SF.  Service and food were amazing at very reasonable prices.  I don't see how it gets better than this for New American dining in the city.  Marlowe, you got it baby.
author: Justin L.

description:
Another stop on our journey for the best steak tartare in town. Unfortunately, it seems that the steak tartare was the only thing worth stopping for . . . The steak tartare which is made with ground chunks of ribeye was marvelous. Coming in right behind Bix, which to date tops our list as the best thus far. The simple toast points that the tartare was served with were great. They didn't have much flavor, but that only served to highlight the delicious flavors for the tartare, and bring about a nice crunchy accompaniment to the raw meat chunks. 

Though the fries were nice, that's pretty hard to screw up. But, I will admit the horseradish dip it came with was interesting in a good way. 

As for the other stuff . . . not so good. Not so good at all. I think the Spiced Prawns were seared or grilled for much too long. The shrimp wasn't succulent; it was dry. My friend thinks they had sprinkled some celery salt on it. But, I'm not sure if that was actually from the accompanying "hot and boozy cocktail sauce," which tasted more like celery infused cocktail sauce. 

The Little Gem Salad took the prize for the biggest YUCK! of the night. It was overloaded with flat leaf parsley. I guess if you like that yuck stuff it'd be okay, but I hate the taste of it, and ended up not finishing my salad because of it. I blame the parsley for my lack of fiber . . . 

About $90 for all that and a carafe of red wine (including tax and tip).
author: Christina L.

description:
I went again last night and I fell in love again!

-brussels sprout chips 5 stars
-baked oysters               5 stars     
-bone marrow                5 stars
-duck liver toast              3 stars  (not a fan of the sweetness)
-steak tartare                  4 stars
author: Anne-Mary P.

description: Old Location was great but Anna & Co have taken it up several notches at the new Marlowe location.......awesome new bar & the experience, food & service outstanding.
author: Lloyd G.

description: I took my friend here for dinner on 01.17.2017. We had a reservation at 7pm. It had been planned for sometime, perhaps 3 weeks. So, there was quite a build up to the big dinner. We ordered A LOT and everything we ordered was delicious. My ONLY bummer was that the chef, or whomever, was heavy handed with the salt. The Brussel sprout chips and the french fries were WAY too salty. I really want to give a 3-star rating BUT fortunately, the wait staff, whose name I did not get, was the saving grace and what gives Marlowe the extra star. She was super sweet and friendly. She was also knowledgeable to the wines which my date ordered. The young lady was also training a gentleman which I am sure will narrow this down. Both were fun and made us laugh as we did them. I will definitely go back and do recommend this restaurant as I am a concierge. I will however, advise that the diner tell the wait staff to remind the kitchen to go easy on the salt if you don't like salty appetizers.
author: Anthony R.

description: After hearing a lot of hullabalu and how great the burger is over the years, we finally got a chance to try it all by stopping in at the bar the other night.  Despite the fact that the place still pretty much looks like Coco 500 minus the green beans (sad face), we settled in.  A couple of cocktails and the burger later (along with a side of roasted cauliflower with cheese), I have to wonder what all the hype is about.  The burger was good (once I took off half of the giant bun), but the actual patty couldn't have been more than a 1/4 lb (tiny).  Good fries, but I wouldn't go out of my way for either.  What am I missing here?  A nondescript dining room, fine food but not blowing my skirt up, I just don't get it.
author: e w.

description:
Savory Bread Pudding.  Rich, velvety Parmesan cream.  Ribbons of melt-in-your-mouth Prosciutto.  Peppery arugula.  Hmmm...this is making my stomach growl.  I had the chance to head to Marlowe in January with my boss for my one-year review.  My review went well, but the lunch went better!  We started with the brussel sprout chips that I swear they make them out of crack.  Well, not crack, but maybe something really addicting and delicious, like Shamrock Shakes.  But not Shamrock Shakes, cause god knows this place isn't McDonalds, so maybe the best way to analogize those brussel sprout chips is to liken them to pure happiness.  There, that's about right.

I then followed up my pure-happiness-in-a-bowl-brussel-sprouts with the Savory Bread Pudding that was oh so yummy I can still taste it if I close my eyes shut and put on the slightest hint of a smile.  We washed everything down with some crisp Sauvignon Blanc...mmm.  If I could have this repeated every week I would be the most productive worker on the planet.
author: Ali L.

description:
If you can stand the wait, the food is a welcome payoff. I've lowered my rating from 5 to 4 stars because the hostess/owner and server didn't come through as promised while we waited. Given the success of both Marlowe and Park Tavern, my experience is probably rare.

I recommended Marlowe to a friend from Seattle who was interviewing since I'd heard great things about their burger and wanted to try it. Despite this being a weekday, Marlowe was crowded, even early, like a Friday night. 

The hostess, who identified herself as the owner, offered us a free glass of wine because our table wasn't ready. Then she promised one at the end of our meal if we could leave the table...my friend's verbosity was stretching out our meal and he wasn't picking up  my hints to leave. Before you rise to his defense, we'd passed the 1.5-hour mark and 10-15 people were waiting inside and outside the restaurant. 

Unfortunately though, we paid for both rounds, as well as the third round (second at the time) of wine ordered at the table. Oh well, stuff happens. I haven't been back but obviously plenty of other people have.

The bacon cheeseburger itself was very good, though not the transcendental experience I'd expected based on friends who knew about my burger list and claimed it was the best burger in SF. If you're a burger lover, don't be afraid to eat it. If I'm wrong, please let me know why I need to go back and try again. 

Regardless, the quality of every dish is obvious. Pricing is high but not unexpected, given the number of people who pass through small Marlowe on any given night.
author: Mike H.

description:
First Visit: I went on the first night of being open, so I expected a few hiccups...to my surprise, there were none. 

My takeaway is that the menu under-promises and that the resulting dishes over-deliver. Bucking the "4 adjectives per entree" trend I despise, the dishes are very simply described on the menu...the dishes themselves were much more visually impressive and tasty than expected.

I hope they keep the same attention to detail that I experienced. Consider the appetizer of grilled shrimp, served head- and tail-on but otherwise peeled, served with a great cocktail sauce (which included kaffir lime vodka), all served in a little cast iron pan, on top of a nicely folded napkin, on top of a small simple plate. You get the idea...plenty of flourishes.

Oh, and the apple crisp dessert was fan-effin-tastic, especially with the wine that our waiter, Patrick, suggested.

Great people, great food...here is hoping that they keep it up.
author: Greg J.

description:
I don't usually review but I'm hoping the number of reviews saying "TOO SALTY" might encourage Marlowe to ease up on the sodium.

Came here with a reservation (highly recommended) and was seated immediately. For apps, ordered the bone marrow (AWESOME), deviled egg (AWESOME), and duck liver crostini (AWESOME). 

The entrees were where my dreams were shattered. I ordered the burger and my BF ordered the pork chop. It was as if the salt shaker fell onto our food because I couldnt even eat my burger (TOO SALTY). I was chugging water/wine after each bite which is a shame cuz I could totally tell that if it weren't for the saltiness, the burger would have been dynomite. BF's porkchop was tender but SALTY. His sweet potato gratin was really nummy too if it wasn't so darn salty. I'm really not even a picky eater - I could probably eat a wooden stick with ketchup on it and like it but I thought I was going cray cuz everything was so salty.

I was really sad after dinner because the entrees had so much potential if it twernt for the salt. Overall, the hostess was beyond nice, service was good, ambiance was super chill, appetizers knocked my socks off... but damn that salt. Will definitely go back but might ask them to ease up on the salt for the entrees.
author: A. C.

description: The food was good but not as good I would expect from a restaurant that is so revered (and hard to get into). The hamburger was good - I'd say great, in fact. The brussell sprout chips were definitely a highlight. My bone marrow was undercooked. The drink was fabulous. The service was abysmal but I believe my experience was unique and definitely not the norm (just bad luck on our part). I loved the look and feel of the space but I hadn't been to the old location.
author: carol m.

description: I had such high expectations for this place due to all the amazing reviews, but unfortunately,  they were not met. Brussels sprout chips were a little too salty and I did not care for the buns for my burger. It tasted like they were from a cheap grocery store. Plus, the meat for my burger was not sufficient in size. I took several bites where all I was eating was that distasteful bread. They should either make the buns smaller or the meat patty wider. Having said all this though, I have to point out that the meat was cooked to perfection and I absolutely loved the ambience of this place!
author: Sue J.

description:
As the GM reached out to me to address the issues with my original review, I am going to add a star to my rating. I appreciate and respect her accountability to make sure the next dining experience would be top notch. 

The next time I am in SF, I look forward to trying Marlowe again and having some of that delicious food.
author: Matt L.

description:
I would give Marlowe more than 5 stars if I could. Here is why:

SERVICE
Absolutely the best service I ever had at a restaurant. I made reservations at 7:30 on a Monday, showed up early at 6pm and they hostess was very friendly and accommodating, we were able to get seated right away. The server through out dinner was very attentive(but not overly so, which is good).

FOOD
1. Bone Marrow
2. Brussel Sprout Chips
3. 2 Oysters - New England Clam Chowder style
4. Marlowe Burger (medium rare) - best burger I've ever had. Also the best fries I've ever had, perfectly crispy on the outside and wonderfully fluffy on the inside.
5. Wild Mushroom Polenta

Everything was perfectly cooked and well seasoned. The burger was fantastic, better than Umami Burger and Father's Office in SoCal (Sorry SoCal peeps, I'm still a fan though!)
author: Pearl L.

description: The most pretentious and overrated place ever, designed for uncaring snobs. I went here with a group of co-workers, who wanted to go to a nice place for a celebration party.  But the food literally stunk. I am trying to eat a clean diet, with organic healthy food, and I sometimes like having rich food, but this place was horrible. They could use some fresh vegetables and fruits to balance out their unhealthy animal based fare.
author: jonny s.

description:
Favorite restaurant in SF hands down. Yes thats including Espetus and House of Prime Rib!

Came here on Monday and ordered:

1) Brussel Sprout Chips
2) Bone Marrow
3) Baked Oysters
4) Marlowe Burger
5) Polenta & Mushroom entree

Marlowe Burger  =  BEST burger you'll ever have in your life. I almost cried it was THAT good.

The End.
author: Tony L.

description:
