Best French Fries Ever.  Perfectly crunchy on the outside, smooth on the inside.  Just absolutely perfect.  5 stars for the fries.

Burger was fine, Soup was fine.  Deviled egg was interesting and complex.  Chocolate cream dessert thing was rich and kind of too salty but delicious. 4 stars for everything but the fries.

I'm already planning on taking out-of-town guests here for the fries.
author: Lynne W.

description:
I had some friends coming for a visit and wanted to take them out for a non-touristy dinner.  I found Marlowe through Yelp, and made reservations.  Here's how the night went down:

Parking: if you take the Cal train into the city this place is super easy to get to.  We had to drive and opted for the valet because I was stupid enough to make reservations the same night the Giants were playing a home game (only $12 for valet 2 blocks away from the restaurant).  

Ambiance:  there's a yippie type of vibe in the place (similar to what you'd find at restaurants in the surrounding area).  Family style seating and there really isn't that much room in the whole place, so I would highly recommend reservations. MIT is pretty dark in the place and I could have used a little more light to read my menu.   It is also pretty loud and was hard for all members in our party of 5 to have one conversation going on.

Food:  it was all pretty darn good.  Fairly simplistic and "California".  Salads were dressed with simple dressings.  The deviled eggs were really tasty.  I had the polenta.  It was a really hearty meal.  Other members of my party got the Marlowe burger.  They all said it was delicious as the juices were running down their arms.  I personally loved the fries that came with the burger.

Staff:  all staff members were friendly and gave us attention, nothing to complain about.

It didn't get 5 stars from me because it was a little cramped and noisy for our group.  If you're just looking for a nice place to have a not so intimate meal with your honey, this is a great option.
author: Lauren R.

description: Best service from the bar. My lack of planning always leads us to be eating at the bar. For this place, I would actually reserve a bar spot if I could. The bar tenders are always attentive and knowledge. Getting samples of some drinks is a bonus. The food is good, but could be a little heavy and salty at times. Their appetizers usually are more interesting to me than the main entrees. Dinner is a little pricey and it's always packed, otherwise I'd definitely go more often.
author: K T.

description:
Well, I thought I had to try it. Basically, they ruin what probably a well cooked burger with an overload of carbs and cals, so that the flavor of the burger is totally obscured. 

Next time, I will remember to omit the cheese and bacon to see what the burger actually tastes like.
author: Cliff L.

description: The food here is fine, but uninspiring. It's overpriced. It's one of those places that is clearly popular with hip rich San Franciscans, but doesn't actually taste good and skates by on its ambience.
author: Jesse W.

description:
Came here with a friend today for lunch. We both had the Marlowe burger, and it was delicious! I especially like how flavorful the meat is.

Burgers come with fries or a salad. I chose fries. They were fresh and crispy. I especially liked the dash of dried parsley on top.

My friend liked the aioli. It was my first time ever having any kind of aioli, and I'm sure it is really good quality, but I have decided I do not like it. The texture did not agree with me.

Service was great. The server religiously kept our water glasses full, without the hovering feeling. Quick, efficient, and friendly.
author: Bonnie N.

description:
I feel like food and service at Marlowe have both been downgraded after they moved to the new location.

The Marlowe burger comes with a normal burger bun that you can buy from Safeway which does not justify for its price.

I was abandoned by my waiter for 30 mins before I could get a chance to ask for the cheque, wtf...
author: Cindy L.

description:
It was an amazing dinner,. great service, great food and def great price. 

It was a group of 5 girls,. we practically ordered everything on the menu...

My favorite must have dish is the BONE MARROW and the OYSTERS!

The bill only came out to be $40 a person and I was so full. I am a big fan of oysters and marlowe did not let me down. I love the mini bacon pieces smothered on my oysters ;) not only that,. The bone marrow pieces were huge,. And loved how they had cut the bone in half and provided toasted bread for us to eat it with.  

We also ordered the Brussels sprout chips, I wasn't a big fan since the pieces tasted bitter ;( blehh!

My main entree was the Marlowe burger, luckily I shared this. I was so full from everything else, the burger tasted just like any other burger and it was there to stuff me up. 

Service was super! Everyone was so nice and patient witH us and didn't even feel pressured to leave,. My girlfriends and I were there for at least 3 hours having a gossip session!

Will be back!
author: Chanel L.

description:
No better place to have a nice meal before a Giants game! (Exactly what we did for my husband's birthday) Make sure you make a reservation though because you won't even find bar space after 6pm. 

I recommend sharing a few appetizers and the burger, wash it down with a beer or a glass of wine.  You'll be ready for the game and still have some room for garlic fries.
author: Sara L.

description:
It baffles me how mediocre restaurants can exist in San Francisco.  It's impossible to head down any street or alleyway and not trip over a bushel of small, innovative (fairly) reasonably priced restaurants that would be the talk of the town anywhere else.  While Marlowe certainly isn't hidden (across from Caltrain) or obscure (on literally every best new restaurant list in 2010), it still makes you glad you live in a place that loves food so much.

In terms of food, it's hard to argue with items like deviled eggs with bacon, brussel sprout chips, poulet vert, or the almighty Marlowe burger.  The burger in particular stood out with its nice bun and generous toppings (horseradish aoili!).  Beer and wine selection was focused and pretty reasonably priced.

The space is comfortable and cozy, if a little odd.  We were seated at the communal table, which happens to have a big steel beam angling from its center up to the ceiling.  Not a big deal, but it would kind of suck to get seated directly in front of it.  The place was busy, and crowded, but service was prompt due to how small the place is.

As a side note, I have a theory that the only way to truly enjoy brussel sprouts is to treat them purely as a vehicle for delivering delicious salt and fat.  Anyone who says they love the taste of them plain and/or steamed is a liar or an incurable health nut.  Either way, you probably don't want them giving you food advice.  They probably don't even like bacon.
author: Ted B.

description:
Go there and order everything on the appetizer menu.  It is all that good.

Stop reading and just go... 

Yes, I did order every appetizer.  Not cheap, but worth it.
author: Frank M.

description:
This cool little spot is right in Soma, and located across from the train station. I literally had no idea this was here until I was searching for sweet new dinner spots in my hood, and alas, I found Marlowe. 

I came here with a girlfriend, and we cozied up at the bar, which was perfect. The restaurant is pretty small, and it's got this really cool ambiance that seems fairly dark since the colors are dark walls, tables and chairs, with white floors and dim lighting, which makes it feel small, and not like you're in a massive bustling restaurant. It's a pretty quiet and laid back atmosphere - yet intimate and cozy.

The first starter we got here was the crispy brussels sprout chips served with lemon and sea salt ($6) These are the most awesome concept of brussels sprouts that I've ever seen on a menu.  They are crispy and salty like a chip or a potato crisp, and at the same time it has this citrusy flavor with it that makes it perfect. I could easily eat brussels sprouts like this every day, but they are a bit greasy since they are obviously cooked in olive oil.  Regardless, they are awesome and you must try them if you come.

The other starter we got were the deviled eggs. These come with aged provolone, a pickled jalapeno on top and bacon ($1.5 each). MMMMMM! These might be the BEST deviled eggs that I've had in the city.  The pickled jalapeno on top is an awesome touch because its bitter and distinguished, and almost *anything* is good with bacon - let's be honest here.

We were also served a complimentary baked oyster, which is served hot with oyster in the shell.  How nice of them to give us a little something extra on the side!

For the main dish, I got the Anson Mills polenta, which is served with wild mushrooms, truffled pecorino and a poached farm egg ($18).  This polenta was awesome! The poached egg is a nice touch too, because you get the runny yolk to mix into all of the mushroom and polenta goodness :)  I really didn't want anything too heavy for a main course, and even though I couldn't finish the dish because it was big, it was really awesome!

Overall, Marlowe gets a solid 4 stars in my book. The service was great, the food was awesome, and it's like a little undiscovered gem in Soma!
author: Taylor L.

description:
Went here to try "the best burger in SF" and found out it isn't actually served here (lol).  The burger was fine -- good size, good toppings, cooked perfectly -- but doesn't deserve the title -- there are 3 burgers within easy walking distance that kick the crap out of it -- Ironsides, 21A, and Nova.  The wine was pleasant but not cheap; the service was solid but not exceptional.  Also tried the brussel sprout chips, which were ok.  

In short, this dining experience made me miss South and I will almost definitely will not bother going back here (never say never).
author: Tasha D.

description: Came here with my girlfriend for dinner with reservations through OpenTable and we were seated 30 minutes earlier than we had down for our reservation. Nice! Between the two of us, we ordered the two deviled eggs, roasted lemon brussel sprouts, pork chop, and the supposedly famous burger. I'm not usually a fan of deviled eggs because I dislike the oily taste of mayo, but the deviled eggs are so good here I would have no problem eating at least half a dozen of them. Warmed up with a generous slice of bacon is probably the best way to serve a deviled egg. The brussel sprouts were also very tasty. In many ways, the seasoning reminded me of what you would toss fried calamari with. I would recommend this whether or not you're a fan of brussel sprouts. The only real disappointment I had from Marlowe was the pork chop. At $27, the second most expensive item on the entree menu next to the steak, I thought the pork chops would be a good bet, as it was also recommended by many Yelpers. Unfortunately, the pork chop did not deliver. The pork chop didn't even look like your traditional pork chop, rather, it looked like a cross between pulled pork and ribs. While I was certain that I was eating pork, the pork lacked any flavor and was very forgetful. I wouldn't recommend getting it. The burger on the other hand, tasted delicious, especially with the mayo aioli and bacon that the burger is topped with. While Marlowe is a good date place, I wouldn't actually come here again because it seems like the menu hasn't been changed in a very long time, and the selection itself is fairly limited.
author: Austin W.

description:
Although the food wasn't "perfect", though it was quite good, this place deserves five stars just for the service. It started a little ominously with not having our seats at our reservation time. But this was quickly made up for by the complimentary sparkling wine brought to us by the host. Very nice touch. Love the brussel sprout chips and although my companions found the bisque too rich, I found it to be delectable. A little side of toast with some sort of tapanade made it special. Tri-color salad was quite excellent and refreshing. 

Our Steak was juicy although a little on the chewy side, still worth a try.  Polenta was interesting and very tasty with some nice mushroom sauce.  Our fish was by no means terrible but all of us felt it was a bit fishy. And here is why I give this place five stars. Our server could tell that we were not enjoying it and proceeded to get our feedback about the dish, took it away and then completely took it off the bill. No questions asked and this is a $26 item. Maybe this is something that should be practicec more frequently but I had to give them a big shoutout. for doing that. 

Based on the ambiance, the food, and more than anything the service, we will be returning.
author: Diego C.

description:
Everything about this place was fantastic. Small restaurant with rustic decorations, amazing service. The food was also beyond fantastic.

APPETIZERS
Deviled eggs: Wow, heaven in a bite.

Beef Tartare: Not really a fan of beef tartare but this was nicely spiced.

Artichoke soup: My least favorite appetizer but still great!

Brussel sprout chips: Fantastic! Light and flaky with lots of flavor.

ENTREES
Pork chop: HOLY COW, this is the best pork chop I've ever tasted.

Poulet vert: Chicken cooked perfectly, very juicy.

Polenta: Mushrooms, truffle, and a poached egg. Need I say more...a heavy dish, but that just means I had fantastic leftovers for lunch the next day!

Crab and shrimp louie: I didn't love this one but my boyfriend was a big fan. One of the lighter dishes because the stuffing goes in lettuce cups instead of on bread.

DESSERT
Apple crisp: Needed more apple but the ice cream and sauce were tasty.

Chocolate mousse: Good mix of sweet and salty.

Overall, I loved the entire meal. Will definitely be back!
author: Amy F.

description:
Incredible food and great environment.  
I like the fact that it is a small restaurant, and the wait staff is excellent.

Be sure to try the chicken and/or the pork chops and combine it with the little gem salad.
author: Navid M.

description:
Went here for my work colleague's going away lunch with a party of 12 last week. We had an amazing luncheon at Marlowe's. I'm definitely coming back and bringing them more business. 

For starters, we had the pistachios with maple, bourbon and sea salt and the crispy brussel sprouts chips! As my appetizer, I shared the burrata cheese tomato relish. That was delicious! Then my crispy fried chicken sandwich came and OH MY GOODNESS!!!! This was the icing on the cake. This had to be the star of the show. Seriously, this was the reason why I was so happy when they picked Marlowe as the restaurant to celebrate Traci's bon voyage party. The chicken was light and crispy, the bread just held everything together, it had bacon too with a ceasar aioli spread -- OKAY! *two snaps up* with micro greens. Mad automatic drool! It was also came with fries, it tasted like crack. 

We ordered the smokey cauliflower which kinda resembled a mac 'n cheese but it was just as good though. 

For dessert, they brought out three types of desserts in small mason jars. I believe one was the panna cotta, another one had chocolate mousse in it and the last one had a fruit crisp, caramel sauce and ice cream! Man, we were so stuffed but gleaming with smiles.
author: Mika D.

description:
With a party for four, they got two mildly custom orders wrong (fries instead of salad, no aioli sauce.) They were happy to correct the mistakes, but one person ended up getting his meal after the rest of us were all done eating.

The food is solid, with some of it being mildly interesting. However, if I had to pay for the food myself I wouldn't have been as happy: $20 a person for lunch.

Around lunch and dinner time, the small dining room is packed to the gills. We had to wait 20 minutes even with reservations.

Meh.
author: Alexander J.

description:
Pricier $$. delicious food. come in a party no bigger than three- or order take out (OrderAhead app!)

I love the burger ($14-cheapest entree usually). lemme rephrase. I love love love love love the burger. and the fries. and the horseradish aioli. Compared to Umami, Father's Office, Chez Maman- this is the place to be. oofta. 

Too bad neither my wallet nor my waistline can handle one of these every week. 

they also have tasty interesting cocktails and other delicious things when I sat down with my friends- big wait unless you come at a weird time.
author: Jessica P.

description: Okay drinks, but some of the food is pretty good. I had the drink "The Calf" and didn't care for it. Probably just not my palette. I highly recommend the English Pea Pancakes for an appetizer - they were delicious!
author: Katherine D.

description: Great place and food, wish they would change the menu up a bit; always seems to be the same.
author: Nicholas C.

description: Probably my favorite neighborhood spot in Soma for a great meal, or a glass of wine at the bar. Incredibly pleasant atmosphere, if a little loud at times. I've never had one bad bite of food here. It's all amazing. The chicken slays. The burger destroys. The deviled eggs dominate.
author: Allison B.

description:
This review is for two aspects only: the noise and the communal table.  

The chairs at the communal table are kept way too close together. I understand that with demand for seating there's a strong push to pack as many folks in as want to eat there, but when we ate there the chairs were close enough together that you'd frequently inadvertently make eye contact with people across the table who were not in your party, and while I am fine with being friendly and all that, in this situation it felt awkward and uncomfortable. 

The noise.. man, coco500 had figured out how to mute the noise. It's loud in Marlowe, sometimes to the point of having to raise your voice so the person seated in a bar seat next to you can hear you.  Lots of places have this figured out, and it needs to be fixed here.
author: m l.

description:
LNO at Marlowe last night was such a success.  I am an instant fan, the food was insane and we kept joking that we were literally eating as if it was our last meal.  I think we might have thrown some elbows when the burrata came out--stupid good.  The dining room is much smaller than I expected, making for a super cozy and family-style environment.  

My favorite things: the deviled eggs (we ordered 2 or 3 ROUNDS), the burrata, the shrimp (good heavens--the sauce it comes with! spicy deliciousness), the polenta (there are no words, it has truffle...), poulet vert & the strawberry dessert.

Same owner and executive chef as Park Tavern, another favorite.  I will return many times and hopefully soon..
author: Lola C.

description: After hearing and reading so much about the food here, I was disappointed.  Went for lunch. Inside was stark, but inviting, and sat at the bar. Drinks and bartender were good, but the "burger" which I heard so much about was overseasoned and very salty. As if kitchen didn't trust the meat. It also came out cooked differently than I would have classified what I ordered. However it was far from the best burger in SF, let alone anywhere. Definitely not a $200 lunch for 2 when you factor in drinks, app & tip. If you are going to be so highly regarded concerning a specific item, and that your server steers you to it, you better deliver. Disappointing and not in a way I'd want to give it another try.
author: Joseph S.

description:
This place is a young, hip eatery with a fun vibe, catering to those willing to try some unexpected foods, such as roasted bone marrow and steak tartare. They have a short, but decent, selection of wines and beers to delight in before the main event. Noise levels were lively, but still allowed for good conversation, as we sat at a long communal table next to other diners.

We started with the signature brussel sprout chips, bone marrow, and steak tartare. The tartare was my favorite of the three, having a delicious mixture of herbs and spices. Even members of our group who were not sure of eating raw meat enjoyed it. The bone marrow was left to us more adventurous folks as it was served in the bone, but was quite good. The brussel sprouts were an indicator of how the rest of the food would go: salty.

Salt is a great ingredient when used in moderation. Unfortunately the cook at Marlowe this evening had a salt-heavy hand. It did not seem to matter what anyone at our table ordered, it was all overly salted. Pork chops, steak, "poulet vert", all just very salty. It is quite odd to me why you'd bother getting high grade meats only to douse them in so much salt the flavor of the meat was hidden. Even the desserts, both the chocolate pudding and strawberry ice cream were covered in salt.

I'm giving three stars because I really liked the vibe and the options on the menu, but I cannot get past the salt. Maybe if I visit again I can get a chance to change my mind, but that's where it stands for now.
author: Graham O.

description:
I came here a couple times at the previous location and once at the new location.  When I first came here, I thought the food was fantastic especially the burger and brussel sprout chips.  Somehow getting the burger this latest outing did not satisfy me.  Not sure why...was the burger smaller, did they change the recipe, or has my palate changed that much?

Anyways, I do like the new location, because it is roomier.  Service is solid.  I am just starting to think the food may be a little expensive for what it is.
author: A W.

description:
It's places like Marlowe that make the Bay Area dining scene as great as it is. Anna Weinberg and Jennifer Puccio give us a warm and comforting restaurant that also has style and most importantly, delicious food. What goes in your mouth is what this restaurant all about.  Customers are treated like they are guests at someone's home being welcomed to a good meal, not food groupies needing to be impressed. You get courtesy, comfort and respect here. The location is also great for a pre-Giants game bite or post happy hour dinner.

I'm a big fan of beets and their beets and burratta dish is something i'd probably never get tired of eating.  The dill, basil, mint and Aleppo chili oil provide layers of flavor that allow you to experience the dish in a number of different delicious combinations.  The crispy brussels sprout chips are not just hype.  They are seasoned perfectly and fun to munch on while enjoying a cocktail.  The red wine porcini jus on the steak frites is a great alternative to a more common sauce béarnaise. I only had one bite of the Marlowe Burger, but it was enough to know that it will be my next order when I return here.  Finishing off my meal with the upside down peach crisp with bourbon ice cream and brown butter caramel sauce was wonderful.

Simply delicious food, as all restaurants should strive for.
author: Luis M.

description:
This is probably a 4.5 star review...I'm not really sure I have a really great reason to deduct a full star; my wife and I had a great time at Marlowe.

The impetus for our visit is, of course, the Hamburger Hype.  Between Michael Bauer and every food blogger who has visited SF in the past six months, the hamburger at Marlowe has achieved quite a deal of attention.

But I'm getting ahead of myself: first of all, we were running late and they graciously held our table for an extra ten minutes.  Quite a feat given the size of the restaurant.

I started with the brussels sprout chips and my wife had the sweet corn soup.  The soup was better than the chips by a smidge, but both were outstanding starters.  My only complaint with the b sprout chips was that I reached my saturation point with those salty, lemony, savory little buggers about halfway through the portion.

On to the mains.  My wife ordered the lamb, which was cooked perfectly.  The only complaint from her was that the ricotta & parmesan dumplings were not all that great.

Then...the burger.  Yes, I ordered the burger medium rare.  it arrived perfectly stacked: no bacon drooping over one side, no messy lettuce mound, no cheese squirting out the side.  Almost picture perfect.  And the flavor was astounding.  The horseradish aioli complemented the beef and bacon, the cheese had flavor, and the shredded lettuce- at first thought, a stumble step- actually ends up being a benefit.  From my perspective, a big leaf of lettuce simply provides a slippery surface that can send your burger squishing out the back when you take a bite.  Shredded lettuce solves this.  Yay, I say, for shredded lettuce.  I'm a convert now.  I "get it".

The burger was perfectly cooked, with just enough juice dripping out the back of the contraption as I ate.

And the fries?  Well, they are too often an afterthought when presenting an excellent burger, but they are fantastic at Marlowe- not greasy, just enough salt...top notch.

For dessert: pot de creme.  Very, very excellent.

Another bonus was the availability of carafes on the wine menu, so those of us who normally blast through more than a glass of wine can be set up in an affordable way.

The only real bummer (which, along with the parmesan dumplings) was that we arrived just as a "best of" Billy Joel CD was beginning...and continued to play...for the entire...meal.  Now, I'm ok with SOME Billy Joel, and my wife pretty much hates him.  So a complete mix CD of all Billy's hits put a bit of a crimp in the vibe of Marlowe until the CD changed.  C'mon, folks...mix it up a little.  I'm pretty sure 45 minutes of Billy Joel is more than enough for just about anybody.

But those two issues are minor, and certainly not enough to keep us from returning from Marlowe for the burger alone.

The service, by the way, was excellent, friendly, and efficient.  Absolutely no complaints.
author: Ben G.

description: They have one of the best burgers that I've had in SF. They were perfectly seasoned and everyone's burgers were cooked to their liking. The fries were crispy and well done too. We also had a few cocktails and the deviled eggs which were on point. Service was friendly and the decor in the restaurant is nice. Lovely place to take a date! Would definitely like to come back and try their brunch menu.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Came here for the famous, blogged-about, raved-about Marlowe Burger, and was a little disappointed.  It's not that great of a burger--a little underseasoned and lacking in any punch or "wow factor."  

So why the 4-star review?  First, the service was excellent.  The hostess was very apologetic for making us wait and hooked us up with some champagne, gratis.  Second, the appetizers (brussel sprout chips, bone marrow) and fries were also really good.  This is a tough call, but I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt--that they had an off night or that I'm just a total burger snob--and would definitely come back.  Maybe next time I'll try the chicken.
author: Matt Y.

description:
This place was highly recommended by a former colleague and friend. I reserved a table through Opentable and then took the Caltrain up to the City. It was perfect, because I left the train station and walked across the street.

The food was great! I had deviled egg, pea soup, and prawn cocktail. I also had their dessert. VERY delicious! Will be heading back to the restaurant soon!

By the way, the place is packed when I left @ 8:30 p.m.

Try to book the table before 7 p.m.

Why one star away from the 5 star? Well, I wanted to stay longer, but a table was needed. I just felt rushed.
author: Geri M.

description:
Been wanting to visit Marlowe for sometime. Heard great things about their burger. I made a reservation on Open Table for a Monday early evening dinner. Got there at 6 pm and my reservation was not listed. Turns out I had made it for the wrong week, but luckily it was still early and the hostess provided me with a table for our group. The place was smaller than I expected so be sure to make reservations.

Had the deviled eggs and fried brussel sprout chips to start. Very good eggs, especially with the slice of bacon on top. The "chips" were unique and surprisingly quite addictive. Two of us got the burger and the other two got the grilled niman pork chop. The burger was actually pretty good. No ketchup necessary. Soft bun. Fries were only ok. Was it the best burger? Eh, not on my list, but it's definitely in my top ten. Nevertheless, I will have to come back and give the chop a try since my friends described the pork chop as "ridiculous." I wonder how it matches up to Nopa's pork chop. My meal ended well as I had the strawberry and rhubarb crisp for dessert. It was served in a jar and covered with a brown butter caramel sauce. It was really good and something I'd have again.
author: Rick T.

description:
This place isn't worth they hype.  We made reservations for a Friday night a few weeks in advance.  We were seated promptly, but after placing our drink order, we waited at least 15 minutes for our drinks.  In the meantime our waitress came by and we ordered the brussel sprouts chips as an appetizer.  After our drinks finally arrived, our waitress came back over and we placed our order and she proceeded to ask if we wanted anything to snack on in the meantime.  At that time I reminded her we had placed an order for brussel sprout chips.  

Our food then came out about 15 minutes later and we had not received the brussel sprout chips.  We told the food runner to please cancel the order, which he said he would take care of.  A few minutes later our waitress came by and apologizes that they got "lost in translation" and that they would be arriving soon, and she offered to comp them.  They also gave us a free cocktail.  Not a great experience, but at least they did what they could to make up for it.  I don't think I will be rushing to return though.
author: Mohl D.

description:
Two starts for a terrible service and for getting us to wait for 25 mins outside the restaurant when they were running behind our reservation. It's the annoying piece where no waiter updated us how long it would take, didn't follow up or offer us any water while we wait. The bar is tiny and was full when we arrived so they told us to wait outside. Sorry, but I expect a better service and follow up from a restaurant that's highly rated and raves about it's food. The mains took a while too but at least they were warm and delicious.
I am glad I didn't pick your restaurant for any special occasion.
author: Pooja S.

description:
Marlowe.  I was pretty pumped to check out this eatery especially after looking at the menu and reading the Yelp reviews, but I am going to have to disagree with the majority of people here.

The place itself was cozy and had a cool vibe, the only downside was the massive bar angling through the middle of our table which made it hard to see or converse with the person across from you (this would only be a problem with a large group seated in our location, don't worry).

The wine list looked decent and we got a couple of bottles of wine.  Service was attentive but not overbearing until the end of the meal.  I will get to that later.

We started out with some appetizers; the brussel sprout chips were good but a little too greasy for my liking.  The fries were good but nothing special.  What really had me salivating though was the pork chop that people had been raving about.

When it arrived I was disappointed.  They had cooked it all the way through when I had specified medium.  I alerted them to this and they quickly took it back and cooked another one for me while assuring me they would not charge me for my meal.  It was returned a little less well done but still definitely far from medium, I decided to not press the issue and started thinking about the quality of their meat and the fact that they might be scared to cook it medium.  Now I enjoy a well done pork chop as well but this one just did not wow me. Maybe NOPA spoils me.

To wrap the meal up the bill comes and they charged me for 2 pork chops!  This was quickly remedied but still Marlowe did not live up to my hopes.
author: Ryan J.

description:
Decent, but not worth the money.  

My friend and I decided on a whim to try this place since we were in the area on a Saturday evening.  We walked in around 6pm and decided to eat at the bar so we wouldn't have to wait 45 minutes to be seated at a communal table.  This place is tiny!  From the outside, this place looks so much bigger because of the deceiving mirrors.   

BAKED OYSTERS:  $3 each and so worth it!  

GRILLED NIMAN PORK CHOP:  $25 and so not worth it.  Asked for it medium, but it came out burnt, and definitely not gasm-worthy.  Only good thing about this entree was the bread pudding. 

MARLOW BURGER:  $13 and kind of worth it.  By far the cheapest entree option.  I've had better burgers for cheaper.  I actually liked the perfect crunchy fries on the side better than the actual burger. 

Ambience is nice and cozy.  Service was meh - bartender seemed judgmental and pretentious.  Food took an unpleasantly surprisingly long time - the couple next to us at the bar also seemed to wait so long for their food they were getting unhappy. 

Disappointing for the price, but there were lots of people willing to wait inside and even outside in the cold with their glasses of wine.  I guess it's the trendiness?  Meh.
author: Amy H.

description:
Marlowe is almost a 4. I think they are really strong in their appetizers, but just okay for the mains. When I went, my husband and I shared 3 apps: the roasted bone marrow which was rich and flavorful, the deviled eggs which had a great creamy texture paired with delicious melted cheese and bacon on top, and the baked oysters which were unique with a layer of clam chowder and breadcrumbs on top. For my main I ordered the burger. I was really excited because I heard from multiple people that it's one of their favorite burgers in SF. Beside the fact that they use a horseradish aioli, I found the burger to be quite ordinary. The bread was toasted but kinda dry and flavorless, the meat was cooked well and juicy but that shouldn't be praised, and they used common toppings like lettuce, onions, etc. I had a bite of my husband's salmon and again, just okay.

I was sad to have started my dinner with such high hopes to be disappointed at the end. I wouldn't get the burger again, but I would like to go back to try more apps and maybe one of their desserts; which are served in these adorable jars. They also have a nice wine list which makes it a nice spot for happy hour. It's also in a great location right across the street from the CalTrain and close to the ballpark.
author: Alice J.

description:
I think the best part of this place is the outside, they have beautiful quotes printed on their glass windows.  My favorites are - 
"There are only two glasses of wine between someone who is boring, and someone who is interesting" - Peter The Winemaker
And
 "The secret of staying young is to live honestly, eat slowly, and lie about your age" - Lucille Ball

The hostess was so nice, we didn't want to sit at the communal table so she made room for us on a somewhat private table.  And right after we got seated, an awesome table opened up so she re-allocated us right away (even without us asking)!  And she offered to bring us wine while we waited.  

I ordered the Polenta with wild mushrooms, Parmesan & poached farm egg.  It was pretty much the best Polenta I've had till date, it has a hint of mint and lime.  

For future visits - I have to try the deviled eggs, and make reservations since the place is pretty tiny.
author: Anoo L.

description:
Woh.  This place is amazing!  We had a bunch of different items including the pate, burratta, burger and much more!  We were just blown away with the quality of the food.  The burger is up there for best gourmet burger in SF.  Definitely give it a try.

The only downside to this place is the size and as such, reserving a table.  But it is worth it so, plan ahead and make sure you go.
author: David H.

description:
Go hungry! Order a lot and get the BURGER! Oh so good.

They have a great wine list that includes wines from Croatia and Slovenia. One of the first SF restaurants to include the regions on their menu so that's a big plus for them! 

Their service is great! Staff is super nice and very friendly. Take the bar if there are no tables available b/c it will be just as awesome! The restaurant is pretty small so the wait may be a bit longer than you would like, BUT it's worth it!
author: Em D.

description:
Friday night dinner with my lovely girlfriend and we finally said let's try Marlowe. Not only do we live right by it but we've walked by it numerous times as well as talked about trying it out forever.

WOW why did I wait so long. 

Server was awesome. Great attitude, not overbearing and just on point.

The food! The food! Grilled squid with bbq' muscles that was chopped up as almost a bruscetta topping that you built yourself and topped with an aoli was rediculous.

Entree's. I've read so many things about the burger so I got the burger and my gf got the pork. So the burger is not a ginormourse burger but it is one of the best burgers I've had in the city. HOWEVER the pork that my gf was even better. It was tender flavorful and came with little rolls of prosciutto. Just delicious. For desert we got some kind of chocolate mouse thing that was awesome. 

We both walked away and thought it  was one of the better meals that we've had. Huge contrast from the days when this place was "South" the Australian wine bar. Talk about a come back.
author: Hyung L.

description:
As a frequent Giants game attendee, I have passed this restaurant whenever I have parked by the Cal Train station and have always been intrigued to go here to eat.  
Let's just say I'm glad that I finally have come to enjoy their food.  

Upon arrival, my friend and I were worried that we wouldn't get seated as we were in our Giants garb and everyone else in the restaurant was not, plus the restaurant looked slightly full.  We were pleased that we were able to get a seat at the bar.  

There were several items we wanted to try, but we ordered several appetizers, instead of a full entree. We were both very pleased with what we ordered.  I ordered the following:

Crispy Brussel Sprout Chips- If you like brussel sprouts, you'll probably like these.

Corn Soup-Our server said he always tries to take a shot of this when he works....let's just say, now I know why.  It's delicious!  The portion is on the smaller side for the price, but very yummy!!!

Wedge Salad with Bleu Cheese & Crispy Chicken Skin-  A very yummy version of a wedge salad because of the addition of the chicken skin.  The crispy chicken skin added a subtle saltiness to the salad.

Will definitely come back to this establishment when I'm thinking of a place to eat before and after a game or at anytime for that matter. There is still many dishes I'd like to try.
author: Caroline A.

description:
YUMS! here's what to do:

1. make a reservation.
2. come with a small group (i was here with a party of 3, it was perfect)
3. order many small plates to share (snacks, appetizers, soups, potted meats & things, sides)
4. skip the entrees, especially the stuffed sole

the small plates - everyone feigned niceness by offering the others the last bite when there was clearly a malicious glint in their eye challenging anyone to dare skuttle away that lingering bit of goodness. here's what was at stake:
- crispy brussels sprout chips - better than the best popcorn
- shot of heirloom carrot soup - served in a teacup, and good til the last drop
- roasted bone marrow - huge portion, served with crostini
- dungeness crab & rock shrimp louie - like a glamourized lettuce wrap
- cauliflower gratin - just couldn't tell where the cauliflower ended and cheese picked up. mmmmmm.

The stuffed sole was a HUGE disappointment. fish was fishy, stuffing bland, and mystery veggies strewn around inedibly salty.

Wine by the bottle, carafe or glass.
author: Ting S.

description: I went to Marlowe twice in two weeks and both times were solid as always. Love the food (as well as their new restaurant Park Tavern over in North Beach). Get the beef tartare and brussels sprouts chips.  I've also had the bone marrow and burger and both were delicious. These last two meals I had the Duo of Ahi Tuna and the Pan Seared Arctic Char. Both fish dishes were executed perfectly. Can't go wrong with anything at Marlowe!
author: Dave L.

description: This place is pretty solid. I only have a couple of complaints -- for instance, the burger was under-cooked (very bloody, although we ordered "medium rare"). Overall a great place to eat, but the dishes can be overly meat-y.
author: Derryl C.

description:
Love the atmosphere of this little place, love the food, love the menu, love that it's so close to my work.  There isn't one thing on there I would think twice about getting. 

Carrot soup is delicious, comes in shot form, so good I ordered another one.  Brussel sprout chips were strange and addictive. 

Be sure to have reservations, this is a pretty strict booking type restaurant, we got lucky and scored seats at the bar.
author: Yingjue C.

description:
Yum,

Had the following
Duck liver with a pickled grape yum
The scallop tartare amazing 
Okra ok 

Starter - cheese one with tomotoes. Amazing wow best I've had of that cheese ( bollete I think) 

Shrimp decent spicy 
Tartine of chorizo and tobiko wish it had more tobiko but it's good
author: Joey N.

description:
I loved the ambiance of this place and setting. I can see how Park Tavern is the sister restaurant to Marlowe. The service was excellant and food was overall good, but was on the salty side. The chicken entree was perfectly cooked but almost inedible because it was so salty. I had the fish entree with quinoa, but again the quinoa was so salty that I had to eat it with this yogurt sauce. 

The two things I do recommend are the deviled eggs and brussel sprout chips.
author: Tif L.

description:
I had a meal of appetizers - bacon and figs, bone marrow and devolved eggs. All were delicious, and my personal favorite were the bacon n figs - a little salty, a little sweet, the yummy fat & chewy bite of bacon coupled with the subtle crunch of the fig seeds. I actually got really full from my "appetizer meal" and couldn't get myself to finish the last bite of crostini and rich bone marrow n acidy salsa verde.

Husband/date got the burger and was impressed. I had a bite and the patty was juicy and flavorful. Like another reviewer noted, it seems like a small sandwich, but the burger itself was hearty.

I thought the service here was perfect. We were seated promptly according to our reservation time on a Saturday night. Staff was friendly and professional, and though we had more than one person help us, they really worked as a team; never an empty glass of water and the recommendation of the deviled egg was on-point. Can't wait to come back.
author: Angelica T.

description: Marlowe has always been amazing not only on food but also in service. Even back when they were in their old address on Townsend St. We walked in and had reservations for 2 but had some last minute changes and the host accommodated us and made us feel welcome. They are usually quite busy and you can easily see why. I highly recommend this restaurant, highly recommend getting reservations.
author: Francis A.

description:
I was able to make a same-day reservation for two via OpenTable--SWEET! We arrived on time and were promptly seated. What I immediately noticed and liked about Marlowe was how low-key it looked. It was in a very quiet part of SOMA and I felt like I was going to a secret location for dinner. Another observation I had made, was that the restaurant was really small. The mirror on the back wall really gave me the illusion that the restaurant was much larger. Even though our table was sandwiched between two other tables, with about two inches of space in between, we still felt cozy and at ease. Lights were dimmed, giving it a very warm and intimate ambiance. Wooden chairs and tables gave it a very rustic feel. I really have no complaints about the overall environment and decor--it was nice!

Well anyway, let's get onto the food. We ordered the brussels sprout chips, Marlowe burger, and grilled Niman pork chops. I really liked that our waitress gave us the option to share our food. Our burger came, cut in half, and on two separate plates! The pork chop also came out, cut in half. They were so accommodating and thoughtful! 

We ate the brussels sprout chips with our hands. I've never had anything like it. The chips were a little on the salty side, but tasted great. There was a hint of broccoli aftertaste, so I assume they fried the brussels sprout with broccoli or broccoli oil. The hint of lemon was a refreshing addition to the very salty sea salt! It was definitely a fun snack. 

The pork chop was just okay. It just wasn't as succulent and tender as other chops that I have tasted. I did love the ricotta bread pudding though, it was so comforting and delicious.

The best part of the meal, however, was the Marlowe burger! It was the most amazing and most well prepared burger that I have ever tasted! No joke, no sensationalism going on here! The combination of cheddar, bacon, caramelized onions, and perfectly medium rare beef melted in my mouth with every bite. The horseradish aioli added a great kick and the fries were amazing! I really wish I had the burger to myself. Why did I have to share?! 

Prices are fair, granted the location, and customer service was excellent. The Marlowe burger was a whopping $13, but it was so worth it! I will have to find some time to come back!
author: Lien T.

description:
SF Chronicle had named Marlowe the best burger in SF.....I had to see it to believe it.

Plus, I was very late in trying this place since I was already hearing great things about their deviled eggs and brussel sprout chips.  

So thankfully, someone organized a birthday dinner here and gave me the perfect reason to go.  However, I'd advise against large parties over 6 since the venue is quite small and intimate(not a bad thing, but don't roll through with 10+ heads expecting a good time).  They also do make good use of the space and I think with people seated, its rather comfortable with good lighting and great industrial feel decor.

While I was waiting for the rest of the party to arrive, I got to try some of the beers they had, which were a good selection.  Unfortunately, nothing on tap, and its all bottled.  No hard liquor either, just beer and wine.

I ended up having a San Diego IPA (I think I've had before, but its your typical California IPA with a good hop) and something out of the norm, a Czech Republic dark lager which tasted like there was a choclatey aftertaste.  Definitely liked!

At the demand of the birthday girl, we had somewhat of a family style on the appetizers, and doubled up on the deviled eggs.....excellent call.

-Brussel Sprout Chips - amazing.  Well worth the hype.  Crispy yet light salt and buttery coat
-Deviled Eggs - these were divine.  Great flavor, and spices to make it stand out from your typical deviled eggs.
-Mussels and Calamari Spread - interesting and tasted good
-Crab Louie Spread over lettuce - delicious
-Steak - cooked in buttery goodness.
-THE Burger - this was fairly good.  With the aoili sauce it was a nice touch and the fries were amazing.  I did enjoy it, but I wouldn't put it up to the hype and with the joints like Roam or the burger at other places like NOPA, it doesn't get too far ahead of these.  But nonetheless, it doesn't disappoint and I'd definitely come back to indulge on the other dishes.
author: Vincent K.

description: The only time in my dining history that I was asked to leave the table to make room for the next reservation. That's shameful, especially when you paid big bucks for some sub par food (i.e. burger, polenta, duo of ahi tuna).
author: Matt L.

description:
Service - 7 stars
Food - 4.5 stars
Ambiance and overall experience - 5 stars

One of my favorite things about coming here is the hostess (maybe she's also the manager).  She's awesome! The first time we went to Marlowe I brought my Netflix to drop into a mailbox on our walk over but when we ended up at Marlowe I completely forgot I even had the movie in my hand.  The woman asked me what we were watching tonight, I was completely confused until I looked down to find my bright red envelop still in my hands. She offered to walk it to the mailbox down the block. I insisted that it was alright but she insisted that she needed some air.  Anyhow...back to the food.

I have yet to try the burger even though everyone raves about it and a friend of ours swears their polenta is the best polenta EVER.  The reason I have yet to try these two other highly recommended dishes is because I"m absolutely in love with their Stuffed Sole - stuffed with blue crab, baby turnips and a bit of heaven. The dish is surprisingly light. You feel completely satisfied but not heavy after the meal.

Their service is so awesome - we ordered the roasted bone marrow as an appetizer, we hadn't been waiting long for it but the hostess lady came to our table and apologized for the delay. She explained the first bone they roasted didn't meet their standards so they were preparing another for us and that it would be a few minutes longer and she was going to comp the app!  She totally didn't have to do that but it says a lot.

You can always count on Marlowe.
author: Becca L.

description:
What a gorgeous hidden neighborhood gem! 

Have been meaning to try this restaurant for ages...but seriously had heard so much about the burger that I didnt really know the restaurant had other amazing dishes to offer. Was I wrong! The food was delicious! 

The ambiance of the restaurant is warm and inviting....definitely smaller than I had imagined but really quaint and cosy. I would have loved to start off with a cocktail but there was only one on offer and at $12 I passed. 

We started with the brussel sprout chips - which weren't as wow as some other yelpers had written about. The bone marrow was tasty & the chicory salad was wow! 

The Poulet Vert was so moist and tender with an incredible jus - just the right amount.....and we're not really chicken lovers! 

The Chocolate cream pie was the perfect amount to share..and again was not what we expected....but at this restaurant it is above and beyond! A really fantastic dining experience tucked away down by the Caltrain at 4th & King.
author: Nicole E.

description: Excellent Pork chops. The steak was cooked to perfection. Appetizers and bites were equally top notch. The smoked flavor of the cod was excellent and moist. Coffee and chocolate at dessert rounded out the meal. Modern wine list
author: Dan W.

description:
Really really really great place.  I go here at least twice a month.  Marlowe is consistently good.  I've never been disappointed.  Items that are spectacular:

Deviled eggs - sinful.  I honestly think the best in the city
Brussel sprout chips - sometimes to lemony for me, but still excellent
Burrata - perfect consistency and served with bread and tomato compote
Burger (medium rare) - One of, if not my absolute favorite in the city.  Great toppings, perfect fries, cooked to perfection.  

I've also had the bone marrow, the chicken, and a variety of other entrees and they've all been great.  Though I have to say, when I go I tend to order a variety of apps and split the burger ;-)

In addition they've got a great wine list and the bartender/bar server is awesome!  Take his advice on food and wine!
author: Jennifer C.

description: The food was good, but the waitress with glasses and ponytail was very, very unfriendly. It was very humiliating. As if she hates her job, or she hates me. She stared at me after I said: I'm waiting for my friend so I don't need anything now. She stared at me with humiliation after my friend wanting to keep the glass coke bottle. She grabbed my credit card in a very rude way from my hand.
author: Wenxin Z.

description:
The morning after and my mouth will water on queue when I recall the savory bread pudding I had for lunch yesterday at Marlowe. We were told it is a new addition to the menu, and it is definitely a keeper. 

It is a vegetable bread pudding, lightly sauteed to make it a bit crispy and served up with thinly shaved ham, grilled asparagus and arugula. I am not sure what exactly is happening to deliver such incredible flavor, but a bite of this pudding, with a bit of ham and a leaf of arugula may have caused me to moan a little! It is truly a masterpiece of comfort food. 

And, you must try the brussels sprout chips! Call me crazy, but they are a superior french fry, crispy, ciitrusy and good for you too!

The space is cozy like a worn yet sophisticated farm house. The service is friendly, especially given that she recommended the bread pudding.

I hope I will have an excuse to return soon! 

P.S. Marlowe, you are always welcome to move to Vegas!
author: Misti Y.

description:
Awesome neighborhood restaurant!  Service is excellent.  The ambiance is nice... the space is cozy and dimly lit, but feels casual at the same time.
Only wish it were easier to get in, and that the menu had more variety.

Stand-out dishes:
+ Grilled Niman Ranch Pork Chop: juicy, tasty, cooked to perfection.  

+ Marlowe Burger with caramelized onions, cheddar, bacon: it's meaty, it's sweet, it's salty, it's crunchy, it's cheesy.  This is no ordinary burger!  The fries are great too!

+ Anson Mills Polenta: at first glance, it's easy to pass over this dish on the menu.  Who wants a plate of mushy polenta as a main course?  But the mushrooms and the poached egg lend such a rich depth to this dish, that it's worth going vegetarian for once.  

+ Roasted Bone Marrow: enough said.

Could be better:
- Brussels Sprout Chips: sounds great, and the first few bites are good.  But very soon, you realize they are way too greasy.  

- Brown Butter Brussels Sprouts: I am a big fan of brussels sprouts, but these look very anemic because they had stripped all the outer leaves for the chips, so all you get is the core.


The menu is not huge and does not change that much.  I wouldn't want them to switch out any of the awesome dishes listed above, but would be nice to see more variety.  That would make me come back more often!
author: Thomas L.

description:
I can't front: I am still thinking about this daggone burger four days later.  I want it.  I want it bad.  And now, as I write this review, I am sad because it is a good 2,820 miles away.  In a moment of weakness, I looked it up, convinced that a three or four-day drive would be worth it.
The patty was thick, juicy, and at medium-well, just the way I like it.  The bread was light enough but firm enough to support the beefy burger and the cheese was a melty provolone.  Writing it now, I know this sounds like just a normal good burger, but it was anything but.  You have to taste it to believe it.  Words do not describe this heaven on a bun.  Seriously!
I ordered it with the fries, which were crispy and not oily (perfect!) and ordered a glass of the Rosé.
Marlowe is very small and unassuming with a menu a lot more glamorous than burgers (even though that is what caught my eye).  It's a non-pretentious little gem that is definitely a must-visit when you are in San Francisco.  If you actually DO live in San Francisco and you haven't been there yet, you are wasting precious time.  GO NOW.  Order the burger.  Think of me.  In fact, dedicate one of your bites to me.  I'll know ;)
author: Elsa M.

description: Exceptional service and food!  Truly a five star experience. We needed a to go order at the last minute for four dinners and the receptionist and manager were awesome. Literally what ever we needed was prepared.  Oh, and the food simply the best!   As a native San Franciscan, Marlowe represents the best of our city!
author: Andrew D.

description:
I really did enjoy the food here but my experience wasn't the best. We came with a party of 11 with reservations on a Saturday night and it wasn't too busy. We checked out some other yelp reviews and wanted to get the bone marrow and our party noticed that other people were ordering it so it probably wasn't on the menu. We requested the bone marrow and the waitress told us that since we're in a large party, we get a limited menu which excluded all of the best stuff - the bone marrow, scallops, duck liver, cod, and probably more. I found it really frustrating. So if 5 parties of 2 showed up, they would get a regular menu but in a party of 11, we don't? That's totally not okay. 
Aside from that I had the burger, super tasty and the fries reminded me of the old burger king fries which I really liked. It is really rich and fattening but it was enjoyable. I would also recommend the baked cauliflower, it was deliciously cheesy!
Then the bill comes along with a mandatory 20% gratuity and on top of that there is a required sales tax on gratuity. Basically we had a bill of like $360, add the sales tax, then add gratuity, then add sales tax again and the total was about $470. What???

To top it off, where you sign off on your credit card, there was a little spot for "additional gratuity". That's laughable. 

My recommendation to you is, don't come with a party larger than 5.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Great menu, ambience and service - highly recommended for a small group of foodie friends or maybe a date. Make a booking though!

I had the delicious ahi salad and my friends had the wild mushrooms and polenta; something with buffalo mozzarella and levain (some kind of artisan toasted bread); and the burger. It all looked delicious and it was! Desserts were great too.
author: Rob K.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for dinner on a Monday night, and we liked it a lot. Cute little place in SOMA right across from the train station. Overall - staff service was attentive, food was well prepared (portions are decent), ambiance is a little yuppy (which I dig). You must make reservations in advance. For appetizer, we ordered the warm deviled eggs. For our mains, we ordered the cod and the hamburger. 

For a Monday night dinner, I couldn't have asked for more. It was good. I'll be back for sure.
author: Beeta O.

description: Had the Marlowe burger and their special drink of the night. The burger was very juicy but salty and I'm accustomed to eating saltier food. The drink was refreshing, sparkling wine and grapefruit, nice mix. My friend had the rock cod which was tasty and cooked to our liking. It's a small place and everyone raves about the burgers so I'm going to give it one more try.
author: Minh H.

description:
I really wanted to give Marlowe 4.5 stars, but since I couldn't, they are now a 4 star review.

I dined here a couple of weeks ago with two of my friends for a belated birthday dinner for me. I had made the reservations 4 days before and all I found was a 9:45pm. I was a bit unhappy with the time, but a colleague of mine said to just take it and that it's worth it. So I took it and learned that you SHOULD get a reservation before coming here to avoid the long wait. 

The reservationist called the day of and confirmed my reservation. I asked for an earlier time and they said they'll call me back if something earlier cancels. Fifteen minutes later, I get a call for a 7:45pm! I was so happy so that's one star for them!

When we got there, the seating hostess greeted us and showed us to our table. One downside to Marlowe is that it's a small restaurant so the tables are all close to each other, enough where you can listen to their conversation. We started with some wine that I brought and some brussel sprout chips. It was nice that corkage was only $20, and they waive the fee if you buy from their list (FYI).

So let me talk about the food:

Brussel Sprout Chips: delicious! Great snack if you're health conscious. But then again, its coated with sea salt, oil (might be olive, not sture), and a hint of lemon zest. Ask the server how they make it and they'll be more than happy to tell you!

Mussels and Calamari w/ toasts: it was a bit salty, but then again it was completely different from what I expected. The calamari was not your typical breaded calamari. But overall it was a great starter.

Dungeness Crab Souffle: yummy! It was nice and fluffy, almost quiche like. I could probably eat this every day.

Marlowe Burger: everyone on Yelp raved about the burger so I had to try it. It was definitely a great burger, but there wasn't anything about it that is like OMG I HAVE TO HAVE THIS DROOOOOL type of thing. I got mine medium rare, but personally it was a little too rare. I really liked the fries. It was the right crunch and the right amount of potatoes inside. Don't get me wrong, the burger was great, just not OMG great. 

We also had two desserts, but I forgot what they  were called. One was with panna cotta and coffee and one was the chocolate creme pot. Both were great, I personally liked the chocolate one just cause I love chocolate and I like the texture of the cocoa nibs contrasting the smooth, velvety feel of the chocolate creme. I also enjoyed the panna cotta, but I'm a chocolate girl ya know?

I would have given Marlowe 5 stars, but one thing that kind of bugged me was our server. The service was great and everyone was more than willing to help you but our main server was kind of rude. When he gave us the menu, five minutes later he came back and asked if we had any questions. I felt he didn't take the time to engage with us and make us feel welcome. Another thing was when I asked if he can take a picture of my friends and I. He took one with my camera and then my friend asked if he can take one with his iPhone. The server sighed and said "Really? You already have one on her camera."  I know he was probably trying to be funny, but it just seemed kind of rude. 

Anyway, I'll definitely try Marlowe again especially that their chicken burger is one of 100 things on 7x7's Big Eats 2012.
author: Danna D.

description: This is a really good restaurant, the food and workers are very nice and respectful.
author: Cassandra B.

description: Marlowe is hands down my favorite restaurant in SF.  There are a ton of highly rated and reviewed restaurants that just don't live up to the hype.  Ordered the crispy brussel sprouts, steak tartare, deviled eggs, black cod, and bone marrow.  Bone marrow was so good that we ordered a second one.  Their specialty drinks were delicious, I tried an old favorite with gin, but can't recall the name.  I really like the ambiance, it was nice, but not overly pretentious.  Great date place, would totally recommend.
author: Andrew M.

description:
The roasted bone marrow... was fantastic!  with just the right amount of toast points to go with it.  the little spread distributed the fresh herb and sour salty caper goodness well amongst the melt-in-your mouth richness of the marrow spread on my toast points.  

the burger was, frankly, disappointing.  I expected a NOPA level work of art... but instead, the burger was just a little warm.  the bun was baked from scratch, toasted, and COLD.  the whole thing was kinda... flat and cold on my plate.  Meat texture was OK, but a bit grainy, not dripping with hot juices like I prefer.

My friend (vegetarian), got the brown butter brussels sprouts.  WIth a name like that I would expect some awesome brussels sprouts.  These were overcooked little hearts of brussels sprouts, completely soggy and soaked in butter.  This is clearly what they did with the leftovers from their famous brussels sprouts chips.

So much potential... honestly I went here last year, but didn't finish my review til now.  I'll give them another chance probably this year sometime.
author: Fong L.

description:
I GOT FOOD POISONING from the steak tartare! do not eat that here! besides it was WAY too salty. 

the Brussel sprout chips and baked oysters were delish though.

unfortunately, since i was sick from the raw steak, for a whole 10 days, i wont be coming back.
author: Kristine T.

description: Seeing how crowded the place is, i was curious to see if it is worth the wait. As I looked around, it seemed that the burgers were the choice item. Grabbing a burger from them, I would have to say it was nothing special. It was average, the bone marrow on the other hand is the reason for the 3 stars, it was worth trying. It was really good. I would say if there isn't a wait stop on by, but if there is a wait just keep walking.
author: Sasan J.

description: Starters and entree's were delicious and flavorful. The wine we had was great as well and not too bad for the price. I would definitely visit Marlowe again.
author: Cheryl J.

description:
Great service and atmosphere/aura. The restaurant isn't very big, and the only two seating options were a communal table with a large pole coming down from the ceiling separating the view of the seat across the table or at the bar...we chose the bar. 

Took a while for our food to arrive. We ordered the ahi tuna appetizer, which was fresh, light and delicious. really great sauce and vegetables accompanying it and it was nicely seasoned with salt. Ordered the salmon as an entree...It was underwhelming and disappointing, and did not have very much flavor, natural or otherwise. It could have been seasoned better. It came with a cou cous type medley which was flavorful, grilled eggplant which was amazing and some type of cucumber salad which was tasty. Overall, the entree was good because of the eggplant. I would not order it again otherwise. My date had the steak and fries, and said it was decent. Overall, I would go back because the prices aren't terribly high, the aura is nice and the service is friendly. Try to make reservations.
author: Ronnie S.

description:
Came here to meet up with a girlfriend. I have driven by this place many times and somehow never noticed it. I know I sound like a broken record, but you should make a reservation or be prepared to drink at the bar and wait. This place can get pretty nuts after work, especially with all the foot traffic from the Cal-Train station and surrounding office buildings.

Everything we had was super delicious. We started with their crispy brussels sprout chips which every table had also ordered. They were a bit on the greasy side, but perfectly seasoned. My friend and I both opted for the Marlowe burger, except I had mine without bacon. This burger was moist and hearty and the fries were a perfect compliment. Their fries are really good.

We looked over their dessert menu and ordered their TCHO Chocolate Cream Pie. It sounded like s'mores. Although we were both super stuffed, I had to try this. I love TCHO chocolate and this just sounded too good to pass up. This was off the charts good. 

I will definitely be back here. Good eats all around.
author: Caroline L.

description:
I took out of town guests here because I didn't think Marlowe would disappoint.  I was correct in my deduction.

The hamburger and steak dish were mediocre.  There have been other occasions where they have excelled in their perparation.  Not that evening though.

The standout dish was the porkchops.  They were the highlight of our meal.  Along with the respectable wine list.

Guess I know what I'll be ordering the next time I stop by.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
I've been to plenty of restaurants in the city that I truly believed were delicious.  I'd walk out thinking "that was really good".  But Marlowe is one of those places that I can actually remember every single bite I took of my meal.  It was THAT amazing.

First off, they have THE BEST brussel sprouts anywhere.  Period.  They actually peel away each "leaf" and make them into these crispy chips.  Wow, I could have had 3 orders just for myself. 

Also, if you are a fried chicken lover, their fried chicken sandwich is, yup, THE BEST in the city.  Ridiculously moist and juicy on the inside and perfectly crispy on the outside.  I wish I could have had 3-5 more bites. 

Lastly, for that perfect one bite, their baked oysters are phenomenal.  *sigh* Flavorful and just right. 

My entire party enjoyed everything they ordered.  And really, how can you go wrong with that?

Enjoy!
author: Susan L.

description: Pretty good hipster haunt. Nice service for a place that seems to always be slammed at the dinner rush. Deviled eggs were really unique with a creative use of sliced jalapeño pepper and bacon. Had the famous house burger which was really unimpressive. I can see how this burger (done right) could be really great but mine featured over cooked meat, a burnt bun and one sad little piece of bacon. Felt like botched execution of a burger that could have been much better.
author: A G.

description:
I'd been intrigued by Marlowe ever since I walked by and read the cheeky meat-loving quotes outside, and just took a friend there for Dine About Town. Was not disappointed!

Mushroom soup was fantastic--savory, salty, creamy, almost certainly terrible for me. Couldn't eat it fast enough. Burger was stupidly decadent--I finished about a third of it--but delicious, with the horseradish aioli being my favorite part (it was awesome on the fries, too). My companion raved about the little gem salad and egg sandwich, but I'll leave that for her to review.

Overall a great DAT lunch spot, but a bit on the pricey side for a regular day, and busy--get reservations if you don't want to wind up turned away.
author: Connor Skye R.

description: Went there at 11 PM for a late dinner with my bf, we ordered devilled eggs, salmon crudo, some chicken main dish and a side of baked cauliflower. I love everything here; the food, the service, and the ambience. The only thing I hate about going to this restaurant is finding parking especially during the game, I would say. But all in all, it's worth it.
author: Joelle K.

description:
After tons of recommendations, we finally got a walk in spot at Marlowe last Friday night. We were squeezed onto the end of the bar thanks to the hostess that managed to find a spot for us. 

We ordered a couple of beers and brussel sprout chips to begin. I loved the chips but my husband thought they still tasted too brussel sprout-y. They got a bit too oily by the end but I still ate them all! 

Because everyone rants and raves about Marlowe's burger- we both ordered them since we were both craving junkfood. Our burgers were cooked perfectly, the fries were good but there was nothing SPECIAL about it.. pretty standard actually. Didn't love the horseradish overpowering a lot of the dish but for $13 it is a good value.
author: Seema M.

description:
As a foodie wannabe (or poser, whichever you wanna call it) with a champagne taste and a beer budget in Sydney means that a visit to any of Luke Mangan's restaurant was nothing more than an obsession.  A meal at previous restaurant in this space, South Food and Wine Bar, would have been the perfect opportunity to finally break that spell.  Unfortunately it shut before I had a chance to (I blame the gazillion other awesome restaurants in SF), and along came Marlowe.

It still took me almost a year before I finally set foot there.  

Not only that - I've also had enough of hearing friends raving about the infamous brussel sprouts chips.  Seriously? My memories of brussel sprouts is one of mild repulsion - it's only served once a year during the fam's christmas lunch for a good reason: neither my brother nor I would touch them (and oh, it's also not fun eating such a heavy christmas meal with turkey, gravy, ham and mashed potatoes when it's 90 degrees and sunny outside).  

But I had to make an exception on this one - sure, it still tastes very brussel-sprout-y (i.e., mildly bitter), but it was super crunchy with random burnt bits, and the salt and lemon did make all the difference.  So I found myself ordering a second helping of these surprisingly tasty nibblies.

Next, the Marlowe Burger.  On top of friends' major raves, I've also seen it featured in any articles that talk about SF's best burgers.  Again, collective intelligence works wonder.  It definitely is one of the best burgers I've had: plump juicy patty, awesome fries (try putting a few just under the crown and eat them together with the burger), caramelized onions and horseradish aioli.  I ate all the  900+ calories of it. 

And as if the caloric holocaust caused by the burger wasn't enough, I had to also have the TCHO chocolate cream pie - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c0WpyZFR3EoEBKcoY2LZ3Q?select=YP4vpJZlwS0L18WWLVhuCg - having sea salt as one of the ingredients, as I learned from a recent visit to the Culinary Institute of America in St. Helena, is a brilliant idea as it opens up the taste buds so the sweet from the chocolate becomes more intense.   

From now on Marlowe will be my Soma's dining destination of choice.  Now if only it didn't cost $20 to park on game day!!!!!!! )(@!*#%!)@#@_(!@%*@#*()@$*%^%^%#%&%^$&
author: Ange L.

description:
This place is soooo close to a  5-star rating in my book. Let's start with the negatives: the fries were pretty good, but Nopa was a bit better. Kinda loud environment too... But everything else was great!
The burger is definitely in the top 3 I've ever eaten in the city. Wine and beer selection was superb. Service was very kind and attentive. Can't believe I'm saying this, but the polenta main course was somewhat more memorable that my burger, i liked it a lot!  It was like eating 6 different flavors at once, and rich in texture. Again, i'd never say this but i'd prefer the polenta dish next time, it was THAT good...
author: Ethan L.

description:
Brought the family that was visiting from the UK and took out our 3 week old baby for our first night outing.  The staff was extremely accommodating to our party of 6.  The food was delish, I had the Steak Tar Tar for app, and Pork chops for main.  Everything was made to perfection.  My man had the Bone marrow (he absolutely loved it) and the polenta for main, which was good but not great.  

If you have a large party I would reco for you to make reservations as we made an early reservation for 6pm and when we arrived the place was rammed already.  

I will definitely return!
author: Kelli M.

description: These guys have great staff and great food. My experiences have only ever ranged from "delicious" to "delicious and awesome"
author: Cassio P.

description:
This place is small and intimate. Reservations are highly recommended due to limited seating. 

Food is very fresh and non-commercial. Burger was voted best in town/city recently, so I was compelled to order it and it completely met my expectations. Great meat and amazing sauce put in the burger. 

I also had their steak tartar which was also very good, flavorful and with a nice touch of vinegar. 

Large variety of bottled beer of all sorts, except commercial. It would be nice if the prices were a bit cheaper, but definitely worth the price.

I would definitely return here and recommend it highly.
author: O M.

description: The food was great. I had the New York Steak $30 and my husband had the Marlowe burger $16. We also had a flatbread $6 with different sauces which was really good. And we had the calamari which was about $12 I think, it was a little small but delicious. The place is clean and they have great customer service.
author: Elvira M.

description: One of the best burgers I've ever had. Very cool atmosphere and very attentive service. The quality of the meat is outstanding. Creekstone meat for the win! I'll definitely be back!
author: Erhan A.

description: Decent food cool space. I miss Coco 500. The food was ok they have some cool bartenders but it wasn't on par with Coco 500, the food was definitely on point at Coco 500.
author: Beddaden B.

description:
Tried  

1. bone marrow
2. Marlowe burger 
3. clams&calamari pot. 
4. Panna cotta 

Everything was very tasty! Bone marrow was a tad bit oily. I kept having to wipe my lips to prevent the grease from dripping down my chin. But it's bone marrow, so my carnivorous fatass cannot complain all that much.

The fries which came with the burger were amazing! Perfectly crisp on the outside and soft on the inside. 

When they say clam and calamari "pot," they actually mean a tiny little glass jar filled with chopped goodies which you top onto a crostini. (more of an appetizer - don't make my mistake and expect a large steaming pot of clams) 

Panna cotta was lovely - especially the bit of coffee flavor on top!

Best part was it's walking distance my from my sister's pad.
author: Jade C.

description:
i decided to come to Marlowe for a casual friday night dinner with a friend after hearing rave reviews about the place. First impression was the great service since I had a 10pm reservation online through open table but decided it was way too late, so I called in to see if there was an earlier time and managed to get one at 8:30pm which is perfect. 

Food-wise, we had to go with the brussel sprout chips for appetizer. Honestly, it does live up to its craze. The brussel sprout were peeled leaf by leaf and fried till crispy perfection, seasoned with sea salt and lemon zest. I really wished I had these in abundance at home so I can munch on them all the time without feeling guilty. We also had the bone marrow with salsa verde served with grilled baguettes. It was spectacular, in a sense, much better than the bone marrow appetizer I had at Morimoto. Bone marrow gets really rich after some bites but the salsa verde cuts through the fattiness really well and balances out the flavors. 

Main courses: I had the dungeness crab stuffed sole that was served with a shaved fennel salad. My friend had the special which was a crab and shrimp louie served with lettuce wrap, sea salt and hot sauce. The sole was really filling, wished it had a bit more acidity to it. The louie was a fun, hands-on dish as you get to wrap the mixture in the lettuce wrap yourself and add in salt/hot sauce. We also had our dinner with their cocktail specials which all had very interesting names but were also very very thirst-quenching. 

Overall, I enjoyed my dinner. Great, casual atmosphere. The menu selection was limited so it's not somewhere I would want to go to once a month, but definitely from time to time with friends.
author: Kelly C.

description: After reading about Marlowe's burger I decided to take my husband here (I'm a vegetarian but a foodie who gets some kind of sick pleasure out of my husband eating the "Best Of' meat dishes the city has to offer). I started my meal with a burrata salad with tomato marmalade and grilled baguette. The baguette was a little burned but the dish was still excellent. For my meal I just had a bowl of mushroom soup-- very good but nothing mind blowing. My husband, on the other hand, was indeed blown away by the burger. He pointed out that oftentimes places overdo the burger by making a huge patty that just makes a giant mess when you're trying to eat it. Theirs was carefully proportioned with thoughtfully balanced flavors. I would certainly  not be disappointed if I ended up back here for dinner one night.
author: Kathryn M.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in SF because their food is always amazing and their service is excellent!
