I had the burger and artichoke soup.  Both were delicious and well paired.  The burger came with a simple mixed greens salad dressed with olive oil and some delicious salt.  The soup was topped with hazelnut oil, cream fraiche and some crisped onion maybe... to die for.

The food at Marlowe is 5.  

The service we had was ... eh ok... I mean she didn't screw up our order, but she wasn't exactly friendly and it seemed like we were inconveniencing her.  I mean I know we were there for Dine About Town doing a prix fixe, but the difference in cost from the a la carte and the savings was about $2-3 for the entire meal... so it's not like she wasn't going to get a tip.  I'll give her the benefit of the doubt that it was during lunch rush and the place was hoppin'......

Anyways, the food was amazing and I'll definitely be back, just hope the server will smile next time.
author: J P.

description:
We had reservations at 7:30, but we weren't seated until about 20 min past. So why am I giving them 5 stars?? Because they definitely know how to treat their customers well. They gave us champagne for being so patient! woot wooot!! Bubbly while you wait? YES PLEASE!!

Now on to the food:

Bone Marrow appetizer: Flavorful, but very oily. I liked the salsa verde sauce & cilantro that went with it, but the bone marrow was a bit hard to scoop out. Parts of it definitely stick to the bone

Sole Stuffed w/Crab: Delicious! It's light but oh so good!

Grilled Porkchop w/ Parmesan Dumplings: Loved it. And I especially love the smokiness from the grill. Definitely had a strong scent to it since I think there was some type of vinegar w/ the apples, but still really good. Loved the dumplings too!

Upside Down Pear Crisp: originally I wanted the lemon souffle, but the table next to us thought it was a bit to tangy, so then I wanted the TCHO chocolate cream pie, but they had JUST ran out. sadface. So we ordered the pear crisp and it did not disappoint! I love that they come in little jars so it's more like a broken down version of whats listed on the menu. With the bourbon ice cream and caramel sauce...I could eat another one just thinking about it!

TIP: make a reservation on open table since the place isn't huge and it gets packed!
author: Kristen C.

description:
More like a solid 3.5 stars, I would give this place a 4 stars if it is more memorable.

This is a busy place, the whole space is quite small but very beautifully put together.

Burger is fantastic, service is good. 

Everything is good, but nothing stands out.
author: Alice C.

description:
Glad that I made a reservation! And I'm even more happy that I picked this restaurant! I knew from the minute I arrived that this was the restaurant for me. Right outside on the window are quotations from chefs and the best one was "VEGANS NOT WELCOME HERE." At last I am at home.

My homegirl and I took a look at the menu and we were immediately excited and ordered up a storm: bone marrow, brussels sprouts chips, and the paté (special) just to start. And we ate it all. (Especially because I just came off the plane from LA and purposely starved myself for dinner.)

I know that I'm going against the grain, but I wasn't really into the brussels spouts chips. If anything, it reminded me of fried seaweed sheets (the ones you can purchase from the Korean market). :\ But the bone marrow and the paté? DAMN GOOD. The paté really made my night; it was served with two condiment/sauces: a mustard seed sweet-n-sour and a cherry chutney 'dressings'. 

Now for the best part - my entree: polenta with mushrooms and arugula. ALSO DAMN GOOD. Rich and flavorful. Hmmm. 

My homegirl got the burger and it looked just as delicious my meal. The burger reminded me of something from Father's Office (for any LA-ites out there). WINNERS ALL AROUND!

My SF peoples, you guys are so lucky to have this really awesome restaurant. I sometimes regret not taking that job in San Jose so I can come up to eat Marlowe's more frequently.
author: Jody Y.

description: Service here is excellent and wine knowledge very good. However, food was over priced and too rich. Overall, sweet atmosphere and not cramped for the lack of room.  Will definitely go back and may revise the review with a different food order.
author: Kelly M.

description:
I am a frequent traveler to SF and always try to seek out new places to eat. I didn't book well in advance, but I got a 9pm reservation for Thursday Jan 20th. When we showed up to this tiny place, it was still packed. Unfortunately, the bar was full. so there was nowhere really to get a drink. This was my biggest minus for Marlowe. Inside the interior was very well done, butcher shop meats renovated factory.

Now onto the food. We started with the brussel sprout chips, which were really interestingly done, not at all what I had expected. I think that these must be fairly difficult to make. Portion size could have been a bit larger, but good for 2 people.

For my appetizer, I ordered the Steak Tartare, which was excellent. The poached egg was fresh and I was asked to crack it to prevent further cooking. The overall dish had a bit of a kick to it, so I was pleasantly surprised by the spice, but I wouldn't label it CLASSIC. I paired this with a GSM blend from Unti in Sonoma, CA. One of my favorite value wineries and was very happy to see it by the glass on this list.

Onto the main course, I decided to go with the Stuffed Blue Sole after having red meat for my starter. The sole was cooked to perfection, I hate when places over cook fish, I realize this becomes more complex when you stuff it. The combination of flavors was excellent, salty and sour. The texture from the sole, crab, celery root, and fennel were wonderful and well integrated. I paired this with a glass of Pinot Noir from Corkscrew in Sonoma, CA. This was recommended by the waiter, he said that this was essentially declassified wine from another good vineyard and that this 2007 vintage was a great value. I happen to agree on the Price:Quality ratio. No room for dessert, the sign of a great meal, but I was tempted with a glass of Monbazillac, the poor man's Sauternes, as I like to call it. 

Overall Marlowe was a great experience and I will be going back there on my next trip to SF. It's casual, a good small menu that is very well executed. The wine list was better in terms of bottle selection, but they had a few interesting by the glass wines to let people experiment.
author: Robert V.

description: Great experience. We were there on valentine's with no Rez. The hostess was very accommodating. And food was delicious. We had the burger, cooked perfectly!  We also had poulet vert so juicy.  The bartender was fun. Overall a great experience.
author: Yvette B.

description:
Marlowe has easily become one of my go-to/never-fails/default/date-night restaurants. 

I came here for dinner and left completely satisfied with every dish we had. Everything on the menu sounded delicious, but here is what we ended up getting: 

- Little Gem Salad- so tasty, the ingredients were crisp and fresh and the dressing was well balanced
- Crab & Rock Shrimp Louie
- Marinated Mussels & Calamari w/ garlic aioli
- Brussel Sprout Chips- because you can't come here and NOT have this
- Roasted Bone Marrow- served with toasts...couldn't get enough
- Duck Liver Mousse
- Cauliflower Gratin- delicious...creamy, tasty, but not heavy...it's like magic! 
- Ny Steak
- Stuffed Sole

Overall an amazing dinner, and a nice intimate ambiance. I loved everything I had, and definitely planning on returning!
author: lauren j.

description:
Came here for dinner last night and the food was great. One star off for telling us that we can get seated early but actually seating us 45 minutes after our reservation time. 

We sat at the bar area for drinks while we waited. They had a special on this German Riesling. It was delicious! While we waited we had the crispy brussel sprouts chips. 

When we were finally seated, we had the baked oysters (heavy but good), and bone marrow (came with mashed capers and toast. yummy) for appetizers. I had the "poulet vert" and my friend had the steak frites. Both were delicious. Chicken wasn't dry at all and had great flavor. The steak was cooked perfectly and the french fries were nice and crispy.

Overall a great meal, I just wished they would've told us the real wait time. Also they switched the Riesling on me without telling me (they ran out). That was kinda odd, didn't they think that I would notice... We would've been happy just eating at the bar. I'd still come here again tho since it's a nice place in my hood.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
First I have to say "Thank you" to everyone who raved about the burger.   Among other dishes we tried tonight, the burger was in fact mighty good.  Yay!

We started off with the little gem salad.  A little different from how we've had it in other restaurants.  Usually you get the petite heads of lettuce you have to cut yourself (at least, that's how I've ever seen a little gem salad).  This one is basically lettuce leaves tossed with avocado and (what I believe) thinly sliced shallots and a yummy vinaigrette dressing.

Hubby ordered the burger, which was fantastic.  I had the steak frites, which was cooked to a perfect pink medium.  Both came with crispy fries.  We also ordered a side of the smoky cauliflower gratin.  Now THAT was delicious.  The cauliflower was not cooked to the point of mush.  It was still a little crunchy, and covered with provolon and cheddar cheese.  Hot, melting, gooey goodness.

As someone mentioned, the food here is on the salty side.  We ended up refilling on water several times through the meal.  Aside from that, everything was delicious. 

Glad to have another neighborhood restaurant to chose from.
author: Denise M.

description: I live nearby and frequent this place often. One time I came with no reservations but they fit us in quickly..so nice if them! Service is great and their bone marrow and brussel sprouts are really good. For take out it's got to be the Marlow burger, awesome fries with horseradish and mayo sauce... it's the yummiest :)
author: John N.

description: went in for a burger and was very satisfied with it and the appetizer we got. service was good but you should try to get a reservation, although we managed to walk in.
author: M S.

description: One of my favorite casual restaurants in the city.  The Marlowe burger is other worldly and the mixology here is some of the best in SF.  5 stars+
author: Isaac F.

description: Their blush sangria was amazing! Burger was good and would order again! Overall I see this place as a tapa vs. entree experience.  Order the Burata you will not be disappointed.
author: Callie O.

description:
3.5 stars. 

The interior is so San Franciscan. It's small, intimate, and hip. I say intimate because it was packed when B and I dropped in Friday night. Luckily a reservation for two hadn't shown up, so we got that table fairly quickly ('fairly' quickly because the table was cleared and set for us, but the hostess seemed to have forgotten us for 15 minutes, though I'm not sure she missed us, since the place is SO small)

We ordered one of each appetizer, and then the burger to share. 

The Baked Oysters - oysters and cheese baked into ooey gooey goodness? SO good. but they only had ONE left when we ordered, so we had half an oyster each. 

Steak Tartare - good! generous portions.

Roasted Bone Marrow - now, bone marrow is not a novel dish in a Chinese family, but it was cool that it was included in an American bistro's menu. The plate comes out with two gigantic bones cleaved in half, and a little spoon to scoop out the marrow onto toasted bread with a little salsa verde. I was a tad disappointed - the salsa overpowered the marrow, so it tasted like oily salsa verde on crunchy toast. But the chef did send us an extra plate, since sometimes the marrow groove is too shallow to get anything good.

Marlowe Burger was good, no complaints there. Also heaping pile of fries.
author: Julia C.

description:
I decided to bring my mom to this restaurant for her birthday.  My mommy likes food that is different and that is tasty- Marlowe delivers.  

Since I read the Yelp reviews, I knew it was a restaurant that basically required reservations.  I reserved the night before the dinner and the earliest time they had was 8:00.   

We wanted to eat earlier since we have some early risers in our family.  The hostess went out of her way to get us an earlier sitting, though it was at a smaller table.  

The food was lovely.  I especially like the shrimp =)  A brussel sprout will always be a brussel sprout so I wasn't too impressed with the dish that so many people raved about.  All the other food was tasty, original and satisfying.  Our family ordered almost everything beside the main entrees.
author: Aaron K.

description:
Convenient SOMA location, right near the CalTrain depot. Small, smart,
Euro/modern decor. Unfortunately, it's pretty noisy. First class employees--warm and welcoming hostess; knowledgeable, efficient server, good bus person. Small menu, but they do it well. Don't even think about going without a reservation!

Good marks to the Brussell sprout chips (but eat 'em while they're warm and crispy), the roasted pistacios, the savory bread pudding, the peach bourbon upside-down desert, and the special peach ice tea. 

We enjoyed it very much, but would have loved a somewhat quieter environment for ease of conversation.
author: Joanna S.

description:
A very interesting restaurant to try, came here on a weekday, definitely hard to find parking just because there was a Giants game going on. Reservation is recommended to be made if planning to eat during the usual dinner time, otherwise expect a wait time 30+mins.

Started the night with the Bone Marrow and the baked oysters. Full in flavor, a interesting must try bone marrow if you never had, its full in flavors and the compliments with it must be used for it to make the bone marrow taste a bit more interesting. The oysters was good, but it was full of dry bits of garnish that if you want to suck the whole oysters off the shell becareful not to choke on the dry garnish they had on the oysters, I almost did, was coughing for awhile. 

Ordered the fish, sort of bland, but it was a good size. The filet was a bit overcooked even though it was ordered as medium rare, but near the center it was more juicer and felt like it needed more full body taste to be satisfying. 

Overall its a nice place to try, located in SOMA few blocks from the stadium and across from Caltrain station.
author: Linh D.

description: Had an early dinner with hubby and kids there.  Services were wonderful (glasses were always filled, waitress was friendly). Ordered the New York steak, medium rare, and was not satisfied at all.  The meat was tough which is not contributed by the cooking but the quality of the beef.  Kids had burger and it was not better than the ones we had in four-star restaurants.  Hope the review will help improve the quality of the ingredients.
author: michelle l.

description:
Oh man. I get the hype, I really do, I just think that for this town Marlowe doesn't quite cut it.

It has a fun atmosphere, good service, and food that is just fine. The menu looks good (although a little on the heavy side) and features a fistful of 'in vogue' dishes (bone marrow, fried brussel sprouts, greasy burgers et al)

But for this town, it was only an OK. I've got a scores of places to check out before I'll be stopping back over.
author: Amanda F.

description: I came here after work one day and ordered the hamburger. OH. MY. GOD. Best hamburger I've ever had, hands down. The meat was cooked perfectly, the buns were toasty, and the horseradish aioli was delicious. It even had bacon in it!
author: H. L.

description:
Yummy, solid restaurant that more than makes up for the previous restaurant, South. 

The bone marrow is amazing and not for sharing (well, if you're a FFL like me...). I had my doubts about the burger and the roast chicken - could it REALLY be better than Nopa/Zuni?? Well....it was damn good. Really good. And the brussel sprouts were awesome!

Wonderful addition to the area and the SF dining scene. Notes for future diners: wine/beer/champagne cocktails only, tiny spot, resos highly recommended, order the burger/chicken and you'll be a happy foodie for the night.
author: Adrienne C.

description: Bone marrow was good and the burger was the best that I've had in awhile, in terms of trying something new.  A lot of recommended burgers didn't make the cut (like Zuni or Pearl's).  I would definitely come back.  The menu is not extensive, though.
author: Erika C.

description: It was really casual, but fancy at the same time. I had the warm rock something: it was a sandwich with shrimp, coleslaw, and such.
author: Milli F.

description: Great spot. A reservation appears to be mandatory, this place is packed. Cool, down to earth feel. The pork chop was tender, cooked to perfection and delicious. Reasonably priced for SF. We plan on making many return visits.
author: Jay D.

description:
We arrived at 7pm on a busy night, and the waitress made room for our party of 3 at the bar.

The champagne cocktail was delicious but not life changing, however the bartender was very knowledgable about wines and was fun to talk to.

Brussels sprouts chips were amaze, but the rest of the meal (beet salad and polenta were just as expected). 

Overall, great ambiance with wonderful staff.
author: Stacie C.

description: This place is expensive but good. Very friendly staff. Close to a Megabus stop. Brussel Sprout chips, cauliflower soup, chicken sandwich & burrata cheese were good. Bread was burned on burrata.
author: Christine G.

description:
Ok - so I have to say I'm not 100% sure that Marlowe deserves a full  4 stars. The reason I say that, is I felt that most of the dishes I had were a bit heavy on the salt quotient. But that could also be the fact that I rarely salt anything, and am somewhat sensitive to it if it's very "present" in a meal. 

That being said, the Burgers were cooked to utter perfection, the portions were fair sized without being either skimpy or way over the top. The staff were extremely courteous (and might I add CUTE), and they had a decent wine/cocktail program happening. 

They also let you offset corkage fees if you buy a bottle in-house off their list, so that's a nice little bonus if you're like me and my friends and like to bring in bottles of nice wine to a meal.

A simple and minimal menu really lets you focus on your meal, rather than plying you with so many options that you have a hard time making choices. 

Oh, and the desserts were nicely portioned, and very yummy - again, the dessert menu wasn't overburdened with options, which made picking one easy, and which seemingly allows their staff to focus on quality.

Since I work down the block from them, I think I'll be trying their lunch menu as well - Marlowe definitely warrants a second shot.
author: Marco M.

description:
It took my friend and I like a month to have the time to come here to try their burger so we were expecting it to be like an explosion of flavors in the mouth!

We had reservations at 1 and it took 5 minutes to seat us so that was pretty normal.  The hostess was very nice but it felt like she forgot about us until we asked her again about our table..

I had the artichoke soup for starters which was probably the best part of this lunch experience.  Hazelnut in my soup?  Sure why not.  I told my friend it tasted like gravy and she said "Coming from a Texan, that is probably a good thing"

We both ordered burgers (medium on both) and while it took a bit long to get us the meal, hers was completely drenched in grease while mine was fine (except for it being luke warm)

Burger was nice for me.  Friend though it could use a little salt but the I thought it was okay, maybe not worth trekking all the way there though..

I say try Pearls if you have a hankering for a delicious burger..
author: Chris H.

description: Nice upscale feel to such a small spot. The fried chicken sandwich was good, but nothing spectacular. Brussels sprout chips are a must try!
author: Brandon T.

description:
Lunch with the gals from the office - and thankful we had reservations as the place was packed.  Start with the Brussel sprouts chips - which were absolutely delicious - we even had two orders.

My friend and I split the Marlowe burger and the crab louie salad.  It was perfect for lunch portion.  My girlfriend had the ricotta dish and raved about it.  The service was attentive and the food came promptly.

The burger was perfectly cooked, and very tasty.  The meat is a great blend and full of flavor and juicy.  The salad came in a little pot, with baby romaine leaves, sea salt and Tabasco on the side.  Very nice.

We finished our meal with the peach crisp.  Unbelievable!!!  I would go back for that alone.

Very nice and worth a repeat visit.
author: Sallye M.

description:
Heard all about the burger and fries, supposed to be the BEST in San Francisco.  HOME RUN! Get it, don't mess with how it's served (Medium Rare) wow yum, mmmmmmmm. And the spicy aoli with the amazing crispy french fries...mouth watering good.

Brussel Sprout chips as the appetizer - get it! Seriously wonderful.

Dessert...it is such a drag when dessert disappoints. I came so close to not ordering because I didn't want to risk the ending...carrot cake - my favorite...carrot cake.

Blach. Served in a jar (all the desserts are). Are you kidding me? Cute to some, maybe, absolutely didn't work for me. There was a nice strong 'nutty' cheese flavor and not all sugary, but, I couldn't get over the jar, and in the end, it wasn't that good.

GO FOR THE BURGER/FRIES and Brussell Sprouts (and the red wine...).

Well worth it!
author: Mark M.

description: The food was great. They are clearly known for their deviled eggs, as the server mentioned them to every table, and they did not disappoint. They were velvety in the mouth and packed a ton of flavor. My sole was slightly overcooked, but the citrus flavors and the crab meat, perfectly stuffed inside, helped me to overlook that minor flaw.
author: Heather S.

description:
This place sure live up to its hype. We finally got a chance to try the place out after reading so many great reviews. I made reservations for right when they open in the evenings, so getting a table was not an issue. Our waitress was really friendly and attentive. 

My husband and I ordered a bunch of appetizers and shared the burger. We tried a little of everything - had to try the brussel sprout chips, spicy shrimp and the bone marrow everyone was raving about. Also tried the beef tartar and their baked oyster, which I thought was just OK but everything else was wonderful.

The highlight was definitely the burger, which they were kind enough to split for us. It was juicy and flavorful and definitely one of the best burgers we have had in a while. So definitely a must try if you go there.

Only reason it didn't get 5 stars was because we were charged for refills of iced tea. We have been to some pretty high end restaurants, and NONE of them had ever charged for refills. It bothered me a little, more on the principal of it, it's not like we just ordered only $10 worth of food (I ordered a pitcher of sangria along with our food), but really, for such a nice place like Marlowe, why be so chintzy about that???
author: Jenny T.

description:
Food: 4 stars
Service: 2 stars

Food was good but I have a few grievances with this restaurant.  First of all, we were seated half an hour after our reservations--though the hostess did offer us glasses of champagne--which was nice of her to do.

We were seated for 3 and had ordered brussel sprout chips, bone marrow and steak tartare and I felt like the server rushed us through the appetizer.  He motioned to take the bone marrow plate away when there was still some marrow and bread left on the plate so I had to tell him we weren't done yet.  Then a couple of minutes, he came back and took the empty plates away along with the brussel sprout chips when there was still more than enough to cover the bottom of the bowl!  HOW RUDE!!!

The burger was overall very good.  Fries were yum too.  My only complaint was that the bun was not grilled or served warm.

I'd still come back bc the food was good but it the experience did not leave a warm, fuzzy feeling in my heart =(
author: Kim C.

description:
Food here is great, although a hair on the pricier side. 
For appetizers the brussels sprout chips are a must. We also typically order the warm deviled eggs, (3 stars) Spiced jumbo gulf shrimps (4 stars, can be a little salty) and steak tartare (4 stars)
Dinner the boyfriend always gets the steak frites, which he RAVES about. The frites that comes with dinner is very crispy and well cooked and taste great smothered in the red wine porcini jus. One of the few fries that I can eat without ketchup. 
I've ordered their fish dish (depending on the night the fish will be different) and it is mediocre to me. They were not very accommodating to substitutions when we asked for something other than the peewee potatoes that comes with the dish. (carb restrictions) 
The Smokey baked cauliflower is also a good side to try. It taste just like mac n cheese minus the carbs. 
Overall I enjoy this small place very much. The english hostess at the door is very friendly. Make sure to make a reservation! They are always packed, even on a thursday. 
My only small qualm with this place is that they only have wine and beer. I'm very surprised because they do have a bar area, and their sister restaurant, which is newer, does.
author: Jenny X.

description:
Everything I have eaten here has been delicious....even the crispy brussel sprout chips are good and I normally hate brussel sprouts.

The burger here is very popular and I definitely recommend it. Is it the best burger ever? Probably not....but it is a very, very good burger.

I also recommend:
- steak tartare - one of my favorite places to order this dish.
- spiced prawns - grilled and come served with a cocktail sauce reminiscent of a bloody mary.
- roasted bone marrow

It does get crowded so I recommend either making reservations or coming early. You also have the option to sit at the bar.
author: Lester W.

description:
My friend AT and I came on a whim. Chanced it on a Friday night with no reservations. We were lucky since we arrived just around 7p. While there were no tables just yet, we only had to wait about 20 minutes before getting a spot at one of the 2 long communal tables. So we were a little close to our neighbors and eavesdropping is certainly possible, but who cares right?

We started with beverages - I was lured by the Australian Ginger Beer ($4). Very nice, not overly strong ginger taste. Not sure why it needs to come from Australia though.

Appetizer: Brussel Sprout Chips ($6) seasoned with hints of Meyer Lemon and sea salt. Each baby leaf was fried up crisp (no batter) and seasoned. They were a little oily to the touch but great flavor.

Main: We both had our own Marlowe Burger ($13) topped with caramelized onions, cheddar cheese, bacon, and aioli with some sprinkling of fries. Mine was cooked perfectly to medium rare with the pink center. This is one of those burgers where you shouldn't deconstruct it, meaning if you're a girl like me, and sometimes I like to take the top bun off since it's too much carb to consume, well, it messes with the balance of salt to bread ratio. You definitely need all of the bun to cut through the savoriness of the cheddar and the bacon. It was good but a bit much for me. 

The fries were fantastic though. Firm and crisp on the outside, with some skin left. Love it.

Side: We actually opted for a side of Creamed Seasonal Greens ($8). It was more like a veggie gratin - baked with parmesan, garlic and bread crumbs. It was not creamy dairy as you may imagine but more dry but still mushy but in a good way. The pamesan imparted a lot of savory flavor. Really great. Would have been even better with some cracked pepper methinks.

We didn't have room for dessert though they sounded intriguing. By the time we left the place was FULL. Do make reservations or else come early. Small place, tight quarters, but good simple food done well.
author: Cindy W.

description:
thought i'd write a review for something BESIDES the burger for us non-meating eating folks:

First, the service is impeccable. The ambiance is casual fine dining like only SF can pull off.  The communal table trend in full effect here.  My guest and bellied up to the bar. 

Do not miss the Baked Oysters described appropriately as New England Clam Chowder in a shell...i still dream about them

Equally delish: Brussel Sprout Chips: wouldn't be surprised if we see these on the shelves of gourmet groceries very soon. 

Great selection of wines by the glass....
author: Angela N.

description:
Marlowe is my favorite lunch spot in SOMA. I have been there three times now. The atmosphere is intimate, the service is very attentive. But really, let's get down to the important stuff, what I ate. My favorite thing to eat at Marlowe is the Crispy Chicken Sandwich, it is a gem and the best chicken sandwich I have ever had! The breading is salty, crispy and amazing, the chicken is juicy and the whole thing is topped with greens tossed in a lemony Caesar dressing, delicious crispy bacon, and a garlicky mayo spread on a fluffy light bun, YUM-myyy for reals! Seriously best chicken sandwich ever, sorry chick-fil-a! Then on the side are some salty crispy fries and I like to accompany this meal with their bottled lemonade. It's a really satisfying lunch.  So much so I have never been able to order anything else off the menu!

The burger at Marlowe is pretty famous and I had a bite of my boyfriends, and it was very very good as well. If you're into burgers this one is pretty perfect. Visit Marlowe!
author: Fabiola M.

description:
OMG we had the most delicious dinner at Marlowe. 
It started with some baked oysters and some duck liver mousse with crostini (deee-lish!).
Then we had the steak frites and the lamb with a side of the caramelized brussels sprouts (a little bit too salty...)
Overall it was wonderful food, good wine and amazing service. 
Definitely go!
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
one of my favorite lunch places that's near the Zendesk office.

my recommendations:
poulet vert
french fries with aioli
peach with burrata salad
marlowe burger
author: Helen Y.

description: Loved the fried brussel sprouts. Everything else was great. Nice atmosphere, nice quirky front of the restaurant with all the quotes, nice service... just an overall solid restaurant. Will be back.
author: Harry K.

description:
I really wanted to like Marlowe.  It's new, cute, and has good reviews.  But it fell short.  

The good: both appetizers were great.  Both desserts were good.  My boyfriend's entree, the Marlowe Burger, was excellent.  The restaurant is well decorated and organized.  The price was as expected: $88 for 2 appetizers, 2 entrees, 2 desserts, 1 beer, 1 coffee.

The bad: First, our waitress (20-something Caucasian w/ dark hair and tattoos), while attentive, was not friendly.  The waitress next to our table chatted and joked with her customers.  Ours did her job, but was cold.  Second, I ordered "poulet vert" as an entree because the waitress recommended it.  The menu neglected to mention that the main seasoning for the sauce was olives.  I HATE olives.  So I only ate the inside where there was no sauce.  

The vibe of the place is good, so if the waitress just stepped it up and the chef added "olives" to the menu description, Marlowe would be awesome.
author: Melissa A.

description: Great meal plenty of unique small plates to share and then the burger was super tasty.
author: Billy M.

description:
If you live in the neighborhood (as I do), you probably love Marlowe (as I do), go there at least once a week (as I do) and would give it 10 stars if you were rating how great of an addition to the neighborhood it is (I would if Yelp had this category :).

If you are coming from afar, what you're looking for will be different than what I'm looking for, so let me clarify a few things and set your expectations:

1. Yes, the burger is delicious and deserved of all the "best burger in SF" accolades. Fries and aioli that are served with the burger are awesome too.

2. The other food is quite delicious as well, including the gem salad, soups (usually cream of something), spiced shrimp, bone marrow app, veggie au gratin (varies depending on season) and pork chop.

3. It's small with minimal decor; in other words, it's not "nice trendy" like a Perbacco or a Prospect or a Town Hall, but more "neighborhood trendy". 

4. It gets hot inside, so it's perfect during the winter but very, very stuffy on nice days. I understand they are working to fix this.

5. It's very loud inside.

6. They only serve beer and wine (they always have fun Prosecco special "cocktails" that are quite tasty), and there is usually only one person working the bar, which is why bar service may be a little slow at times.

7. The owners and most of the staff are SUPER nice and will go out of their way to accommodate you, with or without a reservation. I think this is why you may have to wait sometimes even if you have one, because they're trying to figure out the optimal seating situation for everyone (they get a ton of walk-ins from neighbors like me). 

8. It's probably not great for a big group dinner. I said this about the restaurant even when it was it's former reincarnate South, and has more to do with the space than anything else. 

Hope this helps. I personally adore Marlowe and I think that a lot of the gripes have more to do with expectations than anything else.
author: Veronica S.

description:
Three of us sat at the bar one uncrowded afternoon for a few hours ordering everything and sharing it.  Everything was good, or very good, nothing was extraordinarily good.  The famous burger was fine, about as good as any, but as long as the meat is rare and the bun is not stale, I'm happy.  The tartare was a treat-just the right amount with the right add-ins.  
 
By the time we wobbled out (we ordered many glasses of wine) the chilly black-and-gray room was abuzz with hungry hipsters, and the crowd of desperately texting couples spilled out into the street.  

If Marlow were in my neighborhood and not riding the "restaurant of the moment" trend, and was a bit less hectic in the evening, and the ambiance was relaxed and casual like the menu, I'd give it 4 stars, but there is a schism between the experience, the menu, and the prices that just don't add up somehow.

OK...the lemon souffle cake in a jar was TDF.  We fought over the last spoons-full.  I wonder if they serve it to go?
author: Rob B.

description: I love this restaurant. The space is a little small but decor is modern. We had to wait a long while for our table even w a reservation, but the hostess was really warm and sweet so we didnt mind. The food is really good! The filet mignon plate was a little small but tasty. The chicken was to die for. Well seasoned, juicy, scrumptious. The brussel sprout  chips were delicious too. The sea salt chocolate pot de creme for dessert was luxurious. Definitely recommend!
author: Maggie T.

description: I haven't had a full meal here but my favorites include the cooked oysters with chowder, the deviled eggs and all of their desserts!
author: vinney a.

description:
The bf has been wanting to try Marlowe for a while now, so when i had to stay late in SF one day (and he was coming to pick me up) I decided to get us a reservation for dinner. Luckily it was not a game night and we were able to find parking right on Townsend. 

We ordered the brussels sprouts chips and bone marrow for appetizers, and the burger and scallops for dinner. The BF does not llike brussels sprouts at all, so i was shocked when he started gobbling all the chips down! The lemon gives it a great tang and it was totally delicious. I loved mopping up the bone marrow with the bread, but I did wish I had more bread though. The BF and I shared the burger and scallops, and they had split the burger (and fries) onto two plates for us. I actually didn't mention that when I ordered so it was a really pleasant surprise. The BF have been hearing/reading about the hype on this burger for a while, so he was really excited to try it. Unfortunately it did not live up to it's hype. The burger was actually lukewarm when we got it, probably because they were waiting for the scallops. The scallops, on the other hand, was amazing! The scallops were tender and sweet, and the bacon wrapped asparagus, mushrooms and peas, and wine sauce was perfect with the scallops. 

For dessert the BF had the chocolate cream pie and I had the upside down strawberry crisp. they were served in little mason jars which were the perfect size for them. I really enjoyed the strawberry crisp, which was basically just the bourbon ice cream topped with strawberries and crisp. The only downside for me is that they didn't have coffee, only espresso, and their espressos were incredibly strong. 

I'll come back again, just not for the burger.
author: Janny N.

description:
love love Marlowe. 

Came here with a couple of friends and got seated right away even though we showed up a few minutes late. the place is fairly small and gets pretty packed, so I would recommend making a reservation in advance. 

Our waitress recommended a red from Slovania, and it was exactly what I was looking for to complete my steak dinner. I also liked the crispy brussel sprouts, the duck liver, and roasted bone marrow. definitely one of my favorite spots in the area
author: Azin D.

description: Had a reservation and still had to wait 20 mins. The restaurant had 4 open tables but the hostess did not seat anyone there. Order a salad to share, a fried chicken sandwich, and the wife had the crab crepe. We waited another 20 mins to get a salad! Who takes 20 mins to make a salad!! Food was okay, we saw a table of 6 that sat down way after we did and they got their food before us.  Horrible!
author: Allen L.

description:
Marlowe sounds like it could be a cute name for a dog. Or for an adorable orange clown fish.. like Nemo's little sister.

The tiny space that used to be South is now transformed into the new Marlowe restaurant. And by "transformed" I mean they changed the wall art and added some cheeky but cute quotation appliques to the outside glass pane.

But the cuisine... oh my. Definitely some thumbs-up transformations there. The boy and I were so addicted to the crispy brussel sprout chips with meyer lemon + sea salt that it felt like we were in a Hidden Valley commercial where everything was replaced by veggies- in this case, buttered popcorn became salted brussel sprout leaf chippies. Just marvelous.

The roasted bone marrow, although not an entirely new concept in many of SF's fine American New establishments, was well prepared and satisfying all the same. I had the Marlowe burger with carmelized onions, cheddar, and bacon- with a side of horseradish aioli + fries. The boy ordered the seared black cod with bagna càuda butter (see below), spring veggies, and a side of spinach.

A brief history on bagna càuda butter, kids:
In the Piedmont region of Italy, eating bagna-cauda butter is a favorite ritual. The diners gather around an earthenware pot filled with hot olive oil, anchovies and garlic, and they dip raw vegetables or bread into the "hot bath"- a kind of Italian fondue.

A hot bath of oil and garlic. Yes, please. 
Per usual, my writing is riddled with run-on sentences and digressions. Where was I?

Ooh, Marlowe. From our extremely attentive server to the sunny and friendly hostess, the staff at Marlowe was top notch. The ambiance felt casual and easy, but the noise level was rather high. When we went in for an 8:30pm Friday night dinner, the buzz level was just one notch below that of a typical bar/lounge. I was practically yelling across the table. Not terribly lady-like on my part.

But, other than the unusually high uproar due to Marlowe's small space and low ceilings causing the sound to have no place to escape, the food is well worth the visit.
author: Elaine T.

description: Was walking around SOMA and someone recommended this place. Tried the polenta and was not disappointed - delicious! If I lived in the neighborhood I would come here more often
author: S J.

description:
Context: Tuesday night with a 5:30 reservation but we arrived at 5:00. There was a giants game and the place is close to the stadium so the crowds may have been related to the 7:15 game.

Atmosphere: small room with seating for about 40 including a communal table. White and black tile floors, lots of mirrors, windows, a small bar and black ceiling make for a lively, convivial and somewhat light atmosphere. Place is close and crowded where you've got to move the table to get out of your seat.

Service: we were greeted promptly at the door and seated in a nice corner table. The place was pretty empty and they let us chose our seats. Service was very competent and efficient with regular water filling and quick clearing of the table so you do get the feeling you are getting moved right along. Service stayed good despite increasing crowds.

Food: at 5, they are still serving their midday, very limited menu so we got Brussels sprout chips with lemon and salt, a glass of white and a black lager. The chips are the individual leaves of Brussels sprouts peeled and fried tossed with salt and lemon. They are very good, but also pretty greasy. You can really taste the lemon and we wolfed them down in seconds.
Once it was 5:30, we ordered our dinner. Starting with a beet salad with s smoked rogue creamery blue cheese and arugula; two deviled eggs and for mains hamburger and crab cake. Everything was good, but nothing was great. The burger is cooked as ordered and comes with a bit of heavy bun, slow cooked onions that were undetectable, lots of bacon and lettuce. The burger was good but it needed to be more burger and less bun.  It comes with a very small serving of parsley tossed fries that seemed to be double fried. They were good but fries are not where you should skimp, given how cheap potatoes are. The crab cake was very greasy but heavy with crab served with an unusual shaved celery salad and a creamy dressing, both of which were refreshing and quite good.  The beet salad comes with cubed, roasted beets and shaved uncooked beets, heavy dressing, a nice size serving of candied pecans and a very, very slim covering of blue cheese, which was a disappointment.  The deviled eggs were tasty with bacon and melted cheese they seemed to be broiled or something because they were warm. It's $2 per half egg, so they come steep.
We also ordered dessert, a chocolate pie, but its really chocolate pudding in a jar with a bit of Oreo cookie crust. Too sweet, to small and not flavorful enough. 

Drinks: we had a glass of wine and black lager. Both were good and when I described the type of wine I wanted the staff knew exactly what I should order.

Overall thoughts: if you are trying to get in and out quick, this place works. It is not a relaxed dinner option, at least not on game nights. Portions seem small but the food is good.
author: Vivek V.

description: The food is delicious (everything highlighted on yelp was a win), the service is special as well - the host goes out of his way to be polite, the bartender is welcoming too. It will take you forever trying to get a reservation here and will take you a while if you wait as well so plan accordingly.  I believe I saw a sign that said they were considering opening for dinner on wkends (Sunday I think).
author: Alias A.

description:
Friend saw it on Yelp, figured it'd be good and I thought it sounded interesting. We didn't know there was a Giants game that day. So she spent an hour looking for parking while I got our reservation. Note: DO NOT GO TO SOMA RESTAURANTS ON A GAME DAY. But they do have valet parking if you do decide to take that chance, with 25 Lusk. 

Crispy Brussels Sprout Chips. With Meyer Lemon and Sea Salt. This was alright, though unique, it was slightly overrated. They had the natural bitterness of brussels sprouts, tanginess of the lemon and savoryness of the sea salt. I do wish it was less greasy, they made my finger so shiny and looking at the paper on the basket after we finished was scary.

Baked Oysters. New England Chowder in a shell. Presentation was great, very clever to put it on top of a bed of sea salt. Taste-wise, it was okay. It was a little on the salty side so I couldn't really even taste the oyster at all, remind me, why did I order a baked oyster again if I can't taste it? 

Marlowe Burger (Half). With Caramelized Onions, Cheddar, Bacon, Horseradish Aioli, and Fries. Our server was kind enough to split it in the kitchen for us. The burger was alright though, got the patty cooked medium so it was more juicy, but I've definitely had better. Their patties don't have the fresh taste of nommy Niman Ranch Beef Patties. But still alright in my book. The horseradish aioli was pretty good, my friend who doesn't even like horseradish liked it a lot. The fries were really good too, even plain, the seasonings on it was noms.

Grilled Pork Chop. With Crispy Parmesan Dumplings, Apples and Pickled Mustard Seeds. The pork chop was well cooked, but I was really full by that point so it could have been better than I remember. The parmesan dumplings were not my thing, I'm usually not a fan of parmesan and especially not fried, so I didn't really like this. It was way too rich for me. The apples were really good though, the sweet yet tangy flavor helped combat the richness of the cheese. 

Lemon Souffle Cake. With Raspberry Curd, Whipped Cream and Lemon Zest. This was pretty good too. I liked the tangy-lightness of the cake, helped me feel a little less full than I was. I think it was the only dessert that could have fit into my stomach at that point. Though I must admit, Sutro's at the Cliff House would be a better choice for a lemon souffle, theirs is BOMB.

Their service is great and that is what bumped them up to 4 stars since their food itself is only worth 3. Our server was really attentive and nice. I love that she split our burger onto two plates as well.
author: Constance C.

description:
+4 stars because everyone here was super nice, I like the space, wine is cheap and food was tasty.

-1 star because for $11, you cannot serve one small bone marrow and split it in half to fill up the plate.  The amount of tapanade and greens on the plate cannot be way more than the actual amount of marrow and what is the point of giving 4 pieces of bread when there is really only enough marrow for 2.  It was actually a plus and minus, but splitting the bone marrow in half is great for easy access but it also highlights the fact that there wasn't much marrow.  

Just for reference:  For $11, you can get boneS at Bar Tartine served on their awesome bread.   Also even at crazy New York dinner prices, for $14 you also get boneS at Prune - my all time favorite for marrow bones.
author: Jen C.

description: Awesome, perfectly executed, innovative "comfort" food, great service, cool ambiance. Loved it.
author: Gary C.

description:
A pleasant surprised!!! Great little place that's packed on a tue night.  The food took a lil longer than usual to come, but it's definitely worth the wait.  My fav: brussel sprouts chips, grilled bone marrow, and burger!!! Yes, you heard me, the burger is mouthlicious! 

I am taking half a star off for the loong wait for food. Otherwise, a great place to hang!
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Baked oyster-- Yum!!!
The pork chop was pretty good too, and good sides, especially the dumplings.
BTW, french fries were good too.
author: Elena L.

description:
5 stars just for the FRIES.
3 stars for everything else.

We had reservations at 8pm, but ended up waiting around until being seated at 8:45pm. Hunger grumpiness was mildly abated when the hostess apologetically offered us some complimentary crispy brussels sprout chips. While they were good, they were also extremely salty and oily... so... not something I'd order on my own.

Once we were finally seated, we were again offered some complimentary goodies-- this time the toasted pistachios (yum) and the sauteed Padron peppers (good-- a mix of sweet and spicy peppers... watch out! Its like playing landmines). Neither were snacks we would order on our own, but it was a nice touch for the staff to offer them to us due to the horrendous wait time.

AMBIANCE: dimly lit, I saw a lot of couples going at it, regardless of whether or not they were placed in a cozy corner. It was fairly loud, making it hard to hear the server if they spoke across the table to you.

SERVICE: meh. Like many others have noted, they kept on removing our dishes before we were finished! Honestly, what's the rush?! You've already kept us waiting 45min past our reservation time, I doubt anyone will be waiting for the table after us. Let us eat in peace!

FOOD: we ordered:
- Sweet corn soup (REALLY sweet)
- Berkeley Burrata (peaches were very sweet, burrata was meh) 
- Spiced prawns (yes, the sauce really is BOOZY.)
- Roasted bone marrow (very rich; toast was chewy, not crispy)
- Marlowe burger (juicy, but too SALTY)
- Summer squash gratin (tasted like lasagna minus the noodles)
- Raspberry & lemon pudding cake (nice way to end the meal)

OVERALL:
Of all the things we tried/ordered, I would only recommend ordering the burger. However, while the much touted Marlowe burger was indeed quite good (not sure if it lives up to all the hype though), it was the amazing FRIES that will keep me coming back (if at all).
author: Susanna W.

description: The food was not to my taste (that isn't to say that there was anything wrong with it, I'm just not terribly into the kind of dishes they have on offer - I just stopped in because it's convenient to the Caltrain station), but I still wanted to leave this review in order to mention how incredibly warm and kind the service is.  The service at Marlowe deserves applause, and whoever is responsible for ensuring the great service (owner? manager?) - thank you!  This is the level of service to which more restaurants should aspire.
author: Printe R.

description:
Marlowe is pretty damn awesome!  We were due to share the communal table, but some party canceled and we got a regular table for the 4 of us.

Those brussel sprout chips are da BOMB!  If I could, I would've eaten it all by myself!  The bone marrow also da BOMB!  Although they could've included a few more pieces of bread....

I had the burger and the bf had some fish...fish was tasty but not as tasty as my burger.  Now I wouldn't claim it's the all time best burger on the planet....but it's pretty damn awesome...juicy, flavorful and cooked just the perfect medium rare!!  

End your meal here with apps and entrees as the desserts were just ehh and you'll be disappointed.  Save the dessert and head down to District for their bread pudding...which is to die for!!!
author: Mao K.

description: THis place is great! One of the best restaurants in the city. It's always crowded becuase it's a great place to eat. I had the fried chicken and loved it! I would come back again and again.
author: Christy T.

description:
I went with a group of six. The place is small and kinda cramp, we sat on long padded benches which is kinda hard to get in and out if other people from the other table are sitting and you're wearing a dress. The service was very good. We had a baby with us and they accommodated to our needs concerning him like providing a high chair, water, etc.  

We order for appetizers the brussels sprout chips (soo addicting), bone marrow (not too much), baked oysters (dee--lish) all were very yummy. Though overall they had a heavy hand with the salt. The main courses we ordered was the burger, polenta, chicken, and lamb. The burger was extremely juicy and delectable. The polenta had just the right consistency of creaminess. The chicken and lamb having a small bite of each were also very pleasant.
author: Julie B.

description:
I went here for a business lunch. I had the fried chicken sandwich, which was delicious. Even the side salad was good - micro-greens and vinaigrette, with finely-chopped onions mixed throughout which added dimension.

I will definitely be back - not just because it's close to my work and there's a lack of good food in the area, but because I've been dreaming about the chicken sandwich ever since my first visit!
author: Karen C.

description: Amazing food in a gorgeous decor (if you don't look up to see the acoustic ceiling tiles that were obviously an afterthought), and the service is relentlessly warm and friendly. I like that you can spend more (drinks, appetizers, deserts, and less filling plates) or spend less (the burger), and either way have an awesome meal. Great for small groups, though the one long table looks like it might seat up to around 20.
author: Lian C.

description: Very intimate and cozy. Everything we ordered was very good, but the pork chop was definitely one of the best I've had...ever. Easily enough food for 2 adults to share and the server even asked if we were. Service was top notch.  Went to the restroom twice and both times, my napkin was folded and reset on the table. Seriously go.
author: Nathan T.

description:
Second time here - really comfortable space, service is sharp.  The roast chicken with olives and radicchio was pretty inventive (I was surprised I ordered it, I can't remember ordering chicken when there's steak frites *and* a great burger to choose from).  The brussel sprout chips are good, but I'd rather have the old SPQR version.  They have a vegetable side of mushrooms on grilled bread that we ordered as a starter - definitely would recommend it.

The only problem with this place is the portion sizes.  I'm not *that* big of an eater, but when the waiter brought out the buratta app today, I would have laughed if it hadn't been $12.  I'm talking maybe a quarter of a peach, 2 teaspoons of buratta and - wait for it - a single arugula leaf.    I actually debated taking off another star just for that...
author: Katie P.

description: Mmm delicious burger, cooked to perfection! The bone marrow appetizer was also spot on and the service was great!
author: Leanne S.

description:
Love this place and so glad it's just 1/2 a block from the office.  It's proximity lends itself to frequent visits, although only for lunch.  

Definitely get the brussels sprout chips.  Don't ask; just order and enjoy... they're phenomenal. I've had the burger, rock shrimp roll, and ham & cheese sandwich - all of which were excellent.  I cant confirm but have heard and dont find it hard to believe that the crispy fried chicken sandwich is a must-have.  They have some great wines, beers, and non-alcoholic drinks for those of you so inclined. 

Excellent restaurant with great service.  

The only reason I give it 4 stars is I want their menu to change a tad more often - I'm running out of things to try...
author: Jason R.

description: Pia our server was amazing. Attentive and knowledgable.  We both had the Marlowe burger. The deviled eggs were amazing and the steak tartare was to die for.  Kinda pricey, but a great experience overall. We'll be back
author: David R.

description:
The inspiration behind the new eatery has shifted from a South down under, to a South Boston butcher shop. And I like it. A LOT.

Marlowe dishes up New American bistro favorites including roasted bone marrow, steak frites and a namesake burger. The brief menu still manages to offer a big variety, and certainly got me salivating over the options. We decided to select a few dishes and share everything: first, the spiced prawns with a hot & "boozy" cocktail sauce and classic steak tartare with poached quail egg and crostini which absolutely melted in my mouth. Then the seared black cod which was perfectly cooked with a crisp skin over soft flaky fish. We also enjoyed a side of brown butter baby brussels sprouts. For dessert (which really gives my rating a full 5 stars), we devoured the TCHO chocolate pot de creme with creme fraiche and meyer lemon curd cake with whipped cream. They were so good that we scraped both glass jars clean.

The timing of the food was perfect - a slow pace so that you could savor it to the last bite, but never a long pause in between so that out table with never without food. 

Be sure to check the butcher paper hanging on the wall for daily cocktail and wine specials. I tried both offerings - a blood orange champagne cocktail and a red wine - which I really enjoyed.

I like that they kept the black ostrich banquettes that I clearly remembered from South, as well as the long communal table in the center, but still changed the look and feel. Try reading the quotes stenciled onto the exterior windows backwards - it makes for an even more entertaining dining experience.
author: Connie C.

description: Nice service.  Yummy food.  Cute decor.  Worth a visit.
author: S S.

description:
I had heard such promising things about Marlowe's (the burgers and the fries) and I work right across the way so I ventured in for lunch today. They were a bit busy, so they just had us sit on a shared bench and join with another party - totally fine, but some diners might not be keen on that.

We had several diners in our party, and we had the fried chicken sandwich, the signature Marlowe burger with fries, some had the burger with the mixed greens salad, and we also had an accompanying side of brussels chips.

The burger was very good - however, the portion size is large, and I wish that they had sliders. That would have been a perfect offering to enhance their appetizer menu, or for those of us who weren't so hungry. Brussel sprouts aren't hard to prepare, but to prepare them well is difficult. I felt the top part of the bunch was well seasoned (it comes with lemon juice, salt and olive oil) but the bottom was way too salty, and there were garlic clumps making for really potent flavors. Some of them were really burnt too, making for a very mixed batch. Also, at most restaurants, I feel an aioli or a dip of some sort is good to offset the saltiness of the brussels. 

The server was not very proactive in attending to our table. However, the bussers were very overworked, but still managed to cater to our needs, and refill our waters constantly. She didn't tell us about the specials (which were listed on the wall) but we didn't notice until halfway through our meal, and we would have appreciated knowing about them. Wish they had more offerings on their menu.

Down to come back and give them a second chance, but wasn't too impressed.
author: Tammy H.

description: Here it Is in a nutshell:  too loud, too expensive, too crowded.  The food is average and the staff so so.  The six of us could not have a conversation at all.  When the ambience is described as trendy, that just means it is a trend. Good food, some ability to converse, and good portions would outlast the supercool follow us to this place for now group. If they think every one likes it. they have to go and pretend it is worth their money after they take an Uber car to get there.
author: dave d.

description:
The Beatles sang that all you need is love but Julia Child said that all you need is butter. And Marlowe understands both concepts as exhibited in their Asparagus bread pudding . Great lunch spot- literally everything on the menu sounded and looked appealing as I snuck looks around. 

Loved the tables, nice details, professional service. Thanks you for simple syrup in a small pitcher for my iced tea. Brought so fast I didn't even know it was there. Usually people look at me like I'm weird when I ask for it.  Parked a block away at Safeway and if you spend 5 bucks there parking is free for 90 minutes. So I stopped in for cat food. Will definitely be back.
author: Joan P.

description:
This review is a little late, but we had reservations for 2 sometime in August.

What we ate:
- steak tartare
- bone marrow
- brussel sprout chips

Main dishes:
- marlowe burger
- polenta

Dessert:
- some type of panna cotta (along with a glass of port)

Overall impression: Service was very friendly and responsive. We had reservations early (maybe 6PM or so) and we were sat immediately. Place is tiny. Food came out incredibly fast. I mean I think we ordered and three minutes later all our appetizers came out. Wine was good, but not great. The drink specials seemed very... feminine. Light and sweet. Our neighbors to each side of us decided to order similar items to what we did, because it looked so good.

Food: steak tartare and bone marrow were very yummy. Good texture, seasoning, temperature, etc. Excellent portions as well. Brussel sprout chips were good to try. They are crispy and well-seasoned. I'm not sure if it's really my style, but I would recommend them if you're curious. The burger was tasty. The bun was kinda blah though. Don't underestimate a good bun! Still like Spruce and the nopa burger better. Polenta was yum. I only had an itty bit left but I needed to eat it again so I took it home.

Dessert was fine. I like my desserts light, and I was satisfied.

I would go again and maybe try a bunch of appetizers, because by the time we got to the main dishes, I was no longer hungry...
author: Jenny T.

description: rain and reservations...standing still...twenty-five minutes past the reservation...complimentary champagne while standing...complimentary brussel sprout leaf chips for waiting...assume greased and baked...would be great with sweet miso...but, good snack on own and free....enough bubbly & greens, and requesting real food...honey glazed pork belly...dressed with nuts and beets...a small block of pork...cutting to five thick slices if sharing...tender, but not melting...good texture and delicious appetizer...to the main...round ball of new york steak medium and fries...mentioned sharing, but no special requests...generously splitting the steak to two on separate warm plates with fries on both...great surprising service...standard steak and cut of lean meat...beef resting on a drizzle of sweet red wine mushroom reduction guessing...great flavors...bite of the cheesy hot cauliflower gratin next...oh that cheesy sinful cauliflower....job well done...on to the second main....the favorite, a polenta!...marvelous mix of texture and flavors...great earthy mushroom flavors...fresh leafy greens...wonderful artisan polenta...topped with a farm fresh egg...taking bites a la carte...enjoying each taste and play...cracking of yolk and mixing...even better!...a sip of red and another glass...$one-hundred-twenty-five dinner for two...seeing good potential for marlowe with a great mix of varying ingredients, flavors and textures...added service and server making better...
author: Hen A.

description:
Came here a couple of times for lunch - yep this is the place if you want to spoil for lunch!

I LOVED the Brussels sprouts chips - a deliciously great appetizer to share. All other sandwich items were very tasty and there were no complaints. Service and staff was friendly and welcoming.

The perfect spot for a leisurely Friday lunch.
author: Sonja S.

description:
Favorite place to eat in Soma!

If they have the corn soup (seasonal), GET IT!!!

Poulet Vert is awesome!

If you're in to it, the baked oysters are yummy!
author: Oren F.

description:
Just go here, it's great (in case you're attention impaired).

Came here for lunch.  Industrial tiny chic, whatever.  Edge of the train tracks.  It's a very abstract place, limited lunch menu, big hefty picnic table size communal tables.  High concept but not stuffy.  Saw Nish here.

Fries were in the top 5%, so was hamburger, and a generous and tasty shrimp sandwich.  Prices aren't cheap and portions are moderate.

Everything was solid.  But the real OMG moment, something beyond just good to the point of inspired, was a simple lettuce salad that sat on my sandwich plate.  Perfect, fresh, tasty little leaves, pickled shallots, lemon vinaigrette, tossed just enough to coat every leaf, and a perfect dusting of smoked medium crystal sea salt.  The flavors were just perfect, the texture, even the temperature was right.  If a salad can make me gush, I'm happy.

It was fairly short staffed for lunch, although they're obviously pros, but that did mean some wait times.  Everyone does double or triple duty at a place this small, the host does food running, the cook buses a table or two, and the waitress checks the bathroom.
author: Gil S.

description: In a town where 4 and 5 star restaurants seem to be the norm, I'm flabbergasted that Marlowe only receives a 4.  The atmosphere is intoxicating and the pork chop I ordered was scrumptious.  Who would have thought I'd find something better than Vietnamese grilled pork chops?!  The only thing that would have improved the experience is if I were able to see better what it was I was actually eating.  Otherwise, A+.  It also has a great location right across from the Caltrain station, so a South Bay person starving for a juicy pork chop can get easy access.  Bravo!
author: Jeff J.

description: I ate the steak tartar and salmon entree with a glass of Cabernet. The menu is somewhat basic brasserie, but the food is absolutely delicious. The quinoa was infused with lemon, the food was fresh, perfectly cooked, and just had remarkable and unpredictable flavor. The wine wasn't outstanding but to each his own. The service was very good.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
Marlowe, you seduced me with the Spiced Prawns with Hot & Boozy sauce.  You intrigued me the the warm Egg Salad Sandwich.  You won my heart with the Crispy Brussels Sprouts Chips.

You did it casually, handsomely re-dressing one of my favorite SOMA spots, South.  You were friendly, sending me a nice server who knew just what to recommend.  You gave me the familiar - fries, but kicked up with a horseradish aioli.  

You took care of my family, making sure my cousin had a beautiful gluten-free meal.

You made it so easy.  So affordable.  So delicious.

You had me drinking wine at noon.

You promised me a future together, showing me other tables with juicy burgers, steak tartare, baked oysters, crisp sausages.

Marlowe, I believe this is the beginning of something beautiful.
author: Liz S.

description: Came here for Sunday brunch and it was good, but nothing was spectacular.  The space is nice and airy and makes you forget that right outside is the construction nightmare that is 4th Street these days.  Service was quite good, our server was knowledgeable and friendly, and did an excellent job with refilling water/coffee.  The food itself was fine, good not great.  We had their spicy jumbo prawns which were tasty, but the cocktail sauce tasted just like slightly more spicy cocktail sauce.  The eggs with tomato and chickpeas was not my favorite.  I thought it was too watery, and it was hard to take a "bite" of the dish when the sauce didn't stick to the chickpeas or the eggs.  We had the ricotta toast with kumquat, which probably ended up being one of the better dishes, but the crust was fairly hard making it difficult to eat without making a huge mess.  Overall, it was a nice brunch and I'm glad I tried it, I just don't think it's the best brunch you can get at that price point.
author: Michelle C.

description:
came here friday night for a friends birthday. from the outside it looks just like a warehouse, but the inside was cozy and cute. we sat near the wall, and i felt a bit smushed as 3 girls each sat on a bench, and my friend who was sitting across me, we kept banging our foots against each other. it was also really hot inside.

we started off with the bone marrow and spicy prawns. the bone marrow was good, but they only give you 4 small baguette slices, even though we had 6 girls. i think the bone marrow was the best part of our meal, and we ordered another, as there's hardly much to begin with. the spicy prawns were just okay, i feel shrimp and prawns are the same wherever you go.

we ordered the marlowe burger, and after reading the reviews, i also ordered the steak frittes. to be honest, i was trying not to expect a lot from the marlowe burger, and was really dissapointed. the bun gets sooo soggy so quickly, and the rest of it is just okay. my friend mentioned she thought in n out was better, and i almost felt like i was eating a five guys burger all over again. except this was $13. the steak frittes, i honestly had one or two bites, and i was done. it wasnt appetizing at all. it was just a big fat piece of meat.

for dessert, we shared all 3 kinds of desserts. the summer berry pudding, the dark chocolate pot de creme, and raspberry and lemon pudding cake. i would say this was my only other favorite from the bone marrow. we all had our favorites, i thought the summer berry pudding was the best, very cool and crisp.

our server was exceptionally great, recommended great wines (at least from my friends' opinions as i dont drink it), and the atmosphere was cozy and cute.

oh, also we parked at safeway after reading off yelp that you can park for 90 minutes if you purchase $5 worth of things. so we did so, since we had so much trouble finding parking as a giants game was going on. after we bought some things, we put in the parking ticket to find out we owed $30. on giants game days, you pay the $30 fee no matter what.
author: Denise L.

description:
Do me a favor and order the Brussels Sprout Chips, you will not regret it!

I love the atmosphere of Marlowe; it is small and romantic feeling with a large communal table in the middle. The only complaint is that they squeezed 6 of us into a little part of the communal table and we didn't have much room.

The Brussels sprout chips were delicious and crunchy. (they are the individual leaves of the Brussels sprouts that are peeled off individually) The steak tartare was ok, it kind of tasted like it was cooked and had a bit too much black pepper in it.

Seared black cod, excellent dish, very light and fresh. The lamb was also very good and tender.

Upside down apple crisp was delicious, how can you not like bourbon ice cream with caramel and a crunchy apple topping. There could have been a bit more caramel in it though, but I couldn't stop eating it. That should tell you something!

Overall friendly Australian servers, good atmosphere though a bit on the pricey side for what it is.

Oh btw if you want to try to recreate the Brussels sprout chips this might help www.theappetight.com
author: Elaine S.

description:
Go to Marlowe.

Have the cute waitresses or Kraig the super friendly bartender bring you the following:

- Crispy brussels sprout chips with that i-can't-stop-eating-this taste 

- Baked oysters New England chowder in a shell with that slurp-me-out-of-the-shell flavor

- Spiced prawns with that extra kicky cocktail sauce

- Roasted bone marrow with that flavors bursting salsa verde

- Marlowe burger with that thin toasted bun, caramelized onions, cheddar, bacon, and spicy horseradish aioli and addictive fries that are crispy on the outside and creamy on the inside

- Upside down apple crisp with that bourbon ice cream and brown butter caramel sauce

Then come and thank me after.
author: Christine C.

description:
It ain't cheap but it's good quality food. 
Deviled eggs= delicious 
Burger= juicy
Steak = cooked to perfection
Desert= who's got room for dessert?

Not a place for vegans / kids / dogs
author: Joseph M.

description:
5 stars for its kind.

Terrific, neighborhood gem that is here to stay.  Innovative dishes and tasty wines by the glass with timely, friendly service.  Perfect to catch up with an old friend I hadn't seen in a while.   Why wouldn't you come here??  

For a Thu dinner, my friend and I ate our way through the snacks and appetizers menu: 
Brussel sprout chips - yum but agree that it's a bit salty & greasy
Bone marrow - lusciously rich and delicious
Crab Louie in lettuce cups with tobasco - Tasty, not sure I'd order again, but glad that Marlowe experiments with stuff like this 
Baked oysters, briny-style - gulped and done.
Deviled eggs - I never eat deviled eggs but since my friend ordered one, I did too.  Nice - I'd have again.
Marlowe burger medium - we split this.  Scrumptious way to end the savory part of the meal...
Lemon souffle cake - nicely done but both of us craved more raspberry, and fresh ones too.  

Our server recommended an interesting South African "Quinary" Raka red - full taste to pair well with richness with lingering 
For my second, she recommended a grenache/syrah/mouvedre blend - complex fruit - lovelylovely - my new favorite.  In fact, I ordered a bottle of such a blend at Bisou and that turned out terrific!!  But that's another review.

Back to Marlow, on my next trip, I'd like to try the steak tartare, spiced Jumbo gulf shrimp, and some other main.

Street parking is fairly easy (albeit taking the T here from Embarcadero was a tad shady).  OpenTable reservations are easy - FYI, weekend nights are packed so reserve early.  Weekdays do get full but seem to have one seating so walk-ins are possible.

This will be a welcome add to my favorite neighborhood gems list.  Should be a San Franciscan hotspot but under the touristy radar (hopefully forever!!)
author: FoodieGal I.

description:
Date night with my boo and like most people read the sfgate review and needed to try this burger....

There were so many things I loved:
$15 corkage and if you bought a bottle there the fee was waived. Gonna force me to drink two bottles of wine... twist. my. arm. 
Parking for only $5 and in SOMA
Burger with perfectly cooked bacon
OpenTable points
The oysters
The FRENCH FRIES

Huge mistake getting the brussel sprout chips. They are difficult to eat and I with I got the baked ones instead.  My only complaint and loss of star was I asked for my burger medium well and it was VERY pink in the middle. 

So delish and I have already recommended to friends.
author: Nancy B.

description: We finally made it to Marlowe for our 15th anniversary. We were greeted with genuine warmth by Sarah and Shawn, and then had flawless, friendly service by Malissa and others. You can always tell when the staff at a restaurant likes working together because the vibe is good and the teamwork seamless. That was the case here. The Huz said that the lamb/beef burger was the best burger he'd ever had. I loved my black cod conserva. We shared the gingerbread, which was spicey and dense enough to stand up to vanilla bean ice cream and caramel sauce. Oh, and the La Cuchilla was yum. We will definitely be return patrons.
author: Cydney B.

description:
I was excited to try Marlowe thanks to the Yelp reviews and it's proximity to my bf's and my new apartment. However, I was let down! 

It was a Monday night and we had to wait 30 min for a table. This however will never affect my Yelp review. It's not their fault they're popular.

I always start with 5 stars. 

We're sat at the bar which is so cramped that I'm constantly bumping elbows with the guy next to me. -1 star.

The waitress/ barsmaid seems grumpy and a bit allergic to smiling. -1 star. 

The appetizer (baby brussel sprouts which are pretty good) comes at the same time as the food. -1 star

My meal is delicious. +1 star. (No more because my polenta has a bit too much garlic.) My bf thought his burger was a little greasy and the bacon was underwhelming. -1 star.

The suggested red wine pairing to my bf's burger was spot on. +1 star.

We both have to wait for our empty water glasses to be refilled, even though we are sitting at the bar staring at the water pitcher. - 1 star.

We order some type of lemon souffle for dessert. Not bad, not amazing. A bit on the bland side; needed more zing.

It wasn't a terrible meal, but the overall experience was truly disappointing. Don't think I'll ever be returning. 

A 2 star experience. I know of WAY too many amazing restaurants in SOMA for whom I'd prefer to walk the extra 3 blocks to get to.
author: Rebecca L.

description: Stopped here with a colleague after our meeting for lunch.  Great suggestion.  I had one of their burgers and switched out the fries for a salad.  High quality food, nice clean surroundings.  Nice find in Mission Bay area.
author: Jason O.

description:
I was greeted by quotes on the side of the building/window leading up to the handicap ramp and I had a few good laughs. This place and Credo are probably the two most memorable places with quotes on the walls. 

Anyhow, onto the food! Had the Steak Tartare appetizer and it was amazing, huge amount of beef seasoned perfectly and chopped to perfection. Next up, steak frites, probably the best i've had in several years. Fries done perfectly, double fried I think I heard. Steak cooked to a specified medium - rare, and perfectly seasoned. 

The burger looked so good that I could tell you it was good just from looking at it. 

Oh the bartender served up some wonderful wines as well, but... I was too intoxicated to remember which ones they were. 

I might add service was great, the only thing was the long wait which is expected with any good restaurant.
author: Steven C.

description: Ok, not that great. The brussel sprout chips were good but tasted burned. The bone marrow was actually good. The steak was great and very well cooked. The hamburgers are not the best by any means. It's just a burger and the bacon taste over powers the meat flavor. The server forgot to mention the specials which was a bummer because after finishing dinner and seeing the specials on the wall, I wish I had asked. All in all, save your money and go some place else.
author: Javan E.

description:
Ordered a Marlowe burger and fries to go based on a friend's recommendation. YUM!!!

Their beef-lamb burger was a perfect size (as it fit in my mouth... only barely) and was topped with bacon and cheese. Doood. Moo, Baa AND Oink?!? ALL OF GOD's CREATURES in a bun! A tad greasy and totally not kosher, but very delicious. My meal came accompanied by crispy fries and horseradish aioli. YAY!

Take-out should always be so good.
author: Debra C.

description:
We were here on Saturday for a friend's birthday dinner.

Pros
- Although the place was quite small (seats about 40 people total I think), we were able to get a large connected table for our party of 12 people.  

- Service was pretty good.  The waiters kept on refilling my water promptly though my cup of hot water was never refilled.

- Ambiance was nice.  It wasn't too loud so we were able to hear ourselves talking pretty easily.

- We stayed there for about 2 hours (5:30 to 7:30) and they never rushed us out even though we were sitting at their largest table that could seat about 20 when we were only a party of 12.

- The appetizers we ordered were all pretty tasty.

Cons
- I ordered the Poulet Vert, the chicken, and it was overly salty and a bit on the dry side.  It felt like there was too much chicken and salt and not enough potatoes and greens to accompany it.  I ended up only eating half the chicken as I couldn't manage to finish the other half.

- The chocolate cream pie dessert we ordered also came with sea salt on top which created a weird flavor and wasn't so tasty as well.
author: Janice C.
