description: You know the food is good when you leave a place and think about it throughout the rest of your day...or dream about it at night (yes I've been here for lunch and dinner). The open faced deviled egg sandwich stayed in my head all day. The baked oysters were unbelievable, as in I really didn't believe it was possible to exceed my expectations like that. Bone marrow = deliciousness. I'm still thinking about that little gem salad I stole a bite of (from my friend's place I promise). Let's just say little gem my ass that is a giant gem in my book. Then we get to this burger that everyone is raving about. I think I may have liked it more than Bauer because I promise you I had a dream I was eating it again that night. Only thing I'm disliking is the fries. They're crisp and flavorful in all the right places but a bit too oily for me..which is terrible because I really like their ketcup.
author: Andrea B.

description:
TO SHARE OR NOT TO SHARE...

This is one of those neighborhood gems that you may not want to broadcast 'cause it's impossible to get in as it is...but you do want to share so others can enjoy the experience.  I like to share so I'll yelp this.

I've yet to tried the famous Marlowe burger so I can't be the judge of that because I've been distracted by the other amazing dishes on the menu.

- Brussels sprout chips - with sea salt and lemon oil - you won't think about brussels sprouts or chips the same way after you try this...I kid you not
- Ox tail marrow - tasty but I'm partial to the ones at Blue Ribbon Brasserie NY
- Parmesan and ricotta cheese dumplings with mushrooms - you won't look at another dumpling after you try this...this is a seasonal dish...so catch it while you can
- Little gem salad - delicate and refreshing
- Boozy spiced prawns  - spicy and tasty
- Polenta with mushroom - best polenta I've ever had!
- Poulet Vert - Well-seasoned chicken with green sauce
- Grilled lamb - tender and well-seasoned and it comes with fresh peas
- Steak and frites - tasty caramelized steak with fries
- Raspberry, lemon cake - light and delicious!
- Chocolate pudding - Great for chocoholics like me!

A+ for food, ambiance and service!

Tip: They have a community table for drop-ins.
author: Lis A.

description: I was able to experience Marlowe during Dine About Lunch. Excellent food, surprisingly good wines and mediocre service. The room was much smaller than I expected; thus LOUD and claustrophobic when full. I would return as long as the room wasn't packed.
author: Richard L. D.

description: Awesome service, excellent food, great atmosphere. Make reservations in advance to avoid waiting in line. Great for a weeknight dinner.
author: Farid H.

description:
My boyfriend and I were at a Giants-Dodgers night game, but our hunger didn't arrive until the eight inning when all the concessions were closed. We decided to take a chance on Marlowe even though it was a Saturday night and we were sure it would be packed.

Packed it was, but we were seated at the bar within a half hour, barely making a dent in our carafe of cab franc. Brussels sprout chips and bone marrow to start -- both were excellent, although the sprouts were a little too greasy. For entrees we had the burger (very tasty but cooked medium-plus, not the asked-for medium rare) and the pork chop (also a little overdone), which came with a fantastic spinach and ricotta bread pudding. We forgave the doneness issues because we had front-row seats of a kitchen meltdown, which kept us entertained.

The bartender took pity on us being surrounded by drunk baseball fans (it pays to be from out of town and not wearing Giants gear) and comped us two glasses of cab franc and two glasses of vin santo with our dessert.
author: Kevin D.

description: I came here for my birthday with my girlfriends last week. We had an amazing meal at this cute little restaurant. I LOVED LOVED the brussel sprout chips. They were to die for and very addicting. We ate it all so fast that we had to order an second order. The bone marrow, burger, and pork chop were delicious as well. I can't wait to go back. This week my coworker will be celebrating her birthday there. I hope she will have a fantastic experience, too!
author: Michele L.

description:
went for a company luncheon, so this is judging without concern over price.*

a lot smaller than I would have thought, only a few tables available, and at 8 we were definitely the hugest group in the room, taking over 1/5 of the space. but the delight of large groups is getting lots of little sides--the brussel sprout chips were AMAZING. like flaky crisps of lemony herbaceous flavor. everyone's face lit up on the first munch. 

the french fries were fried frenchly to perfection. the horseradish aioli presented a delightful crisp spicy counterpoint. just those two sides alone were joy-inducing. i didn't even finish half my burger since i was still munching on all the little snacks. even in my half-full stupor i was able to appreciate the charred meat delight on my medium rare beef. a charming place with delicious foods and a friendly atmosphere with ninja-like service. recommended
author: Jade L.

description:
I've been to Marlowe twice so far, once for a work dinner and once with a good friend.  Both experiences were fantastic, from an ambience, food, and service perspective.

The atmosphere at this place is lovely.  It's like a cozy, modern brasserie with warm lighting. It was a fun place to go with colleagues for an after-work dinner yet it was also right for an intimate 3-hour dinner with a friend.

Also, I've fallen in love with brussel sprout chips.  I think I dreamed about them the other night.  I crave them.  

I really must give a shout out to the baked oysters too, which have a beautiful combination of flavors.  I rarely taste baked oysters that don't taste more baked than oyster.

So far, I've had the burger (which I think rivaled my other favorite burger in the city @ Zuni) and the lamb. The lamb was perfectly cooked and just simply delicious.  It is so refreshing to go to a restaurant and have a dish that is done just right.  Not overdone or underdone.  And lamb is one of my favorite things to order.

The wine list is smart and well-studied by the servers.  I had a beautiful crisp South African brut to start and a perfectly paired red with lamb.

The service was attentive without being intrusive.  For a new restaurant, I was impressed with the pace and timing of dinner.

I will definitely be back...need to try the cod next time.
author: Sean L.

description:
I was looking forward to trying Marlowe-- heard good things, menu looked fantastic, it's always packed on weekend nights-- and when I finally did I wasn't blown away.

The menu was a unique take on familiar items, which I loved.  Had I been a little more brave or willing to spend more money, maybe my experience would have been different.  As it was, we got a half bottle of wine, which was tasty, a "snack" of toasted pistachios (YUM!) and I got steak frites, which I didn't think was anything spectacular. My boyfriend got the pork chops stufffed with spinach ricotta, which I thought sounded great but he said was just "all right."  And of course, as is to be expected, everything is a little on the pricey side.

A good experience, but I'd rather go try new places before coming back here.
author: Katy R.

description:
Yes, the brussel sprout chips were amazing.

This fish was perfect.  My friend and I both ordered the sole (complimented with dungeness crab?!?!) and were far from disappointed.  The service was terrific.  We showed up for our reservations early and the staff rushed to clean off one of the nicer tables to accommodate us.

Maybe it was the ambiance, the company... or maybe the wine, but I left this place in SUCH a great mood...  I'll be back!
author: Lauren R.

description: Mmmmmmm!!!!!! This place is sooooo delicious my mouth is watering just thinking about it! Every morsel of food that went into my mouth was memorable...from the succulent shrimp app, Brussels sprout chips, & the Pork Chop which by the way was the juiciest pork chop I have eaten in a loooong time. Only draw back...no full bar:( Can't wait to go back!!!
author: ada l.

description:
This place is awesome- 

Poullet Vert- mmmmm
Pork Chop- transformed into something heavenly

Definitely recommending it to friends and definitely returning!
author: Beebe J.

description:
Had a nice dinner with my BFF last night here and we both thought it was just OK.

We had:
baked oysters
brussels sprout chips
burger
chicken

The baked oysters were just OK. Lots of cheese. I hardly tasted the oyster itself. Quite salty for my taste too.

The brussels sprout chips were good. It was too oily though. I was nibbling them throughout dinner and as it cooled, you can really see all the oil it soaked up. 

The burger was again....OK. It wasn't what I expected it to be. Reading the reviews, I expected it to blow my mind. But it was just a burger. The meat was pretty good and there was a lil kick to it. But nothing that blew my mind. The fries the burger came with was not the way I liked it. It was extra extra crispy. It was to the point of being hard. Tasted like Burger King fries. 

The chicken though was pretty daym moist. It was the best chicken I had (esp since I'm not a chicken fan). But the sauce it was on was too salty. It made the broccoli that came with it too salty also.

The service here is really good though. It's a very small place, but the ambiance is quite nice.
author: Mai H.

description:
Came for dinner, left confused:

+water refills. bussers were on top of it. (not a good sign i led the review talking about water)
+food service. they gave me an extra half bone since half my bone marrow order was skimpy.  
+burger. overall a decent, juicy burger cooked to the perfect medium rare (as requested). proportion of bun/toppings to burger could've used some work though, and the beef essence was almost masked completely. horseradish aioli was sharp and creamy, though it almost overpowered the beef entirely.
-bizarre service. server didn't hit our table up for drinks until 10 min. had passed. server ignored our request to order food along with our drinks. they served a skimpy bone that required additional fixing later on.

What could've made for a decent meal with friends was marred by poor service.
author: Alvin Y.

description:
Love, love love.
I was a big fan of South, but Marlowe takes it up a notch. Outstanding service, spot on food. You know you're having a good night when you can't help but say, wow, this is REALLY good with every bite. I can't wait to go back.
author: Jen S.

description:
great place to have lunch or dinner. been here a few times and haven't been disappointed. the food is great and we always try lots of items on the menu and usually enjoy them all.

i also like the ambiance of the place...it's happenin' but intimate at the same time. and feels comfortable.

special shout out to the marlowe burger which i would call on the "fancier" side but hey, sometimes fancy is fun :) it's a super yummy burger that comes with cheese, caramelized onions, bacon and horseradish aioli. you can get it during lunch or dinner. highly recommended!
author: Jill L.

description:
i had never been to south but marlowe seems to be doing much better!  people are always outside waiting for a table.  we thought we would take our chances and walk in at around 8 on a friday night and were seated within 20 minutes at the bar.  the hostess is really good about letting you know what the situation is.

the dandelion and burdock soda is a bit medicinal.  we had the artichoke soup with mushroom to share.  it was good!  light and well seasoned.  once we got the soup we had to wait another 45 minutes to an hour for our entrees.  blah. i was getting ansty and beginning to starve and get irritated.  they ran out of the brussel sprout side but had the chips which we didnt get.  we got the cauliflower au gratin instead which is basically like macaroni and cheese.  yum!  

i had a taste of the burger and it is really good.  juicy and tasty.  i ordered the black cod.  i think because its such a hearty, oily fish, it probably needs to be marinated.  here, they did it with just some salt.  so its a bit fishy.  its cooked perfectly though but tastes a bit bland.  the veggies underneath were well seasoned.

for dessert, we had the apple crisp with bourbon ice cream.  they serve all their desserts in these small mason-ish jars.  cute!  the dessert was yummy!

on another occasion we came back for dinner again.  turns out they removed the dandelion and burdock soda from the menu.  they dont have a full bar here so only champagne cocktails.  i tried the special prosecco cocktail and it was good.  we shared some deviled eggs which were good.  not your regular deviled eggs at all.  we did try the brussel sprout chips and they were good!  i also got to try to chicken and pork chop this time.  both were delicious!!

we got the TCHO chocolate cream pie and also the pear crisp and i did start noticing the initial criticism of marlowe oversalting.  these two desserts were salty!  so salty that we didnt even dent the chocolate one!  it was SO salty!  like swallowing sea water
author: claudia y.

description:
I love you Marlowe. 

Last night the bf and I decided to have a chill date night around our neighborhood.  We always drive/walk/run by Marlowe (admiring all the funny quotes on their windows), but have never tried it - and man we were missing out!! 

We came here on a Friday night (no reservations) and we were greeted by a sweet hostess who immediately gave us a drink menu.  She was so quick - I swear one minute we said one IPA and a Pinot Noir and by the time we turned around, we had our drinks in our hands.  

We got to lounge around in front while we waited for our bar table seats to open up.  Once they did we were greeted by the friendly face of Craig - the ultimate waiter/bartender extroidinare! Craig was helpful in explaining to us the contents of the menu and was so on point with asking us if we wanted a refill for our wine & beer.  Honestly, Craig is the MAN!! My bf and I heart you!

As for the food - everything was spectacular.  We had the toasted pistachios, bone marrow, prawns, baked oysters, and we shared the marlowe burger -- ALL SOOO AMAZING!  

To my fellow carnivores out there - please come here and show some love to one of the BEST restaurants in the SOMA area.  I will be coming here frequently :P
author: Cherlyn M.

description: Had a good meal here while catching up with an old friend. Headed there in the early evening, made a reservation on open table. Seating in close proximity but all in the spirit of trendy bistro style dining. The fried brussel sprouts were fantastic, as everyone has raved. They were on the oily side, however. I also enjoyed the baked oysters and loved the roasted bone marrow. The latter is difficult to present well - it is, after all, a single bone that's been stuck in the oven and roasted...there's nothing elegant or elaborate about it. It's the accompaniments that characterize a good roasted bone marrow, and Marlowe's was pretty good (if you are a big marrow fan and ever in Toronto, check out The Black Hoof). The bread wasn't as generous as it could've been, and no one wants to sit staring into a soupy pile of oil and fat waiting for another round of carbs for very long. Overall though, a pleasant place that I'd return to on another trip out to San Fran.
author: Hope C.

description:
Dim lights, super romantic and very quaint. 

We came across this gem last week when we were looking for a late dinner on a weekday. 

We had the gem salad which I really enjoyed, the green chicken and the steak tartare. Loved all of them and can't wait to go back for the bone marrow!
author: Nez B.

description:
Brussel sprout chips, Brussel sprouts in butter, grilled pork chop, spicy prawns, steak tartare are all excellent and melt in your mouth. 

We went here for a late dinner and were so impressed by the great service and quality of food. Good date spot, dim lighting, classic 80's music in the background. I love that this place is in the neighborhood, we'll be coming back often!
author: Tami W.

description:
Am I the only one who is really sad that South has been replaced with Marlowe or is anyone out there in mourning with me? I love Oz cuisine, and South was the only place in the Bay Area to get it. 

I went, I tasted the burger, and I have to say it's not this hype worthy people! Yes it's good, but it's so over the top because of the toppings. The burger at Slow Club, Zuni, or even more casual places like Acme is just as good in my opinion. I love the one at Eos also. 

I get the sense people like Marlowe because everything at the place is really flavorful, especially the burger. And you know why? Because they use lots of fatty ingredients, so it tastes good. This is an example of a restaurant relying on sheer sinful calories to make things tasty and most people falling for it.
author: Shoshana D.

description:
Great service.
We had reservations and still ended up waiting 20-30 minutes. The hostess apologized and gave us complimentary champagne. She also, then asked us which table we preferred - we ended up with a great corner spot and only waited a few minutes longer, thanks to her. This is how all places should handle this situation, it was great and made us want to come back!

The food was really delicious - my husband had the burger, I had the risotto.
author: Kerry F.

description:
My sis and I were looking for a place to have dinner and catch up, somewhere between the CalTrain station and BART. The polenta with poached egg on the menu sold me, so we chose Marlowe.

In an earlier review, someone said it was right for an intimate 3-hour dinner with a friend. Not quite. We tried that and apparently presented a bit of a problem for the staff. We made a reservation for 6:30 on a Friday, arrived closer to 6:00, just planning to have a glass of wine at the bar while waiting. Turns out our table was ready, so the hostess sweetly seated us right away. 

We each had two glasses of wine, the brussel sprouts, burrata with radish, the polenta, and the burger. All the food was good, but my favorites were the appetizers. Bill plus tip came out to a bit over $100. A little pricey but not unexpected.

We were still talking, lingering over our drinks, about 2 hours later. Them giving us the bill was a strong hint they wanted us to leave, but we weren't ready. After more time passed, the hostess came and said she had people waiting for our table and, that if we moved to the bar, she would buy us a drink. It was a little awkward to grab our stuff and move because my sister was still drinking her coffee, but we felt bad for taking long so we moved. There wasn't space at the bar, so we sat at a long table near the bar. No drink ever materialized, and the hostess didn't approach us again. 

I understand it was Friday and that we were taking a long time. But don't promise a drink and not deliver! This doesn't mean I wouldn't come back for (a shorter) dinner again, but I did think it was unnecessary.
author: Priscilla H.

description:
three words...SO MUCH SALT.

maybe i'm not an experienced brussel sprouts eater but the brussel sprout chips were cute, but they had a bitter aftertaste after you got past all the salt. 

the marrow was good, very velvety.

the burnt part on my brioche bun really overtook my palate and made it hard for me to enjoy my burger. and for some reason my break was also really hard and not soft like the other people at my table. the fries were great after i scraped off some salt. 

the chocolate mousse...thank gosh we asked them to take the salt off because the pistachios were so salty. 

it's okay food but i probably won't come back again, unless my sister wants to come back.
author: Loan H.

description:
We originally had community table reservations, but we came a little late and so our spot was taken. But the hostess with the mostess hooked us up with a real table even though they were packed, with people waiting for their seats at the bar and a couple who dropped in were told it was a 45 min wait!!! AWESOMENESS!!!

We had a certificate so we went a little ballistic and ordered like crazy. We started with brussel chips (not bad), followed by their clam chowder baked oyster (da bomb!!!). For mains we had the crab stuffed sole, green chicken, and a pork chop - lol... The sole was decent, the green chicken was yummy, but their pork chop was very very good. Almost NOPA good :D We wrapped it up w/ the lemon raspberry souffle... eh... I was a little bummed that they were all out of the brussel sprouts with brown sugar though.

All in all a very good dining experience. I need to come back to taste their famous burger :) Can't wait!!! You better have my brussel sprouts though :P
author: Minh V.

description:
get the Marlowe Burger + Fried Chicken Sandwich. 
get their fries + horseradish dip. (which comes with the burger or sandwich)

I liked the ambience a lot. Cool, casual place to take a buddy or a group. (they have a long table which can seat at least 15)

Not a must-go, must-eat place. But nice to go if you're in the area!
author: Miss A.

description:
LOVED my dinner at Marlowe.
My friend and I split the Brussels sprouts chips..with meyer lemon, bone marrow and a burger.
Everything was super tasty and reasonably priced.
The burger was one of the best I've had in the city for sure.
The one drawback was that it was extremely warm in the restaurant, the space is small and was packed.
Other than that, all good. 
I will be back soon.
author: Karlee D.

description:
Lunch at Marlowe during Dine About Town.

Wednesday 1230pm- must say it was pretty packed with people waiting outside. The service was nice and didn't rush lunch, probably just over an hour.

Atmosphere: work lunches, and friends meeting friends for lunch. no hipsters at this joint.

Little Gem Salad- beautiful to look at, romaine leaves with avocado topped with beets, carrots, and other colorful veggies.  At first I thought it was delicious, but as I ate more it became increasingly salty and oily.  

Shrimp on a Roll- I don't remember what it was called exactly. Shrimp were large and juicy.  The roll had a bit too much sauce for me and was a little messy to eat, but I managed to devour it.  I think it could have been made a little lighter.
author: Skye W.

description: The deviled eggs are delicious. Also the steak tartare. The ambiance is nice -- standard minimalist style that is popular these days. The wait staff is also really friendly.
author: Johnny D.

description:
Best lunch in SOMA right now.  I live locally and try to eat out for lunch every Monday if I can.  In the last few months I've been to Ironside, Primo Patio, Tres Agave, Le Mar, Mehfil, Gordon Biersch, Specialty's, and OSHA.  Each is good in it's own right but bite for bite, I left Marlowe feeling most satisfied.  Here's the skinny (or fatty if you prefer) on what we ordered:

- Started with the Classic Steak Tartare ($11) with poached quail egg and crostini.  It was perfectly done.

- Ordered the Brussel Sprout chips ($6) to snack on while we waited.  These are a must have!  Light, crispy, tasty, and much healthier than fries!

- I had the Marlowe burger ($12).  While it was slightly smaller than burgers found elsewhere, it made up for it in taste.  The patty was perfectly seasoned and juicy and the horseradish aioli added a nice spicy touch.  I had the seasonal greens which were fresh and lightly dusted with a delicious dressing.

- She had the Warm open faceed deviled egg sandwich with pickled chili, bacon, and aged provolone ($9).  It was by far the best egg sandwich I've ever tasted.  The fries were the perfect crispy texture and came with the same horseradish aioli that was on the burger.  I don't normally eat fries but I couldn't stop stealing them from her plate!

- The special drink of the day was a blood orange iced tea with mint ($5 for a caraffe) and it was just the right amount of sweet and minty to cut the meal.  Again, a must have.

We didn't have room for the deserts but saw some on the tables next to us.  They looked good!  We also didn't order any wine but I did peek at the list - great selections from all over the world as well as local wineries.  

The place is small (same space as predecessor South Food and Wine) but modern with clean lines and exposed steel beams, and somehow cozy at the same time with comfy booth seats around the perimeter and rustic wood tables to balance.  There's one community table that will work for a group.  Take a second to read the quotes on the windows outside to add a little extra something to your experience.

Well done Marlowe...we'll be back for sure!
author: Kris N.

description: I've been here twice and love this place! The brussel sprout chips are amazing; I feel like I'm eating healthy (I tell myself to ignore the copious amounts of oil) and getting my chip fix. I also enjoyed the cauliflower cheese dish, because who doesn't like cauliflower and cheese?
author: Jacqueline K.

description: Super tasty and elegant plating. But small dishes, few vegetarian hearty choices, and  just slightly pricey (again for the portion).
author: Mahsa K.

description:
I did a back-to-back date with friends here. First, met a friend for a drink and then another friend for dinner. It is definitely a convenient location (with tons of parking nearby!) and right off the Caltrain for those commuting back to SF.

For date #1: I was surprised to see there were no cocktails but there was a drink special, mixing Prosecco and watermelon juice for $11. I honestly felt that there was nothing special about this drink, and a bit steep in price for just mixing two liquids together (way more of the juice than Prosecco). I wish I had just gotten a beer.

For date #2: I ordered a deviled egg, the little gem salad and green garlic soup. All were fantastic, and very well seasoned. The deviled egg had a small slice of bacon on it and was definitely one of the richest deviled eggs I've ever eaten - a great way to start a meal. The little gem salad was no wimpy salad. There was avocado in it, shavings of radish and lots of parsley. The dressing was a bit acidic, but overall a good new take on the little gem salad, which is on a lot of menus these days. The green garlic soup was also very good and well seasoned. It came with what I think was a mussel tapenade, which was definitely too salty, and I left most of it alone. My friend ordered the burger, and I had a bite. I understand what the buzz is about - definitely will be ordering that next time.

Overall, for the price, I would have probably given this place a 4.5 stars if I hadn't ordered the drink that I had.
author: Jessica D.

description:
This place is located right across from the Caltrain station.  Restaurant is cute and surprisingly small so I think resies are a good idea.  I came on a Thurs night and found parking across the street for free.  Now onto the food:

- their cocktail of the day was this lovely blend of prosecco and passionfruit juice, it was money
- brussel sprout chips: really yummy and also just a really unique thing to eat, it was nice and salty and lemony
- seared cod had this awesome crispy skin with super soft flesh that was cooked perfectly
- cauliflower gratin was essentially mac and cheese but with cauliflower...it was a little bowl of heaven
- I was a little disappointed in the dessert.  We got the apple crisp and it was just vanilla ice cream with a tiny bit of apple crisp on top.  It came in this little jar that was a little difficult to share and 85% of it was just ice cream and I was hoping for more of a 70-30 apple crisp to ice cream ratio

Overall quite the yummy meal.  I would definitely come back again and try some of their other food.  I hear the burger is great.
author: Doris L.

description:
Carnivores rejoice in this warm, rustic butcher shop inspired SOMA bistro. 

Food: I'm a fan. Lots of flavor in every bite. In order of deliciousness - 
-Brussel sprout chips - Give me anything that is deep fried, oily, salty, crunchy and I'll put it at the top of my must try list. These brussel sprout chips are worth all the hype.
-Marlowe burger - I'm not much of a burger person, but this burger was delish. The patty was cooked to medium rare perfection - each bite was crazy juicy with the salty yumminess of bacon. 
-Roasted bone marrow - Smokey, earthy bone marrow served with a crunchy crostini and an amazing pickled salsa. I could've eaten more!
-Little gem salad - Beautiful salad, and refreshingly tasty too. The avocado added great flavor and texture. Citrus vinaigrette I wanted to bottle up and take home.
-Upside down pear crisp - Super duper sweet, but with all my favorites. Bourbon ice cream, brown butter, caramel. Yummm.
-TCHO chocolate cream pie in a jar - If you love chocolate, you'll love this dessert. I wasn't the biggest fan.
-Anson Mills polenta - This was just OK, a bit mushy and bland. It is a meat place after all. I've had amazing polenta at Bottega in Napa and this just doesn't compare. At all.

Service: Not perfect, but good. We got there a few minutes after they opened, so it took them a while to figure things out like where we should sit, who our server was, etc. Oh and they almost gave our burger to the couple next to us. Aside from those minor details, they were friendly, attentive, and thoughtful. 

Ambiance: Cozy, charming, dim. Noise level could use some work. When the restaurant was empty, the music was loud which is fine. When the tables were filled, they didn't turn the music down so we had to talk loudly to hear each other.

Tip: If you want a table for 2, make resos!  We came here at 5:30pm on a Thursday night, and we ended up sitting at the communal table which would have worked had we been a group of 4. Instead, it ended up being really awkward to negotiate bench seating with strangers and then hear every word of their conversation.
author: Connie C.

description:
The first time I went here, they didn't have our reservation because something was wrong with the BB OpenTable app.  Fail.

Next time I went, I made triple sure that we had our reservation and I even had my email confirmation queued up.  Didn't need it since my name was right up there at the top of the list.  

I must say, the service level of my server was top-notch.  Yes, it's a little restaurant near the ballpark, so I would imagine it doesn't attract the creme de la creme, but I was happily wrong.  Our reservation was for 6p and my friend was running late from work, so I ended up sitting at the table for a good 20 minutes before she showed up.  My server (didn't get her name, so we'll call her Carla), was attentive and continued to check on me, in a non-hostile way.  When my friend showed up, "Carla" said "she's here!" in the happiest of tones I've ever heard.

On to the food.  Whenever I see bone marrow on a menu, I must have it.  This one did not disappoint.  I really enjoyed the salsa verde and little herb salad.  It really did a good job of cutting the fat.  The wine "Carla" recommended also went very well with it.  I also very much appreciate it when the bone is cut in half, versus the traditional way.  It makes it much easier to get every little morsel of goodness out.  My friend had the steak tartare and it too was very tasty.  It came with a poached quail egg (which was interesting) and had the right balance of flavors.

Our entrees were the poulet vert and the pork.  I really liked that the pork came with a piece of the rib.  It was all very tasty.  We also ordered the brussel sprouts, which I found to be funny.  They have their famed brussel sprout chips, and the hearts of those brussels are what's used for the side dish.  So it looked like brussel hearts.  Either way, they were tasty.

I'm definitely coming back for the spicy prawns and more bone marrow.  Hopefully everyone there is as nice and professional as Carla.
author: Alison N.

description:
Came here with my friend on a somewhat late night and was pretty much forced to park at one of the ridiculous meters due to a game that was happening that night. Just about every street parking within the area is metered parking so keep a note of that and will gouge you if there's a game going on.

The hostess was very nice and accommodating, we waited roughly 15 minutes and sat at the bar/counter. We started with deviled eggs which were pretty good but I felt like that the bacon was overpowering so I didn't get much of anything else other than bacon and creaminess from the yolk.

We also got the crab cake which was excellent, the only thing I could ask for is perhaps a bit of sauce and even though the crab cake itself wasn't dry, it felt like that it could have used some sauce for a bit more moisture. It also came with a small citrus salad which was surprisingly good.

We both got the burger and it's probably by far one of the best burgers I've had. It was cooked perfectly with great buns to accompany it by absorbing some of the juices. The fries were also very good; crispy on the outside, a bit mushy on the inside. It also comes with additional aioli should you wish to put more on your burger or use it as a condiment for your fries.

Over all, I had a great experience here. Service was great, food was great, the only gripe I have about this place is the parking but it is of no fault of theirs. Definitely see myself coming back here again.
author: Richard C.

description: Amazing food! I made reservations on open table and was running a little late and they did not mind at all. They accommodated us and thanked us for calling ahead. (was even right after giants game) I ordered the Baked oysters, brussel sprout chips, calamari, baked cauliflower and the English pea pancakes. Everything was amazing. The baked oysters were the best oysters i have ever had in my life. highly recommend and will defiantly repeat frequently. only down was that it was VERY loud. The sound was reflective off the tiled walls.
author: Jaclyn S.

description:
Marlowe, Marlowe, Marlowe...what to do with you?

Your burger costs thirteen dollars, exactly double price of the delicious burger up the street. And while your burger is good, I wonder whether it is twice as good as Un-named Delicious Burger up the street. Once you get to charging THIRTEEN DOLLARS for a burger, you have to wonder whether it is, as Un-named Chronicle Food Critic feels it is, in the running for being the best burger in town. Unfortunately, the Marlowe burger has a problem of grease overload, especially when you add in the fries that come with the burger. Each fry feels supersaturated with fat, like it's made out of foie gras or something. Foie gras is delicious, but one can only eat so much of before feeling funny! After several lunches at Marlowe, I have to classify their burger as too much of a good thing, at double the price.

We wanted to wash our lunch down with a shot glass full of an industrial-strength de-greaser. Is that how YOU want to feel?
author: Ian G.

description: 5 stars for fantastic meal, great ambiance, informed and attentive service. Well done Marlowe
author: Tatum T.

description:
Cute little restaurant. Great Service - and food. ( good date place )

Baked Oysters were super yummy.
Their Shrimp Starter was nicely done as well.
Main dish - their Sole and Brussels were a great combo. 
The salad we got was OK ( something tangy )
author: ThuZ W.

description:
Excellent restaurant.  The menu was so amazing that we weren't sure what to get.  The bone marrow certainly stands out.  And well, EVERYTHING ELSE.  There was nothing that we didn't like.  Really.

We also had a very large party... one of those parties that keeps changing sizes up and down as we get closer to the reservation.  The staff was super accommodating the whole way, and helped us through the exasperation of our flakey dinner companions. =)
author: Jon S.

description: Great new spot! Kind of place you are going to have to go back to repeatedly to take full advantage of the menu. I heard a ton about the burger and was not disappointed.
author: Matthew K.

description:
Good grub and good atmosphere. Love the natural vibe of this place. It isn't pretentious and just very cozy.

Here's what we ordered:
Baked Oysters - it was just ok, the toppings tasted like baked potato toppings
Deviled Eggs - YUM!
Fried Brussel Sprout Chips - A bit oily, but tasty
Polenta - love the flavor and the mushrooms
Some fish dish - yummy and tender
Spicy Prawns - nothing special
Pear dessert - WAY too sweet
author: Vanessa W.

description:
-Brussels Sprout Chips-
Simply awesome. Delicate crispy leaves with a brush of meyer lemon zest. I wanted to hoard it to myself and eat it like a bowl of cereal. I relented and shared. It's good friendship food.

-Market Radishes with Whipped Goat Cheese-
It sounds so simple and while it is, they've elevated it to something sublime. Chopped and thinly shaved radishes, black (or was it red?) salt and herbs accompany the goat cheese.

-French Fries with Horseradish Aioli-
Fries that taste like potatoes! Wonderfully hot and crisp on the outside and earthy potato inside. Devour them immediately before they cool. The horseradish aioli is a genius tangy dip.

-Lamb Mixed Grill-
I've never had lamb this tasty, really.  A beautiful, buttery piece of lamb held together by the perfect sear on the outside. I gnawed on the bone.

-Anson Mills Polenta-
Comfort food for cold or rainy nights. Kinda sensual with richness from the golden-yolked-poached egg. A bowl of hugs for your mouth.

-Upside down apple crisp-
With bourbon ice cream and brown butter caramel sauce served in a homey jar. The clear winner for an after-dinner, palate-sweetener. 

-Ambiance-
SF-chill, intimate space and relaxed.

-Service-
Not too sweet, not mean. Just perfectly professional.

-Accessibility-
Parking is street-simple and access is easy from freeway or Caltrain.
author: Thanh T.

description:
Two Stars for slow service and running out of entrees (who runs out of hamburgers?)  Since they were out on entrees I had to order two appetizers, neither of which were any anything special.

Hopefully can re-review when they get their act together and work out the kinks in service. We had to wait 45 minutes for french fries and cauliflower au gratin which is pretty poor.
author: Zk K.

description:
Marlowe truly redeemed themselves from the mistakes made on one of my visits.  The owner of the place took the time to explain what happened and gave me a certificate to try the place out again.  

I saw the main executive chef there and knew my office would want to try it out again.  Great food.  I am a big fan of their vinaigrette with the salads. 

Great work on managing your reviews, staff and quick follow up.  It shows you are very dedicated to your quality.
author: Milan D.

description: Everything was perfectly done and amazing. I've been waiting a while to come here and it was totally worth it. Sarah was extremely helpful and found us a table earlier than we expected. The service was great and the ambiance was perfect. Romantic, rustic, energetic.
author: Shirley S.

description:
The crowd from South is back!  Marlowe retains the location, some staff, half of the owners from South, and a lot of what that original restaurant did right in terms of super friendly service and innovative cuisine.  This time instead of focusing on Australia, they are focusing on meat.

Atmosphere was pleasant, open and modern.  Tables were a touch small.

Had a radish and goat cheese salad as an appetizer and a blackened cod as an entree.  Both were very good but not mind blowing.  Wine list was appropriate for a neighborhood restaurant.  

In summary, a nice neighborhood eatery to drop into for some good fare served with a smile.
author: David A.

description: Great tasty food.  Nice intimate setting.  I don't think the prices are over-priced, but certainly not a bargain.  I think the portions are on the smaller side, but I still leave feeling full and satisfied.
author: Dan K.

description:
Depressed and downtrodden after being turned away from AT&T Park, the game was sold out and it was my last chance to check out the Giants while I was doing my touristy thing in California, my girlfriend and I decided to catch a bite to eat instead.  Turned to yelp and found a nice, respectable place close by and had no idea what to expect, we were, after all, dining on a whim.

Started off with the Bone Marrow, just because I wanted to see what the heck that even was, and it ended up being tasty.  The texture is something that might take some getting used to, but used as a spread on the soft, soft breads they came with was a genius idea.  However, it was not amazing enough to impress me other than the fact that I was eating Bone Marrow.

We both ordered the burgers, cooked medium, without knowing about the hype, and they were phenomenal.   I don't want to say it was the best burger I've ever had, because it really depends on my mood that day.  Some days I just a fat, greasy, 10 napkin, BMI greater than 35.0, quadruple bypass inducing burger.  This one was definitely one of the tastiest burgers I've enjoyed, and it went down in what felt like seconds.  

All in all a fairly cheap meal for the quality we received (49$ for appetizer, 2x entrees + dessert?)  Service was wonderful, until the end when it was getting a little bit busy and we had a little trouble getting our check, but it was nothing outrageous.
author: Tam V.

description:
The food is not bad but just about every dish was bathed in butter.  There was no punch in any of the dishes.  Decent quality ingredients nonetheless.  The highlight of the place is the room and ambiance.  This is a noisy restaurant and great for drinks and prices are reasonable.

This restaurant is very similar to the Salt House and very typical of many mid-tiered restaurants in the City.  I'd hang out for a casual dinner anytime.
author: Laurence H.

description:
In chatting with some neighbors in our elevator, they strongly recommended the burgers at Marlowe. We love a good burger, so we eagerly headed down to try them.

We were surprised they recommended the burger, since it was the only one on the menu and the only item under $20. Still, we threw down our $11 and ordered away. 

The burgers were pretty decent, though nothing too exceptional, and certainly not for the price. I can't comment on the rest of the menu, but despite having a reservation, it still took 35 minutes to seat us, and then we were seated on bar stools, next to the door, sharing a table with strangers. 

Overall: Meh...
author: Belén T.

description: Great place for dinner after a game :). Food was really rich and flavorful and well presented, staff was really friendly too
author: Mandy C.

description:
Marlowe is good as it gets for bistro style food. And it's so great that they took over the old South spot. That was a really sad closing for me given that my office is just around the corner. It's a small place so don't come with big groups. Bar area is tiny, hot since it faces the kitchen and oftentimes crowded. I'd say no to doing any first dates here either. But grabbing a bite with friends or coworkers before peak time, a definite yes.

These are my faves on the menu: brussel sprout chips (flash fried with sea salt and meyer lemon), steak tartare with quail egg, cauliflower gratin and spicy shrimp (so spicy!). And hands down for sharing is the Poulet Verde which is half a chicken smothered in an herb rub. The burger is good but definitely have had better.
author: Kimmie N.

description: If you stick to appetizers, you'll fint it is worth 5 stars. I've gotten several entrees here but were never as impressed. For appetizers, highly recommend Brussel Sprout chips, Baked Oysters, Prawns, and deviled eggs.
author: Tia G.

description:
The food was way too salty!!!!. Left a bad after taste after every bite. The pistachios are a great start, the burger was very flavorful and juicy with the most accurate medium cook I've had in a while. The upside down strawberry crisp was good but had more salted caramel than fresh strawberry (really??? the strawberries aren't cooked into the crisp, which doesn't really make it a crisp) I was disappointed, and desperately drinking my water to get the salty flavor out Of my mouth. 


On another note, this place should be $$$ and not $$
author: Anna T.

description:
I've been several times now and each time the customer service has been excellent, and the food is delicious. Specifically I am in love with a few things. First, the cauliflower/ cheese dish . . . think macaroni and cheese but its cauliflower instead . . . excellent! I also love the way they serve the oysters and the chicken is to die for! Last recommendation is the bone marrow . . if you like that, try Marlowe's version . . .yum!

The ambiance is very cool  . . . has a chill and loungy look to it, good for a date or with a group of friends. Its amazing how they've turned this spot into such a winner versus the last business that was there.

Finally, kudos to the late night hours. Its so hard to find a place to eat later in the evening and I appreciate you Marlowe for that!! I will be back . . . myabe this Friday :)
author: Elizabeth S.

description: incredible food, atmosphere, service, decor. this place doesn't disappoint.
author: Claire A.

description:
While visiting a friend in the city, she suggested we go to Marlowe.  She lives a couple of blocks away, and had wanted me to try it.  We went to brunch the first time, and we shared the burger and the chicken sandwich.  The burger was amazing, one of the best I have had.  Not too big, great smokey grilled flavor.  If I lived nearby, wouldn't be a good thing :).  The chicken sandwich would have been almost as good, but I really think they needed to change their fryer oil.  I had a weird fishy taste to it.  It was crispy and moist, just shouldn't have tasted like fish.
The second time we went, we went late on a Sunday night.  We weren't looking for a big meal, so we shared the burger again, and tried the chicken fried okra and browned butter brussels sprouts.  Being Southern, I was excited to see fried okra.  It was good, and had an almost creamy texture to it on the inside.  I would fry it a little more crispy and brown than they do, but I still liked it.  Brussels sprouts were great, small, tender and nicely browned and crispy.  We also just ordered a couple of beers. And I think maybe that was a little bit of our waiters issue.  We didn't order a $50 bottle of wine, or a large meal.  I think it irked her a little.  
My reason for taking off a star is the waitstaff. While they have all be nice, the tend to hover too much.  I don't know if they are really trying to turn tables that fast, and really want to get you out of there. But on our last visit, I really didn't appreciate our plates being ripped off the table while we were still eating. We had to ask for our fork back so we could finish.  A simple "are you finished?" would have been nice.  Since it was late, and empty tables nearby, the only thing I can think is that she was in a hurry to get out of there.
Will definitely be back, but I hope not to feel liked I'm being rushed out again.
Oh, and the place is really loud. Doesn't make for a nice dining experience.
author: Robyn W.

description: Came here with a group of friends while in town for a couple nights.  We were blown away by the absolute deliciousness of the brussels sprout chips.  Seriously, I don't know how someone came up with the idea, or how they make them taste so amazing, but I could eat an entire bowl myself for lunch and be perfectly satisfied.  OTHERWISE...the burrata appetizer was very good, and though I didn't try the prawns or the pistachios, everyone else thoroughly enjoyed those, as well.  I had the Marlowe burger (sans bun), which was tasty, though I've had several other burgers in LA that are better, and the bottom of it was a little too charred for my liking.  Dessert was to die for--the upside down strawberry crisp was inventive and each layer was perfectly proportioned.  I would definitely go back here again next time I'm in town...
author: Maggie C.

description:
My husband and I had an amazing dinner here before heading over to the Cavalia show across the way.

We tried the bone marrow because it was so highly rated on yelp..  My first time trying it, it was roasty and fatty and SIMPLY AMAZING.  Don't miss it, thanks yelpers for the recommendation!

The oysters were very good, and I got the polenta (so rich and truffled, the quail egg made it over the top good) and hubby had the rib-eye, which was absolutely delicious - perfect medium rare.  We stuffed the bourbon pear crisp in for dessert, which was fantastic.

We are from Washington State and work in the East Bay most of the year, we'll come back here as often as the place exists, I'm sure!

Prices are reasonable, considering the quality of the food!  Professional wait and kitchen staff.  Definitely get a reservation.  LOVE!!!
author: Mona D.

description:
Came here for lunch on a weekday. Wait time was minimal. Ordered the Marlowe burger. I think it was okay.... Wouldn't come back for the burger. But this is also coming from someone who doesn't crave burgers. 

Nice atmosphere, casual chic. Good place to have lunch and chat. 

I think I would come back to try something different on the menu.
author: connie h.

description:
Marlowe, you redeemed yourself with your amazing burger and your other delights (more on that later).  

Yes, the food was overpriced, and yes, the seating was awkward and cramped (we were seated under a slanted beam on a long table about 8 inches away on either side by other diners), and yes, our waitress was a little hard to get a hold of, but your food was definitely worth it.

The horseradish dipping sauce for the fries was a rare and delicious treat, and your homemade ketchup was an excellent condiment for your gourmet, succulent burger, which had just the right amount of carmelized onions, bacon, and cheddar.

If anyone can make a brussel sprouts taste like a savory candy, it is you, Marlowe. It is amazing how you turned a normally bitter vegetable into something I didn't want to stop eating.  

And let's not even talk about the fact that your summer squash gratin was better than my mom's zucchini and potatoes!! (a sacrilege, because hers are really delicious).  Even our sangria was superb--made with rose wine (a unique touch that brought out the sweetness of the fruit without being too cloying). 
  
If you are looking for bistro fare in an upscale environment where you will leave with an empty wallet but a happy stomach, this is the place for you.

As I was savoring my last bites of my burger, this place made me (a Philadelphia native) mutter "I seriously think I could stay and eat in San Francisco forever...."
author: Nina B.

description:
3.5 stars for Marlowe.  

The food was good, but I had pretty high expectations given the reviews.  I have to agree with another reviewer that the dishes were heavy on the salt.  I ordered the chicken which was very juicy and tender, but a tad too salty for my taste.  The brussel sprout chips were fun, but also on the saltier side.  My friend enjoyed her pork chops, which looked oddly like red meat to me.  It was dark in there, I guess.  I was quite fond of their wine by the glass list because they had a good variety with reasonable prices.  We both enjoyed a couple of glasses. 

The ambiance was lively for a weeknight crowd, but it wasn't so loud that I couldn't carry on a conversation.  Didn't note much else about the place or the service.

Overall, I think Marlowe came up a bit short of my expectations.  It was definitely worth a try and I can see myself giving it another go.
author: Wendy L.

description:
4.5 stars

The food was fantastic! Albert and I both had the same thing. We both had the drink special: cava, elderberry, grapefruit, and lemon drink, shared bone marrow, and each had our own marlowe burger. 

Everything was fantastic. I think the bone marrow was my favorite, it was perfectly decadent! The burger and fries (amazing aioli) were tasty! The sauce was a bit over-powering on the burger, but man was it good! Fries and aioli on the side- deeeeelish.

I'll def be back for more food and I gotta try the desserts! :)
author: Art A.

description: We were late for our reservation but they were gracious and understanding. Our server was excellent! She took care of us but was un-obtrusive. The food was awesome!
author: Robin A.

description:
I had never been to this place when it was South, but boy was it a treat! I was given the incredibly difficult task to find a restaurant, with resos open on a Friday night. With a foodie boyfriend (myself included), that is no easy feat! We walked right in-our reservation was at 9pm and were seated promptly. The owner (can't remember her name) was so gracious, through out the entire meal and was so accommodating. 

We started off by ordering the Spicy Prawns in Hot & Boozy Cocktail Sauce and the Little Gem Salad. And out came the Crisp Brussel Sprout Chips and the Baked Oysters! The oysters were the best baked ones I've ever had, with it seemed like a gratin. All the Yelpers have been saying to get the Brussel Sprout Chips and they were great, but about half-way through they were just too salty. I love how with the Little Gem Salad, there is almost a guacamole in the middle-you could almost eat the leaves like chips, if you were feeling particularly daring. Equally daring, is the Spicy Prawns with the heads. It certainly does keep the flavor in-the dipping sauce was completely not needed-but you won't find me suckin' on brain just yet.

I guess our waiter put in "Polenta" instead of the "Poulet Vert" that I ordered, still workin' out the kinks. But that was A-OK with me because I needed to digest our first course! In between they brought us the Toasted Pistachios, which were cooked in Bourbon-yum!

On to the next course! Like I said, I ordered the Poulet Vert-the half roasted chicken. I have to say, this chicken was so tender, juicy, and perfectly cooked. I was afraid it was going to be a run of the mill chix, but that it was not. The sauce tasted like a coconut-curry type, and my complaint was that it was overly salty and the chicken was drenched in it. My other half ordered seared Black Cod, and let me just say his plate was clean afterward.

Overall, the food was fabulous! The restaurant reminded us of one from New York, very high energy and open.

Will be back again!
author: Ashley H.

description: The ambience is hip and fun, the food is really mediocre. We sent back one of our appetizers because it was overly fishy (smelled like someone opened a can of tuna fish). I ordered the polenta entree and found it lacking in texture. Polenta + egg = gooey. The service was nice, but I wouldn't go back.
author: Avital S.

description: My boyfriend made reservations but we still had to wait about a half hour after our reservation time. However, the hostess was incredibly apologetic and gave my boyfriend's wine and our appetizer on the house. Our appetizer was the brussel sprout chips that were pretty good. I don't particularly like brussel sprouts but these were yummy and crispy. I ordered the steak frites and my ordered the Marlowe burger. The burger was quite tasty but my steak was more charred than I cared for, I requested the steak to be medium rare which was but the flame might  have been too hot that it charred the outside. I would definitely come back to try other items on the menu, we were so starving that we didn't have a chance to really enjoy our food.
author: Linda L.

description:
Love the new look and menu!  First thing I noticed was the fresh floors and comfortable feel.  I have to say its much better than South.

Brussel sprout chips were interesting and tasty.  The bone marrow was delicious! Great wine selection.

Five stars for abiance, service and food.   Great job guys.
author: dion c.

description:
Jennifer Puccio is one of the few chefs that I actually follow.  Ever since I ate at Cortez I've been a big fan.  So when she popped up at Marlowe I came here upon the first week of opening. Upon my 2nd trip I had to get the much hyped burger.  Without a doubt, it really lived up to the hype.  

Marlowe is now one of my top restaurants in the city.
author: Roger H.

description:
Love, love, love this place. The makeover (or is that a makeunder?) from the restaurant formerly known as SOUTH is amazing. You walk in and feel right at home. From the warm greeting of the always smiling and congenial, but never smarmy overbearing owner Anna, to the wonderfully edited wine list created by sommelier and general manager Gerard, to the straightforward, yet bold flavors assembled in the kitchen by Executive Cher Jennifer Puccio, this place is a winner all around. 

The menu is deep enough to give you a wonderfully diverse array of "can't go wrong" choices, without being overwhelmed. Additionally, the price points are great for a night out on your own, with a special someone, or even the whole gang from work. (Did I mention they are steps from the 4th and King Caltrain Station?)

My first trip there was snack heaven with the brussel sprout chips, french fries, the Marlowe Burger and prawns with the kicky "Bloody Mary" sauce. Not a misstep among them.

I will be back and ready to dive into the menu even more deeply. With a friendly staff, modern menu, cool vibe and convenient location, it's a must do when in SF.
author: Michael T.

description:
Just got back from my 3rd trip to Marlowe.  I was a big fan of this place when it was previously South, but now I'm an even bigger fan.  

Marlowe is a very stylish, yet comfortable restaurant.  The food and wine is top notch.

For starters and sides, definitely try the Brussels sprout chips and the shrimp appetizer.  

The little gem salad was delicous as was the cod.   However, I was blown away by the polenta with wild mushrooms, truffle oil, poached egg and arugula.  

If you haven't been here, you should definitely give it a try.  If you have been here, I suspect you'll be back very soon.
author: Dheeraj I.

description:
Wish I can give 3 1/2 star. Not sure why this is such a highly rated place --- I feel like places like these are all over SF. 

Brussel Sprout Chips - fried brussel sprout - cripsy and lightly salted. thumbs up
devil eggs - top with a slice of cheese and bacon...it's apparently their signature...have had better 
pork chop - cooked well, it's medium. (kind of freaks me out that pork isn't cooked all the way) It's topped with a pineapple sauce...good pairing with the pork. 
burger - have had better. Order it if you are in a burger mood - don't order it if you like burgers and are the ones that like to go around town looking for the perfect burger. 
chocolate dessert - can't remember what it's called but it's essentially an oreo crusted dark chocolate mousse. They sprinkled sea salt in there so the combination of sweet chocolate and a hint of saltiness is pretty savoring.
author: Keara C.

description:
My friends and I were looking for a place like this that wasn't in the Mission. It's a cute little place. Dim lighting, cozy and casual. Not ideal for groups, but a great place to relax and have a chill time with a couple friends.

Started off with a cheese plate and wine - always a great way to start off an evening.

Spiced prawns: I thought they were just ok

French fries with a horseradish aoli: crispy with just the right touch of salt.

Smokey Cauliflower Gratin: OMG! soooo yummy!  The aged provolone and the smoked cheddar...it just all melts in your mouth!. It's a must have!

Seared Black Cod: tender, moist and the spinach went every well with it.

Dark chocolate bar pudding: Not quite what I had expected, but the chocolate definitely hit the spot!

It's definitely a place to go back and try some of their other dishes.
author: Fran H.

description:
Very cute place. Great for couples and groups of friends. This place packs them in, so you'd be best to reserve a spot, if you come anytime like happy-hour time.You can always take a chance or just settle up to the bar and dine there. But when we were there we got lucky (not _that_ lucky) because a reservation had just been cancelled. Boo yah!

The bartenders and wait-staff were totally awesome hooking us up with seating --- especially for the late-comers and then hooking me up to some pretty tasty non-alcoholic beverages. That was a special touch rarely seen I have to admit. And the burger that I had ordered medium-rare arrived juicy, succulent, perfect. I can't say much more than that. Except that whoever was dj'ing the music was also doing a stupendous job with the old school R&B. Sweet.

And no I haven't tried the brussel sprout chips, in my zest to try the burger, I didn't really pore over the menu. I just found out about the chips thing like two days ago. So I've got to go back for that and to get another perfectly-made burger.
author: Jen A.

description:
4.25 stars!

Our dining experience here was unusual and memorable in that it got better with each course.  I love when that happens!

We started with the crispy brussels sprout chips--delicious and a fun snack item.  The mix of crispy, salty and the carmelization of the leaves made for a great combo.  The Spiced prawns and Steak tartare starters were both delicious.  The tartare was probably the best version of it I have ever had.

And then the main dishes came.

The seared black cod was perfectly prepared but was dwarfed by the polenta.  I am not usually a big polenta fan, but for Marlowe's version, I would do cartwheels down the street.  The combination of greens, truffled cheese and egg with the smooth and creamy polenta was divine.  Yes--divine!!

Service was very good--attentive, friendly and prompt.

So why not 5 stars?  The place is loud.  The house was full, and it was necessary to shout in order to have a conversation with someone who was seated right next to me.  As well a server didn't quite know a lot about a few of the menu items when we sought a few recommendations.

I will definitely be going back and highly recommend.
author: Jen Y.

description:
A fantastic restaurant.  Marlowe's Poulet Vert is presently the best meal I have ever eaten, and has got to be one of the best roast chicken dishes you'll find in SF.  The devilled eggs are delicious and there is a lovely sparkling muscat on their dessert wine list too.

The food, service and atmosphere at Marlowe are all excellent.  Consequently, it's very popular; aim to reserve a table rather than attempting a walk in.
author: Rebecca N.

description: My husband had a perfect birthday dinner at Marlowe. Our server Mikey summed up the entire night with "Are you ready to go to heaven?" Marlowe is a meat lovers heaven.
author: Kailo M.

description:
Marlowe is a great restaurant with unique menu options, cozy ambiance, and consistent service. The restaurant is relatively small, but the food really speaks for itself. 

My favorites from the menu include the bone marrow, deviled eggs, foie gras (when it was still available), and cauliflower au gratin. My friend also recommends the burger. 

Pretty good wine selection, no beers on tap unfortunately. Will definitely come here again in the future.
author: Teresa K.

description: I've been to Marlowe quite  a few times- and their menu and service is consistent through lunch or dinner.  They have an item on 7x7s big eats list: brussel sprout chips, and they're perfect. The right amount of crisp and salt to them, I get them every time no matter what. They also have a decent burger, worth checking out. Do it.
author: Lacy R.

description:
Joined some of my co-workers here for a business lunch.  The restaurant was new-ish in the neighborhood, and we had been on the lookout for a quiet place with great food.  I had the parsnip soup.  Now, a huge pet peeve of mine is when restaurants fail to describe everything that will be on a dish.  A good example, would be sour cream on Mexican food.  I believe that if you are going to put something on a plate that can change the flavor of the entire dish, it should be stated.  Thus was the case here.  I don't like creme fraiche, and there was a big dollup of it in the soup.  When i brought this to my waitress's attention, she immediately brought me another bowl of soup, sans the creme fraiche.  She also said that they would start including that on the menu going forward [and it appears they have! :)  ]  The soup was delicious! The texture was smoother and consistent throughout.  My dining partners thoroughly enjoyed their dishes as well, which included a shrimp salad that was beautifully presented with heads on, accompanied by a brightly colored endive and cabbage salad.

I would definitely come here again if I'm ever in the area.
author: Lacey H.

description:
We lucked out and scored a table (due to a cancellation) for dinner on a Sat evening.

We ordered:

Brussel sprout chips : crispy and tasty with a hint of salt.  It was pretty good but I can eat about 5 of them because they were on the greasy side.
Baked oysters: fresh, juicy and downright yummy
Baked bone marrow: good I could've used a few more slices of bread to eat it with. 
Marlowe burger: very good and tasty.  The patty was perfectly seasoned and juicy and the horseradish aioli added a nice touch. 

I'll def be back for more especially since I live right across the street.
author: Michelle T.

description:
I decided to go here with my boyfriend when he got back from his business trip. We reserved our seats on OpenTable for dinner. It took a bit longer than expected. Our reservation was made for 9:00 PM. We were seated at 9:30 PM. It was busy when we got there. They served us complimentary champagne for our patience. Which was great. :D

We had the sweet corn soup, baked oysters and roasted bone marrow for starters. The soup was delicious, creamy, soothing, mild but tasty. The bone marrow was good but it really isn't something we would order again. The consistency was kind of off - jelly like not creamy. The taste was decent.

I had the Poulet Vert. Delicious. The portions are very generous for this plate. I got a thigh, wing, and breast - generously served over tasty vegetables. I was almost full by the time I cleared half of my plate. When I finished the meal I was very satisfied.

My boyfriend had the Grilled Lamb. The portions were a bit smaller than the Poulet Vert but still moderately generous. The meat was perfectly cooked. Very tender, juicy and flavourful. 

The atmosphere, yet again, was very loud. Then again, it's busy, it's popping and people love to meet and talk there.

The service was great. Our waiter was very attentive and the hostess was very friendly, talkative and made our wait not seem as long even with our grumbling stomachs.

I highly suggest this spot for anyone looking for affordable American (New) food with generous portions. I'm very impressed yet again for the 2nd time.
author: Sara M.

description:
Normally I steer free of restaurants which looks pretentious or too fancy, but this place won me over, the service was friendly and the food amazing. I had the Poulet Vert and my husband the burger, we shared the artichoke soup as an appetizer. The chicken was just perfectly cooked and the sauce was delicate and had me begging for more, the soup was  a new experience to us but we both loved it, the flavors were good together and there was a little bit of salt crystals on the top which we loved.
The service was a little slow, but they seemed busy and very nice so it was not a big deal to me!
author: Christina L.

description: This is a nice place.  I've eaten here a couple of times and came away happy both evenings.  My highlights are the deviled eggs (wish I could eat these all day) , bone marrow (ummm, this is awesome!) & the burger ( nice size, killer fluffy bun & a tasty ass burger).  You can't go wrong with these three.  I also had the steak & pork chops...these were good as well but not as memorable as the top 3.   The service is good for how crowded this place gets.  Fairly hip joint!! My only bummer...no full bar.
author: Ramon L.

description:
Such a great place, I can't believe it's taken me so long to try it. Came here on a friend's recommendation and had the steak tartare, baked oysters, soup, pork chop and roasted chicken (has a long name that I don't remember) oh and desert was chocolate creme pie, and lemon souffle. Everything was so good, the pork chop was perfectly cooked (medium) and I wouldn't be going out on a limb to say that the chicken was some of the best I've ever had. i thought the lemon souffle was heaven, my boyfriend liked the chocolate a little more, and everything was paired with a really nice wine. all in all, a great experience.

They also had really great service, our server was sweet and competent and the manager was really fun and quirky. Definitely 5 stars all around.
author: Lauren B.

description: I came here years ago and go lamb.  It was single-handedly the BEST meal I've EVER had in San Francisco.  I've tried to replicate this dish repeatedly, but with only a fraction of the success that the cooks here had.  I wish I had reviewed it years ago, but I plan on bringing a hot date here in the next few weeks :)  Update...to be continued!!!
author: Jessi K.

description: Five ladies, aged 60 to 60+++ went to lunch today at Marlowe. We had reservations at 1:30 and they put us at a bar table with bar stools. Two in our party need the support of a chair back and we requested a table. As a result there was a brief wait at the bar, 15 minutes maybe? And guess what, they treated each of us to a drink to apologize for a delay that wasn't even their fault! They were lovely, the food yummy, service spot on and the kindsness shown to us senio-strangers was over the top. I highly recommend it. We ate way too much and left feeling like youngsters again.
author: Nancy B.

description: Disappointed. Terrible attitude by the staff! Overpriced food. I asked to get mushrooms instead of bacon on a $18 burger and I was told they can not do replacements! The server was very rude. Wont recommend to anyone. There are great places nearby. I regret wasting my time and money there.
author: Sam N.

description: A fantastic place to eat.  The chicken and scallop entrees were fantastic along with the baked oysters and deviled eggs.  If you're trying to circumvent reservations and hit the bar, come early.
author: Jeff P.

description: The brussels sprouts and bone marrow were delicious.  The long benches  at the communal tablesare a little challenging in a dress, but the restaurant ambiance generally is warm and intimate.  I would definitely go again.
author: Catherine T.

description:
Everything about Marlowe was incredible.

I had a reservation for 4 people up until an hour prior, at which point I called and lowered the number to 3...no problem. Then approximately 5 minutes prior, I was still at home waiting for a cab with my friend, when we learned that our third party member had forgotten the reservation entirely - awkward.

I called the restaurant yet again and explained our plight. Melanie, the hostess, asked when we could all reasonably be there, and I told her 8:30 (1/2 hour after the reservation's originally scheduled time). She graciously offered to hold our table.

When we got there (around 8:25), our table was nearly ready. Melanie was so sweet and shook my hand upon arriving, realizing I was just a wee bit frazzled. From the moment we sat down, the service was outstanding. Our waitress (who seemed more like the manager, honestly), was so knowledgeable, guiding us through every course of the meal. After fun champagne cocktails (they do not appear to have a liquor license), we started with the salted lemon brussel sprout chips...as good as rumored, and deviled eggs (never my thing, but these were great with a spicy little kick). I added the cream of mushroom truffle soup...delicious. And the other two split a burrata appetizer that looked sinful. We all moved on to the incredible burgers for entrees. AMAZING. These rival the Spruce burger, which I at one point believed to be the best in the city. Marlowe's edge is that the tasty bun does not get soggy from all the juiciness of the meat and fixin's. 

Finishing with the chocolate cream pie in with a salted graham cracker crust was a must. 

I cannot WAIT to go back!!
author: Kiesha R.

description:
Checked in at Marlowe Friday night with galpal Lyora. I went because I was looking for something near her place in the Soma. It's across from Caltrain where South Food and Wine used to be. What an upgrade from that odd little place!!

We walked up and it was so cozy and cute inside. It had a nice bustle going without being a shit show. We were able to sit right away at the bar when two women left. I really loved the energy there.

Sitting at the bar was a bonus because our server, who maybe was named Trey, was attentive without being obtrusive, which is a difficult thing for servers to master these days. 

Food: Burratta cheese with some fancy salts. Not as good as the Uva burrata, but delicious, and served with nice bread. The salt was awesome I promise. Also a gem salad which was super refreshing and tasty. For dinner we split the bacon burger/frites and the poulet verte, a strangely herbed chicken that was fantastic. It came with vegetables that I ignored. Except for the fingerlings.

Wine: They have a really nice wine by the glass list. Every recommendation from Trey hit the spot exactly. 

Dessert: Hello - some sort of jar of chocolate.

As I said, ambiance and service was great. We left really satisfied and happy. Never felt rushed. AND! price was right. 2 apps, 4 glasses of wine, 1 glass of port, 2 entrees, and dessert came to $120 with generous tip. 

Not quite a destination but more than worth it if you're in the area for a cozy fun bistro-y night.
author: Andrea S.

description: Kinda pricey but good.  Try the 'Nueske's Bacon & Bruléed Figs'.  The bacon is thick cut and the fig match the savory with sweet.
author: Matt B.

description:
Whats "poulet vert"? "Take a guess." "Place a bet." 
ITS CHICKEN!!!! 
Glad I ordered it because it was delicious.  

Have you had "brussels sprout chips"??? 
Its interesting, especially the first  bite. 

I'll be back for more questions and be prepared for answers.
author: K L.

description: Chicken was tasty. Burger was not really worth it. Overall its a place with fancy plating and food no better than a 10 to 15 dollar spot.
author: David L.

description:
I did not know what to expect from this small former Aussie sandwich space.  Wow, we got there late and ate some yummy small plates including brussels sprouts chips...great.  The crudo of the day was tuna with a mustard sauce and the gratin w beans was great.  Simple but elegant and great wine pairing suggestions.  

The owner and the chef both came out and were completely engaging.

Will go back soon!
author: jon s.

description:
An excellent experience.  Took my girl here for her birthday, first time trying the place and we both had a great time.  Service was stellar, the waitress helpful and attentive without being intrusive, rest of the staff equally on the ball.  At one point in the meal, I dropped my napkin and, within seconds, a new napkin appeared without my having to call it to anyone's attention.

Food was excellent, the Brussel Sprout chips a treat, the pork and special burger prepared perfectly and clearly of top quality meats.  

Easy location to get to and comfortable interior, not too noisy, not too big.
author: Rene G.

description: Food was pretty good.  I had the burger and it had great flavor. But the service was average and the portions were small
author: Tony A.

description: My wife took me here for my birthday and it didn't disappoint.  Started out with the Brussels Sprout Chips and they were so tasty.  I don't even like Brussels but these things were awesome.  Also loved the Pork Chop, meaty, full of flavor, juicy... loved it.  $20 Corkage Fee on wines, Im all in for another visit.
author: Nick V.

description:
Rounding up 3.5 stars to 4 stars for quick dinners.

I tried the shrimp cocktail and the little gem salad.  The flavors are strong and punchy so if you're looking for strong flavors, this is the place to go.

Woody interior makes for a comfortable place that takes you a bit away from the concrete and asphalt of the city.  I'd knock back a few drinks with friends here.
author: Peter K.

description:
$12 for a chicken sandwich and you get these for fries:

http://kc.sysco.com/products/productpage.asp?prodID=292&ctID=36&ptID=1

Unacceptable....  I wouldn't be suprised if the moderately stale buns also came from Sysco.
author: Justin T.

description: I went here on a Friday night and it was amazing! The Brussels sprout chips were really good, just a bit greasy. I ordered the roasted chicken and it was probably the best chicken I ever had at a restaurant - it was so most with perfectly seasoned skin. My boyfriend got the pork chops which had an incredible sherry jus. I want to come back to try the burger!
author: Amy N.

description:
while walking down the street you glance over and see a window full of quotes pertaining to food. it intrigues you and you must know what lies behind that glass. you walk in and are greeted with a chill vibe and an industrial space. the first thing you see on the wall are four hanging drawings that look like a chalkboard outlining the cuts of meat from a cow, pig, sheep and goat. seems promising.

during the lunch hour people tend to order the baked oysters, the burger or the fried chicken sandwich. i can only speak for the burger, which i found to be really flavorful and one of the better burgers in this city. the brussel sprout chips are a must. all of their desserts are served in a glass, which means they're mostly puddings and things of that sort. no thanks, not my thing. 

based on my lunch experience, i'd definitely like to see what they have to offer for dinner.
author: Regina C.

description: We knew we were back in San Francisco (after a stint on the east coast) once our server genuinely welcomed us at our table.  The place is totally hip, but that doesn't mean they aren't friendly too.  The food is incredible and unique while still familiar,  and it's been one of our favorite spot ever since that first meal back.  The brussels sprouts, the polenta, the roasted chicken...YUM.  Unfortunately, it's usually too popular for last minute plans or reservations, but we love going back here and introducing travelers and friends to it when we can get in.
author: Brooke S.

description:
Cool small restaurant with tasty dishes. A bit on the pricey side but high quality ingredients & big portions. What I liked of the non-meat dishes (which I guess they are known for...oops!): 

Brussels Sprout Chips-perfect to share if you are siting at the bar & having a drink. Good salty flavor. 

Oysters-HUGE & so delicious! 

Gem Salad-pretty decent salad option (well it IS the only salad option) but wouldn't necessarily order again. 

Stuffed Blue Sole-lots of flavor from the crab which I loved! (This was a very big portion which I recommend sharing.) 

Brown Butter Brussels Sprouts-a MUST GET item. We ate them all! 

Good for a small group dinner (2-4ppl) & definitely make reservations. I went with a group of 4 people on a Monday & all the tables were seated throughout the night.
