Try to get there early so you can sit at the cute bar & have a cocktail or glass of wine & the brussels sprout chips before your meal and you will be one happy camper.
author: Mel A.

description:
Sick - this place reminds me a lot of Animal without the same sheer volume of pork.  The flavors of the dishes were spot on.  Every dish was well executed and focused.  There wasn't as much inventiveness but its in the same neighborhood.  I didn't get the burger but I had some fries.  Some of the best fries I've ever had.  

My favorite dishes of the night were the baked oysters, brussel sprout chips, poulet vert and fava beans.  Great little place that was busting out at the seams.  A great $35 bottle of malbec, ok 2 bottles.  Marlowe is a great little joint in SF that should be on everybody's short list.

The desserts were fantastic.  We ordered all 3 and devoured them.  My personal favorite was the dark chocolate ganache like thing in the mason jar.  Great stuff all around.
author: Jerrold S.

description:
My gal pal and I dove in, after seeing Marlowe appear on several Foodie lists. Conveniently located across the street from the CalTrain station, and buzzing with action on a Tuesday night.

We were seated immediately, in this man-cave of a dining hall. 
Although the juicy burger and fries being positively devoured one table over tempted us, we chose a healthier route.

We shared the little gem salad (an endive-y masterpiece), stuffed blue sole (stunning),  and brussel sprouts (tasty, but dripping in oil). Lovely offerings of wine by the glass, including a few sparkling ones that highlighted the sole (soul?).

Service was fine, professional, yet unmemorable. 
Next time, I'll be more than tempted to try that temptress of a burger.
author: Bonnie B.

description:
Marlowe is fabulous! It has an edited menu of new american foods and I've literally eaten everything on their menu at one time or another.
It's a warm, cozy place to eat with friends, making it a perfect Wednesday night restaurant.

Try the baked oysters, the brussels sprouts chips, and the Marlowe burger. Depending on the night, the initial greeting can range from friendly and speedy to disinterested and slow. Once you sit down, the service is generally good, with attentive and unobtrusive waiters, and the head of house lady will tell you all about each dish if you have any questions. However, if you just want to be left alone to try each other's pork chops and bone marrow, that's easy to accomplish.

The desserts are forgettable, unfortunately. 

If you have a big group, make a reservation. Their space isn't huge and they only really have one big table.
author: Betty G.

description: At about my third visit I'd decided that this was the burger I'd be comparing all other burgers to.
author: James G.

description:
Can't say enough about Marlowe's burger and fries.  All the hype you have read/heard is absolutely correct.  Not only is the burger perfectly cooked, but you can really tell that thought and care has been put into the making of this burger.  The balance of ingredients is wonderful with the bacon adding a savory smokiness, and the caramelized onions providing a delicious sweetness.  The Acme bun holds in everything  and the shredded lettuce helps the burger stay in place (rather than the whole leaves getting soggy and then sliding off the patty).  

Now to the fries - they are perfectly crisp with a delightfully pillowy center.  I don't know what kind of oil they are fried in, but they are easily the best fries in the city.  Make sure to order the famed Brussels sprout chips - they are nutty and salty with just a hint of lemon.  I have also ordered the chicken and it is covered in herbs and is super moist.  Desserts are perfectly portioned, but the upside down apple crisp is really an ice cream sundae.  The lemon cake is great and tastes like a lemon bar.  Parking can be challenging, but if you show up early there are generally spaces (though not when the Giant's have a home game).  Great little space with awesome burgers!
author: Dana H.

description: We had a reservation but still waited an hour for our table. The hostess was very apologetic and brought us complimentary champagne and comped an appetizer. The tables were extremely close together and the restaurant was very loud. The food came out quickly but definitely didn't live up to the hype. Many of our dishes were cold and the bone marrow that everyone raved about wasn't up to par. Overall it wasn't worth the wait in my opinion.
author: Erin B.

description:
Stardate: Lunch.

Burger: amazing... who woulda thought Michael Bauer knew anything about fooooood? But really... these guys nail it with the burger. An oft overlooked detail: a perfectly toasted bun. A-mazing.

Fries: hot to trot amazing.

Brussels sprout chips: couldn't stop amazing.

The upsidedown/insideout/lemmetellallyoufoolswhatit'sallabout apple crisp? Let's put it this way. If the senses and stomach were pants, they'd be tight with wood, friends. Total foodie wood.
author: Roy M.

description:
I tried making a reservation the day of - except I made it for the wrong day. Oops. Luckily, they were able to fit us in at the communal table with only a 10 minute wait. The hostess was very understanding of my stupid-ness. ( I would call it blonde-ness but I'm now brunette). The communal table was cool, we sat next to a couple who offered to let us try their brussel chips and discussed  motorcycles. On the other side of us was a couple that looked like father/daughter but from the snippets of conversation we heard, they were not. It was intriguing.
Onto the food...
Fried brussel sprout chips = AWESOME. Seriously, my date doesn't even LIKE brussel sprouts and he liked these. He said because they were lemon-y. I had the burger with a side salad. The side salad was not a typical, boring side salad. It was arugula, radish & a light vinaigrette. The burger was fine, not the best burger I've ever had - by far. It was cooked perfectly medium rare so that made me happy. Something on it was burnt. I think it was the bacon but the burnt flavor overtook any other flavor. I liked the horseradish mayo but I wish it were spicier. 
My date had the polenta. It was creamy & rich. If you are looking for a vegetarian option, this is great.
author: Sara P.

description:
Came here the other night for the Marlowe Burger. The Chronicle claims it's one of the best burgers in town. 

Started with the Beratta and brussel sprouts appetizer. Carafe of wine.

Burger was good, but not awesome as the hype. Fries were super yummy. Dessert cobbler was good too. 

We walked in 8:00 pm on a Thursday night and we were seated in 10 minutes. On our way out, looks like there was a wait though! 

I'd go back just b/c the food is good, the location is convenient, parking is tolerable if the Giant's aren't playing. Like everywhere in SoMa, the restaurant is lacking value.
author: Cindy Y.

description:
1- Comfie decor - reminded me someone's house done in all restoration hardware

2 - DELICIOUS and approachable menu - food and wine

3 - Very knowledgeable and friendly staff

Favorite dishes:  brussel sprout chips were surprisingly good and the burger was outstanding
author: Gracie L.

description: Started off with an appetizer, the brussel sprout chips. Not too bad, but it left me waiting for the burger I ordered even more. And boy was that a great tasting burger cooked medium rare. I looked through their drink menu for a dark beer and noticed they had Krusovice as the only option. And it didn't disappoint at all and went great together with the burger. The Krusovice beer was so good I had 2. Hard to believe this is near the Caltrain station. If I had to take that to commute, I think I'd eat some of my dinners over here.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
We like to come in for the burger. It's my wife's favorite burger in the city. 

The place is small and it's pretty tough to get a table but the staff is always willing to help make it happen. A few weeks ago we stopped in with a couple of friends to see if we could slip in and even though they were booked they said, "if you can finish in 45 mins we'll get you in." now some may be offended by this, but we loved it! We loved how they made it work for us. 

The burger is a sure fire winner.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Great service, reasonable prices, and a menu that can suit wide ranging palettes all highlight my first of many experiences at Marlowe.  The space is welcoming and nice on the eyes.  Whether you want to go for a casual small bite or a multi-course meal, this place is good for a variety of occasions.  

Loved the oysters, Brussels sprout chips (the vegetable wasn't overwhelmed by it being slightly fried), the poulet vert and the upside down apple crisp.  

Try this place soon before it starts getting packed!
author: Peter H.

description:
All and all, a fabulous dining experience. I had the Shrimp, Lamb, a special triple cheese plate and the Oysters though the Brussel Sprouts might have been the highlight of my evening. 

The only negative was, we came in at 8:30pm for a table of two and were told by the host would be a 1/2 hour wait. 45 minutes later we werent offered a glass of wine, some bread or anything to make our overwait tolerable. The host ignored us and sat with people who looked like friends that were eating dinner. It was very odd! She never came to check on us, nor speak with us again. There were many tables open, though no one was sitting at them. Finally at 9:30 we were approached by the bar tender stating he was sorry for the delay and would like to offer us a glass of wine. In my mind, that means it would be a complimentary glass no? It actually was on our bill! We were too late for our movie to dispute the charges and just paid for it. 

Fabulous food and music, though poor service and understaffed.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Super adorable restaurant. We sat at the bar and had a nice, relaxing dinner with a carafe of their cab.  The gem salad and the grilled shrimp were both delightful and not too heavy.  The burger was pretty good, but not life-changing. I did thoroughly enjoy their french fries though.  Everything was presented beautifully and the service was right on.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Candace C.

description: Every dish was the best of its kind really enjoy coming and always try to come to this place when I can!! Their fries break like glass and are cream in the center!! Best ever!
author: Jacob K.

description: Tasty and friendly, Marlowe is a SoMa favorite with a nice balance of quality and value.
author: Jan M.

description:
Had the Poulet Vert chicken and a taste of everything else.  Just as good as the first time.

Need to change the menu.  I've been here twice within four months and the menu is the same.  I don't know when I'd go back, but it won't be till its changed.
author: Mark K.

description:
Marlowe hit the spot today for lunch. Started with the Brussel Chips, by recommendation of many yelp reviews. They were a tasty snack, that will definitely be part of any future meal here.

Got the burger, was perfectly prepared, had a great grilled flavor, real juicy. Their fries were spectacular, had that sort of tempura crispiness that I love in a fry.

I've gotten comfortable spending around $10-12 in this neighborhood for a fancy sandwich at lunch, what with ironside, Centro, Butler and the chef as frequent choices. Marlowe delivers great quality, delicious food, without going too far overboard on style or price.
author: Shawn S.

description:
Tues work lunch.  The steak tartare was strangely un-pink; the preparation in a vinaigrette par-cooked it like ceviche.  (Make a sad face)  Bummer, since the point of tartare is that it is raw like crudo.  

Fries really are totally awesome here, and the rest of the menu looks like it has a lot of potential.  But the service here was harried and strangely unfriendly.  Did I miss something?  Is this a hipster lunch joint?
author: Lorin Y.

description:
Three words: Warm Deviled Eggs.
Wow!  Never in a million years would I imagine going bonkers for a deviled egg, but these are so darned creamy & flavorful w/ a bacon accent! Heavenly!  So good, we ordered another round!
Just go sit at the bar, grab a glass of wine a few deviled eggs and enjoy!  I also recommend those with a side of Brussels Sprout Chips...
author: Nicole B.

description: I loooove my experience at this restaurant. Decided to go here while visiting San Francisco based on yelp reviews and ratings and it was such an amazing surprise! The food was so delicious and we ordered pretty much the whole menu to taste and share and everything was absolutely well seasoned and delicious!!! The best part for me was the coffee panna cotta. It was the best panna cotta that I've ever had! I wanted to go back the next day, just to order the panna cotta!
author: Marie T.

description: Delicious brussel sprout chips, good steak, and a cool atmosphere.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Matt J.

description:
Airy, loft space.  Typical SOMA lunch crowd- Guy at next table staring at his phone trying to figure out who was calling as it blared some awful tone. Sigh...

Great Burger!   Caramelized onions, cheddar, bacon & horseradish aioli  on a "just right" bun.  The baked oysters were ok.

Good, friendly service.
author: Bill S.

description: I have eaten lunch here twice and dinner once. The food was great and the wine list had some intriguing choices. The service at the bar at lunch time has been outstanding. I only wish they had a full bar and a bit more space as I wasn't crazy about the community seating that my date and I were placed at, there was a beam that was kind of in the way. I will, however, be back! Check it out.
author: Raf B.

description: Every single dish we were served at Marlowe was divine. When they recommend you order a deviled egg, order 2. I look forward to visiting you again very, very soon.
author: Annie T.

description:
Actually, more like 4 1/2 stars! I went with a total of 4 people for dinner last week and from the moment we walked in, the service and overall experience was stellar. 

We were early for the reso so my friend and I sat at the bar while waiting for our other 2 friends. The place looks pretty much the same as when it was South Restaurant (Aussie) and I wonder if its the same owners?? Anyway, the atmosphere was fun, lively, and yes, its a bit loud. We had the brussel sprout chips, the spicy prawns to share as a starter and I ordered my own baked oyster. All insanely delicious. And that oyster was off the charts!

In fact, I ordered another oyster. It was creamy delicious and cooked perfectly (ie not chewy and overcooked grossness) so it tasted like an oyster should but with some crunchy pork fat sprinkled greatness on top.  

For a main course, I had the polenta with truffle oil and poached egg but I couldn't finish it because I had stuffed myself with those oysters and appetizers. The burger looked really awesome too.

I have been super bored with SF restaurants lately so am so happy that Marlowe is in the house!
author: Sylvie L.

description: I came for one thing - the much-lauded burger - but it was so much more. Never mind the noise or lack of space. The food, drinks and service are brilliant. At the bar, having arrived early, we savored the baked oysters with some wine, which the staff monitored - sweeping in to offer another pour at just the right time. At the table, we tore apart the crab claws in brown butter and experienced the glory of bone marrow for the first time. It didn't hurt that we chose to open a very nice cabernet sauvignon for the occasion, or that the fries were utterly perfect, or that ample horseradish aioli was provided, but the burger was indeed a star in its own right. Beautifully cooked and complemented, it was a fitting finale because we simply had no room for dessert...
author: Corey B.

description:
Awesome burger!  A bit petite, but has you craving for more.  This burger has you enjoying the beef/lamb favor that just oozes juice with every bite.  The fries are spectacular, crispy and fresh!  

There are other plates here that are great...all around a great lunch eatery!
author: MTBer I.

description:
We went to the restaurant opening last week, so no comment on the service.  It was understandable that they were just getting the hang of things, so we will let the "How are things?" every 2 minutes just slide.

Marlowe was reviewed based on their "snacks", so we had to give it a try.  The crispy brussels sprout chips seasoned with meyer lemon and sea salt, are no doubt more delicious (and healthier) than what you'd nosh on at your house, and the toasted pistachios with bourbon, maple and smoked salt beat your bowl of peanuts any day. 

For dinner, we had the classic steak tartare, with poached quail egg and crostini, and matched it up with a side of their smoky cauliflower gratin.  For dessert, their chocolate pot de crème with crème fraiche and maple pistachios was too cute to eat, but of course, that didn't stop me. 

Marlowe is just like being at home, only with better food, friendlier people, and you don't have to clean up after yourself.  Sort of.
author: Ivy R.

description: Let me be the last to get on the classy burger bandwagon following the Bauer story.  Had it not been for his raving of the fries, I might have passed this up, but had to see what he was talking about.  The fries were excellent, though mine were a bit less hot than optimal and somewhat oversalted.  The burger was nice.  All the ingredients merged well and it was just stable enough to not be too sloppy, but good amount of grease.  I was starved and the meal proved to be the perfect size.  Nice classy napkins.  Good toothpicks.  Crowded on a Monday, which is impressive, yet free parking is easy when no Giants game, so recommend this day to visit.  Well worth the $17.26 all-in with no beverage.  Minus 1 star for luke-warm fries and the bill taking a long time to be presented.  But will be back for sure.
author: Marc S.

description:
I went to this Marlowe for lunch, its a new restaurant in the neighborhood.

We ordered Marlowe burger and a 4505 Sausage hot dog. (4505 isn't the number of sausages you get but a company name where the tasty sausages came from. )

I tasted the hamburger, it was really juicy and had a really nice charbroiled meat scent.
The french fries were really garlic but taste really fresh as well.

The  4505 Sausage hot dog wasn't as great as I expected, not as flavorful. I think the burgers are very popular because every table had an order of the Marlowe burger.
Also the salad was very bitter and salty.

I really enjoyed this new restaurant and will come again to try various items on the menu.
author: M T.

description: Enjoyed a meal here last night with a girlfriend. My first impression was that I loved the ambiance - cozy but elegant and hip.  A nice selection of wines by the glass to choose from, and I selected a temperanillo that was very good.  We started with the crispy brussels sprout leaves - so good. I am trying to figure out how to make them at home. Next, was the pork belly appetizer, also quite good, maybe a tad on the dry side as compared to other times I have enjoyed that dish.  At this point I should say that while the dining room is very loud, it still seems intimate and I enjoyed the overall vibe of the place and the service is excellent.  For my main dish I ordered the cod. It was tasty, but while the portion was not huge, a little bit went a long way.  Cooked perfectly, however, I do think that dish can be a little more oily than my palate is comfortable with, but I honestly think that is just me, not the preparation.  My friend had the polenta with egg, and she loved it, couldn't finish it it was so rich. For dessert, we shared the dark chocolate mousse type thing, cannot remember what they call it, but it comes in a mason jar with graham cracker crust on the bottom and sea salt crust on the top - OMG! Taste-gasm!  Place seemed popular, definitely recommend getting a reservation. Parking is tough, try the Safeway lot across the street. I would love to come back with my husband, I think this place is right up his alley.
author: Rachel H.

description: As a past fan of Marlowe's, the Cavalier, and ParkTavern regretfully last night after dining once again at Malowe's there appears to be a constant theme that is now present with the Marlowe Burger, 80% bun 20% beef where now I would strongly suggest you look for something else on the menu.
author: Steve G.

description:
No res for 2 on a thursday (i think) around 7pm. We were seated at the bar within 15 mins. Had a great dark wheat beer, and took our time looking over the menu. Lady friend ordered the following:
-Deviled eggs  - Fucking fantastic. Seriously the best deviled eggs Ive ever had
-Baked Mussels or clams or whatev - Not a big fan of brine laden slime, so this was a no go for me. But if thats what youre into, have at it, i guess.
-Bone Marrow - Looked cool as hell, but was a bitch to eat. Not much there either. Tasted alright. Again slimy, salty stuff...
-Pork Belly - AMAZING. I wanted to rub it on my face, it was so good. If you get one thing here, make it the pork belly. 
-Steak Frites - Not bad. Good meat, nice and juicy, and they brought it on 2 plates for us which was thoughtful, but by that time I was already full of that beautiful pork belly.
-I think we had some little salad thing too, but I cant remember. Must not have been too good.

Service was good too, food took a little while tho. The big guy with glasses behind the bar is a cool guy.
author: Gerhart H.

description:
I want to like Marlowe more.  Consider my rating the veiled 3.5 stars although after tonight's meal, maybe 3.14 ... but I am adjusting upwards out of a spirit of forgiveness and rooting for the underdog.

The first time I went was for lunch, and I had the famed hamburger.  It really is great.  The meat is moist, the condiments are perfectly arranged and seasoned.  The fries are as good as at the previous concept, South, and that's no small feat.

The second time, also lunch.  I had the poulet vert.  First off, I think poulet vert is just a very sensible preparation.  SF has lots of perfectly-roasted chicken; it's like some kind of litmus test for every place that opens.  But it's usually ye olde meat, crispy skin, veggies on the side  (or underneath) format.  The fine line to walk, of course, is that with poulet vert you can cover up badly executed chicken with "green stuff."  Marlowe doesn't do that; it's perfectly tender chicken with, uh, very delicious green stuff.

Tonight I had dinner.  We had the bone marrow to start.  It really is great.  It seems like lots of restaurants in SF offering bone marrow seem to forget the, uh, bone marrow.  I typically get lots of bone, not much marrow.  Not here.  It's a big serving, well presented, with nice garnishes (some caper-heavy thing ...).

The main courses were somewhere between mediocre and bad.  I had the halibut.  The menu says it's seared, with glazed baby vegetables, and spinach with a butter sauce.

First of all, if you say a piece of meat is seared, it has to be BROWNED and have a crust on top.  Not lightly browned.  SEARED.  The fish was thinly cut so presumably they cut off the sear to avoid overcooking it.  That's no good excuse.  Go to Boulevard, guys, order the Halibut there.  It's a thick cut with an amazing brown crust.   The spinach was undersalted and slimy.  The glazed baby vegetables weren't really glazed, just buttered.  

Fortunately the sauce and the quality of the ingredients made the halibut pretty palatable overall.  I don't think a kitchen like Marlowe should put a dish like that out.  But it kinda hits the "OK, maybe they just hit a foul ball" note.  I'm not so fussy I'll cry over a not-perfect piece of good halibut.  

Lamb, on the other hand ... 

My partner's lamb ... ummm ... was a total mess.  Apparently all the sear I didn't get, he got in spades on the lamb.  The outside had grill marks, and it had that super-bitter, over-charred taste.  The inside is cooked to the right temperature, but it's dry ... definitely way under-rested.  The side is parmesan and ricotta dumplings ... suupppperrr dense, like eating heavy rocks.  The vegetables were fine but kinda just there for kicks.  Way oversalted, too.

Dessert ... pot de creme.  I ordered it because it's made with TCHO chocolate.  I'd eat TCHO sprinkled on broken glass.  It was fine.  Overcooked by pot de creme standards, very dense, but still ... lots of TCHO goodness.  Hard to beat.

I don't want to knock Marlowe down because of one bad night.  I love, say, COCO500 but they've had bad nights, and I still love and support them.  The unfortunate fact though is that, although I'm forgiving, I doubt I can convince my boyfriend to make this place a "destination spot" now.  It's a shame.  One bad night can really throw a place off, and any night is your potential first impression. 

My advice to Marlowe:  make all the food as good as the burger, keep up the attention to detail, do it every night, and don't stop.
author: J W.

description: Best burger in SF.  Nice to grab a seat at the bar, have a glass of wine and split the burger and fries with someone you really love. If you don't really love them, don't share. Because the burger is too good to give up half!
author: Melissa H.

description: I had a massive case of dinner envy when my friend went with the pork chops.  Who would think that a pork chop cooked perfectly with a side of prosciutto under a bed of parmesan cream could trump my perfectly cooked steak?!  Marlowe is definitely a gem in / around the South Beach area that doesn't have as many good restaurants within walking distance as many other districts in the city.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Tried Marlowe last night (a Monday) after reading so much about it.  

Made a 7:15 reservation was seated immediately and the waiter came promptly and was good through out the meal....Star

Wine list was good a lot of good wines under $50...... Star

Pistachios roasted in a Bell Jar cute

Oysters with clam chowder yum.  

Shrimp bloody mary appetizer not amazing.

Main lamb cooked well and and seasoned nicely.....Star

Will I go back?  probably some day but I can not imagine craving anything I had. Maybe for the burger which everyone loves so much.

Cute place by the Ball Park
author: Tim B.

description: So this is a tough review.  I would normally give Marlowe 3 stars and say that it is a slightly above average New American place at a reasonable price point.  I bumped it up to 4 stars for two dishes that I am not even sure are on the menu anymore: Peaches with Burrata and Cauliflower Gratin (with some sort of smoked cheese).  I distinctly remember both of these dishes and the Gratin has become a Thanksgiving staple.
author: Michael S.

description:
I came to this location when it was South, and found the appetizers generally were better than the entrees. Perhaps because the owners haven't changed, I'm still finding the same phenomenon. 

In any case, it's a cozy place to meet up with friends and the staff is friendly.
author: Ellen S.

description:
This is the perfect location for my wife and I and our weekly Friday night date night.

Cozy, fun (but not too loud) atmosphere.

Great and unique food (crispy brussel sprouts? how cool).

And best item on the menu (and for some reason cheapest) is the famous Marlowe burger... Definitely wayyy better than any In'N'Out offering...

Overall, really a great, local restaurant in SF!
author: Amit S.

description:
I came here for a work event.  I really enjoyed the prawns and a champagne drink with elderflower? and pink lemonade maybe... it was excellent.

Service was good and everyone really enjoyed themselves.
Will definitely return soon.
author: Lizete S.

description: Amazing!  The service was stellar (took 5 minutes longer to get seated, so the hostess offered us their amazing brussel sprout chips), the food was out of this world (get the pork chop!) and the vibe was cozy and comfortable.  Well deserved 5 stars!
author: Shannon H.

description: Really good experience! We walked in without a reservation and got a table within 10 minutes.  Wine recommendations went really well with our food choices, which were all excellent.  I got the chicken, which was easily the best roast chicken I've ever had, and the other half got the pork which was also really tasty.  Definitely recommend.  Fantastic night.
author: Anna J.

description:
I went back and ordered the Strip Steak with Frites.

Don't.  It isn't good.  The steak was overcooked and hard, and lacking in flavor.  I say, stick with the burger and the chicken.

I did try the brussels sprouts chips, and they were excellent, just as my friend said.
author: Jennie Y.

description:
Small venue, interesting setup. The food is good! 

Not many veggie choices on the menu.. eh.
author: Ava K.

description: A nice intimate spot that's nice for dates and conversations. The restaurant is not big but they pack a lot of seat and seating is close to other customers which make it a little loud but you get the community feeling. Started with brussel sprout chips which were crisp and delicious. Fried greens in general are amazing. I got the Niman pork chop for entree which was excellent. Juicy and full of smoky flavor. Very nice yet casual restaurant in SOMA. Only downside is they do not serve liquor.
author: Ed L.

description:
My wife and I go to this place quite often.
Great place, very profesional staff, unbelievable service, great food and fair prices.
It is always very busy and for good reason it is one of the best restaurant quality/price ratio you can find in the city.
Very attentive floor manger a wait team, the had a slight delay of few minutes with the delicious chicken mushroom polenta we didn't even compliant about it and they were so apologetic and comp the dish. 
Worth the wait and not expected at all.
What is more to say but try it.
author: T. M.

description:
So, it is totally a shame that I live a good ten hour drive from this San Francisco restaurant. But, you know, I think those brussel sprout chips might be worth $4 a gallon for a road trip south.  Wondering what exactly a brussel sprout chip is? Well, here is what I could gather from the bowl that I inhaled. Stripped of each tiny leaf, the chips were flash fried and doused with salt, pepper, lemon zest, and juice...maybe, this is my best guess as to what is involved in my new favorite beer snack. I also kept imagining them as a topping on some kind of creamy soup. They were crunchy, acidic, and salty and extremely addictive. What else was on our menu? We had a great carmelized pork belly with some amazing roasted beets. Steak tartare that had a surprising touch of chili pepper heat to set off the cold-silky bite spooned on top of crostini. And, baked oysters. Oh the baked oysters. That one you just need to taste for yourself. But, let's just say I could easily hop in my car and make the drive down from Portland just for a table full of those oysters.

The space of the restaurant was tiny, but intimate and romantic. Slightly busy though you can't fault them for that. And, the staff was spot-on with drink orders, food, and accommodating my ever-changing reservation. Thanks for that Marlowe.
author: Kristie B.

description: i don't eat burgers often and when i do, i expect them to be awesome.  the burger here was pretty awesome, although the accompanying fries were underwhelming (a bit on the thin and not quite crispy side).  the lager steamed mussels were delicious and I found the broth really interesting and different than any mussel dishes I've had before.  the brussels sprout chips were also great, as promised.  the servers and hostess were all very friendly and attentive.  however, it was a very cramped and loud dining experience, as the space is about the size of two car garage, and they try to park three cars in it.  but, i suppose, if you're looking for satisfying food, Marlowe is on point.
author: Ash T.

description:
Went to dinner with a group of people. Had the following:

*Toasted Pistachios (bourbon, maple & smoked salt):  Tasted like sweet/salty nuts.  Didn't taste the smokey flavor.
*Warm Deviled Egg (aged provolone, pickled jalapeno & bacon): $1.50 each and it wasn't that flavorful.  The main thing that you tasted was the bacon.  I've had better at potlucks.
*Crispy Brussels Sprout Chips (lemon & sea salt): This was tasty but I don't know why people are going crazy over them.  They taste similar to the roasted brussel sprouts I make every week. 
*Bakes Oysters (New England chowder in a shell): The oyster was drowned in a creamy sauce.  My thought - where's the oyster?
*Creamy Mushroom Soup (truffle oil & chive): The truffle oil wasn't very aromatic.  They could have skipped the oil and it would have been the same. 
*Marlowe Burger (carmelized onions, cheddar, bacon, horseradish aoili & fries): I didn't have any but my friend said it was good.  
*"Poulet Vert" (brown butter brussel hearts, roasted rose fingerling potato, black trumpet mushroom & mustard jus):  3 large pieces of chicken which was a bit dry.  I wasn't a fan of the mustard jus.
*Dessert - Vanilla Bean Panna Cotta Affogato (amareto, lemon biscotti): This was a clear winner.  Light, creamy and the espresso and amaretto on top was perfect.

Would I go here again? Probably not.  I wasn't really "WOWed" by the food,  

Btw, they only have wine and beer.  Wine selection is reasonably price.

One star for the dessert
One star for the wine selection
author: Ling K.

description: Marlowe is one of my favorite restaurant in town. The ingredients they picked are fresh with good quality. The Marlowe burger, oh my god, all the people need to try this if you come to Marlowe, it is so flavorful and juicy, everything comes perfect together in your month. I'll say this is the best burger! Love it~ I also love the grill chicken (forget the name), and few appetizers there.
author: Carol X.

description:
Loved the food. Loved the ambiance. 

We got their Peach and Burrata starter to share (when ordered, $1 went to support the Breast Cancer foundation, which was nice!), which was alright. But I would have also liked to have tried their Brussels Sprout Chips and Sweet Corn soup too...I guess next time!

For the entrée, I ordered the only vegetarian one on their menu: Anson Mills polenta wild mushrooms, truffled pecorino & poached farm egg. It was REALLY good...I could get a whiff of the truffled pecorino in every bite, and the shaved parmesan on top mixed with the wild mushrooms went very well with the polenta. My only complaint would be that it got a little too salty towards the last few bites, but hey, that's because I left nothing on the plate!

I'd love to try their summer squash gratin and brown butter brussels sprouts some time as well! It's a popular place, so you better have reservations. They do take walk-ins, but you'll have to wait for 45+ mins for a bar seat.
author: Chinmayi B.

description:
For once, my view on a restaurant is aligned with the Chronicle's food critic Michael Bauer.  I wouldn't say it's the best burger in San Francisco (that honor goes to the animal-style In-N-Out cheeseburger hands friggin down), but Marlowe's is pretty good.  The french fries...now they're amazing.  I don't know if it's because I asked for them extra crispy, but they were damn good especially dipped in the mayonnaise they were served with.  

As for the service, I think Marlowe recruited from the school of the deaf.  Several times, we called out above the din, "Excuse me."  And then again at screaming level, "EXCUSE ME."  Customers in the middle of the restaurant had to stop two different waiters twice, "That table has been calling for you."  Ironically, the restaurant space is rather small, too.

After a while, I think the place will go south like its predecessor, but for now, Marlowe owes its business to Mr. Bauer.  Every single person in the restaurant was chowing down on a burger.
author: catherine g.

description:
Amazing:
The Anson Mills Polenta with wild mushrooms, truffled pecorino & poached farm egg was amazing and complex and truffley. One of the most delicious entrees I've eaten in recent history. I would definitely come back just to try this again.
The Upside down peach crisp with Bourbon ice cream & brown butter caramel sauce was excellent and I would order it again even if full.

Darn Good:
The "Poulet Vert" with heirloom tomatoes, fingerling potatoes & spring onions was tasty as well and well herbed.
The Brown Butter Brussels Sprouts with lemon & sea salt were good and reminiscent of toasted pumpkin seeds.
The Crispy Brussels Sprout Chips with lemon & sea salt were interesting and similar to kale chips. 

Just Ok:
The Warm Deviled Egg with aged provolone, pickled jalapeño & bacon was good, but it's really just a deviled egg and how exciting can that be.
The Steak Tartare with poached quail egg & crostini didn't have a great flavor, but I'm not a tartare person.
The Roasted Bone Marrow  with salsa verde & fine herbs was a little too greasy. Maybe it's supposed to be like that. The salsa verde was great.
The Smoky Cauliflower Gratin with aged provolone & smoked cheddar was creamy and tasty, but veggies covered in cheese aren't really exciting.
The TCHO chocolate cream pie with Graham cracker & chocolate cookie crust, cocoa nib, sea salt was ok but I expected more from a classy chocolate dessert. It reminded me of eating a packet of Swiss miss hot chocolate powder.
author: L B.

description:
Spiced prawns with hot and boozy cocktail sauce were savory and fun to eat.  Husband and I shared the "poulet vert" (green chicken) and it was tender, juicy, and flavorful with a medley of potatoes and olives.  To finish off a tasty dinner, we had the upside-down apple crisp with bourbon ice cream - it was simply devine.  

I can't wait to go back for the Marlowe burger.
author: Nina L.

description:
Marlowe is the ideal local restaurant. Unpretentious, friendly, warm and phenomenal food without flair. The staff at Marlowe are exceptional and are always accommodating. Special mention to Kraig for comping us drinks after not having a table ready for us when we arrived. 

As most people have written, the burger is a reason to visit Marlowe; it does not disappoint. That said, you must try the "Poulet Vert" Yes, its chicken and even I (a recovering NYer with moderate cooking skills) can make chicken, but not like this. It is moist, flavorful and perfectly accompanied by tomatoes, olives and squash blossoms. I have introduced 3 people to the chicken dish and non have regretted not getting the burger.
author: Stephen B.

description:
I really liked South, so I was disappointed when they closed and put off trying out Marlowe.  Marlowe is in a teensy space by the ballpark, so it wasn't hard to put it off.  

But I finally gave it a go last night, and I shouldn't've waited so long.  Service is good, food is good, the wine list is nice.  

I had the corn soup and the much-lauded cheeseburger.  My husband had the spicy prawns and the ribeye.  We shared some sangria with our starters and mains, and then shared a chocolate pot de creme for dessert.    The sangria special, with apples, peaches, and mint, was nice and refreshing.  My corn soup was lovely, the husband thought that his prawns were a bit bland.  The cheeseburger almost, but not quite, deserved the accolades -- it was awfully drippy, which probably means they either didn't sear it properly or didn't let it rest properly.  My husband really liked the ribeye, but thought that the portion was bit skimpy.  The pot de creme was nicely rich but not overly so.

The only thing that will keep me from coming back is that I'm rarely in that neighbourhood, and there's so many great restaurants in the neighbourhoods that I spend more time, so it'll take an effort to come back.
author: D C.

description: Nice urban atmosphere with country chic twist and good food.
author: Maria M.

description: Oh wow.  I had heard about the famous Marlowe burger, and I learned tonight why it has such a good rep.  I do think it is one of the (if not the absolute) best burgers in the city.  It was cooked to perfection, juicy, and wonderfully complemented by the cheese, bacon, and horseradish sauce.  The burger was so good, that I stuffed myself to the point where I barely touched the yummy, crispy fries (and I usually find fries, particularly good ones, irresistible).  The gem salad had great flavor---loved what they did with the avocados.  And their special cocktail of the night, a prosecco-blood orange combo of deliciousness was great.  I will definitely come back to this place when I need a fabulous burger.
author: Danielle B.

description:
Nice addition to the city!  Reasonably priced but has some stellar dishes (in particular, the baked oysters with bacon pieces and the much-touted crispy brussel sprout chips, which were delicately flavored with lemon).

The hamburger deserves the hype with a flavorful patty (mixed lamb and beef) with bacon and cheddar.  Not that big and bit greasy but it really hits the spot.  It also comes with perfectly crispy fries with horseradish aioli.  The medium-rare steak frites was also a hit (and the portion size was impressive).

The only issue I had was that the size of the entrees seemed to vary significantly.  Someone ordered the lamb with ricotta dumplings that was highly recommended by our waiter ... but it only came with a few small pieces, which compared to the steak, seemed really not worth it.

But the desserts made up for everything.  Tried all of them (each are served in a jar).  The upside down apple crisp with bourbon ice cream was like a sundae with crunchy apple pieces on top ... and by far the best (we ordered two).  The spongy lemon curd cake was pretty good as well.  Didn't really enjoy the dark chocolate bar pudding (but that's probably b/c I don't really like dark chocolate).

Nice, solid option in the South Beach area.
author: F. P.

description:
3.5 stars if I could.

We had the burger, brussel sprout crisps, the baked oysters, califlower gratin, and the new dumplings.  Everything was tasty but there was definitely a heavy hand with the salt.  I think the burger was the only one that I thought was really good.

Everything else, if it was just slightly less salty, they would have been great.  I'd come back and give it another shot though.
author: Arthur T.

description: Brussel sprout chips and bone marrow!! I can't get enough of them. Wine list can be better and the service is a bit slow. Overall, the foods secure 4 stars.
author: P. L.

description: I would have given Marlowe 5 stars if the deserts did not suck! Everything else was wonderful, the food, wine and service. I recommend the spicy prawns.
author: John D.

description:
This place is horrible. Today was the first and the last time for my boyfriend and I. The food were average, we can tolerate that.....the wine was horrible. I am a Pinot Noir lover, never could not finish a glass...but fine I could still tolerate this. 

Monday, 1st  Oct 2012 was my birthday and my boyfriend was trying to treat me for the nice lunch (we hoped!) at Marlowe. The service was very poor, VERY RUDE and this was and still unacceptable to us. The waitress in this restaurant seemed to have attitude problem. PLEASE FIX that nonsense!  My boyfriend asked the waitress to take a photo of me and him with a dessert just to remember the special day and guess what the waitress said " I have no time!" Super rude!! We have never been to any restaurants in San Francisco especially with this kind of attitude encountered! We paid the food and the bill wasn't cheap $100++ and this nonsense to expect?...No time for a photo when the customer kindly asked? Unbelievable!!!!

Well with this kind of attitude problem.....no surprise if you still wait tables for the next 20 years. Life will not take you further with this kind of behavior!!!
author: IJ J.

description: Place is overrated and pricey.  Its crazy they charge so much for some Brussels spouts and a burger.  The burger is good, but I prefer the burger at Maven and at Le Garage much better.
author: Mike P.

description:
I had lunch here with a group of folks from work and I must say that I was pretty impressed with their food and menu. Now, I've read a lot about their burger but I did not have that. Instead, I tried their warm open faced deviled egg sandwich and it was one of those "melt-in-your-mouth" moment. The size was not overwhelming and getting it with either fries or greens was just perfect.

This used to be South but I guess that went south. Anyway, this is an equally good replacement and I hope that with what their offering, that this place will be more successful that its predecessor.

To note, I will have to check out their burger  and the upside down apple crisp when I come back to this place.
author: Chad B.

description: Amazing burger. Solid space: dark, understated, comfortable but a bit small.
author: brett a.

description: Came here for the burger. Was not disappointed. Although, had I been my usual gluttonous self, I would have been mad at the size of the burger.
author: Peter H.

description: Food was great, service excellent and a fantastic spot for a bite before a ball game.  Setting doesn't offer a lot of ambiance and it's quite small but aside from that the place is definitely worth a look.  There were four of us and we all ordered differently, can't really go wrong with any of the mains.  The DiStefano Burrata cheese starter is absolutely delicious, I'm going to be looking for burrata next time I go shopping for sure!
author: Pink L.

description: Things you must have: the poulet vert, the pork, and the brussel sprout chips to start. What an incredible meal. Marlowe has a fantastic atmosphere-- it's rustic and classy at the same time. Based in SOMA a couple blocks from the Caltrain station, Marlowe is a fantastic spot to grab some good eats.
author: Alice Y.

description: The wonderful reviews and the reputation of Marlowe left me with high expectations. I was supremely underwhelmed.  The food was disappointing at best.  The burger was no better than mediocre.  I don't understand the "best burger in San Francisco" raves in so many reviews.  The service was very good, but that doesn't make up for the less than stellar food.  I have had much better at other places. I loved the broccoli chips, but that was not what I went there for.  Sorry Yelpers.  This is not a place I would recommend or go back to.
author: Lynn R.

description:
Casual dinner with reasonable prices and excellent food. The salad was to die for. I had a yummy burger, and they let me substitute the brussel sprouts for the fries. The only negative was the excessive use of salt. You could tell the food didn't need all the extra salt, it had excellent flavors without it. Kudos on having a good selection of non-alcoholic drinks. Try the ginger beer from Australia. 

Acoustics are a bit loud but that is a norm with restaurants. Staff was wonderfully attentive without being annoying, and the waitress had a cute accent. One of the staff even ran out after us to thank us and wish us a good evening.
author: Tina K.

description:
This review for the burger only.

Friend told me a local publication said that Marlowe had the new best burger in the city. I'm all about the burgers so I went. We didn't know we had to make reservations so we ended up sitting at the bar with one of our party of four standing. Not their fault, but a little awkward. Service was really good from the get go. Burgers came and proceeded with eating. The bacon taste like the bacon from Subway(I think, haven't had that in a long time). It's really dry and crispy. My bun was a little burned which took away from my medium rare patty. I have had several better burgers in the city and Pearls is at the top of the list and it's much cheaper.
author: Wes K.

description:
High Marks for Marlowe!  

From beginning to end my recent experience at Marlowe was a treat:  Snagged a parking spot right in front of the unusual plate glass window extolling various and humorous food-inspired quotes; beat the lunch rush by arriving before noon; and spent the next three courses loving what was in front of me and longing for what was coming next.

First Course: Smoky Cauliflower Gratin - which we all agreed could easily be called cauliflower mac 'n cheese and was Perfection with a capital P; the Brussels Sprouts Chips (yes I said chips) that were an inspiration to this avid b-sprout lover; and a Gem Salad with fennel, radish and orange that actually came with a citrus dressing that had some flavor (gasp) instead of the typically under-dressed and under-seasoned pretentious greens served at most SF restaurants.

Second Course:  Warm open face deviled egg sandwich with pickled chili, BACON, and smoky provolone on toasted brioche that was divine.  Just the right size for lunch when accompanied by the best fries I've had in... who can remember?  Extra crispy exterior, yet light golden in color with a creamy center and a dusting of chopped parsley, served with a tasty horseradish aioli.

Third Course: a light lemon custard souffle cake thing that was just the right sweet/tangy/light/refreshing dessert you want this time of year (and following the aforementioned gorging); and the upside down apple crisp served over the absolutely inspirational Surprise Breakfast ice cream (yes - bourbon, cornflakes and cream turns out to be the breakfast of champions)... both served in cute little mason jars.

My only disappointment is the chance that it may be months before I make my way back.  Don't let that happen to you.
author: Beth H.

description: Fantastic date spot without breaking the bank. Marlowe is upscale with a comfortable ambiance without being stuffy. We lucked out on a Saturday night and were quickly seated at the community table - which was surprisingly comfortable and still allowed for good conversation and flirting.  It's not  a terribly large restaurant, which adds to the charm and it's not overly noisy.  The brussels sprout chips were oo soo good.  I enjoyed the polenta which was creamy and delicious with the unusual egg addition.  The burger was complex and flavorful  - a great melding to flavors without being greasy.  The wait staff was attentive, polite and mindful. All in all, a lovely dining experience.
author: Valerie S.

description:
Ooh Marlowe, you are a little vixen! Co-worker suggested takeout for lunch, and I tried the open-faced deviled egg sandwich. Sounds weird, but oh my LORD was it delicious.

Perfectly toasty bread, rich and seasoned egg, all covered in chilis, bacon, and melted provolone, with horseradish aioli on the side. How good does that sound?! Tastes even better, and it comes in a somewhat compact size to not overwhelm you with the richness.

Got it with a side of the fries, which were perfectly cooked and salted. So delish. We will be back frequently, I'm sure, especially because they had our order prepared in about 10 minutes for pick-up. Love!
author: Kelly B.

description: It is great to have a place like this in SOMA!  The service is probably a 4 as is the food... The part that kills the rating for me is something simple...  when your average bill is $50+ (for 2)... a $4 ice tea isn't a free refill!  Come on!
author: Ray C.

description: Killer lunch spot - brussel sprout chips are amazing, the fries and horseradish dipping sauce are delicious, the soup is one of my favorites.  And when I really want to go nuts, I get the burrata dish as well and waddle back to the office.
author: Robby W.

description:
First of all, the ambiance: it is DARK in this place, and hubby and I were seated at the communal table with a diagonal post right in between us.

That said, the food was delicious.  Big winners included the brussels sprout chips (a little oily, but soooo tasty), the marinated calamari and mussels, the jerusalem artichoke soup, and the desserts.  Ohhh the desserts--we shared a chocolate cream pie and an upside down apple crisp, and both were off the charts.  I thought the french fries were good, but nothing to write home about.  Hubby also enjoyed the marrow and the deviled eggs.

I'd go back, but would call ahead for a reservation to avoid the communal table seat with the bar in the middle.
author: H A.

description:
Small and tasty establishment. Had the $13 burger with fries. Not the greatest burger I've ever had, but highly acceptable and one I would certainly have again. Cauliflower cheese was mouth itchingly cheesy, not sure there was any cauliflower in there, but it tasted great so I didn't care. 

Had to wait an hour for a table without reservation. This would have been a lot less had the 5 hags who hogged the corner table for 90 minutes after there dinner had fucked off. Who sits at a table in a busy restaurant for 90 mins without ordering anything, just sipping the water? If you hags read this learn some manners. You cost the waiter about $50 in tips by occupying that table.

Staff really nice and friendly and give us free fries to make up for the aforementioned bitches. I see this place scores 4 and 5s a lot so maybe I'm just mean, but I like to reserve my 5s for true greatness. It's a good place with tasty food and nice staff. I will go again, providing the hags aren't there.
author: Lager K.

description:
We had:
*brussels sprout chips 
(tasty, super crispy, very salty)
*the burger 
(good, but definitely not the best ever--I liked the crispness of the bacon very much and the horseradish aioli was a good accompaniment. however, I ordered medium and T ordered well done, and they seemed cooked to the same degree.)
*cauliflower gratin
(virtually inedible for us, as the smoke flavoring was extremely overpowering. I can still imagine that for those who like a strong smoke flavor, this would be a satisfying dish.)
*upside down apple crisp
(my favorite part of the meal--the ice cream was creamy and flavorful, and the caramel was so tasty. I love the jar it's served in as well--it reminds me of catching fireflies in an imagined childhood.)

I love the ambiance and loudness of this place--it makes you feel like you're at a party even if you're a party of two. Extra points for serving Session lager, one of our favorite beers. We sat at the counter and our server was really attentive, and quietly funny. (Side note--the counter is wide and fairly roomy, though the stools were terribly uncomfortable. There was also no good place to store my coat or bag--there was a hook under the counter but it was in a very awkward spot.) 
All in all I have a positive feeling about the whole visit, though none of the dishes I tried instilled a burning desire to go back and eat more. (Except for the dessert, and that's because I'm a dessert whore.) :)
Food 3.5; Ambiance 4; Service 4
author: Marissa R.

description:
Without a reservation, I was able to get seating fairly quickly (including an interim seating at an unusual bar seating).  While seated at a lower section of the forgotten section of the bar, we were eventually offered a drink menu and ordered beers.  Approximately 10 minutes later, a waitress kindly greeted us and told us a table had opened up and that we could move to their if we wished.  We moved to the table (more conducive to group discussion) and looked forward to food service.

After reviewing our menus, we eagerly placed our orders for food.  I order the Poulet Verde, while my two friends ordered the Marlowe burger and polenta, respectively.  A slight wait later, we were offered bread accompanied with butter and sea salt -- a pleasant offering while waiting for our main dishes.  In the interim, we conversed over our beers and found the ambience of the venue pleasant, but a bit odd given a strange I-beam running at an approximately 30 degree angle across a nearby table.

When the food came, we were quite eager to quickly dig in to our delicious choices.  As I had heard, the menu sets very basic expectations but the food delivers beyond what is described in the menu; I rather enjoyed my Poulet Verde but found it slightly on the salty side.  The fingerling potatoes that accompanied my dish were quite welcomed -- it may have been the black olives that provided an additionally salty taste that I noticed.  After our mains, we proceeded to order the dark chocolate dessert which featured slightly sweet pistachos that had a hint of salt that accentuated the pleasant chocolate notes without the dessert coming across overly sweet.

Overall, the experience was quite pleasant, and I was particularly pleased to find a great bistro in SoMa that I hope become one of my well-frequented establishments.  This is a cozy place that would be great for a date or casual small group gatherings.
author: Josh H.

description: Yummy. Make reservations - it's a small, cozy place and fills up fast!
author: Ching V.

description:
The atmosphere here is nice, although I would have loved to be seated at a table. The hostess asked us to sit at the bar because she didn't have anything open, even though several spots remained open for the duration of our dinner. The bar stools there are uncomfortable. 

The food was very good. The burger was delicious, not the best I've had in the city but in my top 4.The brussel chips were very tasty, so similar to the sideboard's brussels in Danville-maybe a little better. 

The menu has a nice variety, lots of yummy things I'd like to try. Beer list needs work! I'm always a bit disappointed when there's not an IPA on the menu especially when northern CA is home to so many great ones.
author: Alanna G.

description:
bottom line: a greasy affair

we came to grab a bite for lunch and ended up ordering the marlowe burger and fries, which we had heard a lot of good things about.  the burger tasted fine and didn't really stand out, though it was a bit on the greasy side (dripping with grease down the side of my hand, not quite my thing).  the fries were also underwhelming and had us both feeling pretty gross as they were too heavy and salty as well, and didn't taste any different than your average fry.  on a more positive note, the crab and rock shrimp louie was fairly fresh and tasty.  overall, the food was just alright and i feel that i can find a better burger place that lives up to the hype and pricing.
author: Aaron T.

description:
I have high hopes for new Soma spot Marlowe, but my first visit did not meet expectations. Or hit anywhere close to expectations.

The restaurant is smaller than inside than it appears from the outside. The bar seats six across and I became well acquainted with it while my party of 4 waited 30 minutes to be seated. The decor is well done, and I probably would have enjoyed the "cozy" feel of Marlowe if I didn't experienced feeling cramped into the bar then being seated at the communal table (leather topped oak park benches are still park benches). The small tables look like they could be the charming backdrop for an intimate date. The lighting is low as are the ceilings, making the place feel more claustrophobic than quaint when you're squished onto the communal table.

The food didn't really make up for the wait. Starting with the Brussels sprout chips we ordered at the bar, the food just didn't meet expectations given how much they charged. As a huge Brussels sprout fan, I was excited to try the interesting sounding dish. Unfortunately when the mostly soggy, oily dish arrived and I got a mouth full of lemon zest, I wasn't impressed. The few crispy "chip" like pieces I managed to find were delicious, but they were few and far between -- the majority were soggy and another portion had gotten all of the lemon flavoring. They were otherwise bland.

Among the 4 of us we had 2 orders of polenta, a burger and the lamb dish. The only one who was entirely impressed with his dinner was my friend who had ordered the lamb. Having not tried the burger, I can only note that there was apparently nothing outstanding about it. The polenta was bland, well cooked with a nice texture but entirely lacking in flavor. The mushrooms it was topped with felt nicely decorative on top of the oily arugula but didn't really add much to the polenta. The pecorino cheese and truffle weren't really present in the flavor, leaving me to wonder why I had paid $18 for what tasted like a half-hearted attempt at polenta. To round out the food review, I should mention that they have a decent wine list.

All that being said, the reason I have hope for Marlowe is that the owners seem involved, from what I can see on their website they were pulling both serving and hosting duties. I think they'll learn to work with the space, lowering how many people they attempt to accommodate, and just generally setting in. I plan to go back with my fingers crossed to see how they do going forward.
author: JessKate O.

description: YUMMM... We had the pleasure of trying the fried chicken sandwich and the burger. Both sandwiches were delicious, you could tell they pan fried the breads with butter from the crunchy buttery feeling when it enters your mouth. The burger was extra juicy, so my bread got soggy pretty quickly. I think if the fries hadn't sit so long, it would've been great. It seemed like they fried the fries a little longer which makes it crispier, but when it sits longer it actually just becomes hard. We sat at the bar and got a lot of attention from the waitress. We also fried the pomegranate ice tea. My boyfriend insists on trying everything that is pomegranate, it could be socks, he won't care and still eat it. The ice tea was not so great. You had the lipton tea taste with a tartness.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I was sad when South Food + Wine Bar closed, both because of the great food, as well as because of the great staff. Fortunately, Marlowe continues the tradition, including some familiar faces. And I like the new interior.

We went there for dinner. The Baked Oysters were very good (thank you, guys!), and the Spiced Prawns were better than the somewhat similar dish at South (which was good). Some people here loved the Lamb Mixed Grill, but I actually preferred the lamb at South. But just like the Cod it was good. The Upside Down Apple Crisp was very good.

I still hope somebody would open an Aussie place in SF - but Marlowe is definitely a good American Bistro-kind of place. Try it out!
author: Kaj HeGe H.

description:
Everything I've had here has been really good.

Try the crispy brusselsprouts, oysters, cheesy cauliflower.  Solid burger also.  And a nice selection of wine & beer.
author: Kelvin H.

description: Since my original review, I visited Marlowe a number of additional times while living in the neighborhood. I've had a lot of great dinners there so I'm updating the review to reflect my current view.
author: Ryan B.

description: Figs with bacon, mushroom soup with truffle oil, local black codband couliflower gratin were perfect. I cannot wait to come back. Also, it's a stone's throw from Caltrain for peninsula foodies.
author: Peter D.

description: I've been here a few times, convenient location in the neighborhood - and have always ordered the burger...fantastico! Nice intimate atmosphere, good wine list but menu seems a little pricey for what you get.
author: Alex C.

description: This little place has a great menu and good energy! I only had wine and an appetizer, but I can't wait to come back for dinner!
author: D. S.

description: I went for the burger, and I was not disappointed. The fries are also fantastic. However, this space is really small and it's pretty much impossible to have a conversation, even if you have your own table.
author: Ashley T.

description:
One of my favorite spots in the city. A little noisy and crowded but I've been here several times and always had a great meal. A good spot for out of town guests. 

Try the brussel sprout chips and the poulet vert. The burger is also good.
author: Robert J.

description: Wonderful meal with great service. Really tasty brussel sprouts and possibly the best pork chop Ive ever had.
author: Sharon H.

description:
Highly recommend the Crispy Brussels sprout chips. Crazy good. 

Fun place to go after work for a drink too!
author: Mike J.

description:
Very enjoyable meal on a Saturday night ! We had :
Grilled Oysters(delicious),little gem salad with avocado - equally delicious. The cod was absolutely a perfect dish with lovely vegetables, only the lamb could have been a bit b etter.It was undercooked for medium and a bit tough.
Dessert was the chocolate pudding and it was great. The wine list is priced well and we had a very nice Preston Petite Syrah for under $ 50.00.  The waiter though good was a bit over attentive.
I will be back for sure.
author: Maria C.

description: Very cool inside!  Really liked the decor and ambiance. Service was just ok, our waiter seemed put out when I asked for ketchup and took forever to box my friend's leftovers.  Food was good, but not great.
author: Maureen B.

description: Looove this place.  The brussel sprout chips were just as good as they were cracked up to be. I died and went to heaven after tasting the foie gras mouse, and the burger/fries were delicious as well. The service was excellent, I love the interior, and the location is great (right near the caltrain station). I will definitely go back again.
author: Michelle T.

description:
3.5 stars....

The chowder oysters were good. Unique, but probably really easy to make at $3 an oyster. The burger was a good size and not too overwhelming. It was also cooked well with a unique flavor mix. The fries were delicious. Totally unhealthy and very salty, but now and again you just have to enjoy your fries. The special mint and orange ice tea was also good, but for $5 totally not worth it.

The ambiance was really nice and so was the decor. It's also really affordable for what it is.

On the downside....The service was really really nice and friendly, but super slow and perceptive. I also had to ask where my to-go box was because they forgot to give it to me even though we were waiting for awhile. Our water glasses were constantly empty and we always had to ask instead of them coming to fill it up. I would give this place a 3.5 star if I could.
author: Katherine F.

description:
This is one of my faves in SF.  The food is terrific and the atmosphere is great.

The chicken is one of the best in the city.  The sauce that comes with it is the bomb.

The burger is one of the best in the city - you'll feel like you need a quadruple bypass after eating it but its DELICIOUS.

The bussel sprouts chips are plain awesome.

There spicy prawns are incredible, smokey and spice = good.

Overall this place is awesome.
author: Alan P.

description:
Best Chicken I have ever tasted in my 52 years of living! 

None of my party, nor I liked the Brussell sprouts, but we went wild for the apple crisp dessert with bourbon icecream and the chocolate pudding was to die for.

Atmosphere is loud, industrial, and suited to the young crowd. Not a place for old broads like me.
author: Jen C.

description:
Marlowe does not disappoint with its rustic American fare, and the simple, elegant butcher shop aesthetic. Our reservations were at 9:30 for a group that had dwindled to three at the last minute. The hostess never missed a beat, and seated us promptly. Our host was friendly and helpful, charting us through the menu and offering suggestions. We went with the crab and shrimp louie with tabasco to start, and it was fantastic. 
If you've heard rave reviews for the Marlowe burger, it lives up to the hype. My friend, the burger connoisseur, gave it a two thumbs up, and thats an accomplishment, considering her hands were busy with the burger! Main courses were flavorful and well portioned, and the chocolate creme pot for dessert is chocolate-y with crunchy bits of...something, and ever so slightly salty as well. It was definitely the most mature chocolate creme pot I've ever encountered. 
I could sum up this experience as being: Grown up. And that's a good thing. It's a great neighborhood addition, a step away from Caltrain and MUNI, and upscale enough to bring co workers or out of town guests without the pretentiousness. Classy and casual. Marlowe, you've earned yet another fan.
author: Zehra A.

description: Decent food, and I can see why others like it, but not for me.  Bone marrow was decent, there just wasn't enough of it (may have been that particular oddly-shaped bone).  The duck liver is very good (I like all things liver), but the spiced shrimp was ok and the brussel chips were way too oily. The burger was decent, but not good enough to be the most popular menu item IMO.
author: Josh Q.

description:
first off, no reservations for 4 people and two people were 30 mins late. we got a table and no one gave us crap for hogging the table. we're sorry for doing that, but thank you for making us feel welcomed. next time, reservations for sure!

order the drinks.  yes, you have to have a wife and a mistress. delicious!

the brown brussel sprouts are sooo good.  not what you used to have as a kid, theses were salty, buttery morsels of delicioiusness.  you will NEED two orders, yes, you're welcome.  

don't judge, but we ordered the burger and split it 4 ways as an appetizer.  now that you know, you can do the same.  again, you're welcome. it's as good as everyone said it was, i'm so glad I ordered it.  yes, the fries were damn good too.  

that little jem salad, not little at all. packed full of all the goodness of vegetables and makes you feel just a tad less guilty about the burger and fries, just a little, cuz we also had the brown butter sprouts staring back at us.

oh the artichoke soup, so creamy. it's large enough for both of us to get a good taste.  great started.  

polenta that good?  the perfect creamyness of polenta with those little mushrooms and crunchy arugula?  oh and you have to top it off with an egg?  oh HEAVEN!.

the porkchop, so tender, so good.  

I can't wait to try out the rest of the menu on my next trip to Marlowe.
author: Ames K.

description: I'd give 4 stars if their oysters are a bit bigger. Otherwise, I can see food are created with care and craft, setting's intimate and service is great.
author: Bo D.

description:
their burgers are 5 stars, but paying almost $15 for one is just too hard to justify. that said, if you are up for emptying your pockets for a gourmet burger, you can't go wrong with the marlowe burger. i ordered mine to go, and 20 mins later it was still ridiculously juicy with the bun intact(read...NOT SOGGY) how do they do that??? and what's better than bacon and cheese in your burger? that's right, nothing! every bite was scrumptious, finger lickin gooood. 
don't overlook the fries that come with your burger. these are fries from the higher beings. they are extremely crunchy with a very distinct taste. i say thumbs up to frying potatoes in rice oil! i thought fries from holy grill are good, these take it up another notch!
author: Melissa Y.

description: Great Pan Seared Co-Ho Salmon with Quinoa Salad,and Yogurt sauce
author: Leon F.

description:
Dinned with my daughter after a long drive for me.  The place was a delight.  Simply Awesome!  

Food was exceptionally flavorful.  Loved the crispy Brussels spouts.  The corn soup was superb, and even more so with the Riesling.  You've never had deviled eggs like these - I kept popping one after another in my mouth.  Forget about the cholesterol.  The pork chop, laced with prosciutto complemented each other amazingly well and the sauce just melded everything together.  The flavors in the poulet vert just exploded in your mouth with flavor - very herbaceous.

The staff was also amazing.  They seemed to love their work.
author: Jay F.

description: I have to admit, I thought I'd already discovered some of the best burgers in the Bay Area; but GAWD DAMN, then I tried Marlowe.  Yeah yeah yeah, Michael Bauer, blah blah.  Well color me purple, the man was right.  This really might be the mothership for burger lovers.  We came in for Dine About Town ... the gem salad was spectacular and simply gorgeous.  We also had the chocolate cream pie in a jar and that too was amazing.  This place keeps it very simple, but with a lot of attention to detail.  My only complaint - dang this place is small!  If you can get in, I highly suggest you check it out.
author: Sho O.

description: Holy goodness this is my new favorite gem. Relaxed, confident, consistent... I am in love. Coming from fine dining three days a week ( I work at a pretty high profile joint in sf) I was thrilled to walk in at 9:30 on a warm Thursday with a great table, wonderful service and a lovely fish entree. I loved the sole and the brussels... I cannot wait to return
author: Liz C.

description: Enough about that burger already. I recently tried Marlowe's warm open-faced deviled egg sandwich and it blew my gastric gasket! The bacon and provolone add to the richness, contrasting the creaminess quite nicely, but it's that pickled chili that moves this sammy towards the divine.
author: Nish N.

description: Food was amazing!!! Went there and we tried multiple dishes that I would recommend. We got the bone marrow, devilled eggs, beet salad, oysters, brussels sprouts  and Marlowe burger. Everything was spot on with its flavors. Prices were reasonable. Dinner for 4 with a bottle of wine came out to $140. What are you waiting for, go there now!
author: Rashad R.

description: the lamb was amazing and the hamburguer too, in my opinion .  desert chocolat with salt absolutly delicioso. personal friendly
author: Ramon R.

description: Was able to get a reservation same day on a Monday which was great. The brussel sprout chips are awesome. Not really chips though and it's a small serving but still worth it. The mussel/calamari toast was pretty incredible too. Good appetizer size portion. We all got the burger and we were not disappointed. It was amazing. All in all I'll definitely be going back.
author: nick g.

description: Yep, the burger is fantastic and got it without the cheddar and bacon to be sure... I'm sure. At $14 with fries, that's quite the deal. Add the Little Gem Salad (oh so light and delicious - olive oil, lemon, shallot, salt) and great company. and life is complete, at least for tonight.
author: Becky S.

description: Beyond good. Great thoughtfulness for the dishes. The brussel sprouts were so unique and a tasty appetizer. The burger was amazing. And, their signature drink of the night was superb.
author: Rachel S.

description:
On our first visit to Marlowe, we LIKED...
**chocolate cream pie in a jar. This was the best item we ate that night. The chocolate cream was rich and smooth, the Graham cracker crust added contrast, the sprinkle of sea salt on top contributed wonderful flavor.
**brussels sprouts chips was interesting and original. Tasted good but loaded with oil.
**honey glazed pork belly was tasty and meaty, a generous portion with delicious sauce, but lacked the crispy exterior that is the hallmark of this dish.
**coffee ($4) was freshly brewed, generous size cup, came with 2 lumps of raw sugar on the side.

We were LESS impressed with...
**Poulet Verte (chicken) looked mouth watering, perfectly roasted and smothered with a rich brown sauce. The chicken was juicy and tender, but the sauce was the spoiler, gloppy and had an unappealing sour and bitter taste.
**black cod was melt in your mouth tender but the flavors were unremarkable, bland and a little sour.
author: Jerry M.

description: I hate it when you go to a restaurant that spaces the tables only 6 in apart and you feel like you are going to bump the person sitting at the table next to you. Well this place was like that. There is no place to stand and wait for your table, there is no space to hang out in the bar area (if thats what that was) and the restaurant was obscenely hot, I was happy the the man sitting next me finally just opened a window himself. I can't even remember if the food was good honestly because there was so much wrong there. It looked like an old nail salon turned into a restaurant.
author: L N.

description:
A Fun place with a casual atmosphere. I love the fact that they have Boylan's cane cola available if you don't feel like drinking. FYI they  only serve beer and wine. 
Now, on to the food. A friend at dinner and I tried their Deviled eggs, and brussel sprout chips for appetizers. The eggs were odd because of the melted cheese on top but otherwise tasty. The brussel sprout chips were unique and flavorful. Three of us had the burgers w fries. Good burger, at first. I would definitely have them hold the horseradish mayo because by the third bite that was all I could taste, and kept tasting all night, if ya get my drift. The polenta with wild mushrooms, arugala and a poached egg was very good and the components of the dish went together very well. The pork chop was excellent but the bread pudding it came with was odd with  a squishy yet burned texture. 
Skip the desserts. The pound cake with lemon curd and raspberries tasted like Pledge, The apple crisp was passable at best.
I would come here again to try the bone marrow which looked amazing. Be forewarned that it is a small, warm and noisy restaurant. Some people like that, others don't. Most of the staff was very nice.
author: Kim R.

description: Highly recommend getting the brussel sprouts chips and fried chicken sandwich. The chicken is moist and tender. The chicken sandwich is way better than the burger.
author: Kar Y.

description: Absolutely a great place to eat. I love their burgers along with roasted pistachios.
author: S J.

description:
great spot. for certain things of course. but for what i was there for on this particular night, it was perfect. cool decor, comfortable and pretty fly, all good waitstaff and the food was delish. 

came on a first date, shared the marrow app, something i'd never order on my own simply because the thought of ordering bone marrow is a little strange to me but it was really fantastic. then had the poulet vert entree. also delicious. 

definitely not cheap but a great option if you're looking for a new date night spot.
author: Georgia W.

description: Great South of Market atmosphere, delicious and artfully prepared dishes.
author: David B.

description:
the marlowe was the first bite of red meat i had in 3 months.  i dont know if it was the withdrawal from the  addictive qualities of slaughtered bovine but it tasted wonderful.  best burger in SOMA.  better than brickhouse?  i think so.  definitely classier.

gets crowded at dinner time.  be prepared.
author: Paran Y.

description: I enjoyed my food, it was nice! I tried the burger, fried chicken sandwich, fries, greens, and truffle mushrooms. Everything was fine, good, the mushrooms were to die for!  There was nothing particularly amazing about the place...somewhat typical rustic American SOMA style restaurant along the lines of Serpentine and Slow Club. I liked it but I wouldn't go out of my way to go back.
author: Hella M.

description: This is a great hidden gem in Mission Bay. They're known for their burgers, but the deviled eggs are what keeps me coming back. They are amazing!
