The staff is friendly and the food is great, the only negatives are that the space is a bit small so when it's crowded, it's really full (which it often is...again a testament to their food)  and it can be a bit pricey, especially if you're enjoying some wine with dinner. but their price is very typical with SF prices, nothing outrageous.
author: Ashley G.

description:
The impending arrival of our first child has influenced us in unexpected ways.  We loved burgers to begin with, but the hunger associated with pregnancy may have amplified E's appetite for them even more than usual.  We also are concerned that our ability to eat at restaurants outside of our immediate neighborhood may be severely curtailed soon.  These two factors motivated us to try out Marlowe up in the city, which has a reputation for serving a great burger.

I came in from work on the Caltrain - Marlowe is conveniently situated across the street from the 4th and King station on Townsend, and walked right in to a seat at the bar.  I ordered some of the fried brussels sprout chips to munch while I waited for E.  They were pleasantly bitter and crispy, maybe a tad on the oily side.  E arrived shortly and we both ordered a burger done medium.  The burgers are moderate in size, but very well executed.  Both our patties were done to what we consider medium (still pink inside).  The buns were ever so slightly burnt on the outsides, which gives a satisfying charred taste to the sandwich.  The bacon and cheddar toppings come standard and were tasty.  The fries were also perfectly executed - crispy outside and moist inside with a generous side of horseradish sauce.  We agreed it's tied for our favorite burger with the Refuge down in San Carlos.  Of course it's pricey compared to a fast food burger, but the craftmanship and quality ingredients are in ample evidence here and I felt like it was worth very penny.  

Finally, no Coke served here, only Cane Cola, which while maybe more environmentally responsible, does not refresh me as well as a real Coke.  

On the way out the hostess congratulated us and told us that some families do manage to come with their little ones.  We hope to be able to do the same.
author: Don L.

description: I love love love love the burger and fries here. Did I say i love it yet? Went here for lunch yesterday and it was pretty crowded. Reservations (yup even for lunch) is recommended if you want to get guaranteed seating within 10 minutes of your arrival. I haven't tried anything else on the menu but will be coming back to taste the deviled egg sandwich and of course anytime I need an awesome burger. YUMMY!
author: quynh n.

description: Brussels sprouts chips. Well, isn't that clever. Go there, order a drink and eat the brussels sprout chips...do it.
author: Jessica H.

description:
the place is a bit cramped but has a generally welcoming vibe to it.  Not all of the tables are very friendly for conversation.  The bench seats in the center has beams that may obstruct you from actually seeing the person across from you!  Very very bad.  Other seats seemed cozy and great for small groups (2-4 only).  Luckily, we had the seats on the bench that didn't have the big pillar between me and my dinner-mates.

The food in general is good.  3-4 star.  Appetizers are absolutely knockout.  Ordered the spiced jumbo shrimp, dungeness crab louie, baby beats and burrata and the crispy brussell sprouts.  Each and all were amazing.  

We did also order the deviled eggs (good, not great) but there's a story with this.  We were told when we were seated that they only have 3-4 deviled eggs left for the evening and that we should rush order them now (as soon as we sat down) so that we can grab them.  So in a panic, we ordered 4 (one for each of us).  She came back and said she only had 3 left for the night.  We took them.  When we got them, they were good, not great....but what was annoying was around the time we received our entrees, the table next to us ordered 6 deviled eggs and got them promptly.  Hmmm...did they just go out and get more eggs?  I thought they ran out?  Was it a tactic used to get us to order them?  Were they trying to get rid of them?  Who knows.  But the place came off as dishonest.

The entrees themselves were a bit underwhelming.  We ordered the marlowe burger (definitely NOT something to get) and the Poulet Vert, which was overly salty.

We passed on dessert after much debate once we noticed that all of them are prepared in a jar.  Did not sound appetizing (could be though!) so we passed.

-------
UPDATE

The gm at marlowe wrote after seeing this review. Was good that she did. It does make one feel that their voice is being heard. In any event, i am left feeling I should give it another go sometime. Esp for the apps. They are standout.
author: Alex Y.

description: Well, 3.5 stars. I'm always looking for new places to eat in the city, after studying reviews on yelp, I'm a little disappointed in Marlowe's. It's overrated. The staff was friendly but didn't come around too often to "wait" on the tables. I had ordered the burger, it was a little undercooked. The place itself was modern but small so you would have to yell to conversate.
author: Linda N.

description: I've been to Marlowe a couple of times and it's been consistently delicious both times.  I am a huge polenta fan and when it's paired with mushrooms, truffle oil, arugula and a poached egg it does not get any better!  I would eat this stuff every day if I knew it weren't filled with more butter than I should probably consume in a week.  The creamed seasonal greens were delicious as well... I could have eaten the whole bowl on my own!  The famous Marlowe burger is very tasty but I think there are definitely some restaurants in the city that can compete with it.  The restaurant is pretty small but both times I walked in with one other person without a reservation and managed to grab a seat at the bar.  If you're looking for a seat in the dining room I would absolutely suggest reservations.  Good job, Marlowe... I'm a fan!
author: Ali K.

description: For the neighborhood, not a terrible option. Brussels Sprout Chips were indeed pretty good. Everything was too salty, IMO.
author: Sam Z.

description:
just here to validate what everyone's already said - their burger is to die for.  i hear they soak the bun in duck fat or something terrible like that.  the bacon doesn't hurt and the cheese is smoked.

then the fries are double fried.

wash it down with brussel sprout chips & burrata and your evening is complete.

TIP:  don't forget to leave a giant carafe of water by your bedside at night after dinner cause all that good stuff is MIGHTY SALTY!
author: Josie M.

description: Did I show up on a bad night? The burger that i had was messy and I had to down 4 pints to get rid of that grease out of my mouth. I have to go back with one of you that loved your burger but mine sucked.
author: Chris D.

description: Went here for lunch and it was damn good. Had the burger and split the cauliflower gratin with my wife - holy crap that was delicious.  A little on the pricey side but good quality food.
author: German L.

description:
My friend and I came here on a Saturday night. Unfortunately, we had issues getting a taxi (imagine that) and were a little late for our reservation. Our table had been given away, so we were offered a spot at the communal table (no thanks) or the low end of the bar . We should have just left because waiting for the table was the highlight of the night. Well, the bread was okay, too. 

I ordered the little gem salad which was fine, though nothing special, with the seared black cod. The fish was watery, flavorless and poached - not seared. I was told the dish could not be prepared without butter and that it was just a taste, but the flavor overwhelmed my palate. I'd have sent it back if I hadn't been starving....

To top off the experience, there were little bugs flying around that seemed attracted to a decorative piece on the wall of the bar filled with fresh limes and lemons. Let's just say the interior decorator had it right ... 

It's a lemon.
author: Jamie S.

description: Went to this place today, and even though it was crowded the wait wasn't long at all. We got the brussel sprouts chips and it was great! Tasted just like regular potato chips, but had a different taste. Then we ordered the Marlowe Burger which was fantastic. The burger wasn't the best burger, but it was very delicious. Their fries were great as well. Really good service, their coke, and lemonade was like imported from England or something, but it had a different taste. Overall a good place, very pricey though.
author: Jonathan L.

description: Directly across from the CalTrain station, very pleasant interior, great food and drink. My personal favorite? The warm deviled egg sandwich. Absolutely amazing. Yummmmmm.
author: Bret W.

description: Amazing burger! Great atmosphere and really cool seating.  Any place with open kitchens has nothing to hide so I dig that too.  Only minor drawbacks: they messed up my reservation, also brought me the fried brussel sprouts when I ordered french fries....but no worries, they still sat me, brought me fries, and the sprouts were on the house.  Will be back for sure
author: Ryan H.

description:
Noticed Marlowe had moved into South's old digs on my way to work and decided to try it for dinner.  

The idea of an American brasserie is cool to begin with and Marlowe's decor seemed to live up to that image -- dark wood, white tile floor, casual but sophistocated, small but stylish.

Started with a cheese plate special.  Featured a cool, crunchy tapanade whose acidity cut through the richness of the cheese nicely.  Outstanding truffle sauce.

Poulet vert (chicken) was delicious.  Super moist and tons of flavor.  Waiter mentioned it's marinated overnight.

Burger was cooked perfectly.  Simple and nuanced.

Staff were very attentive and friendly.

Can't wait to get back there for the novelty of brussels sprout chips and roasted bone marrow!
author: John W.

description: We have dined here by accident and by design.  We love it so much, we followed Anna's blog on NYC when we spent the weekend there 11/3-7.  Anna and Jennifer are the perfect combo and great advisors.  Wish we'd gotten to Park Tavern before the reviews, but we'll brave the crowds!k
author: Cheryl B.

description: The Marlowe Burger is the surprisingly the best burger I've ever had! I took it Medium-Well. The shoestring fries that accompany are cooked to a nice crisp and served with lemon aioli. The burger has caramelized onions and bacon -nothing crazy but full of flavor!
author: Harper C.

description: So good.  We went to try the burger, which ended up being our last favorite.  I say "last" favorite (rather than least favorite) because everything was really good.  We shared everything.  My favorites were, in order: baked oyster (one is enough per person, but silly good, otherwise probably diminishing returns would dilute the deliciousness), cauliflower gratin, deviled egg and fried brussels sprouts.  The burger and fries were good, but I would rather graze on the other things.  We also got the corn soup and pea soup/ricotta toast which were good, but not like the other things.  If you go with others that are willing to share, you are set, so you don't have to order an entree and be cornered in!
author: Amber B.

description: I really enjoyed the atmosphere and the service. Our waitress was awesome. She helped us decide between wines by giving us a taste of two different wines.  The steak was good but could be better. The steak was a little tough. This was the biggest upset. The sauce was incredible. It had flavors of mushroom and meat... Yumm. The cheesy cauliflower was to die for.  Lastly, the brussel sprouts was beyond great. I would come back just for these and I'm not a brussle sprout fan.
author: Ryan A.

description: Probably 3.5 stars.   I think marlowe has potential - the dishes are pretty good, I have loved the space (slightly industrial, very SOMA) since it was South Food and Bar, and the service was very friendly and helpful (if a bit slow because they're packed), but the food was honestly a bit too salty for me.  My bf started with the little gem salad which he enjoyed (avocado, market veggies, citrus vinaigrette) and then had the poulet vert, which was good. But I started with the roasted bone marrow which turned up swimming in oil (I give them kudos for giving me an extra portion because the first bone was too small,  except I couldn't really enjoy either because of the oil).  And then I had the stuffed sole (stuffed with dungeness crab, glazed celery root, baby fennel, meyer lemon and capers) which definitely had potential but was too salty.  We did enjoy our malbec and cabs.  All in all, definitely worth going back to try again, but I might need to ask for less salt.
author: Vivian W.

description: Love this place. It is small and can get loud but feels cozy so it's fine. The service is great and everyone is really nice. Great wine selection. The reason why this place is so awesome is because they have one of the best hamburgers in SF (arguably the best underrated burger in SF) Seriously, it's juicy, tasty perfect size, perfect burger. yuuuuummm.  Actually the meatballs here are pretty awesome too.
author: Cori B.

description:
amazing food.

make sure you don't miss the deviled eggs (but pretty much everything there is just awesome, you can't go wrong with anything)
author: Daniel V.

description: Definitely get the burger!! It's SO good. Great ambiance, reminds me of a small intimate restaurant in NYC. Very friendly staff. Would highly recommend it!
author: Stephanie B.

description: What a gem!  Modern, yet unpretentious atmosphere, excellent food - the marrow and the burger were particularly delicious - and great value. Since trying this place, I have recommended it to others, who all equally enjoyed their experience.
author: Lindsey C.

description: We had tickets to see Cavalia, and Marlowe seemed like a fine place to visit before the 8pm show.  It is easily walkable to AT&T Park and the nearby field hosting the horse extravaganza.  Marlowe is small, and has a vibe like a friendly tavern.  We arrived around 5:30 and had a communal table to ourselves.  The bar menu is the way to go.  Wines were reasonably priced and good quality.  R is still talking about the 'best hamburger in San Francisco."  I loved my perfectly seasoned steak tartare.  We both demolished the fab brussel sprout chips.  Go!  Enjoy this gem of spot when in the area.
author: Pat M.

description:
Came here last week with some co-workers, after hearing rave reviews.

Started with the pistachio nuts and Brussel sprout chips...they were okay, a little greasy but tasty.

It was a party of six, and all of us decided to order the little gem salad. There was nothing LITTLE about this salad.  We could have easily split 3 for the group, but the majority of us finished their salad.  The dressing was light, and the avocado was creamy and tasty.

I ordered the pork chop and fried cheese dumplings...and it was prepared perfectly.  Not exactly diet food, but all tasted fresh and cooked perfectly.

Some of the other entrees our group included polenta (good but rich), burger (good but not the BEST EVER), stuffed sole (amazing).

Will definitely go back, when I can get a reservation.

Beer and wine only, people!
author: thai p.

description:
exactly my style of menu.  items enhanced with bacon, caramelized onions, truffle oil, poached farm egg...plus taking something i don't usually like and making it tasty, i.e. crispy brussel sprouts
came for lunch and tried:
Sauteed wild mushrooms with grilled sourdough, truffle oil & poached farm egg -- very tasty, mix of flavors and textures spot on
Brussels sprouts chips with Meyer lemon & sea salt -- surprisingly excellent, just the perfect amount of lemon and salt
Baked oysters covered with bacon bits -- good
Warm open faced deviled egg sandwich with pickled chili, bacon, & aged provolone -- tasty combination, bacon done expertly
Marlowe burger with caramelized onions, cheddar, bacon & horseradish aioli -- not unique but executed perfectly, fries too
few specials on the wall
fast lunch, efficient with great execution and flavor profile
this place highlights why SF dining is good (chef previously from Cortez)
author: Rob C.

description: Excellent revision to the previous SOUTH format. I have been there 3 times for dinner over the past month. Once at the bar, once at the low bar table, and once in the dining room. I was sure to sample something different each time and I was never disappointed. The one constant at each of my meals was the Crispy Brussels sprout chips. Awesome! The polenta is fantastic and the Poulet Vert and Grilled Lamb were perfection. The desserts are quite wonderful as well, especially the TCHO dark chocolate bar pudding. Excellent. I'll be a regular!
author: Ram T.

description: I am a huge fan of Marlowe's.  I love the space and ambiance.  You have to try the burger and a nice, bold red.  It is a great way to spend the night.
author: Joe S.

description: My girlfriends wanted to try the burgers, since they read that they are best in the city. I had the poulet vert, which was seasoned so perfectly. My husband and girlfriends had burgers and they all raved that they were cooked perfectly. All of this was great, but when two other friends arrived the staff went the extra mile to accommodate us. It was the cherry on top.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
Came here on a Friday evening at around 9 pm with my sister.  We had no reservation but were seated within 15 minutes which was very nice.  The place is small but it is very nicely decorated. It was cozy and modern yet warm.  We parked on Townsend which was free after 6pm so that was nice.  The hostess was very friendly and tried to seat us as soon as she could (5 stars to her).  She told us when we first got there that we were going to sit at the bar but then a spot on the communal table opened up and she put us there.  We ordered the brussel sprout chips, two baked oysters, the pork chop, and the burger.  I was debating whether to get the burger or the steak.  My sister debated over the pork chop or the scallops and went with the pork chop since the scallops don't come without the mushrooms (which she hates).  

Brussel Sprout Chips - 5  stars - Amazingly delicious!
Baked Oysters - 4 stars - Tasty, full of stuff on top which supplemented the small oyster.  
Pork Chop - 5 stars  - My sister said it was the best pork chop she has had.  I thought it was very good but not the best ever.  The seasonings reminded me of thanksgiving, probably because of the sage that was used.
Burger - 3 stars - This was recommended over the steak since they said they sell more of it.  I didn't really think it was as good as everyone makes it out to be.  My bun had the chargrill marks and tasted pretty burnt.  The meat was nice and juicy but the accompaniments weren't as flavorful as I thought they should be to add to the flavor.  My sister thought it was just okay also.  The fries that came with it were good
Strawberry Upside Down Dessert - (5 stars) - So yummy! It was vanilla ice cream with a gooey caramel crunch on top with diced up strawberries.  

The waitress was very nice (5 stars).  The lemonade is sparkling lemonade, not flat.  My sister sent hers back after she took a sip not knowing it would be sparkling.  The waitress kindly took it back.

I will definitely be back and will order the steak the next time.  The lady next to us made a comment about how the chicken at this place is the best chicken she has ever had.  My sister said she would try the chicken the next time.
author: Bling L.

description:
Came here a few months ago to see what all the fuss was over this burger. We arrived right on time for our reservation (a Saturday evening) and the hostess let us know that the couple at our table was just finishing dessert and it would be a few minutes. No problem. Fast forward 30 minutes and the couple at our table has ordered a second round of coffee and apparently has nowhere to go all night. Moments before I was about to go check with the hostess again about our table, she comes to find us with complimentary glasses of champagne in hand and apologizing profusely that our table is still occupied. This woman is a class act. Totally not her fault that this couple had a 45 minute dessert course and she couldn't exactly kick them out. She did exactly what every other host or hostess should do when a guest is left waiting well beyond the reservation time. She acknowledged us and was totally empathetic. The free champagne certainly didn't hurt either. How can you be annoyed when a lovely Australian (or New Zealand?) woman gives you free bubbly and is so nice? 5 stars for her alone. Then there is the food.

We had the brussel sprout chips which are totally genius. Salty and lemony and crunchy and divine.  We also had the shrimp cocktail which is not your average right-from-the-jar cocktail sauce. Spicy and boozy sauce served with perfectly roasted shrimp that have some kind of seasoning that makes you not even need the sauce.

For the main course, we shared the burger and the sole. The sole was great but the burger really stood out. I didn't really believe the hype but it was seriously the best burger I have ever had. So juicy and delicious and just right. It is perfect. Wouldn't change a thing.

As if we weren't full enough, I couldn't resist getting dessert in a jar. The lemon souffle cake was dynamite. Light and fluffy and lemony and a great way to end a fabulous meal. Highly recommend this place (and the rockstar hostess).
author: Carrie L.

description:
The food here is definitely 5 star quality, but the service could use a little bit of work.  Arrived a little bit earlier than our reservation time, but the hostess was super friendly and constantly checking in with us, which I thought was pretty cool for a place as casual as this one.  We only waited about 5-10 minutes, but she must have talked to us about 3 or 4 different times.  haha

But before I get to the good, let me explain the missing star.  Service at Marlowe is just so-so.  I am not sure if it is the system they use or because they use those long picnic tables and it is hard to really keep track of things.  To gauge service, I use my water test.  Simply put, if my water cup remains empty for long periods of time during the night, it means that the waiters were not attentive enough.  Pretty fair, IMO.  Needless to say, my cup was empty a few times during the night, and it didn't help that the cups were quite small.  Also, bread is available upon request, but when we finished ours, it was not refilled, and there was a nice 15 min window between our starters and entrees.  Lastly, we did not order any special drinks for the night and I got this resentful vibe from one of the waitresses like "oh great, these are some cheap a** people," and after saying we just wanted water, no waitress was to be seen or heard from for about 10-15 minutes.  So after being checked in on 4 times in less than 10 minutes while waiting outside, we got checked on about 1 time in 20 minutes while sitting down inside.  

Now ,the good.  The food!

Brussel Sprout Chips - read almost every review from this place and this is a must order...I've been eating brussel sprouts for years and this is by far the best way to eat them...these are on limited quantity (probably because it is a pain to separate the leaves) so make sure you order these asap

Crab and Rock Shrimp Louie - these are served more like lettuce wraps, and they are excellent...served along side sea salt and some tabasco...nice and refreshing

Pork Chop (friend's order) - cooked about medium, but very tasty...extremely tender

Chicken (friend's order) - I believe this chicken is slow roasted, as the waitress told us it takes about 30 min to prepare (which it did) and it was definitely worth the wait...I don't know if I've ever had roast chicken be so moist before...the sauce on top of it is really good too..savory with a little bit of sweetness

Stuffed Sole (my order!) - this pretty much tasted like the louie I mentioned above, stuffed in a filet of sole...very tasty..a little on the salty side, but not enough to prevent me from licking my plate clean

Upside Down Pear Crisp - not really a pear crisp, but more like a pear sundae...ice cream served in a jar with a bourbon caramel sauce, diced pears, and some "crisp" (granola?)...the combination was really godo but not quite what we really expected...when we read crisp, we all imagined something more traditional...but it was very good anyway

They have valet parking here, but if you have legs and don't mind using them, street parking is not so bad.  The venue itself is really, really small so I highly recommend reservations, on any night.  We went on a Thursday night and it was packed with people waiting.  Like I mentioned above, the service was the only sketchy part, but the food was so good that it overshadows that.  The portions aren't that big, so I recommend not arriving here starving to death.
author: JP T.

description: My favorite restaurant in SOMA. Every time, just as good as the last.
author: Jessica B.

description: Wow! Delicious dinner, great staff, the Butcher's Widow such a wonderful aperitif!! Lillet, fennel, orange. Crisp, bright, a perfect balance of fennel and citrus. Mmmm!! The cauliflower gratin, beef tartar with a quail egg, Brussels sprout chips, sole stuffed with crab in a butter, caper, fennel sauce. So good and tasty. Serving sizes are good. I have to go back for the burger.
author: Matthew B.

description: Yum! My first yelp review and I'm so glad its for Marlowe. Definitely get the Bone Marrow, the sauce that comes with it is amazing. I got the polenta and I didn't want this meal to end. The polenta was so creamy and the mushrooms and pecorino added such a great flavor. For dessert we got the peach crisp and it was a perfect ending.
author: Beatriz C.

description:
My first impression of Marlowe was the lovely hostess Sarah. My husband and I were an hour late to our reservation due to rain and traffic. Not to mention a little crabby. As soon as we walked in the door she greeted us with a beautiful smile and offered us a glass of wine. Instantly cheering. She was so accomodating and understood that traffic can't be helped.
The food was delicious, my husbands burger was wonderful. I had the chicken which was lovely also.
The cons were the small room and tight seating. I was wearing a skirt and was seated in the middle of a bench with strangers. It was a tad embarrassing every time I had to get up to clamber over the bench without showing the strangers under my skirt. Awkward.
Also, the bathroom was in a strange location. I had to wait for it and the only place to stand was practically in the kitchen where the waiters and waitresses are bustling through.
author: Heather A.

description: Bone marrow appetizer and the marlowe burger was YUMMY
author: Caroline B.

description: Love the whole mason jar theme and food was fantastic.
author: Windie W.

description: Enjoyed excellent lunch. Nice atmosphere, loved everything we ordered especially Brussels sprout chips and strawberry crisp. Would definitely recommend.
author: Lyn K.

description: Solid burger and greasy ass brussel sprout chips.  The lemon with the chips made them addicting.  The desserts here were better than the entrees.
author: Fatty A.

description:
4 stars only because I didn't think it was the MOST amazing food I've ever had, but it was pretty darn good.  We had the brussel sprout chips and deviled eggs for "snacks"...thanks for the tips yelpers, both were delicious!  My bf had the bone marrow, which he really enjoyed.  I didn't try it cause that creeps me out too much.  What I liked most about the bone marrow though was that the waitress came back with a second serving saying that there wasn't enough in the first dish...excellent customer service!  I had the baby gem salad, my only mistake of the night.  There was so so soooo much parsley in the salad I could hardly taste anything else.  If you're a big fan of parsley, and lots of it, then you'd enjoy this salad--I,  however, did not.  For our mains we had sole stuffed with crab, yummy, and the Marlowe burger, amazing!  We did not have dessert, but the few selections on the menu looked pretty bomb.

All in all we had a really nice dinner at Marlowe.  The prices were reasonable, the food was good and the atmosphere was pleasant.  Service was good also.
author: Veronica F.

description: Burger was divine.  Ate 6 deviled eggs too.  Deliciousness.  Great, great wine list - small, selective, good choices, fair/great prices.
author: Adrian M.

description: Really good food and well prepared.  Although we ordered the brussel sprout chips, it was lukewarm and too oily.  The Duo Sashimi was very good, bone marrow tasty but really small.  But the stand out dishes were the pork chop and roasted chicken. Oh, my!  So yummy!  I would come back just for these two dishes!!  Only drawback is how loud it can get and one has to shout to be heard.  But their food makes it worth putting up with the noise.
author: Shirley Y.

description: Food 9, atmosphere zero.  How can people enjoy dinner with the next table practically in your lap and the noise level in the danger zone.  My ears were ringing when we left.  Too bad, the food is good.  I know: get it to go!
author: Joel C.

description:
the warm deviled eggs are an-absolute-must-melt-in-your-mouth-crazy-pop-of-delicious-love.  and mikey, our awesome waiter, helped make our warm deviled egg dream come true after we were told they had sold out for the evening.   i begged.  i offered to run across the street to buy my own eggs.  he graciously triple checked but nothing.  then, to my surprise, three deviled eggs arrived at our table.  a food miracle, thanks to someone who had them held in the back but must've forgotten.  mikey swooped in and claimed them for us.  

marlowe never fails to disappoint...
author: Jen L.

description: I went back again ('cause I can't help myself) and had a fantastic lunch. Everything was top-notch and it was a great experience. I hope that this remains a consistent occurrence and I will make Marlowe one of my go-to spots forever!
author: Gabriel R.

description: I like the space, and from the reviews people love Marlowe.  My experience was different.  The food is average and below average. The sauce on the chicken had a  gummy mouth feel, really bringing the dining experience down, but what really brought it down was the unprofessional wait person.  For example, who wants to watch your server impatiently tapping her fingers when you are inquiring about a dish? Just a sour personality that soured my meal.
author: T H.

description:
Here's the thing. Their food was good. The burger was as good as it gets, and the fries are some of the best I've ever had.
But........
    When we came in we were greeted by some fo-hawk douche bag who in an extremely condescending tone asked, "can I help you?". After we answered his obvious question he then asked us if we had reservations. Mind you the restaurant was less than half full at 11:00 A.M., an hour before lunch. It just seemed like he didn't want us there. He then proceeded to hand us off to another waiter.
    That being said the other waiter was really helpful and the food was great. We might have gone back if the initial person who greeted us wasn't such as asshole.
author: Lance B.

description:
I got my own fabulous chance to check out Marlowe when I was in town visiting my best friend and I already want to go back, which sucks because I live in Cleveland and that's going to be a while :(

The food/drink was top notch, and yet very reasonably priced.  We're talking the kind of quality you expect for a nice date night out on reservations, and yet we managed to get in on a whim (our original plans for the evening fell through) and the appetizers and burgers were very doable price wise.  

The #1 thing that comes to mind, oddly enough, are the deviled eggs we had for an appetizer.  If you are at all a fan, their version with jalapenos and bacon and whatnot is fabulous and I can totally see stopping in for just those and a couple glasses of wine and some other appetizers if I was in the mood for a light bite.  We also had steak tartare which was likewise delicious and there were a few other apps on the menu that sounded tasty and seem well-reviewed enough to try next time.

We went the burger route like many and were not disappointed.  Theirs is not my absolute favorite but it's solidly in the running for a top spot, and their preparation (bacon, horseradish aioli, and a few other things) is unusual and tasty, so it's definitely worth trying just as something out of the ordinary.

I enjoyed a Butcher's Mistress cocktail and liked it so much I ended up drinking three.  "Nuff said.

Now for the drawbacks, with a couple caveats.  We showed up asking for a table for four sans reservations since that's just how the evening worked out, and between that and the size of the place (cute decor and all, but really tiny), it was kind of a wait and a pain.  The server did her best to make sure we had drinks but theirs is really a place you don't want to wait in at all because there's hardly any room to stand, let alone sit down while waiting.  So avoid all this and call in beforehand, OK?

On another note, I was peeved I had to figure out which of our four burgers was mine, as I was not initially given the rare burger I ordered (it went instead to my best friend, and I got someone else's medium done one).  We sorted it out amongst ourselves, but it did not help that when I asked the server about it, he snapped that he'd brought me the "right one" because he "made sure to keep them in order."  I wouldn't even mention this normally (hey, it happens)  but I almost felt like I shouldn't even have asked based on the snarky response, and that rubs me the wrong way on the "service" category.
author: Carolyn M.

description:
Simply a great restaurant to have in SOMA/Mission Bay, where the pickings are slim in terms of fancy but well-priced sit-down food.

The burger was as juicy and seasoned as I imagined it to be.  The poulet vert is also a must-try for super moist, marinated chicken.

The place seems to be packed all throughout dinner service on any given day, so make sure to get a reservation first.
author: S L.

description: Really accommodating staff and good food, albeit on the salty side, though me and salt are close friends. Try the burger and oysters.
author: Jihad L.

description: I went here on Friday night with a couple of friends for dinner and I was thoroughly impressed by everything. The service was friendly and attentive in the small but trendy space. The wine recommendations were spot on and the Brussels sprout chips have occupied my dreams ever since. I also had the Louie salad as an appetizer, which was delicious and followed that with the green garlic soup with mussels which was very unique (mussels are served like a tapenade) and very tasty. The table shared an order of the cauliflower gratin which brought another "o my god" moment of yumminess for us all. Overall it was a yummy experience for a not so bank breaking price tag.
author: Jess W.

description: If you can get a seat here, go for it!  I've had some amazing dinners here in the past and look forward to many more.  The brussles sprout chips were great.  I also had an amazing corn dish.  The drinks were great as well.  I cannot remember what I was served, but it was a type of cocktail using something they had a limited supply of.  That said, get there early!
author: Andy S.

description: so far so good - menu has a lot of tasty options. comfort food with an 'bistro' atmosphere
author: Shadi N.

description: Second a previous review: everything there is way too salty. Other than that, things are pretty delicious. The cozy atmosphere is a plus.
author: X L.

description: Good ideas and presentation. However, taste and price left me unimpressed.
author: Mz S.

description:
After having a drink at Bar Basic tonight , my BF, another friend and I went to Marlowe in San Francisco's SoMa neighborhood. Housed in the space formerly occupied by South, Marlowe offers an intimate dining experience in a rustic and cozy environment. The space is pretty small, but it didn't feel cramped. I really enjoyed the service in the restaurant. Our waitress was just cheeky enough and seemed to be having a good time. And, of course, an accent always wins over the American diner. Just think of Marlowe as your neighborhood bistro with a Australian flair.

We began with a drink at the small community table. I had a Czech dark lager that I enjoyed, but it didn't blow my mind. I'm amazed how my beer expectations have grown over the past couple of years. After drinks, Lee (the friend) abandoned us and we were seated at our table.

Based on Lee's earlier suggestion, we started with the brussel sprout chips: crispy, oily, salty. If you like brussel sprouts, you will undoubtedly like these light crunchy leaves of salty goodness. For dinner, we ordered the black cod with fennel and spinach, the burger with bacon and horseradish aioli and a side of cauliflower gratin. The cod was subtle but good. The broth was definitely dunk-worthy (which reminds me that the bread was nice and soft). I think the spinach could have been a little richer or spicier, but it was a solid dish. The burger was good (ordered medium rare) and the bacon added the touch of umami that I expect. I definitely missed the pickled onions that I can get at other places (shout out to NOPA), but the horseradish aioli was a good compromise. The cauliflower was a dish of smoky cheesy veggie goodness--I recommend it. I would like to try the brown butter brussel sprouts next time, too.

For dessert, we had the Tcho Dark Chocolate Bar Pudding with creme fraiche and maple pistachios. Much like a pot de creme, it was thick and rich and chocogasmic. All the other desserts looked quite good, too. I would have been happy with any of them, but chocolate is always hard to pass up.

For dinner, I chose the Husch Pinot Noir. After it breathed a bit, it really opened up and tasted quite good. At $13 a glass, it lived up to my expectations.

All in all, Marlowe is a great addition to the neighborhood, and it really appeals to me more than South ever did. I'm looking forward to trying out several of their other dishes and stopping by for a drink (or two) after work. Here's to the beginning of a beautiful friendship.
author: Todd X.

description:
warm, cuddly, and fuzzy all around.

warm - service with a smile, genuine care for making sure we get a table with no more than a 15 minute wait without rezzies both times (why not throw in a glass of wine), and cozy interior of dark wood, long benches, and farm-like accents.

cuddly - small menu filled with an array of spot-on goodies. lamb, BURGER, brussel sprout chips, halibut, burrata, carafes of wine, delicious dessert wines, ooh-la-la.  we keep getting the BURGER, which is just awesomely satisfying. i hearby swear i will try another entree next time. i could probably afford to skip dessert and get my sweet on from the dessert wines.

fuzzy - as in, fuzzy... tongue-tickling! flavors are well balanced and just plain interesting. a spectrum of comforting things to choose from on the menu, stretching from deep fried goodness to light, refreshing bites. 

feed me more!! feed me more!

now if i could only hug the hostess without freaking her out, this review would be complete! :)
author: Diana L.

description: I have been attempting to get a table at this hip joint for quite some time.  Finally the time came and it was quite an enjoyable experience. Friendly staff, good prices, and great food.  The spinach chips and pistachio snacks to start were a great way to get our taste buds rolling.  I had the pork entree and my BF had the Marlowe Burger (which we had heard was ranked #1 burger in SF).  Pork entree: good but woud try something different next time we go.  The burger: quite tasty but I have to admit not the best burger we have had in SF.  All in all, very satisfied with dinner and will go back.
author: nicole s.

description:
HAD to see what Michael Bauer was talking about, especially since I'm not really a burger fan. But the Marlowe burger does live up to Bauer's proverbial flame. The bun was just the right thickness and crispness, the filling was perfectly moist.

I knocked off one star because of the brussels sprouts. If you like brussels sprouts with your oil, you'll enjoy their offering, which engulfs any goodness in the sprouts with cups of oil. I could have fueled my car with the amount of oil in this dish.
author: Aiko S.

description:
I checked out Marlower last night with a friend and I was pleasantly surprised to find that it is a very charming space with good service, great food and is very affordable.  The parking is easy (as long as the Giants aren't in town) which also makes it appealing.  

We decided to split a bunch of things in order to get a good sampling of the menu.  I would definitely recommend the deviled eggs (spicy and delicious), the beet and burrata salad and the steak tartare.  This was  my first experience eating steak tartare and I am in love!  So, to be fair, I have no basis for comparison but it melted in my mouth and was super flavorful.  We also split the brussel sprouts and the pork chops which were equally delicious.  

We ended an already great  night with a very memorable dessert.  They serve all their desserts in a glass jar and no words can truly describe how amazing it was.  We orderd the warm peach crisp which came with caramel sauce and boubon ice cream.  Don't pass this up!

All in all, a great new spot for dinner with friends or a date night.
author: Jamie S.

description: good brussel sprout chips and i don't like veggies. probably closest i'll come.
author: Princess Pompom Patootie W.

description: Ok...a little slice of heaven.  I've only been here for lunch (twice) and can't wait to try Marlowe for dinner. I've ordered the same thing both times - yes, it was that good.  Brussel Sprout chips as an app for the table...if you have a group larger than 3, I recommend ordering at least TWO of these. I promise you...even if you aren't a fan of brussel sprouts, you will like these.  And then, for the main course...the fried chicken sandwich.  The best fried chicken sandwich I've ever had.  Today's was even more delish than I remember the first one.  Fun wine/champs/beer list.  Service is good and friendly.  Atmosphere fun and casual.  Highly recommend as a place to meet friends or clients.  Can't wait to go back....
author: marci h.

description:
ate here on a monday night with a friend and we ended up eating for about two hours! we didn't feel rushed and thoroughly enjoyed our food and the service! the set up of the restaurant is different but nice. don't know but it feels crowded and spacious at the same time. a good balance. anyways on to the food: 

we ordered: 
- bone marrow - saw this as highly reviewed on yelp and wanted to come immediately. i love bone marrow. not the best that ive had but delicious 
- stuffed blue sole with dungeness crab - sealovers dream. the crab was delicious and the fish was good. however the bottom was slightly uncooked and you couldnt even cut through it :(
- marlowe burger - the fries are to die for. the burger itself ok
- upside down pear crisp - the ice cream on the bottom and the pears and caramel on top in a jar. interesting the bourbon ice cream was veryy creamy not your typical ice cream but its homemade
author: Jen S.

description: Over-hyped and trendy.  The brussels chips are good, but WAY to oily.  The polenta was very creamy. but had so much truffel oil in it it was disgustingly unctuous.  The burger was not worth the money.  Yes, good, but not worth the build up.  The service was unremarkable AND they tried to bring a wine that was the same name different year--possibly an honest mistake, possibly not.  Won't be back.
author: Jorah N.

description: Love this place.. For those fancy burger fan.. I suggest you try it on your first visit.. Been there a few times and it hasnt disappointed me yet.. :) love the commune table :)
author: Mar S.

description:
Good Food and Ambiance, TERRIBLE Customer Service

I went to Marlowe about two weeks ago. It was cozy and the server was good.  The food turned out to be delicious. However, I saw the next day that my credit card had been charged twice- once for correct amount, and an additional $140 charge! I called and talked to a manager who said she would look into it. Two days later, the charge was still there and I had received no call from Marlowe. I called again. And then again every day after that for three days, as well as numerous calls to my bank. 

Marlowe claimed they could not find the wrong charge in their records, and didn't offer to talk to my bank or do anything to help. Finally, a full six days after the charge occured, I got my bank to pull it off my statement. I called Marlowe to tell them that my BANK had taken care of it, and they offered to send me a gift certificate in the hope that I would actually return for a meal. I got it in the mail several days later and it was for... $25!! 

Unbelievable. They incorrectly charge me $140 which was gone from my account for almost a week, barely help to correct it, then send a gift certificate for an amount that would barely cover two drinks! I certainly won't be going back, despite those delicious brussel sprouts...
author: Marguerite H.

description: Best burger in the City!  Seriously. We also enjoyed the tuna crudo and prawn appetizer. Cool vibe inside and a warm, intimate setting. Will be back.
author: Greg A.

description: Great atmosphere, fantastic service (surprised by some negative reviews on their service--they were really attentive, even when it was super busy), and delicious food.  The brussel sprout chips are really great, but my husband who doesn't like brussel sprouts still didn't like the chips.  The deviled eggs are mouth-watering.  The polenta is amazing and rich.  The hamburger was excellent.  Great little spot tucked away in SOMA!  Only semi-negative comment is that it is a tad noisy, BUT I like a lively place, so it's not really a con to me.
author: Sara B.

description:
Came for: impromptu weeknight din
Will come back for: yummy mains!

Finally made it out to check this place out; it'd been on the radar, but had not yet been planned out.
No reservations, but a gf and I popped in ~8pm to try our luck.  After grabbing a glass of vino (helpful&friendly hostess) and waiting ~15min, she called us to our seats at the bar.

Good food, but enjoyed some more than others:
- crispy brussels sprouts chips -- just had to try after reading all the raves, but a bit disappointed by these airy fried and crispy brussel chips.  Not bad, but now that I know, I'd rather spend money on something else.
- steak tartare -- comes in a mound with quail egg on top served over a bed of greens with crostinis.  Good flavor; the egg is a nice touch.
- stuffed blue sole -- white fish stuffed with blue crab.  Very good!  I had a bite and regretted not going with that dish.
- polenta -- polenta topped with a poached egg and mushroom and truffled pecorino accompanied by greens.  Although generally not a huge fan of polenta, but wanted to try it that night.  The polenta wasn't too buttery (good) yet had bits of gritty texture (also good).  It was too rich as an entire dish for me, but one of the better polenta I've had.  Amazing flavor!
- upside down pear crisp -- with bourbon ice cream and brown butter caramel sauce.  Meh.  It was not what we expected and I wasn't a fan so stopped after a bite.  It's mostly ice cream with diced pieces of pears.  NOTE: apparently, all their desserts are served in a jar.

Smaller space (small tables as well as communal tables) with gastropub feel that makes it good for after-work casual eats.  Not so much if you're looking for something phancy or intimate of a setting.

2 appetizers, 2 glasses of vino, 2 entrees, and one dessert = ~$100 total.

Take-Away: Good for casual after-work eats to enjoy a crowd and good main eats.  Note their dessert as mentioned above.
author: Carol K.

description:
in my never ending quest for the best burger in the world...well, in my little ol' world, anyway....i ended up at Marlowe based on recommendations.  it was a damn good burger....nice and juicy.  not too huge, so i felt i could have dessert.  the fries were good too.  i'm not sure if it's the best in the world, but i will definitely go back there for another one!

the brussel sprout chips tasted good...kinda light and airy...almost a bit too light and airy....definitely not going to fill you up...and potentially awkward in terms of eating it. 

one of my dining companions got the pork chop which was fine, but the best part of the meal was the parmesan dumpling!  they need to make that a side dish.  you hear that, Marlowe?
author: Miss P.

description: Pretty good bang for your buck. I felt my arteries choking as I was devouring the bone marrow. Not many restaurants will serve you a fat log of bone marrow just like that but any restaurant that does has my vote. There now  go ahead and kill yourself slowly but happily. Just wish it wasn't so darn hard to eat there. If you ever oh say feel like just strolling in.... hmm I'm in the mood for Marlowe... Nah uh ain't gonna happen. Book a week ahead of time.
author: M C.

description: $13 caraffes, but not amazing selection. Steak tar tar is really good. Very loud but wonderful design.
author: Nisha M.

description:
This place is ok. I was ready to be wowed, but was completely underwhelmed.
     The brussel sprout chips were not what I expected. They were flavorful and well seasoned. However, they reminded me of the scrapings on a pan after making roasted brussel sprouts.
     The spicy prawns were also ok. They were well seasoned, and cooked well, but there was nothing spectacular about them.
     The famous bone marrow ended up being....eh. There was a lot of beef flavor, but the richness was just too much for me. I think I prefer foie over marrow for a fatty spread and I don't particularly like foie.
     On the other hand, the chicken was really good. The meat was extremely moist, and it was perfectly seasoned. The chicken flavor was brought out by the perfect amount of salt.
     The marlowe burger ended up being ok as well. The meat was fresh, the bun was perfectly toasted, the cheese was melted, and the bacon was perfectly crisp. However, the burger flavor itself was masked by a little too much char. It was a good burger, but for 12 dollars, there is a list of much better burgers out there.
     The carrot cake trifle was terrible. Any of the sweetness it had was completely drowned away by an orange peel taste. The waitress said that it was persimmon, but I tasted orange peel. She was nice enough to take it off the bill.
     Overall, this place is good. But for the prices, I will be trying other places before I return.
author: Siao W.

description:
I came here first with Zehra A. for her birthday.  I was so much of a fan of this place that I returned with my hubby.   I like that this restaurant is not pretentious like other American/Traditional restaurants.  The service is great.  The dungeness crab and shrimp louie is a great appetizer to start off with.  Their burger is very good.  I did not enjoy their chocolate dessert.  I am quite the chocoholic and I think they missed the mark with trying to serve dark chocolate salty.  I think if they focused on making their chocolate option more like a divine vulcan chocolate cake with ice cream then that would be a hit.  Even the waitress admitted that most people don't like the chocolate dessert.  I think this is a hint for them to reconsider their recipe.  I really liked the upside down pecan crisp with bourbon ice cream.  So for now, that's my dessert of choice until they offer a delicious chocolate option.  

I did not like that unlike most restaurants they allow people with reservations to book the entire restaurant.  As a walk-in, we had the option to wait an hour and half since there were no reservations made at 10 pm.  I think they should advertise this on their website as there were walk-ins who walked away unhappily from the restaurant.  They also only have a single bathroom where my husband had to wait 20 minutes to use.  I awkwardly ordered for the both of us since he was still in line when the waitress was ready for our order.    

Apart from this, I like Marlowe because it is a solid restaurant that I look forward to revisiting in the future, as long as I remember to make a reservation ahead of time and avoid using the bathroom.
author: C L.

description: Great for lunch or dinner! Oysters are a MUST and "poulet vert" is also delish. Can't go wrong with much though...
author: Katherine L.

description:
Not what it was cracked up to be.

This was my 2nd visit to Marlowe. First visit was better.

We sat at the bar and had drinks while deciding what to order. The menu is short but very appealing, with plenty of emphasis on saturated fat, pork, and fried things. (Not that there's anything wrong with that.)

Starters:
Roasted mushroom: delicious, period. Mushrooms with truffle flavoring, toasted bread, other tasty things I forget now.
Brussels sprout chips: tasty as hell, but much greasier than they were on my first visit.
Butternut Squash soup: Very nice, but there's a lot of good soup in this town.

Mains: we ordered burgers with fries. That's what they're famous for, right?

First problem - they basically forgot our order. We watched the bartender actually key in the order in the computer, so it wasn't his fault. But we were waiting and waiting and waiting...  We had to ask WTF and then he looked into it, and then they brought the wrong orders, and then finally they showed up. Like 45 minutes of waiting, seriously. And the kitchen was 5 feet away.

Problem 1: not hot. They were obviously sitting around with nobody picking them up. If I weren't in such a hurry (due to the lateness) I'd have definitely sent my meal back and gotten a fresh one.

Problem 2: Not cooked right. I asked for Medium and I got medium rare/rare. Maybe they gave me someone else's plate since mine had gotten lost?

Problem 3: Fries were way too salty. Yes, I'm being nitpicky, but these guys are reputed to have the city's best fries, so I'm allowed to be critical here. 

So that's about the size of it. It's not a cheap place, and while the food is good, it's not worth that kind of inconsistent service. If they could just notch up their quality control a little, this place could be awesome.
author: Al M.

description: I believe in reinvention, especially when your neighborhood restaurant decides to redo its entire concept. From the menu to the interior--this is Marlowe's (re)birth. Speaking from just visiting and sampling the wine (since I have yet to taste the food), the place is completely redecorated--thick, rough wood tables, black leather,  and chalkboards with butcher-style drawings of animals. This restaurant feels more casual, sexy, and a little more welcoming than the red and white upscale South. This is a place I'd definitely drop in for a glass of wine and a meal when I decide to stay in the area.
author: Alex H.

description: We ordered the brussel chips, burger, chicken & park chop and all were great. Dessert in a jar was good too. Can be a little loud but the energy was good for a Friday night. People were still coming in at 10PM.  The best part was the $211 bill (all in) for six people with one bottle of good wine.
author: Mario S.

description: food five service 1.   hovering over you as usual to rush you outta there.  just sloppy.  i did like the other marlowe better.   wish the servers were less concerned with getting you outta there.  so uncomfortable
author: Amanda J.

description: I have been wanting to try out Marlowe for awhile now. It is a great restaurant with a great lil ambiance. Very New Yorkish and intimate. Ordered the burger which was good. The dessert was the best part, the pear dessert. Took a bit of a wait..but so does all restaurants. I hope there are more restaurants like Marlows around! Will def be back...
author: Kristi G.

description: A friend recommended Marlowe to my husband and I for dinner and it was indeed a great choice.  The restaurant is pretty small, making it a little more intimate.  The atmosphere was nice...good place for a first date.  The food was delicious and the portions were rather large, something I'm not use to with fine dining.  We started off with the spicy shrimp appetizers which were delish!  I ordered the pork chops for dinner and they were AMAZING with this chutney style sauce.  It was accompanied by three fried potato dumplings and lots of what tasted like arugula.  My husband had the NY steak and it was cooked to perfection.  We coffee and tea after with our crustless pie.  I'm not a big sweets fan and could've done without it but overall, the pie was good.  For all this we barely spent $100 which included the tip.  I would definitely go back again.....
author: KC C.

description: Fantastic.  Have the Steak Tartar and you will know why the Hamburgers are so damn yummy!  The whole menu is just great!  Love the Brussel sprout chips.
author: Stephen P.

description: Went there for lunch.  Small spot but awesome vibe.  Burger was awesome.  Fries came with a fantastic horseradish aioli. Can't wait to go back!
author: Matt S.

description:
Swoon times two!! 

I went here recently for a second date. He wanted to know if there was anywhere in my neighborhood I wanted to try. Well, I'd heard many good things about this place and it's amazing burger so I suggested Marlowe. Two ingredients for a potentially lovely night: cute boy and amazing burger. 

Much has been said about the link between food and sensuality, and I must admit that I have never fully understood the relationship. Who knew that baked oysters, a phenomenal burger, chocolate bar pudding and an apple crisp would be a minor epiphany for me? 

I was the second to arrive and my date was standing nervously in front waiting for me. Naturally, I gave him a hug. He looked so cute and he was wearing a Barbour jacket! I have a soft spot for men in finely tailored clothes. We definitely had the second date jitters, you know, where you like each other but don't know each other well so the conversation is still filled with awkward smiles and pauses. 

We went inside- I never went to South, but I really like the space. It is small, intimate, and dimly lit. Very romantic. Our table wasn't ready when we arrived, but the hostess politely showed us to the bar where we perused the wine list. Marlowe has a great selection of beer and wine. Alcohol is a great catalyst for familiarity so I was thankful we headed to the bar first. After a brief wait, our waitress arrived and showed us to our table. She took our wine glasses (perhaps she didn't want me to eat it in my heels and ruin my chances) to the table which I thought was a nice touch. 

We ordered the baked oysters and burgers for dinner. The baked oysters, covered in bacon pieces, are everything that I look for in an oyster: slippery, crunchy, salty, sweet and smoky. Heaven. Then we had the burger, which I will say, is a bit over the top covered in caramelized onions, cheddar and bacon. However, as my date and I agreed, if you are going to have a burger you might as well go big or go home. The patty, which we both ordered medium rare is full and flavorful with irony goodness and the meat melts in your mouth. Plus, who can complain when such tastiness is accompanied with cheddar and bacon? Score, right? Also, the fries were wonderful, with their bright crispy exterior and light fluffy centers. 

Now, I am a dessert fiend. I will have a conniption fit if I don't get it. My date ordered the chocolate bar pudding and I ordered the apple crisp. The desserts arrived in adorable mason jars. I couldn't help myself and I reached over to have some of his pudding. Amazing: cool, creamy, not two sweet and slightly bitter. My dessert was heavenly, but I've never met an apple dessert that I didn't like. Diced apples, covered in a brown sugar sauce, were hot, crisp and tart and contrasted nicely with the cool richness of the ice cream and the buttery crunchiness of the topping. Needless to say, we finished our desserts in no time. 

Anyhow, I really enjoyed my experience at Marlowe. I thought our waitress was attentive and our hostess was very friendly. The food speaks for itself and the space was very nice. Also, I like the quirkiness of the restaurant: they played Johnny Cash during dinner, which my date greatly appreciated. All told, we didn't try much of the menu, but what we had was great and what is better than eating excellent food with an adorable boy you like smiling back at you? Not much, in my opinion. 

After dinner, my date walked me to my car, and underneath the night sky and city lights...he kissed me! Swoon once for Marlowe and swoon twice for my date! ;)
author: grace c.

description: Pretty good! had the brussel sprout chips which I shoulda doggie bagged home for a late night snack! steak--good too much sauce, burger and fries--good on a buttery brioche--bone marrow---can't go wrong!!!
author: Monster E.

description: This is a solid 3.5 stars.  Went with a group of 10+ people for lunch during the work week. The service was extremely slow; approximately 1.15 hours long.  We ordered the brussel sprouts chips, nuts, shrimps and oysters. Most people liked the chips-- i think it was better than average and fun to eat. I liked the shrimp with spicy sauce. Nothing special about the nuts or the oysters. Sure if you like cooked oysters with lots of mayo or ailoli, then go for it.  I ordered the shrimp roll. It was good but not out of this world good. Not a huge sandwhich but good enough for lunch. Most people ordered the fried chicken salad and they all liked it. Some ordered the deviled egg open face sandwich and they all thought it was just okay.
author: Bren L.

description: I love the food at Marlowe, the brussel sprout chips are amazing and I think they have the best burger in the city.  Although the last time we went we both ordered burgers and split a salad and a bottle of wine and the bill was well over $100.   I don't mind paying $13 for a burger but you better load the plate with fries.  I was  bummed about the meager portion of french fries because I love the fries here especially the horseradish dipping sauce.  I will go back, but I'll just request a heaping portion of fries. Update: the owner contacted me and offered me a burger on her with lots of fries!  Being a business owner myself, I love that kind of customer service!
author: Greg G.

description: Had a fabulous meal sitting at the bar.  Great wine.  Loved the artichoke soup and the cod stuffed with Dcrab.  Wasn't a fan of the prawn apptz.
author: Vincent C.

description:
It's official. I really like this place. I've been twice and my only complaint is that it's a touch loud, but nothing a glass of wine can't help you adjust to. 

-Great wine selection
-Consistently excellent food. 
-Terrific service

*Get for the brussel sprout chips.
*I don't normally go for vegetarian dishes, but the polenta was maybe the best meal I've had in many many moons. I almost cried.
author: Derrick C.

description: Some of the dishes are on the salty side, but do not cross the line. If you are sensitive to salt, try to stay away from the fried brussel sprouts (excellent) or the poulet vert (also very tasty). Steak frites were not too spicy. Fries were perfectly cooked. The best thing on the menu, though, is the peach crisp. I will never ever go there and share an order of the peach crisp no matter how full I am. I've made that mistake twice. Never again.
author: Jasper L.

description: Came here with my family the other month and was not disappointed. The meal was delicious and the service was great. The only problem with this place is the seating. Other then that, I had a wonderful night Marlowe.
author: Hunter S.

description:
We turned up without a lunch reservation on this rainy day and were immediately seated at the lower section of the bar, which was private enough for a decent conversation. A limited menu of soups, salads, sandwiches and two hot dishes.

 I had a prosecco, nothing to write home about, she had a lager, good. We both got the baguette sandwich with prosciutto, cheese, pickled apple. Great baguette and delish sandwich.  I got arugula on side, she got fries that she said were tasty. The brussels sprouts chips were incredible. The cappucini we got were excellent and the upside down pear crips we shared was to die for. 

Service was very good.  It got a bit hot and stuffy, as it was packed, so I'd layer the clothes next time. Place is small, charming, very urban. Love it. And there will be a next time.
author: Carol C.

description:
As a frequent customer of Marlowe's for over a year, I am sorry to have to write a bad review.  I made a large lunch reservation with them, and had to cancel the Monday prior to the reservation.  When I called to cancel, I was told that my reservation had been made for Tuesday, not Wednesday, and so I was not canceling within the 48 hour time frame necessary for cancellations, and would be charged $15 per person, a total of $400.  After argueing for some time with the hostess about the reservation date, I was told I would be called the following day by the event coordinator to work something out, and if they decided to charge me, would be sent a $400 gift card to the restaurant.  As I have been a loyal customer of the establishment, and was calling in a good-faith effort to respect their 48 hour notice policy, I assumed we could reach some sort of agreement to waive the $400 fee, which seems not only tremedously unfair, but also incredibly excessive, as we hadn't booked the restaurant out, and were ordering from the regular menu (nothing had been pre-determined).  I never received a call back from the event coordinator, and assumed that she was waiving the fee.  Fast forward three weeks, and there is a $400 charge on my credit card from them, and they have never attempted to contact me to resolve this issue.  I also have not received the $400 gift card.  

Prior to this issue, I had never received bad service from the restaurant and had taken many clients there for lunch, as well as recommended it to friends.  Needless to say, I will not be going back.   It's a shame that they didn't feel it worthwhile to try to work something out with me.
author: Very D.

description:
brussel sprout chips - yay
poulet vert - yay!
marlowe burger - it's fine but not mindblowing
oysters (baked?) - yay
sangria - yay
author: S O.

description:
WONDERFUL FOOD. but a little too cramped.

i highly recommend; the corn soup if you like rich sweet creamy tastes, the bone marrow, and the burger. 

I was a little upset though because we felt super cramped (like the girl in the group next to us was breathing on me) and we tried to move our table away while the waittress insisted we move back to seat others.
author: beth b.

description: Everything we had was so good. From the brussel sprout chips to the polenta to the burger and the wine. Everything was delicious.
author: Johanna W.

description: So I struggled with the review.  Long story short, my friend and I visited Marlowe on 1/31/14.  I had been waiting to come to Marlowe and a dear friend came up from LA so I thought "let's go to this awesome spot in SoMa".  Long story short, while the meal was DELICIOUS, we both got violently ill from food poisoning.  That is not the reason why I'm only giving 2 stars because I know things like this can happen to any restaurants.  I'm giving a low rating because my friend wrote rather a polite and articulate email to them about our experience.  Not complaining, not demanding for anything.  Just a simple note informing them of what happened, just in case others may have gotten sick, too.  All we got was "We'll take it into consideration".  What?!  Take into consideration to do what?  I was dumb founded.  No apology (not for the poisoned food but for the bad experience). Nothing.  I've been around the food circuit for a long time in SF, Chicago, NYC and London.  This is unacceptable.  Really? We'll take it into consideration??  Get out of here.
author: J Y.

description:
sigh.

i was excited for my dinner at marlowe, having made my reservation weeks prior. got to the restaurant a little early and liked the small and intimate room (until later, when i had to eat in it). our hostess was great and my wife and i enjoyed a drink before our table was ready. i had a beer and her prosecco cocktail was quite nice. we were then seated.

this is where the small room started to feel cramped rather than intimate. tables were too closely set, it's that simple for me. our waitress often had to bump into my shoulder or arm to serve the table next to us and the path behind me to allow access to the table to our right, which was a corner table, forced me to move my chair several times during the night. add in the cacophony of a loud room and it made for an evening lacking in the comfort that i'd expect, even in the city.

so much of the room would have become unimportant had the food been delightful. started with the brussels sprouts chips and the toasted pistachios. they, though yummy, were far too candied and sweet while the brussels sprouts were almost wonderful but were overdressed. had the creamed seasonal greens and fries as sides. 

i ordered the steak and my wife had the pork chop. both were fine and i think that was the problem. they were sufficient but not more. i came away from this place feeling much the same way that i did at Luce and 25 Lusk - there are far too many really very good restaurants in the city (and hell, in the east bay now as well) to go out for a dinner that's simply sufficient. i'm mindful that this was one dinner on a friday night (perhaps i should try again mid-week) and that i might have a better experience on another visit but with so many other places to try and better ones to revisit i'm not sure that i'd bother.
author: james d.

description: I had no idea Marlowe was just 3 blocks from my office! What a fantastic neighborhood gem, a pleasant surprise, and fantastically well-thought-out food. PERFECT. I had the jerusalem artichoke soup and the little gem salad. An excellent lunch combination!
author: Marisa L.

description:
3rd time back to Marlowe last night with friends. Still really good! But - - - 
I love salt, love it! I even salt up my salads, but not the one I had last night. It was TOO salty! The chef got a little happy with the salt, in everything. 

I had the little gem salad, and it was so salty I could only eat half. The sole, which was really a beautiful, and tasty dish, was really tasty. But the salted slaw was SO over powered with the salt I feel hungover today from Salt! 

The brussel sprout chips still remain among my favorite bites. And the fries, jeez - they're awesome! 

The burger is still the winner at Marlowe. It's a great place for meat, brussels, fries - and salt. 

I'm on the fence about a return - sorry folks.
author: Lori L.

description: If you love burgers, you WILL love Marlowe.  O.M.G.  The burger is as good as it ever gets.  The fries, done in rice oil, are crisp and stay crisp throughout the meal, and the garlic aioli is OTH (off the hook).   I would gladly slather the aioli on anything (this has to be PG-rated review, so I'll stop there) and be in heaven.   But the burger is a perfectly cooked, juicy, flavorful, yummy sandwich of heaven.  I'll write more when I actually order something other than the Marlowe Burger, but I don't know when I will, because whenever I go there, I HAVE TO HAVE IT.
author: Michael Y.

description:
I really want to give 5 stars! In fact, I'll give 4 despite a list of mistakes... here's how it went down:

We walked in at a little after 9pm on a Monday night and the place was full. We did get a spot at the bar right away though, and after a little wait we got some menus and placed our order.

1. The waitress gave us water - only one had ice in it, the other was warmish. 
2. No bread... we're waiting... waiting....
3. Waitress is apologetic - we're out of soup! I changed my order to pork chop.
4. 9.51 - about 50 mins after we walk in - my pork comes. I am polite and wait for my SO's food... And wait... waitress is really very sweet; gives my SO a free beer! We eat the pork chop... (It was AMAZING. And the parmesan dumplings? ZOMG. Delicious. Just bring me a plate of those next time.)
5. At last the burger arrives, we share that too. Despite requesting aioli on the side, it's ALSO covered in aioli on both buns - my SO hates mayo like products... he's hungry, so he scrapes it off.
6. We finish up, and decline dessert. The bill comes... it has a dessert for $6 listed... waitress apologizes again...

So we have 6 errors (!),  a very sweet waitress, a free beer and some simply out of this world pork.

All in all, I'll go back, but next time: a) ask for bread b) be crystal clear with the order and c) check the bill. Because yes, *the pork was that good!*
author: Annie S.

description: Really good ambiance even better burgers. Only problem is space is small  so you may have to wait.. Not really a fan of the Brussel sprouts.
author: ally K.

description: Best...chicken...sandwich...ever!  Seriously, I dream about it sometimes.  Too bad they only do it at lunch, although the dinner menu always has some gems to counterbalance its absence.  This is a go-to kind of place when you want well-crafted, casual food.   Reservations are a must for the most part even with the casual vibe.  Cautionary note: I had a recent dinner experience when the salt bomb had been dropped on all the dishes and let me tell you, while I am on the extreme edge of loving my salt, it was way too much, even for me.  Hope this isn't a trend!
author: Andrea E.

description: Go before it gets too well-known - we had a wonderfully relaxed lunch, but it wasn't filled to the gills...  service was great, atmosphere was perfectly San Francisco (casual but cool).  Standouts were the brussels sprout chips (crunchy, lemony, salty, yum) and the horseradish aioli that comes with the fries (zingy).  The lunch menu is fairly small, and most of us ordered the deviled egg sandwich - delicious, albiet a little unwieldy, even with a steak knife!  i.e. provolone & bacon are prone to sliding off the egg.  Faint of heart eaters beware, the spicy shrimp come with their heads on.  (But they're tasty.)
author: Julie L.

description:
this review is for the owner. i haven't met her, but she boasts that she stalks her online reviewers and tries to find out if their reviews are "worthy" of her attention. i don't care if she stalks me. in fact if she wants i would be happy to tell her in person (wearing my mask of anonymity, of course) why her restaurant is getting a measly two stars. 

come and get me. 

maybe she will blow me off and call me names instead. now that i think about it, perhaps she should rename her restaurants "Yes a###%^^e", as this blog explains. 

http://insidescoopsf.sfgate.com/blog/2011/08/19/thanks-for-asking/

reason 1) there are more flavors in the world than salt. the mussels? salty. polenta? salty. cod? salty. sprouts? salty. baked oysters? salty on a bed of salt...would it kill the cook to try a different spice here and there? at least salt house gives a warning. we were so salted that one of my guests drank three water glasses but still started to get a dehydration headache afterwards. this is what i call boring crutch cooking. make it salty and fatty and the masses are supposed to rave about it. i don't like bacon for a very simple reason. over-used crutch food by lazy chefs. if you're going to try this place, come on a hot day, drink a lot of water and eat only the appetizers with a few beers and skip the main. or go to a dive bar and get chips/fries for the same experience. meh.

reason 2) wait staff are sub par. dishes were left empty for what seemed like forever. we emptied and refilled wine glasses twice in the time it took them to clear two plates. at one point i had to reach out and say "hey!" to a waitress. she seemed so coy as i was trying to make eye contact she gave me sideways glances but moved along. i had to say "i am only paying attention to you because you are supposed to be a server. otherwise i would ignore you. if you want to strut and play the look away game, find a runway". another time they took our plates away when we needed plates. i had to get up and get our plates back myself so we could eat. meh

reason 3) have you ever seen a tourist snapping photos at a monument they do not understand or care to understand? they snap, snap and say "oh, now i have taken a picture of it. it's so amazing" and then they walk away. groups of young asian couples were coming into this restaurant doing exactly this. they take pictures of every dish and say "omg, i've always heard about this place and wanted to come here." then they flash their camera in your eyes as they try find the right angle on their shrimp. normally i would say whatever but i couldn't help but notice the restaurant was full of people coming to witness something they did not understand. i like to sit in restaurants that have people coming BACK and who are familiar. no one was a regular and the wait staff were so distant and detached i wouldn't expect them to care. lines and crowds snapping photos of each other and trying to capture the moment because they can't figure out how actually to experience it? meh

the meal ended with a thud, as no one even wanted to see the dessert options. when the wait staff asked if we were ready for the check i couldn't help but say

Yes a###%^^e

the funny thing about SF cuisine is that the cheap food can be excellent but the expensive places are rarely very good or worth half the cost. 

bottom line, if you eat mostly at in-and-out and want to feel special, this place is for you and your salty fatty trained taste buds. if you know anything about flavor, texture, temperature or service, you'll be disappointed and wonder why you wasted your money.
author: Mulberry S.

description: The steak was excellent, and the service was good. A little loud, but it's a small room and hard to avoid. Extra credit for having Anchor Porter on the beer list, but -1 star for not having a full bar (yet, I hope).
author: Ziad E.

description: Dinner last night at Marlowe was okay. The space is cute and the service was good but the food was just okay. If I was in the neighborhood, I'd pop in again but I won't be seeking out another reservation any time soon.
author: Jessica P.

description: Everyone already knows about the burger here, but I'll confirm, it's awesome.  Very nice little gems salad and padron pepper app, dessert was also good.  Super friendly staff at the bar where we sat.  Relatively quiet inside despite a nearly full house.  This is a really solid place.  You can always go find more incredible food, but for the price, I think you can do very well at Marlowe, and it's a very pleasant place to eat and chat.
author: Erin b.
