description: It was incredible how quickly the hype surrounding the burger at Marlowe reached a fever pitch. But after coming here and trying it out for myself, the praise is completely deserved. The meat was perfectly cooked and the horseradish aioli (I initially thought it was wasabi) gave the entire burger a very special kick that helps to set it apart in a city filled with delicious burgers. I didn't think the brussel sprout chips were anything special, although they did taste okay. Biggest qualm with Marlowe is the tiny space (the size of an office lobby) that they crammed with as many seats as they could fit.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
Marlowe has done everything to perfection! The decor is fabulous and the menu is off the charts good!! It's a quaint little spot that would be great for a date or a casual dinner with friends. They really made great use of the space, which is fairly small. The two standout dishes that I tried were the brussels sprouts chips with meyer lemon and sea salt and the polenta entree. Have you ever heard of a chef peeling brussels sprouts before?!?!? That's love! Seriously! The polenta is so full of flavor and one of the best vegetarian entrees I've ever tried. I'm usually not satisfied with a meal unless there is a protein involved, but this entree is really incredible! I've heard their burger is the best in SF and it certainly looks like it. In fact, my vegetarian friend caught a glimpse of one at another table and said "I might have to go to the other side so I can try that". Now that's a burger with power :)

With a friendly staff and reasonable prices, I foresee Marlowe being a long living restaurant in SF. I can't wait to go back!
author: Kandace K.

description: Like most reviews given, the burger is awesome!  Describing it does no justice - just try it and at medium rare.  Unlike most, I prefer the seasonal greens over the fries.  The greens were very fresh and crisp with a nice vinegarette dressing.  I haven't ventured outside their burger but need to...
author: Martin I.

description: Eaten lunch here twice, it's within walking distance of where I work. Great burgers, nice selection of frosty brews. Decor is warm and inviting, friendly staff.  Good place to meet a friend for lunch.
author: Kevin S.

description:
mmmm we got the brussels sprouts chips (so amazing), the bone  marrow (delish), I got the polenta with mushroom and he got the burger. 

very happy with the meal and service!! yum
author: Claire b.

description:
this place is pretty small, but extremely busy. we had reservations at 7pm and when we got there, we had to wait 10 mins, not because our table wasn't ready, but b/c the hostess was too busy talking to her boyfriend and friends. she did however make it up to us, by giving us champagne and some pistachios.

it took about 30 mins for our food to come out, but it was worth the wait.

brussel sprout chips-interesting and addicting
baked oysters-soooo good
beef tartar-love it
corn soup-the best i ever had....
halibut-it was ok...i can do without it
marlowe burger and fries-it's really good, but i don't know if it's the best i ever had
author: Karen H.

description: Again with The Joy and her sister...enjoyed small plates, Brussel chips, Tartare, Bone Marrow, and Burrata. We saved room for the Burger and shared two. I recommend all the smalls and the burgers. The team was very nice and attentive. The Joy and her sister had dessert, Blueberry Lemon which was also very good. We sat at community table which was not first choice however team was accommodating and changed out the bench seating for more comfortable chairs for the ladies. I'll be back!
author: Gerry C.

description:
Make sure you make a reservation- always busy for week day lunches and dinner.

Burger is the signature dish (great fries, don't ask how healthy they are). I also like the crispy chicken sandwich which not too heavy or greasy.

Not sure about the weird wine-based cocktails, but perfectly good wine list.
author: ed s.

description:
Typical of trendy SF restaurants, it was either a 5:30 or a 10:00 seating.
Anyhooo . . . .  this is a pretty small restaurant with the only view being a train yard.  

However, the food is very solid.  Interesting and tasty appetizers.  Had the pistachios, deviled eggs and brussel sprout chips.  As for the brussel sprout chips, how could such a derided vegetable taste so good?  You fry it in butter and add a lot of salt.  Genius.   I literally could have powered back 8 or 9 of the eggs and just called it a night.  

Tasted the chicken, burger and pork chop.  All top notch.

Beverage service was awkward. Older man in our party ordered a club soda and the waitress seemed perpelexed.  Offered him a 33 ounce bottle of water.  Huh?

Beer and wine only, so don't expect a bar scene.
author: Joe C.

description: This place is only a few blocks away from us, yet it took months before we stopped by. We've been back every week since. Whether it was fried Brussel Sprout chips and a supremely-perfect burger after work or a nicer evening of steak and pork-chops, this place has been consistently amazing with their food and service. On one occasion with my mom visiting we had to wait a little longer than usual for our food; without missing a beat our waitress pre-emptively offered us complimentary desserts, ensuring our return. The menu is not vast, but what else do you need besides good meat?
author: Jessica B.

description: Get the burger.  It's one of the top in SF.  And the fries are top billin.  I got the pulled pork sandwich once, it was awesome.  Shrimp sandwich was too salty, so they took it back and gave me a tasty burger.  So good.
author: Jason D.

description: came here on a friends recommendation and i really enjoyed it.  pretty much everything we ordered was great - the tartare, burger, and duck liver crostinis.  the one thing that really stuck in my mind were the deviled eggs.  not really something i usually eat, but after trying them, we had to order a couple more each.  didnt really care for the brussel sprout chips - they were just oily and overly salty.  small spot so a reservation is a good idea.
author: Robert K.

description: I had an unfortunate experience with a crab salad sandwich at another restaurant yesterday in which I was left wanting more, so I tried Marlowe's version today. It was much better: lots of crab meat and a light dressing not overwhelmed by mayonnaise. The side salad was good too. However, the sandwich was tiny. So when you plan to come here, bring some extra cash to get an appetizer or dessert to complete your meal.
author: Adam B.

description: The brussel sprout chips were amazing! Came here for lunch. Was busy and the servers were very sweet. The burger however, was just too greasy and really didn't live up to the hype.
author: B S.

description:
marlowe burger was somewhere around $10 - tasty and filling, pretty good bang for your buck for a fancy bistro butcher burger - comes with fries.

poulet vert was very good.  moist, soft, tasty with wonderful blends of green herbs and leaves alike hence "vert". pretty large portion [enough to share with 1 other unless you're hungry]. $19

ginger beer $3 - yum - it's like ginger ale on steroids - some like it some don't

brussel sprout chips $6 - not bad, not amazing great crunchy texture since they're deep fried but a bit on the oily side with a bitter aftertaste - not everyone's favorite but an interesting taste for your palette to try

their desserts are all very good - they come in unattractive, plain mason jars [if i remember correctly] and i don't quite remember how much they were but i think in the $6-$8 range.

service isn't bad, isn't memorable, some people that work there are really nice and some are meh.  place is cute and cozy.  my friend got a little dizzy with the lighting and i think not enough air circulating but i dont know.  it does get a bit warm but it's a smaller place so its expected.
author: J K.

description: I had an amazing girls day in the city yesterday with my cousin. We stopped by Marlowe's for lunch as we both were craving good burgers! The restaurant is very charming, the decor is rustic, very cute. My cousin and I both had the Marlowe burger, you can never go wrong with the house specialty right? Everything from the bun to the horseradish aoili was delectable. The only criticism I have is that the burger was really salty in some bites. But other than that, the burger was cooked very well. There was just enough lettuce and caramelized onions on the burger so that it did not mask the flavor of the beef but added to the perfect bite. The best part was definitely the bun, the bread was so warm and buttery and tasted really good! Overall, I would say that this place is definitely worth a visit!
author: TJ B.

description: What a great addition to the SOMA neighborhood. We sat at the bar because they are super popular at the moment so we couldn't get a table. Our bartender was really helpful and made us Marlowe's signature cocktails "the Butcher's Wife", YUM. We tried some appetizers including the baked oysters and prawns. Really affordable. Can't wait to go back.
author: Greg B.

description: cute little place directly across from the Caltrain yard. solid service and tasty enough dishes, but nothing really stood out for me.
author: Clover Dan ..

description:
burrata! burrata! burrata! burrata! steak tartare! steak tartare! steak tartare! STEAK TARTARE! bone marrow! bone marrow! 

I loooooove steak tartare and Marlowe does it soooo well.

When you come to Marlowe, set expectations -
1. Meat!
2. Space is limited - even with a reservation, you may have to wait if there's a rush.
3. Servers may not be as attentive as you want them to be. In my experience, they usually are and if they aren't, they're super nice and try to accommodate you.
author: Jen Y.

description: mMmmmm.. this place is heaven.  Came here for my birthday lunch with my coworkers on a Thursday afternoon.  I was told that they had THE BEST burgers in town so I had to try it.  We started off with the brussel sprout chips.. O-M-G!!! I wish I thought of that amazing creation before they did.  The Marlowe burger was also TO-DIE-FOR.  (medium rare) w/ fries.  We didn't get a chance to try the oysters, but you can bet I will definately be back in the near furture to try them.
author: Natalie L.

description: The food was interesting, but the portions were small. Good stuff, cane sugar sodas, burrata with peaches.
author: Lindsay J.

description: Someone mentioned Los Angeles animal as a similar referance. Got the polenta and the lamb, bone marrow and the tartar and the pistachios. My favorite was the Bone Marrow.
author: Ryan K.

description: Went for a business lunch. Food tasted pretty good but the portions were small.  Environment is hip but not ideal for business because a) it was noisy, b) it was crowded so the waiter rushed us by taking our plates too soon and sending not too subtle hints that we should move on.   We had to move to another establishment to continue the meeting.  So good place for a classy small portioned quick meal.
author: J H.

description: Good food, good wine and great service. I have been there several time when it was south but after the renovation only once. but it didn't seem to have changed much. I rather go there with friends or during the week. For a cosy dinner is not good because the tables are too close and you almost hear people next to you all the time. So I rather have a conversation in German.;-)
author: Visda G.

description: A fun place for dinner... bone marrow was delicious, but a bit skimpy... I've had better hamburgers... After reading the reviews about the hamburgers and chicken, I was somewhat disappointed.  Brussell sprouts were good... a bit salty.
author: Gail W.

description: Amazing food and great ambiance --- long wait if you don't have reservations, so plan ahead.
author: Hilary C.

description: Great middle of the road place to go. Brussels Sprout chips are delicious.  Food was fantastic, well priced and a cool atmosphere.  Nothing special, but a good location to try if you are coming from the peninsula as it's right across the street from the train station.
author: Ken P.

description:
Because more than a few  Yelpers  are talking about Marlowes and their burger,  off I go around 2:30 on a gray, foggy day to test their taste buds against my vast burger expertise, and again the Yelpers have steered me right.  I'm sitting on a caned, rough hewn wood chair at a small two top looking at the kinda bleak Caltrain Station across the street, the bicycle hut directly in my line of site waiting for my medium Marlowe burger with determined anticipation of that peculiar sensual satisfaction your burger guru finds when consuming a good burger.

Johnny Cash is crooning on the sound system adding to the atmosphere mellowness and memories and out of nowhere a white rectangular sunken plate is put down in from of me and it a pretty picture indeed.   A generous portion of heavenly fries occupy about 1/3 of the plattered presentation with two ramekins between said fries and the perfectly toasted, still warm lightly seeded bun, the charred Niman beef patty with a thick slice of tasty cheddar melted just right, and nice tomato, grilled onions, crisp bacon and shredded greens atop the meat and cheese.  The bun is a perfect fit to the burger and trimmings and the lightly spread special sauce complements the whole experience kisses with love.  Every bite of this superb burger was crisp, crunchy and filled with sensory delights from the well  thought out balance of components and the masterful cooking and presentation.  Mixing bites of the burger with the addictive lush fries, washing it down with a great cane diet cola is the stuff of opium dreams for me, sensory exhilaration.

The sauces in the ramekins were a good catchup and an interesting horseradish sauce that seemed like it would be overbearing, but turns out to be a great spiked complement to both the burger and fries, again well thought out and executed.   The lunch and dinner menu's both offer the burger, about a buck more at dinner, and well worth it.  Another lunch offering that caught my eye is an open face deviled egg sandwich with bacon and provolone, yum.   Pulled pork and as did a warm Caribbean Shrimp Roll and adding to the attractions on their menu are a sweet corn soup, a little gem salad, summer squash gratin and intriguing Brussels sprout chips.  All in all, a fun, compelling and interesting menu, one that invites me back to try more.   Desserts consist of a trio of offerings including a ToHo dark chocolate pot de crème, raspberry and lemon pudding cake and a summer berry parfait.

Marlowe is up near the top of my burger bible ratings and I hope you find it so yourself.
author: Stu S.

description: I know that everyone else has talked up the burger...but damn it was good.  The dumplings that came with the lamb were delicious.  There is one thing that stood out more than the amazing food, and that was our amazing server.  He was there when we needed him, and gone when we didn't.  We got up and left after paying the check, and since another staff member handled the bill, he ran out and after us and thanked us for coming and wished us a good evening.  It left me feeling great for the rest of the evening.
author: Erick A.

description:
atmosphere is great.  good for a date, though a little loud.  

bone marrow  - very good
pork chops - yummy
chicken - excellent.
author: Nolan R.

description: I agree with all the good praises that I read on Yelp.  We had the brussel sprout chips  (yummy but a little over oiled), the bone marrow (really yummy...highly recommend), the little gem salad (good, nice salad).  We split the Halibut and the poulet verte plus a side of brussel sprouts.  The poulet was fall off the bone delicious and i was happy with the stuffed squash blossoms (they are one of my favorite veggies).  My only complaint was the champagne could have been colder.  There was also a fight outside in the street (on the other side of the resaturant but you could still hear and see it).  It was a little scary.  I still recommend Marlowe, the food was really good and the ambiance was nice.
author: Michelle S.

description:
After closing down our old favourite (South) and reinvesting into a new opening as Marlowe, I was really wondering if Anna could top the last experience. I shouldn't have bothered: it's a sound 5 stars.

The Spiced Prawns, the Poulet Vert, the Marlowe Burger, the steak, the Brussel Sprout chips, the Baked Oysters...I could go on. All of them are really fantastic and all of them are usually quite consistent. I rate at this level rarely and I rate at this level after several consistent experiences. Protip: this is a restaurant, not your kitchen. Don't come here regularly expecting low calorie, low sodium crap. Do come here once in a while with expectations of a real treat (you may need to work it off at the gym!). 

The decor and layout of the space is also greatly improved since the reopening. The additional high table where previously a desk stood works well to fill the room with more life, and benefits the restaurant with a few more seats to turn. And somehow the dark treatment with the light butcher-style tiled floor just works. It's cosy but brings meat to mind. 

Well worth it.
author: Nick W.

description:
I hate that yelp still does not have a way to rate something .5, I would give Marlowe 3.5 stars but since I can't I went with 3 since it was a little pricey (not the burger so much but the burger in combo with appetizers and wine). I don't know that I'd go all the way across the City again to have dinner here but if I was in the neighborhood I might stop by. I feel like when a restaurant only has 6 entrees all 6 of them better kick a whole lotta butt, unfortunately I did not think the burger was all that butt kicking. The description sounded sooo good; bacon, cheese, carmelized onions, aioli sauce....what not to like? My burger was just okay. It wasn't bad, I'm not complaining or sending anything back but it wasn't an item on a 6 item menu that was anything special and I don't even remember tasting the onions and that is so key! The fries were tasty, nice and crispy, and the brussel sprout chips and pistachios were both excellent too! Maybe I picked the wrong menu item BUT like I said when I see 6 items on a menu I expect greatness from them all! 

The staff was attentive and nice, they would have gotten 4 stars!
author: Amber E.

description: The best damn burger in town.  For the duration of me eating it, I kept having the same scene from Pulp Fiction in my head - "Mmm-mmmm. That is a tasty burger!" - without the bloody finale.  There is usually a wait, and the beer may take it a while to get to you, but the wait is worth it if you can spare the time.  Damn good burger!  However, if you want *variety* of burgers, go elsewhere (like Barney's).
author: Iggy V.

description:
The atmosphere and food here are both fantastic!

The sweet corn soup is AMAZING! This alone is enough to keep me coming back. 

The grilled lamb was delicious - serving was a little on the small side, but maybe I just wanted more because it was so tasty!

Minus 1 star for screwing up our reservation and giving it to someone else. But I don't really care, the food here is worth the wait.
author: pb ..

description:
I see some other folks who wrote on the fence reviews as well. 
I had been looking forward to trying Marlow since I saw the picture of the prawns in the SF gate. 

I'll start by saying that most of the reviews are for the burger. I didn't try it but if you can't get that right then you should not be in business. It isn't hard to grind your beef and have good toasted buns piled with all sorts of goodness. Heck, in and out does a fine job. 

My dinning companion and I sat at the bar and tried 4 dishes to share.

"Baked Oysters-New England chowder in a shell"... I'm reluctant to say it was ok. It read fun but the oysters tasted pre-shucked and I imagined more of a creamy soup texture. There was some indication of a soup and a random bite of potato, but that was all. The oysters were too milky, mushy and old tasting. No redeeming sweetness or brine. I had some baked Pt. Reyes oysters last week that were phenomenal!. large yet sweet, tender not mushy. Fresh and briny like the ocean. 

"Artichoke soup"... a bit watery, and lackluster. The flavor was Ok but the cream fraiche didn't add enough fat or substance to the soup. Kind of like how the foam in your latte only adds surface fat. It quickly dissipates not really adding richness or substantive dairy notes leaving behind a cup of  lonely bitter coffee screaming for help.
 The soup had Morel mushrooms as well but they tasted  rehydrate and rubbery. At first I thought that the soup way too salty but my companion pointed out that it must be finishing salt on the surface. We didn't mix the soup, as some might, because we wanted to eat it bite for bite. A little cream fraiche in each spoon full.. overall the soup base was good enough. maybe just maybe if the chef had taken a shallow bowl, placed a saute of spring vegetables (favas, mushrooms, peas, and artichokes) in the the center and ladled a small potion of soup base around it might have given it more credibility and substance. 

"Steak Tartare" ... probably the best dish we had. Nice tender beef, well seasoned, sauced and plated. I actually would have preferred a raw quail egg but at least there was some yolk to mix into the beef. The crostini they served along side the meat was ok but grilled bread or something more tender would have been better. Crostini is too predictable "a pre-service dreaded prep item".. fresh grilled smoky bread is always preferred AND a better companion to any dish that calls for bread.. it's the small things that do the trick. 

"Spicy Shrimp"... are you nuts! it blew my head off. Yes it did say spicy in the menu description but if I had had this prior to my main then I would have been very upset. After my first prawn I spent the rest of the time trying to wipe off the heat so that I could finish them. It was kind of like putting too  much wasabi on your sushi. Aside from trying to be manly, whats the point; all heat and nothing else, certainly no sweet seafood flavors. If I was hung over, a plate  with a pint would be prefect! 

some of you might say "how can you review a place based solely on their apps?".. well, for me it indicates how they kitchen approaches food. It's the first impression, first sensation that a dinner experiences. It should blow the dinner out of the water in anticipation of whats to follow. Not the reverse. 

Overall everything seemed too random. The chefs vision is a little muddled. You can see that there is experience but not depth. Excitement but no restraint. I'll go back  to check out the mains.. who knows..
author: Stephen G.

description: Best Polenta ever tried. Really good wine selection. Amazing dessert! Place is small and could be awkward, but cool atmosphere!
author: L L.

description: Baked oysters were really good, in addition to some mushroom dish I had there.
author: Ken M.

description: I took my partner here for dinner. Some good food & excellent service. Order the baked oysters to start off, have the classic steak tartare with poached quail egg & crostini for an appetizer, and grilled lamb for the main course, with a side of the smoky cauliflower gratin. That was my meal, and I'd repeat every bit of it! The seared halibut wasn't worth it, though. It was forgettable & over-priced. So I give Marlowe 4 stars for my experience. I definitely want to go back. I'd just steer clear of the halibut.
author: Tony K.

description: FANTASTIC. I am very glad to have taken Rob C.'s word on this place. On my recent visit to the bay area, I wanted to find a place close to SF MoMA for dinner so I made reservations for Marlowe. The small, intimate space was cozy and inviting and the service was friendly and attentive. The food was spectacular-- comforting and familiar without being boring in the least bit. We started off with the roasted bone marrow, which was decadently tasty and served with a salsa verde and bread. If I could eat this every day, I would..although my cholesterol levels would probably rise. For entrees I ordered the Poulet Vert and the boy got their grass-fed burger. He loved his burger, which was a very tasty lesson in the basics and my chicken was perfectly cooked, juicy, and incredibly flavorful! The poulet is marinated in olive oil and herbs for 24 hours and so it turns a little green on the outside. Everything about it was well-balanced and delightful. It was served with pee-wee potatoes (Peruvian blue and Dutch yellow) roasted perfectly whole, as well as some sauteed broccolini which was tossed with some lemon and chili flake. I loved the sides, but found some of the broccoli too spicy from the chili flake. Other than that, perfection. It was exactly what I wanted and it truly delivered. I also had a beautiful glass of 2009 Barbera d'Alba....heavenly to the last drop. I will most definitely be back soon.
author: Frances L.

description: Family dinner after an afternoon concert.  Burgers all around.  They were very good burgers with the dressing on the side - fries were crisp and delicious.  Side of brussel sprouts was excellent and the deviled eggs were fabulous.  Good wine recommendation from an interesting and fairly priced list.  Servers were attentive and friendly.  will definitely return.
author: Elena A.

description: We had a superb meal at Marlowe....The burrata was delicious, the pork belly was very good, and the deviled eggs are legendary!  Our burgers and fries were excellent. The wine list is interesting. The service is very nice. The atmosphere is cool.
author: Sarah W.

description:
My girlfriend and I had an amazing time at dinner. It was our first time having dinner at Marlowe and needless to say i will be back for more dinners in the future. 

They had the deviled eggs as a special and she wanted me to try them since I've never had a deviled egg before, after their eggs i am now a fan of deviled eggs. 

We also tried the steak tar tar and I was nervous given I am not a big tar tar fan, but the steak tar tar was perfect! By far the best tar tar I've ever had. 

For our mains we had a burger and the pork chops. My girlfriend who has never been to Marlowe insisted she had to have the best burger in sf and I remember correctly she told me "babe if you bring me a burger other than a Marlowe burger I will send it back." I think she liked it. Ha.  

For our desserts we had  chocolate cream pie and it was a challenge to share it, I honestly felt like I was grade school again and I didn't want to share the markers. 

Needless to say will be returning to Marlowe again.
author: Äuston H.

description: I really love going to Marlowe because they have a lot of unusal food which my wife and son love and the service is great.  Always a great experience.
author: Ken S.

description:
After a long week,  a meal at Marlowe was exactly what I needed! First, I loved the staff at Marlowe--the hostess and waitress were both extremely friendly, helpful, attentive, and sweet.  Even though they were very busy, the hostess went out of her way to secure us a table and keep us updated...the wait ended up being only about 10 minutes, during which we sat at the bar and had a glass of wine.

The food was excellent, too--we started out with the steak tartare dish, which was perfectly seasoned. It was not too salty, tender, and came topped with a poached quail egg. With crispy toasts, this was the perfect starter!  We shared the roast chicken, which was also extremely tender and juicy and came with a flavorful sauce.  Finally, we ordered a serving of fries, which were heavenly--thin-cut and extremely hot and crispy, but starchy on the inside, ideal for dipping into the zippy horseradish mayo!  The portions of chicken and fries were definitely enough for the two of us girls to share.

My only regret was that they were out of their brussel sprout chips that evening--guess I'll have to make a repeat visit!
author: Bear S.

description: An overpriced lunch option if you happen to be stuck in this odd part of town and on an expense account.  I reeked of garlic for an afternoon of meetings...
author: Disco B.

description:
Marlowe has been on my list for a while, given that it's in the neighborhood and that I've heard very good things from several different friends. 

In short, I went twice - the second time largely because they ran out of the Creekstone Farms steak the first time - and I probably won't be back.

The space is well done, if small, but tends to be on the noisy side. The food varies from ok to excellent. The excellent includes the brussel sprout chips, the good includes the burger, and the ok includes, unfortunately, the Creekstone Farms steak. I was particularly disappointed by the steak, as I count the Creekstone Farms ribeye at nearby Fringale as one of my favorite steaks anywhere. The steak at Marlowe was a bit dry and not very flavorful, despite being faithfully cooked to medium rare.

Ultimately, the biggest downside to my experiences at Marlowe has been the service. Yes, I get it, you've got a very small space with relatively few tables. Turning those tables, especially on a Friday or Saturday night, is critical for the restaurant. That said, towards the end of a two-hour dinner with a friend, I do not appreciate being rushed out of the restaurant by a staff trying to take away my friend's clearly-not-finished plate every three or four minutes, being asked if we had decided on dessert two minutes after receiving the menu, and having our check plopped down on our table when we weren't even a quarter of the way through our dessert. I'm sorry if we exceeded your standard, expected time for dinner guests taking up valuable table space (90 minutes?), but two hours does not seem terribly excessive to me, and certainly does not seem worthy of such brusque, almost rude, service. 

Thanks, but no thanks. I'll stick with Fringale, Coco 500, or, on off days, Burger Joint.
author: Ping S.

description: First time here. Made reservations for two at 6 PM on a Thursday night. Had no problem finding parking. Of course, the Giants were not home. Made life easy when you don't have to drive around looking for a parking spot. This area of the City is bustling with excitement. My other half was running a little late but, the hostess was able to sit me down with no problem. What I liked about the atmosphere was you were able to talk to all the servers. You weren't stuck with just one. Everyone was very helpful and pleasant. While I waited I had a very good German Beer (Hopf). Twenty Five minutes later my guest arrived. Sine we were both new to the restaurant, we had the waitress pick her favorites. We were not let down at all. We had the Brussel Sprout Chips and the Steak TarTar as appetizers. Very good. The chips were almost like a starter salad. Didn't have to order a salad for dinner at all. We both decided on sharing our main course selection. We ordered the Marlowe Burger and the Pork Chop. To our surprise they split both for us with out asking. Very nice detail. Both were delicious. In fact, might of been too much. We were staring to get full but,  we couldn't leave without dessert. So, we ordered the Strawberry Bourbon dessert. Total sugar high. Loved it. This is a restaurant that will be placed on our to go place, again and again.
author: J G.

description:
The boss took us here for a lunch outing and we got a late reservation for almost 1pm. Got there and it was still packed- completely! Simple menu, and I have been dying to try this for a while.
Small place, kinda noisy but cool environment. Small to medium portions. If you are a huge eater you might want to try two entrees.
Upon all the hype i ordered the hamburger. It was GOOD, but not the best I've had. Yes it was like subway bacon, it wasnt thick nor juicy, seemed precooked like the other review said. But the sharp melted chedder and juicy juicy patty made up for it. THere was a bit of sharpness not sure if from the actual cheese or maybe a horseradish spread on the bun that gave it a nice kick. Good percentage of fat to lean meat which made it yummy. Hamburger is on the smaller size, but good for my appetite. If my BF ate it he would be hungry an hour later. Side of garlic fries good too butnot mind blowing.

Also got brussell sprouts whic were good, some of the bits a bit burned, but not bad. Boozey prawns wre goood but if they only fried the head like amaebi! What a waste here. -japo food lovers know what I am talking about here. 

Friends had the poulet vert and it loooked good and they said was good but was TINY. THE TINIEST half bird ive ever seen. 

Same as egg sami.

Will com eback to try the bone marrow, one of my favs and also baked oysters.
author: Petri Y.

description: I went here for my friend's birthday on a Thursday at around 12:30. It was pretty busy, and we had to wait almost 10 minutes for our party of four. One of my friends ordered the Marlowe burger and I did as well. My other friends had the deviled egg sandwich and the shrimp sandwich. I liked my burger. It was a good portion. I was able to get full off it without feeling gross. The burger was really juicy and flavorful. The aioli that came on the side was pretty good too. I tried my friend's deviled egg sandwich which was sooo good! It tasted really buttery but it wasn't too heavy. My other friend's shrimp sandwich was pretty good too. It had a nice Asian spice to it. We also all shared the wild mushroom which was delicious! Super buttery and garlicky without being too greasy. Since it was lunch time and the place was packed, it took alittle while for our waitress to get to our table after we flagged her down, but she was polite. It wasn't too difficult to find parking but it was $3/hour. Welcome to SF though right? Overall, I do recommend this place. Next time I'm here I want to try the bone marrow which is on the dinner menu.
author: Kayla V.

description:
Hooray for a new restaurant in the neigborhood!

We went to Marlowe last Friday and I was really impressed with the food, however the service was mediocre at best. If they could improve their service they would have 5 stars from me. 

We could only get 5:30 reservations, and when we arrived at 5:45 there was only one other couple in the place....and they seated us RIGHT NEXT TO THEM! We asked to be moved and they obliged, but can you say awkward?? It's one thing to be cramped when the place is full, but when it is empty? Just plain weird.

Our waitress came over with menus, and failed to mention the special champagne cocktail of the day. I remember reading about it and I overheard the waitress explaining it to folks later on that came in. I was a bit peeved because I would have liked to try it.

Anyhoo, on to the food. My husband and I had the Brussel Sprout Chips, Spiced Prawns, the burger, and the chicken. All were fantastic.

Whoever said the chicken was small must be crazy. It was a very generous portion and we ended up having to take 90% of it home because we shared the burger and other appetizers.

For dessert we had the Upside down apple crisp...it was tasty but it didn't look anything like I expected. It was a jar of ice cream with bits of apple and caramel sauce. Again, it was tasty, but I was expecting something different.

Overall a great new and welcom addition to South Beach.
author: M. C.

description: I've never had anything here I didn't love. Favorite little dinner spot in the city!
author: T. M.

description: Their burrata with peaches, chili and smoked salt is one of my favorite appetizers ever!  It's the perfect salty-sweet combo, but then they bring it to a new level with the creaminess from the burrata.  I wanted to order 2 of them, but restrained myself.  I'm glad I saved room for their chicken.  Perfectly cooked, but it had a little too much sauce on it.  I love the simple decor with butcher shop decorations.
author: Shannon C.

description: Came with a party of seven so we got to try a lot of the items on the menu. The food is very flavorful, the service was excellent, and the decor is nice. Our favorite apps were the gulf shrimp and deviled eggs and our favorite entrees were the ginormous pork chop and the polenta. And for dessert, we liked the panna cota and found the other two to be too sweet. Overall, a good experience although we did find the food a bit too heavy and oily so as much as I enjoyed the beginning of the meal, I slowed down quite a bit towards the end.
author: Jenny I.

description: This is my 7th visit and I always say I would try something new.........WRONG!   I can't resist the burgers....THE BEST!
author: Carrie F.

description: We ordered several appetizers and small entrees for dinner.  Everything was great.  I would come back and order most of the same things.  We had the baked oysters, mussels, Marlowe burger, and butter brussels.  I'd like to come back and try some of the proper main dishes.
author: Aaron F.

description:
so close to at&t ball park, and sooo good. small place,
 cool people and fun feel. 
the food was wonderful,fresh, and unique
the service was great and attentive.
author: Steve M.

description: Wonderful meal last Saturday night--everything from the crispy brussel sprouts to the poulet vert to the superb desserts, was excellent.  Loved the service, the crowd, and and the food.  A new favorite.
author: Niland M.

description:
my gf n i almost gave up because we were told the wait was 25-30min.
though when we were just about to leave, i began to see a group of
people taking off.  So I suggested we stay.

well, i made the right decision because i really enjoyed the dinner!

the reason i give them 4 stars is because it can be really lound
and you cant hear what your friend is saying even tho shes only a fist away :o


but aside from that, i love the atmosphere w brick walls and cozy decor...the crowd was also nice.
author: Shine W.

description: For starters, the food here is delectable.  Convenience is great too - for someone who doesn't live in San Francisco - Marlowe is literally a hop, skip, and a jump away from the 4th & King Caltrain station.  Convenience is key, especially if I'm hungry.  The restaurant itself is rather small, and the bar was rather crowded when I went for dinner.  I had the risotto - the flavors were incredibly rich.  A friend of mine had the burger with garlic fries - perfectly crisp with fresh aioli.  The wine list is quite good, and for anyone that likes sweet wine I would highly recommended trying one of their dessert wines.  The service was great - our waiter was quite attentive.  As a tip, I would highly recommend a reservation here!
author: Jessica T.

description: Great space, food and service. Fun, relaxed atmosphere with nice bar to hang at if there is a wait. I'll be back for sure.
author: Richard R.

description: Very good food (Burger was awesome), quiet room. Too bad you have to book at least few days in advance if you want to get a table at a decent time.
author: Matt T.

description: No menu has whetted my appetite for a long time. My taste buds are revived by marlowe. When my husband showed me the menu for our date night, I had already planned in my head what I wanted. When we finally got there tonight, I executed that very plan - baked oysters, duck liver mousse, roasted bone marrow. Yes cholesterol!!! My arteries sing in delight. We got the pork chops for main course. Oh my everything was delightful. Usually I am not too fond of baked oysters cos sometimes it tends to be overlooked but this was just amazing. The duck liver was in a generous pot and if u run out of crostini, they are generous about replenishing. The duck liver came with a side of figs and some mustard dressing. Loved it but the highlight of the evening was the roasted bone marrow. Wonderful presentation and the bone marrow was like butter when u spread it on the crostini. And the tapenade on the side with its acidity helped to cut the fat. Grilled pork chops were sooo yummy with that brioche bread pudding. Totally unique pairing unlike the usual potatoes. Dessert was Amazing just a great way to end the evening and date night sans baby! We had the TCHO choc cake and the upside down apple crisp. I loved that both presentations were served in jars. The desserts werent too sweet which I loved and was balanced nicely with a savory touch. Ooooo!!! Service was soooo amazing and attentive. They are always checking to see how we are doin and they do so at appropriate timings. So we had requested for our pork chops to be cooked medium. They apologized telling us our pork chop was overdone so we had to wait a lil longer and they followed up another time afterward. I was really impressed at their quality control and attentiveness. I'd rather they be honest with me than me having to follow up with them. All in all, 5 stars, I'll be back for sure! Another plus is that they are rather kid-friendly it seems as we saw two families with kids there. Toddler age is best, it doesnt seem like they have high chairs. Reservations definitely recommended as they get crowded pretty fast.
author: Topazskye L.

description: Very, very good!  Some of the tastiest dishes I've had in a long time.  The baked Oysters, Deviled eggs, and a side of Brown Butter Brussel Sprouts were delicious. We followed this with the wedge salad and then split the "poulet vert" dish.  Not your ordinary roasted chicken dinner... the poulet vert was very tasty.  The waiter was a little strange but overall pleasantly surprised all around.
author: S B.

description:
I went to Marlowe for lunch with my friends L and CC and our former supervisor P. We were promptly seated and it was pretty busy and loud there at 1 pm. Our server was friendly and attentive even though she was juggling a whole bunch of tables. We shared the brussels sprout chips and the fries, which were both really good but of course greasy. The chips were really unique and you could definitely taste the lemon juice. The fries came with the horseradish aioli, but the fries really were well seasoned. They were medium sized with the skin left on. I also got a baked oyster to try since other Yelpers had amazing pictures of them. On the menu, they're described as chowder in the shell which I would definitely agree with. The delicious oysters were covered with cream, chives, and bacon. On my first bite, I tasted super chopped up potatoes and onions, along with a small oyster. The oyster was definitely very rich, so good thing I only ordered 1. 
L and I then shared a Little Gems Salad and the much raved Marlowe Burger. The Little Gems Salad consisted of shaved root vegetables like radishs and carrots in a mini butter lettuce bowl. Avocados were underneath the vegetables and the entire salad was covered in a citrus vinaigrette. Personally, I thought the salad had too much dressing, which was kind of salty. I liked the vegetables because they were really fresh and crisp. On the other hand, L didn't like the salad because of the dressing. 
Then we had the Marlowe Burger which came with a side of Cauliflower Gratin. The burger, made out of beef and a bit of lamb, was on a nice toasted bun with cheddar cheese, crisp bacon, horseradish aioli, and caramelized onions. I definitely tasted the lamb, which gave the meat a nice kick. Normally, I don't like cheese on my burger but it really worked well with the burger. Overall, I liked the burger but I wouldn't say it was the best. The cauliflower gratin was really rich, cheesy, and creamy. I would have preferred bigger chunks of cauliflower.
This was a pretty decent place for lunch and I would come back again, maybe before a game next year.
author: Fiona N.

description: Better than South. They redecorated, and the place looks great. Had a  really nice burger and roasted herb chicken. Hopefully, this place will make it. The ramp at the front is weird, but once inside the place is busy and welcoming.
author: Sasha K.

description:
Really good lunch here today. 
Brussel sprout chips were quite yummy as was the crab roll... which was tasty, but could have used a bit more crab.
author: leslie y.

description: Went to Marlowe tonight with my husband and 2 teen daughters after the theatre.  The meal was superb!  We started with the brussel sprouts chips and an ahi tuna appetizer.  Both were outstanding.  3 of us had the burgers which were maybe the best burger I've had in the Bay Area.  Perfect size.  The fries were delicious too.  My husband had the poulet vert and added a side of sauteed brussel sprouts.  The chicken was so tender, the green sauce perfect and the brussel sprouts out of this world.  He doesn't even like brussel sprouts!  For dessert we had and would highly recommend the dark chocolate pudding.  Also, the service was perfect.  Everyone was so helpful. Cant wait to go again.
author: Marci D.

description: I love Marlowe!  Our friend Michael took my fiance and I here for drinks and dinner and the food was amazing. The staff was warm, personable, friendly, and engaging. The wine recommendations were spot-on, and I haven't been able to stop thinking about their crispy brussel sprout chips. Those brussel sprout chips are so very good - and I hate brussel sprouts. Their spiced prawns cocktail sauce had a fantastic kick, and I still dream about their polenta. I liked the urban decor with the little details that make it warm and inviting rather than cold, and am really looking forward to my next trip back.
author: Gayle Karen Y.

description:
To summarize: excellent service, excellent burger.

We went to Marlowe last night without a reservation. The hostess was nice enough to take our name and number so we could go to District for some wine while we waited for bar seats to become available. she called us at District when a couple of seats at the bar were available and we walked over and were seated immediately.

We ordered the burger and it was juicy and flavorful. The fries are also crispy and tasty.  That is all we ate at Marlowe and we would definitely go back for the burger and the friendly service. I agree that it is one of the best burgers in SF.
author: sara m.

description: At Marlowe, the energy is lively, the service is outstanding and the food is superb.   Try the brussels sprout chips with the "butchers wife", a cocktail made with prosecco, lillet and blood orange.  The deviled eggs here are not your grandma's deviled eggs so make sure you have a couple of these heavenly creations.  And don't get me started on the Poulet Vert and the Pork Chop with creamed spinach.   Hands down, the best restaurant I've tried in a very long time.   You must check it out!
author: G A.

description: This place probably deserves 3.5 stars but I'll be generous and bump to 4. The only thing ive had here that is worth commenting on is the burger. I had high expectations going in and was not disappointed. So delicious and fresh! I will say that it's not your huge juicy hamburger that you might be used to, more of a smaller gourmet type burger. It actually left me wanting another one!! The brussel sprouts that we heard so much about were a let down. Fried and dripping with ridiculous amounts of butter and oil. Of course anything will taste good if you cook it like that but I would think a restaurant like Marlowe could do better. Service was excellent, atmosphere was fun and energetic before the baseball game.   I will say the only time I'll ever come here is before a giants game or if I'm randomly in the area. The meal was good but location is not. Also a side note, the rest od the menu looked reasonably priced but not much selection at all. If you come here get a burger!
author: Kate N.

description:
I went to Marlowe for dinner last Friday night. I loved South and was sad to see it go, and wanted to check out the new restaurant. They were packed and running late, so we had to wait for 25 minutes after our reservation time to be seated. The hostess did bring us over free wine, which was appreciated.

The food was definitely enjoyable but not amazing (compared to some nearby places). Be prepared for a very crowded and loud atmosphere. I would agree that the service was good.

Overall, I was surprised by high reviews. A good place to go for dinner, but I wouldn't go out of my way for this place.
author: Nicole V.

description: Killer burgers, good service, fun decor. Made for a fun lunch.
author: Matt F.

description: I had amazing food at the understated Marlowe. Everything was perfect. From the artichoke and cream soup, to the brown butter brussel sprouts, the polenta with mushrooms, truffle pecorino, and the chocolate mousse!
author: Thomas K.

description: Showed up at this place around 9:30 pm on a Thursday after a food startup event down the street, and the restaurant was packed. Luckily my party of two was able to get seats at the bar and get served right away. We started by sharing the Brussels sprout chips, which were crispy, lemony, and salty, and left me wanting more. I also had one of the deviled eggs, which, though I thought it was good, was pretty forgettable (as in, while writing this review, I almost forgot I had it). For entrees, my dining companion got the scallops and I got the Niman Ranch pork chop. First, let me say the portions at this place are super generous, then I will proceed to sing the praises of the pork chop. My pork chop, cooked medium per the chef's recommendation, was probably one of the best pork chops I've ever had. Every slice I cut was juicy, flavorful, and beautifully cooked. Yum. And I had just come back from Vegas and gorging myself on buffets and fine dining. It was mouthgasmically better than any cut of meat I had there. The sides were also delicious and my date kept stealing bites of my corn pudding. And since I returned the favor by stealing her scallops, I can attest that the pan-seared scallops were also quite delicious. Service at the bar was very friendly and attentive, and the food came out quickly. I'm definitely stopping by Marlowe again the next time I'm on Townsend Street, and I recommend it wholeheartedly to anyone looking for a place to try.
author: Lyman T.

description:
I was here for lunch on a Friday afternoon with my co-workers. The place wasn't too busy partially because we had a late lunch. The food was delicious...we had a salad, the spicy prawns, brussel sprout chips, and we each had the burger (highly recommended by our server). My favorite were the brussel sprout chips and the burger. The burger wasn't the best I've ever had but it was definitely quite tasty. 

The only problem with my experience was the service was ridiculously slow. It took twenty minutes in between courses! 

Overall, the service was personable and the food was tasty. But they need to pick up the pace.
author: A. K.

description: Amazing pork chops. Great staff and hostess. Definitely would do this again.
author: Stephen R.

description: Great food and ambiance!  Perfect place for couple or a small group of friends.
author: P J.

description: cool soma spot.  bar area is great (small but really nice).  great burger.  serve only beer and wine.
author: Dom P.

description:
So far I've eaten at Marlowe twice and it's been a bit of a hit and miss in terms of both food and service, but overall still pretty great.

During my first visit we set at the bar. The place was not too busy. The food was excellent. We had the eggs, the sprout chips, the baked oysters, the polenta and the NY steak. The steak was alright but everything else was absolutely delicious. We also ordered the upside down peach crisp for desert and ended up sending it back because all we got was ice cream in a jar. They modified it by adding some crumbs but it was nothing like what we expected. Service at the bar was so-so. The lady was not friendly, not very attentive, and had greasy hair. We sat there with empty plates and empty glasses right in front of her nose for at least 10 mins and then finally had to ask her to take stuff away and get us the check. 

During my second attempt the service was much better but the food was so-so. When I saw the same lady serving the bar area (hair even greasier than the first time!), we opted for seats at the community table. The place was insanely busy - every seat in the house was taken. We ordered some of my prior favorites (eggs, polenta) and a few new things like steak tar tar, and a side of Brussels sprouts (not to be confused with Brussels sprout chips). The eggs were a little dry and one of them was simply broken apart. They were nothing like what I had the first time. The polenta was also a little dryer and the poached egg on top of the dish was clearly overdone. The Brussels sprouts were burned and we had to send them back. I don't know who allowed this dish to leave the kitchen because they were completely black. They had them redone for us though and took the dish off the bill (without us complaining or asking them to do so). The steak tar tar was pretty good.

My absolute favorite is still the polenta. My least favorite is the lady manning the bar area. I will definitely be back for more food.
author: Alina B.

description: a VERY delicious burger and the hostess could not have been more kind and funny.
author: Oanh N.

description:
My partner was in town so we decided to have a nice dinner out.  I had read about the roast chicken on some SF food blog and that enticed my desire to dine here.  We started with the toasted pistachios.  Personally, I could have done without these, but my partner wanted them.  Next we had the roasted bone marrow: absolutely delicious and set the stage for the rest of the meal.  For entrées, my partner ordered the roast chicken, and I ordered the Marlowe burger.  We did this with the expectation or sharing, but it was nearly impossible to get any of the chicken from him.  The burger was good, but I wanted chicken too!  From the chicken that I did manage to snag, it was moist, had a pesto-y marinade/coating (my understanding is that the "flavor" changes often and I see that it is different on the menu online).  The burger was cooked to my liking and I enjoyed it; I don't have a ton to say about it--I wish I would have tried one of the other menu options because I feel like burgers are everywhere.

For me, what really set Marlowe above the rest was the service.  We had reservations and arrived about 10 minutes early thinking we'd grab a drink at the bar.  The bar was full of people eating, but the host cleared a spot for us at a table that was waiting for the reservation to come in.  The host was pleasant and accommodating without us requesting any "special" treatment--I would have been perfectly happen standing.  Without much waiting, our table became available.  The waitress was prompt, politely, and appropriately disappeared and appeared when needed.

All in all, I would go back to Marlowe.  There are plenty of top-notch restaurants in San Francisco and Marlowe, with service and food that I so thoroughly enjoyed, is one that I hope stays for a long time to come.
author: Jason S.

description: Great burger and big improvement on 'South' where service was pretty darn slow. Place is bit snobby...and staff/owners can be hot or cold.
author: Jason E.

description:
the chocolate cream pie was a bunch of cake frosting on ground-up oreos, presented in a jar. the chicken sandwich was so run-of-the mill. the fries were delicious, but that takes no effort so it doesn't count.

if these represent the rest of the menu at marlowe, then it doesn't compare to coco 500 ( which is just down the block ).

the staff also seem very distant and un-sincere.
author: Razmig M.

description: hearty, filling, and delicate at the same time.
author: Fzarond K.

description: Went for lunch to try the famous Marlowe burger. Sat at the bar as the restaurant filled up shortly after noon. The space was very nice and the service was just fine. I was, however, not terribly impressed by the burger. It was not that big and the meat was very run of the mill to my tastes. Though it was certainly better than average, I have had much better elsewhere in the city. Maybe next time I'll try something else from the menu.
author: Keith S.

description: 5 stars for the burger, brussel sprouts and fries. 3 stars for the roast chicken and the blood orange mint iced tea. My husband is a total burger snob and he thought it was one of the best he ever had. I was pretty disappointed that the roast chicken was dry and a little too saucy. The iced tea was pretty bland. But I would still love to come back and try some of the other sandwiches and have some more deep fried goodies!
author: Keromi K.

description: I came here about a month ago haven't had a chance to write this review. I ordered their famous burger while a friend ordered the lamb. The lamb was a bit skimpy but very tasty along with the excellently grilled asparagus. So onto my burger... I ordered medium rare. Usually, medium rare patties come either mushy and wet or charbroiled dry. The pattie was perfectly crispy on the outside but super moist and delicious on the inside (perfectly grilled the way I like it). And you can really taste the char-grilled taste of the burger meat without it being dry. How do they do that? I initially thought they must've used wood grill chips and asked the waiter, but he said that they didn't. Anyway, it was amazing. It came with thinly cut fries (similiar to pomme frittes) but a tad thicker. They were perfectly fried and came with a horseradish aioli sauce. Mmmmm, that sauce was absolutely delicious! I was so stuffed but I kept on eating the fries dipped in the aioli. The burger and fries are enough to stuff you (and I'm a really big eater)! I can't wait to come back again...
author: Bernice C.

description: The Best Burger EVER!!  Amazing chicken!  Even my son ate the brussel sprout chips.  Hot, crispy fries.  And the wait staff is superlatively good.  Can not wait to go back!
author: Barb T.

description: I love that we have a cool new restaurant in our neighborhood! And its not a chain! Marlowe's awesome- great look w communal seating, a nice bar, reminded me of a NYC bistro. The menu's super too - I've had the burger which is delicious, and the steak which was pretty good too. They also have a great radish appetizer which is yummy and very unique- who knew radish and cheese went well together ?! My only complaint is that the menu is a little small. But despite that, everything is delicious. Unfortunately both times I've been the famous brussel sprout chips were finished, but I'm hoping to go back soon to try them...
author: M S.

description: I've had dinner at Marlow twice and it was fantastic. The food was really interesting, fresh, clean and very flavorful.We started off with the deviled eggs, which I wasn't excited about ,but they were very tasty and they texture was smooth, topped of with a piece of bacon. YUMO. Next came the baked oyster. OMG I could eat 6 of these with a salad and be good for the night. I had the polenta with mushrooms and an egg on top. Super creamy and light. I wasn't going to finish it because I wasn't very hungry, but I couldn't stop eating the dish. My friend had the poulet verde. Wow, it was amazingly delicious. The service was fantastic. Perfect timing. Our waitress was very pleasant and relaxed and had the cutest outfit on, at first I didn't think she was a server, thought she was the owner or something. She was great. I highly recommend this place! Make a reservation. It's a small venue. Arrive early to read the quotes on the front window!!!
author: Jennifer M.

description: This place is awesome and I have the pleasure of living a block away from it. Our meal was fantastic! We had the brussel sprout chips, bone marrow and steak and everything was cooked perfectly and absolutely delish! I highly recommend this place!
author: Alessandra M.

description: I admit that my expectations were high for the burger. Luckily, Marlowe's burger definitely did not disappoint! It was a bit on the salty side for my tastes and I LOVE salt. :P The burger itself was super juicy and all the toppings were delicious. The fries were nice and crisp and well-seasoned. The spiced prawns were tasty, but I probably wouldn't order them again. Minus 1 star for the service, it took way too long for our orders to be taken. I would definitely come back for the burger! I want to try the brussels sprout chips and oysters too.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
can't think of a reason why so many people like this restaurant.  the two stars is for the OK food. 

- overpriced.  

the pork chop $23 - 3 small pieces of parmesan potatoes, two pretty small pieces of pork chop and one of them is 80% bone.   my friend ordered the burger, it's not much better than in&out for triple the price.

- inexperienced and unfriendly staff, slow services

- uncomfortable seats

- A very dark cafeteria 

please don't waste your money.  we deserve something better for $50 per person.
author: Nikki C.

description:
My husband and I had dinner here last night - are we the only two people in SF who don't see what the big deal is with Marlowe?  If you enjoy eating dinner with one person sitting in a hard wooden seat, in an atmosphere where you have to yell both to each other and to your server in order to be heard, and sitting so close to the people at the table next to you, you might as well be honest and just call the whole restaurant a communal table. . . then Marlowe is for you.
Here are the pluses - very pleasant and friendly hostess (Australian?) who sat us, only had to wait maybe 5 minutes to be seated, very reasonable prices.
Yes, the food is good.  But if you want a fabulous hamburger served with more than just 10 excellent french fries in a beautiful atmosphere where you can easily be heard, with piano music playing in the background and very friendly service, go to the bar at Seasons (in the Four Seasons).  Same price as Marlowe and such a much more pleasant experience.  
We didn't have dinner until 9:00 on a Sat. night - we can only imagine what the decibel level was for the previous 3 hours.  
Hard to imagine that Marlowe can survive forever because everyone in the Bay area will eventually be hard of hearing.  Why is that a fun way to spend an evening??
author: Sarah A.

description: Stopped by for late lunch,  burger was small but good- meat tender and bun delicious.   The shrimp roll and the chicken sandwich were too greasy/oily to enjoy but would have otherwise been good.  The aioli for the french fries was also overly oily....Thus, one could get cardiac arrest from eating here too often.    Featured cocktail was lovely and well balanced in flavors...prosecco w/ elderflower and grapefruit.  Hostess and wait staff could use some fine tuning in attention to  customer needs.  Simple order incorrectly taken. Took too long to get correct item.  Restaurant had emptied out but still had to wait for the tab and change.  Lunch took half hour longer than it should have...we had places to go, things to do.
author: Joan H.

description:
my first impression was excellent... greeted with smiles we immediately felt warm and welcomed... our waiter and servers  were just as polite...
because, everything here is so tasty we  shared our meal so we can try as many dishes as possible...  I really liked how they feature foods that are in season...   I highly recommend Marlowe...
author: William W.

description: My expectations for Marlowe were high; I've read a lot about their burger, their fried chicken sandwich and their general amazingness. Maybe that's why I have to give them only three stars. When a restaurant in SF comes so highly recommended, you expect nothing but the best. Marlowe had some aspects of this. The waitstaff, for example, was a flawless example of what a waitstaff should be. I called in around 8 last Friday night and was told by a friendly British accented voice we could not get a table until 9:30 but the walk-in time for a seat at the bar or a community table was only 25 minutes. The hostess recognized me when we came in and said the wait was now only 15 and could she get us drinks while we waited. She was just the nicest person and seemed genuinely interested in helping have a nice experience. We were seated at the bar in only about 5 minutes! Score. The bartender, again, was a fantastic person to be helped by. He knew the menu well and was very friendly and accommodating to all our requests. He kept by water glass filled all night. The ambiance was small and nice. Dim lighting, a good date setting. The food runners were very nice too. So why the three stars (i'm even beginning to ask myself this question!)? I think it was just the food. My friend and I got the Burrata, the brown butter brussel sprouts and the burger. The buratta was yummy but just not as fantastic as at other places. They serve it with tomato marmalade, crispy capers and smoked chili. The flavors overwhelmed the buratta for me. The brussel sprouts (which I generally go nuts for at places like Frances and Flour + Water) were just mediocre. The burger, again, was fine, but nothing I'd go back for. The bun was a bit too big for the meat and there were no special flavors. Basically, this restaurant impressed me to death until I ate the food and then i was just a bit underwhelmed for all the word on the street around this place. It's worth a shot to try, but I don't think i'll be back with all the other great dining options around.
author: theresa v.

description: Food was good - not spectacular.  Steak Tartar and lamb were delicious.  Parking was troublesome.  Service was wonderful - noise level was beyond a bomb.  We had to shout across the table.  Not a good thing.
author: nina l.

description: They do a nice burger...it must be said. Loud, and uncomfortable communal table, but a solid-lunch place. Great alternative to the (lately much too rude) Slow Club.
author: Tonya M.

description: GREAT dinner at Marlowe last night. Sinfully good corn soup; great burgers & fries; and friends' lamb & steak were cooked well and were flavorful. Limited but well chosen wine list. And the service was really, really great -- although our reservation had been misplaced, they made room for us, and our server was skilled and had a great sense of humor. Can't wait to go back!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Best burger I've had in a long time.  Beef marrow app was outstanding.  Service was amazing.  I have a reservation to go back.
author: Nate H.

description: Excellent food, friendly and helpful staff. Loved the toasted pistachios and the Berkley Burrata. Can recommend the halibut and the lamb, both were delicious.
author: Dave B.

description: Had dinner at Marlowe last night.  nice relaxed atmosphere with small dining tables and one communal table with benches.  I had the Brussel Sprout chips and have to say its the best way to eat that vegetable. The polenta was delicious and the desserts were served in jars that not only made the presentation but delivered delicious bites of sweet treats.  will definitely go there when i'm in san francisco next.
author: vanessa h.

description: Fantastic food, cozy atmmosphere and great service.  What more could you want in a restaurant?  Good selections on the wine list, easy parking, and reasonable prices.  Yup, had those too.  Overall a great experience...can't wait to go back!
author: Ruth B.

description: a friend treated me to a belated birthday dinner at marlowe.  i'm happy that he brought me here because everything was so good!  we started off with the baked oysters - new england chowder in a shell, little gem salad and roasted bone marrow.  the baked oysters were delicious - i wanted more.  this was the second time i had tried bone marrow - the first time i'd tried it, it just tasted "fatty & oily".  i liked the way it was made and presented at marlowe.  like buttah!  it didn't taste "fatty or oily".  the salad was yummy and colorful - although i tasted a hint of onion flavor and i can't stand onions but i still ate it since it was just a hint.  our entrees consisted of the grilled lamb and marlowe burger.  the lamb was flavorful and tender and the burger was juicy!  i was really impressed with every single dish!  the wait staff was friendly and the food was served promptly and hot.  i'll be bringing my friends here in the near future!
author: Vic S.

description: I liked it as South and I like it as Marlowe. The wine list had plenty of fine wines that we enjoyed tremendously. The brussel sprout chips and pistachios were AWESOME.  The Little Gem Salad was beautifully presented and was outstanding.  Others had the parsnip soup and spicy prawns. - both were tasty and the prawns were presented whole! All mains were delish! 2 x Steak Frites, 1 x Lamb and 1 x Burger. The cauliflower gratin was scrumptious.  The healthy mash - it is good. - nothing spectacular.   We had all 3 desserts and shared them - the Chocolate pot de creme was decadent. The service was great - cutlery was down when it needed to be, plates and glasses cleared appropriately.  It was crowed and lively but not loud.  The ambiance and decor was superb - rustic even. There were a few servers that had more than their fare share of oopsie daisy drops during the evening...I hope they have a great vendor for glasses and plates.
author: Christopher A.

description: I had read about this place, but never thought I would go there until MB said it had the best hamburger in SF.  So like a dutiful lemming I showed up there at 5 this evening to check it out.  I liked the casual, modern atmosphere, the friendly staff (especially our server who was thin with curly hair), and the ability to watch hot people coming in and out.  Most superlative was the wine selection; I tried the Malbec and the Sangiovese, both of which were excellent.  The hamburger, I'll have to admit, was definitely not the best in SF, although I couldn't tell you what is (my current favorite is Trueburger but its in Oakland).  The fries however were the best in SF.  The lamb sounded good so I ordered that and it might just have been the best lamb chops I've ever had: two very thinly sliced chops, barely cooked, served with a merguez sausage, beans and spinach.  I also enjoyed the prawns, served whimsically with the cocktail sauce in a glass with celery stalks, as if it was a bloody martini (wish it was).  So MB might have been a bit off base but I'm sure glad I came anyway.
author: David T.

description: We decided to try out Marlowe since it is just around the corner from us but were also very sad to hear that South had gone under (no pun intended!) I think they did a great job with the small space and the vibe of the restaurant was very inviting and relaxing. I was excited to try the brussel spout chips based on other reviews and they were mighty tasty. They are definitely not healthy by any means since they are fried and tossed with lots of salt but that is part of the reason they are so good! The mains were ok. My friend ordered the Poulet vert (herb roasted chicken) which was good but nothing special. I ordered the lamb mixed grill which was good, but for $24 I really did expect something better. We decided to try dessert since they had a Meyer lemon curd cake which sounded delicious. Sadly it wasn't. It had reasonably good flavor but the texture of it was almost like pudding and a bit mushy. The server we had was very good and was also very pleasant which is a plus in my book. I would give Marlowe 3.5 stars if I could give half stars. One of the downsides I think is the menu price point. Marlowe isn't overly pricey by any means, but I think it may be a bit high for their food.
author: M S.
